description: The CompTIA Server+ certification validates your ability as an IT professional to plan, secure and maintain a variety of server equipment. CompTIA Server+ is an industry-recognized, vender-neutral credential designed to meet today's and future IT needs. CompTIA Server+ addresses the changing server environment, dealing with the latest technologies and trends, including virtualization, data centers, software-defined networking and network attached storage.

episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.050 --> 00:00:04.672
[SOUND] In this video,
we're gonna take a look at

2
00:00:04.672 --> 00:00:09.888
CompTIA Server+ certification
series on ITProTV.

3
00:00:09.888 --> 00:00:14.387
We're launching this series to cover
the new SK0-004 exam and this is for

4
00:00:14.387 --> 00:00:19.364
the CompTIA Server+ certification which is
targeted towards anyone who works inside

5
00:00:19.364 --> 00:00:22.600
of an IT data center or
is looking to work there.

6
00:00:22.600 --> 00:00:25.740
In a smaller medium environment,
you may only have a handful of servers and

7
00:00:25.740 --> 00:00:28.990
supporting them is not much different
than supporting a workstation.

8
00:00:28.990 --> 00:00:31.850
But once you get into a larger
enterprise environment,

9
00:00:31.850 --> 00:00:35.590
managing large quantities of
servers becomes pretty challenging.

10
00:00:35.590 --> 00:00:40.000
And actually doing trouble shooting and
warranty repairs and server maintenance,

11
00:00:40.000 --> 00:00:43.590
installation really becomes a very
different beast than it does with

12
00:00:43.590 --> 00:00:44.960
supporting a work station.

13
00:00:44.960 --> 00:00:47.550
So we need to understand the differences,
understand how we're supposed

14
00:00:47.550 --> 00:00:50.940
to handle servers and
make sure that they're done in a stable,

15
00:00:50.940 --> 00:00:55.800
consistent environment, which is what's
required to run an enterprise data center.

16
00:00:55.800 --> 00:00:58.330
So let's take a little bit
of a look at the exam.

17
00:00:58.330 --> 00:01:01.430
First off, the CompTIA Server+
exam is from CompTIA, so

18
00:01:01.430 --> 00:01:03.712
it carries the same weight as A+ or

19
00:01:03.712 --> 00:01:08.630
NET+, That it tries to give you a vendor
neutral approach to managing servers.

20
00:01:08.630 --> 00:01:11.975
This is the SK0-004, and
if you look on their website,

21
00:01:11.975 --> 00:01:16.183
they'll reference the older one,
the SK0-003, the previous exam.

22
00:01:16.183 --> 00:01:19.805
The previous exam did a great job
of covering server technologies but

23
00:01:19.805 --> 00:01:22.680
like any technology,
they change pretty rapidly, so

24
00:01:22.680 --> 00:01:26.240
in 2015 it was updated to
reflect the new changes.

25
00:01:26.240 --> 00:01:28.220
New changes include just
new technologies and

26
00:01:28.220 --> 00:01:31.250
advancements as people move towards
more cloud-like infrastructure and

27
00:01:31.250 --> 00:01:34.910
other technologies have kind of changed
the way that we look at servers.

28
00:01:34.910 --> 00:01:37.630
The exam itself hasn't
change as far as the format.

29
00:01:37.630 --> 00:01:41.300
It's still a 100 question multiple
choice computer based exam.

30
00:01:41.300 --> 00:01:45.170
You can take it Pearson vue,
testing centers located around the world.

31
00:01:45.170 --> 00:01:49.130
If you ever go to the vue website vue.com,
you can do a search for

32
00:01:49.130 --> 00:01:51.380
testing location centers that in your vue.

33
00:01:51.380 --> 00:01:52.290
They're everywhere so

34
00:01:52.290 --> 00:01:56.670
you can usually find them within maybe
a 45 minute drive of where you're at.

35
00:01:56.670 --> 00:01:59.540
When you take the exam,
it is a 90 minute exam.

36
00:01:59.540 --> 00:02:01.950
So 100 questions, only 90 minutes.

37
00:02:01.950 --> 00:02:05.680
You're expected to know the data, to be
able to move through that pretty quickly,

38
00:02:05.680 --> 00:02:07.610
less than one minute per question.

39
00:02:07.610 --> 00:02:09.640
So you've gotta get that done.

40
00:02:09.640 --> 00:02:13.970
But it is scaled where you
only need 750 points to pass.

41
00:02:13.970 --> 00:02:17.220
So you can get a handful wrong and
still be all right.

42
00:02:17.220 --> 00:02:18.870
As far as a prerequisite,

43
00:02:18.870 --> 00:02:23.180
you don't have to be working in a data
center to get a Server+ certification, but

44
00:02:23.180 --> 00:02:26.590
they do expect you to at least
have the A+ certification.

45
00:02:26.590 --> 00:02:28.300
You need to understand
hardware components.

46
00:02:28.300 --> 00:02:31.380
Understand how a hard drive works,
how network adapters work.

47
00:02:31.380 --> 00:02:34.000
Understand the basic hardware
components of any system.

48
00:02:34.000 --> 00:02:36.460
And then we're gonna look at it
from the server side of things.

49
00:02:36.460 --> 00:02:38.890
So you can learn and get ready for that.

50
00:02:38.890 --> 00:02:43.800
The typical target candidate is going to
have 18 to 24 months of IT experience or

51
00:02:43.800 --> 00:02:46.030
the equivalent of that experience.

52
00:02:46.030 --> 00:02:49.980
You might not even working in IT but
if you've studying, practicing,

53
00:02:49.980 --> 00:02:53.858
doing this as a hobby from home, you may
already have the same level of experience,

54
00:02:53.858 --> 00:02:55.590
and you'll be ready to move right in.

55
00:02:55.590 --> 00:02:58.250
If you find yourself getting
overwhelmed with Server+,

56
00:02:58.250 --> 00:03:01.230
you can always take a step back and
jump down to A +.

57
00:03:01.230 --> 00:03:03.690
They don't mention it here but
I do recommend Network+ also.

58
00:03:03.690 --> 00:03:06.720
If you have A+ and Network+,
you'll have a great foundation and

59
00:03:06.720 --> 00:03:09.060
none of the topics in
Server+ will blow your mind.

60
00:03:09.060 --> 00:03:12.590
It's really just enhancing, building on
top of those topics that you learned from

61
00:03:12.590 --> 00:03:15.550
a work station perspective and
moving into the server level.

62
00:03:16.660 --> 00:03:20.940
Now from there, the certification exam,
itself is $294 USD, if you're in the US.

63
00:03:20.940 --> 00:03:25.160
But if you're outside of the US, the
pricing is all right here on the webpage.

64
00:03:25.160 --> 00:03:27.940
It is just one exam, which is nice.

65
00:03:27.940 --> 00:03:31.460
One exam, you pass, and
you get your Server+ certification.

66
00:03:31.460 --> 00:03:33.180
So a great certification to have.

67
00:03:33.180 --> 00:03:35.640
As far as getting ready for
the exam, well,

68
00:03:35.640 --> 00:03:38.320
there's plenty of content out
there like The ITProTV content.

69
00:03:38.320 --> 00:03:41.580
And what we do is we cover
each of the objectives, and

70
00:03:41.580 --> 00:03:44.980
we do it thoroughly to make sure
you prepared for that exam.

71
00:03:44.980 --> 00:03:47.980
Now the content is broken
up into seven domains,

72
00:03:47.980 --> 00:03:51.090
each domain covering a different
area of server technologies.

73
00:03:51.090 --> 00:03:55.370
And you'll see that each one
is kind of subdivided and

74
00:03:55.370 --> 00:03:57.710
weights a different amount on the exam.

75
00:03:57.710 --> 00:04:01.090
So for example, server architecture,
which is just general concepts for

76
00:04:01.090 --> 00:04:04.540
how server environments are built out,
is 12% of the exam.

77
00:04:04.540 --> 00:04:08.740
But server administration, keeping the
servers running, that's 24% of the exam.

78
00:04:08.740 --> 00:04:12.250
It's almost a quarter of the exam
right out of that one objective.

79
00:04:12.250 --> 00:04:16.362
Storage is another 12%,
we've got security beyond that for 13%,

80
00:04:16.362 --> 00:04:19.743
networking at 10%,
disaster recovery is only 9%, and

81
00:04:19.743 --> 00:04:24.454
that's because a lot of IT workers are not
involved in the disaster recovery process

82
00:04:24.454 --> 00:04:28.998
that we have, security, or information
security officers that are handling.

83
00:04:28.998 --> 00:04:33.421
And if you're in the ISO type role, or
CISO type role, you'll be heavily involved

84
00:04:33.421 --> 00:04:37.273
in that, but if you're working in the NOC,
you might be responsible for

85
00:04:37.273 --> 00:04:42.120
detecting the disaster, but not
actually resolving or resuming from it.

86
00:04:42.120 --> 00:04:46.230
And then troubleshooting is another 20%,
because once our servers are up and

87
00:04:46.230 --> 00:04:48.130
running they have a habit
of not staying that way.

88
00:04:48.130 --> 00:04:50.510
So, we need to be able to troubleshoot,
isolate the problems, and

89
00:04:50.510 --> 00:04:52.580
get them back up and
running and healthy again.

90
00:04:52.580 --> 00:04:55.750
So, a distribution here is not very even,
right?

91
00:04:55.750 --> 00:04:59.255
The bulk of the exam questions are gonna
come from server administration and

92
00:04:59.255 --> 00:05:03.410
troubleshooting and then the other ones
get kind of sprinkled across from there.

93
00:05:03.410 --> 00:05:06.590
Now each of these domains is
broken up into a ton of topics and

94
00:05:06.590 --> 00:05:09.350
if I went over them here this
overview would be an hour long.

95
00:05:09.350 --> 00:05:12.720
But if you go to CompTIA's website
you can download the exam objectives,

96
00:05:12.720 --> 00:05:13.830
this list right here.

97
00:05:13.830 --> 00:05:15.100
It will show you each one.

98
00:05:15.100 --> 00:05:21.040
So for example, server architecture covers
form factors, components, cooling and

99
00:05:21.040 --> 00:05:25.100
power, all those different things that are
inside of the servers and make them go.

100
00:05:25.100 --> 00:05:28.080
Server administration,
how do we install an operating system?

101
00:05:28.080 --> 00:05:31.380
What are the different server
roles available, and so on?

102
00:05:31.380 --> 00:05:35.380
All of this is broken down,
and it is, at first,

103
00:05:35.380 --> 00:05:37.900
an intimidating amount of information.

104
00:05:37.900 --> 00:05:41.650
But you'll there actually is a bit of
overlap between them as you go through and

105
00:05:41.650 --> 00:05:43.740
so all starts to kind of snap together but

106
00:05:43.740 --> 00:05:46.070
they've divided it up to
make it easier to consume.

107
00:05:46.070 --> 00:05:47.580
I can focus in on one area.

108
00:05:47.580 --> 00:05:50.610
I'm gonna focus just
on server maintenance.

109
00:05:50.610 --> 00:05:52.720
I'm not worried about installation and
disaster.

110
00:05:52.720 --> 00:05:56.490
Let's just do maintenance and then as each
one goes you learn more and more they

111
00:05:56.490 --> 00:05:59.810
build on top of each other and before
you know it, you're ready for that exam.

112
00:05:59.810 --> 00:06:02.720
I do encourage you to go to CompTIA's
website and download the exam objectives.

113
00:06:02.720 --> 00:06:05.260
It's a great way to, to just track
your own training to make sure.

114
00:06:05.260 --> 00:06:08.079
You've learned each of
the topic as you go through.

115
00:06:08.079 --> 00:06:11.550
Now once you've studied your content,
you're ready to take the exam.

116
00:06:11.550 --> 00:06:14.560
And if you're an ITProTV subscriber,

117
00:06:14.560 --> 00:06:18.540
you've got access to practice
exams through Transcender right?

118
00:06:18.540 --> 00:06:20.590
We have those available as
part of your subscription and

119
00:06:20.590 --> 00:06:23.750
we also have practice labs available,
where you can fire up servers and

120
00:06:23.750 --> 00:06:26.990
actually run through some step
by step exercises on Windows and

121
00:06:26.990 --> 00:06:30.990
Linux based systems to reinforce
the knowledge that you're learning here.

122
00:06:30.990 --> 00:06:33.150
Some of the knowledge is hardware based,
though.

123
00:06:33.150 --> 00:06:36.470
And so during the show we do our best to
bring a real server up here on the screen,

124
00:06:36.470 --> 00:06:39.470
and actually show you how to perform
maintenance, and other activities,

125
00:06:39.470 --> 00:06:42.930
on the physical box, cuz you might
not have one that's available to you,

126
00:06:42.930 --> 00:06:45.640
although you can go on eBay and
pick them up pretty inexpensively, or

127
00:06:45.640 --> 00:06:47.870
if you work for
an organization that already has servers,

128
00:06:47.870 --> 00:06:51.500
they may have older ones that you can
experiment with and kind of get used to

129
00:06:51.500 --> 00:06:54.270
instead of practicing on the production
servers which is always dangerous.

130
00:06:55.320 --> 00:06:57.330
All right, well if all of that
sounds exciting to you and

131
00:06:57.330 --> 00:06:59.660
this is what you wanna learn,
you're in the right place.

132
00:06:59.660 --> 00:07:02.000
We're gonna be tackling it
all in the upcoming episodes.

133
00:07:02.000 --> 00:07:05.300
Again, if it sounds a little intimidating,
don't worry.

134
00:07:05.300 --> 00:07:08.750
Reach out to A+, reach out to Net+
first and once you get through those,

135
00:07:08.750 --> 00:07:11.460
the rest of this just builds right
on top and it's not a big deal.

136
00:07:11.460 --> 00:07:13.552
But if you're here to learn about servers,

137
00:07:13.552 --> 00:07:16.951
stay tuned because the Server+
episodes are starting coming up next.

138
00:07:18.370 --> 00:07:21.262
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don take a look at the various shape, sizes and characteristic of server form factors. They will discuss topics such as rack mount, tower and blade servers as well as server racks, dimensions and enclosures.
episodes.title: Server Form Factors
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:04.554
Welcome to ITProTV I'm
your host Don [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:04.554 --> 00:00:08.269
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.269 --> 00:00:10.900
>> You're watching ITProTV

4
00:00:10.900 --> 00:00:12.067
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:12.067 --> 00:00:16.320
Welcome to another exciting episode here
at ITProTV, I'm your host Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:16.320 --> 00:00:20.794
And in today's episode, we are continuing
through our series in CompTIA Server+.

7
00:00:20.794 --> 00:00:24.030
And joining us in the studios today
is none other than, Mr. Don Pizet.

8
00:00:24.030 --> 00:00:25.130
Don, how you doing, sir?

9
00:00:25.130 --> 00:00:27.996
>> I'm doing great Wes,
ready to dive right into Server+ and

10
00:00:27.996 --> 00:00:30.763
we're going to kick things off
with kind of a neat topic.

11
00:00:30.763 --> 00:00:33.586
A lot of you that are here watching
the show are people who have worked with

12
00:00:33.586 --> 00:00:34.380
servers for years.

13
00:00:34.380 --> 00:00:37.440
And you're just pursuing the Server+
certification, and that's awesome.

14
00:00:37.440 --> 00:00:39.930
But many of you haven't worked
with servers much at all, and

15
00:00:39.930 --> 00:00:42.080
this is your first chance you'd
expose them, and see them.

16
00:00:42.080 --> 00:00:46.370
And so, it makes sense that our
first episode would focus, really,

17
00:00:46.370 --> 00:00:49.460
kind of on the differences of
a server versus a workstation.

18
00:00:49.460 --> 00:00:52.310
And so we're gonna talk about
one of the primary differences,

19
00:00:52.310 --> 00:00:53.910
which is the form factor.

20
00:00:53.910 --> 00:00:56.308
Servers come in a lot of
different shapes and sizes, and

21
00:00:56.308 --> 00:00:58.051
they're way different than desktops.

22
00:00:58.051 --> 00:01:00.810
Although, desktops come in a lot
of different shapes and sizes,

23
00:01:00.810 --> 00:01:03.400
little tiny ones,
really big ones, whatever.

24
00:01:03.400 --> 00:01:06.770
Servers, though,
don't have as much flexibility,

25
00:01:06.770 --> 00:01:09.690
that you can't come in too many
different sizes, because they're gonna

26
00:01:09.690 --> 00:01:12.630
go into a data center that's gonna have
racks like what you see behind me.

27
00:01:12.630 --> 00:01:16.530
And if we expect the server to fit in
our rack, then it's gonna have to follow

28
00:01:16.530 --> 00:01:20.120
a couple of standard measurements
in order for that to work.

29
00:01:20.120 --> 00:01:22.244
If you start going nonstandard,
people get really angry and

30
00:01:22.244 --> 00:01:24.750
it makes it hard to support the servers,
people won't buy them.

31
00:01:24.750 --> 00:01:27.810
So there's really just a few
different form factors that we see in

32
00:01:27.810 --> 00:01:28.690
the server world.

33
00:01:28.690 --> 00:01:31.370
We're gonna take a look at those
right here in this episode.

34
00:01:31.370 --> 00:01:33.820
>> So Don you mentioned,
for instance, PCs right?

35
00:01:33.820 --> 00:01:37.330
They have different form factors going
back to like the early days of the AT and

36
00:01:37.330 --> 00:01:40.040
then the ATX standard that's
been around forever now.

37
00:01:40.040 --> 00:01:43.170
And it always talks about size,
shape, and characteristics.

38
00:01:43.170 --> 00:01:46.480
Is that what we're looking at when we talk
about form factors in servers, as well?

39
00:01:46.480 --> 00:01:48.120
>> Yea, absolutely.

40
00:01:48.120 --> 00:01:51.510
We're gonna to focus on the external
stuff, you know, the size, and

41
00:01:51.510 --> 00:01:53.420
characteristics and
all that in this episode.

42
00:01:53.420 --> 00:01:55.280
In our next episode,
we're gonna go on the internal.

43
00:01:55.280 --> 00:01:58.530
We'll talk about CPU and RAM and
hard drive, brake controllers, and

44
00:01:58.530 --> 00:02:01.140
all that other magic,
the guts of the server.

45
00:02:01.140 --> 00:02:02.180
But on the outside,

46
00:02:02.180 --> 00:02:06.340
just the cases alone are different
than what we see in a work station.

47
00:02:06.340 --> 00:02:09.840
The main difference, where I wanna kick
this one off, is that when you buy

48
00:02:09.840 --> 00:02:14.920
a server the majority of servers out
there, what are called rack mount servers.

49
00:02:14.920 --> 00:02:18.148
They're servers that are designed to
be put in high density environments.

50
00:02:18.148 --> 00:02:21.731
When you but a workstation, you can put it
on your desk or under your desk, right?

51
00:02:21.731 --> 00:02:23.772
How many people sit at that desk?

52
00:02:23.772 --> 00:02:25.024
One person.

53
00:02:25.024 --> 00:02:26.948
Yeah I mean, you might have two
people sharing the same chair,

54
00:02:26.948 --> 00:02:28.012
but that's not normally happen.

55
00:02:28.012 --> 00:02:30.114
Usually everybody has their
own little work space, and

56
00:02:30.114 --> 00:02:33.000
the workstation is able to occupy
as much of it as they want.

57
00:02:33.000 --> 00:02:36.950
Well, servers, they don't go under a desk,
well at least they shouldn't.

58
00:02:36.950 --> 00:02:38.470
They go in a data center.

59
00:02:38.470 --> 00:02:43.220
And in a data center every square
foot costs precious dollars.

60
00:02:43.220 --> 00:02:45.200
it's expensive to maintain a data center.

61
00:02:45.200 --> 00:02:49.940
You have to have subfloor, air
conditioning, cooling, cable management.

62
00:02:49.940 --> 00:02:53.380
Just the general maintenance of it,
you have to have special fire control,

63
00:02:53.380 --> 00:02:55.650
there's all sorts of
crazy things you need.

64
00:02:55.650 --> 00:03:00.130
So everything needs to fit in as
small of footprint as possible.

65
00:03:00.130 --> 00:03:03.391
So we can't do tower server.

66
00:03:03.391 --> 00:03:06.980
I use the word can't,
which is a little permanent.

67
00:03:06.980 --> 00:03:08.270
You can do tower servers,

68
00:03:08.270 --> 00:03:10.480
a tower server would be a server
that looks a lot like a desktop.

69
00:03:10.480 --> 00:03:12.160
It's usually just a really big desktop.

70
00:03:12.160 --> 00:03:15.380
In fact, here, instead of just saying it,
let me show you guys an example.

71
00:03:16.500 --> 00:03:21.064
I've got pulled up here Dells,
Dell sells a lot of servers, Dell and

72
00:03:21.064 --> 00:03:24.303
HP really are the two big ones,
or it's HPE now.

73
00:03:24.303 --> 00:03:25.940
You have Lenovo.

74
00:03:25.940 --> 00:03:27.557

00:25:36.360 --> 00:25:39.630
So, there's really not
much of a difference that

528
00:25:39.630 --> 00:25:42.070
you can save a lot of money,
you can minimize your infrastructure,

529
00:25:42.070 --> 00:25:45.230
you can really fit a lot of service in
the small amount of space by doing this.

530
00:25:45.230 --> 00:25:50.220
But it is still 19 inches wide and it's
designed to fit in that standard rack.

531
00:25:50.220 --> 00:25:53.890
Now, this might be 12U tall, or
I think this is actually 10U.

532
00:25:53.890 --> 00:25:58.385
But it can be a lot taller to hold this
by you can stack chassis on top of each

533
00:25:58.385 --> 00:26:03.061
other, fill up a rack and have a ton of
service right there on a single rack.

534
00:26:03.061 --> 00:26:06.371
Another thing worth mentioning,
I said one year servers are really common.

535
00:26:06.371 --> 00:26:11.391
So, when I go back to my rack servers,
and we pull up some of those, they

536
00:26:11.391 --> 00:26:17.690
show a rack here that's populated with
a mixture of some 2U, some 1U, and so on.

537
00:26:17.690 --> 00:26:20.330
See how they fully populated this rack?

538
00:26:20.330 --> 00:26:25.170
There's a server in every single slot,
in real life land,

539
00:26:25.170 --> 00:26:28.250
you don't see that very often, and
there's a few reasons for that.

540
00:26:28.250 --> 00:26:31.747
One is temperature, even though air is
moving through here really well that's

541
00:26:31.747 --> 00:26:34.107
a lot of temperature to have
jammed in one small area.

542
00:26:34.107 --> 00:26:36.460
So, that's one reason.

543
00:26:36.460 --> 00:26:42.230
The other reason is if you have a server
fail, you've gotta slide it out and cable

544
00:26:42.230 --> 00:26:45.910
management with this many servers and
this density becomes really challenging.

545
00:26:45.910 --> 00:26:47.440
Not impossible, it can certainly be done,

546
00:26:47.440 --> 00:26:50.220
it just becomes challenging,
it's difficult to maintain.

547
00:26:50.220 --> 00:26:52.840
The other thing is,
the sheer weight of the rack.

548
00:26:52.840 --> 00:26:56.463
The rack starts to get really heavy, so
your floor has to be designed to handle

549
00:26:56.463 --> 00:26:58.766
that, it has to be designed
to handle that load.

550
00:26:58.766 --> 00:27:02.930
It is also a tip risk,
right, a rack can tip over.

551
00:27:02.930 --> 00:27:04.190
The more weight that's in the rack,

552
00:27:04.190 --> 00:27:07.350
especially up towards the top the more
risk that that's introducing.

553
00:27:07.350 --> 00:27:11.264
So, normally what you'll see is the
servers might be spaced out with some gaps

554
00:27:11.264 --> 00:27:14.169
or all the servers are down at
the bottom part of the rack and

555
00:27:14.169 --> 00:27:17.107
you'll normally see networking
gear up towards the top.

556
00:27:17.107 --> 00:27:20.004
Because all these servers need to
plug into a switch somewhere, and so

557
00:27:20.004 --> 00:27:22.361
you'll typically see a switch
at the top of every rack and

558
00:27:22.361 --> 00:27:24.970
then those switches will run
back to a core somewhere.

559
00:27:24.970 --> 00:27:28.990
So, these type of server deployments
where every slot is full, they look

560
00:27:28.990 --> 00:27:33.720
great in marketing material, but in real
life land, that's not terribly common.

561
00:27:33.720 --> 00:27:36.833
>> Don, one of the things I'm thinking,
just kinda looking back here at the back

562
00:27:36.833 --> 00:27:39.587
of this little server here is that
there are a ton of ports back there.

563
00:27:39.587 --> 00:27:42.660
I can only image if you've
got four power supplies.

564
00:27:42.660 --> 00:27:44.540
You've got redundant network adapters.

565
00:27:44.540 --> 00:27:47.310
You've got a lot of cables coming
off the back of these servers.

566
00:27:47.310 --> 00:27:48.191
How do we keep these managed?

567
00:27:48.191 --> 00:27:50.690
How do we keep these rack mount
servers managed on the back?

568
00:27:50.690 --> 00:27:53.500
>> Yeah, so on a lot of them,
they'll come with cable management arms.

569
00:27:53.500 --> 00:27:56.972
These little I always call
them accordion things, but

570
00:27:56.972 --> 00:28:01.400
they're really shaped like a v
that can stretch out like this.

571
00:28:01.400 --> 00:28:04.970
And it attaches to the back of
the server and it attaches to the rack.

572
00:28:04.970 --> 00:28:09.277
And so, you run the cabling all along this
v-shaped item, so, it just runs along.

573
00:28:09.277 --> 00:28:12.745
And when you slide the server out,
it extends, and so

574
00:28:12.745 --> 00:28:14.990
now the cable is run out straight.

575
00:28:14.990 --> 00:28:17.500
And when you push it back, it folds up.

576
00:28:17.500 --> 00:28:19.220
In theory, they work really well,

577
00:28:19.220 --> 00:28:21.220
in real life they don't
actually work all that great.

578
00:28:21.220 --> 00:28:24.640
But they do keep the cables isolated,
and if you have somebody standing behind

579
00:28:24.640 --> 00:28:27.300
the rack making sure the cable management
arm doesn't get in the way, and

580
00:28:27.300 --> 00:28:29.900
somebody on the front of
the rack sliding the server out,

581
00:28:29.900 --> 00:28:32.540
then it will kind of goes pretty well.

582
00:28:32.540 --> 00:28:35.029
So, you just kind of have
to work around that but.

583
00:28:36.220 --> 00:28:38.680
But basically when it
comes to these things,

584
00:28:38.680 --> 00:28:41.800
there's usually in a two sets
of hardware that come with it.

585
00:28:41.800 --> 00:28:44.950
One is gonna be a cable management arm for
the back, not every server comes with it,

586
00:28:44.950 --> 00:28:45.716
but a lot of them do.

587
00:28:45.716 --> 00:28:48.190
And the other thing is a rail kit.

588
00:28:48.190 --> 00:28:51.280
The rail kit are long metal rails,

589
00:28:51.280 --> 00:28:54.400
that bolt the side of the server,
and then they attach to the rack.

590
00:28:54.400 --> 00:28:57.722
Now, the rack has four post, two post
in the front, two post in the back.

591
00:28:57.722 --> 00:29:01.160
19 inches apart,
with the screw holes along the sides.

592
00:29:01.160 --> 00:29:04.950
And the rails have little ball bearings,
so they can slide in and

593
00:29:04.950 --> 00:29:08.960
out, because if these servers are all
stacked, and I need to do work on one,

594
00:29:08.960 --> 00:29:13.870
I've gotta slide it out of
the rack to do work on it.

595
00:29:13.870 --> 00:29:17.279
Well, when you slide it out,
you can't slide it out half-way.

596
00:29:17.279 --> 00:29:21.240
Let me stand this server back up again,
and I'll show you what I mean.

597
00:29:21.240 --> 00:29:24.980
So, the face plate of this server is
going to be pointing straight down.

598
00:29:24.980 --> 00:29:27.290
So, that would be at
the front of the rack.

599
00:29:27.290 --> 00:29:30.940
If I wanted to do work on this server,
I would have to slide it out.

600
00:29:30.940 --> 00:29:34.050
Well, the opening for the server
when I open it, which I'll do in

601
00:29:34.050 --> 00:29:38.050
the next episode, starts right here and
this whole back panel comes off.

602
00:29:38.050 --> 00:29:41.380
It comes off by sliding this way.

603
00:29:41.380 --> 00:29:46.640
So, if I only slide the server halfway
out the rack, I can't get this panel off.

604
00:29:46.640 --> 00:29:49.447
I've got to slide it not even just here,

605
00:29:49.447 --> 00:29:52.759
I have to slide it out
beyond the end of the rack.

606
00:29:52.759 --> 00:29:56.906
I've gotta get this server dangling
full out the front of the rack so

607
00:29:56.906 --> 00:30:01.400
that I can take this panel off and
get the equipment inside of it.

608
00:30:01.400 --> 00:30:04.990
Now, when you do that, that is dangerous.

609
00:30:04.990 --> 00:30:06.170
You've got a server.

610
00:30:06.170 --> 00:30:07.213
There's a lot of weight to this.

611
00:30:07.213 --> 00:30:11.062
The hard drive's on the front, so
this thing is front-heavy, and

612
00:30:11.062 --> 00:30:13.980
now I've got it dangling out of a rack.

613
00:30:13.980 --> 00:30:16.070
All this weight,
just sticking right out the front.

614
00:30:16.070 --> 00:30:21.690
So, the rails are usually
made of reinforced steel that

615
00:30:21.690 --> 00:30:26.010
are designed to be able to hold the entire
weight of the server at full extension,

616
00:30:26.010 --> 00:30:28.110
because the rail will
be made of two pieces.

617
00:30:28.110 --> 00:30:31.240
And as it slides, the first piece
is sliding out on bearings, and

618
00:30:31.240 --> 00:30:33.670
then the second piece
slides out on bearings.

619
00:30:33.670 --> 00:30:36.930
So, that one piece becomes very,
very long, and

620
00:30:36.930 --> 00:30:38.610
it's got to support all this weight.

621
00:30:38.610 --> 00:30:41.580
So, those rails are really important.

622
00:30:41.580 --> 00:30:44.958
Dell, HPE, Lenovo,
they all sell rail kits, and

623
00:30:44.958 --> 00:30:48.820
they usually cot 2 to $300,
And people balk at that.

624
00:30:48.820 --> 00:30:53.880
I'm not gonna pay $300 for rails,
I can get $20 rails on Amazon.

625
00:30:53.880 --> 00:30:57.340
You can, and
eventually you're gonna get really hurt

626
00:30:57.340 --> 00:31:00.050
cuz those are just not
designed to handle the weight.

627
00:31:00.050 --> 00:31:02.730
You need to get the good ones or

628
00:31:02.730 --> 00:31:04.540
you need to not work on servers
while they're in the rack.

629
00:31:04.540 --> 00:31:06.950
Cuz you could just slide it out and
take it all the way out and

630
00:31:06.950 --> 00:31:09.490
work on it over on a workbench or
something, and do that.

631
00:31:09.490 --> 00:31:12.200
But if you use the factory rails, they are
designed to hold the weight of the server.

632
00:31:12.200 --> 00:31:14.590
>> Yeah, I was gonna say, I don't think
my back could handle any of that.

633
00:31:14.590 --> 00:31:16.360
But it also makes sense too, Don,

634
00:31:16.360 --> 00:31:19.580
that just the investment alone is worth it
because of the price that you could pay in

635
00:31:19.580 --> 00:31:22.020
those servers as you were
just adding four CPUs.

636
00:31:22.020 --> 00:31:24.610
I think that was $7000 it
added to the package alone.

637
00:31:24.610 --> 00:31:25.731
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

638
00:31:25.731 --> 00:31:27.216
>> So, it does look like a $200

639
00:31:27.216 --> 00:31:30.560
investment definitely is worth it
to protect quite a few thousand.

640
00:31:30.560 --> 00:31:31.220
>> Yeah.

641
00:31:31.220 --> 00:31:34.415
The other thing is that when you buy
a rack, almost all of them have wheels on

642
00:31:34.415 --> 00:31:37.714
the bottom, so you wheel them into place
and then they have these little metal

643
00:31:37.714 --> 00:31:40.428
feet that you unscrew that drop
down to kind of lock it in place.

644
00:31:40.428 --> 00:31:43.918
Well, if your rack is fully
populated with servers, and

645
00:31:43.918 --> 00:31:47.117
you start to slide more than
one server out at a time,

646
00:31:47.117 --> 00:31:51.718
you can exceed the tipping limit for
that rack and the rack can tip and fall.

647
00:31:51.718 --> 00:31:55.829
If it falls, and you're in the way,
You don't survive that.

648
00:31:55.829 --> 00:31:59.410
And it is a lot of waves, so
it is an extremely dangerous thing.

649
00:31:59.410 --> 00:32:04.060
So if you have a fully populated rack,
it really needs to be bolted to the floor.

650
00:32:04.060 --> 00:32:05.310
Where that get challenging is,

651
00:32:05.310 --> 00:32:07.758
in most data centers you
don't have a normal floor.

652
00:32:07.758 --> 00:32:10.756
We're kinda fortunate here that we do,
but normally you have a subfloor.

653
00:32:10.756 --> 00:32:13.530
You have removable panels,
a foot and half, or

654
00:32:13.530 --> 00:32:16.200
two foot of distance between you and
the actual floor.

655
00:32:16.200 --> 00:32:18.270
So when that server rack
gets bolted to the floor,

656
00:32:18.270 --> 00:32:21.690
it's being bolted to tiles that
are designed to be removable.

657
00:32:21.690 --> 00:32:24.738
So it's really gonna be bolted
way down into the concrete.

658
00:32:24.738 --> 00:32:26.290
Your data center has to be designed for

659
00:32:26.290 --> 00:32:28.380
that if you're gonna
fully populate the racks.

660
00:32:28.380 --> 00:32:31.480
Otherwise you need to pull
the engineering documents for

661
00:32:31.480 --> 00:32:34.750
your rack, determine the tipping weight,
and read a.

662
00:32:34.750 --> 00:32:36.560
They'll explain how it's
supposed to be loaded.

663
00:32:36.560 --> 00:32:39.191
And you might find that, yes,
you've got a 42U rack, but

664
00:32:39.191 --> 00:32:42.280
you can't put 42U of equipment
in there and maintain safety.

665
00:32:42.280 --> 00:32:44.618
So always read the safety instructions
that come with those racks,

666
00:32:44.618 --> 00:32:45.529
it's really important.

667
00:32:45.529 --> 00:32:49.730
I can't stress it enough,
it is really, really important.

668
00:32:49.730 --> 00:32:53.040
After that,
most of it is pretty cut-and-dry.

669
00:32:54.260 --> 00:32:56.630
These servers are designed for
good airflow.

670
00:32:56.630 --> 00:32:58.810
When you buy racks,
a lot of them have doors.

671
00:32:58.810 --> 00:33:02.270
You might notice that none of our racks in
the background here have doors on them.

672
00:33:02.270 --> 00:33:06.050
And we don't do that just to make them
look pretty, although it does [LAUGH].

673
00:33:06.050 --> 00:33:08.490
We do it because that's
how you maximize airflow.

674
00:33:08.490 --> 00:33:10.950
Doors are really optional on a rack.

675
00:33:10.950 --> 00:33:14.860
When you go to some of those really
state-of-the-art, pretty server rooms,

676
00:33:14.860 --> 00:33:17.280
they'll have doors on the front of their
racks, and those obstruct airflow.

677
00:33:17.280 --> 00:33:19.870
Now they usually have holes in them,
they're ventilated, right?

678
00:33:19.870 --> 00:33:24.320
But if you've got excess air conditioning,
then you can survive through that,

679
00:33:24.320 --> 00:33:25.240
and that's fine.

680
00:33:25.240 --> 00:33:27.650
But don't feel like you have
to have doors on your racks.

681
00:33:27.650 --> 00:33:31.060
If you have multiple tenants in an area,
you might need doors to be able to lock

682
00:33:31.060 --> 00:33:34.820
them, to stop people from getting to
the physical front of the servers.

683
00:33:34.820 --> 00:33:37.450
Tower servers will have that,
a little lock on the front.

684
00:33:37.450 --> 00:33:39.220
Rack servers may have that,

685
00:33:39.220 --> 00:33:42.140
you'll see where the faceplates
might have a little lock on them.

686
00:33:42.140 --> 00:33:45.189
Dell does that with all theirs,
I don't know if HP does, they might.

687
00:33:46.290 --> 00:33:49.042
But that's all stuff to think about.

688
00:33:49.042 --> 00:33:53.857
And faceplates, more and more vendors are
moving away from faceplates these days.

689
00:33:53.857 --> 00:33:55.986
Where the front of the server is
just the front of the server, and

690
00:33:55.986 --> 00:33:57.800
there's not a removable faceplate on it.

691
00:33:57.800 --> 00:34:00.690
But Dell still does faceplates, and that's
why they're able to have a lock on there.

692
00:34:00.690 --> 00:34:02.280
And that's why I said,
I don't know if HP does,

693
00:34:02.280 --> 00:34:06.460
because they don't typically
do faceplates on theirs, so.

694
00:34:06.460 --> 00:34:08.770
All right, I think it's
a pretty good run down on this.

695
00:34:08.770 --> 00:34:13.072
Let's see, we've talked about blade
technologies we've talked about the rack

696
00:34:13.072 --> 00:34:15.639
mounts, and
we've talked about tower mounts.

697
00:34:15.639 --> 00:34:18.139
The web pages I went to here were
just examples to show you guys,

698
00:34:18.139 --> 00:34:19.895
I'll post links for
them in the show notes.

699
00:34:19.895 --> 00:34:21.815
But you can browse to any vendor.

700
00:34:21.815 --> 00:34:25.858
Lenovo, Dell, HPE,
they're probably the three big ones.

701
00:34:25.858 --> 00:34:28.514
There's plenty of other organizations
that make servers, though.

702
00:34:28.514 --> 00:34:30.333
These days, thanks to the cloud,

703
00:34:30.333 --> 00:34:33.608
a lot of people aren't buying
servers in the volume they did.

704
00:34:33.608 --> 00:34:36.624
So the smaller server vendors
have kind of started to go away,

705
00:34:36.624 --> 00:34:39.063
and you end up with this
handful of big companies.

706
00:34:39.063 --> 00:34:43.400
But they make great stuff, HPE servers
are some of the best on the market, and

707
00:34:43.400 --> 00:34:45.549
they do a really good job with theirs.

708
00:34:45.549 --> 00:34:49.000
So if you need on-premises equipment,
you can shop the three vendors.

709
00:34:49.000 --> 00:34:52.670
You'll see they're all pretty standard,
they all use Intel processors,

710
00:34:52.670 --> 00:34:55.130
because they work the best
in the server environments.

711
00:34:55.130 --> 00:34:58.270
They all follow standard rack sizes and
dimensions.

712
00:34:58.270 --> 00:35:02.000
They usually are spec'd pretty similar,
so it's finding which ones have the best

713
00:35:02.000 --> 00:35:05.090
warranty and support, is usually
how you make that final decision.

714
00:35:05.090 --> 00:35:06.670
>> A lot of great information, Don, here.

715
00:35:06.670 --> 00:35:09.200
We talk, here at ITPro.TV,
a lot about software.

716
00:35:09.200 --> 00:35:11.030
So it's nice to step behind the scenes and

717
00:35:11.030 --> 00:35:14.592
see some of the actual hardware that's
doing some of the heavy lifting here.

718
00:35:14.592 --> 00:35:17.770
Don, it does look like we're coming to
the end of another wonderful episode.

719
00:35:17.770 --> 00:35:18.790
But before we sign off,

720
00:35:18.790 --> 00:35:21.470
do you got any additional words that
you'd like to throw in with this one?

721
00:35:21.470 --> 00:35:23.790
>> That's about it for
server form factors.

722
00:35:23.790 --> 00:35:26.870
There are some nonstandard ones out there,
I'm not gonna cover them here,

723
00:35:26.870 --> 00:35:28.410
because in real life you don't buy them.

724
00:35:28.410 --> 00:35:30.620
But there are some that you'll encounter.

725
00:35:30.620 --> 00:35:33.640
And there's plenty of servers that
are way shorter than this one, but

726
00:35:33.640 --> 00:35:36.410
it just depends on how much
hardware it needs inside of it.

727
00:35:36.410 --> 00:35:39.690
So there are variations out there,
don't assume they're all the same.

728
00:35:39.690 --> 00:35:42.520
But that's it, and if you're wondering
when we're gonna get to the good stuff,

729
00:35:42.520 --> 00:35:43.680
stay tuned for the next episode.

730
00:35:43.680 --> 00:35:45.558
Cuz that's where we're gonna go
inside inside the servers and

731
00:35:45.558 --> 00:35:46.880
start talking about the components there.

732
00:35:46.880 --> 00:35:49.569
And things get to be a little
more interesting on that one, so

733
00:35:49.569 --> 00:35:50.450
stay tuned for it.

734
00:35:50.450 --> 00:35:52.480
>> Great information,
Don, thank you for that.

735
00:35:52.480 --> 00:35:53.710
Thank you for the viewer watching.

736
00:35:53.710 --> 00:35:56.100
Looking forward to
the additional hardware episode.

737
00:35:56.100 --> 00:35:59.320
Signing out for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

738
00:35:59.320 --> 00:36:00.111
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

739
00:36:00.111 --> 00:36:02.328
>> And we'll see you next time.

740
00:36:02.328 --> 00:36:08.344
[MUSIC]

741
00:36:08.344 --> 00:36:11.641
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

681
00:32:59.060 --> 00:33:02.067
In the really big servers though,
they use those cards that pop in.

682
00:33:02.067 --> 00:33:02.720
>> Yeah.
>> And

683
00:33:02.720 --> 00:33:07.020
that's just a completely different thing,
because now the CPU is actually soldered

684
00:33:07.020 --> 00:33:10.340
on to a larger board,
a larger silicon board.

685
00:33:10.340 --> 00:33:14.070
So it pops in that way and
that's just different at that point.

686
00:33:14.070 --> 00:33:16.670
So don't count on it
being a particular way.

687
00:33:16.670 --> 00:33:18.910
Fortunately, it's not something
we have to deal with very often.

688
00:33:18.910 --> 00:33:20.710
It's a rarity.

689
00:33:20.710 --> 00:33:23.890
In fact, I'm trying to think of the last
time I took a CPU out of a server, and

690
00:33:23.890 --> 00:33:25.600
it was probably over eight years ago.

691
00:33:25.600 --> 00:33:27.130
Not something you do very often.

692
00:33:27.130 --> 00:33:29.440
And that was a failed CPU.

693
00:33:29.440 --> 00:33:30.870
That's not a frequent thing, either.

694
00:33:30.870 --> 00:33:33.180
You don't see failed CPUs very often.

695
00:33:33.180 --> 00:33:36.570
But you can bake them and
if you bake a processor, it'll die and

696
00:33:36.570 --> 00:33:37.760
you'll have to replace it.

697
00:33:37.760 --> 00:33:40.440
>> Would you call that history
cycling around on itself?

698
00:33:40.440 --> 00:33:44.528
Cuz you remember some of the earlier Intel
Pentium 2s were slot-based processors.

699
00:33:44.528 --> 00:33:46.130
>> Yeah.
>> They completely disappeared and

700
00:33:46.130 --> 00:33:48.480
now they're like, well, they were good
enough, let's bring them back and

701
00:33:48.480 --> 00:33:49.880
put them in the production machines.

702
00:33:49.880 --> 00:33:55.280
>> Well, what actually caused it to
come back were hot swappable CPUs,

703
00:33:55.280 --> 00:33:57.000
which was not possible in the past.

704
00:33:57.000 --> 00:34:02.520
But some servers actually have hot swap,
you can add CPUs while the thing is on,

705
00:34:02.520 --> 00:34:05.447
it's amazing, right, it's amazing
technology but it is out there.

706
00:34:05.447 --> 00:34:09.790
And you can't manipulate a socket
like this while the server is on.

707
00:34:09.790 --> 00:34:12.420
I mean I'm gonna touch the casing or

708
00:34:12.420 --> 00:34:15.100
whatever while I'm working on it,
short the server out, I'm gonna power off.

709
00:34:15.100 --> 00:34:19.460
So the ones that are hot swappable
they're always card based always and

710
00:34:19.460 --> 00:34:24.575
they'll have these, it's not plastic but
it's this weird like fiber

711
00:34:24.575 --> 00:34:29.450
paper-type material that is non-conductive
that will be in between each CPU.

712
00:34:29.450 --> 00:34:31.980
So you can swap one out and not have to
worry about grounding out the system.

713
00:34:31.980 --> 00:34:33.510
And you can do it while
the system is online.

714
00:34:33.510 --> 00:34:35.230
It's really cool stuff.

715
00:34:35.230 --> 00:34:38.470
So that's another difference
you'll see on servers.

716
00:34:38.470 --> 00:34:39.317
I know we're out of time, Wes.

717
00:34:39.317 --> 00:34:41.388
But when you look around the servers,

718
00:34:41.388 --> 00:34:44.570
sometimes you'll notice really
weird colors on things.

719
00:34:44.570 --> 00:34:47.040
Like the handles on the hard
drives on this one are purple.

720
00:34:47.040 --> 00:34:51.930
And the little buttons here on
the power supply are purple also.

721
00:34:51.930 --> 00:34:53.600
Does HP like purple?

722
00:34:53.600 --> 00:34:55.170
No, well maybe, I don't know.

723
00:34:55.170 --> 00:35:00.050
But anytime on an HPE server that you
see purple, that means hot swappable.

724
00:35:00.050 --> 00:35:02.470
That this is something that I can
change while the server's online.

725
00:35:02.470 --> 00:35:06.830
So if my CPUs have little purple
tabs on them, they're hot swappable.

726
00:35:06.830 --> 00:35:09.130
Lenovo, if I remember right,
they do light blue on theirs.

727
00:35:09.130 --> 00:35:10.010
So look for

728
00:35:10.010 --> 00:35:13.410
weird colors like that, read the manual
to make sure it's not just pretty.

729
00:35:13.410 --> 00:35:16.891
But usually it'll mean that's a hot
swappable component, you'll find where you

730
00:35:16.891 --> 00:35:19.940
can get hot swap memory, hot swap
processors, all sorts of neat stuff.

731
00:35:19.940 --> 00:35:24.280
>> I'd say that's absolutely amazing,
being able to give your server a lobotomy

732
00:35:24.280 --> 00:35:26.890
while it's full turned on like that
>> Now Don I know we're

733
00:35:26.890 --> 00:35:28.940
pushing the envelope on
the clock over there.

734
00:35:28.940 --> 00:35:32.870
I know we've got a lot more hardware
that you'd like to show us, but

735
00:35:32.870 --> 00:35:34.890
it looks like we're gonna
have to go into a part two.

736
00:35:34.890 --> 00:35:37.720
But before we do, do you have any
additional words you might like to throw

737
00:35:37.720 --> 00:35:38.560
in this one while we're here.

738
00:35:38.560 --> 00:35:41.220
>> Yeah, just a few last things
to be objective complete.

739
00:35:41.220 --> 00:35:46.058
In the exam objective they do mention arm
processors, you really don't see those in

740
00:35:46.058 --> 00:35:51.051
servers right now because they're not as
powerful as the X86 and X64 processors.

741
00:35:51.051 --> 00:35:55.611
But they're way more power-efficient so
you're starting to see data centers trying

742
00:35:55.611 --> 00:36:00.545
to implement those and, mark my words,
it's 2017, by 2020 I'm certain we'll see

743
00:36:00.545 --> 00:36:04.120
arm processors in servers because
they're more power efficient.

744
00:36:04.120 --> 00:36:05.600
Which means you can have
a lot more of them,

745
00:36:05.600 --> 00:36:07.370
without running your electric
bill through the roof.

746
00:36:07.370 --> 00:36:11.030
These CPUs, that's a big limitation they
have is they do draw a lot of power.

747
00:36:11.030 --> 00:36:15.930
The other thing is just like any
processor, with these you always have your

748
00:36:15.930 --> 00:36:20.160
bus speed, your clocking,
we've got our multiplier, right?

749
00:36:20.160 --> 00:36:24.828
And so, I might have a 3.4 gigahertz
processor that's running at a 13/33

750
00:36:24.828 --> 00:36:28.710
megahertz clock and if you're an over
clocker you know that you can go in and

751
00:36:28.710 --> 00:36:31.130
manipulate that and
bump the speeds up or whatever.

752
00:36:31.130 --> 00:36:34.530
Server CPUs are almost
always under clocked.

753
00:36:34.530 --> 00:36:37.740
And you might say, well wait a minute,
I can overclock and get some more speed.

754
00:36:37.740 --> 00:36:39.180
The reason they're under
clocked is two reasons.

755
00:36:39.180 --> 00:36:41.790
One, temperature, right?

756
00:36:41.790 --> 00:36:43.140
They're trying to control the temperature.

757
00:36:43.140 --> 00:36:44.940
You've gotta very small space here and

758
00:36:44.940 --> 00:36:47.950
you can't have a huge heat sync
on it like you do on a desktop.

759
00:36:47.950 --> 00:36:51.847
You gotta small space, you can't
over clock as much as you can, so

760
00:36:51.847 --> 00:36:53.800
they under clock them.

761
00:36:53.800 --> 00:36:55.890
The other reason, warranty.

762
00:36:55.890 --> 00:36:58.860
They're giving you a three or
a five year warranty on this stuff.

763
00:36:58.860 --> 00:37:01.633
They need to guarantee that CPU can run,
and if it's over clocked, or

764
00:37:01.633 --> 00:37:04.460
even clocked at full speed,
it will have a shorter lifetime.

765
00:37:04.460 --> 00:37:06.040
So they're under clocked because of that.

766
00:37:06.040 --> 00:37:11.180
And for
that reason you typically can't modify

767
00:37:11.180 --> 00:37:15.230
the clocking or
the multiplier because it's locked in.

768
00:37:15.230 --> 00:37:18.070
You have to go into the bios and
these vendors write their own bios.

769
00:37:18.070 --> 00:37:19.230
So you're not able to change that.

770
00:37:19.230 --> 00:37:22.290
So don't plan on over clocking
your servers any time soon.

771
00:37:22.290 --> 00:37:23.750
You wouldn't want to, even if you could.

772
00:37:23.750 --> 00:37:26.340
So just a little word of advice there.

773
00:37:26.340 --> 00:37:28.730
>> What great information Don,
we appreciate that and

774
00:37:28.730 --> 00:37:30.780
we look forward to seeing
you in part two there,.

775
00:37:30.780 --> 00:37:33.220
And we look forward to seeing
you the viewer out there.

776
00:37:33.220 --> 00:37:36.210
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

777
00:37:36.210 --> 00:37:36.810
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

778
00:37:36.810 --> 00:37:38.804
>> And we'll see you next time.

779
00:37:38.804 --> 00:37:45.194
[MUSIC]

780
00:37:45.194 --> 00:37:48.498
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their discussion on the various components that make up server hardware. They explain the characteristics of random access memory (RAM). They talk about error correcting code (ECC) vs non-ECC memory, RAM standards such as DDR2 and DDR3. They also mention other major components such as hard drives, BIOS/UEFI, firmware, RAID controllers, power supplies and network interface cards (NICs).
episodes.title: Server Components Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.984
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.984 --> 00:00:08.402
[CROSSTALK]
[SOUND]

3
00:00:08.402 --> 00:00:12.127
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.127 --> 00:00:16.031
>> Welcome to another episode here at
ITProTV, I'm your host Wes Bryan, and in

5
00:00:16.031 --> 00:00:20.179
today's episode, we are continuing through
our series in Comp TIA Server Plus,

6
00:00:20.179 --> 00:00:23.506
coming back with a part two of
the fun stuff, server components.

7
00:00:23.506 --> 00:00:26.685
And joining us back in the studios
today is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:26.685 --> 00:00:27.955
Don, how're you doing, sir?

9
00:00:27.955 --> 00:00:30.065
>> I'm doing great, Wes,
ready to dive right back in.

10
00:00:30.065 --> 00:00:32.945
In the last episode, if you watched it,
we opened up a server and

11
00:00:32.945 --> 00:00:34.465
we started talking about some
of the components in there.

12
00:00:34.465 --> 00:00:37.113
We really just focused on
the CPU in that last episode, so

13
00:00:37.113 --> 00:00:40.769
we kind of have some other parts we need
to talk about to get through this thing.

14
00:00:40.769 --> 00:00:44.018
And I did actually forget to mention
one thing in the last episode that I do

15
00:00:44.018 --> 00:00:45.160
need to cover.

16
00:00:45.160 --> 00:00:50.137
In the olden days, when you wanted
a multiprocessor server, it had multiple,

17
00:00:50.137 --> 00:00:51.635
physical processors.

18
00:00:51.635 --> 00:00:55.380
And in the one that we're using here
in the show, it's only got one CPU.

19
00:00:55.380 --> 00:00:57.280
That's actually really common these days.

20
00:00:57.280 --> 00:01:00.151
I'm making noise,
I'm hitting this air shroud,

21
00:01:00.151 --> 00:01:02.193
let me just chuck that out of there.

22
00:01:02.193 --> 00:01:04.320
But it's really common to have
a single CPU because now,

23
00:01:04.320 --> 00:01:06.910
we have multicore processors, right?

24
00:01:06.910 --> 00:01:11.640
So you might have one physical CPU
in there, but it has four cores.

25
00:01:11.640 --> 00:01:16.450
Well, that's the equivalent of having
four physical processors in the past.

26
00:01:16.450 --> 00:01:19.112
But it takes up a lot less
space inside of a system.

27
00:01:19.112 --> 00:01:23.568
They're baking those cores right
into the same wafer on the chip.

28
00:01:23.568 --> 00:01:27.795
So in today's world,
if you have multiple physical CPUs,

29
00:01:27.795 --> 00:01:30.065
you've actually got a lot of cores.

30
00:01:30.065 --> 00:01:33.615
Now be careful with that because
sometimes, those cores are real and

31
00:01:33.615 --> 00:01:35.295
sometimes, they aren't, right?

32
00:01:35.295 --> 00:01:39.405
When we talk about technologies
like Intel's hyper threading, hyper

33
00:01:39.405 --> 00:01:44.285
threading says hey, look, inside of a CPU,
inside of a core, you've got transistors.

34
00:01:44.285 --> 00:01:47.290
And sometimes those
transistors are all being used.

35
00:01:47.290 --> 00:01:49.730
But sometimes,
only half of them are being used.

36
00:01:49.730 --> 00:01:53.139
And if they are, we might be able to use
the other half to do something else, so

37
00:01:53.139 --> 00:01:55.972
we could actually do two instructions
at the same time, right,

38
00:01:55.972 --> 00:01:58.188
because they're using
different transistors.

39
00:01:58.188 --> 00:02:00.969
But that doesn't always happen,
sometimes it does, and when it does,

40
00:02:00.969 --> 00:02:03.330
it's like having double the cores, right?

41
00:02:03.330 --> 00:02:06.080
But when it doesn't happen,
when you're using enough of those

42
00:02:06.080 --> 00:02:09.200
transistors that it can't be shared,
then it's like you have one.

43
00:02:09.200 --> 00:02:13.950
So they might say hey, you've got a four
core processor with hyper threading, and

44
00:02:13.950 --> 00:02:18.750
so in Linux or Windows or
whatever, it shows as eight cores.

45
00:02:18.750 --> 00:02:20.580
But you don't really have eight cores.

46
00:02:20.580 --> 00:02:23.010
Sometimes you do, not always.

47
00:02:23.010 --> 00:02:28.030
So if you want to guarantee that you've
always got your cores available,

48
00:02:28.030 --> 00:02:29.700
you need to make sure
you have enough of them.

49
00:02:29.700 --> 00:02:32.920
Which we can achieve by having
multiple physical CPUs or

50
00:02:32.920 --> 00:02:36.720
multiple physical cores and
not count on things like hyper threading.

51
00:02:36.720 --> 00:02:39.575
AMD has the same thing,
they call it something different.

52
00:02:39.575 --> 00:02:42.333
>> [CROSSTALK] Honestly, I don't know
what theirs is called, hyper transport or

53
00:02:42.333 --> 00:02:43.137
something like that.

54
00:02:43.137 --> 00:02:46.991
>> A little crazy, but same idea,
right, same concept as hyper threading,

55
00:02:46.991 --> 00:02:50.374
it's just hyper threading is
a trademarked name, I imagine so.

56
00:02:50.374 --> 00:02:53.330
But either way, so
you may have multiple physical CPUs.

57
00:02:53.330 --> 00:02:54.660
It is less common these days.

58
00:02:54.660 --> 00:02:58.450
In fact, it's really rare to see
a server with more than 4 physical CPUs

59
00:02:58.450 --> 00:03:01.900
because if you get the 10 or
12 core CPUs, and

60
00:03:01.900 --> 00:03:05.950
you get 4 of them, you're talking
about a lot of cores right there.

61
00:03:05.950 --> 00:03:09.059
And that's what most people need and
we can always add more servers and

62
00:03:09.059 --> 00:03:10.170
cluster them together.

63
00:03:10.170 --> 00:03:13.427
But in the olden days when clusters
weren't so well supported,

64
00:03:13.427 --> 00:03:16.400
having multiple physical CPUs
was the way to handle that.

65
00:03:16.400 --> 00:03:19.720
So just be aware that's
a variation you'll see in servers,

66
00:03:19.720 --> 00:03:21.534
that I didn't really focus
on in the last episode.

67
00:03:21.534 --> 00:03:25.770
All right, moving on from CPUs though,
we've got a lot of the stuff in here,

68
00:03:25.770 --> 00:03:27.300
so let's just kind of move down the list.

69
00:03:27.300 --> 00:03:29.120
I wanna talk about RAM next.

70
00:03:29.120 --> 00:03:31.000
When you look inside of this server,

71
00:03:31.000 --> 00:03:33.770
it looks a lot like a workstation
as far as RAM is concerned.

72
00:03:33.770 --> 00:03:36.500
In fact, the biggest difference
you'll notice at looking at a server

73
00:03:36.500 --> 00:03:38.710
is there's usually just more slots.

74
00:03:38.710 --> 00:03:43.200
In a typical workstation, you're gonna
have what, 4, maybe 6 slots for memory.

75
00:03:43.200 --> 00:03:46.120
But in a server, you could have 24 slots.

76
00:03:47.190 --> 00:03:51.622
I think I showed one two episodes ago of a
server that had 24 slots for memory in it.

77
00:03:51.622 --> 00:03:54.450
And that's because servers
can really eat up RAM.

78
00:03:54.450 --> 00:03:58.060
If you're running a relational database,
a relational database will try and

79
00:03:58.060 --> 00:03:59.900
cache all of its indexes into RAM.

80
00:03:59.900 --> 00:04:02.712
So it needs to have RAM that's big
enough to be able to contain those,

81
00:04:02.712 --> 00:04:03.739
you need a lot of memory.

82
00:04:03.739 --> 00:04:06.750
If you're running a virtualization server,
you have a lot of virtual machines,

83
00:04:06.750 --> 00:04:07.950
each one needs RAM.

84
00:04:07.950 --> 00:04:09.860
You're gonna need a lot of memory.

85
00:04:09.860 --> 00:04:14.010
So servers are designed to handle
more RAM than a typical workstation.

86
00:04:14.010 --> 00:04:18.670
And it gets expensive when you start
getting into the larger memory sizes.

87
00:04:18.670 --> 00:04:21.690
But on a server, it's worth it because
of the way that you're using it.

88
00:04:21.690 --> 00:04:24.870
Now just because there's more slots
doesn't mean we can just start chucking

89
00:04:24.870 --> 00:04:26.640
memory in there willy nilly, right?

90
00:04:26.640 --> 00:04:29.516
That we need to make sure that
we're getting the right memory and

91
00:04:29.516 --> 00:04:31.940
that we're putting it
into the right slots.

92
00:04:31.940 --> 00:04:32.950
When you look at this server,

93
00:04:32.950 --> 00:04:37.190
you'll notice how some of them are labeled
as white and some are black, right?

94
00:04:37.190 --> 00:04:41.140
What it’s telling me is which
ones need to be populated first.

95
00:04:41.140 --> 00:04:43.720
The white ones here need
to be populated first.

96
00:04:43.720 --> 00:04:46.060
And then I can populate
the black ones after that.

97
00:04:46.060 --> 00:04:47.610
And then on the motherboard,

98
00:04:47.610 --> 00:04:50.910
it's really hard to see here, but there's
actually writing on the motherboard

99
00:04:50.910 --> 00:04:54.080
that's telling me which channel
each of these are a part of.

100
00:04:54.080 --> 00:04:57.600
And that's something that I showed
in the last episode that was written

101
00:04:57.600 --> 00:05:00.140
on the lid of the server
when we popped that lid off.

102
00:05:00.140 --> 00:05:02.580
It actually had the channels that
looked easier to see on the lid.

103
00:05:02.580 --> 00:05:04.490
So we saw that on the last episode.

104
00:05:04.490 --> 00:05:05.500
But when I put the memory in,

105
00:05:05.500 --> 00:05:08.270
I need to make sure I follow
the order that my vendor specifies.

106
00:05:08.270 --> 00:05:10.520
And there's not a standard in use here.

107
00:05:10.520 --> 00:05:13.390
So make sure you read
the vendor documentation.

108
00:05:13.390 --> 00:05:15.740
The other thing is it
does use standard memory.

109
00:05:15.740 --> 00:05:17.740
Most servers use standard memory,
but standard for

110
00:05:17.740 --> 00:05:20.340
a server is different than
the standard for a workstation.

111
00:05:20.340 --> 00:05:22.986
In a workstation,
I'm just gonna go out and buy DDR3,

112
00:05:22.986 --> 00:05:24.632
whatever the fastest is I can get.

113
00:05:24.632 --> 00:05:27.753
And if I pick something at too high a
clock rate, the motherboard just steps it

114
00:05:27.753 --> 00:05:30.720
down to the clock rate that's
supported and off you go.

115
00:05:30.720 --> 00:05:33.160
On a server,
you have to be a little more careful.

116
00:05:33.160 --> 00:05:38.640
First off, most desktop memory
is what's called non-ECC memory.

117
00:05:38.640 --> 00:05:41.250
Servers use ECC memory.

118
00:05:41.250 --> 00:05:43.509
ECC is error checking, right?

119
00:05:43.509 --> 00:05:45.543
It does a little error
checking to make sure,

120
00:05:45.543 --> 00:05:48.740
or it's actually error correcting
code is what it stands for.

121
00:05:48.740 --> 00:05:54.540
But it means that the memory is
watching for hey, I just wrote a one.

122

00:21:58.101 --> 00:21:59.205
Gave you that whole range.

419
00:21:59.205 --> 00:22:03.993
So, it could go as low as 200 or as high
as 240 and it's gonna be okay, right.

420
00:22:03.993 --> 00:22:06.930
If it gets below 200,
now it's got a problem.

421
00:22:06.930 --> 00:22:08.570
And the same thing with 100 and 127.

422
00:22:08.570 --> 00:22:13.840
So, when you buy a light bulb and
it says it's 110 volt, what that actually

423
00:22:13.840 --> 00:22:20.070
means is, it's expecting 120, but
if it dips as low as 110, it'll be fine.

424
00:22:20.070 --> 00:22:24.120
If it dips to 109, maybe not so
much any more, right.

425
00:22:24.120 --> 00:22:27.540
And that's why you have this
unofficial 10% rule, if you dip down

426
00:22:27.540 --> 00:22:29.530
eventually you reach a point where
you're just not getting enough power,

427
00:22:29.530 --> 00:22:31.510
things just don't function any more.

428
00:22:31.510 --> 00:22:35.663
So, when I buy a server,
and I'm given a choice.

429
00:22:35.663 --> 00:22:40.103
Do I wanna run it 120 or
do I wanna run it 240, right?

430
00:22:40.103 --> 00:22:46.570
Well, we've got to pick, and if you do
240, the cabling is cheaper, right?

431
00:22:46.570 --> 00:22:48.387
The circuit is cheaper in most countries.

432
00:22:48.387 --> 00:22:50.716
In the US it isn't,
because we messed things up a bit.

433
00:22:50.716 --> 00:22:53.570
But in most countries
it's cheaper to go 240.

434
00:22:53.570 --> 00:22:59.030
And you're able to send a higher voltage,
which results in a lower amperage,

435
00:22:59.030 --> 00:23:01.900
and so your electric bill can
oftentimes end up being lower.

436
00:23:01.900 --> 00:23:04.960
But the rule of thumb is, if you can go
240 on equipment that's gonna be on all

437
00:23:04.960 --> 00:23:07.430
the time,
it usually makes sense to do that.

438
00:23:07.430 --> 00:23:13.100
If it's equipment that's just going on and
off and on and off, then 120 is fine.

439
00:23:13.100 --> 00:23:14.839
But usually we wanna try and go 240,

440
00:23:14.839 --> 00:23:17.908
because it can be a little more
efficient and give you a cost savings.

441
00:23:17.908 --> 00:23:21.618
Now, here in the US we
don't actually run 240.

442
00:23:21.618 --> 00:23:23.407
So when you get a 240 outlet,

443
00:23:23.407 --> 00:23:28.330
what's really happening is they're
taking two 120s and combining them.

444
00:23:28.330 --> 00:23:32.190
So, any efficiency that you had by going
240 you kinda lost, cuz you're really just

445
00:23:32.190 --> 00:23:34.460
pulling these two 120s together,
combining it to create a 240.

446
00:23:34.460 --> 00:23:37.400
So, it's not such a great
thing here in the US, but

447
00:23:37.400 --> 00:23:40.540
in other countries it works
out really well, all right.

448
00:23:40.540 --> 00:23:43.590
So, that's kind of the key thing there
that we need to understand when it comes

449
00:23:43.590 --> 00:23:47.370
to power,
is that these numbers are tied together.

450
00:23:47.370 --> 00:23:50.740
And when you buy servers in today's world,

451
00:23:50.740 --> 00:23:53.290
the majority of them
are rated to run either way.

452
00:23:53.290 --> 00:23:56.006
Where you start to see exceptions though,
is in network infrastructure.

453
00:23:56.006 --> 00:23:58.475
I mention the Cisco Catalyst 6500 switch.

454
00:23:58.475 --> 00:24:00.411
The 6509s or whatever.

455
00:24:00.411 --> 00:24:04.269
They're big switches, and
they have big power supplies on them.

456
00:24:04.269 --> 00:24:06.866
And they can run off of 120.

457
00:24:06.866 --> 00:24:11.255
But if you're doing PoE, if you're
doing Power over Ethernet, right, or

458
00:24:11.255 --> 00:24:13.733
PoE+, they need to draw even more power.

459
00:24:13.733 --> 00:24:16.117
Because they're not just providing
power to themselves anymore,

460
00:24:16.117 --> 00:24:18.180
now they're powering
other devices downstream.

461
00:24:18.180 --> 00:24:20.280
They need to draw more current.

462
00:24:20.280 --> 00:24:24.760
And on a 120 cable, because of
the lower voltage, there's only so

463
00:24:24.760 --> 00:24:28.620
much amperage that we can carry over
that wire before it catches on fire.

464
00:24:28.620 --> 00:24:31.740
But if we switch to 240,
it's a higher voltage.

465
00:24:31.740 --> 00:24:36.380
We can actually carry more amperage
over that wire within its tolerances and

466
00:24:36.380 --> 00:24:39.640
be okay over the same wire
that we were running 120 on.

467
00:24:39.640 --> 00:24:44.340
Instead of going to thinner wire, you can
still get the nice thick 240 cable and

468
00:24:44.340 --> 00:24:46.130
carry even more amperage over it.

469
00:24:46.130 --> 00:24:49.906
And so you'll find some power supplies
where they require 240 because of

470
00:24:49.906 --> 00:24:51.560
the increased power.

471
00:24:51.560 --> 00:24:56.400
Now, this server that I've got sitting
here only has one physical CPU in it, and

00:24:56.400 --> 00:24:57.730
so it's rated for both.

00:24:57.730 --> 00:25:01.265
And in fact, all the servers in
our closet behind us are rated for

474
00:25:01.265 --> 00:25:03.439
both, they'll do 120 and 240.

00:25:03.439 --> 00:25:06.230
I think the biggest server
in there has four CPUs.

476
00:25:07.280 --> 00:25:10.250
But when you start
getting into mainframes,

477
00:25:10.250 --> 00:25:13.840
when you have servers that have
64 physical processors in them,

478
00:25:13.840 --> 00:25:17.080
I'm not talking cores,
I'm talking about 64 physical CPUs.

479
00:25:17.080 --> 00:25:18.905
They draw a lot of power,
right, a ton of power.

480
00:25:18.905 --> 00:25:24.093
If each CPU is drawing 0.2 amps and
you've got 64 of the things,

481
00:25:24.093 --> 00:25:27.400
that adds up to a good bit of amperage.

482
00:25:27.400 --> 00:25:30.520
Usually it's more than what
you can carry over a 120 line.

483
00:25:30.520 --> 00:25:34.550
And so those servers will require 240,
you'll have to have it.

484
00:25:34.550 --> 00:25:38.220
So when you purchase a server,
you've gotta identify that.

485
00:25:38.220 --> 00:25:41.000
You've gotta look and figure out
what the power requirements are.

486
00:25:41.000 --> 00:25:43.306
I know too many people who have bought
switches and they couldn't plug them in

487
00:25:43.306 --> 00:25:45.239
cuz they didn't pay attention
to what the power supplies were.

488
00:25:45.239 --> 00:25:49.227
>> Don, one of the things I was gonna ask

00:25:49.227 --> 00:25:53.036
the certification exam or is this
something that you really need to know for

00:25:53.036 --> 00:25:53.895
the real world?

00:25:53.895 --> 00:25:56.805
And now I think I'm kinda answering that

00:25:56.805 --> 00:25:59.147

00:25:59.147 --> 00:26:03.425
And, by the way, AWG, that's the American

00:26:25.450 --> 00:26:27.540
Even for your household stuff,

00:26:27.540 --> 00:26:30.037
But in a data center it's super

00:26:30.037 --> 00:26:30.893

00:26:30.893 --> 00:26:34.030
And you've gotta make sure you're

00:26:34.030 --> 00:26:37.430
When you have a rack that's loaded up

00:26:37.430 --> 00:26:40.890
distribution units, we're gonna talk

00:26:40.890 --> 00:26:45.430
How do you know that you're providing

00:26:45.430 --> 00:26:47.640
Well, you need to keep
a running checklist.

00:26:47.640 --> 00:26:48.680
You need to have a list of,

00:26:48.680 --> 00:26:51.800
here's all the power supplies that

00:26:51.800 --> 00:26:53.430
How many circuits do we need?

514
00:26:53.430 --> 00:26:55.470
You'll probably need
more than one circuit.

515
00:26:55.470 --> 00:26:59.256
And that leads us to a whole nother topic,
which is, in power,

516
00:26:59.256 --> 00:27:02.270
you have single-phase and
multi-phase power.

517
00:27:02.270 --> 00:27:04.319
Usually it's either one or three phases.

518
00:27:04.319 --> 00:27:08.818
So single-phase power is what you normally
have in a wall socket on your wall.

519
00:27:08.818 --> 00:27:13.558
You walk up to it, you plug in,
and you're just getting a single,

520
00:27:13.558 --> 00:27:18.850
in our case it'd be 120 volt power
source that's coming through.

521
00:27:18.850 --> 00:27:20.570
And that's all you get.

522
00:27:20.570 --> 00:27:21.810
And remember the sine waves,

523
00:27:21.810 --> 00:27:24.760
how I was talking about how it goes up and
then it comes down.

524
00:27:24.760 --> 00:27:28.010
And when it hits that horizontal line,
so it goes up and it comes down,

525
00:27:28.010 --> 00:27:30.510
when it hits that horizontal
line you're getting nothing.

526
00:27:30.510 --> 00:27:32.283
And then it dips down and
it goes negative, and comes back up and

527
00:27:32.283 --> 00:27:33.060
you're getting nothing.

528
00:27:33.060 --> 00:27:35.720
And then it goes positive and
it comes back and you're getting nothing.

529
00:27:35.720 --> 00:27:39.580
So you're constantly getting nothing
every so often on that interval.

530
00:27:39.580 --> 00:27:42.070
With single-phase power,
that's what happens.

531
00:27:42.070 --> 00:27:46.820
Well, multi-phase power, like three-phase
power, it does something really cool.

532
00:27:46.820 --> 00:27:49.970
Which is it sends three
different sine waves.

533
00:27:49.970 --> 00:27:52.550
So each one's slightly offset.

534
00:27:52.550 --> 00:27:58.270
So when one hits the axes and
is zeroed out, the the other two aren't.

535
00:27:58.270 --> 00:27:59.852
And the other two are at different areas.

536
00:27:59.852 --> 00:28:04.619
So that you've always got at least one,
but usually two phases are providing

537
00:28:04.619 --> 00:28:09.258
some level of power when one of
the phases grounds out to zero, right?

538
00:28:09.258 --> 00:28:15.250
So with three-phase, you get a much more
consistent amount of power being provided.

539
00:28:15.250 --> 00:28:20.490
The other thing about three-phase is that
you can run a single three-phase line and

540
00:28:20.490 --> 00:28:24.970
then you can split the phases out
into three separate circuits.

541
00:28:24.970 --> 00:28:27.750
So you can provide multiple
circuits across a single line,

542
00:28:27.750 --> 00:28:29.810
that's another advantage
of doing three-phase.

543
00:28:29.810 --> 00:28:32.110
So when you get into a data center,

544
00:28:32.110 --> 00:28:35.740
you may have some equipment
that requires three-phase.

545
00:28:35.740 --> 00:28:39.846
It's normally really easy to spot,
because we have 120 and we have 240,

546
00:28:39.846 --> 00:28:42.438
those are pretty consistent for
single-phase.

547
00:28:42.438 --> 00:28:47.243
Although in the United States 240
sort of is two-phase cuz you got two

548
00:28:47.243 --> 00:28:52.380
120s linked together, but
they're typically at the same phase.

549
00:28:52.380 --> 00:28:55.700
But when you get to three-phase,
there is three-phase 240,

550
00:28:55.700 --> 00:28:57.330
you just don't see it very often.

551
00:28:57.330 --> 00:29:00.370
It's normally 208,
that you'll get 208 volts.

552
00:29:00.370 --> 00:29:04.900
And if you ever see it you're like,

553
00:29:04.900 --> 00:29:06.960
They must mean 220.

554
00:29:06.960 --> 00:29:09.776
And there is some equipment
that'll do okay and cheat with it.

00:29:09.776 --> 00:29:14.667
But there's a lot of equipment like
the big Liebert air conditioning units

556
00:29:14.667 --> 00:29:19.646
that you see in data centers, or
some UPSs where they actually want 208.

557
00:29:19.646 --> 00:29:24.038
And they want it to be three-phase and
if you give it to them in any other form,

558
00:29:24.038 --> 00:29:25.920
it's a mess, all right.

559
00:29:25.920 --> 00:29:28.580
Now where does that 208 number come from,
right?

560
00:29:28.580 --> 00:29:32.519
120 kind of makes sense if you
think about the sine wave.

561
00:29:32.519 --> 00:29:35.396
Remember how I mentioned the sine
wave is in these 60 second windows?

562
00:29:35.396 --> 00:29:40.118
That if you have a positive and
a negative leg of the sine wave, 60 and

563
00:29:40.118 --> 00:29:41.729
60 adds up to 120.

564
00:29:41.729 --> 00:29:43.361
Right, so there we get our 120.

565
00:29:43.361 --> 00:29:49.390
Well, if you take 120 and you double up
that, you get to 240 so that makes sense.

566
00:29:49.390 --> 00:29:51.120
Where's the 208 come from?

567
00:29:51.120 --> 00:29:55.240
I always wonder that, and a few years ago
I asked a facilities guy that I worked

568
00:29:55.240 --> 00:29:57.970
with and he drew me a picture and
it blew my mind.

00:29:57.970 --> 00:30:02.000
So I'm gonna show you this picture,
and I can't take credit for this.

00:30:02.000 --> 00:30:04.460
Tom, if you're watching,
thank you for showing me this.

00:30:04.460 --> 00:30:09.206
But basically he said, draw a circle and
imagine that the radius of

00:30:09.206 --> 00:30:13.550
that circle is 120,
like a 120 volt circuit, right?

00:30:13.550 --> 00:30:15.022
So I did that.

00:30:15.022 --> 00:30:18.519
And then he said, all right,
now, if you got a radius of 120,

00:30:18.519 --> 00:30:21.140
then it would have a diameter of 240,

00:30:21.140 --> 00:30:24.230
The diameter, the line straight
through the circle, would be 240.

00:30:24.230 --> 00:30:26.190
All right, so
this is the circle that I've got drawn.

00:30:27.190 --> 00:30:31.390
And he said, then put a triangle in it,
put a triangle in the circle.

00:30:31.390 --> 00:30:37.268
And when you do that,
each leg of your triangle would be 208.

00:30:37.268 --> 00:30:41.360
Let's just say that these
were centimeters, right.

00:30:41.360 --> 00:30:44.560
So if it was 120 centimeters and
I double it up to 240 centimeters, so

582
00:30:44.560 --> 00:30:48.620
I've got a circle with
a diameter of 240 centimeters.

583
00:30:48.620 --> 00:30:53.070
That when you draw the lines and
calculate out the length of that side,

584
00:30:53.070 --> 00:30:55.390
it would be 208 centimeters.

585
00:30:55.390 --> 00:30:57.675
That's where that number comes from so

586
00:30:57.675 --> 00:31:00.230
there's a mathematical
principle behind this.

587
00:31:00.230 --> 00:31:05.248
And he said if you continue
to think that way and

588
00:31:05.248 --> 00:31:09.752
you put your radius back in, what you have

00:31:09.752 --> 00:31:15.168
are three 120 radius lines and three 208s.

00:31:15.168 --> 00:31:18.336
And he said the way it works
is when you provide it,

00:31:18.336 --> 00:31:23.250
if the device you plug into connects

00:31:23.250 --> 00:31:26.920
The line-to-line voltage is 208.

00:31:26.920 --> 00:31:29.421
But if they grab just one line,

00:31:29.421 --> 00:31:34.160
And so you could grab all three, and

00:31:34.160 --> 00:31:37.889
Or you can grab two and a neutral,

00:31:37.889 --> 00:31:40.516
And so it's able to pull
the power that it needs, and

00:31:40.516 --> 00:31:43.220
it's able to grab that information and

00:31:43.220 --> 00:31:46.534
It can even convert it into 240 if it

00:31:46.534 --> 00:31:47.651
it's three 120 legs.

00:31:47.651 --> 00:31:49.910
It can just grab a couple of them and

601
00:31:49.910 --> 00:31:52.730
So it's kind of a neat thing,
there's a little bit of mathematics that

00:31:52.730 --> 00:31:54.659

00:31:54.659 --> 00:31:56.059
He drew this picture for me and

00:31:56.059 --> 00:31:59.316
it really kinda helped me to

00:31:59.316 --> 00:32:00.507
That's fascinating.

00:32:00.507 --> 00:32:01.651

00:32:01.651 --> 00:32:05.895

00:32:05.895 --> 00:32:08.020

00:32:27.886 --> 00:32:31.570
But, when you're talking about these

00:32:31.570 --> 00:32:34.750

00:32:34.750 --> 00:32:37.340
then they're gonna handle it, they'll

00:32:37.340 --> 00:32:39.921
They're expecting constant power,

00:32:39.921 --> 00:32:43.070
they wouldn't be getting that constant

00:32:43.070 --> 00:32:47.620
An example I can give of that is,

621
00:32:47.620 --> 00:32:49.948
When I'm on a bicycle,

00:32:49.948 --> 00:32:53.257
There might be two pedals, but

00:32:53.257 --> 00:32:56.170
when I push on the pedals,

00:32:56.170 --> 00:32:59.888
If I push on just one pedal,
when I'm pushing down,

00:32:59.888 --> 00:33:02.011
it makes the bike go forward.

00:33:02.011 --> 00:33:05.780
And when I'm coming back up,

00:33:05.780 --> 00:33:08.700
When you're coming back up on that pedal,

00:33:08.700 --> 00:33:10.265
And then as you push again,

629
00:33:10.265 --> 00:33:14.380
So the power is coming and going,

00:33:14.380 --> 00:33:15.650
When you've got two pedals,

00:33:15.650 --> 00:33:20.060
though, now you can be pushing down on

00:33:20.060 --> 00:33:24.170
And you're always pushing, and

00:33:24.170 --> 00:33:28.100
Well, there is still a time where

00:33:28.100 --> 00:33:31.030

00:33:31.030 --> 00:33:33.001

00:33:33.001 --> 00:33:36.360
