would look like, exactly.

638
00:33:37.726 --> 00:33:41.530
But you keep pushing on all three,
and you'd never have a situation where

639
00:33:41.530 --> 00:33:45.180
two pedals were perfectly up and
down because you've got three pedals, and

640
00:33:45.180 --> 00:33:47.850
that's what three phase does,
is you're able to constantly push.

641
00:33:47.850 --> 00:33:52.150
I guess maybe a better example would
be a tandem bike with three people,

642
00:33:52.150 --> 00:33:54.970
but maybe one of them's got their
feet up on the handlebars and

643
00:33:54.970 --> 00:33:56.580
that example breaks down really fast.

644
00:33:56.580 --> 00:33:58.530
So, but that's how this stuff works, and

645
00:33:58.530 --> 00:34:01.450
it is important to understand
the requirements of your equipment

646
00:34:01.450 --> 00:34:04.940
when you're shopping for equipment or
the existing equipment you've already got.

647
00:34:04.940 --> 00:34:07.960
Don't assume they all use the same power,

648
00:34:07.960 --> 00:34:12.650
because there are variations,
right, and it does get confusing.

649
00:34:12.650 --> 00:34:15.442
Another thing that's confusing, I know
I'm low on time but I want to mention.

650
00:34:15.442 --> 00:34:22.055
I mentioned 48-volt power and how inside
of a computer you'll normally see 48-volt.

651
00:34:22.055 --> 00:34:24.320
48-volt can be used a few
different places, and

652
00:34:24.320 --> 00:34:27.210
sometimes it's written negative 48-volt,
and remember,

653
00:34:27.210 --> 00:34:29.250
what we're talking about with
a current there's a sine wave, right?

654
00:34:29.250 --> 00:34:31.230
So there's a positive and
a negative part of it, and so

655
00:34:31.230 --> 00:34:35.810
negative 48 volt would just be on
the down leg of that sine wave.

656
00:34:35.810 --> 00:34:39.250
And positive 48 volt would
be on the upper sine wave.

657
00:34:39.250 --> 00:34:40.930
Equipment can use the negative side,
right.

658
00:34:40.930 --> 00:34:43.120
You don't always have to
use the positive side.

659
00:34:43.120 --> 00:34:44.960
So you can use the dark side.

660
00:34:44.960 --> 00:34:46.160
It's like Star Wars.

661
00:34:46.160 --> 00:34:49.560
Then we can use this and
get the power that we need.

662
00:34:49.560 --> 00:34:51.530
So you'll see those used interchangeably.

663
00:34:51.530 --> 00:34:53.240
Negative 48 volt, positive 48 volt.

664
00:34:53.240 --> 00:34:56.520
I think the exam objective actually uses,
both get kinda thrown out there.

665
00:34:58.070 --> 00:35:00.590
Inside of a computer, you'll see
48-volt come out of a power supply.

666
00:35:01.800 --> 00:35:04.460
Sometimes you'll get network routers and

667
00:35:04.460 --> 00:35:07.390
switches that have one
power supply in them.

668
00:35:07.390 --> 00:35:11.530
And then it'll say that you can hook
up an external redundant power supply.

669
00:35:11.530 --> 00:35:15.100
And there will be a little port on
the back of the device that'll let you

670
00:35:15.100 --> 00:35:16.880
plug in an external power supply.

671
00:35:16.880 --> 00:35:22.250
Those, not always, but almost always,
a lot of the time, are 48-volt.

672
00:35:22.250 --> 00:35:24.830
They have a little harness connector
that connects to some kind of

673
00:35:24.830 --> 00:35:25.640
extra battery pack.

674
00:35:25.640 --> 00:35:27.742
We used to do them with Cisco
equipment all the time.

675
00:35:27.742 --> 00:35:31.230
I know I've got a couple of Cisco Catalyst
switches is back in the closet right now

676
00:35:31.230 --> 00:35:33.700
that have those 48-volt
connectors on the back.

677
00:35:33.700 --> 00:35:36.390
So 48-volt is not always internal.

678
00:35:36.390 --> 00:35:39.330
Sometimes it's an external device that's
connecting, but it's usually gonna be

679
00:35:39.330 --> 00:35:43.610
a power supply that's connecting, or
potentially a battery backup for 48-volt.

680
00:35:43.610 --> 00:35:45.360
But that's usually where you see that.

681
00:35:45.360 --> 00:35:48.410
I don't think I've ever seen
a 48-volt wall socket on a wall.

682
00:35:48.410 --> 00:35:50.860
That's just not something that happens.

683
00:35:50.860 --> 00:35:52.490
>> Well done.
That's a lot of great information.

684
00:35:52.490 --> 00:35:55.850
And it's interesting some of
the entry level science behind it.

685
00:35:55.850 --> 00:35:57.720
I know I find it fascinating.

686
00:35:57.720 --> 00:36:00.230
And you have already mentioned that it
does look like we're coming to the end of

687
00:36:00.230 --> 00:36:00.930
another episode.

688
00:36:00.930 --> 00:36:02.650
But I know that we still
have some more to go.

689
00:36:02.650 --> 00:36:03.790
So how about we do this?

690
00:36:03.790 --> 00:36:07.300
How about we go into a part two,
and we'll come back and

691
00:36:07.300 --> 00:36:10.980
finish the rest of the concepts and
topics that you have to talk about.

692
00:36:10.980 --> 00:36:11.680
But before you do,

693
00:36:11.680 --> 00:36:14.470
do you have any additional words that
you'd like to throw in this one?

694
00:36:14.470 --> 00:36:16.750
>> Let me just tell them one
last thing on triple phase.

695
00:36:16.750 --> 00:36:19.580
On triple phase, I focused on 208,
cuz that's the most common.

696
00:36:19.580 --> 00:36:23.456
But there's also another
one that's a little weird,

697
00:36:23.456 --> 00:36:26.496
cuz it can be 440, 460, or 480.

698
00:36:26.496 --> 00:36:27.679
There we go.
Let me get it right.

699
00:36:27.679 --> 00:36:32.320
440, 460, or 480 volt, really high.

700
00:36:32.320 --> 00:36:36.590
That's another three-phase power
system that you'll see out there.

701
00:36:36.590 --> 00:36:39.150
It's just incredibly efficient,
cuz the voltage is so high.

702
00:36:39.150 --> 00:36:41.500
It can carry some really high amperage.

703
00:36:41.500 --> 00:36:43.510
You're not normally gonna
have to mess with that one.

704
00:36:43.510 --> 00:36:46.680
Maybe if you have the big diesel power
generators outside that are powering

705
00:36:46.680 --> 00:36:49.990
your building, they might carry
some of the 440, or whatever.

706
00:36:49.990 --> 00:36:54.350
440, 460 and 480 are basically
interchangeable devices at that

707
00:36:54.350 --> 00:36:58.100
high level of voltage, they're designed to
tolerate the difference between the three.

708
00:36:58.100 --> 00:37:01.390
So we don't normally nitpick at that
point over which of the three we get.

709
00:37:01.390 --> 00:37:05.840
But that's another three-phase
power system that's out there.

710
00:37:05.840 --> 00:37:07.900
Really, really high amount
of power on that one.

711
00:37:07.900 --> 00:37:11.370
Really super mega dangerous too,
so it's usually very well labeled.

712
00:37:11.370 --> 00:37:16.212
Because this is the power that reaches the
levels that can really put you down pretty

713
00:37:16.212 --> 00:37:16.914
fast, so.

714
00:37:16.914 --> 00:37:19.582
>> We got a lot more to talk on power,
though, we'll save it for part two, so

715
00:37:19.582 --> 00:37:21.290
I don't wanna ramble on to much.

716
00:37:21.290 --> 00:37:23.380
>> All right great,
well that's a great place to stop Don.

717
00:37:23.380 --> 00:37:25.810
Thank you for being here, and
thank you the viewer watching.

718
00:37:25.810 --> 00:37:29.770
Keep in mind anytime you're dealing with
electrical equipment, be very careful.

719
00:37:29.770 --> 00:37:32.578
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

720
00:37:32.578 --> 00:37:35.839
>> And I'm Don Pezet and
we'll see you next time.

721
00:37:35.839 --> 00:37:41.669
[MUSIC]

722
00:37:41.669 --> 00:37:44.608
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don look at the different concepts and standards when looking at power utilization within servers, computers and a datacenter. They discuss power consumption, redundancy, plug types, the NEMU standards, Edison plugs and cooling concepts.
episodes.title: Power and Cooling Part 2

WEBVTT

1

Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:01.785 --> 00:00:05.917
>> [CROSSTALK]

3

4

5
00:00:11.583 --> 00:00:14.091
>> Welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.091 --> 00:00:15.752
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:15.752 --> 00:00:17.008
And in today's episode,

8
00:00:17.008 --> 00:00:20.674
we're continuing through our CompTIA
server plus certification course.

9
00:00:20.674 --> 00:00:24.474
And we've been looking at electrical
concerns here and joining us back for

10
00:00:24.474 --> 00:00:26.722
a part two is none other than Mr.
Don Pezet.

11
00:00:26.722 --> 00:00:27.559
Don, how you doing, Sir?

12
00:00:27.559 --> 00:00:29.021
>> I'm doing just well, Wes.

13
00:00:29.021 --> 00:00:32.037
Ready [LAUGH] to dive right
back into power and cooling.

14
00:00:32.037 --> 00:00:35.675
I was trying to think of a good joke there
about how we are two people to just exude

15
00:00:35.675 --> 00:00:37.350
power and cool.

16
00:00:37.350 --> 00:00:38.090
Well, that couldn't work out.

17
00:00:38.090 --> 00:00:39.700
I guess maybe the statement
is a joke in and of itself.

18
00:00:39.700 --> 00:00:40.820
So, anyhow, enough of that.

19
00:00:40.820 --> 00:00:41.910
We're gonna talk about power.

20
00:00:41.910 --> 00:00:44.930
I've got a few more points that I wanted
to hit on on power that we need to be

21
00:00:44.930 --> 00:00:45.840
concerned about.

22
00:00:45.840 --> 00:00:48.660
And then we're gonna talk about
cooling inside of servers.

23
00:00:48.660 --> 00:00:51.220
Now I know I got ahead of myself and
talked about it in another episode, but

24
00:00:51.220 --> 00:00:53.350
we'll talk a little bit
more about it here.

25
00:00:53.350 --> 00:00:56.551
Let's get back to power.
So, in the last episode, I talked a lot

26
00:00:56.551 --> 00:01:01.334
about the concepts of current and
voltage and just power wattage.

27
00:01:01.334 --> 00:01:02.402
And we talked about those.

28
00:01:02.402 --> 00:01:06.660
Another key concept that we need to
understand is that electricity costs

29
00:01:06.660 --> 00:01:07.161
money.

30
00:01:07.161 --> 00:01:10.667
It's an unavoidable fact.

31
00:01:10.667 --> 00:01:14.232
Even if you set up your own power
source of some sort like a wind farm,

32
00:01:14.232 --> 00:01:15.184
or solar panels.

33
00:01:15.184 --> 00:01:17.123
Those things have a cost too.

34
00:01:17.123 --> 00:01:20.619
And so we've gotta make sure
that in our data centers,

35
00:01:20.619 --> 00:01:24.495
we are able to measure and
track what those cost are gonna be.

36
00:01:24.495 --> 00:01:25.714
That's really important.

37
00:01:25.714 --> 00:01:30.228
Just as an example, it was actually
us several years ago where we had,

38
00:01:30.228 --> 00:01:34.985
I think it was four servers that were
in our server room that were running.

39
00:01:34.985 --> 00:01:36.796
They ran 24 hours a day.

40
00:01:36.796 --> 00:01:38.804
They were doing their job and
they were doing their job fine.

41
00:01:38.804 --> 00:01:42.191
And usually you replace
servers every three years and

42
00:01:42.191 --> 00:01:46.641
we hit the three year mark in these
servers, and they were doing fine.

43
00:01:46.641 --> 00:01:49.459
So we didn't feel the need to
replace them and so, I said, yeah,

44
00:01:49.459 --> 00:01:52.380
we're not gonna replace them,
we'll just keep them.

45
00:01:52.380 --> 00:01:55.120
And one of the other guys came in and
said,

46
00:01:55.120 --> 00:01:58.980
well, Don, the newer servers that
out today are more power efficient.

47
00:01:58.980 --> 00:02:01.680
And I bet if we replaced the servers,

48
00:02:01.680 --> 00:02:06.025
the power savings alone will offset
the cost of us replacing the servers.

49
00:02:06.025 --> 00:02:10.129
And I know the term I wanna use but

50
00:02:10.129 --> 00:02:15.145
I was disbelieving of that statement.

51
00:02:15.145 --> 00:02:16.909
I said that can't be possibly be true.

52
00:02:16.909 --> 00:02:21.656
And so what they did is they took
a little meter, kilowatt at the time, and

53
00:02:21.656 --> 00:02:26.170
plugged it in to measure
the system's power consumption.

54
00:02:26.170 --> 00:02:29.060
And they measured the power consumption
of our servers, our four servers that

55
00:02:29.060 --> 00:02:33.690
we already had, and showed what that
cost us in terms of our electric bill.

56
00:02:33.690 --> 00:02:36.690
And it was a couple of
hundred bucks a month really.

57
00:02:36.690 --> 00:02:38.600
Over the course of the year for
the four servers.

58
00:02:38.600 --> 00:02:41.370
And sure enough, by the time you looked
at it over the course of a year,

59
00:02:41.370 --> 00:02:44.540
it was a lot of money and that could
offset the cost of buying new servers.

60
00:02:44.540 --> 00:02:47.091
It didn't equal out exactly
buying four new servers, but

61
00:02:47.091 --> 00:02:50.329
it showed that there was a significant
cost savings with the new servers.

62
00:02:50.329 --> 00:02:52.908
That you'd be surprized how
efficient these things can get.

63
00:02:52.908 --> 00:02:54.465
And we need to be able to track that.

64
00:02:54.465 --> 00:02:59.520
Not only that, though, we need to be
able to track what our maximum draw is.

65
00:02:59.520 --> 00:03:02.170
To make sure we've got enough
power to be able to handle it.

66
00:03:02.170 --> 00:03:05.553
So being able to report on a lot
of this stuff is important.

67
00:03:05.553 --> 00:03:07.934
And when you're in a home or
a small office and

68
00:03:07.934 --> 00:03:11.257
you need one power outlet on
the wall to split into six outlets,

69
00:03:11.257 --> 00:03:15.165
you just get a surge suppressor,
whatever and you pop it in and off you go.

70
00:03:15.165 --> 00:03:18.750
You don't think about things like
voltage and current and all that.

71
00:03:18.750 --> 00:03:22.700
But in a server room, if I have
six servers that are all being fed

72
00:03:22.700 --> 00:03:27.030
off of the same link, that's a lot of
amperage to be drawing on one link.

73
00:03:27.030 --> 00:03:30.581
And I might be exceeding what that circuit
is capable of, in which case I'm gonna

74
00:03:30.581 --> 00:03:34.150
trip the circuit, right, which is
something that happens pretty frequently.

75
00:03:34.150 --> 00:03:37.085
But if we're monitoring that,
then we can really see it.

76
00:03:37.085 --> 00:03:41.692
And when you buy power strips for a data
center, there's companies like APC and

77
00:03:41.692 --> 00:03:46.094
TripLight that make really good ones
that actually have a little LED right on

78
00:03:46.094 --> 00:03:49.838
them that will tell you how many
amps it's drawing at that time.

79
00:03:49.838 --> 00:03:52.361
And as you plug in each server,
you can see the amperage go up and

80
00:03:52.361 --> 00:03:54.946
keep track of it and, say, whoop,
this circuit's at its max.

81
00:03:54.946 --> 00:03:59.490
I've got a 30 amp circuit and I'm at
28 amps, so I'm gonna stop right there.

82
00:03:59.490 --> 00:04:01.790
And I'm not gonna add anything more to
that one, let me go and do another one.

83
00:04:01.790 --> 00:04:03.390
And that lets just track it.

84
00:04:03.390 --> 00:04:04.740
But we also need to track it for billing.

85
00:04:04.740 --> 00:04:07.170
And if you've ever looked
at your electric billing,

86
00:04:07.170 --> 00:04:09.499
they always reflect it as killowat hours,
right?

87
00:04:09.499 --> 00:04:10.998
Killowat hours, or kWh.

88
00:04:10.998 --> 00:04:14.265
It's actually a lower case k,
capital W, lower case h.

89
00:04:14.265 --> 00:04:15.773
They're really picky about that.

90
00:04:15.773 --> 00:04:18.140
Killowat hours are what
we're normally billed in.

91
00:04:18.140 --> 00:04:20.320
>> So that should be fairly
easy to calculate, right Don?

92
00:04:20.320 --> 00:04:23.850
I've got a kilowatt and this how
many kilowatts I've used in an hour?

93
00:04:23.850 --> 00:04:26.140
Time domain, measure it up,
we're ready to go, right?

94
00:04:26.140 --> 00:04:28.850
>> Well,
it's one of those weird things where, yes,

95
00:04:28.850 --> 00:04:32.480
it's got hour in the name but
it's not really talking about an hour.

96
00:04:32.480 --> 00:04:35.120
It's not actually
a measurement of time at all.

97
00:04:35.120 --> 00:04:37.437
It's a measure of how
many watts you consumed.

98
00:04:37.437 --> 00:04:40.943
Right, so a kilowatt is 1,000 watts.

99
00:04:40.943 --> 00:04:42.325
That kinda make sense, right?

100
00:04:42.325 --> 00:04:46.230
So, here let me get a text window open and
we'll write this out.

101
00:04:46.230 --> 00:04:50.380
So, what we're talking about
our kilowatt hours, right?

102
00:04:50.380 --> 00:04:53.780
Or kWh as it's normally written on a bill,
right?

103
00:04:53.780 --> 00:04:56.210
That's the unit measure
that we're talking about.

104
00:04:56.210 --> 00:05:01.510
And when we calculate that out, a kWh =

105
00:05:01.510 --> 00:05:08.130
1000 Watts, or
really a kW is what equals 1000 Watts.

106
00:05:08.130 --> 00:05:12.230
So when we talk about a kilowatt hour,

107
00:05:12.230 --> 00:05:14.880
that doesn't necessarily mean
that an hour of time has passed.

108
00:05:14.880 --> 00:05:17.680
An hour of time, it may have
taken ten hours or fifty hours.

109
00:05:17.680 --> 00:05:22.545
It might have taken 30 minutes
to consume a kilowatt hour

110
00:05:22.545 --> 00:05:26.827
because we're not just
consuming a fixed number.

111
00:05:26.827 --> 00:05:31.529
Not every device consumes
1,000 kilowatts in an hour.

112
00:05:31.529 --> 00:05:37.030
When I turn on a lightbulb, it's not
consuming 1,000 kilowatts an hour.

113
00:05:37.030 --> 00:05:41.100
Now, if I had a 1,000 watt power supply,
then, yeah,

114
00:05:41.100 --> 00:05:42.550
it's consuming a kilowatt per hour.

115
00:05:42.550 --> 00:05:44.790
Right, it just happens to line up,
but most things don't.

116
00:05:44.790 --> 00:05:49.140
If you think about a 40 watt light bulb,
I'm gonna do some easy math here,

117
00:05:49.140 --> 00:05:50.800
let's make it a 50 watt light bulb.

118
00:05:50.800 --> 00:05:57.020
If I have a 50 watt light bulb
versus a 100 watt light bulb,

119
00:05:57.020 --> 00:05:59.930
those light bulbs are drawing
different wattages.

120
00:05:59.930 --> 00:06:01.608
And so if I run them for an hour,

121
00:06:01.608 --> 00:06:04.848
the first one is drawing half
the wattage of the second one.

122
00:06:04.848 --> 00:06:11.325
So, for a 50 watt lightbulb to
draw 1 kilowatt hour, right?

123
00:06:11.325 --> 00:06:17.118
So if it were to draw 1 kilowatt hour,
that would actually take it 20 hours.

124
00:06:17.118 --> 00:06:22.493
Versus a 100 watt lightbulb,
which would draw 1 kilowatt hour, if

125
00:06:22.493 --> 00:06:28.246
I can get my casing right after I stressed
it so hard and I can't do it myself.

126
00:06:28.246 --> 00:06:30.177
It would only take 10 hours.

127
00:06:30.177 --> 00:06:36.870
Cuz it's drawing a 100 watts an hour over
10 hours, it would draw 1,000 kilo watts.

128
00:06:36.870 --> 00:06:40.285
So if I'm measuring that light bulb,
and I see that that lightbulb

129
00:06:40.285 --> 00:06:44.930
costs me one kilowatt hour,
it actually took me 10 hours to do it.

130
00:06:44.930 --> 00:06:49.290
And that's why I say that a kilowatt hour
is not truly a unit of measure of time.

131
00:06:49.290 --> 00:06:51.651
It's a measure of wattage consumption.

132
00:06:51.651 --> 00:06:52.916
So, it's really confusing.

133
00:06:52.916 --> 00:06:57.066
And it's hard to explain to people
cuz if you look at a power bill,

134
00:06:57.066 --> 00:07:00.625
how can I consume more than
24 kilowatt hours in a day?

135
00:07:00.625 --> 00:07:01.799
There's only 24 hours.

the average end user for sure.

812
00:39:29.670 --> 00:39:31.570
Thermal dissipation's a lot greater.

813
00:39:31.570 --> 00:39:34.560
Don, in a server closet would you
consider that advanced setup,

814
00:39:34.560 --> 00:39:37.890
considering pretty much everything
about a data center is advanced setup?

815
00:39:37.890 --> 00:39:38.579
Or is that more of a commonality?

816
00:39:38.579 --> 00:39:40.945
>> No, no, no, it's definitely advanced.

817
00:39:40.945 --> 00:39:44.000
Most servers aren't built for, and
I'm glad you said liquid coolant,

818
00:39:44.000 --> 00:39:47.870
because it's not always water sometimes
it's mineral oil or other things.

819
00:39:47.870 --> 00:39:49.530
It doesn't have to be water.

820
00:39:49.530 --> 00:39:53.140
But liquid cooling, this server has to be
designed to do it and most of them aren't.

821
00:39:53.140 --> 00:39:54.320
When you got to Dell's website or

822
00:39:54.320 --> 00:39:58.780
HP's website the majority of the servers
are not built to be liquid cooled.

823
00:39:58.780 --> 00:40:01.350
But when you get a mainframe,
If it's designed for

824
00:40:01.350 --> 00:40:03.840
liquid cooling,
the cooling solution's included with it.

825
00:40:03.840 --> 00:40:05.960
Now mainframes cost millions of dollars.

826
00:40:05.960 --> 00:40:08.250
So when I say it's included with this,
it's not like you're getting a free deal.

827
00:40:08.250 --> 00:40:09.690
You're paying for it, right.

828
00:40:09.690 --> 00:40:11.930
But they've designed it to
require that kind of cooling.

829
00:40:13.020 --> 00:40:15.540
And it'll be installed as
a part of that system.

830
00:40:15.540 --> 00:40:17.530
So mainframes are a big deal.

831
00:40:17.530 --> 00:40:22.160
Most people have moved away from
mainframes to less centralized systems,

832
00:40:22.160 --> 00:40:24.110
but there's still plenty
of them that are out there.

833
00:40:24.110 --> 00:40:26.070
They're, once they're deployed it costs so

834
00:40:26.070 --> 00:40:28.690
much money to move away from
them that they stick around.

835
00:40:28.690 --> 00:40:30.410
So you may encounter that.

836
00:40:30.410 --> 00:40:33.150
It's rare that we're gonna deploy
this just on our own, right?

837
00:40:33.150 --> 00:40:35.390
It's normally gonna be done in
association with a vendor and

838
00:40:35.390 --> 00:40:37.250
it'll be part of their
installation services.

839
00:40:37.250 --> 00:40:38.650
So we just need to maintain it.

840
00:40:38.650 --> 00:40:41.510
things like ensuring that the pumps
are flowing, ensuring that our

841
00:40:41.510 --> 00:40:44.580
temperatures are maintained and
that everything is running normal.

842
00:40:44.580 --> 00:40:46.970
You might have to treat
the liquid from time to time.

843
00:40:46.970 --> 00:40:49.840
There's usually an anti-algae
agent that you have to add.

844
00:40:49.840 --> 00:40:53.200
And then you have to filter the water in
case particulate matter gets inside of

845
00:40:53.200 --> 00:40:54.960
there, because you don't
want a tube to get clogged.

846
00:40:54.960 --> 00:40:56.860
And so you have to do some maintenance and
cleaning there.

847
00:40:56.860 --> 00:40:59.510
It all be part of the installation
process where they teach and

848
00:40:59.510 --> 00:41:00.790
train on how to manage that.

849
00:41:00.790 --> 00:41:03.650
But for
most of us its not going to be an issue.

850
00:41:03.650 --> 00:41:06.520
But it is something that's out there and
call it out on the exam objective so

851
00:41:06.520 --> 00:41:07.880
I wanted to mention it here.

852
00:41:07.880 --> 00:41:11.260
>> Don a lot of great information when it
comes to providing power to our devices.

853
00:41:11.260 --> 00:41:13.140
I know theres a lot of things to consider.

854
00:41:13.140 --> 00:41:17.020
Definitely if for any reason if you
feel uncomfortable dealing with

855
00:41:17.020 --> 00:41:19.880
electricity you do what I do,
you let the professionals handle it.

856
00:41:19.880 --> 00:41:23.320
I know enough about electricity and
myself to stay away from it.

857
00:41:23.320 --> 00:41:26.530
And now judging by that clock, it does
look like we are running to the end of yet

858
00:41:26.530 --> 00:41:27.670
another great episode Don.

859
00:41:27.670 --> 00:41:30.290
But before we do, do you have any
additional words that you'd like to tell

860
00:41:30.290 --> 00:41:34.330
our viewers when it comes too providing
power or even cooling to your devices?

861
00:41:35.380 --> 00:41:36.570
>> Safety first, right.

862
00:41:36.570 --> 00:41:38.520
Some of this stuff is really dangerous.

863
00:41:38.520 --> 00:41:41.390
And even if it doesn't hurt you,
you can hurt the equipment, and

864
00:41:41.390 --> 00:41:42.680
the equipment cost a lot of money.

865
00:41:42.680 --> 00:41:44.980
So you're gonna need to
call in an electrician.

866
00:41:44.980 --> 00:41:48.110
Most data centers have at least
one facilities person who is

867
00:41:48.110 --> 00:41:51.110
typically either a union or
licenced electrician.

868
00:41:51.110 --> 00:41:52.230
Rely on them.

869
00:41:52.230 --> 00:41:54.880
They might not know the first
thing about database servers, but

870
00:41:54.880 --> 00:41:57.970
they know a lot about electricity and
they know how to not die,

871
00:41:57.970 --> 00:41:59.440
and that's kind of the key piece there.

872
00:41:59.440 --> 00:42:02.230
So safety first when it comes
to working with electricity.

873
00:42:02.230 --> 00:42:04.750
>> Words of wisdom from Don, do not die.

874
00:42:04.750 --> 00:42:07.740
Well Don we appreciate all your
valuable information here, and

875
00:42:07.740 --> 00:42:10.040
as always we appreciate
you the viewer watching.

876
00:42:10.040 --> 00:42:12.960
Signing out for
IT Pro TV I've been your host Wes Brian.

877
00:42:12.960 --> 00:42:13.690
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

878
00:42:13.690 --> 00:42:15.915
>> And we'll see you next time.

879
00:42:15.915 --> 00:42:21.976
[MUSIC]

880
00:42:21.976 --> 00:42:29.219
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don examine preparing a server for operating system installation. They discuss determining server roles, firmware updates, BIOS/UEFI configuration and boot order with a demonstration in a BIOS configuration interface.
episodes.title: Installing a Server OS
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:03.526
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.526 --> 00:00:06.474
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.474 --> 00:00:08.297
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.297 --> 00:00:12.120
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.120 --> 00:00:14.590
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:14.590 --> 00:00:16.350
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:16.350 --> 00:00:20.834
And in today's episode, we're continuing
through our series within CompTIA Server+.

8
00:00:20.834 --> 00:00:25.289
And joining us back in the studios is none
other than our residential server guru

9
00:00:25.289 --> 00:00:27.360
with a Kungfu grip, Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:27.360 --> 00:00:28.390
Don, how are you doing sir?

11
00:00:28.390 --> 00:00:28.909
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

12
00:00:28.909 --> 00:00:29.918
Ready to dive right back in.

13
00:00:29.918 --> 00:00:34.144
And in this episode, we're gonna be taking
a look at all the stuff we have to think

14
00:00:34.144 --> 00:00:36.810
about when we install
a server operating system.

15
00:00:36.810 --> 00:00:39.320
Cuz there's a lot that's
involved in that process,

16
00:00:39.320 --> 00:00:44.150
and most of you have probably already
experienced this a number of times of

17
00:00:44.150 --> 00:00:45.850
various operating systems
that are out there.

18
00:00:45.850 --> 00:00:48.440
Maybe some of you have only really
experienced this with desktop operating

19
00:00:48.440 --> 00:00:51.240
systems, this is your
first exposure to it.

20
00:00:51.240 --> 00:00:54.390
A lot of us get in the habit of learning
how to do installations through

21
00:00:54.390 --> 00:00:55.650
virtual machines.

22
00:00:55.650 --> 00:00:59.950
And what you'll find is that when you get
to a real life honest-to-goodness server,

23
00:00:59.950 --> 00:01:01.790
the installation process
is a good bit different.

24
00:01:01.790 --> 00:01:05.050
Things don't quite line up
the way that we expect them to

25
00:01:05.050 --> 00:01:06.710
from desktop type experience.

26
00:01:06.710 --> 00:01:11.675
So understanding how to properly install
a server OS is an important thing to know.

27
00:01:11.675 --> 00:01:15.738
Now, I'm gonna try and
stay kind of OS neutral on this.

28
00:01:15.738 --> 00:01:19.580
Because the reality is these days, there's
more Linux servers out there than Windows

29
00:01:19.580 --> 00:01:24.200
servers, even though there's more Windows
workstations than Linux by a huge margin.

30
00:01:24.200 --> 00:01:25.992
But Linux servers are very, very common.

31
00:01:25.992 --> 00:01:31.090
And since what we usually see deployed on
the exam, they kinda focus on Windows.

32
00:01:31.090 --> 00:01:35.320
And so I wanna make sure that I cover
everything from the aspect of both.

33
00:01:35.320 --> 00:01:37.010
At this stage, at least in this episode,

34
00:01:37.010 --> 00:01:39.870
I'm gonna be focusing more on hardware
than software, so it's identical.

35
00:01:39.870 --> 00:01:43.095
It's identical for Windows and Linux when
you're dealing with the hardware where

36
00:01:43.095 --> 00:01:46.055
things will change as when we actually
get to more of the software concerns.

37
00:01:46.055 --> 00:01:48.410
>> Don, I got a question for
you that's maybe not on the exam.

38
00:01:48.410 --> 00:01:51.230
But in your experience,
would you say that there's more Linux

39
00:01:51.230 --> 00:01:55.069
servers today because of open source or
stability or maybe even both?

40
00:01:56.330 --> 00:01:59.653
>> It's hard to attribute what
it actually is caused by,

41
00:01:59.653 --> 00:02:03.919
I think mostly it's because these
software development projects for

42
00:02:03.919 --> 00:02:07.406
all the scalable web apps has
really happened on Apache.

43
00:02:07.406 --> 00:02:11.424
It's really happened on that platform,
it was designed in a Linux and

44
00:02:11.424 --> 00:02:12.592
Unix environment.

45
00:02:12.592 --> 00:02:13.933
Not designed in a Windows environment, and

46
00:02:13.933 --> 00:02:16.395
you'll get the same performance
out of it in Windows.

47
00:02:16.395 --> 00:02:19.830
But being a more expensive
operating system, developers,

48
00:02:19.830 --> 00:02:22.290
at least amateur developers,
aren't as likely to work on it.

49
00:02:22.290 --> 00:02:25.760
So you get a little less development
effort, so that's more than likely a tie.

50
00:02:25.760 --> 00:02:28.900
But the reality is at the end of the day,
they're both very stable platforms.

51
00:02:28.900 --> 00:02:32.768
And then if I needed to bring up a web
server, I could bring up a Red Hat,

52
00:02:32.768 --> 00:02:34.615
Ubuntu, or Windows web server.

53
00:02:34.615 --> 00:02:37.020
I know they're all gonna run really well.

54
00:02:37.020 --> 00:02:39.596
And then they've all got vendor
support from me to make sure that

55
00:02:39.596 --> 00:02:41.610
I keep them updated, and
patched, and secured.

56
00:02:41.610 --> 00:02:44.730
So that kind of stuff is not
something I have to worry about.

57
00:02:44.730 --> 00:02:50.910
Except, before I even start installing
an operating system on my server,

58
00:02:50.910 --> 00:02:56.060
I need to make sure that whoever made my
server supports that operating system.

59
00:02:56.060 --> 00:02:59.454
Because the vendors, we talked about this
a bit when we're talking about sever

60
00:02:59.454 --> 00:03:02.495
components in our previous episode
where I said that they don't follow

61
00:03:02.495 --> 00:03:04.287
a lot of standards when they make severs.

62
00:03:04.287 --> 00:03:08.860
These aren't standard ATX motherboards and
they can change the arrangements of stuff

63
00:03:08.860 --> 00:03:12.115
that they make proprietary RAID
controllers and chipsets and

64
00:03:12.115 --> 00:03:13.131
all these things.

65
00:03:13.131 --> 00:03:17.345
So when you install an operating system,
you need drivers, right?

66
00:03:17.345 --> 00:03:20.190
Any drivers to support
the operating system.

67
00:03:20.190 --> 00:03:25.090
And in the Windows world, there's
just Microsoft Windows and that's it,

68
00:03:25.090 --> 00:03:28.280
and so all the vendors make drivers for
Microsoft Windows.

69
00:03:28.280 --> 00:03:31.960
But in the Linux world,
there's not just one Linux,

70
00:03:31.960 --> 00:03:33.930
there's several distributions
that are out there.

71
00:03:33.930 --> 00:03:34.763
Some are based on other ones, right?

72
00:03:34.763 --> 00:03:37.480
So, Ubuntu is based off of Debian.

73
00:03:37.480 --> 00:03:39.280
So if you have a driver that works for
Debian,

74
00:03:39.280 --> 00:03:41.780
the driver will work in Ubuntu for
the most part.

75
00:03:41.780 --> 00:03:45.514
If you have Red Hat, CentOs,
Fedora, those guys all share.

76
00:03:45.514 --> 00:03:48.142
Oracle Linux goes in there
also where they all share, and

77
00:03:48.142 --> 00:03:50.130
you can share a common driver.

78
00:03:50.130 --> 00:03:54.300
But if you're running Ubuntu and

79
00:03:54.300 --> 00:03:59.170
you buy a Dell server, and Dell is
only putting out drivers for Red Hat,

80
00:03:59.170 --> 00:04:01.080
you might not be able to run
Ubuntu on that hardware.

81
00:04:01.080 --> 00:04:04.010
You might run into hardware
incompatibility issues where

82
00:04:04.010 --> 00:04:06.520
your operating system is not able to
take advantage of the hardware, and

83
00:04:06.520 --> 00:04:08.160
server hardware is expensive.

84
00:04:08.160 --> 00:04:10.820
So you wanna make sure that you
can take advantage of every single

85
00:04:10.820 --> 00:04:13.560
aspect of what it is,
cuz you paid for it, right?

86
00:04:13.560 --> 00:04:16.150
So always make sure that
your vendor supports.

87
00:04:16.150 --> 00:04:20.220
And that's really the first step
of getting a new server installed

88
00:04:20.220 --> 00:04:23.720
is before you even touch the hardware is
you need to go to the vendor's website for

89
00:04:23.720 --> 00:04:24.910
that server.

90
00:04:24.910 --> 00:04:28.212
And you need to download all
the drivers that are available,

91
00:04:28.212 --> 00:04:31.657
you need to download any firmware
updates that are available.

92
00:04:31.657 --> 00:04:34.996
Cuz often times, there's gonna be firmware
updates that need to be done, and

93
00:04:34.996 --> 00:04:36.882
we need to get those loaded and
put in place.

94
00:04:36.882 --> 00:04:38.526
Now, when I talk about drivers,

95
00:04:38.526 --> 00:04:41.770
there's standard hardware that's
gonna be included, right?

96
00:04:41.770 --> 00:04:45.189
There's a video card, there's gonna
be network adapters and so on.

97
00:04:45.189 --> 00:04:49.433
But we've gotta think about the role
that server is gonna be performing,

98
00:04:49.433 --> 00:04:52.440
because that may change the hardware also.

99
00:04:52.440 --> 00:04:55.490
For example,
I used to support some fax servers.

100
00:04:55.490 --> 00:04:57.566
I know,
fax is a little outdated these days, but

101
00:04:57.566 --> 00:05:00.924
we had these cards that had 16 phone lines
in them that would go in the server.

102
00:05:00.924 --> 00:05:05.193
Well, that was special hardware, I had
to make sure I had the slots to support

103
00:05:05.193 --> 00:05:09.550
that hardware, because I believe they're
PCI-X cards if I remember right.

104
00:05:09.550 --> 00:05:13.226
So I had the PCI-X slots inside of
the server to be able to support it, and

105
00:05:13.226 --> 00:05:16.781
then I had to have the drivers to be
able to recognize that hardware in my

106
00:05:16.781 --> 00:05:18.180
operating systems.

107
00:05:18.180 --> 00:05:20.056
So I had to gather that
information together, and

108
00:05:20.056 --> 00:05:21.627
it varied based on the role of the server.

109
00:05:21.627 --> 00:05:25.200
If it's a typical web server,
there's probably not a whole lot you need.

110
00:05:25.200 --> 00:05:27.080
But if it's gonna be a final server,

111
00:05:27.080 --> 00:05:29.680
you're probably gonna have
extra hard drives in there.

112
00:05:29.680 --> 00:05:32.143
You're going to have a RAID
controller in there.

113
00:05:32.143 --> 00:05:35.080
I mean, you think about what that
RAID configuration is gonna be like.

114
00:05:35.080 --> 00:05:38.648
If it's connected to a SAN, you're
probably gonna need a Fibre Channel or

115
00:05:38.648 --> 00:05:41.039
HBA, a Host Bus Adapter,
to connect to that SAN.

116
00:05:41.039 --> 00:05:45.239
And if you're gonna be doing boot from SAN
where you don't even have the hard drives

117
00:05:45.239 --> 00:05:46.319
in the server at all.

118
00:05:46.319 --> 00:05:49.315
When the server boots up,
it looks at that HBA, it sees the SAN and

119
00:05:49.315 --> 00:05:53.180
it boots from an operating system
disk that's out there on the SAN.

120
00:05:53.180 --> 00:05:56.940
Well, you need server hardware
that can support that, right?

121
00:05:56.940 --> 00:05:58.795
And that's a really cool set up too,
a lot of people do that.

122
00:05:58.795 --> 00:06:00.500
Because if you have
a failure on the server,

123
00:06:00.500 --> 00:06:02.600
you can just swap the whole server out.

124
00:06:02.600 --> 00:06:05.360
Because the operating system,
the data files, all that's on the SAN.

125
00:06:05.360 --> 00:06:09.134
So you could replace an entire server very
quickly, very easily and be back up and

126
00:06:09.134 --> 00:06:10.530
running in no time.

127
00:06:10.530 --> 00:06:16.020
So understanding the role that your server
is gonna be performing and understanding

128
00:06:16.020 --> 00:06:18.550
the limitations of your operating system,
that's gonna be important.

129
00:06:18.550 --> 00:06:20.510
We need to go to our vendors and
find that out.

130
00:06:20.510 --> 00:06:25.868
Now, the server that I've been
using in this show is a HP server.

131
00:06:25.868 --> 00:06:28.764
And with HP,
usually when you buy one of their servers,

132
00:06:28.764 --> 00:06:32.580
they come with a CD that has an HP smart
pack on it that has a ton of drivers and

133
00:06:32.580 --> 00:06:34.819
all that stuff is just
build right into it.

134
00:06:35.910 --> 00:06:41.580
Other vendors like Dell, they'll usually
package in a disk also that has drivers,

135
00:06:41.580 --> 00:06:46.390
but those disks are typically out
of date by the time you get them.

136
00:06:46.390 --> 00:06:48.450
So I don't like to rely on those.

137
00:06:48.450 --> 00:06:50.215
Before I start working with a new server,

138
00:06:50.215 --> 00:06:53.507
I'll typically go to that vendor's
website like I'm on Dell's site here.

139
00:06:53.507 --> 00:07:00.400
And you can come in and find your server
and download the drivers and so on.

140
00:07:00.400 --> 00:07:03.070
It's also a great way to come in and
find out, whether or not,

141
00:07:03.070 --> 00:07:05.960
you've got an operating
system that's supported.

142
00:07:05.960 --> 00:07:11.009
So I'm just gonna pull up,
I'll do an R9, we'll do an R920.

143
00:07:11.009 --> 00:07:14.120
All right, so
I'm puling up a PowerEdge R920 here.

144
00:07:14.120 --> 00:07:17.570
And when I go to look at it, I've got
my drivers and downloads and manuals.

145
00:07:17.570 --> 00:07:20.542
And in the manuals, you'll find out
what operating systems are supported and

146
00:07:20.542 --> 00:07:22.400
what other features
are supported inside of it.

147
00:07:22.400 --> 00:07:25.040
You should have looked at that
before purchasing the server, but

148
00:07:25.040 --> 00:07:26.960
we don't always have that advantage,
right?

149
00:07:26.960 --> 00:07:29.520
You go to work somewhere,
they've already got a few hundred servers,

150
00:07:29.520 --> 00:07:31.664
you weren't involved in that
decision-making process.

151
00:07:31.664 --> 00:07:35.880
But when I come in here, notice how this
R920 defaulted to Windows Server 2008 R2.

152
00:07:35.880 --> 00:07:38.516
That means that when this
server was purchased,

153
00:07:38.516 --> 00:07:41.485
that was the operating system
they were selling on it.

154

the containers, you need to think about
the file system you're gonna use.

530
00:25:29.300 --> 00:25:33.000
And say, all right, if I'm running NTFS,
I can make these pretty big, or

531
00:25:33.000 --> 00:25:36.000
in the Linux world Hey if I'm using ZFS,
right.

532
00:25:36.000 --> 00:25:38.910
ZFS, a lot of distributions
have switched to that,

533
00:25:38.910 --> 00:25:40.880
it can handle some pretty big stuff.

534
00:25:40.880 --> 00:25:44.280
In the Red Hat world, you don't
have official support for ZFS yet.

535
00:25:44.280 --> 00:25:49.090
They're moving towards BTRFS, but
that's not fully authorized yet.

536
00:25:49.090 --> 00:25:52.160
So they're normally doing EXT4, right.

537
00:25:52.160 --> 00:25:56.440
EXT2, 3, and 4, they support
some really big partitions too,

538
00:25:56.440 --> 00:25:58.520
not a whole lot of concerns there.

539
00:25:58.520 --> 00:26:01.860
If you're on EXD2, you really
should be moving to EXD3 anyway.

540
00:26:01.860 --> 00:26:06.170
But if you're running something like UFS,
the old Unix file system, well,

541
00:26:06.170 --> 00:26:10.780
most Linux issue support UFS and
UFS does not like huge volumes.

542
00:26:10.780 --> 00:26:13.800
So make sure you look up what file
system you're gonna be running and

543
00:26:13.800 --> 00:26:16.600
make sure you create containers
that match that size,

544
00:26:16.600 --> 00:26:18.780
otherwise you might exceed
what it can handle.

545
00:26:20.750 --> 00:26:23.530
CompTIA calls out a few other
file systems to be familiar with.

546
00:26:23.530 --> 00:26:25.330
So let me just hit these for completeness.

547
00:26:25.330 --> 00:26:31.380
They call it ReiserFS, nobody really uses
ReiserFS anymore, that project's died off.

548
00:26:31.380 --> 00:26:33.600
It was really known for
the fact that it had journaling.

549
00:26:33.600 --> 00:26:35.800
It was one of the first file
systems to have journaling.

550
00:26:35.800 --> 00:26:37.440
So that you don't write.

551
00:26:37.440 --> 00:26:39.950
When you change a file,
you don't actually change that file.

552
00:26:39.950 --> 00:26:43.710
You change something in a journal,
in a log somewhere else.

553
00:26:43.710 --> 00:26:46.680
And only when you're completely
done writing that change

554
00:26:46.680 --> 00:26:48.390
is it then applied to the actual file.

555
00:26:48.390 --> 00:26:52.460
So if there's a power outage while you're
writing, the original file stays intact,

556
00:26:52.460 --> 00:26:53.030
it doesn't get damaged.

557
00:26:53.030 --> 00:26:54.390
It's a great feature.

558
00:26:54.390 --> 00:26:56.400
Well, then move that
into other file systems.

559
00:26:56.400 --> 00:26:59.820
So if you have EXT3 and EXT4,
they do journaling now.

560
00:26:59.820 --> 00:27:03.980
So in the Linux world, ReiserFS
kinda came and went pretty quickly.

561
00:27:03.980 --> 00:27:09.190
BTRFS also has it built in, and
that's the one people are moving to.

562
00:27:09.190 --> 00:27:10.050
UFS I already mentioned.

563
00:27:10.050 --> 00:27:11.680
Most people don't run UFS anymore.

564
00:27:11.680 --> 00:27:14.890
And then VMFS,
which is the VMWare file system.

565
00:27:14.890 --> 00:27:18.990
So if you have ESXI servers,
they create VMFS partitions.

566
00:27:18.990 --> 00:27:23.630
And if you check VMWare's documentation
with each version of ESXI, they change

567
00:27:23.630 --> 00:27:27.510
the limitations of how large a volume and
how large a container it can recognize.

568
00:27:27.510 --> 00:27:30.380
So make sure that you're following
the compatibility settings for

569
00:27:30.380 --> 00:27:34.540
the file system you're gonna be using.

570
00:27:34.540 --> 00:27:37.490
Let's see,
the other thing worth mentioning here

571
00:27:37.490 --> 00:27:39.000
is if I'm dealing with a swap file.

572
00:27:40.080 --> 00:27:42.480
Most servers these days come with so

573
00:27:42.480 --> 00:27:46.660
much memory that we don't really
leverage a swap file anymore.

574
00:27:46.660 --> 00:27:49.930
But, if you do, if you're leveraging that,
if you have a low memory server and

575
00:27:49.930 --> 00:27:54.660
you need to be able to page to a disc
in case you run out of RAM, then

576
00:27:54.660 --> 00:27:59.530
be aware that page files don't
really like to be on parodied disks.

577
00:27:59.530 --> 00:28:02.280
So things like RAID 5 or RAID 50.

578
00:28:02.280 --> 00:28:05.300
Page files really don't play nice with
that because they're constantly changing

579
00:28:05.300 --> 00:28:07.090
and parodies constantly
being recalculated.

580
00:28:07.090 --> 00:28:08.720
It kind of puts a burden on the system.

581
00:28:08.720 --> 00:28:12.960
So, if you get a page file they always
play a lot more nicely on a mirror

582
00:28:12.960 --> 00:28:14.870
because they can write a lot
faster to a mirror and

583
00:28:14.870 --> 00:28:16.580
they can be read from
a lot faster on a mirror.

584
00:28:16.580 --> 00:28:21.180
So the mirrors are gonna work out
a little bit better or Raid 0 even.

585
00:28:21.180 --> 00:28:22.150
RAID 0's nice.

586
00:28:22.150 --> 00:28:24.280
If you lose a disk,
you lose the whole array.

587
00:28:24.280 --> 00:28:26.050
But it's just the page file,
it's stuff that was in RAM.

588
00:28:26.050 --> 00:28:29.970
So it's not like you lost data that
was written to the disk already.

589
00:28:29.970 --> 00:28:31.920
If you've got transactions
you're working on in RAM,

590
00:28:31.920 --> 00:28:34.780
like in a database, it'll roll
those back after you come back up.

591
00:28:34.780 --> 00:28:36.930
That's where journaling comes in,
or transaction logs.

592
00:28:36.930 --> 00:28:39.060
So you're kinda protected on that.

593
00:28:39.060 --> 00:28:42.650
But just know that swap files typically
you handle a little bit differently,

594
00:28:42.650 --> 00:28:43.610
if you're still using them.

595
00:28:43.610 --> 00:28:45.545
Most of us have kind of stop using them.

596
00:28:45.545 --> 00:28:47.470
They're still there, but
they just don't get touched, so

597
00:28:47.470 --> 00:28:49.764
we don't worry about their performance.

598
00:28:49.764 --> 00:28:52.510
All right,
now when I get into my installer here,

599
00:28:52.510 --> 00:28:55.320
I'm just gonna walk through a little
bit of this here in Windows.

600
00:28:55.320 --> 00:28:59.780
That inside of the installer,
it's gonna offer to install Windows.

601
00:28:59.780 --> 00:29:03.020
And most of the screens we see
are licensing screens like hey,

602
00:29:03.020 --> 00:29:04.310
did you pay us enough money?

603
00:29:04.310 --> 00:29:09.220
And can you completely waive
the right to sue us no matter what?

604
00:29:09.220 --> 00:29:12.160
But the screen that I care about is
gonna come up here in just a moment

605
00:29:12.160 --> 00:29:14.700
where it asks me to configure
my hard drives, right.

606
00:29:14.700 --> 00:29:20.620
And so when I go to configure
the hard drive, I have to tell it

607
00:29:20.620 --> 00:29:25.630
what volumes or partitions I want to
create to be able to support my system.

608
00:29:25.630 --> 00:29:30.080
And so when I come through here,
I see the disk, Disk 0,

609
00:29:30.080 --> 00:29:35.540
unallocated space,
931 GB in size, completely empty.

610
00:29:35.540 --> 00:29:38.870
Okay, now the nice part about this is

611
00:29:38.870 --> 00:29:41.310
I don't know that there's
a RAID controller under there.

612
00:29:41.310 --> 00:29:44.450
I don't know that there's four disks
configured as a RAID 10 array.

613
00:29:44.450 --> 00:29:45.630
I don't know about any of that.

614
00:29:45.630 --> 00:29:48.560
The operating system is unaware.

615
00:29:48.560 --> 00:29:52.820
And it won't be aware until after I'm done
with install and I load drivers in, right?

616
00:29:52.820 --> 00:29:55.730
When we put drivers in, now it'll
be able to see the RAID controller.

617
00:29:55.730 --> 00:29:57.320
And that's important
because we need reporting.

618
00:29:57.320 --> 00:29:58.100
We need to know about it.

619
00:29:58.100 --> 00:29:59.730
And we can adjust the configuration.

620
00:29:59.730 --> 00:30:04.010
But just the base install here, it just
sees it as a disk and I can install on it,

621
00:30:04.010 --> 00:30:04.770
and treat it like normal.

622
00:30:04.770 --> 00:30:06.310
I can create volumes if I want to.

623
00:30:06.310 --> 00:30:11.680
I can do whatever it is that I need when
we get that configured and in place.

624
00:30:11.680 --> 00:30:17.090
However, there are times where you'll get
to this screen and no drives show up.

625
00:30:17.090 --> 00:30:19.020
If no drive shows up,

626
00:30:19.020 --> 00:30:22.460
that means your operating system
doesn't support the Raid controller.

627
00:30:22.460 --> 00:30:24.000
And you're not out of luck.

628
00:30:24.000 --> 00:30:26.610
You just need to load a driver.

629
00:30:26.610 --> 00:30:27.690
I got cool double mouse.

630
00:30:27.690 --> 00:30:29.640
I can do twice as much work
with two mouse pointers.

631
00:30:29.640 --> 00:30:33.010
But [LAUGH] it's the remote
console is cloning my mouse.

632
00:30:33.010 --> 00:30:36.370
But down here at the bottom left,
you'll see Load Driver in

633
00:30:36.370 --> 00:30:42.740
Red Hat Enterprise Linux, in Ubuntu,
in Windows Servers 2008, 2012, 2016.

634
00:30:42.740 --> 00:30:43.820
They all have it.

635
00:30:43.820 --> 00:30:46.260
You can load Raid drivers
during the installation.

636
00:30:46.260 --> 00:30:50.090
And you might need to just to be able to
see the disks that are attached to it.

637
00:30:50.090 --> 00:30:52.460
It's no different than any kind
of custom hard drive controller.

638
00:30:52.460 --> 00:30:54.280
Where you just have to have
drivers to be able to see it, and

639
00:30:54.280 --> 00:30:58.010
once you do, you can choose it,
do the install, and you'll be in business.

640
00:30:58.010 --> 00:31:01.940
So, if your system doesn't see a drive,
go to the vendor's website,

641
00:31:01.940 --> 00:31:04.120
download the driver, put it on a USB key.

642
00:31:04.120 --> 00:31:08.010
Stick it on the server, and then you'll
be able to load that driver, browse,

643
00:31:08.010 --> 00:31:09.410
get it installed, and
you'll be in business.

644
00:31:10.900 --> 00:31:12.050
But for me, the driver shows up.

645
00:31:12.050 --> 00:31:15.840
If you've got a Dell or an HP or
a Lenovo, Microsoft's really good about

646
00:31:15.840 --> 00:31:20.070
supporting their adapters, and
so that's all you really need.

647
00:31:20.070 --> 00:31:21.100
And then your install's gonna go.

648
00:31:21.100 --> 00:31:24.450
And then you'll do all your
customization stuff afterwards.

649
00:31:24.450 --> 00:31:28.490
If you created five or six containers,
at this stage you're normally only

650
00:31:28.490 --> 00:31:31.300
dealing with one of them,
the one where the operating system goes.

651
00:31:31.300 --> 00:31:34.230
And after the operating system is up,
we lower our drivers, and then we

652
00:31:34.230 --> 00:31:37.360
can figure the other drives, and get them
formatted, and all of the stuff set up.

653
00:31:37.360 --> 00:31:40.470
But for right now, this is just
enough to get the OS going, and

654
00:31:40.470 --> 00:31:41.900
then we can tidy up the rest later.

655
00:31:43.150 --> 00:31:45.750
Alright.
Well, Wes, what's gonna come up next is

656
00:31:45.750 --> 00:31:49.577
we're gonna run into the actual kind
of basic configuration of getting

657
00:31:49.577 --> 00:31:54.190
an operating system up going on a network,
but we're way overtime for this episode.

658
00:31:54.190 --> 00:31:56.724
So were save that for the next one and
we'll get in there and

659
00:31:56.724 --> 00:31:58.948
get a chance to see how to
get those configured, and

660
00:31:58.948 --> 00:32:01.940
get our servers closer to
being moved into production.

661
00:32:01.940 --> 00:32:05.070
>> Well, that sounds like a lot of fun and
I look forward to seeing that.

662
00:32:05.070 --> 00:32:08.690
Yeah, that ZFS,
it's an amazing file system and, in fact,

663
00:32:08.690 --> 00:32:10.930
its scalability is just mind boggling.

664
00:32:10.930 --> 00:32:14.210
I mean,
we're talking 256 quadrillion zettabytes.

665
00:32:14.210 --> 00:32:16.110
Kind of give you an idea,
that's 2 to 148th power.

666
00:32:16.110 --> 00:32:19.120
That's the same amount
of IP addresses as IPv6.

667
00:32:19.120 --> 00:32:21.860
>> The biggest challenge
is ZFS Oracle's licensing.

668
00:32:21.860 --> 00:32:25.530
Oracle has a lot of it locked up in weird
licenses, it's not GNU and so that's why

669
00:32:25.530 --> 00:32:28.810
we're seeing resistance otherwise
everybody would be running ZSF right now.

670
00:32:28.810 --> 00:32:29.420
>> Very good.

671
00:32:29.420 --> 00:32:32.170
Well Don, do you have anything else you'd
like to throw on this one before we wrap

672
00:32:32.170 --> 00:32:34.330
this one up and move into our part three?

673
00:32:34.330 --> 00:32:34.970
>> That's about it,

674
00:32:34.970 --> 00:32:37.900
everything we've seen up until now
is pretty much been OS neutral.

675
00:32:37.900 --> 00:32:39.270
Right, I know we use Windows but

676
00:32:39.270 --> 00:32:41.630
it was the same on Linux as
far as what I'm configuring.

677
00:32:41.630 --> 00:32:44.480
What we're gonna go into in the next
part is where we're gonna have

678
00:32:44.480 --> 00:32:45.450
the deviate on the OS's.

679
00:32:45.450 --> 00:32:47.030
So just know up until this point,

680
00:32:47.030 --> 00:32:50.360
everything's pretty much consistent
regardless of what OS you're deploying.

681
00:32:50.360 --> 00:32:51.070
>> All right.
Well, Don,

682
00:32:51.070 --> 00:32:54.300
we appreciate having you here and
we appreciate the viewers watching.

683
00:32:54.300 --> 00:32:57.545
Keep in mind, stick around because we are
going into a part three in installing your

684
00:32:57.545 --> 00:32:59.720
operating system on a server.

685
00:32:59.720 --> 00:33:00.710
Thank you for joining us.

686
00:33:00.710 --> 00:33:02.020
I've been your host Wes Bryant.

687
00:33:02.020 --> 00:33:02.920
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

688
00:33:02.920 --> 00:33:03.770
>> See you next time.

689
00:33:03.770 --> 00:33:11.372
[MUSIC]

690
00:33:11.372 --> 00:33:13.596
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their examination in preparing a server for operating system installation. They demonstrate performing an OS installation on Linux. They talk about installation automation, zero-touch installations, lite-touch installations, PXE, TFTP and more.
episodes.title: Installing a Server OS Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.195
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet-

2
00:00:02.195 --> 00:00:05.887
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.887 --> 00:00:08.255
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.255 --> 00:00:11.635
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.635 --> 00:00:15.375
>> Hello, everyone, and welcome to
another great episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.375 --> 00:00:16.851
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and

7
00:00:16.851 --> 00:00:20.691
in today's episode, we're continuing
through our series in CompTIA Server+.

8
00:00:20.691 --> 00:00:25.911
Joining us back in the studios for a part
three on installing a server is Don Pezet.

9
00:00:25.911 --> 00:00:27.060
Don, how are you doing sir?

10
00:00:27.060 --> 00:00:27.930
>> I'm doing great, Wes,

11
00:00:27.930 --> 00:00:31.690
ready to pick back where I left off and
actually get a server installed.

12
00:00:31.690 --> 00:00:35.210
At the end of the last episode, if you
didn't watch it, we had taken a physical

13
00:00:35.210 --> 00:00:38.960
server and, well, started an operating
system installation on it, right?

14
00:00:38.960 --> 00:00:41.530
We configured our BIOS,
we configured our raid controller,

15
00:00:41.530 --> 00:00:44.810
set up our containers, and
then got to your installation.

16
00:00:44.810 --> 00:00:48.010
Now during that episode I
was using Microsoft Windows.

17
00:00:48.010 --> 00:00:49.460
Now, if you've ever
installed Microsoft Windows,

18
00:00:49.460 --> 00:00:52.530
you know that you basically click
Next three times and it's done.

19
00:00:52.530 --> 00:00:54.900
It's the least exciting
installation ever and

20
00:00:54.900 --> 00:00:56.740
it doesn't give you a whole
heck of a lot of options.

21
00:00:56.740 --> 00:00:59.590
So, what we saw in that episode
really were all the options we had

22
00:00:59.590 --> 00:01:00.780
during the install.

23
00:01:00.780 --> 00:01:05.540
What I wanted to do in this episode
Is kinda switch gears a bit and

24
00:01:05.540 --> 00:01:08.070
go to the installation
using Linux instead.

25
00:01:08.070 --> 00:01:11.829
With Linux it exposes a lot more choices
and options to us that help us to make

26
00:01:11.829 --> 00:01:14.523
sure we get the operating
system deployed properly.

27
00:01:14.523 --> 00:01:18.287
Not that Microsoft doesn't want
you to deploy Windows properly.

28
00:01:18.287 --> 00:01:21.363
The way that Microsoft treats
it is a little bit different.

29
00:01:21.363 --> 00:01:22.213
What they say is,

30
00:01:22.213 --> 00:01:26.360
look, we're just gonna have one
standard install that everybody does.

31
00:01:26.360 --> 00:01:31.460
Once the install is done, then you can
customize it according to your needs

32
00:01:31.460 --> 00:01:35.150
once the server is up and you've got the
full suite of utilities available to you.

33
00:01:35.150 --> 00:01:37.100
On the Linux side,
they go different and they say,

34
00:01:37.100 --> 00:01:40.670
look, we're gonna let you customize
it during the installation.

35
00:01:40.670 --> 00:01:43.520
So that the final product you get
after it's installed is actually

36
00:01:43.520 --> 00:01:45.380
pretty close to ready
to go into production.

37
00:01:45.380 --> 00:01:47.180
So, it's just two different
ways of looking at it, but

38
00:01:47.180 --> 00:01:49.620
it makes the install a little
more exciting on the Linux side.

39
00:01:49.620 --> 00:01:53.090
So, that's what we're gonna
take a look at, right here.

40
00:01:53.090 --> 00:01:57.510
So I've got a Red Hat Linux
install starting up here and RHEL,

41
00:01:57.510 --> 00:02:02.580
Red Hat Enterprise Linux is the basis of
CentOS as well as Fedora, so if you're

42
00:02:02.580 --> 00:02:07.140
doing installs of those, they'll look
the same If you're doing something like

43
00:02:07.140 --> 00:02:12.030
Ubuntu or Debian, they don't look too much
different either during the install phase.

44
00:02:12.030 --> 00:02:14.460
Where things get different
is after they fire up.

45
00:02:14.460 --> 00:02:17.510
But when you start a Linux install, you
usually get a screen like this that'll ask

46
00:02:17.510 --> 00:02:22.930
you if you wanna do the installation or
test the media and do the installation.

47
00:02:22.930 --> 00:02:25.950
Now, What's that test
the media stuff talking about?

48
00:02:25.950 --> 00:02:30.480
When we do an install, we're installing
may be from a USB key, or a CD or DVD,

49
00:02:30.480 --> 00:02:32.230
may be we're installing over the network.

50
00:02:32.230 --> 00:02:35.300
If it's over the network, you can
trust that the data is intact, right,

51
00:02:35.300 --> 00:02:37.070
binary data going over the network.

52
00:02:37.070 --> 00:02:40.260
But if it's a CD, it could get scratched.

53
00:02:40.260 --> 00:02:44.400
If it's a USB key, well,
you can only write to a USB key so

54
00:02:44.400 --> 00:02:46.900
many times and
eventually it starts to wear out

55
00:02:46.900 --> 00:02:49.730
The lifetime of that USB key
can be reaching its end.

56
00:02:49.730 --> 00:02:53.780
If you have a damaged media,
what's gonna happen during your install?

57
00:02:53.780 --> 00:02:56.110
You're gonna get a failure,
hopefully, right?

58
00:02:56.110 --> 00:03:00.350
Worse case scenario, the install goes
fine, but there were corrupted files that

59
00:03:00.350 --> 00:03:03.190
got copied over, and you don't know about
it until the server's in production, and

60
00:03:03.190 --> 00:03:05.110
you start getting random lock-ups and

00:34:55.470 --> 00:35:01.590
So if I create a 16 gig
root partition right here.

and it's asking for

749
00:35:05.240 --> 00:35:08.850
me to pick a device type and

750
00:35:08.850 --> 00:35:13.120

751
00:35:13.120 --> 00:35:14.850
BTFS is not on the exam but

752
00:35:14.850 --> 00:35:19.720
that's a new one that is coming

753
00:35:19.720 --> 00:35:23.540
I shouldn't say it's new cuz it's

754
00:35:23.540 --> 00:35:27.600

755
00:35:27.600 --> 00:35:30.330

756
00:35:30.330 --> 00:35:32.760
But if I stick with standard,

757
00:35:32.760 --> 00:35:34.390

758
00:35:34.390 --> 00:35:37.090
Now choosing your file system is
important cuz you wanna make sure

759
00:35:37.090 --> 00:35:39.080

meets all of your needs.

760
00:35:39.080 --> 00:35:41.480
And so I wanna talk a bit
about each of these, and

761
00:35:41.480 --> 00:35:43.750
we've already talked a little
bit about file systems.

762
00:35:43.750 --> 00:35:47.220
But I know I'm running low on time on this
one, so I think we're probably gonna have

763
00:35:47.220 --> 00:35:49.890
to stop before we can kinda move
forward on the rest of this.

764
00:35:49.890 --> 00:35:53.640
But you'll see that we got a lot of
choices and depending on your distribution

765
00:35:53.640 --> 00:35:55.710
you may have more than I do, or
you may have less than I do.

766
00:35:55.710 --> 00:35:58.680
So it's more of that
decision making process.

767
00:35:58.680 --> 00:36:01.130
>> Well Don, we appreciate you showing us

768
00:36:01.130 --> 00:36:04.390
the first few steps of getting
a Linux server installed.

769
00:36:04.390 --> 00:36:05.760
It's definitely different from Windows.

770
00:36:05.760 --> 00:36:07.920
You got a few more options there,
for sure.

771
00:36:07.920 --> 00:36:09.470
But before we sign out,

772
00:36:09.470 --> 00:36:13.270
Don, do you have any additional words
that you might like to throw in this one?

773
00:36:13.270 --> 00:36:14.830
On this, on the install side,

774
00:36:14.830 --> 00:36:17.600
I can't stress how important it is
to read the vendor documentation.

775
00:36:17.600 --> 00:36:19.390
Because every distro is
a little bit different.

776
00:36:19.390 --> 00:36:24.650
Microsoft Windows, Mac OS, Linux, whatever
it is that you're running on your server

777
00:36:24.650 --> 00:36:26.580
and inside of Linux,
all the different distros,

778
00:36:26.580 --> 00:36:29.660
they all have different requirements and
different features and functionality.

779
00:36:29.660 --> 00:36:31.670
So just make sure you learn
what your distro supports,

780
00:36:31.670 --> 00:36:33.200
that you're taking advantage of it.

781
00:36:33.200 --> 00:36:36.310
>> Well, Don, as always we appreciate
your expertise on this subject.

782
00:36:36.310 --> 00:36:38.320
And we appreciate you,
the viewer, watching.

783
00:36:38.320 --> 00:36:41.330
Signing out for ITProTV,

784

>> And I'm Don Pezet.

11

14

We left off in the last episode where
we were picking a file system for

15
00:00:39.110 --> 00:00:39.740
our installs.

16
00:00:39.740 --> 00:00:40.860
That's where we're gonna pick back up.

17

And Wes reminded me during the break that
I actually already talked about the file

system back in part one and two,

20

you don't worry about it,

23

24
00:01:00.240 --> 00:01:04.320

choose the appropriate file system for

25
00:01:04.320 --> 00:01:05.010

26
00:01:05.010 --> 00:01:05.910
For what it is you're doing.

27
00:01:05.910 --> 00:01:10.020
If you're setting up a database server and
you're gonna have some really large files,

28
00:01:10.020 --> 00:01:12.850
then there's certain file systems
that play nice with that, and

29
00:01:12.850 --> 00:01:14.190
certain ones that don't.

30
00:01:14.190 --> 00:01:16.300

just a bunch of smaller files,

31
00:01:16.300 --> 00:01:17.450
maybe you don't care so much.

32
00:01:17.450 --> 00:01:19.890
Or maybe you need journaling, or whatever.

33
00:01:19.890 --> 00:01:22.990
The features you need are gonna
determine which file system you use.

34
00:01:22.990 --> 00:01:26.290
But also, which distribution you
run is gonna influence that.

35
00:01:26.290 --> 00:01:29.470
So, looking at the Red Hat install
that we started in the last episode,

36
00:01:29.470 --> 00:01:31.980
it's asked me to pick my file system.

37
00:01:31.980 --> 00:01:36.670
So I've got ext2, 3, and 4, which
technically are the same file system,

38
00:01:36.670 --> 00:01:39.230
but with extra features added to each one.

39
00:01:39.230 --> 00:01:41.940
So, it's actually not hard to
convert between those at all.

40
00:01:41.940 --> 00:01:46.380
Well, to go from 2 to 3, or 3 to 4, it's
kind of hard to go from 4 down to 2, but

41
00:01:46.380 --> 00:01:47.950
you can move those.

42
00:01:47.950 --> 00:01:52.400
When we choose xfs though, xfs is its
own file system, it's very different.

43
00:01:52.400 --> 00:01:55.960
And that's actually the default that
Red Hat uses, they recommend that.

44
00:01:55.960 --> 00:01:58.357
If you want BTRFS,
you gotta go a slightly different router.

45
00:01:58.357 --> 00:02:01.987
If you want ZFS, right, ZFS is very
popular because of its performance and

46
00:02:01.987 --> 00:02:05.676
scalability, but because of the Oracle
licensing that's attached to it,

47
00:02:05.676 --> 00:02:07.650
most distributions don't support it.

48
00:02:07.650 --> 00:02:09.835
So, I don't even have
ZFS as an option here.

49
00:02:09.835 --> 00:02:11.138
If I were running Solaris,

50
00:02:11.138 --> 00:02:14.890
it would be the default, so you basically
have those things and influence it.

51
00:02:14.890 --> 00:02:20.526
And then vfat,
that's Microsoft's fat system that we use.

52
00:02:20.526 --> 00:02:24.496
Vfat's tied to xfat, so Microsoft
calls it xfat, and here it's vfat.

53
00:02:24.496 --> 00:02:26.288
But if we wanted to go that route for
compatibility,

54
00:02:26.288 --> 00:02:29.720
you probably wouldn't want to do that on
your Linux box, but you certainly could.

55
00:02:29.720 --> 00:02:32.640
So, you're gonna choose your file system,
make sure you choose appropriately here,

56
00:02:32.640 --> 00:02:34.360
because it is hard to change later.

57
00:02:35.680 --> 00:02:40.130
All right, now, for me, I'm actually

And I needed to define

In Windows, swap is just a file

70
00:03:17.200 --> 00:03:18.990
You have, what's it called?

71
00:03:18.990 --> 00:03:20.870
It's swapfile.sys?

72
00:03:20.870 --> 00:03:23.350
Do you remember the swap
file name in Windows, Wes?

73

>> Gosh, yeah, page.

74
00:03:24.400 --> 00:03:25.590
It's pagefile.
>> Pagefile.

75

>> Pagefile, yeah .sys.

76
00:03:27.370 --> 00:03:27.870
>> There we go.
So,

00:03:27.870 --> 00:03:29.950
it's just a file right there

Well, you know what?

and then going through

00:04:07.770 --> 00:04:10.170

All right, then we got network and

00:04:12.150 --> 00:04:14.750
Now, network and host name is where we
kinda start getting the things that

00:04:14.750 --> 00:04:16.300
are post installation, right?

97
00:04:16.300 --> 00:04:17.940
Stuff we would do after the fact.

98
00:04:17.940 --> 00:04:20.750
Remember, I tried to turn on my
time server in the last episode,

00:04:20.750 --> 00:04:23.300

00:04:23.300 --> 00:04:25.530

00:04:27.510 --> 00:04:31.100
Now, I can configure it after I boot, but

00:04:31.100 --> 00:04:36.040
if I'm doing just a non GUI install.

00:04:36.040 --> 00:04:37.770
It's not the easiest thing to configure.

105
00:04:37.770 --> 00:04:40.380
I gotta go edit a few files to

00:04:40.380 --> 00:04:44.070
So, configuring the network adapter now

107
00:04:44.070 --> 00:04:45.420
because I can do it here with the GUI.

I can set IP Addresses.

00:04:48.210 --> 00:04:52.734
And we can override that,

00:04:52.734 --> 00:04:56.309
if we need to,

00:04:56.309 --> 00:05:01.135
We can enable IPv6, whatever it is that

00:05:01.135 --> 00:05:03.840
802.1x security if we're using that
on the network we can configure it

00:05:03.840 --> 00:05:04.440
all right here.

114
00:05:06.449 --> 00:05:09.430
You can also set your host name, another
thing that can be overwritten later.

115
00:05:09.430 --> 00:05:11.990
But if you know the host name of your
server, you can define it here, so

116
00:05:11.990 --> 00:05:18.400
maybe this is mailserv1.lab.itpro.tv,

00:05:18.400 --> 00:05:21.500
You can punch in that name to

118
00:05:21.500 --> 00:05:23.960
On Windows, it just automatically
generates a fake name, and

119
00:05:23.960 --> 00:05:25.120
then you can change it.

120
00:05:25.120 --> 00:05:27.963
Here in Linux,
it's local host is what they set it to.

121
00:05:30.106 --> 00:05:33.040
And then lastly,
this one is a kernel dump, KDUMP.

122
00:05:33.040 --> 00:05:36.320
And I can choose to enable KDUMP,
or I can turn it off.

123
00:05:36.320 --> 00:05:39.410
Basically, when your system crashes,
if you ever have a segment fault or

124
00:05:39.410 --> 00:05:41.670
something like that,
a system crashes and reboots,

125
00:05:41.670 --> 00:05:45.910
it can take the kernel memory that was in
place at that time and dump it to a file.

126
00:05:45.910 --> 00:05:49.040
If you have a staff of developers or

127
00:05:49.040 --> 00:05:52.290

128
00:05:52.290 --> 00:05:53.575
That's pretty useful.

129
00:05:53.575 --> 00:05:58.670
But if I've got 1,000 web servers that are

00:05:58.670 --> 00:06:00.840
I'll probably don't care

131
00:06:00.840 --> 00:06:04.130
I'll probably just throw it out and bring

132
00:06:04.130 --> 00:06:05.870
we might choose to turn that off.

00:06:05.870 --> 00:06:10.330
It does consume some hard drive space and
a little bit of CPU and memory to keep

00:06:10.330 --> 00:06:14.000
that service up and running,
some people kill it off for performance.

135
00:06:14.000 --> 00:06:15.570
Usually I leave it on, just in case.

136
00:06:17.590 --> 00:06:21.270

important Begin Installation button,

137
00:06:21.270 --> 00:06:23.130
and it's gonna start the install.

138
00:06:23.130 --> 00:06:26.630
And just like we saw on Windows, it's
gonna turn through copying all the files

139
00:06:26.630 --> 00:06:29.690
over, and getting all that stuff
kinda done and taken care of.

140
00:06:29.690 --> 00:06:32.870
And when I do it at the beginning,
it's gonna go.

141
00:06:32.870 --> 00:06:36.870
Now, during an install, normally we're
just sitting here watching the bar

142
00:06:36.870 --> 00:06:40.580
slowly crawl across the screen,
but Red Hat does something neat.

143
00:06:40.580 --> 00:06:45.230
They let us start to perform post
installation tasks right now.

144
00:06:46.350 --> 00:06:48.040
When a server is first installed,

145
00:06:48.040 --> 00:06:50.610
there's several steps that we
want to take to get it ready.

146
00:06:50.610 --> 00:06:52.250
And they're the post-installation steps.

147
00:06:52.250 --> 00:06:55.010
One of them is we need
to create a custom user.

148
00:06:55.010 --> 00:06:57.500
In Windows, you have a default
user called administrator.

149
00:06:57.500 --> 00:07:00.000
In Linux,
you have a default user called root.

150
00:07:00.000 --> 00:07:02.030
Well, attackers know that.

151
00:07:02.030 --> 00:07:03.370
If somebody wants to
hack into your system,

152
00:07:03.370 --> 00:07:06.420
they'll assume that you have a route or
an administrator account.

153
00:07:06.420 --> 00:07:10.100
So, it makes sense that we should
create our own account, and

154
00:07:10.100 --> 00:07:13.280
not allow remote access
to the default account.

155
00:07:13.280 --> 00:07:15.290
In Windows, you can disable
the administrator account, so

156
00:07:15.290 --> 00:07:16.660
it doesn't even work anymore.

157
00:07:16.660 --> 00:07:20.070
In Linux, you can take the root account
and say yeah, it works locally, but

158
00:07:20.070 --> 00:07:24.000
I won't allow remote connections to
authenticate its root, effectively making

159
00:07:24.000 --> 00:07:27.270
an attacker have to be at the machine
to exploit the root account.

160
00:07:27.270 --> 00:07:28.740
Which, if they're at the machine,

161
00:07:28.740 --> 00:07:31.400
you've got bigger problems
than your root account.

162
00:07:31.400 --> 00:07:33.020
So, we can start to do that right here.

163
00:07:33.020 --> 00:07:34.320
We can change the root password.

164
00:07:34.320 --> 00:07:35.320
So I'll come in and

165
00:07:35.320 --> 00:07:40.420
punch in some ultra-secure password
that it's gonna tell me it's too weak.

166
00:07:40.420 --> 00:07:42.740
I'm just doing the word password,
we're not going high security today.

167
00:07:42.740 --> 00:07:45.000
But I can come in and punch that,
I can create a user account for

168
00:07:45.000 --> 00:07:47.430
myself if I want, so
it's gonna let me create one.

169
00:07:47.430 --> 00:07:50.506
I can make myself
an administrator if I need to be.

170
00:07:50.506 --> 00:07:54.853
We can determine what our password will
be, and we can get that one set, and

171
00:07:54.853 --> 00:07:58.855
so those steps that I would normally
take afterwards Are now done, so

172
00:07:58.855 --> 00:08:01.753
it gives me a little something
to do while I wait for

173
00:08:01.753 --> 00:08:04.830
this little bar to crawl
across the screen.

174
00:08:04.830 --> 00:08:10.730
I chose a minimal install so it's just
doing 328 packages, and it's almost done.

175
00:08:10.730 --> 00:08:15.500
If I was doing a GUI install it's over
2,000 packages that it has to install.

176
00:08:15.500 --> 00:08:18.317
It's a huge amount of software to
support that graphical user interface.

177
00:08:18.317 --> 00:08:20.860
That's why servers don't
normally run in GUI.

178
00:08:20.860 --> 00:08:25.139
It's all about minimizing your footprint.

179
00:08:25.139 --> 00:08:28.335
All right, now when that's done, it's
gonna boot up and my system's ready to go.

180
00:08:28.335 --> 00:08:31.520
I've got a Red Hat system that is up and
configured.

181
00:08:31.520 --> 00:08:35.400
I might need to tweak it a little more but
the basic configuration is done.

182
00:08:35.400 --> 00:08:37.210
I've mentioned Windows a few times and
