00:19:41.470 --> 00:19:43.350
I don't think I've ever even launched it.

411
00:19:43.350 --> 00:19:45.550
But I don't worry about that,
it's my work station.

412
00:19:45.550 --> 00:19:50.460
But on a server, I wanna have the minimal
set of software needed for it

413
00:19:50.460 --> 00:19:54.620
to do its job cuz I don't wanna waste time
updating software that's not being used.

414
00:19:54.620 --> 00:19:58.100
I don't wanna have to reboot my
server to apply an update for

415
00:19:58.100 --> 00:20:01.160
software that I'm not even using, that's
just creating downtime for no reason.

416
00:20:01.160 --> 00:20:02.980
So get all that stuff off of there.

417
00:20:02.980 --> 00:20:07.320
If you don't know what's safe to remove,
go to the vendor websites, Microsoft,

418
00:20:07.320 --> 00:20:11.150
Red Hat, Canonical all those
guys put out hardening guides.

419
00:20:11.150 --> 00:20:15.010
You can actually go and download they have
a PDF that gives all sorts of steps and

420
00:20:15.010 --> 00:20:19.260
instructions on how you can harden
that server and disable features.

421
00:20:19.260 --> 00:20:23.230
Any services you're not using, they
really do a good job of detailing that.

422
00:20:23.230 --> 00:20:25.600
But it's different for
every distro and different for

423
00:20:25.600 --> 00:20:27.840
every way that you're
gonna use the server.

424
00:20:27.840 --> 00:20:30.233
So you've always gotta make sure
you take that into account.

425
00:20:31.492 --> 00:20:33.736
All right, the last thing that I have,

426
00:20:33.736 --> 00:20:39.410
which I think the think the last thing
that I've got is performance optimization.

427
00:20:39.410 --> 00:20:44.170
On the performance side, when you do that
default install, the server might not be

428
00:20:44.170 --> 00:20:48.050
running at peak performance, and there's
a few things that we need to tweak.

429
00:20:48.050 --> 00:20:51.990
There's things like, well,
in Windows, the page file, right?

430
00:20:51.990 --> 00:20:56.770
Under Linux, I created the swap
partition during the install.

431
00:20:56.770 --> 00:20:57.870
But on Windows, I didn't.

432
00:20:57.870 --> 00:20:59.220
On Windows, here, let me get to it.

433
00:20:59.220 --> 00:21:02.940
On Windows, it just Just made the file.

434
00:21:02.940 --> 00:21:06.537
If we were to browse to our hard drive

435
00:21:09.894 --> 00:21:15.960
And do a dir/a, then in here,
we will find, right here, pagefile.sys.

436
00:21:15.960 --> 00:21:19.170
It just made a page file for me and
it's right here on the drive.

437
00:21:19.170 --> 00:21:20.300
But I might need to tweak and

438
00:21:20.300 --> 00:21:23.530
customize that to get it to
perform the way that I want to.

439
00:21:23.530 --> 00:21:26.900
And so, there's a few different
ways that you can go about that.

440
00:21:26.900 --> 00:21:31.580
But when we pull up our system
properties into our advanced settings.

441
00:21:31.580 --> 00:21:35.380
Let's see if I can remember exactly
where this is under performance.

442
00:21:35.380 --> 00:21:40.800
>> 20 clicks later under Advanced,
there we go.

443
00:21:40.800 --> 00:21:41.720
Here's my virtual memory.

444
00:21:41.720 --> 00:21:46.780
And you'll see my total paging file
size is right now is 1.4 Gigs.

445
00:21:46.780 --> 00:21:52.821
And if I go in to change,
I can modify the size of the paging file.

446
00:21:52.821 --> 00:21:54.254
I can change what drive its on,

447
00:21:54.254 --> 00:21:57.855
maybe I want the page file to be on its
own drive so I can move it somewhere else.

448
00:21:57.855 --> 00:22:01.342
I can set minimum and maximum sizes for
it, so it can grow and shrink.

449
00:22:01.342 --> 00:22:04.701
Now we can completely customize
how it works for our environment.

450
00:22:04.701 --> 00:22:06.950
Most of us, don't worry about this
any more cuz page files don't get

451
00:22:06.950 --> 00:22:08.000
used like that.

452
00:22:08.000 --> 00:22:10.891
But, if you're still using your page file,
these are all

453
00:22:10.891 --> 00:22:14.860
things we can customize to improve
performance and scalability of the server.

454
00:22:17.254 --> 00:22:20.907
The other thing is,
just general optimizations.

455
00:22:20.907 --> 00:22:25.321
Optimizations, like disabling
certain features or simple things,

456
00:22:25.321 --> 00:22:29.355
like if I know, I'm gonna be
remoting into the server a lot, and

457
00:22:29.355 --> 00:22:33.490
it's got some kind of
graphics-intensive wallpaper, Right?

458
00:22:33.490 --> 00:22:37.030
Microsoft used to do that with these big,
flashy Windows logos and stuff.

459
00:22:37.030 --> 00:22:39.590
When you remote desktop in,
it makes the connection slower,

460
00:22:39.590 --> 00:22:41.000
cuz it's gotta load that background.

461
00:22:41.000 --> 00:22:45.010
So changing the background to something
gray, like this, makes it more simple,

462
00:22:45.010 --> 00:22:47.830
makes it a little better
on the performance side.

463
00:22:47.830 --> 00:22:52.060
There's other tweaks too, like disabling
services that you're not using.

464
00:22:52.060 --> 00:22:55.338
So if I were to go into
the Services Utility and

465
00:22:55.338 --> 00:22:59.738
take a look at all the services
that are running on my system,

466
00:22:59.738 --> 00:23:04.507
many of these services may be important,
many of them may not be.

467
00:23:04.507 --> 00:23:09.025
And everyone that I disable is
a little bit less load on the server.

468
00:23:09.025 --> 00:23:11.370
It's gonna make it perform
a little bit better, right?

469
00:23:11.370 --> 00:23:14.710
These are additional tweaks and it's gonna
vary based on the operating system and

470
00:23:14.710 --> 00:23:15.310
based on your use.

471
00:23:15.310 --> 00:23:19.810
Now, the last thing, and this is probably
the best piece of advice I can give you,

472
00:23:20.830 --> 00:23:23.840
once you finished configuring the server,
and

473
00:23:23.840 --> 00:23:27.980
everything's done,
the next step is documentation.

474
00:23:27.980 --> 00:23:30.830
You've gotta document everything that
you did to build that server up.

475
00:23:30.830 --> 00:23:34.050
So that if there's ever a failure,
how do you rebuild that server?

476
00:23:34.050 --> 00:23:35.700
How do you get a back up in going in?

477
00:23:35.700 --> 00:23:36.660
You need all those steps.

478
00:23:36.660 --> 00:23:38.970
You need that configuration documented,
right?

479
00:23:38.970 --> 00:23:43.330
Also, if we wanna build up additional
version on that server, something changes.

480
00:23:43.330 --> 00:23:46.543
We need you to making sure that
our documentation's up to date,

481
00:23:46.543 --> 00:23:48.394
that is current, that is accurate.

482
00:23:48.394 --> 00:23:52.774
But another cool thing you can include
in the documentation is something called

483
00:23:52.774 --> 00:23:54.354
the performance baseline.

484
00:23:54.354 --> 00:23:57.066
Have you ever had a system,
it happens with me with laptops.

485
00:23:57.066 --> 00:24:00.470
I get a brand new laptop, I'm like, man
this is the fastest laptop I've ever had.

486
00:24:00.470 --> 00:24:04.350
And then a year later,
you'll hear me saying,

487
00:24:04.350 --> 00:24:07.760
I hate this laptop,
it's the slowest laptop I've ever had.

488
00:24:07.760 --> 00:24:13.180
Well, is it actually slow, or did I just
get used to it over that year and forget?

489
00:24:13.180 --> 00:24:17.730
And in my perception it's slow, but it's
actually just as fast as the day I got it.

490
00:24:17.730 --> 00:24:18.530
Is it?

491
00:24:18.530 --> 00:24:19.090
Maybe it isn't.

492
00:24:19.090 --> 00:24:22.770
Maybe I've just gunked it up
with too much software, right?

493
00:24:22.770 --> 00:24:25.670
On a server we have the same problem.

494
00:24:25.670 --> 00:24:28.469
A year later, is the server running
at the same speed you thought it was?

495
00:24:28.469 --> 00:24:31.840
A user calls us, aah,
the email server's slow!

496
00:24:31.840 --> 00:24:32.750
Is it?

497
00:24:32.750 --> 00:24:35.304
It might be,
maybe you added 100 new employees and

498
00:24:35.304 --> 00:24:38.102
the email database has grown large,
and yeah it's slow.

499
00:24:38.102 --> 00:24:42.050
Or maybe it's running at
the same speed it always has.

500
00:24:42.050 --> 00:24:45.609
And this user's just complaining cuz they
like to complain, which most users do.

501
00:24:45.609 --> 00:24:51.230
So, what we need to do is right now,
while the server is done and configured.

502
00:24:51.230 --> 00:24:54.160
And it has optimal settings and
everything is great.

503
00:24:54.160 --> 00:24:55.318
We need to take a performance baseline.

504
00:24:55.318 --> 00:24:59.880
We need to record the levels
that it's running at right now.

505
00:24:59.880 --> 00:25:01.560
So that when somebody calls and says,

506
00:25:01.560 --> 00:25:07.030
hey the server's slow, we can run
the same report then and compare the two.

507
00:25:07.030 --> 00:25:09.927
And compare it and say no, no, it's
actually the same as it's always been.

508
00:25:09.927 --> 00:25:13.209
Or, you're right,
look the CPU is pegged out at 100% and

509
00:25:13.209 --> 00:25:16.950
it isn't normally like that, and
we need something to compare it to.

510
00:25:16.950 --> 00:25:20.203
We have utilities like the Task Manager,
where if I pull up the Task Manager,

511
00:25:20.203 --> 00:25:22.572
it will show me how the server's
performing right now.

512
00:25:22.572 --> 00:25:24.660
Well it'll show me eventually.

513
00:25:24.660 --> 00:25:26.770
There we go.
How the server's performing right now,

514
00:25:26.770 --> 00:25:29.810
I can see my CPU and memory and ethernet.

515
00:25:29.810 --> 00:25:34.190
But how useful is this information if I
don't have anything to compare it to?

516
00:25:34.190 --> 00:25:38.250
It's showing me 60 seconds
in the life of this server.

517
00:25:38.250 --> 00:25:41.240
So I can compare it to 59 seconds ago.

518
00:25:41.240 --> 00:25:43.302
But how useful is that, right?

519
00:25:43.302 --> 00:25:45.300
I need something more.

520
00:25:45.300 --> 00:25:47.760
I need something that can go back in time.

521
00:25:47.760 --> 00:25:50.640
And different distros
have different utilities.

522
00:25:50.640 --> 00:25:52.348
There's tons of third
party software out there,

523
00:25:52.348 --> 00:25:53.697
really good stuff that can do this too.

524
00:25:53.697 --> 00:25:58.090
I really like the Dell Spotlight software,
which is amazing for Linux and Windows.

525
00:25:58.090 --> 00:26:01.301
But just right here, in Windows,

526
00:26:01.301 --> 00:26:07.250
we have the Performance Monitor and
the Resource Monitor.

527
00:26:07.250 --> 00:26:09.174
Performance Monitor's a little better for

528
00:26:09.174 --> 00:26:11.462
historical data cuz what we
can do is we can come in and

529
00:26:11.462 --> 00:26:14.844
you can create a performance monitor
that's tracking various activities.

530
00:26:14.844 --> 00:26:18.866
But you can actually create it
as a data collector set, and

531
00:26:18.866 --> 00:26:22.640
record the data, and
generate reports on it.

532
00:26:22.640 --> 00:26:28.560
So you can record the performance of
the system today and generate a report.

533
00:26:28.560 --> 00:26:31.950
And then six months from now,
when you think the server's running slow,

534
00:26:31.950 --> 00:26:37.210
you can collect the same data,
generate a report, and compare the two.

535
00:26:37.210 --> 00:26:40.240
That performance baseline is really

536
00:26:40.240 --> 00:26:42.900
important cuz it gives you
something to compare to.

537
00:26:42.900 --> 00:26:47.531
You need to know how it ran when things
were good to actually know whether or

538
00:26:47.531 --> 00:26:48.810
not things run bad.

539
00:26:48.810 --> 00:26:50.788
Right, that's what's really important.

540
00:26:50.788 --> 00:26:53.846
And so if I wanted to whip something
up really quick I can come here under.

541
00:26:53.846 --> 00:26:55.831
I could actually choose
one of these default ones.

542
00:26:55.831 --> 00:26:59.925
There's default performance monitor
collector sets that have been created,

543
00:26:59.925 --> 00:27:02.800
like system diagnostics or
system performance.

544
00:27:02.800 --> 00:27:05.529
And these are pretty good for
creating a baseline.

545
00:27:05.529 --> 00:27:10.069
If you take a look at it, Microsoft
has picked processor, physical disk,

546
00:27:10.069 --> 00:27:11.810
memory, network, right?

547
00:27:11.810 --> 00:27:12.540
The big four.

548
00:27:12.540 --> 00:27:14.760
Those are the big four
performance areas of a server.

549
00:27:14.760 --> 00:27:16.405
And that's probably good enough for

550
00:27:16.405 --> 00:27:18.852
me to gather a good set of
data right here to compare on.

551
00:27:18.852 --> 00:27:23.810
And so, what I can do is I can
launch this collector set.

552
00:27:23.810 --> 00:27:25.240
I can actually get it up and running.

553
00:27:26.290 --> 00:27:30.050
So, I'm just gonna choose Start and
it's running, and let it run.

554
00:27:30.050 --> 00:27:32.900
Let it run for 30 minutes or an hour or
however long it is you need it to run.

555
00:27:33.930 --> 00:27:35.470
Best to let it run all day.

556
00:27:35.470 --> 00:27:36.825
Because think about your work, right?

557
00:27:36.825 --> 00:27:38.527
You've got peak times and slow times.

558
00:27:38.527 --> 00:27:41.425
Eight in the morning, everybody's showing
up at work, things are really busy.

559
00:27:41.425 --> 00:27:44.611
Then 10 o'clock, 11 o'clock,
people settle into meetings,

560
00:27:44.611 --> 00:27:47.330
they're not really hitting your servers so
hard anymore.

561
00:27:47.330 --> 00:27:49.400
People go to lunch,
things get really slow.

562
00:27:49.400 --> 00:27:51.950
Then 1 o'clock, people get back from
lunch, things get really busy again.

563
00:27:51.950 --> 00:27:55.110
And then towards 5 o'clock,
it tapers off as everybody goes home.

564
00:27:55.110 --> 00:27:57.700
So depending on when you collect data,
it might not be accurate.

565
00:27:57.700 --> 00:28:00.830
You need to gather the whole day so
you can compare it.

566
00:28:00.830 --> 00:28:03.080
And that sounds like a lot
of data because it is.

567
00:28:03.080 --> 00:28:06.470
I'm gathering data once a second,
I think was the default.

568
00:28:06.470 --> 00:28:09.060
Pretty frequently,
all throughout that day.

569
00:28:09.060 --> 00:28:13.550
That's where the reports come in, is that
once we've gathered some data together,

570
00:28:13.550 --> 00:28:15.930
and I'm not gonna run this long
enough to have usable data.

571
00:28:15.930 --> 00:28:19.590
But once you've gathered the data
together, then you can come down and

572
00:28:19.590 --> 00:28:22.953
you can pull up a report,
like one of these performance reports.

573
00:28:22.953 --> 00:28:27.937
And it'll give you the top disk IO,
or the high disk queue length,

574
00:28:27.937 --> 00:28:30.300
the total CPU percentage.

575
00:28:30.300 --> 00:28:35.060
It'll lay this stuff out in a report
format that becomes very easy to compare.

576
00:28:35.060 --> 00:28:39.250
I can take this, or take a screenshot
of this, stick it in my documentation.

577
00:28:39.250 --> 00:28:41.680
And then, six months from now,

578
00:28:41.680 --> 00:28:44.520
if I'm seeing bad performance I can come
in here and look at it and compare it.

579
00:28:44.520 --> 00:28:48.180
And maybe right now my memory
utilization is 30% and

580
00:28:48.180 --> 00:28:52.314
six months from now people are complaining
it's slow, and my memory's at 95%.

581
00:28:52.314 --> 00:28:54.980
I'm like ooh, I need to add more memory.

582
00:28:54.980 --> 00:28:57.060
Or, what's eating up all that memory?

583
00:28:57.060 --> 00:28:58.090
Why am I out of memory?

584
00:28:58.090 --> 00:29:01.800
Maybe there's something, a memory
leak in some software I'm running.

585
00:29:01.800 --> 00:29:02.629
And now we can go and troubleshoot.

586
00:29:02.629 --> 00:29:04.870
Fine, we know what to look for, right?

587
00:29:04.870 --> 00:29:07.543
We wouldn't know if we didn't
have anything to compare it to.

588
00:29:07.543 --> 00:29:10.670
My memory is at 90%, is that good or bad?

589
00:29:10.670 --> 00:29:12.110
Is it always at 90%?

590
00:29:12.110 --> 00:29:13.750
Maybe that's normal, right?

591
00:29:13.750 --> 00:29:15.410
It's using the resources it has.

592
00:29:15.410 --> 00:29:17.150
We have to have a way to determine that.

593
00:29:17.150 --> 00:29:19.995
So that's kinda the key thing
with a performance baseline.

594
00:29:19.995 --> 00:29:24.470
And once we've got that, now the server's
ready to push out into production.

595
00:29:24.470 --> 00:29:26.430
>> All right, Don, well,
that's a lot of great information.

596
00:29:26.430 --> 00:29:28.760
Keep in mind, guys, this is a part 4.

597
00:29:28.760 --> 00:29:32.560
So if you're just joining us now, go back
and watch some of those original parts,

598
00:29:32.560 --> 00:29:34.568
or the first parts I should say.

599
00:29:34.568 --> 00:29:36.800
Now Don, it does look like we're
coming to the end of another episode.

600
00:29:36.800 --> 00:29:37.510
But before we do,

601
00:29:37.510 --> 00:29:39.911
do you have any additional words
that you might like to throw or

602
00:29:39.911 --> 00:29:44.000
impart to our viewers, when it comes to
installing your server operating system?

603
00:29:44.000 --> 00:29:45.191
>> Ideally, two things, right?

604
00:29:45.191 --> 00:29:47.100
One, make sure you're
making the right decisions.

605
00:29:47.100 --> 00:29:49.550
Cuz some of them,
you can change anything after the fact.

606
00:29:49.550 --> 00:29:52.320
But some are really hard to change,
like choosing a file system or

607
00:29:52.320 --> 00:29:53.260
partition layout.

608
00:29:53.260 --> 00:29:54.278
That stuff's a pain in
the butt to change later on.

609
00:29:54.278 --> 00:29:58.550
So make decisions right early on,
if you can.

610
00:29:58.550 --> 00:30:02.625
And then two, document things so
you can consistently deploy servers.

611
00:30:02.625 --> 00:30:06.040
You don't want a hundred servers
configured a hundred different ways.

612
00:30:06.040 --> 00:30:09.540
You wanna make sure they were all deployed
using the same methodical approach so

613
00:30:09.540 --> 00:30:12.690
that everything is consistent and
far easier to support.

614
00:30:12.690 --> 00:30:15.120
>> Well Don, as always,
we appreciate that information.

615
00:30:15.120 --> 00:30:16.900
We do appreciate you,
the viewer, watching.

616
00:30:16.900 --> 00:30:19.890
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

617
00:30:19.890 --> 00:30:21.667
>> And I'm Don Pezet.
>> And we'll see you next time.

618
00:30:21.667 --> 00:30:29.120
[MUSIC]

619
00:30:29.120 --> 00:30:33.520
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

00:34:47.027 --> 00:34:49.835
[LAUGH] And so
they never said it was free bandwidth.

715
00:34:49.835 --> 00:34:52.665

00:34:52.665 --> 00:34:54.735

717
00:34:54.735 --> 00:34:56.905
So, on a nice side,
if you have a remote access server,

00:34:56.905 --> 00:34:58.725
you're only being charged for
one direction of that traffic, but

719
00:34:58.725 --> 00:35:02.402
you're paying 10cents per gigabyte for

720
00:35:02.402 --> 00:35:04.322
Yeah it is gigabyte,
ten cents per gigabyte.

721
00:35:05.952 --> 00:35:07.832

don't quote me on that.

722
00:35:07.832 --> 00:35:09.732

00:35:09.732 --> 00:35:11.172
So we have to think about that.

724
00:35:11.172 --> 00:35:16.212
But the other thing is, if we're doing a
remote access server and it's a VPN, CPU.

725
00:35:16.212 --> 00:35:20.190

726
00:35:20.190 --> 00:35:22.800

it's got to decrypt that.

it has to encrypt that to send it to me.

728
00:35:25.940 --> 00:35:28.680
So, that's a heavy CPU resource.

729
00:35:28.680 --> 00:35:31.370

So when you go to AWS and you bring up a

00:35:40.630 --> 00:35:42.388

733
00:35:42.388 --> 00:35:45.360
But you gotta make sure you

734
00:35:45.360 --> 00:35:46.580

747

Or the size of the database just grows.

It gets bigger and bigger that happens.

777

783

784
00:38:09.600 --> 00:38:11.680

785

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore various technologies that are used to administer to a server. They talk about concepts like local hardware administration through KVMs,  serial console connections, as well as their limitations. They look at network-based hardware administration through components like KVM over IPs, ILOs and iDRACs with a demonstration of HPE ILOs. Finally, they will discuss network-based operating system administration through technologies like Microsoft Windows’s RDP, the widely popular SSH and VNC.
episodes.title: Administering a Server

00:03:33.430 --> 00:03:35.270

00:03:35.270 --> 00:03:39.220

00:03:39.220 --> 00:03:40.190

00:03:40.190 --> 00:03:42.550

00:03:44.030 --> 00:03:46.330

00:03:46.330 --> 00:03:49.050

83
00:03:50.450 --> 00:03:55.070
The second thing is,
when we have to get up and

85
00:03:57.160 --> 00:03:57.970

86
00:03:57.970 --> 00:04:02.890

00:04:02.890 --> 00:04:05.780

88
00:04:05.780 --> 00:04:10.664
So, you've got to have some way to share

89
00:04:10.664 --> 00:04:14.070
And so that kind of makes

90
00:04:14.070 --> 00:04:17.840

91
00:04:17.840 --> 00:04:18.990
Not normally.

92
00:04:18.990 --> 00:04:21.720
But there are devices called KVMs.

93
00:04:21.720 --> 00:04:25.390
KVM stands for keyboard video monitor.

94
00:04:25.390 --> 00:04:28.630
And it's a device that
lets you share a monitor.

95
00:04:28.630 --> 00:04:30.630
Well, a keyboard and a mouse,

96
00:04:30.630 --> 00:04:35.950
that's the name, it lets you share those
three devices amongst many systems.

97
00:04:35.950 --> 00:04:40.560
Now I've set these up for
years and originally they were

98
00:04:40.560 --> 00:04:45.590

a PS2 mouse, and a VGA monitor.

99
00:04:45.590 --> 00:04:49.390
Newer ones, do USB, because most
keyboards and mice do USB these days and

100
00:04:49.390 --> 00:04:51.330
most servers have USB on them.

101
00:04:51.330 --> 00:04:53.610
But on the video side,
we're still VGA for most of it.

102
00:04:53.610 --> 00:04:56.670
Servers really didn't make
the jump to DVI or HDMI or

103
00:04:56.670 --> 00:04:58.090

104
00:04:58.090 --> 00:04:59.400
Servers, we don't care about graphics.

105
00:04:59.400 --> 00:05:01.320
You're not playing video
games on your server.

106
00:05:01.320 --> 00:05:05.890
So it's okay to have something that
just a VGA connection, doesn't matter.

107
00:05:05.890 --> 00:05:08.330
But we would have a KVM

108
00:05:08.330 --> 00:05:10.640

109
00:05:10.640 --> 00:05:14.420
So if I had 20 servers,

110
00:05:14.420 --> 00:05:15.890

111
00:05:15.890 --> 00:05:20.040
And I would run cables to every

112
00:05:20.040 --> 00:05:24.750
And once they were hooked up,
I can then take a keyboard, a monitor, and

113
00:05:24.750 --> 00:05:27.240
a mouse, and hook them up to the KVM.

114
00:05:27.240 --> 00:05:31.330
And from that box, you can manipulate
buttons right on the front of it to say,

115
00:05:31.330 --> 00:05:32.750

116
00:05:32.750 --> 00:05:34.260
Show me server number 15.

117
00:05:34.260 --> 00:05:35.930
Show me server number 11.

118
00:05:35.930 --> 00:05:39.860
And by doing that, you would see
the actual video output of that server.

119
00:05:39.860 --> 00:05:41.460
That works perfect because
you could see the BIOS.

120
00:05:41.460 --> 00:05:44.080
You could see the RAID controller,
the network boot.

121
00:05:44.080 --> 00:05:45.840
You could see all that stuff.

122
00:05:45.840 --> 00:05:48.590
And it didn't require any
special software on the server.

123
00:05:48.590 --> 00:05:50.230
The server just thought
it was a regular monitor.

124
00:05:51.290 --> 00:05:54.140
Those solutions were great,
except for the cabling.

125
00:05:54.140 --> 00:05:57.730
The cabling was a real pain
in having to run all this.

126
00:05:57.730 --> 00:06:00.340
And so, modern KVMs don't do that anymore,

127
00:06:00.340 --> 00:06:02.560
they don't use cables
the way they used to.

128
00:06:02.560 --> 00:06:07.300
Instead most modern KVMs
are what are called IPKVMs.

129
00:06:07.300 --> 00:06:09.380
And let me show you a picture.

130
00:06:10.700 --> 00:06:12.530
This is a company called Blackbox.

131
00:06:12.530 --> 00:06:15.990
There are several different KVM
vendors that are out there, Blackbox,

132
00:06:15.990 --> 00:06:19.260
Averson, which I think it was
bought by another company.

133
00:06:19.260 --> 00:06:24.660
But there's a bunch of different ones, and
the products are by and large the same.

134
00:06:24.660 --> 00:06:26.831
And there's high quality ones,
and low quality ones,

135
00:06:26.831 --> 00:06:29.430
those like Belkin ones that are cheap and
aren't build very well.

136
00:06:29.430 --> 00:06:32.440
The Avocent ones are expensive and
they're built really well.

137
00:06:32.440 --> 00:06:34.810
There's open source ones where
they have open source hardware,

138
00:06:34.810 --> 00:06:36.240
Opengear makes some of those.

139
00:06:36.240 --> 00:06:39.100
But they all kind of work the same.

140
00:06:39.100 --> 00:06:43.600
Most of them have switched to an IP model,
where you have a KVM

141
00:06:43.600 --> 00:06:48.320
switch which is a box that you plug
a monitor, a keyboard, and a mouse into.

142
00:06:48.320 --> 00:06:50.430
And you plug a network cable into it and
that's it.

143
00:06:50.430 --> 00:06:53.060
You don't plug anything else into it.

144
00:06:53.060 --> 00:06:56.960
And then at all of your servers,
you have a little dongle.

145
00:06:56.960 --> 00:07:00.040
And the little dongle
plugs in one USB port,

146
00:07:00.040 --> 00:07:02.670
which is doing mouse and
keyboard, and VGA.

147
00:07:02.670 --> 00:07:05.210
You plug these two wires in.

148
00:07:05.210 --> 00:07:07.860
And then you plug
a network cable into that.

149
00:07:07.860 --> 00:07:09.400
And so it's done through your network.

150
00:07:09.400 --> 00:07:11.790
That means we don't have to run a bunch
of individual cables to all the servers,

151
00:07:11.790 --> 00:07:13.800
we just need to plug them
in to their local switch.

152
00:07:13.800 --> 00:07:18.290
And we can have one KVM That
powers hundreds of devices.

153
00:07:18.290 --> 00:07:20.070
When I had to plug a VGA cable in for

154
00:07:20.070 --> 00:07:24.760
each server can you imagine 100
VGA ports all next to each other?

155
00:07:24.760 --> 00:07:28.340
You can't physically fit it in the 19
inches that we have in a rack.

156
00:07:28.340 --> 00:07:33.090
So you'd have to buy more than one KVM and
daisy chain them, and it was a pain.

157
00:07:33.090 --> 00:07:35.600
Well IP KVMs make that a lot easier.

158
00:07:35.600 --> 00:07:39.420
And the other cool thing about an IP KVM
is its IP, it's on the network.

159
00:07:39.420 --> 00:07:43.250
So the KVM could actually
be in your office and

160
00:07:43.250 --> 00:07:45.330
then all the dongles around
the servers in the server room.

161
00:07:45.330 --> 00:07:49.720
So I could be sitting right in my office
and still access the console of every one

162
00:07:49.720 --> 00:07:53.200
of the machines that I need to
without going in the server room.

163
00:07:53.200 --> 00:07:56.786
Now, IP KVMs don't do such a great
job stretching geographically.

164
00:07:56.786 --> 00:07:58.948
So, if I'm at home and
I want to view all these things,

165
00:07:58.948 --> 00:08:00.739
they don't usually do
a great job with that.

166
00:08:00.739 --> 00:08:02.829
Some of them do have remote
gateways that you can setup so

167
00:08:02.829 --> 00:08:04.346
you've got remote access IP gateways.

168
00:08:04.346 --> 00:08:07.382
An extra appliance that
helps to optimize it.

169
00:08:07.382 --> 00:08:09.691
Cuz we're usually looking
at the raw video,

170
00:08:09.691 --> 00:08:13.040
and raw video is pretty intense
as far as bandwidth, right?

171
00:08:13.040 --> 00:08:15.880
And it's expecting very, very low latency.

172
00:08:15.880 --> 00:08:17.700
But when you start going
out across the Internet,

173
00:08:17.700 --> 00:08:20.390
you're gonna have latency,
you can't push high video.

174
00:08:20.390 --> 00:08:23.970
And so they use these gateways to
basically downscale the video and

175
00:08:23.970 --> 00:08:25.380
make the quality a little lower so

176
00:08:25.380 --> 00:08:29.950
it streams easier, and it takes care
of the delay that's introduced.

177
00:08:29.950 --> 00:08:32.210
But those are some of the options,
and this is just one vendor.

178
00:08:32.210 --> 00:08:32.902
But like I said,

179
00:08:32.902 --> 00:08:36.269
there's plenty of vendors that are out
there that make KVMs like these, right?

180
00:08:36.269 --> 00:08:39.519
KVMs are a really useful way
of administering your server,

181
00:08:39.519 --> 00:08:42.317
because you don't have to
go into the server room.

182
00:08:42.317 --> 00:08:46.508
Now not every device we deploy is gonna
have video output, or a keyboard or

183
00:08:46.508 --> 00:08:48.270
mouse for that matter.

184
00:08:48.270 --> 00:08:50.750
There's several devices that
we get that are appliances.

185
00:08:50.750 --> 00:08:57.420
So for example, we had a Barracuda Spam
and Anti-virus Firewall, right?

186
00:08:57.420 --> 00:08:59.270
You couldn't hook a monitor up to it.

187
00:08:59.270 --> 00:09:03.830
Instead it had a serial port, you plugged
in via serial port to get your output.

188
00:09:03.830 --> 00:09:07.340
Any Linux server can have its output
redirect to a serial port, so

189
00:09:07.340 --> 00:09:11.020
now you don't need a keyboard or mouse,
you just need serial connectivity.

190
00:09:11.020 --> 00:09:14.250
And the idea is if you wanted to
administer the server, you'd take a laptop

191
00:09:14.250 --> 00:09:17.640
and you'd run a serial cable and plug it
into that device, and there you'd go.

192
00:09:17.640 --> 00:09:19.580
You could see everything you needed,
right?

193
00:09:19.580 --> 00:09:22.940
Cisco routers, switches,
most vendor's routers and switches,

194
00:09:22.940 --> 00:09:25.950
their firewalls, have a console
port on them that is serial based.

195
00:09:27.530 --> 00:09:31.200
On a positive side, all you need is a
serial cable and you can manage it, right?

196
00:09:31.200 --> 00:09:32.470
It's not so bad.

197
00:09:32.470 --> 00:09:36.510
On a negative side, there's not really
a great way to do that remotely, right,

198
00:09:36.510 --> 00:09:37.510
at least the way that it is.

199
00:09:37.510 --> 00:09:41.210
You're kind of limited to the length of
a serial cable, which is not very long.

200
00:09:41.210 --> 00:09:46.440
Well, fortunately, we have the equivalent
of KVMs for serial connectivity.

201
00:09:46.440 --> 00:09:49.200
You can get what are called
console servers, and

202
00:09:49.200 --> 00:09:51.830
there's a number of companies that
make them, there's open source ones.

203
00:09:51.830 --> 00:09:54.010
I like the ones from
a company called Opengear.

204
00:09:54.010 --> 00:09:57.410
The Opengear is where they
release all the blueprints for

205
00:09:57.410 --> 00:10:00.332
their hardware as open source,
so anybody can really make it.

206
00:10:00.332 --> 00:10:02.260
But then they just happen to make it and
sell it too.

207
00:10:02.260 --> 00:10:05.420
So this is an example of one
of their console servers.

208
00:10:05.420 --> 00:10:10.120
And what you'll see is, you buy it
based on how many ports you need.

209
00:10:10.120 --> 00:10:13.670
And so you need a 96 port,
or a 48 port, 16 port.

210
00:10:13.670 --> 00:10:15.870
You buy the appropriate one, and

211
00:10:15.870 --> 00:10:20.460
then you run serial cables from this to
each of the devices in that data center.

212
00:10:20.460 --> 00:10:23.060
And then you can be anywhere in the world,
and

213
00:10:23.060 --> 00:10:26.010
when you remotely connect
in to this console,

214
00:10:26.010 --> 00:10:30.320
you can then see the actual serial console
of all the devices in the back end.

215
00:10:30.320 --> 00:10:33.855
So just to lay us out as an example,
I used to work for a bank.

216
00:10:33.855 --> 00:10:38.280
And our home office was up
in Seattle Washington, and

217
00:10:38.280 --> 00:10:41.100
we had a Disaster Recovery Center
that was out in Spokane, Washington.

218
00:10:41.100 --> 00:10:43.860
On the other side of the state,
on the other side of the mountains.

219
00:10:43.860 --> 00:10:48.780
Well, I think I went to the DR
site maybe twice, tops.

220
00:10:48.780 --> 00:10:50.940
You never went out there.

221
00:10:50.940 --> 00:10:55.680
Instead you'd be sitting right at the home
office, and you'd pull up the IP KVM so

222
00:10:55.680 --> 00:10:59.440
you could view the Windows consoles or
the Linux consoles, and

223
00:10:59.440 --> 00:11:04.300
then you'd pull up the console server to
be able to view the firewalls and routers.

224
00:11:04.300 --> 00:11:07.960
You could manage every server as
if you were sitting right there.

225
00:11:07.960 --> 00:11:09.610
You could power it down and power it on.

226
00:11:09.610 --> 00:11:12.270
You could install an operating system.

227
00:11:12.270 --> 00:11:16.573
You could do a full upgrade and not worry
about if you locked up the server, or

228
00:11:16.573 --> 00:11:19.980
locked yourself out,
cuz you've got console access.

229
00:11:19.980 --> 00:11:21.680
It's as if you were standing
right in front of it.

230
00:11:21.680 --> 00:11:24.520
The only thing you can't
do is put a CD in the tray.

231
00:11:24.520 --> 00:11:26.890
But you can always call somebody and
have them do that for you, right,

232
00:11:26.890 --> 00:11:29.810
if there's at least one person
out there at that location.

233
00:11:29.810 --> 00:11:33.960
So that's the advantage of having
remote access technologies like these.

234
00:11:33.960 --> 00:11:36.740
The only negative is the hardware, right?

235
00:11:36.740 --> 00:11:39.510
I've gotta buy a console server,
I've gotta buy a KVM switch.

236
00:11:39.510 --> 00:11:43.729
I've gotta buy dongles for
all of my stuff to plug into their ports,

237
00:11:43.729 --> 00:11:46.261
their video, and mouse, or whatever.

238
00:11:46.261 --> 00:11:50.271
It is expensive,
you have to pay a lot for this, right?

239
00:11:50.271 --> 00:11:54.429
If we just wanna monitor the servers
while they're running normally, well,

240
00:11:54.429 --> 00:11:56.150
we can use software.

241
00:11:56.150 --> 00:11:59.310
We can use software to remotely
connect to these systems.

242
00:11:59.310 --> 00:12:03.825
The firewalls, and routers, and stuff
that have serial ports that I mentioned,

243
00:12:03.825 --> 00:12:05.230
I can use SSH or telnet.

244
00:12:05.230 --> 00:12:09.960
I could use protocols like that to
remotely connect in and work with them.

245
00:12:09.960 --> 00:12:11.500
Work just fine, right?

246
00:12:11.500 --> 00:12:13.975
You can connect in and access the device.

247
00:12:13.975 --> 00:12:17.364
A lot of them have web interfaces, so
I could fire up a web browser, and

248
00:12:17.364 --> 00:12:20.714
point it to it, and manage it that way,
as long as they're working.

249
00:12:20.714 --> 00:12:22.794
It's when they're not working,
when something goes wrong.

250
00:12:22.794 --> 00:12:25.591
You do a software update and
it says, we're rebooting,

251
00:12:25.591 --> 00:12:30.430
we'll be back up in 60 seconds, and it's
been 5 minutes and you still can't get in.

252
00:12:30.430 --> 00:12:31.930
What the heck is going on?

253
00:12:31.930 --> 00:12:36.300
I need to see what's on the screen, and
that's where these devices come in handy.

254
00:12:36.300 --> 00:12:40.150
So for a small office or a home office
you might not worry about this, but

255
00:12:40.150 --> 00:12:43.600
in an enterprise,
this is really, really handy.

256
00:12:43.600 --> 00:12:45.740
>> Don, I'm thinking of
a man-in-the-middle attack, or

257
00:12:45.740 --> 00:12:50.930
an eavesdropping attack if you have
a remote IP-based KVM like that.

258
00:12:50.930 --> 00:12:53.780
What are doing when it comes to security?

259
00:12:53.780 --> 00:12:56.160
You mentioned things like SSH,
if I connect,

260
00:12:56.160 --> 00:12:57.750
we know that that's gonna be encrypted.

261
00:12:57.750 --> 00:13:00.600
How about these consoles
when I connect to them?

262
00:13:00.600 --> 00:13:04.020
Could I perform a man-in-the-middle
attack between you and your server?

263
00:13:04.020 --> 00:13:07.478
>> Well, it's always possible, right,
especially if you've misconfigured it.

264
00:13:07.478 --> 00:13:10.504
But if you take your time and
design your solution right,

265
00:13:10.504 --> 00:13:12.217
it can actually be more secure.

266
00:13:12.217 --> 00:13:17.284
So for example, we had this one little,
they were CSU/DSUs.

267
00:13:17.284 --> 00:13:21.650
We have several T1 lines, and
the CSU/DSUs supported network management.

268
00:13:21.650 --> 00:13:23.800
If you plugged a network cable into them,
you could manage it right there.

269
00:13:23.800 --> 00:13:28.200
We could actually pull statistics off of
the Telco lines right from these boxes,

270
00:13:28.200 --> 00:13:32.110
it was really cool, but
it only supported Telnet, that's it.

271
00:13:32.110 --> 00:13:34.600
Nope, no SSH, just Telnet.

272
00:13:34.600 --> 00:13:36.300
And so at first I looked at it and
I'm like,

273
00:13:36.300 --> 00:13:37.730
well there's a feature
we're not gonna use.

274
00:13:37.730 --> 00:13:40.930
I'm not gonna enable Telnet cuz it's,
well, it's unencrypted, right?

275
00:13:42.040 --> 00:13:46.980
But then when we got the Opengear
box we put that console in,

276
00:13:46.980 --> 00:13:49.596
it actually had where you
could run that to the CSU.

277
00:13:49.596 --> 00:13:56.580
And so yeah, that was an encrypted line,
but you could SSH to the Opengear box.

278
00:13:56.580 --> 00:13:59.400
So now, across the Internet,
or across the public networks,

279
00:13:59.400 --> 00:14:02.260
I'm doing an encrypted SSH tunnel.

280
00:14:02.260 --> 00:14:03.940
And on the backend it's unencrypted, but

281
00:14:03.940 --> 00:14:07.940
that's not crossing the Internet,
that's crossing just the data center line.

282
00:14:07.940 --> 00:14:11.850
And if somebody's in the data center, then
they can unplug that cable and plug in

283
00:14:11.850 --> 00:14:14.970
their own laptop anyway, so it doesn't
really matter at that point, right?

284
00:14:14.970 --> 00:14:17.800
We're kind of beyond that level
of security at that point.

285
00:14:17.800 --> 00:14:22.110
So you can actually increase your security
by deploying something like this,

286
00:14:22.110 --> 00:14:23.650
right, that's one of the ways.

287
00:14:23.650 --> 00:14:24.980
Now I could have misconfigured.

288
00:14:24.980 --> 00:14:27.909
I could have said, you know what, let me
enable telnet on the OpenGear box, and

289
00:14:27.909 --> 00:14:30.640
then I'm not any better off than
I would have been before, right?

290
00:14:30.640 --> 00:14:33.680
So always keep that in mind,
when you design a solution,

291
00:14:33.680 --> 00:14:36.230
you are the one who controls
whether it's secure or not.

292
00:14:36.230 --> 00:14:40.159
And if you make the wrong decisions,
you likely will end up unsecure.

293
00:14:40.159 --> 00:14:43.594
>> One of the things you'd mentioned,
Don, is for instance if we got SSH.

294
00:14:43.594 --> 00:14:44.690
If the server's on, that's great.

295
00:14:44.690 --> 00:14:47.550
I can connect to it,
I can configure it through SSH.

296
00:14:47.550 --> 00:14:50.860
What happens if the server is turned off,
or it reboots, and

297
00:14:50.860 --> 00:14:52.405
maybe it didn't come back online?

298
00:14:52.405 --> 00:14:55.945
And now don't have access
to a live IP-based network,

299
00:14:55.945 --> 00:14:57.005
because your server is turned off.

300
00:14:57.005 --> 00:14:58.160
Do we have a solution then?

301
00:14:58.160 --> 00:15:01.290
>> Man, there is so much great stuff
when it comes data center management.

302
00:15:01.290 --> 00:15:05.255
If you ever get bored, go to APC's
website, APC, American Power Company.

303
00:15:05.255 --> 00:15:09.865
They're known for creating UPSs,
Uninterruptible Power Supplies, but

304
00:15:09.865 --> 00:15:11.005
they make a lot of other stuff.

305
00:15:11.005 --> 00:15:14.470
They make server racks, and
this whole infrastructure X line.

306
00:15:14.470 --> 00:15:18.660
And they make these power strips that have
a network cable you plug into them, and

307
00:15:18.660 --> 00:15:22.840
you can remote in and
turn each socket on and off independently.

308
00:15:22.840 --> 00:15:25.580
You can actually say, you know what,
this server is locked up so

309
00:15:25.580 --> 00:15:28.920
I'm gonna cut power to it, and
then I'm gonna give it power again.

310
00:15:28.920 --> 00:15:32.440
And so you can do that, you can control
it right from the power outlet.

311
00:15:32.440 --> 00:15:37.450
But even if you don't have that,
a lot of server manufacturers are actually

312
00:15:37.450 --> 00:15:41.388
integrating that type of support
right into the server itself.

313
00:15:41.388 --> 00:15:45.710
And I kinda want it to be something we
covered in this episode, but I kinda let

314
00:15:45.710 --> 00:15:48.302
the cat out of the bag a few episodes
ago because I used it on our server.

315
00:15:49.560 --> 00:15:54.584
Dell and HP both have these integrated
remote management boards that are right

316
00:15:54.584 --> 00:15:59.238
on the motherboard of the server, or
a card that's added right onto it.

317
00:15:59.238 --> 00:16:02.651
Well they basically build
an entirely separate computer.

318
00:16:02.651 --> 00:16:08.681
It's got its own CPU, its own memory, its
own storage, But it's tied to your server.

319
00:16:08.681 --> 00:16:13.150
On the Dell ones, they call it
a Integrated Dell Remote Access Card, or

320
00:16:13.150 --> 00:16:13.677
IDRAC.

321
00:16:13.677 --> 00:16:19.223
And in HP world, it's an integrated
Lights Out Board, or ILO board.

322
00:16:19.223 --> 00:16:21.606
And with ILO or IDRAC, either one,

323
00:16:21.606 --> 00:16:26.750
you can connect this other computer
that's inside of the server.

324
00:16:26.750 --> 00:16:30.658
And even if the server is powered off,
as long as the power cable is plugged in,

325
00:16:30.658 --> 00:16:32.568
this other computer will be running.

326
00:16:32.568 --> 00:16:35.389
And you can connect in and
start to work with it.

327
00:16:35.389 --> 00:16:40.275
Then from there, you don't worry
about things like KVM because you can

328
00:16:40.275 --> 00:16:42.810
connect right into the screen here.

329
00:16:42.810 --> 00:16:43.860
And you don't even need the KDM.

330
00:16:43.860 --> 00:16:45.690
We don't need the extra cables or
whatever.

331
00:16:45.690 --> 00:16:47.108
It's built-in to the server.

332
00:16:47.108 --> 00:16:48.837
So just to show you an example of that,

333
00:16:48.837 --> 00:16:51.900
the server that we had on the desk
here in the other episode.

334
00:16:51.900 --> 00:16:53.340
This is the Lights Out board for it.

335
00:16:53.340 --> 00:16:54.377
So I'm connected.

336
00:16:54.377 --> 00:17:01.670
And if I just get logged in to it,
it has its own IP address, right?

337
00:17:01.670 --> 00:17:02.817

And it's our appropriate
ITProTV naming convention.

565
00:28:14.729 --> 00:28:18.380
But once I'm in here,
I can start to work with the switch, and

566
00:28:18.380 --> 00:28:23.828
pull up the interfaces, and start looking
at configurations, and working with it.

567
00:28:23.828 --> 00:28:26.773
All over a secure connection and
just like VNC or RDP,

568
00:28:26.773 --> 00:28:30.841
where you're remoting into a desktop,
here I'm remoting into a shell.

569
00:28:30.841 --> 00:28:34.125
And I know it's encrypted
because I used SSH and

570
00:28:34.125 --> 00:28:38.243
we pushed it over a tunnel and
so it's a secure connection.

571
00:28:38.243 --> 00:28:40.496
I didn't have to configure this software,
it was built in.

572
00:28:40.496 --> 00:28:44.370
A lot of systems come with their
management software already built in,

573
00:28:44.370 --> 00:28:45.605
RDP being an example.

574
00:28:45.605 --> 00:28:47.187
In the Mac world, you have VNC.

575
00:28:47.187 --> 00:28:50.941
On the Linux world you usually just
have SSH which on a server is fine.

576
00:28:50.941 --> 00:28:54.564
But if you have a GUI on that server then
you might need to add VNC to be able to

577
00:28:54.564 --> 00:28:55.096
get that.

578
00:28:56.793 --> 00:28:57.299
All right,

579
00:28:57.299 --> 00:29:00.494
I think as far as remote administration
is concerned that's probably it.

580
00:29:00.494 --> 00:29:04.570
There's even more out there, like Windows
PowerShell and Win RM, and all those guys.

581
00:29:04.570 --> 00:29:08.829
But we could turn this into a ten hour
show if we tried to cover them all.

582
00:29:08.829 --> 00:29:12.695
But for the exam, they just want you to
know that there are physical connections

583
00:29:12.695 --> 00:29:15.301
for viewing the local console
that will always work.

584
00:29:15.301 --> 00:29:18.730
And then there's software solutions for
viewing the console, but

585
00:29:18.730 --> 00:29:22.775
they kind of expect the server to be
performing normally for those to function.

586
00:29:22.775 --> 00:29:24.586
>> All right, Don, well,
that's a lot of great information.

587
00:29:24.586 --> 00:29:27.529
I can't wait for the episode when we
go into switch naming conventions.

588
00:29:27.529 --> 00:29:28.355
That one will be fun for sure.

589
00:29:28.355 --> 00:29:31.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> It does look like though, again,

590
00:29:31.160 --> 00:29:32.857
we are coming to the end
of another episode.

591
00:29:32.857 --> 00:29:33.801
But before we do, Don,

592
00:29:33.801 --> 00:29:36.644
do you have any parting words that
you'd like to let our audience know?

593
00:29:36.644 --> 00:29:37.700
>> I think that's about it.

594
00:29:37.700 --> 00:29:39.970
Try all the different management
products that are out there.

595
00:29:39.970 --> 00:29:42.622
You'll find one that you
like more than the others.

596
00:29:42.622 --> 00:29:46.927
Like I said, for me, it took me
years to finally get into Royal TS.

597
00:29:46.927 --> 00:29:51.283
I used to use Secure CRT and
other programs before that.

598
00:29:51.283 --> 00:29:53.982
RD Tabs,
there's a ton of them that are out there.

599
00:29:53.982 --> 00:29:55.257
Same thing goes for.

600
00:29:55.257 --> 00:29:56.566
Try a few different ones.

601
00:29:56.566 --> 00:30:00.110
If you get one that's frustrating,
there's other vendors that are out there.

602
00:30:00.110 --> 00:30:00.995
There's some big names.

603
00:30:00.995 --> 00:30:03.245
Avisant you see pretty much
everywhere these days.

604
00:30:03.245 --> 00:30:06.444
But Blackbox makes great stuff,
Open Gear makes great stuff.

605
00:30:06.444 --> 00:30:08.279
Just try them out.

606
00:30:08.279 --> 00:30:10.929
A lot of them have trials and
demos so you can experiment and

607
00:30:10.929 --> 00:30:12.290
find what works best for you.

608
00:30:12.290 --> 00:30:14.867
>> All right, Don well thank you for
being here in the studios with us.

609
00:30:14.867 --> 00:30:16.663
And thank you the viewers for watching.

610
00:30:16.663 --> 00:30:21.012
Signing out for IT Pro TV, I've been your
hosting Wes Switchy McSwitchface Brian.

611
00:30:21.012 --> 00:30:24.947
>> And I'm Don Pezet
>> And we'll see you next time

612
00:30:24.947 --> 00:30:30.746
[MUSIC]

613
00:30:30.746 --> 00:30:32.630
Thank you for watching, ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore the concepts and techniques used in server maintenance. They look at the components of change management and patch management.
episodes.title: Server Maintenance
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:05.573
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:05.573 --> 00:00:08.245
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.245 --> 00:00:11.845
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.845 --> 00:00:16.081
>> Welcome to another exciting episode
here at ITProTV, I'm your host Wes Bryan.

5
00:00:16.081 --> 00:00:19.076
And in today's episode we
are continuing through

6
00:00:19.076 --> 00:00:22.722
our CompTIA Server+ SK0-004
certification course.

7
00:00:22.722 --> 00:00:26.200
And joining us back in the studios
today is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:26.200 --> 00:00:27.430
Don how are you doing sir?

9
00:00:27.430 --> 00:00:30.120
>> I'm doing just well, Wes,
ready to dive into a new objective.

10
00:00:30.120 --> 00:00:34.300
And in this episode we're gonna be
tackling the server maintenance objective,

11
00:00:34.300 --> 00:00:37.710
which is probably one of my most
favorite of all the objectives.

12
00:00:37.710 --> 00:00:40.210
Because it's stinking massive,

13
00:00:40.210 --> 00:00:43.890
it is a gigantic objective that
covers a ton of different topics.

14
00:00:43.890 --> 00:00:45.200
So we're gonna be going through them all.

15
00:00:45.200 --> 00:00:48.540
This is gonna be a multi part episode,
cuz it;s just a lot to get through.

16
00:00:48.540 --> 00:00:51.020
But server maintenance is really,

17
00:00:51.020 --> 00:00:54.910
really critical, and that's why it's
such a big objective, it needs to be.

18
00:00:54.910 --> 00:00:59.650
If you think about it, it takes a lot of
time to plan for servers, to purchase and

19
00:00:59.650 --> 00:01:02.280
procure servers,
you go back the server life cycle, right?

20
00:01:02.280 --> 00:01:04.990
All those early steps, and
then it takes time to deploy them.

21
00:01:04.990 --> 00:01:08.270
It's a lot of work, it's hard,
hard getting those servers set up right,

22
00:01:08.270 --> 00:01:10.550
making the right decisions,
getting them deployed.

23
00:01:10.550 --> 00:01:12.900
But then once they're deployed,
what happens?

24
00:01:12.900 --> 00:01:16.690
They run, they do their job, and
hopefully they do it for years on end.

25
00:01:16.690 --> 00:01:19.170
And during that time, what do we do?

26
00:01:19.170 --> 00:01:20.410
We don't just kick our feet up and

27
00:01:20.410 --> 00:01:24.410
watch TV, we do maintenance,
we make sure the servers stay running.

28
00:01:24.410 --> 00:01:28.540
Because, just because they're running
today doesn't mean they'll run tomorrow.

29
00:01:28.540 --> 00:01:32.970
And most of us have learned that lesson
through numerous real life examples of

30
00:01:32.970 --> 00:01:36.450
things just not working the way
they're supposed to day after day.

31
00:01:36.450 --> 00:01:39.540
And server maintenance is how we
handle that, how we approach it, and

32
00:01:39.540 --> 00:01:43.320
how we try to minimize the impact
it creates on our end users.

33
00:01:43.320 --> 00:01:46.830
Now the very first objective that CompTIA
calls out is a really important one.

34
00:01:46.830 --> 00:01:48.070
I'm glad they put it first,

35
00:01:48.070 --> 00:01:53.940
which is change management,
the enemy to server uptime is change.

36
00:01:53.940 --> 00:01:59.630
That if nothing changes, if everything
stays the same your servers will run and

37
00:01:59.630 --> 00:02:01.600
you'll never have to mess with them.

38
00:02:01.600 --> 00:02:04.654
That was the glory of Novell, if any of
you guys ran Novell servers way back in

39
00:02:04.654 --> 00:02:07.351
the day, Novell NetWare,
that you could set up a NetWare server.

40
00:02:07.351 --> 00:02:11.840
And as long as you didn't mess with it,
it would just sit there and run, and run,

41
00:02:11.840 --> 00:02:12.378
and run.

42
00:02:12.378 --> 00:02:16.732
There was this one story, a true story
about a university where just through

43
00:02:16.732 --> 00:02:20.970
various projects over the years,
they accidentally walled up a server.

44
00:02:20.970 --> 00:02:24.690
There were two doors to this room and
they removed one door.

45
00:02:24.690 --> 00:02:25.820
And then later on they
removed another door.

46
00:02:25.820 --> 00:02:29.400
And they ended up with a server that
was walled up, and it ran for years.

47
00:02:29.400 --> 00:02:33.650
And finally one day it started acting
up and they went where is that server?

48
00:02:33.650 --> 00:02:36.600
And they had to pull up blueprints, and
they found where there was this gap

49
00:02:36.600 --> 00:02:38.579
in the walls, and
that's where the server ended up.

50
00:02:39.640 --> 00:02:42.850
That could happen back then,
but today it's not like that.

51
00:02:42.850 --> 00:02:46.080
Back then you had small networks, networks
that weren't connected to the internet.

52
00:02:46.080 --> 00:02:49.720
Servers that weren't under constant
attack like they are today.

53
00:02:49.720 --> 00:02:53.750
Today, at a minimum, even if we
don't change our configurations,

54
00:02:53.750 --> 00:02:55.370
we've gotta deploy updates.

55
00:02:55.370 --> 00:03:00.640
We've gotta deploy patches, security
fixes, and that is changing our platform.

56
00:03:00.640 --> 00:03:03.590
Changing what is implemented,
even though we don't necessarily want to.

57
00:03:03.590 --> 00:03:06.410
So because there's constant change,

58
00:03:06.410 --> 00:03:10.290
we've got this constant opportunity
to break our systems and it happens.

59
00:03:10.290 --> 00:03:13.110
It may not be your fault,
it may be the upstream provider, right,

60
00:03:13.110 --> 00:03:15.000
it happens all the time.

61
00:03:15.000 --> 00:03:18.050
Microsoft pushes on an update or
RedHat pushes on an update.

62
00:03:18.050 --> 00:03:20.720
And all of a sudden some software
package doesn't work anymore.

63
00:03:20.720 --> 00:03:24.400
And it might be because that software
package needed an update itself.

64
00:03:24.400 --> 00:03:27.050
Or that vendor just hadn't accounted for
it, or whatever.

65
00:03:27.050 --> 00:03:28.720
There's any number of scenarios
that can happen there,

66
00:03:28.720 --> 00:03:30.540
but they can all lead to problems.

67
00:03:30.540 --> 00:03:33.800
And change management works to fix that,
so

68
00:03:33.800 --> 00:03:35.180
let's talk briefly about
change management.

69
00:03:35.180 --> 00:03:36.820
I know I've mentioned it
in a few other episodes and

70
00:03:36.820 --> 00:03:41.640
I'll probably mention it again when we
get into asset management and stuff.

71
00:03:41.640 --> 00:03:46.090
But just at it's basics the idea behind
change management is that nobody should

72
00:03:46.090 --> 00:03:48.082
change a server.

73
00:03:48.082 --> 00:03:53.910
That servers should be pretty much static,
unless you get approval.

74
00:03:53.910 --> 00:03:56.840
And when we get approval,
how do we do that?

75
00:03:56.840 --> 00:03:59.280
Well we do it through
a change request system.

76
00:03:59.280 --> 00:04:01.430
So change request is what
I got on my laptop here.

77
00:04:01.430 --> 00:04:06.390
And the way change requests work is, if
you wanna make a modification to a server,

78
00:04:06.390 --> 00:04:09.840
you fill out a little form,
and then you submit it.

79
00:04:09.840 --> 00:04:12.080
And somebody somewhere
determines whether or

80
00:04:12.080 --> 00:04:14.360
not you should be allowed
to make the change.

81
00:04:14.360 --> 00:04:18.168
Now who is the somebody somewhere,
well that depends.

82
00:04:18.168 --> 00:04:20.930
If you're gonna implement change
management in your company,

83
00:04:20.930 --> 00:04:25.090
you really need to start by creating
what's called a change management plan.

84
00:04:25.090 --> 00:04:27.220
We do these in project
management all the time.

85
00:04:27.220 --> 00:04:29.910
So I'm gonna show you a project
management example here.

86
00:04:29.910 --> 00:04:33.368
But a change management plan simply
dictates how you're going to control

87
00:04:33.368 --> 00:04:34.771
change in your environment.

88
00:04:34.771 --> 00:04:38.110
And this is the template that
I use anytime I make these up.

89
00:04:38.110 --> 00:04:40.310
But basically,
you specify what your approach is.

90
00:04:40.310 --> 00:04:44.719
And your approach might be, I'm gonna
follow ITIL standards for my organization,

91
00:04:44.719 --> 00:04:46.966
or you know something defined in.

92
00:04:46.966 --> 00:04:50.010
Or whatever framework it
is that you choose to use.

93
00:04:50.010 --> 00:04:53.530
And then you specify,
you're gonna create change advisory board,

94
00:04:53.530 --> 00:04:56.880
a group of people that would be
authorizing changes or whatever.

95
00:04:56.880 --> 00:05:00.477
It's the way you choose to manage
change in your organization,

96
00:05:00.477 --> 00:05:02.540
that's what a change management plan is.

97
00:05:02.540 --> 00:05:06.160
The key thing here is that
you can hire a new employee.

98
00:05:06.160 --> 00:05:08.030
And you could just give them a copy
of the change management plan and

99
00:05:08.030 --> 00:05:09.940
they can read over it and now they know.

100
00:05:09.940 --> 00:05:14.090
Hey, if I wanna make a change to a server,
here's what I need to do.

101
00:05:14.090 --> 00:05:18.930
So my change management approach might
say, I'm gonna follow ITIL best practices.

102
00:05:18.930 --> 00:05:21.750
And I'm gonna require that every change

103
00:05:21.750 --> 00:05:24.720
gets submitted through
a change advisory board.

104
00:05:24.720 --> 00:05:29.890
And the change advisory board will meet
every Thursday at 2 PM to approve changes.

105
00:05:29.890 --> 00:05:32.510
But, if there's an emergency change,

106
00:05:32.510 --> 00:05:35.460
here's the procedure we're gonna
follow for emergency changes.

107
00:05:35.460 --> 00:05:36.886
And so we can rush those too,
cuz that happens.

108
00:05:36.886 --> 00:05:41.201
I'm not gonna wait til Thursday at 2 PM,
when a hacker is in my server right now,

109
00:05:41.201 --> 00:05:43.140
I need to make change, right?

110
00:05:43.140 --> 00:05:46.889
So we have to have emergency processes to
be able to step in and take care of that.

111
00:05:46.889 --> 00:05:52.130
So here's how we schedule change,
how we budget change, the scope of change.

112
00:05:52.130 --> 00:05:54.450
Scope of change is important,
that's how big a change can be.

113
00:05:54.450 --> 00:05:57.510
You don't want one change ticket to say

114
00:05:57.510 --> 00:06:02.310
I'm gonna upgrade every server in my
entire environment to Red Hat 7.3.

115
00:06:02.310 --> 00:06:06.570
It should be, I'm gonna upgrade
this web server to Red Hat 7.3 and

116
00:06:06.570 --> 00:06:09.811
I'm gonna upgrade this
database server to 7.3.

117
00:06:09.811 --> 00:06:12.833
Each one managed individually,
cuz they all have separate needs,

118
00:06:12.833 --> 00:06:15.510
separate risks and
separate exposures, right?

119
00:06:15.510 --> 00:06:18.710
If my database server goes off line,
that could be really really bad.

120
00:06:18.710 --> 00:06:21.100
If my fax server goes offline,
I might not care.

121
00:06:21.100 --> 00:06:23.840
So there's different levels of
impact we have to worry about.

122
00:06:25.010 --> 00:06:29.180
If we have a change control board or
change advisory board, different name for

123
00:06:29.180 --> 00:06:30.620
the same thing.

124
00:06:30.620 --> 00:06:32.770
You specify,
who the people are that are on it.

125
00:06:32.770 --> 00:06:37.120
And these might be people like the CIO or
CTO, you might have a CISO,

126
00:06:37.120 --> 00:06:41.120
or even just regular departmental people
that are participating in that process in

127
00:06:41.120 --> 00:06:42.530
helping to make decisions.

128
00:06:42.530 --> 00:06:45.500
But their role and responsibility
isn't the level of authority.

129
00:06:45.500 --> 00:06:48.650
You need to designate whether some of
them are on the emergency contact list or

130
00:06:48.650 --> 00:06:51.320
whether they only meet in
the normal board meetings.

131
00:06:51.320 --> 00:06:52.480
>> And that's what I was going to ask on,

132
00:06:52.480 --> 00:06:56.325
I was thinking could there potentially
be two completely separate teams.

133
00:06:56.325 --> 00:06:58.310
One that does the change advisory board,

134
00:06:58.310 --> 00:07:02.948
like you said, then one that has to get to
maybe an overnight emergency right away.

135
00:07:02.948 --> 00:07:07.050
Would we submit the same ticket
to two different boards,

136
00:07:07.050 --> 00:07:09.430
or how would we work that
out if it is an emergency?

137
00:07:09.430 --> 00:07:14.190
>> I've seen it handled different ways,
and one way says that tou have

138
00:07:14.190 --> 00:07:17.230
this board that meets, and
you have a separate emergency board.

139
00:07:17.230 --> 00:07:18.630
But normally there's so much overlap,

140
00:07:18.630 --> 00:07:21.670
I mean the emergency board is gonna be
made up of people from the regular board.

141
00:07:21.670 --> 00:07:25.470
So typically, instead of having
a separate board, what they'll do is say,

142
00:07:25.470 --> 00:07:29.820
in an emergency, you only need
signed off from three people.

143
00:07:29.820 --> 00:07:31.900
You might have seven on the list,
I just need three.

144
00:07:31.900 --> 00:07:34.460
If I can get three people to sign off,
I can act.

145
00:07:34.460 --> 00:07:40.020
Or the CEO or CIO can step in and
override the board at any moment.

146
00:07:40.020 --> 00:07:42.210
And not in a bad way,
in a good way, right?

147
00:07:42.210 --> 00:07:44.400
It's an emergency,
I've got the CIO on the phone.

148
00:07:44.400 --> 00:07:46.590
If he tells me it's okay, I'm gonna do it.

149
00:07:46.590 --> 00:07:49.723
Or I've got the CEO on the phone, and
if she says it's okay, I'm gonna do it.

150
00:07:49.723 --> 00:07:51.380
I don't need the change advisory board,

151
00:07:51.380 --> 00:07:53.550
we need to have emergency
processes like that.

152
00:07:53.550 --> 00:07:57.294
Not necessarily a separate board,
it might be the same board,

153
00:07:57.294 --> 00:07:59.071
just a smaller element of it.

154
00:07:59.071 --> 00:08:02.039
Then we document things like
how changes are submitted.

155
00:08:02.039 --> 00:08:04.498
How does somebody turn
in a change request?

156
00:08:04.498 --> 00:08:07.972
And once it's submitted,
how do we track that change and review it?

157
00:08:07.972 --> 00:08:09.550
How do we dispose of it?

158
00:08:09.550 --> 00:08:13.250
And by disposing the change, I mean
approve it, decline it, or submit it for

159
00:08:13.250 --> 00:08:14.050
more information, right?

160
00:08:14.050 --> 00:08:14.815
It's called a disposition,

161
00:08:14.815 --> 00:08:16.353
it's a little bit different
than throwing it in the trash.

162
00:08:16.353 --> 00:08:17.490
Right?

163
00:08:17.490 --> 00:08:20.300
So that's all part of
a change management plan.

164
00:08:20.300 --> 00:08:22.520
It's what a change management plan does.

165
00:08:22.520 --> 00:08:25.870
And when somebody needs to
make a change to the system,

166
00:08:25.870 --> 00:08:29.970
they'll submit a change
request according to the plan.

167
00:08:29.970 --> 00:08:33.140
Now how does this help us
to maintain our servers?

168
00:08:33.140 --> 00:08:35.390
Well, maybe one day I'm
looking at the server.

169
00:08:35.390 --> 00:08:37.680
I got a call from an end user and
they're saying,

170
00:08:37.680 --> 00:08:42.030
hey, I can't connect to the server,
it's not working right.

171
00:08:42.030 --> 00:08:43.160
And I start looking at it and

172
00:08:43.160 --> 00:08:48.070
I suspect that it might be
the firewall running on that server.

173
00:08:48.070 --> 00:08:50.490
It's got a software firewall and
I think that might be the problem.

174

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their exploration of the concepts and techniques used in server maintenance. They look at outages and service level agreements(SLAs). They talk about  scheduled downtime, impact analysis, mean-time-to-failure (MTTR). They look at performance monitoring of hardware like CPU, memory, network and disk utilization and process monitoring.

69

they are gonna be times they

The next time of our down time is

and

All right, so

2 am is the lowest usage

And then you go and

102
00:04:52.300 --> 00:04:54.535
So I need to plan for

103
00:04:54.535 --> 00:04:55.450
Scheduled outages.

104

105
00:05:01.860 --> 00:05:04.760

106
00:05:04.760 --> 00:05:09.600
So unscheduled outages are when

Anytime that system went offline.

00:05:38.130 --> 00:05:42.040

00:05:42.040 --> 00:05:43.270
But if it was unscheduled.

00:05:43.270 --> 00:05:45.020

We'd have to focus

00:06:04.420 --> 00:06:06.060

00:06:25.570 --> 00:06:27.830

137
00:06:27.830 --> 00:06:29.680

00:06:29.680 --> 00:06:30.610

00:06:30.610 --> 00:06:34.650

00:06:34.650 --> 00:06:35.960

Wether this should be

00:07:27.580 --> 00:07:31.300

00:07:40.065 --> 00:07:42.796

If I had a server, and for redundancy

00:07:42.796 --> 00:07:47.962

163
00:07:47.962 --> 00:07:49.680

that server for redundancy.

164
00:07:49.680 --> 00:07:51.760
There's a dollar value assigned to that.

165
00:07:51.760 --> 00:07:54.022
Let's say it's a $6,000 server.

166
00:07:54.022 --> 00:07:57.949
Well, that $6,000 server now costs me
$12,000, cuz I had to buy 2 of them for

167
00:07:57.949 --> 00:07:58.567
redundancy.

168
00:07:58.567 --> 00:08:02.651
Well, what were the odds of that

00:08:02.651 --> 00:08:06.079

00:08:06.079 --> 00:08:10.060

00:08:10.060 --> 00:08:13.130
What are the odds of that server failing?

172

We need to know that.

it's something that can be tracked.
