635
00:30:43.270 --> 00:30:45.750
Windows Performance Monitor
is built into Windows.

636
00:30:45.750 --> 00:30:49.110
In the Unix world you have
the activity monitor on some systems.

637
00:30:49.110 --> 00:30:52.600
You've always got utilities like top and
df and you can

638
00:30:52.600 --> 00:30:56.430
write scripts that just automatically
run and gather the data and store it.

639
00:30:56.430 --> 00:30:59.242
But honestly in the Unix
world I like Zabbix, but

640
00:30:59.242 --> 00:31:02.398
Zabbix is built on Nagios so
you can use Nagios, MRTG,

641
00:31:02.398 --> 00:31:06.602
there's a ton of open source products
out there that can monitor those.

642
00:31:06.602 --> 00:31:10.558
And there's commercial products, too, like
SolarWind, CA Unicenter, and those guys,

643
00:31:10.558 --> 00:31:14.790
but have something that's collecting
that data so you can trend against it.

644
00:31:14.790 --> 00:31:17.000
All right,
the last thing I wanna mention is not so

645
00:31:17.000 --> 00:31:20.940
much about performance, but
just about preventing downtime.

646
00:31:20.940 --> 00:31:23.710
And usually, downtime is not a surprise.

647
00:31:23.710 --> 00:31:26.670
It might be a surprise to you, but it's
usually not a surprise to the computer.

648
00:31:26.670 --> 00:31:28.400
The computer normally
knows it's coming and

649
00:31:28.400 --> 00:31:32.390
you'll normally spot it in
the logs on that system.

650
00:31:32.390 --> 00:31:34.920
On Unix systems we have the sys log, or

651
00:31:34.920 --> 00:31:39.760
on newer systems you have the journald
system inside the systemd.

652
00:31:39.760 --> 00:31:43.270
But either way you have
these message logs.

653
00:31:43.270 --> 00:31:45.870
In the Windows world you have
the Event Viewer and the Event Logs.

654
00:31:45.870 --> 00:31:48.690
In the Mac world you have some systems,
too.

655
00:31:48.690 --> 00:31:53.700
So those messages are everything that's
going on in the background of your server.

656
00:31:53.700 --> 00:31:55.732
And you might be getting
some performance errors or

657
00:31:55.732 --> 00:31:57.867
other things that are popping
up in those event logs.

658
00:31:57.867 --> 00:31:59.352
And they start out as warnings,

659
00:31:59.352 --> 00:32:02.047
like hey here's a problem you
probably need to address and

660
00:32:02.047 --> 00:32:05.605
then they turned into straight up errors
>> And that means things are going wrong.

661
00:32:05.605 --> 00:32:09.347
If you keep track of your event logs, if
you monitor those and just sift through it

662
00:32:09.347 --> 00:32:13.660
for information like that, a lot of times
you can spot problems before they occur.

663
00:32:13.660 --> 00:32:16.543
Or more importantly, you can spot
problems before your end users do.

664
00:32:16.543 --> 00:32:18.400
Problems are gonna happen.

665
00:32:18.400 --> 00:32:20.780
If you can fix it before
an end user notices,

666
00:32:20.780 --> 00:32:22.775
that's like that secret win right there,
right?

667
00:32:22.775 --> 00:32:25.230
It's like the problem never existed,
you fixed it.

668
00:32:25.230 --> 00:32:27.790
But you need time to sift those logs and
that can be very hard.

669
00:32:27.790 --> 00:32:32.750
So having some kind of central aggregating
server where all the logs get collapsed,

670
00:32:32.750 --> 00:32:34.850
and a way to be able to search
through those is important.

671
00:32:34.850 --> 00:32:37.220
There's a lot of third party syslog
servers that are out there and other

672
00:32:37.220 --> 00:32:40.450
services that let you do that to aggregate
that information together and filter it.

673
00:32:40.450 --> 00:32:44.355
But it only does good if
you actually look at it.

674
00:32:44.355 --> 00:32:47.800
So it needs to be part of your routine
procedures that you set aside a few hours

675
00:32:47.800 --> 00:32:51.810
every week for reviewing event logs, and

676
00:32:51.810 --> 00:32:55.020
running performance reports on your
servers and collecting that data.

677
00:32:55.020 --> 00:32:57.280
If you can automate it
with third party software,

678
00:32:57.280 --> 00:32:59.900
that software's gonna be expensive,
but it's gonna be worth it.

679
00:32:59.900 --> 00:33:02.200
In a small or medium business,
you'll probably have to do by hand.

680
00:33:02.200 --> 00:33:04.435
But you've got less systems to monitor,
so it won't be so bad.

681
00:33:04.435 --> 00:33:06.660
But that's really the approach
you need to take.

682
00:33:06.660 --> 00:33:08.860
It's something you've
got to stay on top of.

683
00:33:08.860 --> 00:33:11.236
Well, Don, there's a lot of
good information there, I know,

684
00:33:11.236 --> 00:33:13.172
looking at our objectives
list that we've still got

685
00:33:13.172 --> 00:33:13.740
more to go-
>> [LAUGH]

686
00:33:13.740 --> 00:33:16.090
>> But once again we have run out of

687
00:33:16.090 --> 00:33:16.920
time on the clock.

688
00:33:16.920 --> 00:33:20.569
So before we wrap this one up, Don,
on our server maintenance part two here,

689
00:33:20.569 --> 00:33:24.332
do you got any additional words you might
like to let people know about outages,

690
00:33:24.332 --> 00:33:27.112
service level plans, and
even performance monitoring?

691
00:33:27.112 --> 00:33:30.267
>> All right, well, in part one and
part two of this, we've really been

692
00:33:30.267 --> 00:33:33.930
talking about bureaucracy and work,
paperwork, monitoring, maintenance.

693
00:33:33.930 --> 00:33:34.620
It doesn't sound fun.

694
00:33:34.620 --> 00:33:38.280
It doesn't sound glorious, but it is
the difference between a good admin and

695
00:33:38.280 --> 00:33:39.610
a bad admin, right?

696
00:33:39.610 --> 00:33:43.760
A good admin has a monitor on their
desktop that's showing them some kind

697
00:33:43.760 --> 00:33:46.260
of overall status report that
they're able to watch and see.

698
00:33:46.260 --> 00:33:50.010
And a good admin is spotting
errors before the end user does.

699
00:33:50.010 --> 00:33:54.090
A bad admin is one that has Facebook
up on the monitor, on their desk, and

700
00:33:54.090 --> 00:33:57.630
they're waiting for a user to call in and
tell them a problem exists, right.

701
00:33:57.630 --> 00:33:59.500
You've always got work to do.

702
00:33:59.500 --> 00:34:01.689
A system admin is never bored, right?

703
00:34:01.689 --> 00:34:03.960
A system admin doesn't have
time to browse Facebook.

704
00:34:03.960 --> 00:34:07.255
There's always something
to do from monitoring and

705
00:34:07.255 --> 00:34:10.120
rerunning backups to testing
whether you can restore.

706
00:34:10.120 --> 00:34:14.420
Or from monitoring performance,
researching new replacements for hardware.

707
00:34:14.420 --> 00:34:18.610
There's so
much work to be done that you stay busy.

708
00:34:18.610 --> 00:34:22.700
And that's how I recognize a good admin
from a bad admin is the ones who tell me

709
00:34:22.700 --> 00:34:27.070
they've got a system so
stable that they can just relax at work,

710
00:34:27.070 --> 00:34:29.140
they're not doing the work
that they need to do.

711
00:34:29.140 --> 00:34:30.630
And one day it won't be stable.

712
00:34:30.630 --> 00:34:33.320
And that's when you end up with an RGE,
right?

713
00:34:33.320 --> 00:34:35.120
A resonate generating event.

714
00:34:35.120 --> 00:34:38.147
Eventually some kind of failure
happens and it's your fault for

715
00:34:38.147 --> 00:34:39.331
not putting the work in.

716
00:34:39.331 --> 00:34:40.950
You don't want that to happen, right?

717
00:34:40.950 --> 00:34:44.040
We used to make the joke though
that no failure is truly terrible

718
00:34:44.040 --> 00:34:46.410
as long as there's at least one printer
that still works in the building.

719
00:34:46.410 --> 00:34:48.480
As long as you can print
your resume it's not so bad.

720
00:34:48.480 --> 00:34:51.440
But if that last printer fails,
then I get really screwed, right?

721
00:34:51.440 --> 00:34:53.010
So you don't want to get to that point and

722
00:34:53.010 --> 00:34:55.030
maintenance is the way that we
prevent that from happening.

723
00:34:55.030 --> 00:34:57.710
>> All right, Don, well, we appreciate
having you here in the studios.

724
00:34:57.710 --> 00:34:59.710
Again, I'm gonna go ahead and
close down Facebook,

725
00:34:59.710 --> 00:35:02.670
make sure that at least
one printer does work.

726
00:35:02.670 --> 00:35:05.490
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

727
00:35:05.490 --> 00:35:06.280
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

728
00:35:06.280 --> 00:35:08.047
>> And we'll see you next time

729
00:35:08.047 --> 00:35:14.093
[MUSIC]

730
00:35:14.093 --> 00:35:21.359
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their exploration of the concepts and techniques used in server maintenance. They talk about indicators that let the technician know that there is an issue with a server like LED and LCD messages as well as error and beep codes. They also explain the types of devices that can be replaced when they fail such as fans, hard drives, RAM and blackplanes.
episodes.title: Server Maintenance Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.346
Welcome to ITProTv, I'm your host Don.

2
00:00:02.346 --> 00:00:06.712
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.712 --> 00:00:08.198
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.198 --> 00:00:11.822
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.822 --> 00:00:14.515
>> Welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITPROTV.

6
00:00:14.515 --> 00:00:17.275
I'm your host Wes Bryan,
and in today's episode,

7
00:00:17.275 --> 00:00:22.315
we are continuing through our
CompTIA Server Plus SK0-004 certification.

8
00:00:22.315 --> 00:00:25.655
Back with a part three I
believe in server maintenance.

9
00:00:25.655 --> 00:00:28.320
And joining us back in the studio
is none other that Mr. Don Pizzett.

10
00:00:28.320 --> 00:00:29.050
Don, how are you doing sir?

11
00:00:29.050 --> 00:00:30.220
>> I am doing great, Wes.

12
00:00:30.220 --> 00:00:32.450
Ready to dive right back into a little
bit of server maintenance and

13
00:00:32.450 --> 00:00:35.750
you know the last couple episodes
we've been talking about concepts and

14
00:00:35.750 --> 00:00:40.710
theory, and we've been talking about
policies, and procedure, and software,

15
00:00:40.710 --> 00:00:42.540
performance monitoring that kind of stuff.

16
00:00:42.540 --> 00:00:45.140
And this episode we're gonna go
a little bit more on the hardware side

17
00:00:45.140 --> 00:00:48.140
of things because in this day and age, the
majority of the problems that we have that

18
00:00:48.140 --> 00:00:51.310
take a server offline do
actually end up being hardware.

19
00:00:51.310 --> 00:00:55.140
And that's because, well on the software
side we usually have built in redundancy

20
00:00:55.140 --> 00:00:59.210
if you have one web server you have two
web servers or three, or four, and so

21
00:00:59.210 --> 00:01:03.350
if there's a software issue that one just
goes offline, the other ones take over.

22
00:01:03.350 --> 00:01:05.330
You format and
reimage the machine and off you go.

23
00:01:05.330 --> 00:01:07.200
There's not a whole heck of a lot of
software trouble shooting we do these

24
00:01:07.200 --> 00:01:11.350
days, but on the hardware side,
that's physical hardware.

25
00:01:11.350 --> 00:01:13.960
It's already paid for and
if it breaks, and goes offline,

26
00:01:13.960 --> 00:01:16.900
you can't just format your hardware,
and reinstall.

27
00:01:16.900 --> 00:01:17.800
You need to get it working.

28
00:01:17.800 --> 00:01:19.240
You need to identify
the piece that's failed.

29
00:01:19.240 --> 00:01:21.855
So that's what we're gonna talk
about right here in this episode.

30
00:01:21.855 --> 00:01:25.970
Now before I go breaking open a server and
pointing at things,

31
00:01:25.970 --> 00:01:27.660
and potentially breaking it myself.

32
00:01:27.660 --> 00:01:32.260
I wanna a talk a little bit about
some of the visual audio type

33
00:01:32.260 --> 00:01:35.690
cues that a sever will give you to
let you know that it's not happy.

34
00:01:35.690 --> 00:01:37.239
That servers do have a way of doing that,

35
00:01:37.239 --> 00:01:40.490
of telling you that's something is
not right and giving you a warning.

36
00:01:40.490 --> 00:01:44.130
Sometimes they can give you that warning
ahead of time, sometimes they can't and

37
00:01:44.130 --> 00:01:48.210
it's only once the problem is there
that you are given whatever this

38
00:01:48.210 --> 00:01:49.430
message is from the server.

39
00:01:49.430 --> 00:01:50.960
It speaks from beyond.

40
00:01:50.960 --> 00:01:56.095
Well there's no more clear issue with
a server, that when you walk up to it,

41
00:01:56.095 --> 00:02:00.435
look at it's face plate, and
all of it's lights are off, right?

42
00:02:00.435 --> 00:02:01.635
It's powered off.

43
00:02:01.635 --> 00:02:04.705
And you push the power button,
and nothing happens.

44
00:02:04.705 --> 00:02:05.875
The server is dead, right?

45
00:02:05.875 --> 00:02:07.365
Completely dead.

46
00:02:07.365 --> 00:02:10.435
Now that is actually pretty uncommon.

47
00:02:10.435 --> 00:02:14.480
Pretty uncommon for a server to just
be completely dead in the water.

48
00:02:14.480 --> 00:02:18.420
And the reason is there is a lot of
circuitry on the motherboard of a server

49
00:02:18.420 --> 00:02:23.460
that is designed to operate independently
that all of the hard drives can be failed,

50
00:02:23.460 --> 00:02:27.220
but the server's hardware maintenance
systems are still functional and it's ESM

51
00:02:27.220 --> 00:02:32.120
or embedded service manager, or whatever
it's got will still be functional.

52
00:02:32.120 --> 00:02:34.430
That if it's got a remote insight board or

53
00:02:34.430 --> 00:02:39.160
a insight remote,
let me get my naming right here.

54
00:02:39.160 --> 00:02:42.330
The remote insight lights out,
the ILOE board.

55
00:02:42.330 --> 00:02:45.670
If it's got a Dell Remote Access
Controller or a DRAC in there.

56
00:02:45.670 --> 00:02:49.490
Then those systems are gonna be up and
running, and you can connect.

57
00:02:49.490 --> 00:02:54.550
So there's still be some kind of light or
some kind of life signs in that server.

58
00:02:54.550 --> 00:02:59.680
For it to be completely dead in the water,
it either has to be a massive failure,

59
00:02:59.680 --> 00:03:03.310
which is usually visible because of the
massive amount of damage it had to happen,

60
00:03:03.310 --> 00:03:06.490
I'm assuming it takes an axe to the thing
you're gonna notice that, right?

61
00:03:06.490 --> 00:03:08.500
Or power.

62
00:03:08.500 --> 00:03:12.750
If the server's getting no power, then
it can't give you a message from beyond,

63
00:03:12.750 --> 00:03:15.540
it can't give you beeps and tones, and

64
00:03:15.540 --> 00:03:19.860
codes, and lights, it can't give you
that stuff cuz it has no power, right.

65
00:03:19.860 --> 00:03:23.360
So it's extremely uncommon for
that to happen but it does happen,

66
00:03:23.360 --> 00:03:24.910
you do lose power.

67
00:03:24.910 --> 00:03:26.390
Usually you notice because
all the lights are off.

68
00:03:27.500 --> 00:03:30.790
So we don't need the server to tell us
when we bump into things when we're

69
00:03:30.790 --> 00:03:33.340
walking around and hit the light switch,
and nothing happens.

70
00:03:33.340 --> 00:03:35.030
But if you have a UPS.

71
00:03:35.030 --> 00:03:38.340
If you have generators, if you have those
systems in place in theory you should

72
00:03:38.340 --> 00:03:40.400
never be out of power either, all right?

73
00:03:40.400 --> 00:03:45.250
So if your sever's completely off,
what happened there?

74
00:03:45.250 --> 00:03:47.250
Well check your power cables.

75
00:03:47.250 --> 00:03:49.970
Right, the power cables on the back of the
server are really not any different than

76
00:03:49.970 --> 00:03:52.970
the power cables that we use on
the desktop or any other machine.

77
00:03:52.970 --> 00:03:54.290
They can come loose.

78
00:03:54.290 --> 00:03:55.430
They can move free.

79
00:03:55.430 --> 00:03:57.970
They can be chewed
through by rodents if you

80
00:03:57.970 --> 00:04:00.870
have that kind of problem in your
server and hopefully you don't.

81
00:04:00.870 --> 00:04:05.500
But they can also take dust in, and
as they take dust in the components inside

82
00:04:05.500 --> 00:04:07.450
the power supply can overheat,
and burn out.

83
00:04:07.450 --> 00:04:10.150
There's capacitors inside of
the power supplies that can pop.

84
00:04:10.150 --> 00:04:14.590
Now I say power supplies plural
cuz we normally have two.

85
00:04:14.590 --> 00:04:17.220
So again, for the server to be
completely dead in the water,

86
00:04:17.220 --> 00:04:20.430
I would have both power supplies fail.

87
00:04:20.430 --> 00:04:22.210
Which is even more unlikely.

88
00:04:22.210 --> 00:04:24.500
So it's an unlikely scenario,
but it can happen.

89
00:04:24.500 --> 00:04:25.660
Check your power.

90
00:04:25.660 --> 00:04:28.720
Check to make sure your cables
are rated properly for the server.

91
00:04:28.720 --> 00:04:31.870
If it's never worked, you might be
plugging into the wrong type of outlet.

92
00:04:31.870 --> 00:04:35.650
It might be expecting 220 and
it's only getting 110.

93
00:04:35.650 --> 00:04:38.180
Right, you can have the wrong voltage for
supply.

94
00:04:38.180 --> 00:04:41.010
There can be other things like that and
interfere with it.

95
00:04:41.010 --> 00:04:44.660
>> Now Don, this one might have some more
obvious sign as well because additional

96
00:04:44.660 --> 00:04:46.030
device is just might be in that circuit.

97
00:04:46.030 --> 00:04:48.050
But it could have been environment.

98
00:04:48.050 --> 00:04:52.090
I think lightning strikes could that
cost two power adapters to go down.

99
00:04:52.090 --> 00:04:54.430
The [INAUDIBLE] power supply's
to go down at the same time?

100
00:04:54.430 --> 00:04:55.030
>> It could, yeah.

101
00:04:55.030 --> 00:04:58.250
I mean,
ideally you have two power supply's,

102
00:04:58.250 --> 00:05:01.930
run to two different PDU's run
to two different UPS's, right?

103
00:05:01.930 --> 00:05:03.600
You separation across that lane.

104
00:05:03.600 --> 00:05:05.250
But if you don't have that, right?

105
00:05:05.250 --> 00:05:08.580
If you have two power supply's and
use one of those y cables, and

106
00:05:08.580 --> 00:05:10.610
it runs to one power plug in the wall.

107
00:05:10.610 --> 00:05:13.060
Well you never done a power
supply if one fails.

108
00:05:13.060 --> 00:05:15.650
But if you take a surge,
that surge can go into both of them.

109
00:05:15.650 --> 00:05:18.660
And it's just like any other
parts while they can part, and

110
00:05:18.660 --> 00:05:20.980
then that's what we're
going to have to replace.

111
00:05:20.980 --> 00:05:23.100
Now here is where it gets a little tricky.

112
00:05:23.100 --> 00:05:25.810
The power supply failure can
actually be in two different places.

113
00:05:25.810 --> 00:05:27.900
It could be the power supply itself and
if that's the case,

114
00:05:27.900 --> 00:05:30.880
well that's not a big deal,
most power supplies pop right out

115
00:05:30.880 --> 00:05:33.100
just like I've got this
one here on my hand now.

116
00:05:33.100 --> 00:05:35.430
And I can get a replacement,
and pop it in.

117
00:05:35.430 --> 00:05:39.140
I might even have a few replacements
laying around just for that instance,

118
00:05:39.140 --> 00:05:41.760
or I might put in a warranty call and
get them to send me one.

119
00:05:41.760 --> 00:05:44.340
So not a big deal if a failure is here.

120
00:05:44.340 --> 00:05:47.530
But the other place the failure could
be is that on your power supply it's

121
00:05:47.530 --> 00:05:48.740
got a connector, and

122
00:05:48.740 --> 00:05:53.500
that connector usually plugs into some
kind of riser inside of the server.

123
00:05:53.500 --> 00:05:56.400
It usually doesn't go straight
to the motherboard and

124
00:05:56.400 --> 00:05:58.690
I'll show you once we open
the server up how this one runs.

125
00:05:58.690 --> 00:06:04.510
But it's possible that the failure
has leapt from here to the riser,

126
00:06:04.510 --> 00:06:05.580
or even the motherboard.

127
00:06:05.580 --> 00:06:08.350
And the damage can be far more

You guys know,
like double As and triple As and

575
00:28:03.600 --> 00:28:05.220
all the other crazy ones
that are out there.

576
00:28:05.220 --> 00:28:10.540
But most motherboards have standardized
on a CR2032 watch battery for

577
00:28:10.540 --> 00:28:13.100
their clock, for their bios and CMOS and

578
00:28:13.100 --> 00:28:16.040
all the other good stuff that
needs to depend on that clock.

579
00:28:16.040 --> 00:28:18.130
So when we take a look at
a mother board like this one,

580
00:28:18.130 --> 00:28:23.030
usually somewhere if you look around, in
this one I don't have to look too far cuz

581
00:28:23.030 --> 00:28:29.430
it's right here by the CPU, you'll
find a circular CR2032 watch battery.

582
00:28:29.430 --> 00:28:33.520
Now, just because I said it's
a 2032 don't take my word for it.

583
00:28:33.520 --> 00:28:37.150
It might not be,
it might be a different battery types, so

584
00:28:37.150 --> 00:28:38.400
always double check that.

585
00:28:38.400 --> 00:28:41.040
And sometimes, they're removable,
sometimes they're not.

586
00:28:41.040 --> 00:28:43.744
At first glance, this one one
looks removable, it is all right,

587
00:28:43.744 --> 00:28:45.380
this one is removable.

588
00:28:45.380 --> 00:28:48.010
At first glance,
it looks removable because it is.

589
00:28:48.010 --> 00:28:52.050
And [LAUGH] if it's removable,
then we just can go in there and

590
00:28:52.050 --> 00:28:54.810
pry that with a simple screwdriver.

591
00:28:54.810 --> 00:28:58.280
Now If you're gonna actually start
manipulating components do remember

592
00:28:58.280 --> 00:29:02.610
to do the thing that I'm not doing,
which is wear an ESD wristband.

593
00:29:02.610 --> 00:29:05.402
Up until this point I haven't
really touched any components, so

594
00:29:05.402 --> 00:29:07.545
I haven't put myself at risk,
but I'm about to.

595
00:29:07.545 --> 00:29:10.097
So I'm gonna get out my ESD wristband.

596
00:29:10.097 --> 00:29:13.257
Do you guys remember this guy
from one of our other episodes.

597
00:29:13.257 --> 00:29:15.020
I have little tiny wrist, so

598
00:29:15.020 --> 00:29:19.060
I have to struggle with this
thing to get it adjusted right.

599
00:29:19.060 --> 00:29:21.917
But once it's on I can attach this
to the case to ground myself out and

600
00:29:21.917 --> 00:29:25.097
that's important especially since
I'm messing with a battery, right?

601
00:29:25.097 --> 00:29:26.810
You think a battery holds a charge?

602
00:29:26.810 --> 00:29:29.287
Well it should,
that's what it's job is, right?

603
00:29:29.287 --> 00:29:32.379
Now, a 2032 is nothing,
you could swallow one you'd be fine but

604
00:29:32.379 --> 00:29:33.535
don't quote me on that.

605
00:29:33.535 --> 00:29:38.846
[LAUGH] But as far as an electric shock,
it's not really a big deal.

606
00:29:38.846 --> 00:29:40.594
But I'm not worried about the battery,

607
00:29:40.594 --> 00:29:43.380
that's easy to replace I''m
worried about the mother board.

608
00:29:43.380 --> 00:29:46.160
Mother board, that's expensive that
gonna cost me a little bit more.

609
00:29:46.160 --> 00:29:47.832
So now I've got my ESD wristband,

610
00:29:47.832 --> 00:29:51.187
I'm gonna attach it to a nice solid
place here on the case somewhere.

611
00:29:51.187 --> 00:29:55.688
And you always wanna find some place were
you'll recognize if it pops off, right?

612
00:29:55.688 --> 00:29:58.819
Because I have had it before were you
attach it, and you think you're fine, and

613
00:29:58.819 --> 00:30:01.230
then after a few moments,
it pops off and you don't notice.

614
00:30:01.230 --> 00:30:03.801
But anyway I got a nice,
good spot right there on the chest,

615
00:30:03.801 --> 00:30:04.784
I was able to click to.

616
00:30:04.784 --> 00:30:06.317
All right, so now that I'm grounded out,

617
00:30:06.317 --> 00:30:08.114
I can come over here and
I can pop this battery out.

618
00:30:08.114 --> 00:30:11.890
Usually there's just a lever that
you can apply some pressure to, and

619
00:30:11.890 --> 00:30:13.426
the battery will pop loose.

620
00:30:13.426 --> 00:30:18.186
So if I do that again, I'm just gonna take
this screwdriver and apply a little bit of

621
00:30:18.186 --> 00:30:23.229
pressure, and that one will pop right out,
and once it's out, there's the battery.

622
00:30:23.229 --> 00:30:26.626
Pay attention to
the orientation of that battery,

623
00:30:26.626 --> 00:30:31.841
mine was set with the positive side up,
yours might be set positive side down.

624
00:30:31.841 --> 00:30:35.300
I've seen that on some Cisco equipment,
normally the positive side is up,

625
00:30:35.300 --> 00:30:37.800
so just be aware that
there's an orientation.

626
00:30:37.800 --> 00:30:40.662
And once its popped out, its kinda hard
to remember exactly how that's supposed

627
00:30:40.662 --> 00:30:42.447
to be,
unless you have another server to look at.

628
00:30:42.447 --> 00:30:46.293
So always pay attention to that,
but you can buy these at any store,

629
00:30:46.293 --> 00:30:50.478
they're all created equal, you can go
to any convenient store really and

630
00:30:50.478 --> 00:30:54.800
buy these things, assuming it's
a consistent model number, right?

631
00:30:54.800 --> 00:30:57.039
If it's a rare battery you might
need to get it from the vendor.

632
00:30:57.039 --> 00:31:00.141
And to maintain warranty support, you
should probably get the vendor to replace

633
00:31:00.141 --> 00:31:01.562
this anyway instead of you doing it.

634
00:31:01.562 --> 00:31:05.341
>> Don, I know that a place where
we've both worked together before,

635
00:31:05.341 --> 00:31:09.830
you had me replace these and
you mentioned that three year lifecycle.

636
00:31:09.830 --> 00:31:13.221
And I made the comment back
then well Don wait a second,

637
00:31:13.221 --> 00:31:17.445
I don't see time clocks changing here,
why are we replacing them?

638
00:31:17.445 --> 00:31:19.070
These batteries all look good and

639
00:31:19.070 --> 00:31:22.108
you made the mention that it's
preventative maintenance.

640
00:31:22.108 --> 00:31:25.535
Let's change them now, because then we
can ensure that they're gonna be good.

641
00:31:25.535 --> 00:31:29.875
>> Right better to change it on your
schedule than on some unknown schedule.

642
00:31:29.875 --> 00:31:32.463
Cuz what's gonna happen is
once your system is booted

643
00:31:32.463 --> 00:31:35.453
up you're probably syncing off
of a time server and all that,

644
00:31:35.453 --> 00:31:39.505
so you probably won't even notice if the
time gets wrong until you reboot, right?

645
00:31:39.505 --> 00:31:43.251
So maybe you've got some maintenance
window coming up where you told your boss

646
00:31:43.251 --> 00:31:45.644
hey, I need to install this update,
and reboot.

647
00:31:45.644 --> 00:31:48.019
It's just a quick reboot,
it'll take me five minutes.

648
00:31:48.019 --> 00:31:49.614
I need five minutes of downtime.

649
00:31:49.614 --> 00:31:53.757
And you reboot it And all of your config
is messed up because the BIOS clock got

650
00:31:53.757 --> 00:31:58.094
screwed up or whatever and now you got to
track down a battery and replace it, and

651
00:31:58.094 --> 00:32:02.690
all of a sudden that five minute
window becomes a 15 minute window.

652
00:32:02.690 --> 00:32:04.810
If you had known about the battery,
if you replaced it,

653
00:32:04.810 --> 00:32:06.290
that wouldn't have been a problem, right?

654
00:32:06.290 --> 00:32:09.925
And that isn't the only battery
on your system or it might be.

655
00:32:09.925 --> 00:32:13.810
But usually if you have a RAID controller
your going to have battery back

656
00:32:13.810 --> 00:32:15.280
right cache controller.

657
00:32:15.280 --> 00:32:17.990
And so when you look at a RAID controller
like the one that I've got back here on

658
00:32:17.990 --> 00:32:21.130
the server, it's actually get
a little atom board here from memory.

659
00:32:21.130 --> 00:32:25.090
And there'll typically
the battery attached to it also.

660
00:32:25.090 --> 00:32:28.460
Sometimes that battery's replaceable,
sometimes it is not.

661
00:32:28.460 --> 00:32:30.690
Sometimes it's removable and
sometimes it's not.

662
00:32:30.690 --> 00:32:33.940
If it's not removable,
you'll have to replace the entire board,

663
00:32:33.940 --> 00:32:35.910
which if it's under warranty
it's not a big deal.

664
00:32:35.910 --> 00:32:38.570
If it's not under warranty though that

665
00:32:38.570 --> 00:32:41.010
usually means you're exceeding
the lifetime of the server.

666
00:32:41.010 --> 00:32:44.610
They don't expect you to run these
servers for ten years or whatever.

667
00:32:44.610 --> 00:32:46.460
But in this case,
if I wanna get to that board,

668
00:32:46.460 --> 00:32:50.540
I'm gonna have to disconnect this
cable from the RAID controller.

669
00:32:50.540 --> 00:32:52.900
So I'll just pop that one off, and

670
00:32:52.900 --> 00:32:57.730
I do need to remember where this is
plugged in because when I finish,

671
00:32:57.730 --> 00:33:00.960
I need to put this thing back the way that
I found it or it's not gonna work right.

672
00:33:00.960 --> 00:33:05.530
So I plug this storage connection
into the other connector that can

673
00:33:05.530 --> 00:33:07.340
cause a problem with the drive ID's.

674
00:33:07.340 --> 00:33:12.110
HP servers will actually recover from that
just fine but some other vendors don't.

675
00:33:12.110 --> 00:33:15.420
So just a word to the wise there.

676
00:33:15.420 --> 00:33:18.610
Let me go ahead and
remove this whole riser board.

677
00:33:18.610 --> 00:33:21.120
Unfortunately I can't
get the RAID controller

678
00:33:21.120 --> 00:33:23.300
out while it's still
mounted in the system.

679
00:33:23.300 --> 00:33:27.040
So I've got to come in here and
unscrew this and get it undone,

680
00:33:27.040 --> 00:33:30.980
and then this whole board will come out.

681
00:33:30.980 --> 00:33:34.320
On some systems there'll actually be
a lever over here that you crank and

682
00:33:34.320 --> 00:33:36.430
that will release this board to pop out.

683
00:33:36.430 --> 00:33:40.570
On this one though, we're just
gonna come straight up with it, and

684
00:33:40.570 --> 00:33:43.840
it pops right out just
like that easy peasy.

685
00:33:43.840 --> 00:33:48.620
Now once that's done, now I can get this
RAID controller out of here a lot easier.

686
00:33:48.620 --> 00:33:50.990
It should just pop right out
doesn't even have a screw.

687
00:33:52.100 --> 00:33:54.280
And so we'll get that the rest
of the way out there we go.

688
00:33:55.990 --> 00:34:00.580
And I've managed to catch my ESD wrist
band which is why I don't like them.

689
00:34:00.580 --> 00:34:03.290
But now that I've got it out, I can take
a better look at the RAID controller, and

690
00:34:03.290 --> 00:34:04.820
kind of what's going on.

691
00:34:04.820 --> 00:34:08.530
And sometimes you'll see a very
obvious battery stuck on it.

692
00:34:08.530 --> 00:34:11.460
On this one, I actually don't
see a very obvious battery.

693
00:34:11.460 --> 00:34:13.825
So I'm hoping that it is
underneath this card.

694
00:34:13.825 --> 00:34:18.146
And so I'm gonna pop this card out and
flip it over.

695
00:34:18.146 --> 00:34:24.080
And, all right, so looking at this card,
this is the memory, right?

696
00:34:24.080 --> 00:34:26.520
So I've got, this is the right cache.

697
00:34:26.520 --> 00:34:30.040
It's been added on to the board,
but I'm not seeing a battery.

698
00:34:30.040 --> 00:34:31.310
And so when you look at it and

699
00:34:31.310 --> 00:34:35.870
you don't see a battery on the system
that usually means one of two things.

700
00:34:35.870 --> 00:34:37.660
Either one, the battery is integrated.

701
00:34:37.660 --> 00:34:40.150
There's several parts here that
are kinda covered that I can't see,

702
00:34:40.150 --> 00:34:43.540
and the battery could be under one
of those and it's not removable.

703
00:34:43.540 --> 00:34:47.310
Or two, it could mean that
the battery has been removed.

704
00:34:47.310 --> 00:34:50.070
That somebody's already
taken it off of this system.

705
00:34:50.070 --> 00:34:52.220
Now, I don't know if that's the case.

706
00:34:52.220 --> 00:34:54.500
I could have ordered it without a battery,
I suppose [INAUDIBLE].

707
00:34:54.500 --> 00:34:56.300
I forgot to put this in upside down.

708
00:34:56.300 --> 00:34:57.960
It's not always gonna be the case.

709
00:34:57.960 --> 00:35:01.007
But you'll notice there's a few extra
connectors on this RAID controller and

710
00:35:01.007 --> 00:35:03.419
potentially the battery was
designed to attach the outside.

711
00:35:03.419 --> 00:35:07.459
So I need to pull up the vendor
documentation on this to find that out and

712
00:35:07.459 --> 00:35:12.252
make sure that there's a connector right
on here that looks like it's geared up for

713
00:35:12.252 --> 00:35:14.770
a ribbon connector to run to something.

714
00:35:14.770 --> 00:35:16.910
You don't normally have a ribbon
connector to a battery though and

715
00:35:16.910 --> 00:35:17.960
the same thing here.

716
00:35:17.960 --> 00:35:18.910
So I don't think that's the case.

717
00:35:18.910 --> 00:35:22.310
This one's more than likely going to have
an integrated battery right on it and

718
00:35:22.310 --> 00:35:26.672
that way, well it can't be removed
which means I can't replace it.

719
00:35:26.672 --> 00:35:29.320
I'm gonna have to rely on the RAID
controller diagnostics tell me about

720
00:35:29.320 --> 00:35:31.480
the battery I'm just wanna
make sure that it's okay.

721
00:35:31.480 --> 00:35:33.120
And if it is then I don't worry about it.

722
00:35:33.120 --> 00:35:35.610
But if it's not okay I'll likely
send the whole board in for

723
00:35:35.610 --> 00:35:37.430
servicing which can be
a bit of a challenge.

724
00:35:38.990 --> 00:35:39.520
All right, so

725
00:35:39.520 --> 00:35:42.380
those are a couple of example of the
batteries that we're gonna find in there.

726
00:35:42.380 --> 00:35:46.560
One other type of battery that you may
have that I know this one doesn't is that

727
00:35:46.560 --> 00:35:51.530
if you have a remote access board
in it like a DRAC or an ILO board.

728
00:35:51.530 --> 00:35:55.155
That sometimes they'll have
their own battery too so

729
00:35:55.155 --> 00:36:00.830
that this is what we do safety of parts
that I put the cover right by Wes's feet.

730
00:36:00.830 --> 00:36:05.970
So but this is where, we need to be
aware that if the server loses power

731
00:36:05.970 --> 00:36:08.560
the remote access board loses power also,
right?

732
00:36:08.560 --> 00:36:11.480
So it might have it's own battery, it's
own internal battery so the remote access

733
00:36:11.480 --> 00:36:16.160
board can stay awake and I can reach in
and try and connect, and maintain it.

734
00:36:16.160 --> 00:36:19.070
If that's the case that's another
battery we need to be a part of our

735
00:36:19.070 --> 00:36:20.440
maintenance schedule.

736
00:36:20.440 --> 00:36:22.750
>> All right Don, well a lot of
fascinating information here.

737
00:36:22.750 --> 00:36:26.230
A lot of definitely a lot of moving
parts that we've gotta consider here.

738
00:36:26.230 --> 00:36:29.630
Now I am looking at the clock, and I do
see that we're running out of time, but

739
00:36:29.630 --> 00:36:31.670
we still got a little
bit more to talk about.

740
00:36:31.670 --> 00:36:35.210
So what do you say, we wrap this one up,
maybe come back into a part four.

741
00:36:35.210 --> 00:36:38.110
Give you a chance to fit some more
of the concepts in here that you

742
00:36:38.110 --> 00:36:39.160
still need to talk about?

743
00:36:39.160 --> 00:36:41.670
>> Absolutely, just a couple loose
ends to get through on this one, and

744
00:36:41.670 --> 00:36:43.010
then we'll wrap up from there.

745
00:36:43.010 --> 00:36:44.780
>> All right, that sounds good,
good place to stop.

746
00:36:44.780 --> 00:36:48.060
Thanks for being here Don, and thank you
to you the viewer watching out there.

747
00:36:48.060 --> 00:36:50.660
Signing out for ITProTV,
I'm been your host Wes Brian.

748
00:36:50.660 --> 00:36:51.630
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

749
00:36:51.630 --> 00:36:53.645
>> And we'll see you next time.

750
00:36:53.645 --> 00:36:59.550
[MUSIC]

751
00:36:59.550 --> 00:37:01.560
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their exploration of the concepts and techniques used in server maintenance. They look at preventative maintenance techniques like clearing dust out with ESD prevention through a electronics vacuum and proper shutdown procedures. Finally, they will talk about fault tolerance high availability through clustering, round-robin and heartbeats.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.950 --> 00:00:03.020
Welcome to ITproTV.

2
00:00:03.020 --> 00:00:06.894
I'm your host, Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.894 --> 00:00:08.399
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.399 --> 00:00:11.011
>> You're watching ITproTV.

5
00:00:12.200 --> 00:00:15.270
>> Hello, and welcome back to another
great episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.270 --> 00:00:16.620
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:16.620 --> 00:00:21.280
And in today's episode, we are continuing
through our Server Plus Comp TS Series.

8
00:00:21.280 --> 00:00:22.220
This is SK0004.

9
00:00:22.220 --> 00:00:27.040
And joining us back for, yes,
a part four in server maintenance,

10
00:00:27.040 --> 00:00:28.660
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

11
00:00:28.660 --> 00:00:29.800
Don, how you doing sir?

12
00:00:29.800 --> 00:00:31.160
>> Hey, I like to maintain things.

13
00:00:31.160 --> 00:00:32.010
What can I say?

14
00:00:32.010 --> 00:00:34.905
It's a critical piece
of what we do everyday.

15
00:00:34.905 --> 00:00:39.341
So, we're back again with what will
be the last episode, I promise,

16
00:00:39.341 --> 00:00:42.212
on stuff we need to do to maintain or
servers.

17
00:00:42.212 --> 00:00:46.039
And this last one is kind of made
up of a mixture of things, but

18
00:00:46.039 --> 00:00:48.754
lets just start off with air flow, right?

19
00:00:48.754 --> 00:00:49.865
Air flow and dust.

20
00:00:49.865 --> 00:00:52.258
Dust is the enemy of the server, right?

21
00:00:52.258 --> 00:00:55.678
Dust is, we don't think much
of it as human beings, right?

22
00:00:55.678 --> 00:00:59.513
Dust, it might annoy you,
you sneeze a bit, your hands get dusty,

23
00:00:59.513 --> 00:01:01.206
you wash your hands, right?

24
00:01:01.206 --> 00:01:04.502
But to a server,
dust actually does a few different things.

25
00:01:04.502 --> 00:01:06.640
First, it gets sucked in by the fans,
right?

26
00:01:06.640 --> 00:01:09.724
You got these high powered fans in your
servers constantly sucking in air which

27
00:01:09.724 --> 00:01:11.110
can bring in dust.

28
00:01:11.110 --> 00:01:14.170
And that air is being blown
across electrical components.

29
00:01:15.240 --> 00:01:17.000
Lots of corners and edges and

30
00:01:17.000 --> 00:01:20.520
little cables that can catch the dust and
hold the dust.

31
00:01:20.520 --> 00:01:21.840
So it doesn't leave.

32
00:01:21.840 --> 00:01:24.810
If the dust just passed right
through the server, went in and out,

33
00:01:24.810 --> 00:01:26.490
it's no big deal, right?

34
00:01:26.490 --> 00:01:27.192
But it doesn't do that.

35
00:01:27.192 --> 00:01:30.320
The dust deposits,
it stays inside of the server.

36
00:01:30.320 --> 00:01:33.620
And when it does that,
it can cause a few different problems.

37
00:01:33.620 --> 00:01:36.960
The most common problem is
it can obstruct air flow.

38
00:01:36.960 --> 00:01:40.780
Servers expect to have free
air flow from front to back.

39
00:01:40.780 --> 00:01:44.770
Well, if the front grille of
the server is packed full of dust,

40
00:01:44.770 --> 00:01:47.140
that's not gonna work out is it, right?

41
00:01:47.140 --> 00:01:50.580
But if air can pass through
the front grille, it can get inside.

42
00:01:50.580 --> 00:01:51.470
Well, once it gets inside,

43
00:01:51.470 --> 00:01:54.880
the air is supposed to be flowing

When it comes inside and

You want to make sure you got to

00:11:09.100 --> 00:11:13.250

00:11:13.250 --> 00:11:15.020

00:11:15.020 --> 00:11:19.180

00:11:19.180 --> 00:11:22.090
You have two or three servers do that job.

00:11:22.090 --> 00:11:24.898

00:11:24.898 --> 00:11:26.020
And that way,

00:11:26.020 --> 00:11:31.190
when the inevitable failure does occur,

00:11:31.190 --> 00:11:33.430
And they're doing it and
you don't have to worry about it.

259
00:11:33.430 --> 00:11:34.890
That's how Facebook runs.

00:11:34.890 --> 00:11:35.820
That's how Twitter runs.

00:11:35.820 --> 00:11:37.960
This is how all these

00:11:37.960 --> 00:11:41.180

00:11:41.180 --> 00:11:45.180

00:11:45.180 --> 00:11:47.020

00:11:47.020 --> 00:11:47.669

00:35:44.515 --> 00:35:45.295
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

721
00:35:45.295 --> 00:35:45.904
>> And we'll see you next time.

722
00:35:45.904 --> 00:35:53.218
[MUSIC]

723
00:35:53.218 --> 00:35:55.942
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore the realm of asset management and documentation. They will dive into topics like licensing, labeling and warranties. They talk about life cycle management, procurement, usage, end-of-life, disposal and inventory.
episodes.title: Asset Management and Documentation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.003 --> 00:00:02.735
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.735 --> 00:00:08.339
[CROSSTALK]
>> Your

3
00:00:08.339 --> 00:00:12.430
watching ITProTV
>> Hello and

4
00:00:12.430 --> 00:00:14.600
welcome to another great
episode here at ITVProTV.

5
00:00:14.600 --> 00:00:18.490
I'm your host Wes Bryan and in today's
episode, while this is a fun one.

6
00:00:18.490 --> 00:00:23.250
We're continuing on in our CompTIA
Server+ SK00004 certification class,

7
00:00:23.250 --> 00:00:27.200
and joining us in the studios today
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:27.200 --> 00:00:28.320
Don, how you doing, sir?

9
00:00:28.320 --> 00:00:30.940
>> I'm doing great, Wes,
ready to dive right back into Server+.

10
00:00:30.940 --> 00:00:33.770
And we're gonna be tackling
a topic today that is,

11
00:00:33.770 --> 00:00:36.900
it doesn't sound terribly exciting, right?

12
00:00:36.900 --> 00:00:39.830
It's asset management and documentation.

13
00:00:39.830 --> 00:00:44.380
And I can tell you all day long
how important documentation is but

14
00:00:44.380 --> 00:00:46.160
it doesn't change the fact
that it's boring.

15
00:00:46.160 --> 00:00:49.210
And it takes a lot of work and
people hate to do it.

16
00:00:49.210 --> 00:00:50.790
And people don't do it.

17
00:00:50.790 --> 00:00:56.010
You get a lot of that where people just
neglect to keep their systems documented,

18
00:00:56.010 --> 00:01:01.160
but the value of having good
asset management documentation is

19
00:01:01.160 --> 00:01:02.360
worth its weight in gold.

20
00:01:02.360 --> 00:01:03.360
It is super important.

21
00:01:03.360 --> 00:01:04.300
So even if you hate doing it,

22
00:01:04.300 --> 00:01:07.570
you need to take a little bit of time and
make sure that you get it set up right.

23
00:01:07.570 --> 00:01:10.710
So let's start off really simple with what
the heck am I even talking about here.

24
00:01:10.710 --> 00:01:13.000
Well what is asset management and
documentation?

25
00:01:13.000 --> 00:01:15.390
Well documentation we should already know.

26
00:01:15.390 --> 00:01:18.480
Whenever we set up a system,
whenever we purchase servers,

27
00:01:18.480 --> 00:01:20.670
whenever we install an operating system.

28
00:01:20.670 --> 00:01:22.020
We configure backups.

29
00:01:22.020 --> 00:01:23.740
We should be documenting what we do.

30
00:01:23.740 --> 00:01:25.660
Writing it down on paper.

31
00:01:25.660 --> 00:01:28.160
Hey, I just setup this backup software.

32
00:01:28.160 --> 00:01:29.080
I'm gonna write that down.

33
00:01:29.080 --> 00:01:30.170
I setup a backup software.

34
00:01:30.170 --> 00:01:31.910
So I know when it was installed.

35
00:01:31.910 --> 00:01:34.050
Who did it, right, how they did it.

36
00:01:34.050 --> 00:01:37.120
And the reason we need to know how they
did it is, if we ever have to rebuild our

37
00:01:37.120 --> 00:01:39.820
environment, if we have to do disaster
recovery, we need to go through and

38
00:01:39.820 --> 00:01:41.980
rebuild that stuff, right?

39
00:01:41.980 --> 00:01:44.220
And then when I deploy
the backup software,

40
00:01:44.220 --> 00:01:47.380
I then need to create
documentation on how to use it,

41
00:01:47.380 --> 00:01:50.220
how to make sure it's running fine,
how to do maintenance on it.

42
00:01:50.220 --> 00:01:55.380
And how to actually recover lost
data with the backup software.

43
00:01:55.380 --> 00:01:56.420
And we have all that document, and

44
00:01:56.420 --> 00:01:59.250
we know how to use the technology
that we purchased.

45
00:01:59.250 --> 00:02:02.160
A lot of people never even bother learning
the technology they purchased, better yet

46
00:02:02.160 --> 00:02:03.670
documenting the technology.

47
00:02:03.670 --> 00:02:06.056
And that's when we get
sayings like the 80/20 rule.

48
00:02:06.056 --> 00:02:09.750
Where 80% of the people only
use 20% of the features.

49
00:02:09.750 --> 00:02:14.010
That most software goes underutilized,
and that's a very, very true story.

50
00:02:14.010 --> 00:02:16.760
A lot of people don't use
their software to its fullest

51
00:02:16.760 --> 00:02:20.500
because they didn't take time to read the
documentation provided by the vendors and

52
00:02:20.500 --> 00:02:24.150
create their own documentation so
that people within the company can use

53
00:02:24.150 --> 00:02:26.780
that software or
hardware to its fullest, all right?

54
00:02:26.780 --> 00:02:29.100
So we're gonna talk more
about documentation later on.

55
00:02:29.100 --> 00:02:32.900
But one of the critical types of
documentation that we're going to do

56
00:02:32.900 --> 00:02:36.770
is what's called asset management, and
that's what we're gonna focus on first.

57
00:02:36.770 --> 00:02:41.140
When you buy stuff, if you're just
buying something for you at home, so

58
00:02:41.140 --> 00:02:44.040
I decide I need a new wireless router for
home.

59
00:02:44.040 --> 00:02:47.180
I might go to, I don't know,

60
00:02:47.180 --> 00:02:51.010
an electronics store somebody like Best
Buy or JB Hi-Fi or somebody like that and

61
00:02:51.010 --> 00:02:55.530
I go and buy a router and I hook it up
at home and that's the end of it right?

62
00:02:55.530 --> 00:02:58.440
I don't have to get permission,
well maybe from my wife, right?

63
00:02:58.440 --> 00:03:01.650
But I don't have to fill out forms and

64
00:03:01.650 --> 00:03:04.590
do a business case scenario or
anything like that.

65
00:03:04.590 --> 00:03:06.400
I just go and buy it and that's that.

66
00:03:06.400 --> 00:03:08.530
Because we're talking about
the economics of a home, right,

67
00:03:08.530 --> 00:03:10.760
so not a huge amount of money.

68
00:03:10.760 --> 00:03:11.980
It was, well my home.

69
00:03:11.980 --> 00:03:16.600
But when you talk about a business where
you might have a multi-billion dollar

70
00:03:16.600 --> 00:03:19.510
organization that's spread
across multiple continents and

71
00:03:19.510 --> 00:03:22.870
you're not buying one router,
you're buying 1,000 routers.

72
00:03:22.870 --> 00:03:27.300
And those routers don't cost $100,
those routers cost $4,000 each.

73
00:03:27.300 --> 00:03:30.520
Now you're talking about
big amounts of money.

74
00:03:30.520 --> 00:03:35.230
And there needs to be a process in place
for how you choose what equipment you

75
00:03:35.230 --> 00:03:38.520
purchase, how you purchase it, how you
negotiate the price of that purchase.

76
00:03:38.520 --> 00:03:43.790
And that is the first stage of what's
called the equipment lifecycle.

77
00:03:43.790 --> 00:03:47.180
Every device has a lifecycle
that it goes through and

78
00:03:47.180 --> 00:03:50.480
asset management is how
we track that lifecycle.

79
00:03:50.480 --> 00:03:52.310
It starts with selecting the equipment.

80
00:03:52.310 --> 00:03:54.900
How do you pick what the heck
it is you're gonna buy?

81
00:03:54.900 --> 00:03:57.480
And different companies have
different procedures for that.

82
00:03:57.480 --> 00:04:02.130
I have a friend who works for a really
large organization, where his job is R&D,

83
00:04:02.130 --> 00:04:03.990
he's in research and development.

84
00:04:03.990 --> 00:04:06.620
He doesn't actually deploy
any production equipment.

85
00:04:06.620 --> 00:04:10.020
I make fun of him for it all the time,
cuz he doesn't actually do anything.

86
00:04:10.020 --> 00:04:11.850
Well, anything that end users notice.

87
00:04:11.850 --> 00:04:14.020
What he does is stuff that
end users don't notice.

88
00:04:14.020 --> 00:04:17.920
He's one who will test out ten different
routers, or ten different firewalls, and

89
00:04:17.920 --> 00:04:20.220
make sure they meet
the needs of the company.

90
00:04:20.220 --> 00:04:25.600
And select the best one, based on price,
performance, reliability, and a number

91
00:04:25.600 --> 00:04:30.060
of other criteria that they've defined and
prioritize is important for that company.

92
00:04:30.060 --> 00:04:35.760
That's stage one of a lifecycle, selecting
the equipment and then acquiring it.

93
00:04:35.760 --> 00:04:38.390
Then you've got configuring the equipment.

94
00:04:38.390 --> 00:04:39.210
It's gotta be configured.

95
00:04:39.210 --> 00:04:41.330
It has to have a configuration
placed on it so

96
00:04:41.330 --> 00:04:43.670
that it's ready to work in production.

97
00:04:43.670 --> 00:04:47.890
Then we deploy it, it actually goes
into production and is put into use.

98
00:04:47.890 --> 00:04:49.490
And from there we maintain it, right?

99
00:04:49.490 --> 00:04:53.090
We watch the equipment, make sure it
does the job it's supposed to do.

100
00:04:53.090 --> 00:04:55.150
And then finally after several years,

101
00:04:55.150 --> 00:04:58.990
hopefully, we identify that it's
time to replace the equipment.

102
00:04:58.990 --> 00:05:01.410
Maybe faster and
newer technologies have come out.

103
00:05:01.410 --> 00:05:04.520
Maybe the hardware is wearing down,
some moving parts like fans,

104
00:05:04.520 --> 00:05:05.930
eventually they go bad.

105
00:05:05.930 --> 00:05:08.350
Maybe the warranty is no longer valid.

106
00:05:08.350 --> 00:05:09.290
If you buy a server,

107
00:05:09.290 --> 00:05:13.430
if you go to Dell or HP, you can get
three year warranties all day long.

108
00:05:13.430 --> 00:05:16.510
On some of the equipment you can
extend to a five year warranty.

109
00:05:16.510 --> 00:05:20.440
But beyond five years, it's pretty hard to
get warranty service on that equipment and

110
00:05:20.440 --> 00:05:25.060
so maybe we are just coming up around year
four and we know your five is coming up

111
00:05:25.060 --> 00:05:27.890
and our warranty is coming up,
we need to replace the server.

112
00:05:27.890 --> 00:05:29.360
That's part of that lifecycle.

113
00:05:29.360 --> 00:05:31.283
So now we start identifying
the replacement and

114
00:05:31.283 --> 00:05:33.530
the lifecycle starts again, right.

115
00:05:33.530 --> 00:05:35.070
We pick the replacement.

116
00:05:35.070 --> 00:05:36.340
We configure the replacement.

117
00:05:36.340 --> 00:05:38.010
We deploy the replacement.

118
00:05:38.010 --> 00:05:39.850
We maintain the replacement.

119
00:05:39.850 --> 00:05:44.560
And eventually we replace and
finally dispose of the replacement.

120
00:05:44.560 --> 00:05:48.710
The disposition is that end piece where we
actually toss the equipment into the junk.

121
00:05:48.710 --> 00:05:51.190
So that's the equipment lifecycle.

122
00:05:51.190 --> 00:05:55.420
And asset management is all
about tracking that lifecycle.

123
00:05:55.420 --> 00:05:57.020
What equipment do we have?

124
00:05:57.020 --> 00:05:58.520
What version is it?

125
00:05:58.520 --> 00:05:59.500
How much did it cost?

126
00:05:59.500 --> 00:06:01.370
Was PO was issued for it?

127
00:06:01.370 --> 00:06:02.790
Is it under warranty?

128
00:06:02.790 --> 00:06:06.330
If it's not under warranty or if it's
coming up on its end, when is the end?

129
00:06:06.330 --> 00:06:07.770
When does it run out of warranty?

130
00:06:07.770 --> 00:06:12.130
If something goes wrong and
it's under warranty, who do we call?

131
00:06:12.130 --> 00:06:14.260
That is part of asset management.

132
00:06:14.260 --> 00:06:17.400
And this way, when you walk into big
corporations or you go into a hospital or

133
00:06:17.400 --> 00:06:22.910
a school and you see a laptop,
that yeah you might see a Dell logo or

134
00:06:22.910 --> 00:06:25.560
a HP logo or an Apple logo or whatever.

135
00:06:25.560 --> 00:06:30.010
But not too far from there,
you'll see a little asset label.

136
00:06:30.010 --> 00:06:34.010
A label that will say something like,
IT ProTV 00124768 and so

137
00:06:34.010 --> 00:06:39.930
we know that's the IT ProTV asset label,
the asset tag.

138
00:06:39.930 --> 00:06:44.060
And then when that laptop was purchased
that's the number we assigned it.

139
00:06:44.060 --> 00:06:48.418
So that we can go into our system and look
up that number and find that exact laptop

140
00:06:48.418 --> 00:06:52.579
and, find out is it under warranty,
how much did we pay for it, how long have

141
00:06:52.579 --> 00:06:56.703
we had it for, all the other things
that are part of that asset management.

142
00:06:56.703 --> 00:06:57.540
All right now,

143
00:06:57.540 --> 00:07:01.740
why use an asset tag instead of
using the serial number for a unit?

144
00:07:01.740 --> 00:07:04.760
Because that my laptop has a serial
number, Wes' laptop has a serial number,

145
00:07:04.760 --> 00:07:06.750
in fact our,
both of our laptops are Apple laptops.

146
00:07:06.750 --> 00:07:12.010
So the serial numbers are very similar but
we got the TV that

147
00:07:12.010 --> 00:07:16.040
I'm looking at right ahead here or the
camera the robotic camera I'm staring at.

148
00:07:16.040 --> 00:07:19.280
We've got lights and
things they got serial numbers but

149
00:07:19.280 --> 00:07:20.550
they're in a different format.

150
00:07:20.550 --> 00:07:23.280
Different companies choose the format for
the serial number.

151
00:07:23.280 --> 00:07:28.100
If it's a small company that serial
number might just be six numbers.

152
00:07:28.100 --> 00:07:31.890
But if it's somebody like Apple, it's
gonna be a long number with letters and

153
00:07:31.890 --> 00:07:33.220
numbers so they can maximize that, right.

154
00:07:33.220 --> 00:07:34.790
It's gonna get bigger and
bigger and bigger.

155
00:07:34.790 --> 00:07:37.630
So different serial number formats make it

156
00:07:37.630 --> 00:07:40.960
were that's not a really
great way to track a system.

157
00:07:40.960 --> 00:07:43.240
And sometimes it's just annoying,

158
00:07:43.240 --> 00:07:47.880
right, because the serial number will
be written underneath the computer or

159
00:07:47.880 --> 00:07:50.250
you got to like, on a server, a lot of
times they'll put it on top of the server.

160
00:07:50.250 --> 00:07:51.240
So, you got to slide the server

161
00:07:51.240 --> 00:07:53.740
out of the rack to be able to see
the serial number on top of it.

162
00:07:53.740 --> 00:07:55.739
When we make our own asset tags,
you can put it wherever you want.

163
00:07:55.739 --> 00:07:58.849
You can put right on
the faceplate of the server and

164
00:07:58.849 --> 00:08:01.303
now I can see the asset tag right there.

165
00:08:01.303 --> 00:08:03.209
I know exactly where I can go and
look that up.

166
00:08:03.209 --> 00:08:06.909
Now, Once I have an asset tag,
what does that correspond to?

167
00:08:06.909 --> 00:08:11.420
Well, we're typically gonna leverage
some kinda asset management software.

168
00:08:11.420 --> 00:08:15.770
And that asset management software can be
really fancy or it can be really low tech.

169
00:08:15.770 --> 00:08:17.560
It could be no tech.

170
00:08:17.560 --> 00:08:21.450
The old way of asset management is anytime
I bought something, I got an invoice and

171
00:08:21.450 --> 00:08:22.410
I stuck it in a file.

172
00:08:23.450 --> 00:08:27.560
And then, when it came to have me
look it up again, I shifted to

173
00:08:27.560 --> 00:08:30.620
a bunch of file until I find it with take
hours to find anything it was a nightmare.

174
00:08:31.620 --> 00:08:35.420
But thanks to computers, we can
actually automate a lot of this stuff.

175
00:08:35.420 --> 00:08:37.680
And a simple spreadsheet is all you need.

176
00:08:37.680 --> 00:08:41.820
A spreadsheet with one column, that is
the tag number and the other column is

177
00:08:41.820 --> 00:08:44.700
the serial number and another column
is the purchase date and another column

178
00:08:44.700 --> 00:08:48.060
that's the warranty expiration date,
the basic information you need.

179
00:08:49.240 --> 00:08:53.260
But as time goes on,
you're gonna find that you have more and

180
00:08:53.260 --> 00:08:54.800
more information you need to track.

181
00:08:54.800 --> 00:08:57.670
More and more stuff that's considered
important for your company.

182
00:08:57.670 --> 00:09:00.940
And as you create
additional documentation,

183
00:09:00.940 --> 00:09:02.690
that's gonna get wrapped up into this.

184
00:09:02.690 --> 00:09:05.550
And things start to get more and
more complex.

185
00:09:05.550 --> 00:09:07.870
And a simple spreadsheet
can't hack it anymore.

186
00:09:07.870 --> 00:09:10.780
And so, there are a number
of companies out there that

187
00:09:10.780 --> 00:09:12.890
make amazing asset management software.

188
00:09:12.890 --> 00:09:16.150
Some of it can even do
automatic discovery,

189
00:09:16.150 --> 00:09:19.785
where it can scan your network and
find the devices on the network.

190
00:09:19.785 --> 00:09:22.670
And add the serial number and
add a little inflation.

191
00:09:22.670 --> 00:09:24.567
Can't tell you if it's only one or two.

192
00:09:24.567 --> 00:09:26.890
Can't tell you the one that was
purchased or how much you paid.

193
00:09:26.890 --> 00:09:30.450
But you can at least harvest the inventory
and get it put into the system so

194
00:09:30.450 --> 00:09:32.380
you don't have to start from scratch.

195
00:09:32.380 --> 00:09:36.000
But the key piece about any of
the software is just make it quick and

196
00:09:36.000 --> 00:09:39.720
easy to be able to determine where
in the lifecycle that equipment is.

197
00:09:39.720 --> 00:09:42.740
And how it should be managed and
how it should be tracked.

198
00:09:42.740 --> 00:09:45.000
From an IT side, I care about that.

199
00:09:45.000 --> 00:09:48.590
I want my equipment to keep running,
and keeping it under warranty,

200
00:09:48.590 --> 00:09:52.270
keeping it refreshed at
a proper interval is important.

201
00:09:52.270 --> 00:09:55.220
But from a financial side,
you're more than likely required.

202
00:09:55.220 --> 00:10:00.290
When a company buys a server, that's
a physical asset that the company owns.

203
00:10:00.290 --> 00:10:02.170
And it has a certain value.

204
00:10:02.170 --> 00:10:05.850
And that value is something
you have to pay taxes on.

205
00:10:05.850 --> 00:10:10.340
Well, each year the value of that server
decreases and it's called depreciation.

206
00:10:10.340 --> 00:10:12.710
So every year it depreciates in value and

207
00:10:12.710 --> 00:10:16.170
so they can pay less taxes on
it because it depreciated.

208
00:10:16.170 --> 00:10:19.269
Or what they actually do is take
a loss and you get a tax discount.

209
00:10:19.269 --> 00:10:20.600
We won't get into that.

210
00:10:20.600 --> 00:10:24.310
We'll save that for
ITs CPA TV, and [LAUGH] so

211
00:10:24.310 --> 00:10:26.030
we'll get into that some other day.

212
00:10:26.030 --> 00:10:30.800
But basically as a financial reason,
they need to track what they own, and

213
00:10:30.800 --> 00:10:32.270
how much they paid for it.

214
00:10:32.270 --> 00:10:36.270
And then, that way when it is time to
dispose of the equipment, they can write

215
00:10:36.270 --> 00:10:41.760
that off as a material asset that
they no longer have possession of.

216
00:10:41.760 --> 00:10:45.070
>> You know Don, I've seen, especially
as hosting with you on this show too,

217
00:10:45.070 --> 00:10:47.870
that certain devices you can buy them and
you think,

218
00:10:47.870 --> 00:10:50.490
now I've got the functionality
that I need, I'm ready to go.

219
00:10:50.490 --> 00:10:53.310
And then,
if you haven't done your research I guess,

220
00:10:53.310 --> 00:10:56.130
if you do your research this
isn't a problem, you realize that

221
00:10:56.130 --> 00:10:59.200
certain functionalities that you need,
they're behind a wall of money,

222
00:10:59.200 --> 00:11:00.090
you have to add-
>> [LAUGH]

223
00:11:00.090 --> 00:11:00.950
>> That functionality.

224
00:11:00.950 --> 00:11:02.860
I could think of the Cisco ASAs.

00:21:59.370 --> 00:22:03.570
It's tied to the server but its

00:22:03.570 --> 00:22:07.490

00:22:07.490 --> 00:22:09.920

00:22:09.920 --> 00:22:12.070
Now the screen that I'm on here

00:22:12.070 --> 00:22:13.480

00:22:13.480 --> 00:22:17.070

00:22:17.070 --> 00:22:17.810
change all of this.

00:22:17.810 --> 00:22:21.850

00:22:21.850 --> 00:22:25.180
We can start to define
the child assets and so

00:22:25.180 --> 00:22:28.610
on specifying each of those in
here based on what my need is.

459
00:22:28.610 --> 00:22:31.390
And this are just the basic assets then
we start getting the things like our

00:22:31.390 --> 00:22:32.650
details, right?

461
00:22:32.650 --> 00:22:34.771
What's the serial number for the unit?

462
00:22:34.771 --> 00:22:37.323
If I'm having a problem with
that domain controller and

00:22:37.323 --> 00:22:38.960
it looks like a hard drive failure.

464
00:22:38.960 --> 00:22:42.928
And I need to call Lenovo to
get a replacement hard drive.

465
00:22:42.928 --> 00:22:46.380
I don't want to have to go into the server
room and slide the server out of the rack.

466
00:22:46.380 --> 00:22:48.834
So that I can read the little
serial number right off the top or

467
00:22:48.834 --> 00:22:49.951
Dell puts them on the back.

468
00:22:49.951 --> 00:22:51.000
And it's always dark.

469
00:22:51.000 --> 00:22:52.850
Now you've got to get a flashlight and
you've got to shine it in there.

470
00:22:52.850 --> 00:22:54.840
And try and see, it's a pain.

471
00:22:54.840 --> 00:22:56.360
Well, I can just pull it up right here.

472
00:22:56.360 --> 00:22:58.010
Here's my serial number.

473
00:22:58.010 --> 00:23:00.210
Now how does a serial number get in there?

474
00:23:00.210 --> 00:23:03.790
Maybe we have a network management
software that lets us gather that data.

475
00:23:03.790 --> 00:23:07.380
But normally whenever you buy hardware,

476
00:23:07.380 --> 00:23:10.410
somebody checks it in as part
of the procurement process.

477
00:23:10.410 --> 00:23:13.311
And by checking it in,
I mean they enter it right here.

478
00:23:13.311 --> 00:23:16.110
They punch in the name of the server,
the serial number.

479
00:23:16.110 --> 00:23:17.077
The IP address and

480
00:23:17.077 --> 00:23:20.630
name that's gonna be assigned to
it if we have that information.

481
00:23:20.630 --> 00:23:21.657
We might not have that information yet.

482
00:23:21.657 --> 00:23:23.443
In which case,
this becomes a place holder.

483
00:23:23.443 --> 00:23:25.609
And we put the serial number in.

484
00:23:25.609 --> 00:23:27.761
And then when it comes
time to actually apply or

485
00:23:27.761 --> 00:23:29.810
provision that server in our environment.

486
00:23:29.810 --> 00:23:32.730
Then we have to come back and
repopulate this.

487
00:23:32.730 --> 00:23:36.240
This becomes part of our
documentation process.

488
00:23:36.240 --> 00:23:40.750
Any time I deploy a new server, I've
gotta come and update this information.

489
00:23:40.750 --> 00:23:42.730
Some of them it be dynamically gathered,
right.

490
00:23:42.730 --> 00:23:45.010
And that way if I do an operating
system upgrade or whatever,

491
00:23:45.010 --> 00:23:46.470
it's automatically entered in here.

492
00:23:46.470 --> 00:23:49.670
But some of it can't be,
some of it has to be manually entered in.

493
00:23:49.670 --> 00:23:52.080
There's no way the system can
figure out what my warranty is.

494
00:23:52.080 --> 00:23:55.020
So I've got to come in and tell it,
it's got a three year warranty.

495
00:23:55.020 --> 00:23:56.610
And here's the purchase date.

496
00:23:56.610 --> 00:23:58.430
So it's three years
from the purchase date.

497
00:23:58.430 --> 00:24:00.870
Or we can put in a purchase
order number and tied to that.

498
00:24:00.870 --> 00:24:04.788
Because I might have one purchase
order for 700 desktops, and so

499
00:24:04.788 --> 00:24:05.897
I can put those in.

500
00:24:05.897 --> 00:24:07.856
You might have received them
on different dates, but

501
00:24:07.856 --> 00:24:09.780
they were all purchased on
the same purchase order.

502
00:24:09.780 --> 00:24:14.758
A lot of times A lot of times warranties
do what's called code termination.

503
00:24:14.758 --> 00:24:19.576
Code termination is where I might have
had 700 laptops that were bought over

504
00:24:19.576 --> 00:24:24.720
the course of two months and all
are warranties end on the exact same day.

505
00:24:24.720 --> 00:24:25.700
And that sounds bad.

506
00:24:25.700 --> 00:24:27.760
You're like well, I'm technically losing,

507
00:24:27.760 --> 00:24:31.320
on some of those I'll lose two months
of warranty but from a financial and

508
00:24:31.320 --> 00:24:37.340
accounting side, it's way easier to renew
the 700 warranties on the same day,

509
00:24:37.340 --> 00:24:40.930
than it is to renew every single
day over the course of two months.

510
00:24:40.930 --> 00:24:42.620
Cuz that's when you've
brought these laptops in.

511
00:24:42.620 --> 00:24:44.550
So co-termination is something
that is pretty common.

512
00:24:44.550 --> 00:24:47.240
I deal with that with some
of my personal licenses,

513
00:24:47.240 --> 00:24:48.750
the software licenses that I use.

514
00:24:48.750 --> 00:24:52.100
So you might have to specify
that in here too, all right?

515
00:24:52.100 --> 00:24:54.530
If you're PCI complaint or
you have other regulations,

516
00:24:54.530 --> 00:24:57.530
you might need to do audits on
the equipment periodically.

517
00:24:57.530 --> 00:25:01.450
And so you can set the last audit date or
when the next upcoming audit date is.

518
00:25:01.450 --> 00:25:05.280
However you want to do that and
other information tacked in here.

519
00:25:05.280 --> 00:25:08.230
This is all really useful information.

520
00:25:08.230 --> 00:25:11.300
If you start seeing weird traffic on the
network and you've got a Mac address for

521
00:25:11.300 --> 00:25:14.320
it, you could search in the asset
database for that Mac address.

522
00:25:14.320 --> 00:25:16.010

523
00:25:16.010 --> 00:25:19.110
I know it's IP, I know it's name, I know
what version of software is running,

524
00:25:19.110 --> 00:25:22.285
as far as we know assuming
no one's messed with it.

525
00:25:22.285 --> 00:25:24.415
>> Don, one of the things that I'm
impressed by the software that you're

526
00:25:24.415 --> 00:25:27.935
showing us is the granular
documentation you can do.

527
00:25:27.935 --> 00:25:30.065
Is that something that is
specific to solar winds,

528
00:25:30.065 --> 00:25:32.795
which might be why you like
it r is it consistency?

529
00:25:34.495 --> 00:25:36.235
>> Generally you will find
most software has this.

530
00:25:36.235 --> 00:25:39.895
Now just we will go off
the certification beaten path here.

531
00:25:39.895 --> 00:25:43.660
If you don't have asset management
software, and you are looking to buy one,

532
00:25:43.660 --> 00:25:47.190
that the key thing for me, and
most people fix it on price right.

533
00:25:47.190 --> 00:25:48.340
So price is important.

534
00:25:48.340 --> 00:25:51.390
The Solar Winds is not the cheapest,

535
00:25:51.390 --> 00:25:56.510
It's a reasonable price but a lot of
asset management software out there

00:25:56.510 --> 00:25:58.910

537
00:25:58.910 --> 00:25:59.740
You have to customize it.

538
00:25:59.740 --> 00:26:03.180
You have to get in there and customize
all sorts of things to get it to work for

539
00:26:03.180 --> 00:26:07.230
your environment and that's one area
where Solar Winds kind of specializes is.

540
00:26:07.230 --> 00:26:09.530
Hey, we're gonna make this software
work the moment you install it.

541
00:26:09.530 --> 00:26:11.110

So that's kind of why I like it,

00:26:23.670 --> 00:26:26.910

548
00:26:26.910 --> 00:26:29.790

549

CA, the computer associates they have

Excel, you can use it.

556
00:26:45.310 --> 00:26:47.680

557
00:26:47.680 --> 00:26:49.660
>> All right, Don, well,

>> Yeah,

00:27:18.280 --> 00:27:20.120

00:27:26.570 --> 00:27:28.720

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:03.483
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.483 --> 00:00:08.171
[CROSSTALK]

3

>> Hello and welcome to another
great episode here at ITProTV,

5
00:00:14.908 --> 00:00:16.340
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:16.340 --> 00:00:19.091
And in today's episode we
are continuing through

7

our CompTIA Server+ SK0004 Certification.

8

And well, we're actually coming back
with a part two cuz I had to cut him off

00:00:25.658 --> 00:00:28.170

was talking way too much.

10
00:00:28.170 --> 00:00:32.180
We're coming back with a part two on
asset management and documentation.

11
00:00:32.180 --> 00:00:34.660
Joining us in the studios for
this endeavour is none other than Mr.

12
00:00:34.660 --> 00:00:35.300
Don Pezet.

13
00:00:35.300 --> 00:00:36.390
Don how you're doing sir?

14
00:00:36.390 --> 00:00:37.430
>> I'm doing just well, Les.

15
00:00:37.430 --> 00:00:41.860
In the last episode we really focused on
asset management more than documentation.

16
00:00:41.860 --> 00:00:45.240
Although, I did say asset management
is part of documentation.

17
00:00:45.240 --> 00:00:46.840
So, it's really kind of
part of that umbrella.

18
00:00:46.840 --> 00:00:50.440
In this episode, I want to talk about some
of the other types of documentation that

19
00:00:50.440 --> 00:00:53.570
we need to be performing on our
network and keeping a record of at

20
00:00:53.570 --> 00:00:57.050
any given time to make sure that
everything is on the up and up.

21
00:00:57.050 --> 00:00:58.880
It's really kind of
an important thing to do.

22
00:00:58.880 --> 00:01:02.260
So, What we were looking at in
the last episode was tracking

23
00:01:02.260 --> 00:01:05.530
the assets that we have and
whether they're under warranty and

24
00:01:05.530 --> 00:01:07.970
what their serial numbers are and
all that.

25
00:01:07.970 --> 00:01:12.920
But once the asset is logged in it's
going through it's life cycle, right.

26
00:01:12.920 --> 00:01:16.880
We've purchased it, we've deployed it,
it's now in production.

27
00:01:16.880 --> 00:01:20.060
And we need to track what
happens to it over time.

28
00:01:20.060 --> 00:01:22.370
And that needs to be documented too.

29
00:01:22.370 --> 00:01:24.860
And I'm gonna go back into
the Solar Winds Web Help Desk,

30
00:01:24.860 --> 00:01:26.990
the software that I was
using in the last episode.

31
00:01:26.990 --> 00:01:29.560
And we had looked at asset basics and
asset details.

32
00:01:29.560 --> 00:01:34.230
But you'll notice the next two tabs here,
asset history and ticket history.

33
00:01:34.230 --> 00:01:38.210
And when I go into something like
the asset history, we can start to look at

34
00:01:38.210 --> 00:01:42.530
things that have changed on that as
far as for example, warranty renewals.

35
00:01:42.530 --> 00:01:45.190
I might have renewed this
a few times over the years.

36
00:01:45.190 --> 00:01:49.827
If it's an older server it might have been
purchased with a three year warranty, and

37
00:01:49.827 --> 00:01:52.046
then as we got closer to the three years,

38
00:01:52.046 --> 00:01:54.550
we decided to extend it
out to the five year.

39
00:01:54.550 --> 00:01:56.490
And so that's a change in the asset.

40
00:01:56.490 --> 00:01:59.005
And so you'll see some different things
in here, I haven't updated this one.

41
00:01:59.005 --> 00:02:00.020
So these are just synchronized.

42
00:02:00.020 --> 00:02:02.010
See how I was saying
synchronize by import?

43
00:02:02.010 --> 00:02:05.280
They imported this from some other
kind of spreadsheet system, or

44
00:02:05.280 --> 00:02:07.380
other technology that was in place.

45
00:02:07.380 --> 00:02:09.770
But ticket history is
probably the most valuable.

46
00:02:09.770 --> 00:02:12.270
Is that as tickets get
logged into the system,

47
00:02:12.270 --> 00:02:15.340
somebody has a problem,
there's a record of it right here.

48
00:02:15.340 --> 00:02:18.390
And I can start to see what's been
happening with that system, and

49
00:02:18.390 --> 00:02:21.180
is there a consistent pattern of failure?

50
00:02:21.180 --> 00:02:24.760
Because I've spotted that before
using asset systems like this.

51
00:02:24.760 --> 00:02:29.310
For example, we had a fiber optic
line that went down once, and

52
00:02:29.310 --> 00:02:31.480
it went down for a period of two hours.

53
00:02:31.480 --> 00:02:33.530
And it was just kind of
one of those weird things.

54
00:02:33.530 --> 00:02:36.960
We called up the service provider,
and they found a switch

55
00:02:36.960 --> 00:02:41.140
port that had locked up, and they had
reset that port and everything was fine.

56
00:02:41.140 --> 00:02:43.660
Well two months later, it happened again.

57
00:02:43.660 --> 00:02:45.750
And two months after that,
it happened again.

58
00:02:45.750 --> 00:02:47.840
Now it was far enough apart, right,

59
00:02:47.840 --> 00:02:50.920
60 days apart that I might not
have picked up on a pattern.

60
00:02:50.920 --> 00:02:54.030
But when I was looking at
the tickets logged in the system,

61
00:02:54.030 --> 00:02:57.200
I could see them on
the exact same interval.

62
00:02:57.200 --> 00:02:59.290
60 days apart.

63
00:02:59.290 --> 00:03:00.840
These three occurrences.

64
00:03:00.840 --> 00:03:04.390
And so I was able to pick up a pattern,
and then we were able to identify that

65
00:03:04.390 --> 00:03:06.630
switch port was locking up
because of a memory leak.

66
00:03:06.630 --> 00:03:11.410
And it was taking 60 days for
the memory buffers to fill, and then lock.

67
00:03:11.410 --> 00:03:14.350
And a reset would fix it,
for 60 more days.

68
00:03:14.350 --> 00:03:18.000
And so being able to spot that kind of a
pattern is able to be done when you've got

69
00:03:18.000 --> 00:03:20.420
a ticket history that
you can track like that.

70
00:03:20.420 --> 00:03:23.550
So a lot of people fixate on tickets
As far as what's going on right now.

71
00:03:23.550 --> 00:03:25.560
Here's all of the open
tickets on my system.

72
00:03:25.560 --> 00:03:29.170
But historical tickets
are just as valuable.

73
00:03:29.170 --> 00:03:31.180
That you can go back and
establish patterns.

74
00:03:31.180 --> 00:03:34.920
All right, so that's one
advantage of having documentation.

75
00:03:34.920 --> 00:03:37.720
The other advantage is,
depending on the type of documentation,

76
00:03:37.720 --> 00:03:40.730
it can really get you out of
a bind in a lot of scenarios.

77
00:03:40.730 --> 00:03:46.630
For example you call in to a company
because you had a hardware failure.

78
00:03:46.630 --> 00:03:48.510
And they tell you the unit's
not under warranty.

79
00:03:48.510 --> 00:03:49.570
Sorry it's not under warranty.

80
00:03:49.570 --> 00:03:52.140
And you say, well actually we
purchased the extended service plan.

81
00:03:52.140 --> 00:03:54.040
And they say no, no you didn't.

82
00:03:54.040 --> 00:03:58.390
Well if I've got an asset management
system in place with good documentation,

83
00:03:58.390 --> 00:04:01.660
I can go and I can pull the purchase or I
can pull the invoice and I can show that.

84
00:04:01.660 --> 00:04:03.950
I can say here it is here's my receipt.

85
00:04:03.950 --> 00:04:04.570
Have you ever had that?

86
00:04:04.570 --> 00:04:07.310
Something breaks, you wanna return it,
and you didn't save the receipt?

87
00:04:07.310 --> 00:04:10.650
Well, with this stuff, you gotta
save your receipt, it's important.

88
00:04:10.650 --> 00:04:11.790
These are high ticket items.

89
