00:15:30.180 --> 00:15:33.920
So I had to document everything
that I did, how it was done and

316
00:15:33.920 --> 00:15:35.000
how that procedure worked.

317
00:15:35.000 --> 00:15:36.200
Very time consuming.

318
00:15:36.200 --> 00:15:40.313
Easily half of my time was consumed in
documentation, but it's important for

319
00:15:40.313 --> 00:15:43.195
the stability of the organization
that you have that.

320
00:15:43.195 --> 00:15:45.877
Other types of diagrams and
documents we might have, architecture or

321
00:15:45.877 --> 00:15:46.972
infrastructure diagrams.

322
00:15:46.972 --> 00:15:50.723
If you have a building like I
used to work at a skyscraper, so

323
00:15:50.723 --> 00:15:54.484
we had offices on five different
floors in the skyscraper.

324
00:15:54.484 --> 00:15:57.003
And so how's that all interconnected,
right?

325
00:15:57.003 --> 00:16:00.390
If I'm on the fourth,
it would have been like the 21st floor.

326
00:16:00.390 --> 00:16:01.927
If I'm on the 21st floor,

327
00:16:01.927 --> 00:16:05.010
how is my data making it down
to the 17th floor and so on.

328
00:16:05.010 --> 00:16:09.073
So how we coordinate that and how that
information flows, cuz a lot of times

329
00:16:09.073 --> 00:16:13.470
you don't have access to the common
tunnels that pass between the floors.

330
00:16:13.470 --> 00:16:16.290
You end up having to go through
the building facilities,

331
00:16:16.290 --> 00:16:19.770
the building supervisor and
all that to actually get the cabling run.

332
00:16:19.770 --> 00:16:21.030
So how does that work?

333
00:16:21.030 --> 00:16:23.420
Gotta make sure we have that documented.

334
00:16:23.420 --> 00:16:26.960
Recovery documentation, which is kind
of what Wes was talking about there.

335
00:16:26.960 --> 00:16:31.100
If we have a device or system fail,
what are the steps to recover?

336
00:16:31.100 --> 00:16:34.292
And we did an episode where we
talked about business resumption and

337
00:16:34.292 --> 00:16:35.780
disaster recovery planning.

338
00:16:35.780 --> 00:16:39.628
And that's what this is all about is
hey If I have a total server failure,

339
00:16:39.628 --> 00:16:43.601
how can I stand up a new server that takes
over that role in as minimal a time as

340
00:16:43.601 --> 00:16:44.250
possible?

341
00:16:44.250 --> 00:16:46.600
And that can be quite a bit.

342
00:16:46.600 --> 00:16:47.774
Baseline documentation,

343
00:16:47.774 --> 00:16:50.620
we talked about that way back
in the server setup episodes.

344
00:16:50.620 --> 00:16:54.580
When you bring up a brand new server, you
need to take a performance baseline of it.

345
00:16:54.580 --> 00:16:58.822
And that performance baseline is showing
how that server runs on a normal day

346
00:16:58.822 --> 00:17:00.900
when things are working right.

347
00:17:00.900 --> 00:17:04.870
When you first stand that server up,
how much CPU utilization does it have?

348
00:17:04.870 --> 00:17:07.240
What's it's disk IO look like in the IOPS?

349
00:17:07.240 --> 00:17:08.920
What's the network bandwidth?

350
00:17:08.920 --> 00:17:11.720
What is the RAM consumption?

351
00:17:11.720 --> 00:17:15.274
And that way, six months later, or
a year later, when people call in and

352
00:17:15.274 --> 00:17:18.359
say that server's so slow,
I hate it Is it actually slow, or

353
00:17:18.359 --> 00:17:21.240
do people just feel that way
cuz the times change, right?

354
00:17:21.240 --> 00:17:25.230
So we can pull our documentation on that
performance baseline and compare it.

355
00:17:25.230 --> 00:17:29.869
So, that's something that's created way
early in the lifecycle, but it goes into

356
00:17:29.869 --> 00:17:33.870
documentation and it stays there so
that we've got it available for us.

357
00:17:33.870 --> 00:17:38.350
Change management policies, we could
an entire series on change management.

358
00:17:38.350 --> 00:17:41.020
When you deploy a server,
you deploy it a certain way.

359
00:17:41.020 --> 00:17:43.248
And you may have gone all out and

360
00:17:43.248 --> 00:17:47.280
made sure that it was properly
configured and secured.

361
00:17:47.280 --> 00:17:48.160
You hardened it.

362
00:17:48.160 --> 00:17:53.010
You updated all of the firmware,
all of the drivers.

363
00:17:53.010 --> 00:17:56.300
It was in great shape
when you deployed it.

364
00:17:56.300 --> 00:18:00.920
And then over the next six months,
other people did the same thing.

365
00:18:00.920 --> 00:18:03.020
They updated the firm ware,
they updated the drivers.

366
00:18:03.020 --> 00:18:06.780
They kept doing that to make
sure it was in tip top shape.

367
00:18:06.780 --> 00:18:10.660
Well, then the software breaks one day and
nobody knows why.

368
00:18:10.660 --> 00:18:12.320
Hey, my server's not working anymore.

369
00:18:12.320 --> 00:18:13.580
What's going on?

370
00:18:13.580 --> 00:18:17.240
Well, you've got six months of changes
that people have been making and

371
00:18:17.240 --> 00:18:18.990
you don't know what's going on.

372
00:18:18.990 --> 00:18:20.910
Which one of those changes
caused the problem?

373
00:18:20.910 --> 00:18:22.160
We don't know.

374
00:18:22.160 --> 00:18:24.800
And there could be unintentional
changes that are made.

375
00:18:24.800 --> 00:18:25.541
Somebody just goes in and

376
00:18:25.541 --> 00:18:28.230
it's like you know what I'm gonna make
this change it'll make this run faster.

377
00:18:28.230 --> 00:18:29.940
And it breaks something else.

378
00:18:29.940 --> 00:18:31.610
We need a way to track that.

379
00:18:31.610 --> 00:18:35.960
Change management is technically it's
just another word for bureaucracy.

380
00:18:35.960 --> 00:18:39.250
It puts a lot of bureaucracy in
between you and doing your work.

381
00:18:39.250 --> 00:18:41.550
But there's a reason for it, right?

382
00:18:41.550 --> 00:18:43.320
Let me just give you,
I'll give you a great story.

383
00:18:43.320 --> 00:18:47.020
I used to work with a guy,
a phenomenal guy, very, very smart.

384
00:18:47.020 --> 00:18:48.610
Worked very, very hard.

385
00:18:48.610 --> 00:18:52.542
And you always knew when he was going on
a vacation because he would take a week in

386
00:18:52.542 --> 00:18:55.770
vacation but the week prior
he would work twice as hard.

387
00:18:55.770 --> 00:18:59.370
He would do extra work to try and
get more done for when he was gone.

388
00:18:59.370 --> 00:19:01.470
He was a great guy,
really dedicated to the company.

389
00:19:01.470 --> 00:19:03.160
The problem was,
he didn't document anything.

390
00:19:03.160 --> 00:19:04.740
It was super annoying.

391
00:19:04.740 --> 00:19:08.610
And so he would do a ton of work,
and then go on vacation.

392
00:19:08.610 --> 00:19:13.070
And so Monday morning, I'd come in and
all hell was breaking loose.

393
00:19:13.070 --> 00:19:15.633
The servers are messing up,
users are calling in complaining and

394
00:19:15.633 --> 00:19:17.180
all sorts of crazy things are going on.

395
00:19:17.180 --> 00:19:19.490
And I would go what did Bill do?

396
00:19:19.490 --> 00:19:21.545
And then you gotta try and
figure it out and

397
00:19:21.545 --> 00:19:25.140
what the heck did he do over that last
week and I gotta reinvent the wheel.

398
00:19:25.140 --> 00:19:28.293
Well, if it was all documented,
then you say okay,

399
00:19:28.293 --> 00:19:31.170
here's exactly what he
did over the last week.

400
00:19:31.170 --> 00:19:33.600
I know what he changed,
I can roll it back,

401
00:19:33.600 --> 00:19:35.840
I can undue the changes that were made.

402
00:19:35.840 --> 00:19:38.280
Change management is super important.

403
00:19:39.540 --> 00:19:42.979
The key thing about change management
is that you document the change, right,

404
00:19:42.979 --> 00:19:44.580
especially so then people can do it.

405
00:19:44.580 --> 00:19:47.340
But there’s more to it than
just documenting the change.

406
00:19:47.340 --> 00:19:49.400
There’s usually an approval process.

407
00:19:49.400 --> 00:19:51.690
We need to approve the change.

408
00:19:51.690 --> 00:19:53.390
Why are you changing that server?

409
00:19:53.390 --> 00:19:58.230
Wes might be working on a server and he
can't connect to a database that’s on it.

410
00:19:58.230 --> 00:19:59.120
And so he says, you know what?

411
00:19:59.120 --> 00:20:01.160
I'm gonna disable the Windows Firewall.

412
00:20:01.160 --> 00:20:02.350
I bet it's a Windows Firewall problem.

413
00:20:02.350 --> 00:20:03.680
Let me just turn that off.

414
00:20:03.680 --> 00:20:07.100
Okay well, now he can connect to
the database, problem solved, right?

415
00:20:07.100 --> 00:20:10.440
Well, he weakened
the security on the server.

416
00:20:10.440 --> 00:20:12.920
Turning off the firewall
wasn't the right solution.

417
00:20:12.920 --> 00:20:14.300
Opening a port on the firewall was.

418
00:20:14.300 --> 00:20:15.820
But that's not what he did.

419
00:20:15.820 --> 00:20:19.900
But if he was a junior admin and
didn't know that, what was to stop him?

420
00:20:21.050 --> 00:20:23.500
If change management was in place,
that would have stopped it.

421
00:20:23.500 --> 00:20:26.409
If you make a change to the server
without going through change management,

422
00:20:26.409 --> 00:20:27.050
you're fired.

423
00:20:27.050 --> 00:20:28.780
So, there's your motivation to do it.

424
00:20:28.780 --> 00:20:32.530
So, then he fills out a form and he says,
I want to turn off the Windows firewall.

425
00:20:32.530 --> 00:20:33.420
That's what I'm going to do.

426
00:20:33.420 --> 00:20:35.275
I want to do it on this day,
at this time and

427
00:20:35.275 --> 00:20:37.600
it's not going to impact the end users.

428
00:20:37.600 --> 00:20:39.050
And then he puts his business case.

429
00:20:39.050 --> 00:20:43.580
I'm doing this cuz I can't connect to
the database with the Windows Firewall on.

430
00:20:43.580 --> 00:20:47.120
And then he submits it to
the change advisory board, the CAB.

431
00:20:47.120 --> 00:20:49.730
Or you might have a change committee or
any number of names.

432
00:20:49.730 --> 00:20:51.540
Most people call it a CAB,
a change advisory board.

433
00:20:51.540 --> 00:20:55.698
And the change advisory board is made
up of the CIO and other experts,

434
00:20:55.698 --> 00:20:57.430
and they review the change.

435
00:20:57.430 --> 00:21:00.826
And they look at it and they say, Wes,
Don't turn off the windows firewall,

436
00:21:00.826 --> 00:21:02.140
just open up the little port.

437
00:21:02.140 --> 00:21:05.120
I see this in the Linux world
all the time with SELinux.

438
00:21:05.120 --> 00:21:08.020
So many people are like,
I'm going to disable SELinux.

439
00:21:08.020 --> 00:21:10.820
And I say, you can do that if you
don't want to work here anymore.

440
00:21:10.820 --> 00:21:13.597
Or you can figure out the right
context type to assign and

441
00:21:13.597 --> 00:21:15.870
you can get SC Linux to work for you.

442
00:21:15.870 --> 00:21:17.170
That's how it's supposed to work.

443
00:21:17.170 --> 00:21:21.330
So, by looking at it and evaluating it,
the change advisory board can reject

444
00:21:21.330 --> 00:21:25.300
the change if it's not right, or
they can allow the change to go through.

445
00:21:25.300 --> 00:21:25.970
They can approve it.

446
00:21:25.970 --> 00:21:28.520
And if they approve it,
Wes makes the change.

447
00:21:28.520 --> 00:21:31.380
Well now, everything is great,
sunshine and rainbows.

448
00:21:31.380 --> 00:21:32.680
Everything works perfect.

449
00:21:32.680 --> 00:21:35.016
When things don't work,
and in the change ticket,

450
00:21:35.016 --> 00:21:38.370
Wes put here’s how I'll monitor it to
make sure the change is successful.

451
00:21:38.370 --> 00:21:42.900
And if the change wasn't successful
here's how I'll undo the change right.

452
00:21:42.900 --> 00:21:45.877
By having all that documented,
you now know what to watch for and

453
00:21:45.877 --> 00:21:48.870
you know how to undo it in the event
things don't work out right.

454
00:21:48.870 --> 00:21:51.022
It makes things so much better, so

455
00:21:51.022 --> 00:21:54.300
much easier when you have
more than one admin right.

456
00:21:54.300 --> 00:21:57.830
If you just have one admin, you probably
don't need change management, but

457
00:21:57.830 --> 00:21:59.239
if you have two or five or 50 or

458
00:21:59.239 --> 00:22:02.310
500 A lot of people are gonna be
stepping on each other's toes.

459
00:22:02.310 --> 00:22:03.660
And you've got to have change management.

460
00:22:04.780 --> 00:22:07.701
A lot of software,
like the Solar Winds Web Help Desk,

461
00:22:07.701 --> 00:22:11.590
that I was showing earlier,
it's got change management built into it.

462
00:22:11.590 --> 00:22:13.110
In fact, you can see, here.

463
00:22:13.110 --> 00:22:15.760
I'm looking at my tickets, and
most of these are support tickets.

464
00:22:15.760 --> 00:22:16.530
People have a problem.

465
00:22:16.530 --> 00:22:17.830
Here's a password reset.

466
00:22:17.830 --> 00:22:19.180
I need to reset a password.

467
00:22:19.180 --> 00:22:22.370
But if you look in this next one,
you'll see a schedule change for

468
00:22:22.370 --> 00:22:23.530
postponing a release.

469
00:22:23.530 --> 00:22:24.870
They're pushing something back two weeks,
right?

470
00:22:24.870 --> 00:22:27.950
Here's a request for
change that required approval.

471
00:22:27.950 --> 00:22:31.958
And I can look over here and I can see
where one person's already approved it,

472
00:22:31.958 --> 00:22:34.940
but it's still waiting for
the board to approve.

473
00:22:34.940 --> 00:22:37.280
And I can go in, and
I can view it as a change request.

474
00:22:37.280 --> 00:22:40.650
To see if somebody submitted
that change request right here.

475
00:22:40.650 --> 00:22:44.903
And when you look at that ticket, you'll
be able to see what is they're requesting,

476
00:22:44.903 --> 00:22:46.930
and what it is they want to do, and so on.

477
00:22:46.930 --> 00:22:49.984
This is a schedule change,
it's going through a normal process, and

478
00:22:49.984 --> 00:22:52.820
all the little systems that
are affected is a part of it.

479
00:22:52.820 --> 00:22:54.040
That is a critical thing.

480
00:22:54.040 --> 00:22:56.760
If your company is not doing change
management, it really should.

481
00:22:56.760 --> 00:23:00.200
It's super important.

482
00:23:00.200 --> 00:23:02.885
All right, service level agreements, SLAs.

483
00:23:02.885 --> 00:23:05.435
SLAs take two different forms.

484
00:23:05.435 --> 00:23:09.720
There’s SLAs that you've made and
SLAs that people made to you.

485
00:23:09.720 --> 00:23:12.498
If you're not familiar with an SLA
is a Service Level Agreement.

486
00:23:12.498 --> 00:23:18.510
It’s a guarantee that you will provide
a certain of uptime and availability.

487
00:23:18.510 --> 00:23:21.180
If I'm going to host a web server for
a company.

488
00:23:21.180 --> 00:23:22.862
Maybe you hire me to host your web server.

489
00:23:22.862 --> 00:23:24.359
I'm going to make you a guarantee.

490
00:23:24.359 --> 00:23:27.220
I'm going to keep your
server up 99.9% of the time.

491
00:23:28.290 --> 00:23:32.780
So, I need to do whatever it takes to
keep your server up 99.9% of the time.

492
00:23:32.780 --> 00:23:36.630
On my end, I need to document the SLA so
I know my obligation.

493
00:23:36.630 --> 00:23:38.410
This is what I need to do.

494
00:23:38.410 --> 00:23:43.770
On your end, you need to document the SLA
also because I promised it to you.

495
00:23:43.770 --> 00:23:44.440
What if I don't deliver?

496
00:23:44.440 --> 00:23:48.433
What it at the end of the year you
pull up an availability report and

497
00:23:48.433 --> 00:23:50.836
see that I only gave you 97% up time?

498
00:23:50.836 --> 00:23:53.238
But I promised you 99.9.

499
00:23:53.238 --> 00:23:54.435
There should be a penalty.

500
00:23:54.435 --> 00:23:55.979
I should have to pay out on that, right?

501
00:23:55.979 --> 00:23:57.136
But you need to know to look or that.

502
00:23:57.136 --> 00:24:00.015
So you've got to have the SLA
documented and so do I.

503
00:24:00.015 --> 00:24:04.220
>> Don, on that thought of penalties.

504
00:24:04.220 --> 00:24:08.370
Could a company that provides
a customer with an SOA and they don't,

505
00:24:08.370 --> 00:24:11.780
like you said in the example,
meet the SOA and it causes some kinda,

506
00:24:11.780 --> 00:24:15.620
I don't know, financial repercussion for
that company that is the customer.

507
00:24:15.620 --> 00:24:19.200
Could the person that offered
the SLA become financially liable?

508
00:24:19.200 --> 00:24:19.990
>> Yeah, absolutely.

509
00:24:19.990 --> 00:24:22.270
Companies go out of
business over this stuff.

510
00:24:22.270 --> 00:24:26.200
There's government contracts that you can
take where if you sign a SLA with them

511
00:24:26.200 --> 00:24:28.490
that says you're gonna provide
a certain service level and

512
00:24:28.490 --> 00:24:33.390
you don't, the penalties can be so
great, that the company goes bankrupt.

513
00:24:33.390 --> 00:24:34.250
That happens.

514
00:24:34.250 --> 00:24:36.668
You can lose your business based on that.

515
00:24:36.668 --> 00:24:38.047
You can be legally held liable,

516
00:24:38.047 --> 00:24:42.200
if you've falsified information saying you
could provide a SLA and then you couldn't.

517
00:24:42.200 --> 00:24:44.090
You can go to jail.

518
00:24:44.090 --> 00:24:45.950
SLAs are a serious business.

519
00:24:45.950 --> 00:24:48.910
Where we normally see them is not so
serious, it's normally bandwidth.

520
00:24:48.910 --> 00:24:53.670
Where they guarantee you your fiber
link will be up 99.999% of the time.

521
00:24:53.670 --> 00:24:54.580
And then, you find out it's not.

522
00:24:54.580 --> 00:24:55.840
And so, what do they do?

523
00:24:55.840 --> 00:24:58.885
They give you a credit on your monthly
bill, and they discount you for that.

524
00:24:58.885 --> 00:25:01.680
So it was down for
ten minutes longer than we promised, so

525
00:25:01.680 --> 00:25:05.130
we're gonna credit you the cost of
running that line for ten minutes.

526
00:25:06.200 --> 00:25:07.830
It's a negligible amount.

527
00:25:07.830 --> 00:25:09.270
So the SLA's not really significant there.

528
00:25:09.270 --> 00:25:12.370
Sometimes there are huge penalties,
especially on a construction contract,

529
00:25:12.370 --> 00:25:13.319
the penalties got really big.

530
00:25:14.710 --> 00:25:17.530
The other thing to keep in mind with SLAs

531
00:25:17.530 --> 00:25:19.790
is that we do have some
kinda way to monitor them.

532
00:25:19.790 --> 00:25:21.370
So anytime somebody offers you an SLA,

533
00:25:21.370 --> 00:25:24.780
you need to have a monitoring
system that's tracking that.

534
00:25:26.170 --> 00:25:29.980
My cable modem at home,
it goes down all the time.

535
00:25:29.980 --> 00:25:31.560
It's terrible, it goes down all the time.

536
00:25:31.560 --> 00:25:33.656
And I could call the cable company and
complaint and

537
00:25:33.656 --> 00:25:36.810
then get credits or whatever, but
I don't have a monitoring system.

538
00:25:36.810 --> 00:25:39.330
Monitoring system is when the kids
get mad they can't watch Netflix.

539
00:25:39.330 --> 00:25:40.970
So that's my monitoring system, but

540
00:25:40.970 --> 00:25:42.980
in a commercial environment
you need something real.

541
00:25:42.980 --> 00:25:44.718
Something that's actually
monitoring those lines.

542
00:25:44.718 --> 00:25:48.750
Like, WhatsUp Gold, or SolarWinds
Network Performance Monitor or whatever.

543
00:25:48.750 --> 00:25:51.220
And they can tell you,
not just the line went down, but

544
00:25:51.220 --> 00:25:55.050
how long it was down cuz it might happen
at 2 AM in the morning and nobody notices.

545
00:25:55.050 --> 00:25:56.412
But you still deserve a credit for that.

546
00:25:56.412 --> 00:26:00.450
It went down, so you need to be able
to document that and have a record.

547
00:26:02.050 --> 00:26:05.260
The last documentation they call
out is server configuration.

548
00:26:05.260 --> 00:26:08.390
When I build up a new server,
how did I do it?

549
00:26:08.390 --> 00:26:10.230
What operating system did I use?

550
00:26:10.230 --> 00:26:11.830
What license did I put in it?

551
00:26:11.830 --> 00:26:13.650
What software did I add to it?

552
00:26:13.650 --> 00:26:16.100
What features did I change and customize?

553
00:26:16.100 --> 00:26:17.950
What did I do to build that server up?

554
00:26:17.950 --> 00:26:22.130
And this is important because I'm gonna
build more servers in the future.

555
00:26:22.130 --> 00:26:26.320
And if I already know the steps to
complete it, I'm gonna use that.

556
00:26:26.320 --> 00:26:28.230
I shared with Wes, a year or two ago, and

557
00:26:28.230 --> 00:26:29.640
I probably should have brought
it here up for the show.

558
00:26:29.640 --> 00:26:31.510
I had this Linux build
document that I use.

559
00:26:31.510 --> 00:26:32.910
And anytime I deploy a Linux server,

560
00:26:32.910 --> 00:26:34.390
there's a standard set
of things that I do.

561
00:26:34.390 --> 00:26:35.730
I can't remember it all off my mind.

562
00:26:35.730 --> 00:26:36.950
So I'll just rattle it off.

563
00:26:36.950 --> 00:26:40.950
So when I deploy a new Linux server,
I secure a DVD installer.

564
00:26:40.950 --> 00:26:43.660
And I always use the same one
even if there's been newer ones

565
00:26:43.660 --> 00:26:44.210
that have come out.

566
00:26:44.210 --> 00:26:46.460
Cuz I always want a consistent
deployment pattern.

567
00:26:46.460 --> 00:26:53.390
So for example, if I'm deploying CentOS
6.5, I might know that CentOS 6.7 is out.

568
00:26:53.390 --> 00:26:57.951
But I'll still use the 6.5 installer and
just do the update to 6.7 when it's done.

569
00:26:57.951 --> 00:27:00.230
Because I know I'll have
a consistent deployment pattern.

570
00:27:00.230 --> 00:27:02.020
I always wanna have consistency.

571
00:27:02.020 --> 00:27:04.890
If I go to 6.7, now I gotta update my
documentation, and that's a pain, and

572
00:27:04.890 --> 00:27:05.680
you don't really benefit.

573
00:27:05.680 --> 00:27:07.920
So you can always update afterwards.

574
00:27:07.920 --> 00:27:11.730
So I perform my install, and
I have a partition scheme that I follow,

575
00:27:11.730 --> 00:27:13.900
so here's how I outline my partitions.

576
00:27:13.900 --> 00:27:16.480
And then, after that,
we'd let the install complete, and

577
00:27:16.480 --> 00:27:19.430
I always do a minimal install,
always, no matter what the server is,

578
00:27:19.430 --> 00:27:22.320
I always do a minimal install, so
I choose that and do the install.

579
00:27:22.320 --> 00:27:29.101
Once it's done, then I can configure SSH,
I always change the default SSH port.

580
00:27:29.101 --> 00:27:31.665
Port 22 by default,
I move it to something else and

581
00:27:31.665 --> 00:27:35.340
I make sure that the root account
is not allowed to use SSH.

582
00:27:35.340 --> 00:27:38.500
And I create the local accounts
that we're gonna be using.

583
00:27:38.500 --> 00:27:42.620
Then, I customized the firewall in SELinux
to support the software that I'm gonna be

584
00:27:42.620 --> 00:27:44.230
using, and I installed the software
that I'm gonna be using.

585
00:27:44.230 --> 00:27:45.720
These are the steps that I follow, and

586
00:27:45.720 --> 00:27:49.140
I do it with every single
server that I deploy.

587
00:27:49.140 --> 00:27:52.370
By having that document,
it's just a series of steps I follow.

588
00:27:52.370 --> 00:27:55.200
And I never forget a step,
because they're written down.

589
00:27:55.200 --> 00:27:56.220
If I just try and do it from memory,

590
00:27:56.220 --> 00:27:58.340
like I just did,
I probably left some stuff out.

591
00:27:58.340 --> 00:28:00.810
In fact, I can think of it right now,
the network configuration.

592
00:28:00.810 --> 00:28:04.080
I always statically assign an IP, and
I do it through the configuration files.

593
00:28:04.080 --> 00:28:05.940
So here's the configuration files I edit,
and

594
00:28:05.940 --> 00:28:08.690
here's the lines that I edit,
it's all right in the document.

595
00:28:08.690 --> 00:28:12.403
That's part of provisioning consistently,
making sure all of your servers have

596
00:28:12.403 --> 00:28:15.435
a consistent profile and
they've got the settings that you need.

597
00:28:15.435 --> 00:28:19.874
>> You know, Don, before we started this
episode we were kinda talking about this.

598
00:28:19.874 --> 00:28:22.737
I mentioned, Don, is this software
something you're gonna be hosting on your

599
00:28:22.737 --> 00:28:24.890
network or is this something
that's gonna be in the cloud?

600
00:28:24.890 --> 00:28:26.232
And you mentioned, no, no, no.

601
00:28:26.232 --> 00:28:28.790
Wes, you're gonna host this on site
cuz if you think about what's in

602
00:28:28.790 --> 00:28:32.190
this information, you don't want
that going over a public line

603
00:28:32.190 --> 00:28:35.190
secure not out to the cloud and
having somebody else managing that.

604
00:28:35.190 --> 00:28:36.850
So that's a concept on security,

605
00:28:36.850 --> 00:28:39.940
can you talk a little about that when
it comes to all this documentation?

606
00:28:39.940 --> 00:28:42.410
>> So
some of this data is not very sensitive.

607
00:28:42.410 --> 00:28:46.720
The service manuals that we get from HPE
or Dell or whatever, they're on the web.

608
00:28:46.720 --> 00:28:47.890
I don't care if people have that,

609
00:28:47.890 --> 00:28:50.086
and I don't even care if people
know what servers I have.

610
00:28:50.086 --> 00:28:53.743
All right, so they know I've
got a Dell MA-20 or whatever.

611
00:28:53.743 --> 00:28:55.410
Big deal.

612
00:28:55.410 --> 00:28:58.460
But if they know the IP
address of the server, and

613
00:28:58.460 --> 00:29:02.430
they know the unique password I
sign on a local administrator

614
00:29:02.430 --> 00:29:06.170
account on that server, that's not good,
that's not information that I want out.

615
00:29:06.170 --> 00:29:08.900
If they know the exact version of
all the software I've been install,

616
00:29:08.900 --> 00:29:11.190
that's not something I want to get out, so

617
00:29:11.190 --> 00:29:14.470
your documentation contain
information that is very sensitive.

618
00:29:14.470 --> 00:29:19.030
So at a minimum it needs to be
stored in an encrypted form.

619
00:29:19.030 --> 00:29:22.120
Use GPG or GPGTools.

620
00:29:22.120 --> 00:29:26.270
You can use BitLocker on a drive or
file encryption.

621
00:29:26.270 --> 00:29:28.570
Use some kind of a security on that data.

622
00:29:28.570 --> 00:29:32.590
If it's store in software like
the SolarWinds Web Help Desk,

623
00:29:32.590 --> 00:29:34.950
they can store it in a database and
the database can be encrypted.

624
00:29:34.950 --> 00:29:37.410
And I say they can store it,
you actually run that on your own servers.

625
00:29:37.410 --> 00:29:39.129
Well, it is run locally, on-premises, and

626
00:29:39.129 --> 00:29:42.160
that's usually where you want
your documentation to be.

627
00:29:42.160 --> 00:29:45.970
I prefer my documentation to be
on-premises because if my Internet links

628
00:29:45.970 --> 00:29:50.510
go down, I still need access to my
documentation so I can call the ISP.

629
00:29:50.510 --> 00:29:51.400
I didn't even know who to contact.

630
00:29:51.400 --> 00:29:52.420
That's in my documentation.

631
00:29:52.420 --> 00:29:54.965
So you always wanna make sure you've
got a copy that you can get at.

632
00:29:54.965 --> 00:29:57.810
And it's a good idea to
keep some of it on paper.

633
00:29:57.810 --> 00:30:01.020
If you've got business resumption plans,
those should be printed out.

634
00:30:01.020 --> 00:30:04.860
Because when you need business resumption,
when all of your computer systems have

635
00:30:04.860 --> 00:30:09.190
failed, well, if your BRP is a collection
of PDFs stored on your SAN, and

636
00:30:09.190 --> 00:30:13.980
your SAN just got destroyed,
that BRP's not helping you at all.

637
00:30:13.980 --> 00:30:16.720
So I know at more than one organization,

638
00:30:16.720 --> 00:30:19.570
we had our big run books
that were literally books.

639
00:30:19.570 --> 00:30:21.710
I mean, they were phone book thick.

640
00:30:21.710 --> 00:30:26.150
And it had all of the instructions that
we needed to follow for part of BRP.

641
00:30:26.150 --> 00:30:28.657
And there were two copies of that BRP.

642
00:30:28.657 --> 00:30:30.348
One that was at headquarters and

643
00:30:30.348 --> 00:30:34.200
one that was in the disaster
recovery center with the other data.

644
00:30:34.200 --> 00:30:37.690
And so, that way if our main
facility was completely destroyed,

645
00:30:37.690 --> 00:30:38.660
that other copy was there.

646
00:30:38.660 --> 00:30:42.330
But we didn't keep it like, I didn't say,
I'll take one home with me.

647
00:30:42.330 --> 00:30:44.840
Because that was really
sensitive data in that book.

648
00:30:44.840 --> 00:30:47.632
If somebody got a hold on that book,
it was the keys to the kingdom.

649
00:30:47.632 --> 00:30:53.880
So we had private keys and SSL
certificates documented inside of that.

650
00:30:53.880 --> 00:30:56.480
That's not something wise,
something you want locked in a vault and

651
00:30:56.480 --> 00:30:58.690
stored in a secure and safe area.

652
00:30:58.690 --> 00:31:02.845
But don't rely too much on digital
storage if it's business resumption.

653
00:31:02.845 --> 00:31:04.990
Cuz you might not have
access that digital storage.

654
00:31:04.990 --> 00:31:06.520
Always keep that in mind, too.

655
00:31:06.520 --> 00:31:08.630
>> Well, Don,
it's a lot of great information.

656
00:31:08.630 --> 00:31:12.660
I know that if you have been following us
on this series, Don has been hammering

657
00:31:12.660 --> 00:31:16.950
you over the head, documentation,
documentation, and yes more documentation.

658
00:31:16.950 --> 00:31:20.360
So now you actually got to see
what's part of documentation.

659
00:31:20.360 --> 00:31:22.940
Now, Don, it does look like we're
coming to the end of another episode.

660
00:31:22.940 --> 00:31:26.320
But before we do, do you have any final
words on things like asset management and

661
00:31:26.320 --> 00:31:27.750
documentation?

662
00:31:27.750 --> 00:31:29.500
>> That's it for me on this one.

663
00:31:29.500 --> 00:31:32.170
I could harp on for days and
days on end about this.

664
00:31:32.170 --> 00:31:34.959
We're gonna see more just as the series
progresses, especially when we

665
00:31:34.959 --> 00:31:38.170
get into troubleshooting cuz that's where
documentation really comes in handy.

666
00:31:38.170 --> 00:31:41.715
But just remember it's a lot of work,
it's a lot of maintenance, and

667
00:31:41.715 --> 00:31:45.801
it seems like a lot of bureaucracy, but
once it saves your butt a couple of times,

668
00:31:45.801 --> 00:31:48.950
you'll come around and
you'll really appreciate it.

669
00:31:48.950 --> 00:31:50.980
I've been saved by
documentation more than once.

670
00:31:50.980 --> 00:31:54.600
So I really make sure that
I implement it properly.

671
00:31:54.600 --> 00:31:58.900
>> Words of wisdom and one you don't wanna
have to learn from personal experience.

672
00:31:58.900 --> 00:32:00.880
Now, that looks like
a great place to sign off.

673
00:32:00.880 --> 00:32:03.690
Don, as always, we do appreciate
having you in the studios and

674
00:32:03.690 --> 00:32:05.630
we appreciate having you,
the viewer, watching.

675
00:32:05.630 --> 00:32:08.640
Signing of for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

676
00:32:08.640 --> 00:32:09.420
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

677
00:32:09.420 --> 00:32:10.435
>> And we'll see you next time.

678
00:32:12.431 --> 00:32:18.353
[MUSIC]

679
00:32:18.353 --> 00:32:21.491
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don discuss concepts surrounding virtualization. They look at Type 1 and 2 hypervisors, host machines vs. guest machines, resource allocation, hardware compatibility as well as the management interface.
episodes.title: Virtualization
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.656
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.656 --> 00:00:06.460
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.460 --> 00:00:08.396
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.396 --> 00:00:12.230
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.230 --> 00:00:14.853
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.853 --> 00:00:17.455
I'm your host, Wes Bryan,
and In today's episode,

7
00:00:17.455 --> 00:00:19.810
we're coming back with
more CompTIA Server+.

8
00:00:19.810 --> 00:00:22.700
And joining us in the studios is
none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

9
00:00:22.700 --> 00:00:23.970
Don, how are you doing, sir?

10
00:00:23.970 --> 00:00:26.550
>> I'm doing great, Wes,
ready to dive right back into Server+.

11
00:00:26.550 --> 00:00:30.960
And in this episode we're covering one
of my favorite topics, virtualization.

12
00:00:30.960 --> 00:00:33.690
And it's one of my favorites cuz it's so
prominent these days.

13
00:00:33.690 --> 00:00:35.530
It's one of those technologies
that's been around a long time.

14
00:00:35.530 --> 00:00:37.860
And most of you have probably
already deployed it right now.

15
00:00:37.860 --> 00:00:39.130
And in the early days,

16
00:00:39.130 --> 00:00:43.420
it was something that people didn't
really wanna get involved in.

17
00:00:43.420 --> 00:00:46.700
And it's one of those technologies
that really caught on mainstream now.

18
00:00:46.700 --> 00:00:49.970
And I'm surprised anytime when I go to an
environment where they aren't virtualizing

19
00:00:49.970 --> 00:00:50.890
servers.

20
00:00:50.890 --> 00:00:52.600
So let's start up with the basics, and

21
00:00:52.600 --> 00:00:54.870
then we'll work our way up to what
we need to know for the exam.

22
00:00:54.870 --> 00:00:59.360
The first thing we need to understand is
what the heck virtualization is, right?

23
00:00:59.360 --> 00:01:03.749
And the best way to explain it is,
I have a little analogy I like to use.

24
00:01:04.770 --> 00:01:08.130
When most people buy things,
they buy more than what they need, right?

25
00:01:08.130 --> 00:01:11.990
So when you buy a server, you typically
have more CPU than you need, or

26
00:01:11.990 --> 00:01:14.760
more RAM than you need,
more storage than you need.

27
00:01:14.760 --> 00:01:18.190
And what happens to the extra
stuff that you're not using?

28
00:01:18.190 --> 00:01:19.880
It just sits there, it does nothing.

29
00:01:19.880 --> 00:01:23.040
I've got a computer at home with
an eight core processor in it.

30
00:01:23.040 --> 00:01:26.250
I can guarantee you it's probably sitting
there using one core at three percent

31
00:01:26.250 --> 00:01:27.800
right now, and the other core?

32
00:01:27.800 --> 00:01:29.140
Just getting wasted, doing nothing.

33
00:01:30.200 --> 00:01:32.400
So virtualization tries
to solve that problem.

34
00:01:32.400 --> 00:01:35.200
It's the equivalent of car pooling.

35
00:01:35.200 --> 00:01:38.120
I drove to work today in my car and
my car has six seats.

36
00:01:38.120 --> 00:01:42.240
So in theory I could put
six people in the car.

37
00:01:42.240 --> 00:01:44.201
I didn't I drove,
well I took the kids to school,

38
00:01:44.201 --> 00:01:45.710
I guess I get a little credit for that.

39
00:01:45.710 --> 00:01:48.080
But otherwise, I came in,
it was just me in the car.

40
00:01:48.080 --> 00:01:52.160
So, I could have put five
more people in that car and

41
00:01:52.160 --> 00:01:54.330
really got my money's worth out of it.

42
00:01:54.330 --> 00:01:58.300
But instead, it was just me and I wasted
the extra capacity of that vehicle and

43
00:01:58.300 --> 00:02:00.180
wasted gas and all that stuff.

44
00:02:00.180 --> 00:02:02.090
Which I should probably feel bad about,
but don't.

45
00:02:02.090 --> 00:02:04.930
Now, servers are the same way,
we buy these servers and

46
00:02:04.930 --> 00:02:09.160
you got multiple sockets and multiple
cores and multiple network adapters, RAM,

47
00:02:09.160 --> 00:02:12.270
and hard drives, and
all that extra is just getting wasted.

48
00:02:12.270 --> 00:02:15.240
And it gets frustrating because
sometimes you might need

49
00:02:15.240 --> 00:02:17.050
those resources somewhere else.

50
00:02:17.050 --> 00:02:19.770
I might have one server that's
running out of storage.

51
00:02:19.770 --> 00:02:22.670
Meanwhile I've got another server that
has a terrabyte of storage empty just

52
00:02:22.670 --> 00:02:23.660
sitting right there.

53
00:02:23.660 --> 00:02:26.600
But it doesn't do any good because
it's not in the right server.

54
00:02:26.600 --> 00:02:30.390
Virtualization works to
solve that by carpooling.

55
00:02:30.390 --> 00:02:35.730
Allowing more than one server
to run on one set of hardware.

56
00:02:35.730 --> 00:02:37.450
By doing that, they can share components.

57
00:02:37.450 --> 00:02:39.920
And that way,
we start to use our processors and

58
00:02:39.920 --> 00:02:42.040
our memory to their fullest extent.

59
00:02:42.040 --> 00:02:44.370
Now you have to be careful with it,
because you can over subscribe, right?

60
00:02:44.370 --> 00:02:45.830
My car has six seats,

61
00:02:45.830 --> 00:02:49.130
I could probably get ten people in
there,if they were all friendly, right?

62
00:02:49.130 --> 00:02:52.920
But now it's dangerous, now I don't have
enough seatbelts, servers on the same way.

63
00:02:52.920 --> 00:02:56.350
If you get too many people jammed on
there, you're gonna run out of RAM or

64
00:02:56.350 --> 00:02:57.780
you're gonna run out of CPU.

65
00:02:57.780 --> 00:03:01.480
And so that whole brilliant
idea of sharing becomes not so

66
00:03:01.480 --> 00:03:03.000
brilliant anymore, right?

67
00:03:03.000 --> 00:03:07.440
So we definitely have to kinda
use caution as we virtualize.

68
00:03:07.440 --> 00:03:11.330
But the main thing is all these years,

69
00:03:11.330 --> 00:03:15.960
people have been telling us, don't put
multiple services on the same server.

70
00:03:15.960 --> 00:03:18.480
Because if one goes down it
can take down other things.

71
00:03:18.480 --> 00:03:23.390
So if I have a server that's a DNS server,
and a DHCP server, and

72
00:03:23.390 --> 00:03:25.940
a Win server, or whatever.

73
00:03:25.940 --> 00:03:29.760
If one of them crashes it could take
all three down, so separate them out.

74
00:03:29.760 --> 00:03:32.330
But then you separate them out and these
are services that do hardly anything.

75
00:03:32.330 --> 00:03:35.210
And so they just sit there,
wasting resources.

76
00:03:35.210 --> 00:03:40.140
So instead of having them run on their
own physical set of hardware, And

77
00:03:40.140 --> 00:03:43.860
we can run them on a virtual
set of hardware instead.

78
00:03:43.860 --> 00:03:47.890
And we can have more than one virtual
set of hardware on the same piece of

79
00:03:47.890 --> 00:03:52.210
real hardware and
really take advantage of that.

80
00:03:52.210 --> 00:03:54.410
Now, virtualization is not a new concept.

81
00:03:54.410 --> 00:03:56.730
There were servers,
like the old VAX machines,

82
00:03:56.730 --> 00:04:00.190
that were doing
virtualization in the 1970s.

83
00:04:00.190 --> 00:04:04.210
So that's not a new thing, but
as we moved away from mainframes and

84
00:04:04.210 --> 00:04:07.460
moved to more decentralized solutions,

85
00:04:07.460 --> 00:04:10.940
people started doing dedicated
hardware to dedicated tasks.

86
00:04:10.940 --> 00:04:13.840
And so all throughout the late 1980s and

87
00:04:13.840 --> 00:04:17.310
most of the 1990s,
people hated virtualization.

88
00:04:17.310 --> 00:04:18.670
And companies like VMWare,

89
00:04:18.670 --> 00:04:23.230
that started in the 1990s, they didn't
really get a lot of traction right away.

90
00:04:23.230 --> 00:04:25.270
People said no, we'll use real hardware.

91
00:04:26.620 --> 00:04:30.800
Right up until the dot com bubble burst

00:27:27.950 --> 00:27:29.640
We've got those options for tweaking and

544
00:27:29.640 --> 00:27:32.285
adjusting, and
it's really like adjusting real hardware.

545
00:27:32.285 --> 00:27:34.880
You just wanna make sure
you don't oversubscribe.

546
00:27:34.880 --> 00:27:36.880
The only hardware I didn't
mention was video and

547
00:27:36.880 --> 00:27:39.400
that's because on servers we
don't normally care about video.

548
00:27:39.400 --> 00:27:42.240
But if you're bringing up somebody's
desktop as a virtual machine and

549
00:27:42.240 --> 00:27:44.240
maybe they have a thin client,
they connect to it.

550
00:27:44.240 --> 00:27:46.650
You might want it to have
a little bit fancier graphics.

551
00:27:46.650 --> 00:27:48.580
So when you create a virtual machine,

552
00:27:48.580 --> 00:27:51.420
most of the virtualization platforms
out there have where you can adjust

553
00:27:51.420 --> 00:27:55.570
the display settings to be
able to get optimized output.

554
00:27:55.570 --> 00:27:57.930
And this is our server that I'm on here.

555
00:27:57.930 --> 00:28:01.720
So it's got an integrated Intel
video adaptor, so I can't do much.

556
00:28:01.720 --> 00:28:04.740
But if you look,
see how under selected devices,

557
00:28:04.740 --> 00:28:07.660
I've got RemoteFX 3D Video Adaptor?

558
00:28:07.660 --> 00:28:12.660
If I had an NVIDIA video card in this
server, like a nicer graphics adaptor,

559
00:28:12.660 --> 00:28:16.800
I could actually enable 3D graphics
effects inside of the virtual machine.

560
00:28:16.800 --> 00:28:19.290
So now they get a more
desktop type experience.

561
00:28:19.290 --> 00:28:20.830
We don't need that in a server, but

562
00:28:20.830 --> 00:28:24.110
those video options are available if
you're running desktops in there.

563
00:28:24.110 --> 00:28:27.200
>> Yeah, that's what I was gonna ask
because I know that when we broke

564
00:28:27.200 --> 00:28:31.730
open the server, you mentioned how
we typically don't have video cards,

565
00:28:31.730 --> 00:28:35.320
graphics cards in these servers
because we don't care about video.

566
00:28:35.320 --> 00:28:37.950
So you can't get grape
juice from an orange.

567
00:28:37.950 --> 00:28:39.310
How does that actually work?

568
00:28:39.310 --> 00:28:43.060
If you don't have stuff in here you're not
really getting video acceleration unless

569
00:28:43.060 --> 00:28:44.160
you add that, right?

570
00:28:44.160 --> 00:28:46.850
>> Right, you'd have to say like hey,
I need this.

571
00:28:46.850 --> 00:28:48.970
So I'm gonna buy the hardware
that supports it.

572
00:28:48.970 --> 00:28:52.720
So when I buy a server I also need
to buy the appropriate graphics card

573
00:28:52.720 --> 00:28:55.250
to pop in there and enable those features.

574
00:28:55.250 --> 00:28:58.430
Some systems, like VMware, they'll
actually allow you to enable it even

575
00:28:58.430 --> 00:29:01.110
without a fancy graphics card,
it just doesn't work very well.

576
00:29:01.110 --> 00:29:02.350
So you can try.

577
00:29:02.350 --> 00:29:05.650
But you would have to buy the appropriate
hard ware to support that.

578
00:29:05.650 --> 00:29:07.500
It all comes down to your
vendor documentation and

579
00:29:07.500 --> 00:29:10.380
understanding the requirements
to deploy a solution.

580
00:29:10.380 --> 00:29:12.170
>> All right, lot of great information.

581
00:29:12.170 --> 00:29:14.250
And I know when it comes
to virtualization,

582
00:29:14.250 --> 00:29:15.560
I know this is a topic you love.

583
00:29:15.560 --> 00:29:17.390
And we've just barely
scratched the surface.

584
00:29:17.390 --> 00:29:18.630
There's a lot out there, Don.

585
00:29:18.630 --> 00:29:22.790
But well, we don't have a lot more that we
can talk about in the time that we have.

586
00:29:22.790 --> 00:29:23.840
But before we sign out, Don,

587
00:29:23.840 --> 00:29:26.510
do you got any additional words you
might like to throw to our viewers?

588
00:29:26.510 --> 00:29:29.670
If you wanna learn more about
virtualization pick a product.

589
00:29:29.670 --> 00:29:33.790
On ITProTV we have shows on Hyper V and
on VM Ware's ESXI and

590
00:29:33.790 --> 00:29:35.140
the whole V Sphere suite.

591
00:29:35.140 --> 00:29:37.260
We have shows on Citrix Xen Server.

592
00:29:37.260 --> 00:29:38.360
There's a ton of them out there.

593
00:29:38.360 --> 00:29:39.570
They all work great.

594
00:29:39.570 --> 00:29:41.660
But they all implement things
a little differently so

595
00:29:41.660 --> 00:29:43.150
you kinda have to learn
the individual products.

596
00:29:43.150 --> 00:29:46.150
That's why CompTIA doesn't really
harp on a particular product.

597
00:29:46.150 --> 00:29:48.620
They try and stay vendor neutral
cuz it's just too different.

598
00:29:48.620 --> 00:29:50.410
But get out there and learn them.

599
00:29:50.410 --> 00:29:52.410
If you aren't using them already,
you should be.

600
00:29:52.410 --> 00:29:54.380
Pretty much everything's
moved in this direction.

601
00:29:54.380 --> 00:29:57.630
Virtualization is a great solution and
then make sure that you get to take

602
00:29:57.630 --> 00:29:59.790
full advantage of the hardware
that you've paid for.

603
00:29:59.790 --> 00:30:02.610
>> Don, well great information,
thanks for being here and joining us.

604
00:30:02.610 --> 00:30:04.000
Thank you, the viewer watching.

605
00:30:04.000 --> 00:30:07.396
Signing out for IT ProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

606
00:30:07.396 --> 00:30:08.200
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

607
00:30:08.200 --> 00:30:10.307
>> And we'll see you next time.

608
00:30:10.307 --> 00:30:16.262
[MUSIC]

609
00:30:16.262 --> 00:30:19.563
Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore the most common storage technologies found within servers today and some retired technologies. They talk about concepts like SAS, SATA, SCSI and Fibre Channel. They will also look at the important characteristics and specifications of these disk technologies.
episodes.title: Primary Storage Devices
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.036 --> 00:00:02.614
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.614 --> 00:00:06.345
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.345 --> 00:00:08.418
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.418 --> 00:00:12.291
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.291 --> 00:00:12.800
>> Hello and

6
00:00:12.800 --> 00:00:17.122
welcome to another great episode here at
ITProTV, I'm your host Wes Bryan, and

7
00:00:17.122 --> 00:00:21.463
in today's episode we are continuing
through our series in Comp TS Server Plus.

8
00:00:21.463 --> 00:00:23.080
And joining us back in the studios for

9
00:00:23.080 --> 00:00:26.483
this endeavor is none other than
Mr Don Pezet, Don, how are you doing, sir?

10
00:00:26.483 --> 00:00:29.908
>> I'm doing great, Wes, ready to
kick off our great storage adventure.

11
00:00:29.908 --> 00:00:33.366
[LAUGH] In the next couple episodes we're
gonna be taking a look at storage inside

12
00:00:33.366 --> 00:00:37.085
of Server Solutions, and it's actually
a pretty important section because storage

13
00:00:37.085 --> 00:00:39.530
is typically the bottleneck
in most server solutions.

14
00:00:39.530 --> 00:00:42.805
If you look at all the different
types of technologies that we have,

15
00:00:42.805 --> 00:00:46.079
inside of a server the storage is
typically the slowest component,

16
00:00:46.079 --> 00:00:50.176
especially if we still have spinning disks
in your server, which a lot of people do.

17
00:00:50.176 --> 00:00:52.631
That's a physical,
spinning piece of equipment,

18
00:00:52.631 --> 00:00:54.303
that means you've got a motor, and

19
00:00:54.303 --> 00:00:58.058
that's gonna be slower than any electric
to electric communication you have.

20
00:00:58.058 --> 00:01:01.516
Things like RAM and solid state drives,
they're gonna be way faster.

21
00:01:01.516 --> 00:01:04.673
So as we design our servers, understanding
storage is pretty important and

22
00:01:04.673 --> 00:01:07.400
we're gonna look at all the options
in how we make that decision.

23
00:01:07.400 --> 00:01:10.094
>> All right, Don,
I just grabbed your credit card.

24
00:01:10.094 --> 00:01:11.501
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I'm going out and

25
00:01:11.501 --> 00:01:15.805
I'm gonna buy something at Newegg or
Amazon, what are the considerations that I

26
00:01:15.805 --> 00:01:20.106
have to look at when I'm gonna say, okay,
this drive is better than this drive,

27
00:01:20.106 --> 00:01:23.044
maybe I'll use this one,
maybe I won't use that one?

28
00:01:23.044 --> 00:01:25.257
>> All right,
not all drives are created equal,

29
00:01:25.257 --> 00:01:28.493
there are several different types
of drives that are out there, and

30
00:01:28.493 --> 00:01:32.610
even drives that look identical, don't
always have the same performance profile.

31
00:01:32.610 --> 00:01:37.112
So unfortunately, rule number one here
is you're going to have to read, and

32
00:01:37.112 --> 00:01:39.204
you're going to have to read a lot.

33
00:01:39.204 --> 00:01:43.268
When you build out a server, or spec out a
server, and someone else builds it, Dell,

34
00:01:43.268 --> 00:01:46.655
Lenovo, or whoever, when you go to
spec out what you need for a server,

35
00:01:46.655 --> 00:01:49.931
you need to understand the performance
profile of your software, so

36
00:01:49.931 --> 00:01:52.667
what is the software you are running and
what do you need?

37
00:01:52.667 --> 00:01:54.384
If I have a database server,

38
00:01:54.384 --> 00:01:58.833
I know I'm going to be doing a lot of
random reads off of those hard drives.

39
00:01:58.833 --> 00:02:00.753
I'm going to get a query, and
I've got to find data, and

40
00:02:00.753 --> 00:02:02.361
the data could be anywhere
inside of that file.

41
00:02:02.361 --> 00:02:06.173
I need to be able to jump around
the database and read different things.

42
00:02:06.173 --> 00:02:10.025
Versus, like a backup server, where
I know that if I'm restoring backups,

43
00:02:10.025 --> 00:02:13.761
I'm gonna start from the beginning of
the backup, and I'm just gonna read

44
00:02:13.761 --> 00:02:18.174
all the way through sequentially, nice and
in order, there's no random seqs on that.

45
00:02:18.174 --> 00:02:21.721
So things like seq time,
don't matter so much in that scenario,

46
00:02:21.721 --> 00:02:25.078
versus seq time really does
matter in the database solution.

47
00:02:25.078 --> 00:02:27.706
So, we need to know the characteristics
of our software, so

48
00:02:27.706 --> 00:02:30.243
we can make sure that we buy
the hardware that aligns to it.

49
00:02:30.243 --> 00:02:32.864
And even when we get a hardware
that appears identical,

50
00:02:32.864 --> 00:02:35.487
it doesn't always have
the same performance profile,

51
00:02:35.487 --> 00:02:39.525
so, we need to understand how these things
function, what they do and how they vary.

52
00:02:39.525 --> 00:02:42.337
So, we're gonna run through a couple
of examples of that and how we pick.

53
00:02:42.337 --> 00:02:45.026
A lot of people just fixate
on the speed of the disk, and

54
00:02:45.026 --> 00:02:49.298
that's not always accurate because there's
several different things that fall into

55
00:02:49.298 --> 00:02:53.299
the mix, and we will talk about each of
those as this episode kind of moves along.

56
00:02:53.299 --> 00:02:57.745
All right, let's start though
just by demonstrating how there

57
00:02:57.745 --> 00:03:02.036
are differences between even
identical appearing systems.

58
00:03:02.036 --> 00:03:04.999
So, I've got our virtualization
server pulled up here,

59
00:03:04.999 --> 00:03:08.867
this is one that we use in a lot of shows
that we run our virtual machines from,

60
00:03:08.867 --> 00:03:12.917
it's running Windows Server 2016,
it's got an Intel i7 processor, and

61
00:03:12.917 --> 00:03:16.389
it's a pretty fast machine, and
it's got a rate controller in it.

62
00:03:16.389 --> 00:03:20.719
And on that rate controller, we have two
different arrays available for virtual

63
00:03:20.719 --> 00:03:25.254
machine storage, and the two arrays are
actually configured, the same exact way.

64
00:03:25.254 --> 00:03:30.136
If I pull up those drives,
what I'll see in here,

65
00:03:30.136 --> 00:03:34.902
if I go into my system,
is I've got two stripes,

66
00:03:34.902 --> 00:03:39.582
and they're both 1.81 terabytes, okay?

67
00:03:39.582 --> 00:03:43.465
What they are are two RAID zero stripes,
in that they're two terabyte drives, but

68
00:03:43.465 --> 00:03:46.907
we'll talk about the mathematics of
hard drives in another episode, but

69
00:03:46.907 --> 00:03:49.983
you actually end up with about
1.8 terabytes of usable space.

70
00:03:49.983 --> 00:03:54.568
So I have two Seagate hard drives
that are one terabyte each, and two

71
00:03:54.568 --> 00:04:00.369
Western Digital Black drives that are one
terabyte each, and the RAID zero stripes.

72
00:04:00.369 --> 00:04:04.553
Now, RAID zero will typically give you the
best performance, there's no redundancy,

73
00:04:04.553 --> 00:04:06.172
there's no parity calculation,

74
00:04:06.172 --> 00:04:09.206
there's no mirroring,
we break our data up across two drives.

75
00:04:09.206 --> 00:04:12.161
So when I read and write on the Black
stripe here, I'm reading and

76
00:04:12.161 --> 00:04:15.625
writing from two drives at the same time,
I should get double performance.

77
00:04:15.625 --> 00:04:18.309
Same thing with the Seagate stripe here,
I'm reading and

78
00:04:18.309 --> 00:04:21.835
writing from two drives at the same time,
I should get double performance.

79
00:04:21.835 --> 00:04:26.508
Both of these are built up with 7,200
RPM drives, and both of these are sata 6

80
00:04:26.508 --> 00:04:29.962
drives and they're both run to
the same RAID controller, so

81
00:04:29.962 --> 00:04:32.556
you get the same
performance profile there.

82
00:04:32.556 --> 00:04:35.756
In theory,
performance should be identical.

83
00:04:35.756 --> 00:04:39.305
But different vendors have different
performance characteristics, and we may

84
00:04:39.305 --> 00:04:42.750
find that some have better read speeds,
better write speeds, some might have

85
00:04:42.750 --> 00:04:46.212
better seek times, some might be newer
hard drives versus older hard drives.

86
00:04:46.212 --> 00:04:50.945
Remember that newer hard drives will
typically have more platters in them than

87
00:04:50.945 --> 00:04:52.168
older hard drives.

88
00:04:52.168 --> 00:04:55.679
So when a one terabyte drive first came
out, I think I said that backwards,

89
00:04:55.679 --> 00:04:56.250
didn't I?

90
00:04:56.250 --> 00:04:59.425
Shoot, when a one terabyte drive first
came out, it probably had three or

91
00:04:59.425 --> 00:05:01.831
four platters in it, but
by the time we get to today, and

92
00:05:01.831 --> 00:05:05.338
one terabyte drives have been out for
years, they only have one or two platters.

93
00:05:05.338 --> 00:05:08.841
Which is less ground for us to cover with
our mechanical arms to get to our data,

94
00:05:08.841 --> 00:05:12.575
so, they actually perform a little bit
faster even though they're the same size.

95
00:05:12.575 --> 00:05:15.765
>> I would imagine that you would put
more and more platters in there, Don,

96
00:05:15.765 --> 00:05:17.396
why are they reducing the platters?

97
00:05:17.396 --> 00:05:20.566
Is that because the density of
the disk is getting greater?

98
00:05:20.566 --> 00:05:23.882
>> Yeah, they get more efficient at how
they can put that data in there, so

99
00:05:23.882 --> 00:05:26.869
one terabyte might need four
platters when it first starts, but

100
00:05:26.869 --> 00:05:30.659
over time they get more efficient, and
now one terabyte can fit in two platters.

101
00:05:30.659 --> 00:05:33.801
And they can still sell four platter
drives but now they're two terabytes, or

102
00:05:33.801 --> 00:05:36.861
four terabytes, or eight, as they
start growing and growing and growing.

103
00:05:36.861 --> 00:05:40.436
The newest sizes, when those come out,
usually have the most platters, and

104
00:05:40.436 --> 00:05:44.011
that can result in some performance hits
on those, you get a lot of storage and

105
00:05:44.011 --> 00:05:45.444
the tradeoff is performance.

106
00:05:45.444 --> 00:05:48.468
Now, we don't see any of that
in our operating system, right?

107
00:05:48.468 --> 00:05:51.711
The performance is not really visible
to us, but there's utilities available,

108
00:05:51.711 --> 00:05:54.024
usually built right into the OS,
where you can test that.

109
00:05:54.024 --> 00:05:56.726
Windows has a nice one called WinSAT,
which is used for

110
00:05:56.726 --> 00:05:59.736
testing the performance
characteristics of your machine.

111
00:05:59.736 --> 00:06:03.744
A lot of video gamers use it because they
wanna get the best hardware possible, but

112
00:06:03.744 --> 00:06:07.404
it works great on servers too because it
gives me a chance to take a look at how

113
00:06:07.404 --> 00:06:08.936
these drives are performing.

114
00:06:08.936 --> 00:06:15.287
So just so I make sure, I wanna make sure
that I'm comparing the right things here,

115
00:06:15.287 --> 00:06:19.757
and so I'm gonna be looking
at these two stripes, right?

116
00:06:19.757 --> 00:06:25.375
The D and E, D is Western Digital Black
and the Seagate one is E,

117
00:06:25.375 --> 00:06:30.251
and I'm gonna run a quick test,
I'm gonna do WinSAT,

118
00:06:30.251 --> 00:06:33.859
and I'm gonna run a disk test on drive D.

119
00:06:33.859 --> 00:06:36.372
So, I'm gonna test that
Western Digital drive and

120
00:06:36.372 --> 00:06:38.191
see what it's performance is like.

121
00:06:38.191 --> 00:06:41.961
And so this is gonna run a series of
tests, and it's testing the read speed and

122
00:06:41.961 --> 00:06:46.021
the write speed, and while I'm waiting on
that to run, let me change my font here so

123
00:06:46.021 --> 00:06:48.069
it's a little bit easier to see all this.

124
00:06:48.069 --> 00:06:52.079
I'm going to bump up my size,
and my color, there we go,

125
00:06:52.079 --> 00:06:55.184
that'll be a littler easier to read for
us.

126
00:06:55.184 --> 00:06:59.993
And so here it's going, see, it ran some
read tests and a write test, and now it's

127
00:06:59.993 --> 00:07:04.693
doing some queries, looking around,
doing sequenced reads and random reads.

128
00:07:04.693 --> 00:07:08.853
Sequential reads are all right in an
order, so it's reading a bunch of data in

129
00:07:08.853 --> 00:07:12.757
a line, and then random reads,
where it's jumping all over the drive,

130
00:07:12.757 --> 00:07:16.804
that's a great way to see seek time,
and when it's done, I get an output.

131
00:07:16.804 --> 00:07:21.829
And I can see that, as far as the random
reads, it randomly, in the amount

132
00:07:21.829 --> 00:07:27.178
of time the test ran, it was able to
randomly pull 1.74 megabytes of data,

133
00:07:27.178 --> 00:07:31.821
it was able to sequentially pull
181 megabytes of data on a read.

134
00:07:31.821 --> 00:07:33.590
That's a huge difference, and

135
00:07:33.590 --> 00:07:36.546
the difference here is these
are mechanical drives.

136
00:07:36.546 --> 00:07:40.576
Mechanical drives have an arm that
has to move to get to a location.

137
00:07:40.576 --> 00:07:44.973
When the arm is always running in the same
location, it can pull a lot of data, but

138
00:07:44.973 --> 00:07:48.740
when it's jumping around the drive,
look how much we lost, right?

139
00:07:48.740 --> 00:07:53.410
And it's an 100% difference between, or
no, ten times, ten times the difference,

140
00:07:53.410 --> 00:07:55.992
which, I don't know,
whatever, stupid math,

141
00:07:55.992 --> 00:07:59.817
but ten times the difference between
random versus sequential, right?

142
00:07:59.817 --> 00:08:02.107
So if I understand
the characteristic of my server.

143
00:08:02.107 --> 00:08:04.690
And I know my server's doing sequential,
I might be okay with that.

144
00:08:04.690 --> 00:08:08.660
But if I know I need random, that might
be a problem for me that's a big hit.

145
00:08:08.660 --> 00:08:11.780
Well, let's run that same
test on the Seagate drives.

146
00:08:11.780 --> 00:08:14.280
Now I said the Seagate
drives are identical.

147
00:08:14.280 --> 00:08:15.950
They have the same the RPMs.

148
00:08:15.950 --> 00:08:18.510
They have the same interface.

149

00:17:38.100 --> 00:17:40.890
What RAID 5 does is it takes RAID 0,

00:17:40.890 --> 00:17:45.400
striping, and

00:17:45.400 --> 00:17:49.480
And the way it does that is by

00:17:49.480 --> 00:17:51.860
parity works kind of an interesting way.

00:17:51.860 --> 00:17:55.970
As you write your data across your drives,

00:17:55.970 --> 00:17:59.260
one drive will contain a parity block for

340
00:17:59.260 --> 00:18:03.560
And it's not entirely on one drive,
instead it's spread across the drives, and

00:18:03.560 --> 00:18:04.410
there's a reason for that.

342
00:18:04.410 --> 00:18:07.450
Let me kind of walk through this process,
and we'll see the reason.

343
00:18:07.450 --> 00:18:09.770
There is an alternative, which is RAID 4.

344
00:18:09.770 --> 00:18:14.281
RAID 4 is where all the parity is on
a single disk and so that can be used.

345
00:18:14.281 --> 00:18:15.129
Do I have a diagram for that?

346
00:18:15.129 --> 00:18:16.377
No, I don't have a diagram for it.

347
00:18:16.377 --> 00:18:18.813
But that's where all
the parity is on one disk and

348
00:18:18.813 --> 00:18:23.780
there's a particular scenario where it's
beneficial, most people don't need that.

349
00:18:23.780 --> 00:18:27.110
But with RAID 5, when I go and
write a 6 meg file, for example.

350
00:18:27.110 --> 00:18:31.460
Let's say, I have a o1 e meg stripe size,
and I'm writing a 6 meg file.

351
00:18:31.460 --> 00:18:35.517
It's gonna write the first meg on
drive 1 the second meg on drive 2, and

352
00:18:35.517 --> 00:18:37.725
then it's gonna write a parity block.

353
00:18:37.725 --> 00:18:44.033
And it's gonna move to the next set and
write the third meg on drive 1 again.

354
00:18:44.033 --> 00:18:48.960
And then the parity block on drive 2, and
then the fourth meg on drive 3, and so on.

355
00:18:48.960 --> 00:18:52.147
See how the parity block is
moving from drive to drive.

356
00:18:52.147 --> 00:18:55.320
It is not one drive that
holds all the parity blocks.

357
00:18:55.320 --> 00:18:58.910
The idea here is that if I lose a drive.

358
00:18:58.910 --> 00:19:01.268
Let's say that I lose this last drive.

359
00:19:01.268 --> 00:19:03.978
Well I lost a parity block,
which I am okay with.

360
00:19:03.978 --> 00:19:06.080
I don't need the parity block.

361
00:19:06.080 --> 00:19:10.110
And then I lost 4 and 6, the fourth
megabyte and the sixth megabyte.

362
00:19:10.110 --> 00:19:11.721
Now I need those, that's part of my data.

363
00:19:11.721 --> 00:19:14.650
A third of the data in this file is gone.

364
00:19:14.650 --> 00:19:18.299
Well, I don't have those files anymore,
that portion of the file.

365
00:19:18.299 --> 00:19:22.890
But I do have parity blocks and
I can rebuild it.

366
00:19:22.890 --> 00:19:24.780
What happens is something
kind interesting.

367
00:19:24.780 --> 00:19:26.806
It's actually a really
simple operation and

368
00:19:26.806 --> 00:19:28.678
whoever thought of it is just brilliant.

369
00:19:28.678 --> 00:19:31.356
This is what the PhDs in
computer science do all days,

370
00:19:31.356 --> 00:19:33.950
is they come up with
crazy ideas like this.

371
00:19:33.950 --> 00:19:37.272
And the way that parity works is it says,
okay,

372
00:19:37.272 --> 00:19:40.691
I'm gonna look at the data for
a particular bit.

373
00:19:40.691 --> 00:19:44.358
I'm gonna take a look at the data for
a particular bit in drive one.

374
00:19:44.358 --> 00:19:47.570
And I'm gonna take a look at
the data in drive two, that bit.

375
00:19:47.570 --> 00:19:51.070
And remember,
a bit is either gonna be zero or one.

376
00:19:51.070 --> 00:19:56.660
If I've got a zero here and a zero here,
I'm gonna treat that as an even number.

377
00:19:56.660 --> 00:19:58.084
0 plus 0 is 0.

378
00:19:58.084 --> 00:20:01.190
If I've got a 0 here and
a 1 nhere, 1 plus 1 ne is 1,

379
00:20:01.190 --> 00:20:04.030
I'm gonna treat that as an odd number.

380
00:20:04.030 --> 00:20:09.250
If I've got a 1 here and a 0 here,
those add up to 1, that's an odd number.

381
00:20:09.250 --> 00:20:13.480
If I've got a 1 here and a 1 here that
adds up to 2, that's an even number.

382
00:20:13.480 --> 00:20:18.068
And I'm gonna put a mark in the parity
block that says whether they add up to

383
00:20:18.068 --> 00:20:20.151
an odd or an even number, right?

384
00:20:20.151 --> 00:20:22.840
And so we'll designate that so we know.

385
00:20:22.840 --> 00:20:26.210
And when we lose a drive, so
if I lose this drive right here,

386
00:20:26.210 --> 00:20:28.180
I'm gonna lose block 4.

387
00:20:28.180 --> 00:20:33.313
Well, it can look at block 3,
and it sees a 0.

388
00:20:33.313 --> 00:20:34.862
And then it looks at the parity, and

389
00:20:34.862 --> 00:20:38.310
the parity tells me that I'm
supposed to have an even number.

390
00:20:38.310 --> 00:20:42.540
Well if I had a 0 here, and
I had a 1 on the missing drive,

391
00:20:42.540 --> 00:20:44.720
that would add up to an odd number so
that's not it.

392
00:20:44.720 --> 00:20:47.670
But if I add a zero here and
a zero on the missing drive,

393
00:20:47.670 --> 00:20:51.380
that's an even number I must have
had a zero on that last drive.

394
00:20:51.380 --> 00:20:55.705
And so we can figure out what was
on that drive that was missing.

395
00:20:55.705 --> 00:20:58.969
Now here's the good part.

396
00:20:58.969 --> 00:21:02.775
We get redundancy, I can lose a drive and
figure out what I lost.

397
00:21:02.775 --> 00:21:05.110
So I can actually lose a drive
in RAID 5 and I'll be fine.

398
00:21:06.130 --> 00:21:09.370
Here's the bad part, performance.

399
00:21:09.370 --> 00:21:14.560
Every time I write to a RAID 5 array,
I've gotta update the parity block.

400
00:21:14.560 --> 00:21:17.430
So every time we write to the disk,
we've got to do a mathematical

401
00:21:17.430 --> 00:21:20.970
calculation to figure out what
the parity block should be.

402
00:21:20.970 --> 00:21:24.410
It's not a big mathematical calculation,
but it is one nonetheless.

403
00:21:24.410 --> 00:21:26.851
And if you have harder RAID controller
