404
00:21:26.851 --> 00:21:28.866
In software you'd be doing it in your CPU,
so

405
00:21:28.866 --> 00:21:32.190
it's gonna hurt performance
every time you write.

406
00:21:32.190 --> 00:21:36.690
Now when I do a read on a healthy array,
that doesn't affect me.

407
00:21:36.690 --> 00:21:41.196
But if I do a read on a non healthy array,
what's called a degraded array.

408
00:21:41.196 --> 00:21:46.890
Now I do a read, I've gotta look at
parity and rebuild the missing data.

409
00:21:46.890 --> 00:21:50.537
And I could do that every single
time I read from the array,

410
00:21:50.537 --> 00:21:52.481
which is usually constantly.

411
00:21:52.481 --> 00:21:54.685
So as soon as you have a drive fail,

412
00:21:54.685 --> 00:21:58.590
your performance goes down significantly,
all right?

413
00:21:58.590 --> 00:22:03.952
So now my performance is really hurt,
and we've gotta repair the situation.

414
00:22:03.952 --> 00:22:07.259
So when you repair the situation you
go and you get another hard drive,

415
00:22:07.259 --> 00:22:08.670
you pop this one out, right?

416
00:22:08.670 --> 00:22:11.614
Remember, we might have hot swap drives,
will have little colored handles so

417
00:22:11.614 --> 00:22:13.365
you know you can pop
them out while it's live.

418
00:22:13.365 --> 00:22:16.100
And you pop in a new drive and
you can start rebuilding.

419
00:22:16.100 --> 00:22:19.625
If you don't have hot swap, you gotta shut
the server down, change the drive out, and

420
00:22:19.625 --> 00:22:20.557
then power it back up.

421
00:22:20.557 --> 00:22:22.940
So now you had some down
time which is annoying.

422
00:22:22.940 --> 00:22:28.318
But once the system comes back up
with a nice shiny, brand new drive,

423
00:22:28.318 --> 00:22:32.795
then it can go through
the process of rebuilding, okay?

424
00:22:32.795 --> 00:22:36.180
Now the new shiny drive
doesn't have any data on it.

425
00:22:36.180 --> 00:22:38.920
And so it's gonna look and it's gonna say,
okay, well I got one and two here.

426
00:22:38.920 --> 00:22:41.616
So I need to calculate a parity bit,
but I'll wait on that.

427
00:22:41.616 --> 00:22:44.250
And then I've got three here and
a parity block here.

428
00:22:44.250 --> 00:22:49.198
So I'll rebuild 4, and get it put back in.

429
00:22:49.198 --> 00:22:53.374
And I've got a parity block in 5,
so I can rebuild 6.

430
00:22:53.374 --> 00:22:57.610
So it rebuilds 6, rebuilds 4, and
then it rebuilds parity for that stripe.

431
00:22:57.610 --> 00:23:01.905
And now we're back to
healthy status again.

432
00:23:01.905 --> 00:23:09.458
It takes time to rebuild that, and
so during that time, I'm vulnerable.

433
00:23:09.458 --> 00:23:13.716
If I lose one drive, and
I replace the drive, right?

434
00:23:13.716 --> 00:23:17.674
So I replaced it with a new one and
it's in the process of rebuilding.

435
00:23:17.674 --> 00:23:21.770
If I lose another drive while
I'm rebuilding it's too much.

436
00:23:21.770 --> 00:23:24.385
RAID 5 can't survive losing two drives.

437
00:23:24.385 --> 00:23:26.430
There's not enough available to calculate.

438
00:23:26.430 --> 00:23:31.763
For example, if I lost 2 drives,
I've got block 1, I've got block 3.

439
00:23:31.763 --> 00:23:33.404
I'm missing block 2,

440
00:23:33.404 --> 00:23:37.844
and I don't have a parity block
to figure out what was in part 2.

441
00:23:37.844 --> 00:23:40.230
I've just lost too much.

442
00:23:40.230 --> 00:23:43.880
Down here, I've got a parity block,
and I don't have 5 and 6.

443
00:23:43.880 --> 00:23:48.400
I don't have two bits to compare the odds
and evens on, I can't rebuild it.

444
00:23:48.400 --> 00:23:51.993
You've gotta have the rest of the data
there, at least a good portion of it,

445
00:23:51.993 --> 00:23:55.489
to figure out whether it was odd or
even to be able to use that parity block.

446
00:23:55.489 --> 00:23:58.962
So RAID 5 can only survive
one drive failure, and

447
00:23:58.962 --> 00:24:02.199
while you're degraded you're vulnerable.

448
00:24:02.199 --> 00:24:05.080
So, how do we solve that?

449
00:24:05.080 --> 00:24:06.850
Well there was an early solution,
which was RAID 4.

450
00:24:06.850 --> 00:24:08.055
RAID 4 said, hey, you know what?

451
00:24:08.055 --> 00:24:11.610
Let's just put all of
our parity on one disk.

452
00:24:11.610 --> 00:24:15.070
And then roll the dice and hope that
that's the disk that fails, right?

453
00:24:15.070 --> 00:24:17.540
Cuz if the parity disk fails,
it's no big deal.

454
00:24:17.540 --> 00:24:21.190
But if you have a 15 drive array and
all your parity's on one disk,

455
00:24:21.190 --> 00:24:23.410
what are the odds of that
being the disk that fails?

456
00:24:23.410 --> 00:24:26.015
Pretty low.
Now, that disk will see more reads and

457
00:24:26.015 --> 00:24:27.704
writes than any other disk.

458
00:24:27.704 --> 00:24:31.837
So it'll see more load, and theoretically
that would make it the first to fail.

459
00:24:31.837 --> 00:24:34.230
But it doesn't usually work out that way.

460
00:24:34.230 --> 00:24:37.910
So the better solution is RAID 6.

461
00:24:37.910 --> 00:24:41.460
What RAID 6 does is it does double parity.

462
00:24:41.460 --> 00:24:44.300
It says, let's just add
another parity block, right?

463
00:24:44.300 --> 00:24:48.335
And by doing this,
see how I've got where I wrote block 1,

464
00:24:48.335 --> 00:24:51.581
I wrote block 2 and
then parity 1, parity 2.

465
00:24:51.581 --> 00:24:55.450
Then we write block 3, parity 1,
parity 2, block 4, parity 1,

466
00:24:55.450 --> 00:24:57.756
parity 2, block 5, block 6 and so on.

467
00:24:57.756 --> 00:25:02.003
We're staggering two parity stripes,
right?

468
00:25:02.003 --> 00:25:05.934
Now when I do that, if I lose a drive,
if I lose this last drive,

469
00:25:05.934 --> 00:25:08.400
[COUGH] I'm gonna lose blocks 4 and 6.

470
00:25:08.400 --> 00:25:12.630
Well I can calculate block
4 by looking at block 3 and

471
00:25:12.630 --> 00:25:16.580
parity 1, and
figuring out what was in block 4.

472
00:25:16.580 --> 00:25:20.591
And then for block 6,
I can use parity 1 and

473
00:25:20.591 --> 00:25:24.503
block 5 to figure out what was in block 6.

474
00:25:24.503 --> 00:25:25.889
Now what if I lose the second drive?

475
00:25:25.889 --> 00:25:30.620
Well if I lose a second drive,
I've got double parity.

476
00:25:30.620 --> 00:25:32.302
And so I'm able to rebuild it,

477
00:25:32.302 --> 00:25:36.005
because I've got the two different
parity blocks they can tell me.

478
00:25:36.005 --> 00:25:38.982
3 and parity 1 can tell me 4.

479
00:25:38.982 --> 00:25:41.870
Now I kinda drew this a little wrong, cuz
I do have the two parity blocks right next

480
00:25:41.870 --> 00:25:43.457
each other and I shouldn't have done that.

481
00:25:43.457 --> 00:25:44.782
It should be staggered a little more.

482
00:25:44.782 --> 00:25:47.395
So that we've got,
see how we have 9 and 10 here?

483
00:25:47.395 --> 00:25:49.988
There should really be
a parity block in this mix,

484
00:25:49.988 --> 00:25:52.909
versus having two side by
side to do the recalc, right?

485
00:25:52.909 --> 00:25:55.875
So 3 and parity 1, I could recalc.

486
00:25:55.875 --> 00:25:58.199
Parity 2 and 7, I could recalc.

487
00:25:58.199 --> 00:26:01.704
Here, I shoulda swapped these around
in my diagram to illustrate it, but

488
00:26:01.704 --> 00:26:03.124
I made my diagram too pretty.

489
00:26:03.124 --> 00:26:07.630
But it can rebuild it, and calculate
the data even though I had two disks fail.

490
00:26:07.630 --> 00:26:10.350
And the idea is that I shouldn't
be surviving two failures.

491
00:26:10.350 --> 00:26:15.111
That I should be surviving one failure
while another was rebuilding, right?

492
00:26:15.111 --> 00:26:18.965
It's really all about rebuilding, we're
trying to survive that rebuild process and

493
00:26:18.965 --> 00:26:20.189
get back to healthy again.

494
00:26:20.189 --> 00:26:25.019
>> Now Don, with the calculation of the
double distributed parity, does that also,

495
00:26:25.019 --> 00:26:28.405
like the RAID 5,
would that bring the performance down?

496
00:26:28.405 --> 00:26:32.527
Let's say in a perfect healthy array,
do we still see even more performance or

497
00:26:32.527 --> 00:26:34.629
calculation, I guess I should say?

498
00:26:34.629 --> 00:26:37.280
>> Yeah.
>> How you're calculating parity twice.

499
00:26:37.280 --> 00:26:38.543
>> Well, as far as calculating parity.

500
00:26:38.543 --> 00:26:39.477
>> Or writing, I should say.

501
00:26:39.477 --> 00:26:41.284
>> You are calculating parity once.

502
00:26:41.284 --> 00:26:42.895
And you're just writing it
to two different places.

503
00:26:42.895 --> 00:26:46.665
So that the math side really isn't that
much worse, but you are writing twice.

504
00:26:46.665 --> 00:26:48.325
Most rate controllers can handle that,
no big deal.

505
00:26:48.325 --> 00:26:50.430
So from that side,
you don't have any problems.

506
00:26:50.430 --> 00:26:51.530
But when you have a failure,

507
00:26:51.530 --> 00:26:53.820
you still have that same hit
of having to calculate parity.

508
00:26:53.820 --> 00:26:56.570
Even though you've got double parity
blocks, you still have that hit.

509
00:26:56.570 --> 00:26:59.595
>> All right,
with all the calculation of parity now.

510
00:26:59.595 --> 00:27:04.405
It's obviously taken some kind of
performance degradation if the RAID fails

511
00:27:04.405 --> 00:27:06.590
or a portion of the RAID fails.

512
00:27:06.590 --> 00:27:07.510
How can we get around that?

513
00:27:07.510 --> 00:27:08.288
How can we say, you know what?

514
00:27:08.288 --> 00:27:10.941
I don't wanna calculate
parity at all anymore.

515
00:27:10.941 --> 00:27:14.400
>> Well there's a few other solutions
that get a little more advanced.

516
00:27:14.400 --> 00:27:18.012
I know we're low on time, so I think
we're going to have to save those for

517
00:27:18.012 --> 00:27:18.970
part two, tosee.

518
00:27:18.970 --> 00:27:23.160
You can always throw money at a problem,
this is the thing I tell CIOs.

519
00:27:23.160 --> 00:27:25.750
You've got a problem, I can fix it
if we just throw money at it, right?

520
00:27:25.750 --> 00:27:27.581
That's the solution to any problem.

521
00:27:27.581 --> 00:27:28.803
Okay, you don't want to throw money at it?

522
00:27:28.803 --> 00:27:30.224
Well we'll figure something else out,
right?

523
00:27:30.224 --> 00:27:35.033
There's other ways, but there's ways where
we can introduce even more discs and

524
00:27:35.033 --> 00:27:36.715
even more stuff to solve it.

525
00:27:36.715 --> 00:27:39.590
And so there's some advanced raid
levels that I want to talk about.

526
00:27:39.590 --> 00:27:41.250
But since I only have
a little bit of time,

527
00:27:41.250 --> 00:27:43.360
let me focus back on performance for
a second.

528
00:27:43.360 --> 00:27:47.020
In RAID 5, I said a lot of
bad things about it, right?

529
00:27:47.020 --> 00:27:49.540
Like I got to calculate parity,
and that takes effort.

530
00:27:49.540 --> 00:27:53.460
And if a drive fails, I survive it,
but things get really slow and

531
00:27:53.460 --> 00:27:54.670
it sounds kind of gloom and doom.

532
00:27:54.670 --> 00:27:56.080
Why would I do RAID 5?

533
00:27:56.080 --> 00:27:59.950
Raid 6 is kind of a kludge,
sort of fixes a little bit,

534
00:27:59.950 --> 00:28:01.380
but I still have performance issues.

535
00:28:02.720 --> 00:28:09.510
I have performance issues when the drive
is degraded, when my array is not healthy.

536
00:28:09.510 --> 00:28:13.179
But when the array is healthy,
things actually run pretty well.

537
00:28:13.179 --> 00:28:16.730
Remember that RAID 5 is
a mixture of RAID 0 and 1.

538
00:28:16.730 --> 00:28:20.890
I'm getting redundancy and
I'm getting performance.

539
00:28:20.890 --> 00:28:25.220
When I write to this, even though I'm
wasting a little bit on the parity block,

540
00:28:25.220 --> 00:28:27.870
I am still writing to multiple
disks at the same time.

541
00:28:27.870 --> 00:28:30.740
So let's assume a 1 meg stripe size,

542
00:28:30.740 --> 00:28:33.370
I can be writing 2 megs
of data at the same time.

543
00:28:33.370 --> 00:28:37.629
So in theory, I'm writing twice as fast,
not three times as fast,

544
00:28:37.629 --> 00:28:38.837
as I was in RAID 0.

545
00:28:38.837 --> 00:28:43.135
But twice as fast here, cuz I can
write to the 2 and parity, right?

546
00:28:43.135 --> 00:28:44.891
Reads are also gonna be optimized,

547
00:28:44.891 --> 00:28:48.380
when I read I don't need to read
parity if the array is healthy.

548
00:28:48.380 --> 00:28:52.110
And so when I read, I'm able to read
from two of these disks at a time.

549
00:28:52.110 --> 00:28:54.443
And I'm using 2 and
3 because of my diagrams.

550
00:28:54.443 --> 00:28:56.790
In real life,
it comes down to how many disks you have?

551
00:28:56.790 --> 00:29:00.160
If I have 15 disks,
only 1 of them has a parity block.

552
00:29:00.160 --> 00:29:01.551
I could be reading from the other 14.

553
00:29:01.551 --> 00:29:05.913
I could be reading 14 times
as fast on a 15 drive array.

554
00:29:05.913 --> 00:29:08.817
If it would have arrayed 0,
I could be reading from all 15 drives.

555
00:29:08.817 --> 00:29:10.790
I'm reading 15 times as fast.

556
00:29:10.790 --> 00:29:15.120
So that's the performance gain,
you do get a performance gain with RAID 5.

557
00:29:15.120 --> 00:29:21.712
It's not as great as RAID 0, it's one
drive less than what RAID 0 would do.

558
00:29:21.712 --> 00:29:25.515
But that trade off for that one drive
less is that I get redundancy and

559
00:29:25.515 --> 00:29:27.720
that makes RAID 5 very popular.

560
00:29:27.720 --> 00:29:29.290
So while I said bad things about it,

561
00:29:29.290 --> 00:29:31.800
it is the most common form
of RAID that's out there.

562
00:29:31.800 --> 00:29:35.010
It's easy to implement,
it does require a minimum of 3 drives.

563
00:29:35.010 --> 00:29:41.330
A mirror with just two drives,
a RAID 0 array good work with two more.

564
00:29:41.330 --> 00:29:45.430
And there at 5 could work with 3 or more
we need 3 because of that parity block

565
00:29:45.430 --> 00:29:48.158
it's got to have a minimum
of three drives to do it.

566
00:29:48.158 --> 00:29:50.694
The maximum is gonna be
up to a RAID controller.

567
00:29:50.694 --> 00:29:53.184
I've seen RAID controllers that go very,
very high.

568
00:29:53.184 --> 00:29:56.124
I've seen RAID controllers that limit
you to just a handful of drives though.

569
00:29:56.124 --> 00:29:59.181
15 is pretty common because that's
usually what you'd see on a SCSI bus, and

570
00:29:59.181 --> 00:30:01.384
that's kinda what they designed
all this stuff around.

571
00:30:01.384 --> 00:30:03.047
Even though we're doing
serial attached SCSI.

572
00:30:03.047 --> 00:30:04.968
And so
SCSI bus limits don't apply to us anymore,

573
00:30:04.968 --> 00:30:07.320
you still see RAID controllers
follow some of those limits.

574
00:30:08.860 --> 00:30:10.987
But usually we don't have RAID
arrays that are that large.

575
00:30:10.987 --> 00:30:12.818
When you get over the 15 drive limit,

576
00:30:12.818 --> 00:30:15.370
that's when you start hitting sands,
right?

577
00:30:15.370 --> 00:30:18.230
When you have a storage area network and
the RAID arrays are there.

578
00:30:18.230 --> 00:30:21.068
And you might have, well heck there's one,
you guys can't see it on the camera,

579
00:30:21.068 --> 00:30:22.026
it's behind me down here.

580
00:30:22.026 --> 00:30:26.518
Where I know we've got a RAID
array that is 24 disks.

581
00:30:26.518 --> 00:30:30.731
So you can definitely have some
that span pretty large arrays.

582
00:30:30.731 --> 00:30:32.675
All right, well there are some
advance ones I want to talk about.

583
00:30:32.675 --> 00:30:34.890
But let's save those for part two,
and we'll get into that.

584
00:30:34.890 --> 00:30:37.576
But as far as RAID 0, RAID 1, and

585
00:30:37.576 --> 00:30:40.710
RAID 5, those are three basic
commons that are out there.

586
00:30:40.710 --> 00:30:43.680
And I threw RAID 6 into the mix,
that we need to be familiar with,

587
00:30:43.680 --> 00:30:45.411
you'll see those on a regular basis.

588
00:30:45.411 --> 00:30:48.275
The ones we'll do in the next episode
are a little less common, but

589
00:30:48.275 --> 00:30:51.258
more advanced for highly tuned and
high performance environments.

590
00:30:51.258 --> 00:30:53.712
>> All right, fun episode,
love the hardware stuff.

591
00:30:53.712 --> 00:30:56.770
It does look like as you've said, we're
coming to the end of another episode.

592
00:30:56.770 --> 00:31:00.699
But in part one here, Don, before sign
off, do have any additional words you

593
00:31:00.699 --> 00:31:03.250
might want to throw or
a cliff hanger for part two?

594
00:31:03.250 --> 00:31:05.660
>> Remember,
you've got to understand your data.

595
00:31:05.660 --> 00:31:08.511
Picking the right stripe size,
picking the right rate array.

596
00:31:08.511 --> 00:31:10.113
It's gonna depend on your data.

597
00:31:10.113 --> 00:31:14.351
Some things like on a database server,
transaction logs are very write heavy,

598
00:31:14.351 --> 00:31:16.728
they need high write performance.

599
00:31:16.728 --> 00:31:21.740
So RAID 0 would be nice, but
we can't survive a failure, right?

600
00:31:21.740 --> 00:31:24.860
So RAID 1 mirrors will get
you the best performance.

601
00:31:24.860 --> 00:31:28.397
But the database itself needs better
read performance with some redundancy.

602
00:31:28.397 --> 00:31:30.840
And so RAID 5 works out better for
the database.

603
00:31:30.840 --> 00:31:33.158
You might have to mix and
match which you can certainly do.

604
00:31:33.158 --> 00:31:35.554
You can create separate containers and
mix and

605
00:31:35.554 --> 00:31:39.618
match the RAID types to get the best
performance for what your system is doing.

606
00:31:39.618 --> 00:31:41.070
Always be aware of that.

607
00:31:41.070 --> 00:31:43.260
It's not a one size fits all.

608
00:31:43.260 --> 00:31:44.701
>> Well the knowledge Don, as always,

609
00:31:44.701 --> 00:31:46.567
we appreciate you being
in the studios with us.

610
00:31:46.567 --> 00:31:48.660
And we appreciate you,
the viewer watching.

611
00:31:48.660 --> 00:31:51.810
Signing out for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

612
00:31:51.810 --> 00:31:52.580
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

613
00:31:52.580 --> 00:31:54.533
>> And we'll see you next time.

614
00:31:54.533 --> 00:32:00.384
[MUSIC]

615
00:32:00.384 --> 00:32:03.565
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their exploration redundant array of independent disk or RAID technologies and configurations. They talk about RAID 10, 01 and 50. They will look at configuration considerations such as capacity, bus types and capacity, hot and cold spares, as well as the characteristics of array controllers like memory, battery-backed cache and duplexing.
episodes.title: Configuring RAID Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.626
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host, Don-
>> We're creating vector graphics.

2
00:00:03.626 --> 00:00:04.928
>> Live from San Francisco.

3
00:00:04.928 --> 00:00:08.243
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> Photoshop can show you.

4
00:00:08.243 --> 00:00:10.995
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.320 --> 00:00:14.837
>> Hello, and welcome to another
great episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.837 --> 00:00:16.400
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:16.400 --> 00:00:20.790
And in today's episode, we are continuing
through our CompTIA Server+ certification.

8
00:00:20.790 --> 00:00:23.963
We're actually coming back with
a part two on RAID configurations.

9
00:00:23.963 --> 00:00:29.490
And joining us and lending his expertise
in this is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:29.490 --> 00:00:30.330
Don, how you doing, sir?

11
00:00:30.330 --> 00:00:33.010
>> I'm doing great, Wes,
ready to dive right back into RAID.

12
00:00:33.010 --> 00:00:38.801
We left off talking about some of the
standard types, RAID 0, RAID 1, RAID 5.

13
00:00:38.801 --> 00:00:43.526
And when we kinda left off, Wes was saying
how, with RAID 5, we get redundancy,

14
00:00:43.526 --> 00:00:45.030
which is nice.

15
00:00:45.030 --> 00:00:47.000
But we take a bit of a performance hit.

16
00:00:47.000 --> 00:00:49.690
And so there's gotta be a better
solution that's out there.

17
00:00:49.690 --> 00:00:54.640
And I made the comment that, hey,
anything can be made better with money.

18
00:00:54.640 --> 00:00:59.090
So let's double back to that statement and
explain how money solves this problem.

19
00:00:59.090 --> 00:01:03.026
When you deploy RAID, you're,
in a way, wasting money,

20
00:01:03.026 --> 00:01:07.769
that you're taking drives and
giving them up in order for redundancy.

21
00:01:07.769 --> 00:01:10.480
So you lose a certain amount of storage,
right?

22
00:01:10.480 --> 00:01:13.830
Let me go back to my diagrams from the
first show, and I'll explain what I mean.

23
00:01:13.830 --> 00:01:16.620
With RAID 0,
I got great performance, right?

24
00:01:16.620 --> 00:01:19.170
Because I can write to multiple
drives at the same time,

25
00:01:19.170 --> 00:01:20.970
I can read from drives at the same time.

26
00:01:20.970 --> 00:01:25.110
I'm not doing any parity calculations,
so performance is very high.

27
00:01:25.110 --> 00:01:28.910
Let's assume, for a moment,
that these are all 1-terabyte drives.

28
00:01:28.910 --> 00:01:31.340
I have three 1-terabyte drives.

29
00:01:31.340 --> 00:01:34.310
In RAID 0, I get to use all of them.

30
00:01:34.310 --> 00:01:37.630
So I have a 3-terabyte
container that I'm creating,

31
00:01:37.630 --> 00:01:39.980
one big container
stretched across this disk.

32
00:01:39.980 --> 00:01:41.240
I get 3 terabytes.

33
00:01:41.240 --> 00:01:47.070
So if I buy 3 terabytes of storage,
I get to use 3 terabytes of storage.

34
00:01:47.070 --> 00:01:48.451
That's a good exchange, right?

35
00:01:48.451 --> 00:01:49.909
One-to-one ratio, perfect.

36
00:01:51.640 --> 00:01:54.410
Versus, if we take a look at mirroring.

37
00:01:54.410 --> 00:01:57.900
With mirroring, let's assume, for
a moment, these are 1-terabyte drives.

38
00:01:57.900 --> 00:02:04.890
Well, I take 1 terabyte a day to here and
clone it onto the other disk.

39
00:02:04.890 --> 00:02:05.920
And what that means is,

40
00:02:05.920 --> 00:02:10.500
while I have 1-terabyte drives,
I don't get 2 terabytes of storage.

41
00:02:10.500 --> 00:02:13.030
I get 1 terabyte of storage.

42
00:02:13.030 --> 00:02:15.200
The other terabyte's being used for
the mirror.

43
00:02:15.200 --> 00:02:18.180
So I'm giving up 50% of my storage.

44
00:02:18.180 --> 00:02:19.610
Or another way to look at it is,

45
00:02:19.610 --> 00:02:22.800
my storage just got twice as expensive,
right?

46
00:02:22.800 --> 00:02:24.710
Because, instead of buying
a single terabyte drive,

47
00:02:24.710 --> 00:02:25.990
now I've gotta buy two of them.

48
00:02:25.990 --> 00:02:28.360
And I still only get 1
terabyte of storage.

49
00:02:28.360 --> 00:02:31.260
So that's where cost comes in.

50
00:02:31.260 --> 00:02:32.540
Hey, I want this drive to be redundant.

51
00:02:32.540 --> 00:02:33.540
Well, let me just throw money at it.

52
00:02:33.540 --> 00:02:36.390
If I pay twice as much,
I can get two discs.

53
00:02:36.390 --> 00:02:39.809
And now I can get a mirror, and
now I've solved my problem.

54

>> Right, so can my operating
system handle an 8 terabyte drive?

280
00:14:42.310 --> 00:14:45.080
More than likely,
most modern operating systems can.

281
00:14:45.080 --> 00:14:48.450
But if i have 10 eight terabyte drives,
and

282
00:14:48.450 --> 00:14:53.440
I do a RAID 0 across them,
I now have 180 terabyte drive.

283
00:14:53.440 --> 00:14:55.428
Can my operating system
handle an 80 terabyte drive?

284
00:14:55.428 --> 00:14:58.050
Maybe, maybe not.

285
00:14:58.050 --> 00:15:00.930
Maybe my file system isn't able
to handle drives that large.

286
00:15:00.930 --> 00:15:03.140
So, we've always got to
think about capacity too.

287
00:15:03.140 --> 00:15:06.410
When you start doing RAID 10 and RAID 5,
you're giving up some of that capacity,

288
00:15:06.410 --> 00:15:07.420
it shrinks it down.

289
00:15:07.420 --> 00:15:09.450
When you do RAID 0,
you get full access though.

290
00:15:09.450 --> 00:15:12.040
And you end up with some really,
really large drives, and

291
00:15:12.040 --> 00:15:14.050
your operating system might not like that.

292
00:15:14.050 --> 00:15:16.510
So, you don't have to memorize this for
the exam.

293
00:15:16.510 --> 00:15:19.950
But just to kind of reinforce my
point here, I made a little chart

294
00:15:19.950 --> 00:15:23.150
with some of the common file systems,
and what their maxes are.

295
00:15:23.150 --> 00:15:26.200
And their maxes are typically pretty high.

296
00:15:26.200 --> 00:15:28.220
But sometimes they aren't.

297
00:15:28.220 --> 00:15:31.390
When you look at the maximum volume size,
and you go down this list

298
00:15:31.390 --> 00:15:36.750
you'll see like FAT32 for Windows has
a maximum volume size of eight terabytes.

299
00:15:36.750 --> 00:15:40.100
So, if I build something that's bigger
than eight terabytes I can't use FAT32,

300
00:15:40.100 --> 00:15:43.130
it's not gonna be able to handle that,
on the volume side.

301
00:15:43.130 --> 00:15:45.600
I might have a virtual
drive that's that big but

302
00:15:45.600 --> 00:15:47.620
I can't just partition
it in one big partition.

303
00:15:47.620 --> 00:15:50.500
I've got to break it up into smaller ones,
that are less than eight terabytes.

304
00:15:50.500 --> 00:15:53.235
And there's other ones that
have similar limitations.

305
00:15:53.235 --> 00:15:56.259
Like ext2 and ext3 at 32 terabytes, but

306
00:15:56.259 --> 00:16:00.516
if I just upgrade to ext4 I can
go all the way up to one exabyte.

307
00:16:00.516 --> 00:16:02.298
I can go to a huge amount of storage.

308
00:16:02.298 --> 00:16:04.980
And you'll see some that get
just insanely large, like ZFS.

309
00:16:04.980 --> 00:16:08.020
They can get all the way up
to 256 zettabytes, right?

310
00:16:08.020 --> 00:16:10.420
It's just a massive amount of space.

311
00:16:10.420 --> 00:16:14.590
That's why people love UFS, but
it's tied up in Oracle's licensing,

312
00:16:14.590 --> 00:16:16.420
so most of us don't get to use it.

313
00:16:16.420 --> 00:16:21.730
Instead, we deal with things like EXT4 and
EXFS, BTRFS is coming along and

314
00:16:21.730 --> 00:16:26.950
those all allow us to access much,
much larger disk sizes and so on.

315
00:16:26.950 --> 00:16:29.110
So as you start creating these containers,

316
00:16:29.110 --> 00:16:32.460
these virtual disks,
that a RAID controller makes.

317
00:16:32.460 --> 00:16:34.220
You might not wanna go some large.

318
00:16:34.220 --> 00:16:36.010
You might wanna do smaller ones.

319
00:16:36.010 --> 00:16:40.170
So I might have 20 disks, but I take
ten and put them in an array of five.

320
00:16:40.170 --> 00:16:42.210
All right I take another ten and
put them in another array of five and

321
00:16:42.210 --> 00:16:43.600
create smaller containers,

322
00:16:43.600 --> 00:16:46.070
that my operating system can handle
a little better, right Jill?

323
00:16:46.070 --> 00:16:47.000
Always keep that in mind.

324
00:16:47.000 --> 00:16:50.890
Your capacity numbers can get really,
really big with this stuff.

325
00:16:50.890 --> 00:16:53.420
The other thing is bus type limitations.

326
00:16:53.420 --> 00:16:55.070
That we have to use traditional SCSI.

327
00:16:55.070 --> 00:16:58.730
You can have one SCSI cable that
can run up to 14 drives, right.

328
00:16:58.730 --> 00:17:02.170
One for the controller and
then the rest gets eaten up by drives.

329
00:17:02.170 --> 00:17:06.110
So up to 15 drives on
that one SCSI connector.

330
00:17:06.110 --> 00:17:11.820
But when you do SATA and SAS they're
serial, serial ATA, serial attached SCSI.

331
00:17:11.820 --> 00:17:15.680
SATA and
SAS it's one drive per connection.

332
00:17:15.680 --> 00:17:18.260
And so how many connections
can you physically have inside

333
00:17:18.260 --> 00:17:20.642
of a server on a rate controller?

334
00:17:20.642 --> 00:17:22.660
That's gonna limit the amount
of drives that you can have.

335
00:17:22.660 --> 00:17:25.520
And it's gonna limit
the amount of throughput.

336
00:17:25.520 --> 00:17:29.620
If I've got a rate controller
that's plugged into a PCI-E port,

337
00:17:29.620 --> 00:17:32.170
how much data can I move
through a PCI-E port?

338
00:17:32.170 --> 00:17:35.870
If I've got five hard drives, and
they're all six gigabit drives,

339
00:17:35.870 --> 00:17:38.830
that means I could be moving
up to 30 gigabit of data.

340
00:17:38.830 --> 00:17:41.710
Do I have that throughput
availability on my PCIE card?

341
00:17:41.710 --> 00:17:42.950
Maybe, maybe not.

342
00:17:42.950 --> 00:17:45.300
Right, it depends on which
level of PCIE I have.

343
00:17:45.300 --> 00:17:49.280
And if I have 20 drives and I'm trying
to write to all 20 at the same time.

344
00:17:49.280 --> 00:17:52.040
Can one PCIE port handle that?

345
00:17:52.040 --> 00:17:53.350
Maybe, maybe not, right?

346
00:17:53.350 --> 00:17:54.450
I need to understand my drives and

347
00:17:54.450 --> 00:17:58.910
their speed, and the port that the rate
controller is plugged into and it's speed.

348
00:17:58.910 --> 00:18:03.660
There come a time where I can't handle
the amount of drives that I've got, and

349
00:18:03.660 --> 00:18:04.920
I have to create a bottle neck.

350
00:18:04.920 --> 00:18:07.100
The rate controller slows down our access,
and

351
00:18:07.100 --> 00:18:09.100
that's where storage
area networks come in.

352
00:18:09.100 --> 00:18:12.440
SANs have controllers in them that
are specifically designed to handle huge

353
00:18:12.440 --> 00:18:15.700
amounts of throughput, cuz they're not
expecting one server to be connected.

354
00:18:15.700 --> 00:18:18.840
They're expecting 10, 20,
30 servers to be connected.

355
00:18:18.840 --> 00:18:22.170
So it's handling the workload for
all of those systems.

356
00:18:22.170 --> 00:18:25.240
And so their throughput is phenomenal,
through the roof.

357
00:18:25.240 --> 00:18:26.780
But when you're dealing
with internal drives, and

358
00:18:26.780 --> 00:18:28.980
the RAID arrays you build there,
they're not designed for that level.

359
00:18:28.980 --> 00:18:32.680
But you've only got so much storage space
inside of a physical server anyway, so

360
00:18:32.680 --> 00:18:34.080
it's not normally a problem.

361
00:18:34.080 --> 00:18:37.270
But if you add on external arrays.

362
00:18:37.270 --> 00:18:37.850
You can do that.

363
00:18:37.850 --> 00:18:40.520
You can buy these external drive
trays to stick on the servers.

364
00:18:40.520 --> 00:18:41.910
You can saturate your bus.

365
00:18:41.910 --> 00:18:46.020
So you've always gotta keep
your bus speed in mind.

366
00:18:46.020 --> 00:18:47.210
Other things.

367
00:18:47.210 --> 00:18:49.160
You can do RAID across SSDs, right.

368
00:18:49.160 --> 00:18:53.230
In my example, I never mentioned that
they were SSD or spinning disks.

369
00:18:53.230 --> 00:18:56.690
With spinning disks, you have that
limitation of the rotations per minute,

370
00:18:56.690 --> 00:18:57.910
the RPMs, right?

371
00:18:57.910 --> 00:19:03.071
And if I have 7,200 RPM drives, and
5,400 RPM drives and 10,000 RPM,

372
00:19:03.071 --> 00:19:08.050
and 15,000 RPM drives, I usually
don't want to mix and match those.

373
00:19:08.050 --> 00:19:11.630
If I have an array, I want the array
to be built off of common speed drives,

374
00:19:11.630 --> 00:19:14.540
so I get consistent read and
write performance.

375
00:19:14.540 --> 00:19:15.970
If you mix and match, it causes a problem.

376
00:19:15.970 --> 00:19:19.100
So what we normally do is we set
up what's called tiered storage.

377
00:19:19.100 --> 00:19:22.790
Tiered storage is where maybe we've
got a couple of 15,000 rpm drives, and

378
00:19:22.790 --> 00:19:23.790
the rest of them are 7200 rpm.

379
00:19:24.830 --> 00:19:29.370
Your rate controller might support
tiered storage where you can say,

380
00:19:29.370 --> 00:19:34.160
put frequently accessed content
on the 15,000 rpm drives, and

381
00:19:34.160 --> 00:19:38.050
put less frequently or infrequently
accessed data on the 7200 rpm drives.

382
00:19:39.060 --> 00:19:40.590
There's RAID controllers to support that.

383
00:19:40.590 --> 00:19:43.570
Almost every SAN supports that but there's
plenty of RAID controllers that do too.

384
00:19:43.570 --> 00:19:45.070
You can create tiered storage.

385
00:19:45.070 --> 00:19:50.170
So technically separate arrays and
it's just managing where the data resides.

386
00:19:50.170 --> 00:19:53.000
You might have a handful of SSD's and

387
00:19:53.000 --> 00:19:55.090
the rest of your drives
are all spinning disks.

388
00:19:55.090 --> 00:19:57.810
That's a great example where
you'd use tiered storage.

389
00:19:57.810 --> 00:20:00.720
I don't have enough SSD for
all my data, but

390
00:20:00.720 --> 00:20:02.800
my frequently accessed
data can go into the SSD.

391
00:20:02.800 --> 00:20:04.740
And that will improve performance.

392
00:20:04.740 --> 00:20:05.980
That's a term you'll start to hear a lot.

393
00:20:05.980 --> 00:20:08.770
It's not on the exam objectives,
but it is something to be aware of.

394
00:20:08.770 --> 00:20:10.860
I guess drive RPM is on
the exam objectives.

395
00:20:10.860 --> 00:20:12.120
We'll lump it under that [LAUGH].

396
00:20:13.535 --> 00:20:15.180
Okay, the last thing that
I really need to mention,

397
00:20:15.180 --> 00:20:18.090
because we've already talked about
whether things can be hot swapped.

398
00:20:18.090 --> 00:20:19.570
Actually I have two things.

399
00:20:19.570 --> 00:20:22.340
I need to talk about battery
backed right cache controllers and

400
00:20:22.340 --> 00:20:25.820
I need to talk about hot spares and
cold spares, right?

401
00:20:25.820 --> 00:20:28.910
When I was talking about RAID 5,
I mentioned how,

402
00:20:28.910 --> 00:20:32.210
if we go back to my diagram,
if I lose a drive.

403
00:20:32.210 --> 00:20:34.420
So if I lose this drive right here,

404
00:20:34.420 --> 00:20:39.230
and I pop in a brand-new disk,
it's gonna start rebuilding.

405
00:20:39.230 --> 00:20:41.380
And while it's rebuilding, I'm at risk,

406
00:20:41.380 --> 00:20:44.490
because if I lose another
disk I lose the whole array.

407
00:20:44.490 --> 00:20:46.470
RAID 5 can't support two drives failing.

408
00:20:46.470 --> 00:20:47.110
It can only support one.

409
00:20:47.110 --> 00:20:48.880
Well here's the thing.

410
00:20:49.960 --> 00:20:53.170
I wanna minimize that rebuild
time as much as I can.

411
00:20:53.170 --> 00:20:57.560
But if these drives are a terrabyte or
larger, the rebuild can take quite awhile.

412
00:20:57.560 --> 00:20:59.410
It's a slow operation.

413
00:20:59.410 --> 00:21:01.869
So if I have a drive fail
in the middle of the night.

414
00:21:02.910 --> 00:21:05.920
It could be sitting there with
a failed drive all night long.

415
00:21:05.920 --> 00:21:10.540
And then I come in the morning, I'm like
what's that red light on the server?

416
00:21:10.540 --> 00:21:13.700
And then I go, and I look and I got a
drive fail, let me go ahead and swap that.

417
00:21:13.700 --> 00:21:16.990
And I swap the drive out and
it starts rebuilding.

418
00:21:16.990 --> 00:21:17.970
Well meanwhile,

419
00:21:17.970 --> 00:21:21.680
the failure happened six hours before
I just didn't know it, I wasn't here,

420
00:21:21.680 --> 00:21:25.420
I didn't see it, and then I change out
the drive and now we start to rebuild.

421
00:21:25.420 --> 00:21:27.310
Wouldn't it have been nice,

422
00:21:27.310 --> 00:21:32.000
if I had another drive already
sitting there and waiting.

423
00:21:32.000 --> 00:21:35.920
Now, the idea of a spare
drive is not a new concept.

424
00:21:35.920 --> 00:21:40.770
You might have a spare drive sitting
around that is just waiting for

425
00:21:40.770 --> 00:21:43.380
the opportunity to jump in and take over.

426
00:21:43.380 --> 00:21:48.540
Now when you do that,
it's one of those things where

427
00:21:48.540 --> 00:21:53.700
you have to determine how fast
a response you want on this stuff.

428
00:21:53.700 --> 00:21:58.490
So when we talk about a failure happening,
if I want the rebuild to

429
00:21:58.490 --> 00:22:03.340
happen immediately,
what I need is called a hot spare.

430
00:22:03.340 --> 00:22:07.150
I can have an extra disk that's
already plugged into the server

431
00:22:07.150 --> 00:22:08.830
that's not carrying any data, right.

432
00:22:08.830 --> 00:22:10.880
It's just sitting there and it's empty.

433
00:22:10.880 --> 00:22:16.030
So technically instead of
blue I would have grey,

434
00:22:16.030 --> 00:22:20.019
more grey disks that were stuck
beneath it and so on like this.

435
00:22:21.320 --> 00:22:28.580
And these discs would just be sitting,
waiting for me to do something, right?

436
00:22:28.580 --> 00:22:35.450
And when I have a failure, this one
will jump in and take it over, right?

437
00:22:35.450 --> 00:22:37.070
If it's a hot spare,

438
00:22:37.070 --> 00:22:41.490
that means the drive is physically
inserted in the server and waiting.

439
00:22:41.490 --> 00:22:46.660
And when one of these guys fails, like
if this drive were to disappear, it can

440
00:22:46.660 --> 00:22:52.550
immediately take this disk and start
rebuilding block four, and block six.

441
00:22:52.550 --> 00:22:55.790
I just lost block four and block six, so
it can jump in and start to rebuild those.

442
00:22:55.790 --> 00:22:58.540
It doesn't have to wait for
me to come in in the morning.

443
00:22:58.540 --> 00:23:01.830
So if the failure happens at one AM,
the hot spare is already waiting.

444
00:23:01.830 --> 00:23:03.710
It jumps in and
starts to rebuild right away.

445
00:23:03.710 --> 00:23:07.920
That's gonna minimize the time it
takes to recover from the failure and

446
00:23:07.920 --> 00:23:11.310
minimize my exposure,
that if I lose a second disk,

447
00:23:11.310 --> 00:23:14.070
well maybe it's already finished
the rebuild by that point.

448
00:23:14.070 --> 00:23:15.250
This is gonna minimize it.

449
00:23:15.250 --> 00:23:16.960
A hot spare's a great way to do that.

450
00:23:16.960 --> 00:23:20.100
>> Don, so let me see if I can
guess what the cold spare here is.

451
00:23:20.100 --> 00:23:24.930
Does that mean I'm taking a trip out of
the server closet to maybe an equipment

452
00:23:24.930 --> 00:23:28.260
storage room to find an extra hard drive
and come back to the server or storage.

453
00:23:28.260 --> 00:23:33.220
>> Yeah, if I have ten servers and I want
to do hot spares, I got ten hot spares.

454
00:23:33.220 --> 00:23:36.065
That's ten hard drives that
are sitting there doing nothing.

455
00:23:36.065 --> 00:23:40.130
Ten hard drives that I paid for
that are sitting there doing nothing.

456
00:23:40.130 --> 00:23:43.700
They're spinning, so eventually they'll
go bad, but they're not doing anything.

457
00:23:43.700 --> 00:23:45.889
And I might not have a lot of
slots on the servers anyway, so

458
00:23:45.889 --> 00:23:47.602
these are all things
that I need to consider.

459
00:23:47.602 --> 00:23:50.287
So instead,
if they're ten identical servers and

460
00:23:50.287 --> 00:23:54.782
they're all using the same drives, I could
just buy one spare, or maybe two spares,

461
00:23:54.782 --> 00:23:56.731
and stick them on the top of the rack.

462
00:23:56.731 --> 00:23:59.114
Or stick them in a storage closet or
whatever.

463
00:23:59.114 --> 00:23:59.886
Their cold.

464
00:23:59.886 --> 00:24:00.522
They're not spinning.

465
00:24:00.522 --> 00:24:01.315
They're sitting on a shelf.

466
00:24:01.315 --> 00:24:03.710
They'll last a lot longer
cuz they're not spinning.

467
00:24:03.710 --> 00:24:05.559
Right, they're not actively being used.

468
00:24:05.559 --> 00:24:08.844
And when a failure happens, I can see
that I can just go and grab the drive and

469
00:24:08.844 --> 00:24:10.200
swap it out.

470
00:24:10.200 --> 00:24:12.590
Nice part about a cold spar is you
don't need as many of them, so

471
00:24:12.590 --> 00:24:13.910
it's less expensive.

472
00:24:13.910 --> 00:24:16.230
But the negative part is we go
right back to my original problem.

473
00:24:16.230 --> 00:24:20.067
If a failure happens at 1 AM,
who's there to swap the drive?

474
00:24:20.067 --> 00:24:21.897
Not me, I'm asleep.

475
00:24:21.897 --> 00:24:24.240
But when I come in in the morning,
I can go ahead and take care of it.

476
00:24:24.240 --> 00:24:26.250
Now, what if I didn't
even have a cold spare?

477
00:24:26.250 --> 00:24:29.660
I come in in the morning,
I see the drive has failed, and I go and

478
00:24:29.660 --> 00:24:32.430
do a warranty call and
I get a new drive the next day.

479
00:24:32.430 --> 00:24:33.380
I've got to wait an entire day.

480
00:24:33.380 --> 00:24:35.460
Or I've got to drive down to the store and
buy one.

481
00:24:35.460 --> 00:24:38.250
And maybe I don't want to do that
right now, so I do it at lunch time.

482
00:24:38.250 --> 00:24:41.410
Again, continually increasing
the length to recovery time.

483
00:24:41.410 --> 00:24:45.630
So, if we can have a hot spare, that's
the best, you get the fastest recovery.

484
00:24:45.630 --> 00:24:48.120
If you have a cold spare,
at least you got the drive in-house, and

485
00:24:48.120 --> 00:24:49.310
you don't have to go out get it.

486
00:24:49.310 --> 00:24:52.320
So those are two alternatives that
help us kinda correct for that.

487
00:24:52.320 --> 00:24:55.360
Where it really is neat when you
have things like RAID ten arrays.

488
00:24:55.360 --> 00:24:57.210
Again, throwing money at the problem.

489
00:24:57.210 --> 00:25:02.440
If I've got hot spares along with this,
I can survive many drive failures.

490
00:25:02.440 --> 00:25:08.040
When you lose a drive in a mirror,
rebuilding a mirror is super easy, cuz

491
00:25:08.040 --> 00:25:13.698
we're just copying everything on the first
drive down to the new drive, that's it.

492
00:25:13.698 --> 00:25:17.440
Rebuilding RAID five is harder because
you're having to calculate parity,

493
00:25:17.440 --> 00:25:19.900
we're having to do math,
not just copy stuff.

494
00:25:19.900 --> 00:25:24.130
I've gotta read from the two disks that
are still valid to build parity for

495
00:25:24.130 --> 00:25:26.710
what's missing or
I better read from a valid disk and

496
00:25:26.710 --> 00:25:29.330
a parity disk to rebuild
the valid disk that's missing.

497
00:25:29.330 --> 00:25:32.040
So that takes math, it's harder for
the controller to do,

498
00:25:32.040 --> 00:25:34.410
and it takes longer, right?

499
00:25:34.410 --> 00:25:37.770
But as long as you've got a budget,
you can keep throwing drives at it, and

500
00:25:37.770 --> 00:25:40.340
eventually you'll get to a point where
you have instantaneous recovery,

501
00:25:40.340 --> 00:25:42.160
there's no big deal, right?

502
00:25:42.160 --> 00:25:44.240
But most of us are working
within budget constraints and so

503
00:25:44.240 --> 00:25:44.970
we don't have that option.

504
00:25:46.130 --> 00:25:49.350
All right the other thing I wanted to
talk about was the caching controller.

505
00:25:49.350 --> 00:25:51.000
When you write to these disks.

506
00:25:51.000 --> 00:25:54.310
If I'm writing to a RAID 5 array,
it's gotta calculate parity, right?

507
00:25:54.310 --> 00:25:55.140
I'm changing the disk.

508
00:25:55.140 --> 00:25:56.470
It's gotta calculate parity.

509
00:25:56.470 --> 00:25:59.340
If I'm writing to a mirror,
it's gotta write twice.

510
00:25:59.340 --> 00:26:02.760
If I'm writing to a RAID zero stripe,
it's gotta take the data, break it up, and

511
00:26:02.760 --> 00:26:05.070
then write simultaneously
across the disks.

512
00:26:05.070 --> 00:26:07.750
Well, all those operations take time.

513
00:26:07.750 --> 00:26:10.480
And you're operating system is
gonna send to the right command,

514
00:26:10.480 --> 00:26:15.040
and it's gonna wait for the hard drive
to respond back and say yep, done,

515
00:26:15.040 --> 00:26:17.490
I wrote it, and
the operating system can move on.

516
00:26:17.490 --> 00:26:21.450
So the operating system actually
pauses working with that data.

517
00:26:21.450 --> 00:26:25.230
Think about a word processor,
if I mean Microsoft Word, and

518
00:26:25.230 --> 00:26:28.490
I hit the Save button,
can I type while it's saving?

519
00:26:28.490 --> 00:26:29.450
No.

520
00:26:29.450 --> 00:26:33.620
While it's saving it stops me from typing
and it writes to the hard drive and when

521
00:26:33.620 --> 00:26:37.940
it's done writing and it knows that it's
saved then it lets me start typing again.

522
00:26:37.940 --> 00:26:40.465
Not every software does that but
Word's a good example that does.

523
00:26:40.465 --> 00:26:47.510
Now with a raid controller if
it has an extra memory on it.

524
00:26:47.510 --> 00:26:51.260
It can take the write
operation that I just did, and

525
00:26:51.260 --> 00:26:54.090
it can write to the RAM
on the raid controller.

526
00:26:54.090 --> 00:26:56.650
Which is way faster than
writing the physical disc.

527
00:26:56.650 --> 00:26:59.410
If you write to the RAM on
that raid controller, and

528
00:26:59.410 --> 00:27:01.240
send the operating system
a message saying hey I'm done.

529
00:27:01.240 --> 00:27:05.380
And the operating system can move on,
way faster.

530
00:27:05.380 --> 00:27:07.360
But it hasn't actually
written to the disk yet.

531
00:27:07.360 --> 00:27:10.460
And in the background, the RAID controller
can calculate parity and write out and

532
00:27:10.460 --> 00:27:11.000
all that stuff.

533
00:27:12.070 --> 00:27:13.900
The operating system
doesn't have to wait on it.

534
00:27:13.900 --> 00:27:18.000
That makes our OS faster,
but it opens us up to risk.

535
00:27:18.000 --> 00:27:19.660
What if I lose power?

536
00:27:19.660 --> 00:27:22.540
My operating system thinks that
I saved the Word document.

537
00:27:22.540 --> 00:27:24.620
It thinks that I wrote to the hard drive.

538
00:27:24.620 --> 00:27:26.840
When in reality,
the RAID controller kinda lied to me.

539
00:27:26.840 --> 00:27:29.060
It wrote to its memory,
it didn't write to the hard drive yet.

540
00:27:29.060 --> 00:27:33.210
And if I lose power,
what happens to RAM when it loses power?

541
00:27:33.210 --> 00:27:34.410
>> Yeah Don, we're in trouble there.

542
00:27:34.410 --> 00:27:38.340
I mean, no power, we lose all of that
information, and we don't get it back.

543
00:27:38.340 --> 00:27:40.370
>> Yeah,
RAM does electronic refresh, right?

544
00:27:40.370 --> 00:27:43.610
It's gotta have electricity to keep
rewriting what's in each little

545
00:27:43.610 --> 00:27:45.880
cell inside of, or each row,
I think it does it by row.

546
00:27:45.880 --> 00:27:47.720
Anyhow, inside of the memory.

547
00:27:47.720 --> 00:27:50.329
Well, the RAM that's on a RAID
uses the same way, we lose power,

548
00:27:50.329 --> 00:27:51.382
we lose what's in there.

549
00:27:51.382 --> 00:27:54.319
It lied to the Operating System,
and told the OS we were done,

550
00:27:54.319 --> 00:27:55.740
when in reality we weren't.

551
00:27:55.740 --> 00:27:57.240
Now on a workstation it's
probably not a big deal,

552
00:27:57.240 --> 00:27:58.920
cuz the OS is failing too, right?

553
00:27:58.920 --> 00:28:01.230
But on a server,
these are network operations.

554
00:28:01.230 --> 00:28:03.480
We might have told another
server that it was done.

555
00:28:03.480 --> 00:28:06.140
Maybe this is a financial transaction,
and we said yeah,

556
00:28:06.140 --> 00:28:10.740
we wrote it to the database But we didn't,
and now you really get in trouble.

557
00:28:10.740 --> 00:28:14.430
So the RAID controllers that are worth
their salt, the ones that cost a good

558
00:28:14.430 --> 00:28:19.400
amount of money, they have a rechargeable
battery right on the RAID controller.

559
00:28:19.400 --> 00:28:24.770
So if your server loses power, they can
hold what's in the RAM on that card for

560
00:28:24.770 --> 00:28:25.390
weeks on end.

561
00:28:25.390 --> 00:28:30.320
And as long as you get power restored to
the system, as soon as it comes back up,

562
00:28:30.320 --> 00:28:32.680
it will finish writing to the disks.

563
00:28:32.680 --> 00:28:36.170
So what it told the OS it did,
it actually does.

564
00:28:36.170 --> 00:28:39.260
Now, if your rate controller
doesn't have a battery on it.

565
00:28:39.260 --> 00:28:41.310
And it has right caching.

566
00:28:41.310 --> 00:28:42.990
On a server, you'll want to turn that off.

567
00:28:42.990 --> 00:28:44.150
On a desktop, you might not care.

568
00:28:44.150 --> 00:28:45.410
But on a server,
you'll want to turn that off.

569
00:28:45.410 --> 00:28:47.840
So just be aware that the ones
that are really worth it.

570
00:28:47.840 --> 00:28:48.880
The rate controllers are large.

571
00:28:48.880 --> 00:28:51.300
Usually cuz they've got
a battery stuck right on them.

572
00:28:51.300 --> 00:28:54.360
And it's typically rechargeable so
it's constantly charging itself and

573
00:28:54.360 --> 00:28:57.570
it's got a lifetime, it's got to be
maintained and replaced over time.

574
00:28:57.570 --> 00:29:01.250
>> That was gonna be my question because I
was gonna ask is this like one of those,

575
00:29:01.250 --> 00:29:05.590
what is it, three volt watch
battery that we have for Sea Moss?

576
00:29:05.590 --> 00:29:09.150
These are actually real rechargeable and
big batteries Usually yes,

577
00:29:09.150 --> 00:29:13.720
the CR2032 batteries you're talking
about have a three year lifetime and

578
00:29:13.720 --> 00:29:17.980
they hold their own electricity when
you buy them and over time it degrades.

579
00:29:17.980 --> 00:29:19.390
>> These are rechargeables.

580
00:29:19.390 --> 00:29:21.550
Well, think about your cell phone or
your laptop.

581
00:29:21.550 --> 00:29:25.610
What would happen if you plugged it into a
wall outlet and you just left it charging

582
00:29:25.610 --> 00:29:30.630
for three years, never drained it,
just for three years it ran.

583
00:29:30.630 --> 00:29:32.030
The batteries go bad, right?

584
00:29:32.030 --> 00:29:34.740
They can't handle that for
a long period of time.

585
00:29:34.740 --> 00:29:37.560
Now if you're constantly having power
outages and draining the battery and

586
00:29:37.560 --> 00:29:39.210
charging it back up, that's different.

587
00:29:39.210 --> 00:29:42.390
But some of them will actually do
conditioning, but they'll never take it

588
00:29:42.390 --> 00:29:44.799
all the way done, because what happens if
you lose power while it was conditioning?

589
00:29:45.840 --> 00:29:47.520
Now you might as well not have it, right?

590
00:29:47.520 --> 00:29:49.090
So they do go bad and

591
00:29:49.090 --> 00:29:52.030
they usually have alerting built into
the system that warns you of that so

592
00:29:52.030 --> 00:29:56.240
you can replace it, they typically use
batteries that are rated for three years,

593
00:29:56.240 --> 00:30:00.090
but if you run a server for longer than
three years you become at risk yourself.

594
00:30:00.090 --> 00:30:01.990
So just be aware of that, and

595
00:30:01.990 --> 00:30:05.910
on battery backed right cache controllers,
they usually have different sizes And

596
00:30:05.910 --> 00:30:11.210
it usually doesn't sound like a whole lot,
like 256 megabytes.

597
00:30:11.210 --> 00:30:12.450
And you're thinking wow, 256?

598
00:30:12.450 --> 00:30:13.310
What is this, 1997?

599
00:30:13.310 --> 00:30:18.410
Well, when you think about how we write
to a RAID array and how quickly we can

600
00:30:18.410 --> 00:30:22.400
get that data on there, especially with
SSD's, you don't need a whole lot cached.

601
00:30:22.400 --> 00:30:24.810
To be able to get that
performance level up.

602
00:30:24.810 --> 00:30:28.950
So you won't typically see gigs and
gigs of memory on a RAID controller,

603
00:30:28.950 --> 00:30:32.420
it's usually just megabytes of memory
cuz that's all you really need.

604
00:30:32.420 --> 00:30:34.700
>> One of the things you had mentioned
there, Don, is you said, for

605
00:30:34.700 --> 00:30:37.865
instance If one of your CMOS
batteries starts to die,

606
00:30:37.865 --> 00:30:40.435
we know that the time clock's
not gonna stay the same.

607
00:30:40.435 --> 00:30:43.015
Every time we reboot a device,
it's gonna have a different time.

608
00:30:43.015 --> 00:30:46.345
Is it just a warning on the controller
that it's gonna let you know that

609
00:30:46.345 --> 00:30:50.675
the battery's failing or is there some
other condition that we might see

610
00:30:50.675 --> 00:30:53.215
beforehand, if it didn't have an alarm?

611
00:30:53.215 --> 00:30:54.735
>> Yeah, like on Dells.

612
00:30:54.735 --> 00:30:56.015
Dell's servers, the powered servers,

613
00:30:56.015 --> 00:30:58.930
they usually have a little
LCD screen on the front.

614
00:30:58.930 --> 00:31:02.230
And so when that battery starts to
get degraded, it'll flash amber and

615
00:31:02.230 --> 00:31:06.160
it'll have a message on there letting
you know the PERC battery is degraded.

616
00:31:06.160 --> 00:31:08.390
So they give you a very visual warning.

617
00:31:08.390 --> 00:31:11.610
HPE has a little light that
lights up on the front of theirs.

618
00:31:11.610 --> 00:31:15.810
But they all have management software that
you can run to be able to reach out and

619
00:31:15.810 --> 00:31:16.440
control that.

620
00:31:16.440 --> 00:31:20.190
So like HP's Insight software
that monitors all the servers or

621
00:31:20.190 --> 00:31:25.490
reports on the hardware, you can report on
fan speeds and RAID battery controller,

622
00:31:25.490 --> 00:31:30.730
the battery backed right cache
controller status, it's a mouthful.

623
00:31:30.730 --> 00:31:32.390
But it can report back and
let you know, and

624
00:31:32.390 --> 00:31:34.720
you can spot it ahead of time typically.

625
00:31:34.720 --> 00:31:38.370
Sometimes you don't necessarily see it,
that's where you need to keep a schedule.

626
00:31:38.370 --> 00:31:40.270
It's kinda like changing
the oil in your car,

627
00:31:40.270 --> 00:31:42.970
your car might not warn you that it's
time to change oil, but you know, hey,

628
00:31:42.970 --> 00:31:45.460
it's been 3,000 miles,
ut;s time to change the oil.

629
00:31:45.460 --> 00:31:48.520
So you have to track that on your servers,
too.

630
00:31:48.520 --> 00:31:51.280
We'll talk about asset management in
another episode, and that's what this is

631
00:31:51.280 --> 00:31:54.810
all really a part of is routine
maintenance and asset management.

632
00:31:54.810 --> 00:31:57.180
>> All right,
lot of great information, Don.

633
00:31:57.180 --> 00:31:59.270
Does look like we're coming to
the end of another episode.

634
00:31:59.270 --> 00:32:03.020
And judging by our objectives here,
looks like you covered it really well,

635
00:32:03.020 --> 00:32:06.860
but Is there anything else that you
might want to throw into this episode?

636
00:32:06.860 --> 00:32:09.710
And maybe any words of wisdom or
caution, maybe,

637
00:32:09.710 --> 00:32:13.510
when it comes to RAID arrays inside
of your server environments?

638
00:32:13.510 --> 00:32:15.600
>> The only other thing that I
haven't really mentioned is that when

639
00:32:15.600 --> 00:32:20.170
you build a RAID array, you have
typically the option to scrub the disks.

640
00:32:20.170 --> 00:32:22.070
You don't have to do that,
but when you scrub the disks,

641
00:32:22.070 --> 00:32:23.650
it makes sure they're
all in complete sync.

642
00:32:23.650 --> 00:32:27.660
It writes ones and zeros to all
the sectors to get them all evened out.

643
00:32:27.660 --> 00:32:31.800
By doing that it can improve
parity calculations in some cases.

644
00:32:31.800 --> 00:32:33.210
So it's a good idea to do the scrub.

645
00:32:33.210 --> 00:32:34.610
It takes a long time.

646
00:32:34.610 --> 00:32:35.530
You can skip it.

647
00:32:35.530 --> 00:32:36.660
Most systems will let you skip it.

648
00:32:36.660 --> 00:32:37.970
Some systems don't even do it.

649
00:32:37.970 --> 00:32:40.710
But on the higher end controllers,
they'll almost always offer to scrub.

650
00:32:40.710 --> 00:32:43.200
And it's a good idea to do that
when you build out an array.

651
00:32:43.200 --> 00:32:46.660
Just a word to the wise.

652
00:32:46.660 --> 00:32:48.080
>> Great piece of advice there, Don.

653
00:32:48.080 --> 00:32:49.540
Thanks for being with us today.

654
00:32:49.540 --> 00:32:51.150
And thank you, the viewer watching.

655
00:32:51.150 --> 00:32:54.390
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

656
00:32:54.390 --> 00:32:55.000
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

657
00:32:55.000 --> 00:32:56.896
>> And we'll see you next time.

658
00:32:56.896 --> 00:33:02.874
[MUSIC]

659
00:33:02.874 --> 00:33:06.091
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don examine various storage technologies that can be utilized in small, medium and enterprise-level networks. They look at such technologies like direct-attached storage, network-attached storage, iSCSI and Fibre Channel over Ethernet or FCoE. They also dive into Fibre Channel implementation that use switch fabric, FC switches, LUNs and LUN masking as well as JBOD, tape drives, USB and optical drives.
episodes.title: Storage Technologies
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.114
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.114 --> 00:00:02.241
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.241 --> 00:00:04.700
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:04.700 --> 00:00:07.511
>> [MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.511 --> 00:00:11.330
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.330 --> 00:00:14.730
>> Hello, and welcome to another
great episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.730 --> 00:00:16.400
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

8
00:00:16.400 --> 00:00:21.130
And in today's episode, we are continuing
through our series in CompTIA's Server+.

9
00:00:21.130 --> 00:00:24.390
And joining us in the studios again
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:24.390 --> 00:00:25.780
Hi, Don, how you doing, sir?

11
00:00:25.780 --> 00:00:26.950
>> I'm doing swell, Wes.

12
00:00:26.950 --> 00:00:29.120
And in this episode,
we're going to be tackling a neat topic.

13
00:00:29.120 --> 00:00:30.724
We're going to talk about
storage technologies.

14
00:00:30.724 --> 00:00:35.870
We've been focusing on drives and
partitions and rate arrays all this time.

15
00:00:35.870 --> 00:00:38.530
Now we're just gonna look at where
we put all these things, right?

16
00:00:38.530 --> 00:00:40.680
You got all these disks,
where are they gonna go?

17
00:00:40.680 --> 00:00:43.170
When you buy a server,
it's probably got some room for

18
00:00:43.170 --> 00:00:44.680
some hard drives right in the server.

19
00:00:44.680 --> 00:00:48.720
But most servers these days
are only 1U in size, one rack unit.

20
00:00:48.720 --> 00:00:53.690
Which means 1.75 inches tall, and that's
not a whole lot of room for hard drives.

21
00:00:53.690 --> 00:00:55.730
So finding a server
these days with room for

22
00:00:55.730 --> 00:00:59.120
more than even eight disks is a rarity.

23
00:00:59.120 --> 00:01:02.352
So if we need more,
where the heck are these drives going?

24
00:01:02.352 --> 00:01:03.650
So that's what we're
gonna look at right here.

25
00:01:03.650 --> 00:01:06.540
Some of the different places,
different ways of arranging storage and

26
00:01:06.540 --> 00:01:08.671
making it available on our
network in a data center.

27
00:01:08.671 --> 00:01:13.589
Going beyond a work station
which has far less options.

28
00:01:14.620 --> 00:01:18.470
All right, so let's get started
with really the easiest solution,

29
00:01:18.470 --> 00:01:21.800
which is what's called direct
attached storage, or DAS.

30
00:01:21.800 --> 00:01:26.060
You'll hear DAS, NAS,
SAN all these crazy acronyms, but

31
00:01:26.060 --> 00:01:30.950
DAS is really just talking about good
old fashioned, direct attached storage,

32
00:01:30.950 --> 00:01:35.270
where you have a server and it's got
drive bays right on the front of it,

33
00:01:35.270 --> 00:01:38.020
possibly inside, and
you pop the drives in.

34
00:01:38.020 --> 00:01:39.190
And that's it.

35
00:01:39.190 --> 00:01:44.030
Now on a positive side, direct attached
storage is usually directly attached.

36
00:01:44.030 --> 00:01:45.220
It runs right into the motherboard.

37
00:01:45.220 --> 00:01:50.920
You get the highest performance possible
because it's wired right into the system.

38
00:01:50.920 --> 00:01:53.280
On a negative side,
you don't have a ton of room.

39
00:01:53.280 --> 00:01:54.500
Cooling can be an issue.

40
00:01:54.500 --> 00:01:57.680
You have limitations as to
how many drives you can have.

41
00:01:57.680 --> 00:02:02.180
And those drives are tied
to just that one server.

42
00:02:02.180 --> 00:02:03.650
So let me give you an example.

43
00:02:03.650 --> 00:02:05.620
Let's say I have
a virtualization farm set up.

44
00:02:05.620 --> 00:02:07.985
So I've got a VMHOST01, 2, 3 and 4.

45
00:02:07.985 --> 00:02:13.180
And each of these virtual machine hosts
has direct attached storage, right?

46
00:02:13.180 --> 00:02:17.020
Maybe 6 terabytes of storage available for
virtual machines.

47
00:02:17.020 --> 00:02:21.343
And I have a virtual machine like
WEB01 that's running on VMHOST01.

48
00:02:21.343 --> 00:02:25.980
So this is the guest, WEB01,
running on the host VMHOST01.

49
00:02:25.980 --> 00:02:30.820
If it's right here on this storage and
this server were to fail, if VMHOST01

50
00:02:30.820 --> 00:02:37.450
fails and goes offline, I can't rapidly
move WEB01 to one of these other servers.

51
00:02:37.450 --> 00:02:43.111
Because WEB01 exists on these hard drives,
and these hard drives are on VMHOST01.

52
00:02:43.111 --> 00:02:45.930
And there's nothing I can do about that.

53
00:02:45.930 --> 00:02:48.130
I can run as fast as I
can to the server room,

54
00:02:48.130 --> 00:02:52.030
rip the hard drives out of VMHOST01 and
go stick them into another server,

55
00:02:52.030 --> 00:02:54.710
assuming there's room and
assuming they're hot swappable.

56
00:02:54.710 --> 00:02:56.807
But otherwise, direct attached
storage is not going to allow that.

57
00:02:56.807 --> 00:02:59.759
By having non-shared storage like this,

58
00:02:59.759 --> 00:03:05.898
it limits functionality like clusters and
even load-balancing in a lot of cases.

59
00:03:05.898 --> 00:03:09.380
Cuz with load-balancing, I would have to
have some other mechanism on the back end

60
00:03:09.380 --> 00:03:11.280
replicating the data across the drives.

61
00:03:11.280 --> 00:03:13.840
I would have to store
four copies of Web01,

62
00:03:13.840 --> 00:03:16.860
which is a real waste of storage, right?

63
00:03:16.860 --> 00:03:20.500
So direct attached storage is not
very efficient in a data center.

64
00:03:20.500 --> 00:03:23.950
At home, in your office on your desktop or
your laptop,

65
00:03:23.950 --> 00:03:27.230
direct attached storage is really the only
way to fly cuz it doesn't make sense

66
00:03:27.230 --> 00:03:30.620
to have some really expensive
storage hardware for your desktop.

67
00:03:30.620 --> 00:03:33.720
