That's up to the cluster to do that.

294
00:15:10.960 --> 00:15:13.040
The storage is just storage.

295
00:15:13.040 --> 00:15:13.940
It just does it's job.

296
00:15:13.940 --> 00:15:15.694
It says I have hard drives,
I will present them to you.

297
00:15:15.694 --> 00:15:18.820
If you want to screw up and let two people
write to the same one you can do it,

298
00:15:18.820 --> 00:15:19.710
good luck, right?

299
00:15:19.710 --> 00:15:21.270
So it's up to your operating systems.

300
00:15:21.270 --> 00:15:25.629
If I'm running Windows and I'm running
the Microsoft Windows failover cluster

301
00:15:25.629 --> 00:15:28.587
service, it dictates who
gets access to those disks.

302
00:15:28.587 --> 00:15:33.010
The SAN would be saying, everybody's
allowed to write, have at it, right?

303
00:15:33.010 --> 00:15:37.500
So let the storage unit focus on storage,
let the cluster focus on clustering.

304
00:15:37.500 --> 00:15:39.750
That's the approach,
because you may not be running Windows.

305
00:15:39.750 --> 00:15:42.730
Maybe you've got a Linux Beowulf cluster.

306
00:15:42.730 --> 00:15:44.538
And so now you've got a different
system that's managing that.

307
00:15:44.538 --> 00:15:47.826
Maybe you have multiple paths,
and so you're leveraging MPIO,

308
00:15:47.826 --> 00:15:49.260
Multi Path Input Output, so

309
00:15:49.260 --> 00:15:53.109
that you can load balance across the two
different switch fabrics, right?

310
00:15:53.109 --> 00:15:55.927
Now the storage unit definitely doesn't
know what the heck's going on, so

311
00:15:55.927 --> 00:15:57.963
you gotta have a way to communicate and
talk with that.

312
00:15:57.963 --> 00:16:00.406
The storage unit doesn't
get too involved in that.

313
00:16:00.406 --> 00:16:01.957
It's just presenting drives.

314
00:16:01.957 --> 00:16:05.190
With LUN masking, we can restrict
that drive presentation, but

315
00:16:05.190 --> 00:16:06.890
otherwise it's just doing it.

316
00:16:06.890 --> 00:16:09.970
So, that kind of the key principle
behind a Fibre Channel SAN.

317
00:16:09.970 --> 00:16:14.442
It's expensive, but if you go and
buy a Fibre Channel SAN right now,

318
00:16:14.442 --> 00:16:17.307
I've kinda standardized on 16 gigabit.

319
00:16:17.307 --> 00:16:20.290
So we have one gigabit and
10 gigabit network.

320
00:16:20.290 --> 00:16:22.045
Sometimes 40 gigabit networks.

321
00:16:22.045 --> 00:16:26.530
SANs, they're 16 gigabit
right out of the box.

322
00:16:26.530 --> 00:16:29.752
And if you've got SAS drives or
whatever that are six gigabit drives,

323
00:16:29.752 --> 00:16:32.228
they've got plenty of room
to be able to handle that.

324
00:16:32.228 --> 00:16:35.480
And with Fibre, you can be sending on
more than one frequency at the same time,

325
00:16:35.480 --> 00:16:38.080
which can give you
simultaneous drive access, and

326
00:16:38.080 --> 00:16:40.820
that really creates a level of
performance that's pretty amazing.

327
00:16:40.820 --> 00:16:44.320
So, this is the solution that you're gonna
see in larger data centers where you have

328
00:16:44.320 --> 00:16:46.500
clustered systems that
need shared storage.

329
00:16:48.170 --> 00:16:52.912
Now, going all the way back to direct
attached storage, when you plug disks in,

330
00:16:52.912 --> 00:16:57.305
we might build arrays on them, and so
you have RAID on Fibre Channel SANs and

331
00:16:57.305 --> 00:17:01.242
shared storage like NAS and SAN,
you'll build arrays there too.

332
00:17:01.242 --> 00:17:02.512
You don't have to though.

333
00:17:02.512 --> 00:17:04.880
You can leave them as independent disks,
right?

334
00:17:04.880 --> 00:17:09.040
And they call that JBOD,
or just a bunch of disks.

335
00:17:09.040 --> 00:17:11.410
When you present the disks to a system,

336
00:17:11.410 --> 00:17:15.280
if we've applied a RAID array to
it then you see the container.

337
00:17:15.280 --> 00:17:16.920
You see the single drive.

338
00:17:16.920 --> 00:17:19.660
It might be five drives under the hood,
but you only see one.

339
00:17:19.660 --> 00:17:22.500
With JBOD, you see each individual disk.

340
00:17:22.500 --> 00:17:25.770
And that frees it up so the operating
system can use the drives individually or

341
00:17:25.770 --> 00:17:28.500
they can build a software
RAID across them if need be.

342
00:17:28.500 --> 00:17:33.360
But JBOD, that's not typically used on
servers, cuz we want redundancy and

343
00:17:33.360 --> 00:17:34.600
JBOD doesn't do it.

344
00:17:34.600 --> 00:17:36.930
And we're not gonna use software
RAID if we can avoid it.

345
00:17:36.930 --> 00:17:39.800
But on workstations and stuff,
you're technically dealing with JBOD.

346
00:17:39.800 --> 00:17:43.700
Each disk is an independent disk
that functions without the others.

347
00:17:43.700 --> 00:17:45.970
Now, as far as storage is concerned,

348
00:17:45.970 --> 00:17:49.650
these are the primary storage types that
we're gonna be seeing in a data center.

349
00:17:49.650 --> 00:17:52.720
But there are a few other kind of
one offs that I wanna mention.

350
00:17:52.720 --> 00:17:55.640
I don't have pretty diagrams for
but that we should think about.

351
00:17:55.640 --> 00:17:59.819
And that is for example,
I had a pretty picture for one masking,

352
00:17:59.819 --> 00:18:02.579
I didn't even use it,
but any how [LAUGH], so

353
00:18:02.579 --> 00:18:06.750
here I've got my different drives and
they kind of colored.

354
00:18:06.750 --> 00:18:11.015
So on the SAN, we can say like,
WEB01 is allowed to see this green drive.

355
00:18:11.015 --> 00:18:12.585
Or WEB02, you can see the purple drive.

356
00:18:12.585 --> 00:18:14.835
Database 01,
you can see two of these red drives.

357
00:18:14.835 --> 00:18:16.065
And they're all isolated out.

358
00:18:16.065 --> 00:18:19.345
That's what LUN masking is all about.

359
00:18:19.345 --> 00:18:22.735
But those are some of the things that
we're gonna see in a data center.

360
00:18:22.735 --> 00:18:26.430
Other types of one off storage will
be things like if I have tape backup.

361
00:18:26.430 --> 00:18:30.200
If I have tape backup, I might have
a dedicated network just for the tape or

362
00:18:30.200 --> 00:18:33.020
the tape drives might be
directly attached to the servers.

363
00:18:33.020 --> 00:18:35.910
That's a little more common cuz
it's cheaper to do it that way.

364
00:18:35.910 --> 00:18:40.870
When you have tapes, they plug in
usually to a SATA port on the server,

365
00:18:40.870 --> 00:18:41.910
even if your server is all SCSI though,

366
00:18:41.910 --> 00:18:45.920
usually there'll be at least one SATA
port for a CD drive, or the tape backup.

367
00:18:45.920 --> 00:18:48.890
Sometimes they'll even have traditional
older SCSI ports on there for

368
00:18:48.890 --> 00:18:51.190
the tape backup, you can backup to it.

369
00:18:51.190 --> 00:18:54.370
Tape backup doesn't need a huge amount of
speed, cuz you can write over hours and

370
00:18:54.370 --> 00:18:56.900
hours and hours, and it just doesn't
impact the performance of your server.

371
00:18:56.900 --> 00:18:59.110
But it is available, it's there.

372
00:18:59.110 --> 00:19:02.114
You can access that data if you need it.

373
00:19:02.114 --> 00:19:06.206
Most people moved away from tape though
cuz it's faster to back up to SAN or

374
00:19:06.206 --> 00:19:07.800
network storage like that.

375
00:19:07.800 --> 00:19:09.260
We also have optical drives,

376
00:19:09.260 --> 00:19:12.320
I mentioned CD drives,
a lot of servers still have a CD drive so

377
00:19:12.320 --> 00:19:15.730
you can install your operating system
on them or run diagnostic utilities.

378
00:19:15.730 --> 00:19:19.550
But even that's going away, and
a lot of the newer servers just have USB.

379
00:19:19.550 --> 00:19:23.740
That we can have flash drives and thumb
drives that we pop in to boot the system

380
00:19:23.740 --> 00:19:27.970
off of, maybe to install the OS or
run maintenance.

381
00:19:27.970 --> 00:19:30.310
Maybe you boot the OS
off a flash drive and

382
00:19:30.310 --> 00:19:31.890
then all the data is accessed on the SAN.

383
00:19:31.890 --> 00:19:35.000
So you don't have any moving hard
drives in the system at all.

384
00:19:35.000 --> 00:19:36.210
Those are all different solution,

385
00:19:36.210 --> 00:19:38.306
different types of storage
you might find in a server.

386
00:19:38.306 --> 00:19:40.970
But predominately,
you're gonna be dealing with

387
00:19:40.970 --> 00:19:45.950
direct attached storage of hard drives,
or SAN, storage area network.

388
00:19:45.950 --> 00:19:46.620
NAS?

389
00:19:46.620 --> 00:19:48.120
That's more of a replacement for a server.

390
00:19:48.120 --> 00:19:50.123
That's more of small environment.

391
00:19:50.123 --> 00:19:54.250
In a large environment, it's gonna
be all direct attached storage and

392
00:19:54.250 --> 00:19:55.711
storage area networks.

393
00:19:55.711 --> 00:19:58.620
All right, I think that's about all
I've got on storage technologies.

394
00:19:58.620 --> 00:19:59.840
Wes, can you think of
anything I've forgot?

395
00:19:59.840 --> 00:20:01.405
>> No,
I think you've hit everyone of them.

396
00:20:01.405 --> 00:20:03.020
Looking by at our objectives.

397
00:20:03.020 --> 00:20:04.540
I've been marking them off
as you've been going on.

398
00:20:04.540 --> 00:20:08.130
>> There is one I didn't really
mention though which is FCoE.

399
00:20:08.130 --> 00:20:10.810
FCoE is Fibre Channel over Ethernet.

400
00:20:10.810 --> 00:20:12.755
We were talking about Fibre Channel SANs,
right?

401
00:20:12.755 --> 00:20:14.221
And Fibre Channel SANs are grey.

402
00:20:14.221 --> 00:20:15.685
Let me go back to my diagram.

403
00:20:15.685 --> 00:20:19.449
Fibre Channel SANs are grey, if all
the servers are in the same building and

404
00:20:19.449 --> 00:20:23.250
I can just run the fiber right to the
fiber switch and plug in the SAN to that.

405
00:20:23.250 --> 00:20:25.150
And now everybody gets access.

406
00:20:25.150 --> 00:20:27.929
But what if I wanna go to
a model with redundant SANs?

407
00:20:29.040 --> 00:20:32.310
If I wanted redundant SANs and they're in
the same building, that's not a big deal.

408
00:20:32.310 --> 00:20:36.620
But what if they're in
completely different locations?

409
00:20:36.620 --> 00:20:40.690
What if I had a headquarters, right
here in Gainesville with San Juan, and

410
00:20:40.690 --> 00:20:44.390
then I want a failover to Atlanta,
so I have another SAN up there?

411
00:20:44.390 --> 00:20:48.120
How do I replicate data between the two,
these are Fibre Channel SANs.

412
00:20:48.120 --> 00:20:52.920
I can't pay for fiber to run from
here all the way to Atlanta.

413
00:20:52.920 --> 00:20:55.820
Even if I could pay for,
I don't know that I can get it cleared

414
00:20:55.820 --> 00:20:58.580
permit wise to run a cable
from here to Atlanta.

415
00:20:58.580 --> 00:21:04.140
So instead, I can take Fibre Channel and
encapsulate it and

416
00:21:04.140 --> 00:21:08.640
throw it over Ethernet, and send it across
a VPN tunnel or the Internet or whatever.

417
00:21:08.640 --> 00:21:12.546
Now, when I mentioned iSCSI, Wes made
the comment that hey, iSCSI encapsulates,

418
00:21:12.546 --> 00:21:15.421
that slows it down, right,
Fibre Channel doesn't do that.

419
00:21:15.421 --> 00:21:19.310
Here I'm encapsulating Fibre Channel,
so it kills performance,

420
00:21:19.310 --> 00:21:22.960
it's not suitable for
running as far as production use.

421
00:21:22.960 --> 00:21:26.250
But for backups and
replication, it works out well.

422
00:21:26.250 --> 00:21:28.970
So you'll see FCoE,
Fibre Channel Over Ethernet,

423
00:21:28.970 --> 00:21:32.400
where we take our Fibre Channel
communications here and we send them over

424
00:21:32.400 --> 00:21:35.790
an Ethernet network to be able to dump
off onto another SAN somewhere else.

425
00:21:35.790 --> 00:21:38.250
If the SANs are in the same building,

426
00:21:38.250 --> 00:21:40.620
you actually get pretty
decent performance out of it.

427
00:21:40.620 --> 00:21:43.840
But if they're in different geographical
locations, it's gonna be slow.

428
00:21:43.840 --> 00:21:47.140
And that's why it's only used for
replication and failover.

429
00:21:47.140 --> 00:21:50.130
So just another technology with neat
objectives I didn't really mention.

430
00:21:50.130 --> 00:21:53.662
They count that as network-attached
storage, because you're using an existing

431
00:21:53.662 --> 00:21:56.040
network and
you're pushing your storage data over it.

432
00:21:56.040 --> 00:21:59.900
So a little different than
what we consider a normal SAN.

433
00:21:59.900 --> 00:22:02.600
>> I was gonna say I thought we had
a lot of options when it comes to server

434
00:22:02.600 --> 00:22:03.140
environments.

435
00:22:03.140 --> 00:22:07.060
But it looks like, for performance wise,
we really only have a couple there.

436
00:22:07.060 --> 00:22:09.090
Don, it does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

437
00:22:09.090 --> 00:22:10.900
But before we do,
do you have any parting words?

438
00:22:10.900 --> 00:22:13.520
And maybe you'd like to let our
viewers know when it comes to

439
00:22:13.520 --> 00:22:15.980
different storage technologies
in our server environments.

440
00:22:15.980 --> 00:22:17.850
>> Don't be daunted by the price of a SAN.

441
00:22:17.850 --> 00:22:20.320
They're expensive, but
they're a necessity.

442
00:22:20.320 --> 00:22:24.240
And so it needs to be worked into your
IT budget and part of that process.

443
00:22:24.240 --> 00:22:27.980
When you have large amounts of storage,
if you're juggling around iSCSI devices,

444
00:22:27.980 --> 00:22:29.650
the performance is terrible.

445
00:22:29.650 --> 00:22:31.565
Your servers are gonna be running
way better if you just made

446
00:22:31.565 --> 00:22:32.690
the investment in it.

447
00:22:32.690 --> 00:22:34.660
The nice part about SANs
is that they're expandable.

448
00:22:34.660 --> 00:22:36.500
They can grow with your company.

449
00:22:36.500 --> 00:22:38.370
So once you get them deployed,

450
00:22:38.370 --> 00:22:40.760
it's not like you're having to
replace it every two years.

451
00:22:40.760 --> 00:22:43.130
You'll usually be able to run the SAN for
a good five years, and

452
00:22:43.130 --> 00:22:46.580
just continually add storage to it,
before it needs replacing.

453
00:22:46.580 --> 00:22:48.480
It's an investment that's worthwhile.

454
00:22:48.480 --> 00:22:49.940
>> All right Don, great information,

455
00:22:49.940 --> 00:22:52.210
we appreciate you being here
in the studios with us.

456
00:22:52.210 --> 00:22:54.010
We appreciate you, the viewer watching.

457
00:22:54.010 --> 00:22:56.852
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

458
00:22:56.852 --> 00:22:57.631
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

459
00:22:57.631 --> 00:22:59.647
>> And we'll see you next time.

460
00:22:59.647 --> 00:23:05.688
[MUSIC]

461
00:23:05.688 --> 00:23:08.865
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explain the concepts around storage capacity. They talk about the different measurements between drive manufacturers such as gigabyte vs. gigibyte as well as disk quotas in Windows and Linux. They discuss compression and capacity planning considerations.
episodes.title: Storage Capacity
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.170 --> 00:00:01.473
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.473 --> 00:00:02.571
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.571 --> 00:00:07.121
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:07.121 --> 00:00:08.220
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.220 --> 00:00:11.893
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.893 --> 00:00:14.890
>> Hello, and welcome to another
great episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.890 --> 00:00:16.160
Thank you for joining us.

8
00:00:16.160 --> 00:00:17.020
I'm your host Wes Bryan,

9
00:00:17.020 --> 00:00:21.860
and in today's episode we're continuing
through our series in CompTIA Server+.

10
00:00:21.860 --> 00:00:24.810
Joining us back in the studios again
is none other that Mr. Don Pezet.

11
00:00:24.810 --> 00:00:25.860
Don, how you doing, sir?

12
00:00:25.860 --> 00:00:26.680
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

13
00:00:26.680 --> 00:00:28.587
Ready to dive right back into Server+.

14
00:00:28.587 --> 00:00:30.592
And as we've been doing
the last couple of episodes,

15
00:00:30.592 --> 00:00:32.660
we're gonna be focusing on storage.

16
00:00:32.660 --> 00:00:36.590
But in this episode, we are going to take
a step back from some of the hardware for

17
00:00:36.590 --> 00:00:37.350
a moment and

18
00:00:37.350 --> 00:00:41.790
take look at a little more of the software
side of storage on our servers.

19
00:00:41.790 --> 00:00:44.400
And just kinda look at a few things
that we need to be aware of that

20
00:00:44.400 --> 00:00:48.270
are going on in the background and
things that you'll see pretty frequently.

21
00:00:48.270 --> 00:00:53.920
What I wanna start with is one of the
great big storage mysteries of the ages,

22
00:00:53.920 --> 00:00:58.950
which is, you go to the store or online or
wherever and you buy a hard drive.

23
00:00:58.950 --> 00:01:01.390
And it's a terabyte hard drive.

24
00:01:01.390 --> 00:01:03.880
And you plug it into your server and
you fire it up.

25
00:01:03.880 --> 00:01:05.260
And you go to access it.

26
00:01:05.260 --> 00:01:09.000
And all of a sudden, that terabyte hard
drive becomes a 940 gig hard drive.

27
00:01:10.430 --> 00:01:14.780
And you're wondering,
like where'd my 60 gigabytes of data go?

28
00:01:14.780 --> 00:01:18.280
I remember my first computer
that had a hard drive.

29
00:01:18.280 --> 00:01:19.800
My first computer didn't have hard drives,
but

30
00:01:19.800 --> 00:01:22.590
my first one that did had
a 40 megabyte hard drive.

31
00:01:23.710 --> 00:01:26.090
And 40 megabyte, that sounded like a lot.

32
00:01:26.090 --> 00:01:33.110
I mean, that was, I don't know, 20 to 25
floppy disks all stored on one hard drive.

33
00:01:33.110 --> 00:01:34.370
That was awesome.

34
00:01:34.370 --> 00:01:39.300
And the thought of wasting 60 gigabytes

35
00:01:39.300 --> 00:01:41.590
of data would have just
blown my mind back then.

36
00:01:41.590 --> 00:01:43.970
And even having one gigabyte of
data would have blown my mind,

37
00:01:43.970 --> 00:01:45.920
when 40 megabytes was all that I had.

38
00:01:45.920 --> 00:01:51.630
But here we are today and
we lose storage like that all the time.

39
00:01:51.630 --> 00:01:53.530
Well, what the heck is happening, right?

40
00:01:53.530 --> 00:01:54.900
Where is that storage going?

41
00:01:54.900 --> 00:01:57.480
Why is it that I throw these large
hard drives into my servers,

42
00:01:57.480 --> 00:02:01.370
I pay extra money for them, and they
show up smaller than they actually are?

43
00:02:01.370 --> 00:02:05.740
And the reality is they're not any
smaller than they actually are.

44
00:02:05.740 --> 00:02:10.810
There's two different ways to
measure the size of a hard drive,

45
00:02:10.810 --> 00:02:13.690
to measure the amount of
data that a drive can store.

46
00:02:13.690 --> 00:02:18.330
And unfortunately, the hard drive
manufacturers do it one way and

47
00:02:18.330 --> 00:02:20.540
everyone else does it a different way.

48
00:02:20.540 --> 00:02:22.590
Now I know what you're thinking.

49
00:02:22.590 --> 00:02:26.660
Those sleazy hard drive manufacturers
measuring things the wrong way,

50
00:02:26.660 --> 00:02:29.130
so it makes drives look bigger,
how dare they?

51
00:02:29.130 --> 00:02:32.355
But the reality is hard drive
manufacturers actually measure it

52
00:02:32.355 --> 00:02:35.795
the right way, and everywhere
else we measure it the wrong way.

53
00:02:35.795 --> 00:02:37.765
Now let me explain what I'm talking about.

54
00:02:37.765 --> 00:02:41.248
And I'm gonna have to throw some numbers
up here, do a little bit of early morning

55
00:02:41.248 --> 00:02:45.425
math, which is always tough, but it's
important to understand the concept here.

56
00:02:45.425 --> 00:02:50.388
What's going on is that as human beings
we normally count things using what's

57

00:25:26.699 --> 00:25:29.346
we're talking about the last time
I updated was over a year ago.

503
00:25:29.346 --> 00:25:30.542
>> [LAUGH] Nice.

504
00:25:30.542 --> 00:25:33.820
Good to practice proper
security procedures.

505
00:25:33.820 --> 00:25:36.470
Not a critical production system, right.

506
00:25:36.470 --> 00:25:41.015
But speaking of Windows updates, did you
know that the Windows operating system

507
00:25:41.015 --> 00:25:43.840
caches every single
update it ever applies?

508
00:25:43.840 --> 00:25:45.816
You keep a copy of it.
Even though you've already applied

509
00:25:45.816 --> 00:25:47.324
the update, you keep a copy of it.

510
00:25:47.324 --> 00:25:49.440
And that'll fill up your hard drive.

511
00:25:49.440 --> 00:25:51.560
Let's take a look at this Windows server.

512
00:25:51.560 --> 00:25:55.339
So this is a Windows Server 2012 R2
machine, no, Windows Server 2016.

513
00:25:55.339 --> 00:25:56.213
This is the latest and greatest.

514
00:25:56.213 --> 00:26:02.350
It's been up and running probably for
a year now, this particular machine.

515
00:26:02.350 --> 00:26:05.380
And so it's up and it's going,
and it's doing updates.

516
00:26:05.380 --> 00:26:08.200
It was actually annoying me with
an update right before this show, so

517
00:26:08.200 --> 00:26:10.040
it's doing its updates.

518
00:26:10.040 --> 00:26:14.310
And as it does those updates,
it's saving them on the hard drive.

519
00:26:14.310 --> 00:26:18.510
If I browse into this,
I'm gonna go to C and then into Windows.

520
00:26:18.510 --> 00:26:21.300
Inside of your Windows folder,
there's a folder called WinSxS.

521
00:26:22.460 --> 00:26:27.770
This guy right here, SxS, all right.

522
00:26:27.770 --> 00:26:32.240
It is caching every single update
that this system has ever applied.

523
00:26:32.240 --> 00:26:35.318
If you browse into it,
look at all these files.

524
00:26:35.318 --> 00:26:37.942
These are all folders
that contain the updates.

525
00:26:37.942 --> 00:26:42.273
So here's a bunch of ACPI updates,
and dashboard updates and so on,

526
00:26:42.273 --> 00:26:44.520
that this system has taken.

527
00:26:44.520 --> 00:26:51.120
And if I highlight them all here,
17,573 updates.

528
00:26:51.120 --> 00:26:52.697
That's a lot of updates.

529
00:26:52.697 --> 00:26:56.423
And if I take a look at the size
of that folder as a whole,

530
00:26:56.423 --> 00:26:58.368
I think I saw it a second ago.

531
00:26:58.368 --> 00:27:02.930
It was about 6.5 gigs, so
let's let that tally up.

532
00:27:02.930 --> 00:27:08.720
So that's gonna add up here, and it's
gonna be about 6.5 gigabytes of updates.

533
00:27:08.720 --> 00:27:13.890
Now, if I've got a 128 gig SSD for
my operating system, which is usually

534
00:27:13.890 --> 00:27:17.790
plenty for an OS, and then I've got a
bunch of other drives for my data, right.

535
00:27:17.790 --> 00:27:23.010
128 gig drive for my OS, and
I'm consuming 6.5 gigs here.

536
00:27:23.010 --> 00:27:26.520
That's a decent chunk of that storage,
and it's only gonna grow.

537
00:27:26.520 --> 00:27:28.820
It's gonna get bigger, and bigger, and
bigger, the longer we run the system.

538
00:27:28.820 --> 00:27:31.350
So we've got to be sure
that we monitor that.

539
00:27:31.350 --> 00:27:33.463
Microsoft will tell you,
hey when you install Windows,

540
00:27:33.463 --> 00:27:35.102
you only need 20 gigs of hard drive space.

541
00:27:35.102 --> 00:27:37.100
And that's true, on day one.

542
00:27:37.100 --> 00:27:41.580
But over time, you're gonna get patches,
you're gonna get updates.

543
00:27:41.580 --> 00:27:44.350
You're gonna install software,
log files are gonna grow.

544
00:27:44.350 --> 00:27:46.170
All these things are gonna happen.

545
00:27:46.170 --> 00:27:49.954
And that operating system that used
to take 20 gigs on the hard drive,

546
00:27:49.954 --> 00:27:52.113
now takes 36 or 40 gigs, 50 gigs.

547
00:27:52.113 --> 00:27:54.044
It starts growing, and
growing, and growing.

548
00:27:54.044 --> 00:27:55.986
So that's why we have to monitor.

549
00:27:55.986 --> 00:28:01.187
You might have spec-ed it perfectly for
day 1, but not day 100 or day 1000.

550
00:28:01.187 --> 00:28:03.767
>> Don, I know you've had a lot of work,

551
00:28:03.767 --> 00:28:07.004
you've done a lot of
work inside of databases.

552
00:28:07.004 --> 00:28:10.024
Is there anything that we might have to
worry about when it comes to a database

553
00:28:10.024 --> 00:28:11.245
and the storage capacities?

554
00:28:11.245 --> 00:28:15.900
>> Yeah, databases, just by nature,
and same thing for file servers.

555
00:28:15.900 --> 00:28:18.240
When you bring them up, yeah,
you've created a database or

556
00:28:18.240 --> 00:28:20.220
you've populated your file server.

557
00:28:20.220 --> 00:28:21.380
And now you open it to the end users.

558
00:28:21.380 --> 00:28:23.080
Well, what do the users do?

559
00:28:23.080 --> 00:28:25.530
They add data, right?

560
00:28:25.530 --> 00:28:29.440
And if we're adding some records
to the system, then it grows.

561
00:28:29.440 --> 00:28:33.840
And if we're adding tons of records
to the systems, it grows really fast.

562
00:28:33.840 --> 00:28:38.340
So for example, we'll use WordPress.

563
00:28:38.340 --> 00:28:42.050
The ITProTV website used
to be entirely WordPress.

564
00:28:42.050 --> 00:28:44.560
I think there's only two or three
pages now that are part of WordPress.

565
00:28:44.560 --> 00:28:45.800
But it used to be entirely WordPress.

566
00:28:45.800 --> 00:28:47.440
And we had a database for users.

567
00:28:47.440 --> 00:28:49.260
Well, when we first opened for

568
00:28:49.260 --> 00:28:52.350
business, we were adding a handful
of users every single day.

569
00:28:52.350 --> 00:28:54.800
And so the user database
started to grow a little bit.

570
00:28:54.800 --> 00:28:58.246
Well, then when our service
started to catch on,

571
00:28:58.246 --> 00:29:01.373
we started adding hundreds
of users per day.

572
00:29:01.373 --> 00:29:05.277
And now we're in the tens of thousands or
whatever.

573
00:29:05.277 --> 00:29:06.913
Where it's this giant user database,

574
00:29:06.913 --> 00:29:09.157
where there's tons of users
that are going in there.

575
00:29:09.157 --> 00:29:11.327
And that database is growing even faster.

576
00:29:11.327 --> 00:29:14.977
And databases are tricky because,
remember, you never write to a database,

577
00:29:14.977 --> 00:29:17.640
You always write to
their transaction logs.

578
00:29:17.640 --> 00:29:21.320
So the transaction logs grow, and
then they write to the database and

579
00:29:21.320 --> 00:29:21.880
the database grows.

580
00:29:21.880 --> 00:29:22.639
So you're really writing everything twice.

581
00:29:22.639 --> 00:29:26.401
It takes twice the space, and
you can run out of hard drive space.

582
00:29:26.401 --> 00:29:29.130
And that's why we divide things up so
much.

583
00:29:29.130 --> 00:29:33.467
On a file server, on a database server,
your operating system is on one partition,

584
00:29:33.467 --> 00:29:35.310
your data is on another partition.

585
00:29:35.310 --> 00:29:37.620
And if you have transaction logs,
they're on a third partition.

586
00:29:37.620 --> 00:29:41.300
You might move your page file or
your swap to a separate partition, so

587
00:29:41.300 --> 00:29:44.630
that they can't bump into each other's and
impact each other.

588
00:29:44.630 --> 00:29:48.270
And if you're running application servers,
right, any miscellaneous type application,

589
00:29:48.270 --> 00:29:50.870
you need to understand the storage
that application uses and

590
00:29:50.870 --> 00:29:53.240
make sure you account for
it just like anything else.

591
00:29:53.240 --> 00:29:55.180
It's all part of the solution.

592
00:29:56.250 --> 00:30:00.580
And then lastly, remember that just
because hard drive space is cheap,

593
00:30:00.580 --> 00:30:03.500
doesn't mean you should keep
all of your data online and

594
00:30:03.500 --> 00:30:05.170
available at every single moment.

595
00:30:05.170 --> 00:30:08.790
You're going to have data that nobody
uses anymore, that's really old stuff.

596
00:30:08.790 --> 00:30:11.120
We have that,
we have all our video footage here.

597
00:30:11.120 --> 00:30:12.956
And we have episodes that
we filmed four years ago,

598
00:30:12.956 --> 00:30:15.916
episodes that aren't even on the website
anymore because the material is dated.

599
00:30:15.916 --> 00:30:17.557
And it has been re-filmed and replaced.

600
00:30:17.557 --> 00:30:21.810
But we keep it,
that's part of our archive.

601
00:30:21.810 --> 00:30:23.570
We don't need that on our fast storage.

602
00:30:23.570 --> 00:30:24.900
We don't need that
available on the network.

603
00:30:24.900 --> 00:30:26.930
It's a rare day when somebody says,

604
00:30:26.930 --> 00:30:29.470
can I get that video footage that
you guys shot four years ago?

605
00:30:29.470 --> 00:30:34.500
I really need to learn something about
Windows Vista or something ancient.

606
00:30:34.500 --> 00:30:36.614
Well, we don't need that very often.

607
00:30:36.614 --> 00:30:39.902
So it doesn't matter if it's burned on
a DVD and stuck on a shelf somewhere.

608
00:30:39.902 --> 00:30:40.910
We can go and get it.

609
00:30:40.910 --> 00:30:44.450
It doesn't have to be on our SAN and
then available at this very moment.

610
00:30:44.450 --> 00:30:49.655
So archival data is data that
we don't need immediately.

611
00:30:49.655 --> 00:30:53.425
And we can afford to put it on cheaper
storage, lower redundancy storage,

612
00:30:53.425 --> 00:30:57.675
even slow or a remote storage it
takes a while for us to get to.

613
00:30:57.675 --> 00:31:01.692
That helps to take a lot of pressure
off of your server storage.

614
00:31:01.692 --> 00:31:04.371
All right, I think as far as
storage capacity is concerned,

615
00:31:04.371 --> 00:31:06.273
that's the basics of what we need to know.

616
00:31:06.273 --> 00:31:10.480
Do understand that in the world of SANs,
storage area networks,

617
00:31:10.480 --> 00:31:12.400
you can have so much storage.

618
00:31:12.400 --> 00:31:14.100
And it's so easy to slice it and apply it,

619
00:31:14.100 --> 00:31:16.570
that we really don't worry about a lot
of the stuff that we talked about here.

620
00:31:16.570 --> 00:31:20.530
But when you're dealing with cloud
type solutions where you're paying for

621
00:31:20.530 --> 00:31:24.350
every single gigabyte, you really start
paying attention to that storage.

622
00:31:24.350 --> 00:31:28.690
If I'm paying $0.10 per gigabyte, and
the Microsoft updates are consuming 8

623
00:31:28.690 --> 00:31:33.660
gigs on my hard drive, then it's
gonna be costing me $0.80 a month.

624
00:31:33.660 --> 00:31:35.380
Now, that doesn't sound like a big deal.

625
00:31:35.380 --> 00:31:37.060
$0.80 a month, who cares?

626
00:31:37.060 --> 00:31:41.180
What if I have 100 servers,
now it becomes $8 a month.

627
00:31:41.180 --> 00:31:44.700
And if you do that over the course of
years, it adds up to a substantial amount.

628
00:31:44.700 --> 00:31:46.930
So those are things that we need
to be paying attention to and

629
00:31:46.930 --> 00:31:49.020
trying to keep under control.

630
00:31:49.020 --> 00:31:50.160
>> Don, a lot of great information.

631
00:31:50.160 --> 00:31:51.500
I know that's always been confusing.

632
00:31:51.500 --> 00:31:56.635
Is it a giga or gigy bite,
is it 1,000 megs is it 1,024?

633
00:31:56.635 --> 00:31:59.410
So I appreciate you telling us
all that great information.

634
00:31:59.410 --> 00:32:01.743
It does look like we're running to
the end of another great episode.

635
00:32:01.743 --> 00:32:05.291
But before we do, Don, do you have any
parting words when it comes to storage

636
00:32:05.291 --> 00:32:07.850
capacities inside of our
server environments today?

637
00:32:07.850 --> 00:32:11.100
>> The main lesson I want you to take away
here is monitor, monitor your storage.

638
00:32:11.100 --> 00:32:12.336
It's super easy to monitor, right?

639
00:32:12.336 --> 00:32:15.170
We can use SNMP, CIM, WMI,

640
00:32:15.170 --> 00:32:17.470
there's all sorts of different
technologies we can use.

641
00:32:17.470 --> 00:32:21.375
In the Linux world, there's some amazing
open source stuff like Zabbix and

642
00:32:21.375 --> 00:32:24.440
Nagios that let you easily monitor
the storage on your servers.

643
00:32:24.440 --> 00:32:26.110
It not something that should
ever sneak up on you.

644
00:32:26.110 --> 00:32:27.810
You should see it slowly growing and

645
00:32:27.810 --> 00:32:31.240
be able to trend out in the future,
when am I gonna run out of storage?

646
00:32:31.240 --> 00:32:33.180
I can see right here on my current pace,

647
00:32:33.180 --> 00:32:35.100
six months from now I'm
gonna run out of storage.

648
00:32:35.100 --> 00:32:38.240
Plenty of time to put more storage
in the budget, or troubleshoot and

649
00:32:38.240 --> 00:32:40.000
free up storage, and resolve the issue.

650
00:32:40.000 --> 00:32:43.010
You should never be blindsided
by a storage issue.

651
00:32:43.010 --> 00:32:45.920
>> All right, Don, great information,
thanks for joining us in the studio.

652
00:32:45.920 --> 00:32:47.317
It's been a pleasure having
you out there with us.

653
00:32:47.317 --> 00:32:50.229
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryant.

654
00:32:50.229 --> 00:32:51.283
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

655
00:32:51.283 --> 00:32:52.274
>> And we'll see you next time.

656
00:32:52.274 --> 00:32:59.754
[MUSIC]

657
00:32:59.754 --> 00:33:05.890
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:04.586
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:04.586 --> 00:00:07.714
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:11.735 --> 00:00:14.929
Welcome to another exciting

5
00:00:14.929 --> 00:00:16.590
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:16.590 --> 00:00:21.782
And in today's episode we are continuing
through our CompTia Server+ SK0-004.

7
00:00:21.782 --> 00:00:24.370
And we're gonna be looking

8
00:00:24.370 --> 00:00:27.000
Joining us in the studios,
it's non other than Mr. Don Bizet.

9
00:00:27.000 --> 00:00:28.170
Don, how you doing, sir?

10
00:00:28.170 --> 00:00:29.190
>> I'm ready, Wes.

11
00:00:29.190 --> 00:00:29.920
>> All right.

12
00:00:29.920 --> 00:00:31.462
>> Let's get physical.
>> [LAUGH]

13
00:00:31.462 --> 00:00:33.630
>> We need some Olivia Newton-John music.

14
00:00:33.630 --> 00:00:34.409
>> Yeah.
>> Because we're gonna get

15
00:00:34.409 --> 00:00:35.112
physical in this episode.

16
00:00:35.112 --> 00:00:36.942
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right,

17
00:00:36.942 --> 00:00:39.210
in this episode we're talking
about physical security.

18
00:00:39.210 --> 00:00:41.360
And it is super important.

19
00:00:41.360 --> 00:00:43.050
It's super important and it's super easy.

20
00:00:43.050 --> 00:00:45.200
So really, it's something we
should all be implementing.

21
00:00:45.200 --> 00:00:47.560
But so many people don't
that it's almost painful.

22
00:00:48.600 --> 00:00:51.130
When you talk about servers,
and you talk about security,

23
00:00:51.130 --> 00:00:55.560
you'll hear people talk about full disk
encryption, and firewalls, and deep

24
00:00:55.560 --> 00:00:59.540
packet inspection, and intrusion detection
devices, and all this crazy stuff.

25
00:01:00.640 --> 00:01:03.412
And then it's just super simple to shut
their data center down because they

26
00:01:03.412 --> 00:01:05.451
didn't take the precautions for
physical security.

27
00:01:05.451 --> 00:01:10.140
There are steps we can take to ensure
that our data centers are safe.

28
00:01:10.140 --> 00:01:13.450
And they should start with keeping
people out of the data center.

29
00:01:13.450 --> 00:01:15.940
Because if somebody can
get into the data center,

30
00:01:15.940 --> 00:01:20.520
a lot of the fancy technical jargon we
throw around really doesn't do any good.

31
00:01:20.520 --> 00:01:22.620
So for example,
the servers right behind me.

32
00:01:22.620 --> 00:01:25.570
If somebody were to get into that room and

33
00:01:25.570 --> 00:01:27.500
they didn't know the first
thing about a computer,

34
00:01:27.500 --> 00:01:31.610
they don't know how to do a man in
the middle attack, or anything like that.

35
00:01:31.610 --> 00:01:34.640
They can just walk around and
unplug power cables.

36
00:01:34.640 --> 00:01:36.800
It's that simple, and
now my servers are offline,

37
00:01:36.800 --> 00:01:40.120
they just created an outage because
they unplugged power cables.

38
00:01:40.120 --> 00:01:42.584
They could pour water on a server.

39
00:01:42.584 --> 00:01:45.190
It's not like a plant,
where it's gonna be happy about that.

40
00:01:45.190 --> 00:01:47.820
You just pour water on the server and
it'll short out and

41
00:01:47.820 --> 00:01:50.370
shut down, problem solved, right.

42
00:01:50.370 --> 00:01:54.610
So those are challenges we
have to be able to overcome.

43
00:01:54.610 --> 00:01:57.590
And it even extends beyond just that room.

44
00:01:57.590 --> 00:02:01.390
For example, there's an air conditioning
unit that powers just that room.

45
00:02:02.410 --> 00:02:06.080
That air conditioning unit has
an external fan outside of our building.

46
00:02:06.080 --> 00:02:09.820
Somebody could walk up to that exterior
unit and just take a big stick or

47
00:02:09.820 --> 00:02:12.630
a metal meter stick or whatever, and
stick it right down in there and

48
00:02:12.630 --> 00:02:14.170
stop the fan from spinning.

49
00:02:14.170 --> 00:02:16.210
Well, now the hot air is
not leaving the building.

50
00:02:16.210 --> 00:02:18.090
Where's the hot air going?

51
00:02:18.090 --> 00:02:19.783
Right there, and staying in that room.

52
00:02:19.783 --> 00:02:22.332
The temperature builds up,
you get a thermal shutdown,

53
00:02:22.332 --> 00:02:24.600
your data center's offline.

54
00:02:24.600 --> 00:02:26.020
As simple as that.

55
00:02:26.020 --> 00:02:29.520
Physical security should
not be overlooked.

56
00:02:29.520 --> 00:02:32.917
It's harder because somebody has
to be here to use it, right?

57
00:02:32.917 --> 00:02:36.891
So a hacker in a foreign country is not
going to pull off a physical security

58
00:02:36.891 --> 00:02:38.900
attack on your data center.

59
00:02:38.900 --> 00:02:42.630
It's usually going to be an employee or
a former employee or

60
00:02:42.630 --> 00:02:45.520
a business rival that happens
to be in that same area.

61
00:02:45.520 --> 00:02:48.250
Cuz then it's easy for
them to gain physical access or

62
00:02:48.250 --> 00:02:50.900
to at least be within
proximity of your location.

63
00:02:50.900 --> 00:02:53.891
>> So Don what you're saying is we always
think technical when we think of denial of

64
00:02:53.891 --> 00:02:54.838
service attacks right?

65
00:02:54.838 --> 00:02:55.849
A SYN flood attack,

66
00:02:55.849 --> 00:02:59.550
a buffer overflow attack, or just ping
the server until it goes offline.

67
00:02:59.550 --> 00:03:02.250
And you're saying that a denial of service
attack could be as simple as taking

68
00:03:02.250 --> 00:03:05.130
a blanket and throwing it over
an exhaust port on the roof,

69
00:03:05.130 --> 00:03:07.440
creating thermal temperature shut downs.

70
00:03:07.440 --> 00:03:07.970
>> That's it.

71
00:03:07.970 --> 00:03:10.986
And there's countless stories, where
people have shut down really advanced data

72
00:03:10.986 --> 00:03:12.591
centers through simple tactics like that.

73
00:03:12.591 --> 00:03:15.070

74
00:03:15.070 --> 00:03:17.580
So we've gotta make sure
we take precautions

75
00:03:17.580 --> 00:03:19.410
to secure our environment, right?

76
00:03:19.410 --> 00:03:21.180
So let's talk about physical security.

77
00:03:22.480 --> 00:03:25.230
Physical security takes
many different forms.

78
00:03:25.230 --> 00:03:28.070
Any type of security, really,
takes many different forms.

79
00:03:28.070 --> 00:03:30.690

00:03:30.690 --> 00:03:34.040

81
00:03:34.040 --> 00:03:36.720
Well, how do you know if

00:03:36.720 --> 00:03:39.240
You need some kind of
credentialing system.

00:03:39.240 --> 00:03:42.540
A credentialing system is where
people have to prove they are who

00:03:42.540 --> 00:03:43.580
they say they are.

85
00:03:43.580 --> 00:03:46.850
So if there's a data center out there and
I just walk right up to the door and

00:03:46.850 --> 00:03:47.920
I say hi I'm Don.

00:03:47.920 --> 00:03:50.000
I'm going to use my real name.

00:03:50.000 --> 00:03:51.880
I'm Don Bizet, I'm with Dell.

00:03:51.880 --> 00:03:53.660
I'm here to do a warranty
repair on one of your servers.

90
00:03:53.660 --> 00:03:55.530
Can you take me to your server room?

91
00:03:55.530 --> 00:03:57.530
And they'll say well,
I'll need to see some credentials.

92
00:03:57.530 --> 00:04:00.300
And I'll say,
I've got my Dell t-shirt on or whatever.

93
00:04:00.300 --> 00:04:01.920

94
00:04:01.920 --> 00:04:04.150
And as long as you've got a tool kit and
a little rolling cart,

00:04:04.150 --> 00:04:05.320
people will believe you're a technician.

96
00:04:05.320 --> 00:04:06.190
That's all it takes.

97
00:04:06.190 --> 00:04:08.300
And now you're socially
engineering your way in.

98
00:04:08.300 --> 00:04:12.240
And they walk you into the server room and

99
00:04:12.240 --> 00:04:16.780
So If I had a better way to prove
that yeah, I work for Dell, or

100
00:04:16.780 --> 00:04:18.230
I work for HPE, or

101
00:04:18.230 --> 00:04:22.410
whoever, then they would be able to tell

00:04:22.410 --> 00:04:26.033
And if I obviously didn't work for that

103
00:04:26.033 --> 00:04:26.966
they were now safe.

104
00:04:26.966 --> 00:04:29.870
So that's credentialing
on a physical side.

105
00:04:29.870 --> 00:04:31.880
We do credentialing on

106
00:04:31.880 --> 00:04:34.820
You log into your email, you provide

107
00:04:34.820 --> 00:04:35.860
Username and a password.

108
00:04:35.860 --> 00:04:36.920
The username is public.

109
00:04:36.920 --> 00:04:37.570
Everybody knows that.

110
00:04:37.570 --> 00:04:38.760
That doesn't count for anything.

111
00:04:38.760 --> 00:04:40.300
So, it's really just the password.

112
00:04:40.300 --> 00:04:41.840
You know a password.

113
00:04:41.840 --> 00:04:45.120
And because you know it,
you must be you, right?

114
00:04:45.120 --> 00:04:45.980
That's how we're validating.

00:04:45.980 --> 00:04:47.460
Which we all know,

00:04:47.460 --> 00:04:49.300
I can tell my password to Wes.

00:04:49.300 --> 00:04:51.260

00:04:51.260 --> 00:04:53.360

00:04:53.360 --> 00:04:56.010
Cuz he knows the password, he must be Don.

120
00:04:56.010 --> 00:04:58.520
That's as smart as your

121
00:04:58.520 --> 00:05:00.690
Your computer is only as
smart as you make it and

122
00:05:00.690 --> 00:05:02.610
we haven't made them terribly smart.

123
00:05:02.610 --> 00:05:05.520
So, what we just saw
there with passwords or

124
00:05:05.520 --> 00:05:08.630
what we just heard is what's

125
00:05:08.630 --> 00:05:12.160
In authentication,
there's really three methods.

126
00:05:12.160 --> 00:05:17.050
Something you know,
something you have or something you are.

127
00:05:17.050 --> 00:05:19.410
Something you know is the most

128
00:05:19.410 --> 00:05:20.000
I know a password.

129
00:05:20.000 --> 00:05:23.030
If I go to an ATM machine,
I put my ATM card in and

130
00:05:23.030 --> 00:05:26.560

it's gonna ask me for a PIN number.

131
00:05:26.560 --> 00:05:28.510
The PIN number is something I know.

132
00:05:28.510 --> 00:05:30.920
It's a personal identification number,
PIN.

133
00:05:30.920 --> 00:05:33.850
I know it, if somebody else knows my pin,

134
00:05:33.850 --> 00:05:36.978
And that's the weakness of something you

135
00:05:36.978 --> 00:05:39.844
But passwords, pins,

136
00:05:39.844 --> 00:05:41.760
Then there's something you have.

00:05:41.760 --> 00:05:46.199

00:05:46.199 --> 00:05:49.360

00:05:49.360 --> 00:05:51.890
Because I have this,

00:05:51.890 --> 00:05:54.180

00:05:54.180 --> 00:05:56.890
Anybody can fire up a printer,

00:05:56.890 --> 00:05:58.950

143
00:05:58.950 --> 00:06:02.510
Well, sometimes the something you have
gets a little more advanced than that.

144
00:06:02.510 --> 00:06:04.990
This one has an RFID chip in it.

145
00:06:04.990 --> 00:06:08.010
And so, when I walk into the building,
I am able to hold this up to a scanner and

146
00:06:08.010 --> 00:06:09.420
it reads the RFID chip.

147
00:06:09.420 --> 00:06:12.310
So, just printing a card like
this might be good enough for

148
00:06:12.310 --> 00:06:14.090
walking through the hallway.

149
00:06:14.090 --> 00:06:17.820
But it won't get you through a door unless
they can match that RFID chip, right?

150
00:06:17.820 --> 00:06:18.890
Something you have.

151
00:06:18.890 --> 00:06:20.291
They can even be more advanced, for

152
00:06:20.291 --> 00:06:23.060
example, I'm just gonna dig through
my pockets this whole episode.

153
00:06:24.420 --> 00:06:27.520
My very, very beaten YubiKey.

154
00:06:27.520 --> 00:06:31.890
So when I log in to my computer and
I go to log in to my email or

155
00:06:31.890 --> 00:06:35.260
my file server or several other
different things that I have.

156
00:06:35.260 --> 00:06:36.790
I have a Google Chromebook.

157
00:06:36.790 --> 00:06:40.580
Any time I turn the Google Chromebook on,
it says insert your security key.

158
00:06:40.580 --> 00:06:42.870
And I take this little key,
and I plug it in the side.

159
00:06:42.870 --> 00:06:46.980
And I tap the button right there,
so it can transmit my key, and

160
00:06:46.980 --> 00:06:48.260
it lets me into the system.

161
00:06:48.260 --> 00:06:49.606
It's something I have.

162
00:06:49.606 --> 00:06:53.410
Now if you were to beat me up and
take this key, now you have what I had.

163
00:06:53.410 --> 00:06:54.959
Now it's something I had,
not something I have.

164
00:06:56.010 --> 00:06:58.890
So when you take this key you

165
00:06:58.890 --> 00:07:02.220
You plug it in, touch a button and
now you're me, congratulations, right?

166
00:07:02.220 --> 00:07:05.940
Now you get to work [LAUGH].
So that's something I have.

167
00:07:05.940 --> 00:07:07.940
And then there's something you are.

168
00:07:07.940 --> 00:07:09.850
Something you are is your physical being.

169
00:07:09.850 --> 00:07:13.310
And that's normally going to be things
like your fingerprint, your thumbprint.

170
00:07:13.310 --> 00:07:20.060
Retinal scan, blood sample, hair sample,
voice recognition, facial recognition.

171
00:07:20.060 --> 00:07:21.610
That's something you are.

172
00:07:21.610 --> 00:07:24.740
There's companies like Microsoft that's
making a big push with Windows Hello to

173
00:07:24.740 --> 00:07:25.476
identify people.

174
00:07:25.476 --> 00:07:27.700
And we've had fingerprint for a while.

175
00:07:27.700 --> 00:07:30.570
Most laptops have a fingerprint
reader built into them.

176
00:07:30.570 --> 00:07:32.520
But now they're getting
into facial recognition.

177
00:07:32.520 --> 00:07:35.290
The problem with facial recognition
is it's easy to fake, right?

178
00:07:35.290 --> 00:07:37.460
So you could hold a picture up
of somebody and you'll pass it.

179
00:07:38.660 --> 00:07:41.780
And that's why the new ones use
infrared cameras, where they can tell,

180
00:07:41.780 --> 00:07:43.130
is there body heat?

181
00:07:43.130 --> 00:07:44.290
Is it three dimensional?

182
00:07:44.290 --> 00:07:45.810
They can actually tell that stuff and

183
00:07:45.810 --> 00:07:48.192
it defeats the old hold
up a picture type thing.

184
00:07:48.192 --> 00:07:50.900
So there's different technologies
that are available there, but

185
00:07:50.900 --> 00:07:53.560
it's something you are,
it's your physical being.

186
00:07:53.560 --> 00:07:55.810
I can't share my fingerprints with Wes.

187
00:07:55.810 --> 00:07:58.750
I can't say, hey Wes when you get bored
can you log in as me and do some work,

188
00:07:58.750 --> 00:07:59.345
here's my face.

189
00:07:59.345 --> 00:08:01.502
[SOUND] Well,
it was that stupid John Travolta movie I

190
00:08:01.502 --> 00:08:02.500
guess-
>> Face Off.

191
00:08:02.500 --> 00:08:04.656
>> Yeah, yeah, all right,
well maybe you can do that.

192
00:08:04.656 --> 00:08:06.168
All right,
cuz everything in movies is true.

193
00:08:06.168 --> 00:08:10.697
But I can't share my fingerprint, well we
could get more of it, I guess you could,

00:08:10.697 --> 00:08:11.690
well never mind.

195
00:08:11.690 --> 00:08:13.670
All right, so there's ways, right?

00:08:13.670 --> 00:08:16.800
My voice, that would be a little harder,
somebody could record that, but

00:08:16.800 --> 00:08:18.780
there's ways of detecting a recording.

198
00:08:18.780 --> 00:08:21.700
The point is,
all three of these have weaknesses.

199
00:08:21.700 --> 00:08:24.290
Something you are, something you have,
something you know.

200
00:08:24.290 --> 00:08:25.630
There's a weakness to each one.

201
00:08:26.840 --> 00:08:31.990
But if we use more than one,
if we go multi-factor,

202
00:08:31.990 --> 00:08:34.270
now we can really start
to shore things up.

203
00:08:34.270 --> 00:08:38.470
So when I wave my little YubiKey around,
and I said hey,

204
00:08:38.470 --> 00:08:44.740
you can just beat me up and take this key,
or actually this is another RFID fob.

205
00:08:44.740 --> 00:08:48.790
I probably have a radiation
footprint that's pretty big.

206
00:08:48.790 --> 00:08:50.990
But I've got another RFID fob here.

207
00:08:50.990 --> 00:08:54.410
Same idea, you can beat me up and
take this fob and now you've got it.

208
00:08:54.410 --> 00:08:56.740
You're now me.

209
00:08:56.740 --> 00:09:01.170
But, what if I use this in

00:09:01.170 --> 00:09:03.880
I mentioned my
Google Chromebook in my office.

00:09:03.880 --> 00:09:06.970
That if I fire that thing up,
it's gonna ask me for my key.

00:09:06.970 --> 00:09:08.410
But it actually doesn't ask for
the key right away.

00:09:08.410 --> 00:09:10.550
It asks for my username and password.

00:09:10.550 --> 00:09:14.390
I have to provide my username and password

00:09:14.390 --> 00:09:17.990
This is a second form of authentication,
or 2FA.

216
00:09:17.990 --> 00:09:20.130
We used to call it
dual-factor authentication.

217
00:09:20.130 --> 00:09:21.940
Now they call it
multi-factor authentication,

218
00:09:21.940 --> 00:09:24.290
cuz you might have more than two, right?

219
00:09:24.290 --> 00:09:27.980
If I ever forget this key fob I can say,
you know,

00:09:27.980 --> 00:09:33.380
instead, let me present
a code from my authenticator.

00:09:33.380 --> 00:09:37.720
And so, I have an authenticator, which,
I'm not checking my text messages on

00:09:37.720 --> 00:09:40.570
the show here, I'm actually trying to
fire up my authenticator real quick, so

00:09:40.570 --> 00:09:44.450
that when I go to log in
I can take my phone and

00:09:44.450 --> 00:09:48.220
it'll have a six-digit number on it
that's changing every 30 seconds.

225
00:09:48.220 --> 00:09:51.180
And so, when I go to log into that laptop,
if I don't have my key, I can switch and

00:09:51.180 --> 00:09:51.800
use this instead.

227
00:09:51.800 --> 00:09:53.150
Again, something I have.

228
00:09:53.150 --> 00:09:54.890
I have my phone.

00:09:54.890 --> 00:09:57.500
If you were to beat me up and

00:09:57.500 --> 00:10:00.970
you got my code, but

00:10:00.970 --> 00:10:05.130
Or, if you watch over my shoulder and you

00:10:05.130 --> 00:10:07.322
So you don't have my authenticator,

00:10:07.322 --> 00:10:10.260
You'd have to have both
forms of authentication

00:10:10.260 --> 00:10:13.690
to be able to access my account and

235
00:10:13.690 --> 00:10:17.530
Now, on a server that becomes a little
more challenging to do, right?

236
00:10:17.530 --> 00:10:19.640
On a server,
if somebody walks up to it and

00:10:19.640 --> 00:10:23.060
goes to login, do I want them to be able
to plugin USB keys and all that stuff?

00:10:23.060 --> 00:10:26.310
Well, we don't normally let users
access our servers directly.

00:10:26.310 --> 00:10:28.540
They're going through a website or
other service, and

00:10:28.540 --> 00:10:32.060

00:10:32.060 --> 00:10:34.590
But for your admins, your admins,

00:10:34.590 --> 00:10:37.720
the ones who need to be able to walk into
that server room and check the status,

00:10:37.720 --> 00:10:41.180
check the temperature, replace

244
00:10:41.180 --> 00:10:42.820
How do we know they
are who they say they are,

00:10:42.820 --> 00:10:44.010
when they're going into the data center?

00:10:44.010 --> 00:10:47.000
And, don't think of a little data center,
like mine.

00:10:47.000 --> 00:10:48.380
We, what do we have?

00:10:48.380 --> 00:10:49.380
30 employees here.

00:10:49.380 --> 00:10:50.960
I know every employee by name, so

00:10:50.960 --> 00:10:53.660
if there's somebody in the hallway I
don't recognize, they're not an employee.

251
00:10:53.660 --> 00:10:55.100
It's a small company.

252
00:10:55.100 --> 00:10:59.000
But, if you work for IBM, and
you have thousands of technicians and

253
00:10:59.000 --> 00:11:02.840
data centers that are massive in size,
there's no way you know every employee.

254
00:11:02.840 --> 00:11:06.470
And you're hiring new employees
everyday probably, a company that size.

255
00:11:06.470 --> 00:11:08.900
So, you're constantly
going to see new faces.

256
00:11:08.900 --> 00:11:10.710
How do you know they should be there?

257
00:11:10.710 --> 00:11:12.610
You need forms of authentication.

258
00:11:12.610 --> 00:11:13.680
They need to have an ID badge.

259
00:11:13.680 --> 00:11:16.200
They need to have a fingerprint
scan to open the door.

00:11:16.200 --> 00:11:19.750
You need to prevent things

00:11:19.750 --> 00:11:21.660
Let's talk about tailgating.

00:11:21.660 --> 00:11:24.700
In a lot of data centers,

00:11:24.700 --> 00:11:28.060
A man trap is where you don't just

00:11:28.060 --> 00:11:29.600
you go through two doors, right?

265
00:11:29.600 --> 00:11:31.860
Here's the problem with one door.

266
00:11:31.860 --> 00:11:35.960
When I walk up to a door, the front of
our building here, I scan my card and

267
00:11:35.960 --> 00:11:39.000
it unlocks the door for
about 15 seconds, so long enough for

268
00:11:39.000 --> 00:11:39.890
me to get through the door.

269
00:11:39.890 --> 00:11:41.930
So I can open it and walk in.

270
00:11:41.930 --> 00:11:45.390
Well 15 seconds is long enough for
three or four people to get in.

271
00:11:45.390 --> 00:11:48.210
So I might open the door with my badge and
then three or

272
00:11:48.210 --> 00:11:51.840
four more people walk right behind me and

273
00:11:51.840 --> 00:11:54.283
I might even hold the door for

00:11:54.283 --> 00:11:56.128
Hey, here, let me get the door for

00:11:56.128 --> 00:12:00.610
Meanwhile I'm letting unauthorized

00:12:00.610 --> 00:12:02.410
Right, so that's not good.

00:12:02.410 --> 00:12:05.960
So it's supposed to be up to the employees

00:12:05.960 --> 00:12:09.310
But are they gonna pull that door, and
hold it, and wait for that 15 seconds?

279
00:12:09.310 --> 00:12:10.150
I'm not gonna let you in.

280
00:12:10.150 --> 00:12:12.680
They're not gonna do that, right?

281
00:12:12.680 --> 00:12:15.020
So what a man trap does,
is it puts somebody else in charge.

282
00:12:15.020 --> 00:12:17.130
You have two sets of door.

283
00:12:17.130 --> 00:12:19.150
Think of it like
an airlock on a spaceship.

284
00:12:19.150 --> 00:12:21.530
So, you have an external door and
an internal door.

285
00:12:21.530 --> 00:12:24.620
The external door opens and you step in.

286
00:12:24.620 --> 00:12:27.620
The external door closes and locks.

287
00:12:27.620 --> 00:12:31.570
For a brief moment,
both doors are closed and locked.

288
00:12:31.570 --> 00:12:35.830
Then the interior door opens and
you're able to walk in.

289
00:12:35.830 --> 00:12:40.260
And then it closes and locks and
the exterior door opens again.

290
00:12:40.260 --> 00:12:42.130
One person at a time can come in.

291
00:12:42.130 --> 00:12:44.369
And typically, it's a manual operation.

292
00:12:45.410 --> 00:12:49.160
That you have an operator,
somebody who's watching that room, so

293
00:12:49.160 --> 00:12:53.160
if two people come in,
they don't unlock the interior door.

294
00:12:53.160 --> 00:12:56.570
No, two people, one of you has to get
out and just one at a time comes in.

295
00:12:56.570 --> 00:13:00.220
In the big data centers,
if you were to go to AWS,

296
00:13:00.220 --> 00:13:04.520
like Amazon's, or IBM's, or one of the big

00:13:04.520 --> 00:13:07.850
And even their own employees that they

00:13:07.850 --> 00:13:11.610
it's still limited to one person at

00:13:11.610 --> 00:13:13.570
They might even go bigger than that.

00:13:13.570 --> 00:13:14.610

00:13:14.610 --> 00:13:17.030
I've got a little picture here

00:13:17.030 --> 00:13:20.040

00:13:20.040 --> 00:13:21.400
Well, it's not really

535
00:24:32.460 --> 00:24:35.200
That co-location facility I mentioned,
they had racks for

536
00:24:35.200 --> 00:24:37.820
tons of different customers
all laid out there.

537
00:24:37.820 --> 00:24:40.750
If I went into work on my servers what
would stop me from walking over and

538
00:24:40.750 --> 00:24:42.330
messing with somebody else's?

539
00:24:42.330 --> 00:24:44.020
Well, usually the racks were locked.

540
00:24:44.020 --> 00:24:45.220
I couldn't open their rack.

541
00:24:45.220 --> 00:24:47.990
And there were cameras, it would've
recorded me doing it anyways, so

542
00:24:47.990 --> 00:24:49.010
I would've got in trouble.

543
00:24:49.010 --> 00:24:52.140
But having the rack locked will
stop people from being able to

544
00:24:52.140 --> 00:24:53.230
get to your equipment.

545
00:24:53.230 --> 00:24:55.700
Here, we only have our stuff.

546
00:24:55.700 --> 00:24:58.050
Every server you see in
the background is an ITProTV server.

547
00:24:58.050 --> 00:25:00.020
It's powering something that we do.

548
00:25:00.020 --> 00:25:02.900
So, we keep the room locked,
and that's the end of it.

549
00:25:02.900 --> 00:25:07.460
But, there were doors with all these,
or there are, back behind the racks.

550
00:25:07.460 --> 00:25:10.090
We don't use the doors because
they just get in the way.

551
00:25:10.090 --> 00:25:11.780
But if we had multiple tenants,

552
00:25:11.780 --> 00:25:15.580
multiple people sharing this little data
center, then we would put the doors up.

553
00:25:15.580 --> 00:25:16.210
We'd put them up and

554
00:25:16.210 --> 00:25:19.320
we'd lock them to be able to make sure
that only we had that access, all right?

555
00:25:19.320 --> 00:25:21.540
So, having locks on the rack is one thing.

556
00:25:21.540 --> 00:25:24.260
Also having locks on your servers.

557
00:25:24.260 --> 00:25:27.020
If you have encrypted hard drives you
don't really care if somebody steals

558
00:25:27.020 --> 00:25:28.110
the drives.

559
00:25:28.110 --> 00:25:30.870
But if you have unencrypted hard drives
cuz you're trying to get the best

560
00:25:30.870 --> 00:25:35.080
performance, somebody could take
the hard drives right out of the server.

561
00:25:35.080 --> 00:25:38.000
And if they do that,
now they've got your data.

562
00:25:38.000 --> 00:25:40.660
They can run home and
hook it up and gain access to it.

563
00:25:40.660 --> 00:25:42.600
Well, maybe your drives aren't
accessible from the front.

564
00:25:42.600 --> 00:25:45.240
Maybe they gotta slide the server out and
open the case.

565
00:25:45.240 --> 00:25:50.280
Well, most servers have a physical lock on
their case so that you can't open them up.

566
00:25:50.280 --> 00:25:52.950
It's nothing a high-powered
drill couldn't overcome, but

567
00:25:52.950 --> 00:25:56.030
it'll stop somebody from quickly
grabbing components out.

568
00:25:56.030 --> 00:25:58.860
I've heard of that, where data centers,
somebody went in and

569
00:25:58.860 --> 00:26:02.360
stole memory out of a server and
then fired it back up.

570
00:26:02.360 --> 00:26:04.960
So the server was up and
running, it was just slow, and

571
00:26:04.960 --> 00:26:06.360
people didn't know why right away.

572
00:26:06.360 --> 00:26:08.660
And it took a few days before they
realized it was missing memory,

573
00:26:08.660 --> 00:26:09.830
and they were able to go back and

574
00:26:09.830 --> 00:26:12.350
check the cameras and
find footage to show what had happened.

575
00:26:12.350 --> 00:26:14.670
But that type of attack could
be difficult to track down,

576
00:26:14.670 --> 00:26:16.030
physical locks can impede that.

577
00:26:17.300 --> 00:26:20.490
Some systems go even further and you
have locks on individual components like

578
00:26:20.490 --> 00:26:24.320
locks on each individual hard drive to
stop them from accidentally being removed.

579
00:26:24.320 --> 00:26:26.760
It's not as common but
it is something that is done.

580
00:26:26.760 --> 00:26:30.780
I've seen some Dell servers where
they would have locks that would

581
00:26:30.780 --> 00:26:33.188
lock four drives or four at a time out of,

582
00:26:33.188 --> 00:26:37.240
I think this one I remember had 16
instead of four individual locks.

583
00:26:37.240 --> 00:26:39.980
But vendors have kind of
moved away from that because

584
00:26:39.980 --> 00:26:42.210
people are a lot better about
physically securing their equipment.

585
00:26:43.862 --> 00:26:48.690
All right, the last thing that I have to
mention, it's on the exam objectives.

586
00:26:48.690 --> 00:26:51.400
I had a little picture
of server x with doors,

587
00:26:51.400 --> 00:26:52.740
which we can just look at real quick.

588
00:26:54.120 --> 00:26:56.490
Here's an example of a bunch
of APC server racks.

589
00:26:56.490 --> 00:27:01.350
And you'll see on each handle, let's
see if I can zoom in that a little bit,

590
00:27:01.350 --> 00:27:03.770
on each handle,
you've got a locking mechanism.

591
00:27:03.770 --> 00:27:06.550
So that's what's locking it and
holding it closed, and

592
00:27:06.550 --> 00:27:11.070
making sure that people can't just
open the door and get in there.

593
00:27:11.070 --> 00:27:13.770
And then on the individual servers,
there's usually locks also,

594
00:27:13.770 --> 00:27:16.180
which we can't really see these
they are a little too small.

595
00:27:16.180 --> 00:27:19.630
But there'll be locks that are making sure
that people can't just pop a face plate

596
00:27:19.630 --> 00:27:21.790
off and grab a hard drive out of it.

597
00:27:21.790 --> 00:27:26.770
All right, but now let's go super
low-tech and talk about safes, right?

598
00:27:26.770 --> 00:27:29.490
Good, old-fashioned combination safes.

599
00:27:29.490 --> 00:27:33.440
Hard metal that you can't get
into with a blowtorch, safes.

600
00:27:34.570 --> 00:27:37.620
What role do safes have
in the server world?

601
00:27:37.620 --> 00:27:41.720
Safes are really important and
every data center should have a safe,

602
00:27:41.720 --> 00:27:45.850
usually a much larger one than this I just
found this picture because it was easy

603
00:27:45.850 --> 00:27:48.160
to use and it looks funny.

604
00:27:48.160 --> 00:27:52.960
But, safes do play an important role even
in today's IT world because there's some

605
00:27:52.960 --> 00:27:58.828
data that we need to keep protected and
we need to keep it offline, all right?

606
00:27:58.828 --> 00:28:03.150
Examples, private keys,
when you have private keys used for

607
00:28:03.150 --> 00:28:05.730
encryption and you need to back up
those keys you don't want those

608
00:28:05.730 --> 00:28:08.400
sitting on a hard drive somewhere
where somebody can get access to it.

609
00:28:08.400 --> 00:28:12.710
You don't want them on a USB key laying on
your desk where somebody can pick it up.

610
00:28:12.710 --> 00:28:16.960
You want it burned to a disc and
locked in a vault.

611
00:28:16.960 --> 00:28:21.000
Your backup tapes, you don't want them
sitting on a shelf where somebody could

612
00:28:21.000 --> 00:28:23.040
grab them and
restore it to another machine.

613
00:28:23.040 --> 00:28:26.490
You want them locked up in a vault for
physical security,

614
00:28:26.490 --> 00:28:29.120
as well as, what if a fire breaks out?

615
00:28:29.120 --> 00:28:33.070
Most safes are fire rated to protect
the contents of the safe from the fire.

616
00:28:33.070 --> 00:28:35.650
So now your backup tapes could
survive a fire in your building.

617
00:28:35.650 --> 00:28:36.910
You really want them off site, but

618
00:28:36.910 --> 00:28:40.470
if you're going to keep some on site
you want them locked in a vault.

619
00:28:40.470 --> 00:28:43.560
Any kind of password recovery keys,

620
00:28:43.560 --> 00:28:48.060
any kind of really secret information
like that, backups of your

621
00:28:48.060 --> 00:28:52.750
certificate authorities that kind of
stuff you want locked in a vault.

622
00:28:52.750 --> 00:28:56.550
A vault that only the highest
level people have access level to.

623
00:28:56.550 --> 00:28:59.710
Typically it is the CIO and
the CSO, right?

624
00:28:59.710 --> 00:29:01.990
Your Chief Information Officer and
your Chief Security Officer.

625
00:29:01.990 --> 00:29:03.780
And, you might have a CISO,

626
00:29:03.780 --> 00:29:06.590
a Chief Information Security Officer
then that would be the person.

627
00:29:06.590 --> 00:29:10.390
And, anytime something goes in or
out of that safe, that person's involved.

628
00:29:10.390 --> 00:29:13.800
They go and open the safe,
they log what's being taken out or

629
00:29:13.800 --> 00:29:16.560
they log what's being put back in and
they lock the safe.

630
00:29:16.560 --> 00:29:19.230
You keep a log, a record,
of everything that goes in and out.

631
00:29:19.230 --> 00:29:21.760
A safe like that,
is really an essential thing.

632
00:29:21.760 --> 00:29:26.030
Your company likely already has one,
because of all the financial data,

633
00:29:26.030 --> 00:29:27.510
and accounting, and stuff.

634
00:29:27.510 --> 00:29:29.940
So you've probably already got
one that could be used, or

635
00:29:29.940 --> 00:29:31.560
you might have a dedicated one just for
IT.

636
00:29:31.560 --> 00:29:34.790
If you're putting backups in there,
you probably have a dedicated one for

637
00:29:34.790 --> 00:29:37.580
IT, cuz you're gonna need a big one,
versus your company,

638
00:29:37.580 --> 00:29:39.530
which probably just needs a small one for
their records.

639
00:29:40.780 --> 00:29:43.100
But definitely,
make sure that you've got one.

640
00:29:43.100 --> 00:29:44.650
That's where you need to
be storing that stuff.

641
00:29:44.650 --> 00:29:47.720
And it doesn't need to be hidden behind
a picture on the wall or anything.

642
00:29:47.720 --> 00:29:49.520
It can be sitting in plain sight.

643
00:29:49.520 --> 00:29:53.900
But, it just needs to exist, so you've got
a place to lock up those things that is

644
00:29:53.900 --> 00:29:56.780
offline and you don't have to
worry about hackers getting to it.

645
00:29:56.780 --> 00:29:58.160
You can even have it
there in the server room.

646
00:29:58.160 --> 00:30:01.020
I've seen that plenty of times, where
the safe is right there by the servers.

647
00:30:01.020 --> 00:30:02.750
So that we remember about it.

648
00:30:02.750 --> 00:30:04.360
And we remember,
I just generated some private keys.

649
00:30:04.360 --> 00:30:05.960
Let me go and move these over,
stick them in that safe.

650
00:30:05.960 --> 00:30:09.346
I can it right there, so I remember to
do it, but it is an important item.

651
00:30:09.346 --> 00:30:14.330
>> A non-high-tech solution that,
we talk about high-tech gadgets and

652
00:30:14.330 --> 00:30:15.810
now we're going old It's cool for sure.

653
00:30:15.810 --> 00:30:18.920
Don does look like we're coming to the end
of another episode and I tell ya',

654
00:30:18.920 --> 00:30:22.610
we probably should wrap this one
up because Don has pulled out

655
00:30:22.610 --> 00:30:27.150
more security techniques on his person
than any one person should ever have, so

656
00:30:27.150 --> 00:30:30.090
we'll probably have to bring this one
to an end before the fallout happens.

657
00:30:30.090 --> 00:30:32.122
>> I know,
my pockets aren't even empty yet.

658
00:30:32.122 --> 00:30:33.100
[LAUGH]
>> That's right.

659
00:30:33.100 --> 00:30:36.350
So, Don do you have any final words that
you might want to put in this episode when

660
00:30:36.350 --> 00:30:39.430
it comes to physical security for
our viewers?

661
00:30:39.430 --> 00:30:42.250
>> All right,
physical security is often overlooked.

662
00:30:42.250 --> 00:30:46.330
Don't be the person that does that,
because there are very simple commonsense

663
00:30:46.330 --> 00:30:50.130
techniques that can make millions and
millions of dollars in IT infrastructure

664
00:30:50.130 --> 00:30:52.430
for security just go right out the window,
right?

665
00:30:52.430 --> 00:30:55.950
So no matter how great your VPN is and
how great your firewall is,

666
00:30:55.950 --> 00:30:58.790
physical security is gonna be what
backs that up to make sure somebody

667
00:30:58.790 --> 00:31:03.360
can't overcome it through easy, simple
methods, just by physically being there.

668
00:31:03.360 --> 00:31:04.590
>> All right Don well thank you.

669
00:31:04.590 --> 00:31:07.360
We're gonna wrap this one up
before both of our hairs fall out.

670
00:31:07.360 --> 00:31:09.270
Thank you for you the viewer watching.

671
00:31:09.270 --> 00:31:12.450
Signing off for
ITProTV I've been your host Wes Bryan.

672
00:31:12.450 --> 00:31:13.310
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

673
00:31:13.310 --> 00:31:14.910
>> We'll see you next time.

>> Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don talk about a server security technique called server hardening. They explain the common steps to hardened a system like system patched, disabling unneeded services, ports and default accounts and more. They explore vender specific hardening technologies from VMWare, Windows Server 2012, RedHat and the NSA. They will also look at application hardening and endpoint security.
episodes.title: Server Hardening
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.463
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.463 --> 00:00:08.418
I'm your host Don- [CROSSTALK]
[SOUND]

3
00:00:08.418 --> 00:00:12.195
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.195 --> 00:00:15.351
>> Hello and welcome back to another
great episode here at ITPro TV.

5
00:00:15.351 --> 00:00:18.252
I'm your host Wes Bryan and
in today's episode,

6
00:00:18.252 --> 00:00:22.885
we're continuing through our series
in Server+ CompTIA's SK0-004 and

7
00:00:22.885 --> 00:00:26.221
joining us in the studio is
non other than Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:26.221 --> 00:00:27.305
Don, how are you doing sir?

9
00:00:27.305 --> 00:00:30.482
>> I'm doing swell, Wes,
ready to dive right back into Server + and

10
00:00:30.482 --> 00:00:34.535
we're gonna be tackling security, and
specifically, hardening servers today.

11
00:00:34.535 --> 00:00:38.620
So let's start off real quick with just,
what that even means, right?

12
00:00:38.620 --> 00:00:42.730
When we install a server operating system,
whether you do it manually, or

13
00:00:42.730 --> 00:00:45.920
automated or whatever,
there's a certain level of defaults and

14
00:00:45.920 --> 00:00:47.800
assumptions that are being made.

15
00:00:47.800 --> 00:00:53.350
If I pop in that Windows DVD and I install
Windows Server 2012, when it's done

16
00:00:53.350 --> 00:00:57.470
it pops up in a base configuration that
Microsoft assumes is okay for most people.

17
00:00:57.470 --> 00:00:58.889
And then I can add the features I need.

18
00:01:00.030 --> 00:01:02.730
When I install Linux,
whether it's RedHat or Ubuntu or

19
00:01:02.730 --> 00:01:07.040
whatever, I start the install, and
I might have choices where I can pick and

20
00:01:07.040 --> 00:01:08.080
choose between packages, but

21
00:01:08.080 --> 00:01:11.370
otherwise there's still some default
assumptions being made under the hood

22
00:01:11.370 --> 00:01:16.270
that then get rolled out on that machine
and they assume it's okay for everybody.

23
00:01:16.270 --> 00:01:18.070
But it's not always okay.

24
00:01:18.070 --> 00:01:19.540
Sometimes there's features and

25
00:01:19.540 --> 00:01:22.710
functionality that's enabled on
a server that we're not gonna use.

26
00:01:22.710 --> 00:01:25.560
And if we're not gonna use it,
we're not going to think about it.

27
00:01:25.560 --> 00:01:28.460
And if we don't think about it that
means that it might be configured in

28
00:01:28.460 --> 00:01:32.400
a nonsecure way and
attackers can take advantage of that.

29
00:01:32.400 --> 00:01:36.320
When you have a server, you wanna do
what's called minimizing your security

30
00:01:36.320 --> 00:01:40.350
footprint, and
you're minimizing your attack surface.

31
00:01:40.350 --> 00:01:43.500
When somebody attacks you,
they look at a server and

32
00:01:43.500 --> 00:01:44.780
they say, how can I get into that?

33
00:01:44.780 --> 00:01:47.080
And they start looking at all
the different possibilities.

34
00:01:47.080 --> 00:01:47.810
It's kind of like a house.

35
00:01:47.810 --> 00:01:50.310
If you want to break into a house,
the front door might be locked.

36
00:01:50.310 --> 00:01:52.302
It might have some really
big locks on the front door.

37
00:01:52.302 --> 00:01:53.300
You know, like, all right well that's out.

38
00:01:53.300 --> 00:01:56.550
But let's go take a look at the windows
over here, or the back door.

39
00:01:56.550 --> 00:01:58.490
Maybe there's a screen door somewhere.

40
00:01:58.490 --> 00:02:00.900
Finding alternate ways to
get in might not be so hard.

41
00:02:00.900 --> 00:02:04.210
So they look at your server and you might
have a web server configure that is

42
00:02:04.210 --> 00:02:06.900
rock solid,
locked down as best as you can.

43
00:02:06.900 --> 00:02:09.730
And you start looking like,
ooh, he's running FTP also,

44
00:02:09.730 --> 00:02:11.590
let me take a look at that FTP server.

45
00:02:11.590 --> 00:02:13.500
It's plain text,
it will tell me the version number and

46
00:02:13.500 --> 00:02:14.850
once I know that I can find bugs.

47
00:02:14.850 --> 00:02:16.170
And yup, there we go, I'm in.

48
00:02:17.320 --> 00:02:20.690
If I wasn't using that FTP server
I should have turned it off.

49
00:02:20.690 --> 00:02:22.000
I should have disabled it.

50
00:02:22.000 --> 00:02:24.470
And that is what hardening is all about.

51
00:02:24.470 --> 00:02:27.860
Hardening is looking at a server and
saying,

52
00:02:27.860 --> 00:02:31.890
what are areas that default install
that don't match up with what I need?

53
00:02:31.890 --> 00:02:33.340
Stuff that I can turn off and

54
00:02:33.340 --> 00:02:37.500
shrink the footprint of that server,
reduce the attack surface.

55
00:02:37.500 --> 00:02:40.390
So when an attacker looks they
see my highly secured web server,

56
00:02:40.390 --> 00:02:44.380
and they look for another way in,
and there is no other way in.

57
00:02:44.380 --> 00:02:47.620
It's a web server and that's
the only way they can connect to it.

58
00:02:47.620 --> 00:02:50.190
Now we can use firewalls to help
provide this functionality and

59
00:02:50.190 --> 00:02:51.880
not mess with the servers too much.

60
00:02:51.880 --> 00:02:55.270
But, if somebody manages to get through,
or

61
00:02:55.270 --> 00:02:58.190
if somebody is inside
your company already, now

62
00:02:58.190 --> 00:03:02.300
they would have access to the servers that
are in a weaker state than they should be.

63
00:03:02.300 --> 00:03:04.040
So regardless of whether
you have firewalls or

64
00:03:04.040 --> 00:03:06.480
not you should still harden your servers.

65
00:03:06.480 --> 00:03:09.330
And it does vary from operating
system to operating system, and

66
00:03:09.330 --> 00:03:12.010
it varies based on the application
you're running, but there's a few

67
00:03:12.010 --> 00:03:16.550
basic steps that are kind of generic that
really apply to just about everything.

68
00:03:16.550 --> 00:03:17.790
So let me run through the common steps,
and

69
00:03:17.790 --> 00:03:21.150
then I'll show you some better examples
that are a little more specific.

70
00:03:21.150 --> 00:03:23.130
First off, you need to look for

71
00:03:23.130 --> 00:03:25.880
any services that are running
that you don't need.

72
00:03:25.880 --> 00:03:27.810
If you're setting up a web server,
do you need FTP?

73
00:03:27.810 --> 00:03:29.810
Do you need a database server?

74
00:03:29.810 --> 00:03:32.220
What are these other services that
might be installed by default that

75
00:03:32.220 --> 00:03:33.480
you can turn off?

76
00:03:33.480 --> 00:03:37.990
Now in the Linux world, almost all Linux
distributions have sendmail installed and

77
00:03:37.990 --> 00:03:42.200
enabled by default, because they use it to
send little email alerts for the system.

78
00:03:42.200 --> 00:03:45.340
Well, if you're bringing up a web server,
you don't need that stuff.

79
00:03:45.340 --> 00:03:46.180
And so you can turn it off.

80
00:03:46.180 --> 00:03:47.330
You can stop those services.

81
00:03:47.330 --> 00:03:49.590
Or you can uninstall them,
in some cases you can remove it.

82
