running an FTP server and

545
00:24:39.720 --> 00:24:43.450
I connect to it, even if I don't log in
you will get a little header message.

546
00:24:43.450 --> 00:24:47.200
In the header message it might
say you're running Vsftp,

547
00:24:47.200 --> 00:24:51.474
or FTPPro, or whatever, version 1.7.

548
00:24:51.474 --> 00:24:56.540
I can just go to the website for
vsftp and version 1.8 is out.

549
00:24:56.540 --> 00:24:58.600
Let me check the release notes.

550
00:24:58.600 --> 00:25:02.910
Right here in the release notes, fixed
security advisory, see the blah blah blah.

551
00:25:02.910 --> 00:25:06.920
All right, well if they fix that
in 1.8 and Wes is running 1.7,

552
00:25:06.920 --> 00:25:09.229
you just told me how to
break into that system.

553
00:25:09.229 --> 00:25:11.310
Here's a way.
I didn't even have to figure it out.

554
00:25:11.310 --> 00:25:14.130
It's already just right here,
you told me what to do.

555
00:25:14.130 --> 00:25:19.020
So by hiding that, by obscuring that,
by making it where they can't

556
00:25:19.020 --> 00:25:21.720
what operating system I'm running,
what versions of software I'm running,

557
00:25:21.720 --> 00:25:25.580
what ports I've opened,
if I can do that all the better, right?

558
00:25:25.580 --> 00:25:28.580
And so that's part of making sure
that our systems are secure,

559
00:25:28.580 --> 00:25:29.930
and updated, and patched.

560
00:25:29.930 --> 00:25:32.870
Because if you're not patching,

561
00:25:32.870 --> 00:25:35.350
then the answer to how to hack
your server is already out there.

562
00:25:35.350 --> 00:25:36.650
It's already on the vendor websites.

563
00:25:36.650 --> 00:25:38.010
It's public knowledge.

564
00:25:38.010 --> 00:25:40.480
So it's just a matter of time
before somebody uses it.

565
00:25:40.480 --> 00:25:42.080
>> All right, Don,
lot of great information.

566
00:25:42.080 --> 00:25:48.010
I even learned today about the involuntary
NSA bonus program for sure.

567
00:25:48.010 --> 00:25:50.010
It does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

568
00:25:50.010 --> 00:25:50.590
But before we do,

569
00:25:50.590 --> 00:25:53.360
do you have any parting words that you
might like to in part to our viewers?

570
00:25:53.360 --> 00:25:56.390
>> The only objective I didn't
mention was disabling wake on LAN.

571
00:25:56.390 --> 00:25:59.890
If you have network adapters and
you power a server down

572
00:25:59.890 --> 00:26:03.580
it's possible to send a Wake On Lan
magic bullet to wake the server back up.

573
00:26:03.580 --> 00:26:06.090
So you might have a server
that's turned off.

574
00:26:06.090 --> 00:26:08.300
Maybe it wasn't secure, you haven't
had a chance to harden it yet so

575
00:26:08.300 --> 00:26:09.980
you shut it down and you go home.

576
00:26:09.980 --> 00:26:12.660
And somebody sends a Wake On Lan
magic bullet to it.

577
00:26:12.660 --> 00:26:14.670
Wake On Lan doesn't do any authentication.

578
00:26:14.670 --> 00:26:17.480
So if somebody sends a message to wake
it up, the server's going to wake up and

579
00:26:17.480 --> 00:26:18.840
come back online.

580
00:26:18.840 --> 00:26:24.240
You turned it off thinking it was secure,
or more secure to have it off than on.

581
00:26:24.240 --> 00:26:26.780
And now it's up and running and
it's actually targeted.

582
00:26:26.780 --> 00:26:29.360
So they recommend turning
off Wake-on-LAN on servers.

583
00:26:29.360 --> 00:26:32.040
We don't normally use Wake-on-LAN
on servers anyway, so

584
00:26:32.040 --> 00:26:35.000
you can go into your network
adapter settings or into your BIOS,

585
00:26:35.000 --> 00:26:38.190
either one, and disable that
functionality and help to prevent that.

586
00:26:38.190 --> 00:26:41.700
That's one more thing that
you might need to disable.

587
00:26:41.700 --> 00:26:45.485
>> All right Don as always we appreciate
having you here in the studios with us and

588
00:26:45.485 --> 00:26:47.490
we appreciate you the viewer watching.

589
00:26:47.490 --> 00:26:50.082
Signing up for
ITProTV I've been your host Wes Bryan.

590
00:26:50.082 --> 00:26:51.010
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

591
00:26:51.010 --> 00:26:53.007
>> And we'll see you next time.

592
00:26:53.007 --> 00:26:59.081
[MUSIC]

593
00:26:59.081 --> 00:27:04.860
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore various technologies used in network security. They look at host-based ,network-based firewalls, port security 802.1x, network access control, ACLs, NIDS. They will also explain authentication protocols like LDAP, RADIUS, TACACS, TACACS+. Finally, they will examine the characteristics and components of public-key infrastructure or PKI.
episodes.title: Network Security
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.227 --> 00:00:15.918
Hello and welcome back to another great
episode here ITPRO.TV thank you for

3
00:00:15.918 --> 00:00:18.976
joining us, I'm your host Wes Bryan and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:18.976 --> 00:00:22.500
we're continuing through our series and
come see us server plus.

5
00:00:22.500 --> 00:00:25.230
Joining us in the studios is
none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:25.230 --> 00:00:26.320
Don, how are you doing, sir?

7
00:00:26.320 --> 00:00:27.270
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

8
00:00:27.270 --> 00:00:30.310
Ready to continue on with our Server+
adventure and in this episode,

9
00:00:30.310 --> 00:00:35.220
we're going to be talking about network
security because the easiest way

10
00:00:35.220 --> 00:00:40.130
to make sure our servers are secure is
to ask somebody else to do it for us.

11
00:00:40.130 --> 00:00:41.030
Right?
And so if you're a sys admin,

12
00:00:41.030 --> 00:00:43.470
you don't want to deal with
the whole security thing

13
00:00:43.470 --> 00:00:44.690
Make the network guys do it.

14
00:00:44.690 --> 00:00:48.635
Reach over their admin team and say hey,
can you guys, you know, secure my stuff.

15
00:00:48.635 --> 00:00:52.180
[LAUGH] And a lot of times they can.

16
00:00:52.180 --> 00:00:54.270
In a perfect world, you're both doing it.

17
00:00:54.270 --> 00:00:56.220
Right.
Where you're taking all sorts of security

18
00:00:56.220 --> 00:00:58.170
precautions on the server side.

19
00:00:58.170 --> 00:01:02.290
Meanwhile, the net admins are taking
precautions on the network side.

20
00:01:02.290 --> 00:01:06.730
The problem is,
the network guys can't solve every issue.

21
00:01:06.730 --> 00:01:10.940
Because your server provides
a service thus the name and

22
00:01:10.940 --> 00:01:13.380
people need to be able to
connect to that service.

23
00:01:13.380 --> 00:01:16.890
And if we block that off
then that's easy right?

24
00:01:16.890 --> 00:01:20.300
If you want to truly secure your
server just unplug the network cable.

25
00:01:20.300 --> 00:01:23.120
But then your server can't do
the job that it needs to do.

26
00:01:23.120 --> 00:01:27.240
So the network guys can implement
as much security as they can and

27
00:01:27.240 --> 00:01:29.360
still allow you to provide your service.

28
00:01:29.360 --> 00:01:31.550
And then it's up to you to do the rest and

29
00:01:31.550 --> 00:01:34.610
make sure that you've secured
the services on that server.

30
00:01:34.610 --> 00:01:37.460
So let's talk about what
the network guys can do for you and

31
00:01:37.460 --> 00:01:40.250
what they can't do,
what are our limitations.

32
00:01:40.250 --> 00:01:42.990
The first thing I wanna talk
about are firewalls and

33
00:01:42.990 --> 00:01:48.950
what firewalls do is they allow us to
filter traffic Between two networks,

34
00:01:48.950 --> 00:01:50.930
and I used to always say and
between between the internet and

35
00:01:50.930 --> 00:01:54.420
our network, but
you can use firewalls internally too.

36
00:01:54.420 --> 00:01:58.380
And I've done that numerous times where
you had research and development networks

37
00:01:58.380 --> 00:02:00.850
that you didn't want to have access
to your production networks.

38
00:02:00.850 --> 00:02:04.370
And so you could use an internal
firewall to filter that access.

39
00:02:04.370 --> 00:02:08.410
But the most common solution is to
use it between your network And

40
00:02:08.410 --> 00:02:11.540
the Internet, when you connect to
the Internet it's the wild west out there.

41
00:02:11.540 --> 00:02:13.060
You've got the entire world.

42
00:02:13.060 --> 00:02:15.930
And the hackers and the bad guys,
a lot of them are out there.

43
00:02:15.930 --> 00:02:20.560
Now just as many attacks happen
from the inside as the outside but

44
00:02:20.560 --> 00:02:23.490
because the outsiders have to pass
through your Internet connection,

45
00:02:23.490 --> 00:02:26.940
it gives you a single point
where you can easily catch and

46
00:02:26.940 --> 00:02:30.400
stop that traffic which means
we really need to address that.

47
00:02:30.400 --> 00:02:34.860
Now Don, when it comes to firewalls,
is the firewalls that I have, let's say on

48
00:02:34.860 --> 00:02:38.130
my Windows machine, is that gonna be the
same type of firewall that you're gonna

49
00:02:38.130 --> 00:02:41.840
deploy like you were mentioning, between
your internal LAN and the internet?

50
00:02:41.840 --> 00:02:44.060
Or are they gonna be
different types of firewalls?

51
00:02:44.060 --> 00:02:46.670
>> They're actually pretty
similar in how they work.

52
00:02:46.670 --> 00:02:50.710
What a firewall does, it just looks at
packets, and it lets some of them through

53
00:02:50.710 --> 00:02:52.930
and it doesn't let others
through based on a set of rules.

54
00:02:52.930 --> 00:02:54.130
That's how they work.

55
00:02:54.130 --> 00:02:56.290
And so
from that perspective they're the same.

56
00:02:56.290 --> 00:03:00.590
But what Wes is talking about are host
based firewalls versus network firewalls.

57
00:03:00.590 --> 00:03:05.270
And a host based firewall is software
that runs on your server like IP tables,

58
00:03:05.270 --> 00:03:07.880
Firewall D, Windows Firewall.

59
00:03:07.880 --> 00:03:12.530
A network firewall is an appliance that's
on your network that sits in between

60
00:03:12.530 --> 00:03:13.620
two different networks.

61
00:03:13.620 --> 00:03:17.770
That'll be something like a Cisco ASA,
a Juniper SSG, PF Sense,

62
00:03:17.770 --> 00:03:21.170
whatever it is you use, CheckPoint
Firewall One, those kind of things.

63
00:03:21.170 --> 00:03:24.030
Sonic Wall, the list goes on and on.

64
00:03:24.030 --> 00:03:29.440
The main difference is that a firewall
on the network, a main firewall,

65
00:03:29.440 --> 00:03:34.030
can stop an attack before it
gets to your server Versus

66
00:03:34.030 --> 00:03:38.520
a software firewall where the attack
has already made it to your server and

67
00:03:38.520 --> 00:03:40.990
you're trying to stop
it at the last moment.

68
00:03:40.990 --> 00:03:42.890
The best solution is to have both, right?

69
00:03:42.890 --> 00:03:44.610
So let me show you a diagram here.

70
00:03:44.610 --> 00:03:49.360
I might have a file server, and
I want that file server protected, or

71
00:03:49.360 --> 00:03:50.680
even better a web server.

72
00:03:50.680 --> 00:03:53.470
I have a web server and
I want that web server protected.

73
00:03:53.470 --> 00:03:56.810
So I can place it in a special network.

74
00:03:56.810 --> 00:03:58.070
These are called zones.

75
00:03:58.070 --> 00:04:00.290
When you have a network you don't
normally just have one network,

76
00:04:00.290 --> 00:04:02.910
you normally divide it up in
different security zones.

77
00:04:02.910 --> 00:04:05.570
You may have high security zones and
low security zones.

78
00:04:05.570 --> 00:04:10.360
Your LAN, your local area network,
that's gonna be a high security zone.

79
00:04:10.360 --> 00:04:13.160
I don't want people on the internet
getting to my LAN that's where I have my

80
00:04:13.160 --> 00:04:15.980
domain controller, my files and so on.

81
00:04:15.980 --> 00:04:19.470
But if I have a web server,
I want the public to get to my web server.

82
00:04:19.470 --> 00:04:23.030
So I might move that off to a DMZ,
a demilitarized zone.

83
00:04:23.030 --> 00:04:27.500
This is one where I allow people to
get to it, but I just take care,

84
00:04:27.500 --> 00:04:30.430
I take caution to make sure
that my network stays safe.

85
00:04:30.430 --> 00:04:32.760
I want to make sure that if
somebody hacks my web server,

86
00:04:32.760 --> 00:04:36.040
that they can't just leapfrog and
jump right over into my internal servers.

87
00:04:36.040 --> 00:04:38.000
They would have to pass
back through the firewall

88
00:04:38.000 --> 00:04:40.150
where we've got protections in place.

89
00:04:40.150 --> 00:04:42.740
Now if somebody is
attacking my web server,

90
00:04:42.740 --> 00:04:47.060
that attack is gonna come from
the Internet typically, it's gonna pass

91
00:04:47.060 --> 00:04:53.070
through the firewall on it's way down
to the DMZ and to the web server.

92
00:04:53.070 --> 00:04:56.450
And so if I can detect that attack
at the firewall I can stop it

93
00:04:56.450 --> 00:04:58.850
Before it even gets to the web server.

94
00:04:58.850 --> 00:05:02.040
If I was just relying on a software
firewall, you know, one running on the web

95
00:05:02.040 --> 00:05:05.810
server, the attack would actually make
it all the way to the web server.

96
00:05:05.810 --> 00:05:09.800
And if I failed to block it,
then I'm now gonna get compromised, right?

97
00:05:09.800 --> 00:05:12.420
If I have both, that's even better.

98
00:05:12.420 --> 00:05:15.090
I'm filtering here at
the hardware firewall and

99
00:05:15.090 --> 00:05:16.970
again at the software firewall.

100
00:05:16.970 --> 00:05:18.100
Two layers of defense right?

101
00:05:18.100 --> 00:05:20.880
Defense in depth, that's what we really
want to have in a solution like this.

102
00:05:22.860 --> 00:05:25.480
Now one of the bigger
challenges that we have though

103
00:05:25.480 --> 00:05:27.480
is that outside attackers are easy.

104
00:05:27.480 --> 00:05:28.650
Cuz we know where they're coming from.

105
00:05:28.650 --> 00:05:30.920
We know they're gonna come
across our internet link.

106
00:05:30.920 --> 00:05:32.720
But, what about internal attackers?

107
00:05:32.720 --> 00:05:34.670
What if you have a disgruntled employee?

108
00:05:34.670 --> 00:05:37.270
Or, what if you're supporting
the network at a school?

109
00:05:37.270 --> 00:05:41.040
Every student is disgruntled at a school,
right, but especially at a highschool,

110
00:05:41.040 --> 00:05:45.350
where you've got teenagers that are just
learning About computers and the things

111
00:05:45.350 --> 00:05:49.550
they can do, and haven't necessarily
learned restraints, or legal liability,

112
00:05:49.550 --> 00:05:51.770
and all that stuff yet, that you
learn when you get a little older.

113
00:05:51.770 --> 00:05:54.580
So they start doing things like trying to
break into your servers, and poking and

114
00:05:54.580 --> 00:05:56.810
prodding on the servers to
see what they can get at.

115
00:05:56.810 --> 00:05:59.190
Well, they've got a lot more
time on your hands than you do.

116
00:05:59.190 --> 00:06:00.130
That's for sure.

117
00:06:00.130 --> 00:06:03.300
And so they will find ways
to get into those systems.

118
00:06:03.300 --> 00:06:06.630
And so, we gotta have ways
to stop that from happening.

119
00:06:06.630 --> 00:06:09.720
One way we can do that is by
preventing them from running

120
00:06:09.720 --> 00:06:12.180
unauthorized software on your equipment.

121
00:06:12.180 --> 00:06:15.810
If you have work computers, you shouldn't
be allowing users to install software.

122
00:06:15.810 --> 00:06:20.180
And you shouldn't be allowing them to do
actions beyond what they needed from work.

123
00:06:20.180 --> 00:06:23.950
But the way they get around that is
they bring their own stuff, right.

124
00:06:23.950 --> 00:06:28.120
We had this whole bring your own device,
BYOD movement right now where people bring

125
00:06:28.120 --> 00:06:31.370
their smart phones,
their tablets, their laptops.

126
00:06:31.370 --> 00:06:33.050
They bring their own equipment in.

127
00:06:33.050 --> 00:06:36.000
How do I stop them from installing
software on their own equipment?

128
00:06:36.000 --> 00:06:38.150
You can't, you don't.

129
00:06:38.150 --> 00:06:43.510
Instead, what you do is you control what
equipment is allowed on your network.

130
00:06:43.510 --> 00:06:47.430
Network admins can set up what's
called Network Access Control, or NAC.

131
00:06:47.430 --> 00:06:52.220
And what Network Access Control does is
it allows us to restrict the machines

132
00:06:52.220 --> 00:06:53.670
that can plug in.

133
00:06:53.670 --> 00:06:55.480
So if somebody connects to
our wireless network, or

134
00:06:55.480 --> 00:06:59.090
tries to physically plug into a port,
we can see if they're authorized.

135
00:06:59.090 --> 00:07:00.620
On the switch we call it port security.

136
00:07:00.620 --> 00:07:03.740
And it can look for approved MAC
addresses on the network adapters.

137
00:07:03.740 --> 00:07:05.220
If it's an approved MAC, it allows it on.

138
00:07:05.220 --> 00:07:08.550
If it's not an approved MAC,
it doesn't allow it on.

139
00:07:08.550 --> 00:07:10.360
But MAC addresses can be spoofed.

140
00:07:10.360 --> 00:07:12.830
So port security isn't enough.

141
00:07:12.830 --> 00:07:16.180
We can move beyond that though and
we can do network access control NAC.

142
00:07:16.180 --> 00:07:17.600
Or we can do 802.1X, authentication.

143
00:07:18.708 --> 00:07:21.830
NAC and 802.1X are actually, very similar.

144
00:07:21.830 --> 00:07:28.110
When you plug in you have to present
a certificate that validates who you are.

145
00:07:28.110 --> 00:07:30.750
And the switch of the wireless access
point will look at that certificate and

146
00:07:30.750 --> 00:07:32.000
determine, if it's valid.

147
00:07:32.000 --> 00:07:33.800
If it's valid you're allowed to talk.

148
00:07:33.800 --> 00:07:36.050
If it's not valid you're
not allowed to talk.

149
00:07:36.050 --> 00:07:37.880
You cannot spoof the certificate.

150
00:07:37.880 --> 00:07:39.400
You would have to compromise
the private key and

151
00:07:39.400 --> 00:07:43.150
if that happens you got bigger problems
than somebody plugging in on the network.

152
00:07:43.150 --> 00:07:46.210
So, this gives us a very
high level of security.

153
00:07:46.210 --> 00:07:50.170
Now you can control exactly,
which devices on our the network and

154
00:07:50.170 --> 00:07:53.255
no more unauthorized devices.

155
00:07:53.255 --> 00:07:55.690
802.1 x focuses on
the authentication side.

156
00:07:55.690 --> 00:07:57.257
Knack, does the same thing.

157
00:07:57.257 --> 00:08:01.019
And then it goes one step further and
it says all right you just validated and

158
00:08:01.019 --> 00:08:02.759
showed you are who you say you are.

159
00:08:02.759 --> 00:08:05.328
But do you have antivirus installed?

160
00:08:05.328 --> 00:08:06.472
When's the last time you did an update?

161
00:08:06.472 --> 00:08:08.024
Have you updated in the last three days?

162
00:08:08.024 --> 00:08:10.651
Have you done your Windows updates?

163
00:08:10.651 --> 00:08:12.112
Have you done those in
the last three days?

164
00:08:12.112 --> 00:08:13.190
You haven't?

165
00:08:13.190 --> 00:08:14.990
I'm gonna isolate you on the network.

166
00:08:14.990 --> 00:08:18.589
And if you have somebody who's not
updated, who's machine could potentially

167
00:08:18.589 --> 00:08:22.095
be infected with a virus, or whatever
it isolates them in a quarantine zone.

168
00:08:22.095 --> 00:08:25.497
And you can remediate, let them do
updates, let them do scans, and

169
00:08:25.497 --> 00:08:29.439
when they're clean, then it transitions
them into the regular network, but

170
00:08:29.439 --> 00:08:32.930
otherwise, it isolates them and
holds them off.

171
00:08:32.930 --> 00:08:34.700
Just does the authentication.

172
00:08:34.700 --> 00:08:39.650
NAC goes that step further, and
does a lot more on top of that, so.

173
00:08:39.650 --> 00:08:41.950
NAC is actually a product from Cisco, so

174
00:08:41.950 --> 00:08:46.150
Cisco network access control, Microsoft
has something similar called NAP,

175
00:08:46.150 --> 00:08:48.540
right, network access-
>> Protection.

176
00:08:48.540 --> 00:08:50.340
>> Protection, thank you Wes.

177
00:08:50.340 --> 00:08:52.510
So, there's various vendors
that make the same thing.

178
00:08:52.510 --> 00:08:54.202
And it actually leverages 802.1X for

179
00:08:54.202 --> 00:08:56.559
the authentication,
cuz that's a consistent standard.

180
00:08:56.559 --> 00:08:59.320
And then it just adds all
the extra features on top of that.

181
00:09:00.770 --> 00:09:05.050
What are some of the other things that
network admin can do to help us out?

182
00:09:05.050 --> 00:09:08.370
Ideally, we have firewalls for
filtering things.

183
00:09:08.370 --> 00:09:10.740
But in lieu of firewalls or

184
00:09:10.740 --> 00:09:15.240
in addition to firewalls, you might have
routers that can also be doing filtering.

185
00:09:15.240 --> 00:09:18.490
Routers support access control lists,
ACLs, and

186
00:09:18.490 --> 00:09:21.770
ACLs are like the poor man's firewall.

187
00:09:21.770 --> 00:09:24.220
They let you put in rules
that specifically block or

188
00:09:24.220 --> 00:09:25.890
allow certain types of traffic.

189
00:09:25.890 --> 00:09:31.940
The problem with ACLs on a router is that
an access control list is one direction.

190
00:09:31.940 --> 00:09:36.930
So, I am filtering traffic on the way
in or filtering traffic on the way out.

191
00:09:36.930 --> 00:09:39.690
The problem is communications are two way.

192
00:09:39.690 --> 00:09:42.470
I send a message to a server,
the server has to respond to me.

193
00:09:42.470 --> 00:09:46.260
So, anytime I close a router
using rules like these,

194
00:09:46.260 --> 00:09:50.050
I have to add rules for
both directions, which gets annoying.

195
00:09:50.050 --> 00:09:53.610
Firewalls do stateful packet inspection.

196
00:09:53.610 --> 00:09:56.750
So, when they see a communication come in,
if it's allowed,

197
00:09:56.750 --> 00:10:00.530
it assumes that I want the reply to be
allowed also, and it takes care of that.

198
00:10:00.530 --> 00:10:02.380
It's a more bidirectional nature.

199
00:10:02.380 --> 00:10:05.070
So, you can certainly do access
control lists on a router but,

200
00:10:05.070 --> 00:10:06.800
they're not as optimal.

201
00:10:06.800 --> 00:10:10.090
The other thing is, that on a router,
it's not really designed for

202
00:10:10.090 --> 00:10:13.010
packet filtering,
it's designed for packet routing.

203
00:10:13.010 --> 00:10:16.310
Firewalls have hardware built into
them specifically designed for

204
00:10:16.310 --> 00:10:18.260
filtering, routers don't.

205
00:10:18.260 --> 00:10:20.500
So, routers do that work in
their general purpose CPU,

206
00:10:20.500 --> 00:10:23.910
which means they're slower,
they're not as good at it with a firewall.

207
00:10:23.910 --> 00:10:26.390
But one of the things that I do,
I like to access control list for

208
00:10:26.390 --> 00:10:29.020
a router is anti-spoofing.

209
00:10:29.020 --> 00:10:33.230
I know that their certain IP ranges
should not be getting traffic on

210
00:10:33.230 --> 00:10:34.580
from the Internet.

211
00:10:34.580 --> 00:10:38.473
I should never receive RFC1918
traffic from the Internet,

212
00:10:38.473 --> 00:10:42.366
traffic that has a source IP of 192.168,
something, or

213
00:10:42.366 --> 00:10:47.516
172.16 all the way through
172.31.something, or 10.anything.

214
00:10:47.516 --> 00:10:53.852
I shouldn't get traffic like that,
I shouldn't get traffic on 127.anything or

215
00:10:53.852 --> 00:10:57.550
0.anything 22, no, 2, what is it 240?

216
00:10:57.550 --> 00:11:01.266
What is the multicast ends, it's 224, 240?

217
00:11:01.266 --> 00:11:02.012
>> That's 240.

218
00:11:02.012 --> 00:11:05.784
>> So 241.anything,
I should be getting broadcasts.

219
00:11:05.784 --> 00:11:08.200
I should be getting
broadcast from the Internet.

220
00:11:08.200 --> 00:11:11.570
Those are all things that we
can filter out really easily

221
00:11:11.570 --> 00:11:13.410
on an access list on a router.

222
00:11:13.410 --> 00:11:16.620
And there, it's just looking at source IP,
which a router does anyway.

223
00:11:16.620 --> 00:11:17.542
It's a layer three device.

224
00:11:17.542 --> 00:11:20.820
It's gonna look at the layer three header,
so that doesn't impact performance at all.

225
00:11:20.820 --> 00:11:24.780
So, access control on a router can be
used to filter out cheesy traffic that we

226
00:11:24.780 --> 00:11:28.950
shouldn't be getting anyway, and then the
firewall can do the real inspection and

227
00:11:28.950 --> 00:11:32.470
the real filtering and stuff beyond that,
so routers can be used for this stuff.

228
00:11:34.340 --> 00:11:38.790
Another device that network admins can
implement for us is what you call an IDS,

229
00:11:38.790 --> 00:11:40.770
an intrusion detection system.

230
00:11:40.770 --> 00:11:45.250
And I've kind of mentioned this before
it HIDS, host space intrusion detection,

231
00:11:45.250 --> 00:11:49.020
well, you have network based
intrusion detection systems or NIDS.

232
00:11:50.150 --> 00:11:54.220
Now, there's two different devices here
that create a little bit of confusion.

233
00:11:54.220 --> 00:11:56.830
And I know Wes and
I have talked about this in other shows.

234
00:11:56.830 --> 00:12:03.710
You have intrusion prevention systems and
intrusion detection systems, IDS and IPS.

235
00:12:03.710 --> 00:12:07.480
An intrusion detection
system will detect and

236
00:12:07.480 --> 00:12:10.659
attack alert us, but
not do anything about it.

237
00:12:11.730 --> 00:12:16.340
An intrusion prevention system will
detect the attack and then stop it.

238
00:12:16.340 --> 00:12:21.070
It'll prevent the attack, IPS and
IDS, they're two different things.

239
00:12:21.070 --> 00:12:26.280
Where the confusion comes in is that if
you go to whoever it is that you're buying

240
00:12:26.280 --> 00:12:33.390
your hardware from, Cisco or Juniper,
they don't sell IDS, or IPS.

241
00:12:33.390 --> 00:12:35.820
They sell one appliance that does both.

242
00:12:35.820 --> 00:12:37.352
It's one appliance that does IDS and IPS.

243
00:12:37.352 --> 00:12:40.095
It's essentially the same hardware,
the same software, the same configuration,

244
00:12:40.095 --> 00:12:41.570
the same everything.

245
00:12:41.570 --> 00:12:43.190
The only difference between an IDS and

246
00:12:43.190 --> 00:12:46.590
an IPS is where we install it,
where we put it, all right?

247
00:12:46.590 --> 00:12:50.940
An IPS, an intrusion prevention system,
works like this.

248
00:12:50.940 --> 00:12:54.840
I have a device,
this green device, that's my IPS.

249
00:12:54.840 --> 00:12:59.560
And I put it between the firewall and
the network that I'm protecting.

250
00:12:59.560 --> 00:13:03.295
Okay, so here I've got two IPSs,
one between the firewall and my LAN, and

251
00:13:03.295 --> 00:13:05.566
another one between the firewall and
my DMZ.

252
00:13:05.566 --> 00:13:10.750
I could just have one IPS and stick it
between the firewall and the Internet.

253
00:13:10.750 --> 00:13:14.000
Bit IPSs are normally ethernet only, so
we don't normally stick them outside of

254
00:13:14.000 --> 00:13:17.830
the firewall, unless we happen to
have Metro-E or something like that.

255
00:13:17.830 --> 00:13:19.137
But it's usually gonna be on the inside.

256
00:13:19.137 --> 00:13:22.299
So here I've got my IPSs and
if you look how to cabling is run,

257
00:13:22.299 --> 00:13:26.640
the cable from the firewall doesn't
run straight to the switch anymore.

258
00:13:26.640 --> 00:13:28.691
The cable from the firewall
runs to the IPS, and

259
00:13:28.691 --> 00:13:31.059
the IPS is another cable that
runs through the switch.

260
00:13:31.059 --> 00:13:36.019
So, that 100% of the traffic from
this firewall going to the switch has

261
00:13:36.019 --> 00:13:37.290
to pass to the IPS.

262
00:13:37.290 --> 00:13:42.650
And as the traffic goes through it,
it can inspect it, look at it and

263
00:13:42.650 --> 00:13:44.290
determine if there's
a TAC traffic in there.

264
00:13:44.290 --> 00:13:47.260
And if there is, it can block it.

265
00:13:47.260 --> 00:13:50.340
It can block it, and that attack
traffic never makes it to the switch,

266
00:13:50.340 --> 00:13:52.700
which means it never
gets down to my servers.

267
00:13:52.700 --> 00:13:54.560
That's perfect, that's what we want.

268
00:13:54.560 --> 00:13:56.990
Okay, that's what an IPS does.

269
00:13:56.990 --> 00:14:01.160
An IDS is where I take that
exact same hardware and

270
00:14:01.160 --> 00:14:05.800
instead of putting it in line, I just
stick it off of the switch somewhere.

271
00:14:05.800 --> 00:14:10.210
So here, I've got an IDS, that same
hardware, plugged into the switch.

272
00:14:11.210 --> 00:14:16.510
And the traffic from the firewall goes
right to the switch and to the server.

273
00:14:16.510 --> 00:14:19.330
But on the switch,
I configure port mirroring.

274
00:14:19.330 --> 00:14:23.690
Port mirroring is where I say any traffic
on this port, copy it to this other port.

275
00:14:23.690 --> 00:14:28.770
So, a copy of all the traffic is set
over to that box where it's inspected,

276
00:14:28.770 --> 00:14:31.448
and there's attack traffic
found it can't stop it.

277
00:14:31.448 --> 00:14:35.049
It can't stop it, it can't stop it because
the traffic is already gone through,

278
00:14:35.049 --> 00:14:37.390
it's already made it to that server.

279
00:14:37.390 --> 00:14:41.660
But it can detect, it can see the attack,
and it can alert me and let me know and

280
00:14:41.660 --> 00:14:43.000
now I've got a record of it.

281
00:14:43.000 --> 00:14:46.410
It's the same hardware,
the same piece of equipment,

282
00:14:46.410 --> 00:14:49.340
it's just where I install it
that makes the difference.

283
00:14:49.340 --> 00:14:53.460
Now, the question I always get
is if it's the same hardware and

284
00:14:53.460 --> 00:14:57.300
an IPS can stop the attack,
why wouldn't I do that?

285
00:14:57.300 --> 00:14:58.050
That's a no-brainer.

286
00:14:58.050 --> 00:14:59.918
It's crazy,
why wouldn't I use it that way?

287
00:14:59.918 --> 00:15:03.300
And there's really just one reason,
performance.

288
00:15:04.330 --> 00:15:10.240
When we have it inline, everything that
passes through that IPS has get inspected,

289
00:15:10.240 --> 00:15:12.050
and that takes a moment.

290
00:15:12.050 --> 00:15:12.870
Now, when I say a moment,

291
00:15:12.870 --> 00:15:15.650
we're talking about nano seconds,
really small window of time.

292
00:15:15.650 --> 00:15:19.400
But if this is voice over IP traffic,
or streaming video, or

293
00:15:19.400 --> 00:15:21.820
whatever, it introduces a delay.

294
00:15:21.820 --> 00:15:26.210
And if I'm dealing with time sensitive
traffic, I don't want that delay.

295
00:15:26.210 --> 00:15:31.070
If this is a storage network, I need my
storage to be as fast as possible, so

296
00:15:31.070 --> 00:15:32.790
I don't want that delay.

297
00:15:32.790 --> 00:15:38.100
And so, in those scenarios, an IDS is
better, because I can inspect the traffic,

298
00:15:38.100 --> 00:15:41.950
I'll know if there's an attack,
but I don't impact performance.

299
00:15:41.950 --> 00:15:45.876
Now, an IDS,
it can't stop the initial attack, but

300
00:15:45.876 --> 00:15:48.240
it can stop it from continuing.

301
00:15:48.240 --> 00:15:51.229
You can have scripts that are written
on it, so if it sees an attack on it,

302
00:15:51.229 --> 00:15:54.561
it can reach out to the switch and tell
the switch, hey, block out this traffic,

303
00:15:54.561 --> 00:15:57.907
or reach out the the firewall, hey, create
a firewall rule to block that stuff.

304
00:15:57.907 --> 00:16:01.536
Then it stops it,
it gets somebody else to stop it.

305
00:16:01.536 --> 00:16:04.275
But by itself, it can only detect, right?

306
00:16:04.275 --> 00:16:06.210
That's what it does.

307
00:16:06.210 --> 00:16:09.420
So IDS and IPS,
we have our host based stuff.

308
00:16:09.420 --> 00:16:13.100
But by that point the attacker
is already all the way to us.

309
00:16:13.100 --> 00:16:15.490
If we can stop it at the network,
that's even better.

310
00:16:16.850 --> 00:16:21.310
All right, other things that we can do on
the network to help secure our systems,

311
00:16:21.310 --> 00:16:22.670
authentication.

312
00:16:22.670 --> 00:16:25.750
When somebody connects to our network
we don't normally authenticate them.

313
00:16:25.750 --> 00:16:27.710
If you fire up a web browser and

314
00:16:27.710 --> 00:16:31.280
you go to www.google.com,
you're gonna get their search engine.

315
00:16:31.280 --> 00:16:34.140
And you can do searches and
they're not gonna ask you for a username.

316
00:16:34.140 --> 00:16:37.900
If you go to www.amazon.com
you can shop all you want,

317
00:16:37.900 --> 00:16:39.420
they'll never ask you for a username.

318
00:16:39.420 --> 00:16:42.310
Until you want to buy something,
then you've got to authenticate it, right?

319
00:16:42.310 --> 00:16:44.700
So most of the users on
the side are anonymous.

320
00:16:45.750 --> 00:16:48.750
How do I filter people
if they're anonymous?

321
00:16:48.750 --> 00:16:49.860
You can't.

322
00:16:49.860 --> 00:16:52.070
So we can turn on authentication.

323
00:16:52.070 --> 00:16:55.470
Now we might have authentication
built into our system.

324
00:16:55.470 --> 00:16:58.860
But there's plenty of protocols out there,
that really don't have authentication.

325
00:16:58.860 --> 00:17:02.010
So, we can force authentication
through a few different means.

326
00:17:02.010 --> 00:17:05.950
You might have things like a active
directory in place, or open directory,

327
00:17:05.950 --> 00:17:07.840
open LDAP, whatever.

328
00:17:07.840 --> 00:17:12.000
But when somebody is connected to a TFTP
server, TFTP doesn't ask for user and

329
00:17:12.000 --> 00:17:14.090
password, it doesn't have that.

330
00:17:14.090 --> 00:17:16.910
So we can control access
to the network instead.

331
00:17:16.910 --> 00:17:20.525
We can say, in order for you to connect to
the network, you've got to authenticate.

332
00:17:20.525 --> 00:17:23.820
802.1X is one example of that
where you use a certificate.

333
00:17:23.820 --> 00:17:27.740
But there's other technologies that can
be used too, like RADIUS and TACACS.

334
00:17:28.860 --> 00:17:31.390
RADIUS and
TACACS are two very old protocols.

335
00:17:31.390 --> 00:17:33.180
They were designed back
in the dial-up days,

336
00:17:33.180 --> 00:17:35.600
when you dial-up to
an internet service provider.

337
00:17:35.600 --> 00:17:36.990
You had to set up a username and password.

338
00:17:36.990 --> 00:17:39.280
And you would do that through
either RADIUS or TACACS,

339
00:17:39.280 --> 00:17:43.460
you would authenticate, and
then based on that authentication,

340
00:17:43.460 --> 00:17:46.960
they could then authorize you
to perform certain actions.

341
00:17:46.960 --> 00:17:51.310
You are authorized to do tasks X, Y,
and Z, but not tasks A, B, and C.

342
00:17:51.310 --> 00:17:53.080
You could kind of pick and choose.

343
00:17:53.080 --> 00:17:55.820
And then they would do accounting.

344
00:17:55.820 --> 00:17:58.110
Then we keep track of how
long you're connected.

345
00:17:58.110 --> 00:17:59.820
What you did while you're connected.

346
00:17:59.820 --> 00:18:01.430
When you disconnected then and so on.

347
00:18:01.430 --> 00:18:03.210
They keep records of all of that.

348
00:18:03.210 --> 00:18:06.330
So, these are wanted call AAA protocols.

349
00:18:06.330 --> 00:18:10.590
Authentication, authorisation,
and accounting, AAA.

350
00:18:10.590 --> 00:18:13.010
And that's what their function was.

351
00:18:13.010 --> 00:18:16.650
The neat part about them is
TACACS has pretty much died off,

352
00:18:16.650 --> 00:18:21.720
but RADIUS is an open standard and
darn near everybody supports it.

353
00:18:21.720 --> 00:18:24.680
Windows, Linux, Mac OS,
Cisco, Juniper, HP,

354
00:18:24.680 --> 00:18:28.060
all these different vendors support it.

355
00:18:28.060 --> 00:18:32.220
So it's a common element I can use
to authenticate across all devices.

356
00:18:32.220 --> 00:18:33.560
You know, Don, you said TACACS.

357
00:18:33.560 --> 00:18:36.420
It's an old protocol and
we really don't use it.

358
00:18:36.420 --> 00:18:40.930
But I do see one out there and really
the only variation is the fact that at

359
00:18:40.930 --> 00:18:42.380
the end of the name it has a plus on it.

360
00:18:42.380 --> 00:18:43.660
So it's TACACS +.

361
00:18:43.660 --> 00:18:45.060
Could you tell us a little bit about that?

362
00:18:45.060 --> 00:18:46.815
And what would the difference be?

363
00:18:46.815 --> 00:18:47.330
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

364
00:18:47.330 --> 00:18:49.440
What happened is TACACS
basically got abandoned.

365
00:18:49.440 --> 00:18:53.050
And nobody really worked with it anymore,
but Cisco really liked it and so

366
00:18:53.050 --> 00:18:57.000
Cisco kept working with it and
they kept changing it.

367
00:18:57.000 --> 00:19:00.880
And they would change it and it would
submit it to be put into the standard, but

368
00:19:00.880 --> 00:19:03.530
the standards weren't being approved
because nobody used the protocol anymore

369
00:19:03.530 --> 00:19:05.140
so why bother updating the standard?

370
00:19:05.140 --> 00:19:07.140
So Cisco just said screw it,
we're gonna make it better.

371
00:19:07.140 --> 00:19:09.060
We're the only ones using it anyway,
we're just gonna make it better.

372
00:19:09.060 --> 00:19:11.864
So that's what they've done,
and they've changed it so

373
00:19:11.864 --> 00:19:14.736
much that it's not compatible
anymore with the standard.

374
00:19:14.736 --> 00:19:18.780
And so they renamed it TACACS+, which
means this is Cisco's implementation.

375
00:19:18.780 --> 00:19:19.880
It's not a standard anymore.

376
00:19:19.880 --> 00:19:21.620
Now it's kind of Cisco proprietary.

377
00:19:21.620 --> 00:19:26.120
So Cisco devices still use TACACS+, and
remember I mentioned the AAA thing,

378
00:19:26.120 --> 00:19:29.100
Authentication, authorization,
and accounting.

379
00:19:29.100 --> 00:19:34.940
Well RADIUS is really good at
authentication and accounting.

380
00:19:34.940 --> 00:19:37.230
It's not very good at authorization.

381
00:19:37.230 --> 00:19:39.550
It's not able to get really granular.

382
00:19:39.550 --> 00:19:42.090
It basically says yeah you're allowed
to connect or no you're not allowed to

383
00:19:42.090 --> 00:19:44.700
connect, yes you're an administrator or
no you're not an administrator.

384
00:19:44.700 --> 00:19:46.020
And that's it.

385
00:19:46.020 --> 00:19:50.510
But TACACS, boy TACACS,
you could get super granular.

386
00:19:50.510 --> 00:19:55.390
You could say, Wes is an administrator and
he's allowed to run these three commands.

387
00:19:55.390 --> 00:19:58.620
And he's allowed to run this command
with just these command line arguments.

388
00:19:58.620 --> 00:20:01.170
You can get super specific about
what you're allowed to do.

389
00:20:02.280 --> 00:20:04.530
But it stinks at accounting, right?

390
00:20:04.530 --> 00:20:06.010
It keeps bad records.

391
00:20:06.010 --> 00:20:11.690
So what Cisco said was, man, RADIUS is
good at accounting, bad at authorization.

392
00:20:11.690 --> 00:20:14.651
TACACS is good at authorization,
bad at accounting.

393
00:20:14.651 --> 00:20:16.478
What if we combined the two?

394
00:20:16.478 --> 00:20:21.360
What if we used RADIUS for authentication,
cuz everybody supports it.

395
00:20:21.360 --> 00:20:24.660
And we use RADIUS for accounting,
cuz it's really good at it.

396
00:20:24.660 --> 00:20:29.140
And we use TACACS for authorization,
cuz it's really good at it.

397
00:20:29.140 --> 00:20:29.920
And that's what they've done.

398
00:20:29.920 --> 00:20:33.880
Cisco has a product called ACS,
the Access Control Server and

399
00:20:33.880 --> 00:20:37.930
it bonds those two protocols
together to create one solution.

400

00:32:37.360 --> 00:32:39.890
It's gonna be for me to figure that out,
so that's what they do.

623
00:32:39.890 --> 00:32:45.080
And a public infrastructure is really
all the little pieces that make up

624
00:32:45.080 --> 00:32:48.760
a certificate solution,
there's really several different parts.

625
00:32:48.760 --> 00:32:51.860
You've got the client, and
the server,that you connect to, right?

626
00:32:51.860 --> 00:32:56.760
You've got the signed certificate, that's
the public key that's being handed out.

627
00:32:56.760 --> 00:32:59.050
Well, who is it that
signs that certificate?

628
00:32:59.050 --> 00:33:00.840
It's a certificate authority.

629
00:33:00.840 --> 00:33:04.640
So, DigiCert is our certificate
authority that we use on our site.

630
00:33:04.640 --> 00:33:06.550
We went to them to buy a certificate.

631
00:33:06.550 --> 00:33:10.730
Well, when you buy a certificate, the
certificate is stored in the database and

632
00:33:10.730 --> 00:33:14.140
you have what's called the Certificate
Authority that issues that cert and

633
00:33:14.140 --> 00:33:15.770
stores in the database.

634
00:33:15.770 --> 00:33:19.920
Well, if somebody were to break into that
certificate authority, they can generate

635
00:33:19.920 --> 00:33:23.180
all sorts of certificates pretending
to be all sorts of people and

636
00:33:23.180 --> 00:33:25.180
that would be really, really bad.

637
00:33:25.180 --> 00:33:30.720
So most of the providers like DigiCert
keep their CA what's called air-gapped.

638
00:33:30.720 --> 00:33:32.970
It's not plugged in to a network.

639
00:33:32.970 --> 00:33:35.540
It's not connected to the Internet,
it's not connected usually to any network.

640
00:33:35.540 --> 00:33:38.140
They typically don't have
a network adapter in them.

641
00:33:38.140 --> 00:33:42.680
And that CA is kept offline so that
nobody could remotely gain access to it.

642
00:33:43.800 --> 00:33:47.930
And that CA will generate certificates for
what are called subordinate CA's and

643
00:33:47.930 --> 00:33:50.820
the subordinate CA's are online and

644
00:33:50.820 --> 00:33:53.680
they're the ones that are issuing
out the certificates for us.

645
00:33:53.680 --> 00:33:57.310
And any time they need to update
a CA they take a usb key and

646
00:33:57.310 --> 00:34:02.120
they generate an update, they carry it
over to the other server, sign the cert,

647
00:34:02.120 --> 00:34:04.940
carry it back over to the subordinate CA,
and reissue it right?

648
00:34:04.940 --> 00:34:07.850
But that would be for
the subordinate CA cert itself.

649
00:34:07.850 --> 00:34:11.330
The subordinate CA has the authority to
issue out all the other certs without

650
00:34:11.330 --> 00:34:14.580
getting the primary involved so we're
not having to carry everything back and

651
00:34:14.580 --> 00:34:16.790
forth just when we do an update.

652
00:34:16.790 --> 00:34:21.280
Now over time a certificate
might get revoked.

653
00:34:21.280 --> 00:34:24.020
And so, they're maintaining
a certificate revocation list.

654
00:34:24.020 --> 00:34:27.570
So, anytime I see a cert,
I might trust who issued it and

655
00:34:27.570 --> 00:34:30.360
it might not have expired and all that,
but it might have been revoked.

656
00:34:30.360 --> 00:34:33.790
So, I'm gonna reach out to them and ask
them, hey, has this cert been revoked and

657
00:34:33.790 --> 00:34:35.280
look at the list and find out.

658
00:34:35.280 --> 00:34:36.865
That's what that CRL does.

659
00:34:36.865 --> 00:34:37.917
All right.

660
00:34:37.917 --> 00:34:38.900
The CSR I didn't talk about.

661
00:34:38.900 --> 00:34:40.110
That's the Certificate Signing Request.

662
00:34:40.110 --> 00:34:43.350
When I ask for a certificate,
I create a Certificate Signing Request.

663
00:34:43.350 --> 00:34:46.270
That's part of the buying process
when you go to buy a cert.

664
00:34:46.270 --> 00:34:50.170
So all this infrastructure is what's
going on behind the scenes for

665
00:34:50.170 --> 00:34:51.190
these certificates.

666
00:34:51.190 --> 00:34:52.050
When you go to Amazon and

667
00:34:52.050 --> 00:34:55.100
you get that secure page,
they went through this process.

668
00:34:55.100 --> 00:34:57.790
They had to go out and buy a cert and
get that signed off on.

669
00:34:57.790 --> 00:35:00.340
And for many years they used Verisign.

670
00:35:00.340 --> 00:35:05.850
Now, Amazon actually is a CA, and
so they issue their own cert now.

671
00:35:05.850 --> 00:35:09.320
But not everybody trusted Amazon back in
the day, and so they had to use Verisign,

672
00:35:09.320 --> 00:35:10.650
they had to use somebody else.

673
00:35:10.650 --> 00:35:14.330
That's how it works until a company
gets really big and really trusted.

674
00:35:14.330 --> 00:35:17.960
They've got to rely on someone
else to issue those certificates.

675
00:35:17.960 --> 00:35:20.090
>> All right, Don,
that is a lot of great information.

676
00:35:20.090 --> 00:35:21.775
However looking at our list.

677
00:35:21.775 --> 00:35:22.900
>> [LAUGH]
>> I know you've got more,

678
00:35:22.900 --> 00:35:25.100
I mean I love to consider
here with network security.

679
00:35:25.100 --> 00:35:25.800
So, how about this?

680
00:35:25.800 --> 00:35:28.890
How about we go ahead and
stop this episode and

681
00:35:28.890 --> 00:35:32.080
we'll go into a part two and
I'll give you a chance to come back and

682
00:35:32.080 --> 00:35:36.070
maybe finish up the additional topics
that you have for network security.

683
00:35:36.070 --> 00:35:37.890
But, before we sign out on this one,

684
00:35:37.890 --> 00:35:41.440
you have any additional advice you'd
like to maybe tell our viewers?

685
00:35:41.440 --> 00:35:44.560
>> Key thing to remember that I didn't
really talk too much about on certificates

686
00:35:44.560 --> 00:35:45.830
is that they do expire.

687
00:35:45.830 --> 00:35:48.030
And so they have to be renewed over time.

688
00:35:48.030 --> 00:35:51.340
They usually only last one or two years,
so you're constantly having to renew them.

689
00:35:51.340 --> 00:35:53.440
And you'll need that to be
part of your process here,

690
00:35:53.440 --> 00:35:54.740
part of your server maintenance.

691
00:35:54.740 --> 00:35:57.080
Cuz if the certificate expires,
all of a sudden,

692
00:35:57.080 --> 00:35:58.710
your server goes down, you have an outage.

693
00:35:58.710 --> 00:36:00.680
And it takes a little while to
get certificates reissued, so

694
00:36:00.680 --> 00:36:02.640
you don't want to get caught
by surprise on that one.

695
00:36:02.640 --> 00:36:06.030
But we're going to talk more about
certificates in part two because we also

696
00:36:06.030 --> 00:36:09.800
need to talk about VPN tunnels, which
leverage certificate technologies as well.

697
00:36:09.800 --> 00:36:11.710
So we're gonna see a lot
more of that coming up.

698
00:36:11.710 --> 00:36:13.290
>> All right, Don,
a wealth of great information.

699
00:36:13.290 --> 00:36:14.660
Look forward to seeing it in part two.

700
00:36:14.660 --> 00:36:16.760
We look forward to seeing
you there as well.

701
00:36:16.760 --> 00:36:19.900
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

702
00:36:19.900 --> 00:36:20.632
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

703
00:36:20.632 --> 00:36:22.552
>> And we'll see you next time.

704
00:36:22.552 --> 00:36:28.580
[MUSIC]

705
00:36:28.580 --> 00:36:31.758
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their exploration of various technologies used in network security. They dive into VPN technologies an explain the security benefits of VPN. They also look at IPsec, VLANS and DMZs
episodes.title: Network Security Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.150
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.150 --> 00:00:02.843
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:02.843 --> 00:00:08.430
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.430 --> 00:00:11.811
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.811 --> 00:00:14.145
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.145 --> 00:00:15.559
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:15.559 --> 00:00:19.861
And in today's episode we're continuing
through our CompTIA Server Plus series and

8
00:00:19.861 --> 00:00:23.160
we're actually coming back with
a part two in Network Security.

9
00:00:23.160 --> 00:00:27.360
So to help us with the topics we missed
in the first part of this is Don Pezet.

10
00:00:27.360 --> 00:00:28.500
Don, how are you doing, sir?

11
00:00:28.500 --> 00:00:30.130
>> I'm doing great, Wes,
ready to jump back in and

12
00:00:30.130 --> 00:00:32.960
tidy up some of the stuff that we didn't
get to in part one and we're gonna

13
00:00:32.960 --> 00:00:36.240
talk about some technologies here that
are really focusing on the network, right?

14
00:00:36.240 --> 00:00:38.820
This objective is called
Network Security so it makes sense.

15
00:00:38.820 --> 00:00:41.810
And usually we're talking
about securing the network

16
00:00:41.810 --> 00:00:43.660
that our server is connected to.

17
00:00:43.660 --> 00:00:47.410
So all the devices in part one
the firewalls that we talk about, and

18
00:00:47.410 --> 00:00:48.900
certificates and

19
00:00:48.900 --> 00:00:52.230
stuff like that is all designed to secure
the network that the server is on.

20
00:00:52.230 --> 00:00:55.360
But increasingly, we're gonna see
where our servers are connected

21
00:00:55.360 --> 00:00:58.700
not just to a little old network
somewhere but to the Internet.

22
00:00:58.700 --> 00:01:02.780
And via the Internet to networks all
over the world, a massive environment.

23
00:01:02.780 --> 00:01:05.090
And so how do we secure that?

24
00:01:05.090 --> 00:01:08.070
How do we make sure our
data access is secure

25
00:01:08.070 --> 00:01:09.900
even when it crosses
something like the Internet?

26
00:01:09.900 --> 00:01:13.240
Well, in the last episode we talked
a little bit about certificates.

27
00:01:13.240 --> 00:01:15.640
We talked about SSL and how they work.

28
00:01:15.640 --> 00:01:17.730
How we have a private key and public key.

29
00:01:17.730 --> 00:01:20.980
We build an encrypted session in
between a server and a client.

30
00:01:20.980 --> 00:01:23.250
And it works great for web servers.

31
00:01:24.420 --> 00:01:26.860
But what about all
the other stuff that we do?

32
00:01:26.860 --> 00:01:31.050
What about things like file servers and
other stuff?

33
00:01:31.050 --> 00:01:35.560
Well, SSL, and I don't want to go too deep
because I know I mentioned it in the last

34
00:01:35.560 --> 00:01:37.880
episode that SSL's kind
of been replaced by TLS.

35
00:01:37.880 --> 00:01:41.190
And TLS allows us to apply SSL
Certificates to all sorts of crazy things.

36
00:01:41.190 --> 00:01:44.710
To things, like, file servers,
and email servers, and stuff,

37
00:01:44.710 --> 00:01:46.800
where it really wasn't intended for it.

38
00:01:46.800 --> 00:01:50.920
But, you're still going to have
other services on your network

39
00:01:50.920 --> 00:01:54.380
that don't support that,
that may not be secure, but

40
00:01:54.380 --> 00:01:58.870
you need to make them secure somehow, and
so, there's another great technology that

41
00:01:58.870 --> 00:02:02.340
we use in conjunction with our service
to provide that and it's called a VPN.

42
00:02:02.340 --> 00:02:05.420
A VPN is a virtual private network.

43
00:02:05.420 --> 00:02:08.758
And virtual private networks came about
as a result of two different things.

44
00:02:08.758 --> 00:02:12.185
One, people working remotely a lot more,
right?

45
00:02:12.185 --> 00:02:15.286
So people aren't always in your office,
or in their office,

46
00:02:15.286 --> 00:02:18.910
they might be in temporary
locations all over the place.

47
00:02:18.910 --> 00:02:21.280
And then, two,
the proliferation of the Internet.

48
00:02:21.280 --> 00:02:25.480
We have Internet access everywhere,
so no matter where somebody goes,

49
00:02:25.480 --> 00:02:28.280
they're might be at their office,
they might be in a hotel room, but

50
00:02:28.280 --> 00:02:33.110
they'll have Internet access, and they'll
need access to their work materials.

51
00:02:33.110 --> 00:02:36.080
Don before the show started I'm
thinking if I've got a remote

52
00:02:36.080 --> 00:02:38.860
user why don't I just get one
of these dedicated lease lines?

53
00:02:38.860 --> 00:02:39.660
Why don't I use that?

54
00:02:39.660 --> 00:02:43.370
Why do I need any other technology if
I've already got something like that

55
00:02:43.370 --> 00:02:44.600
that was in place?

56
00:02:44.600 --> 00:02:46.385
>> Well that's the old way to do it,
right?

57
00:02:46.385 --> 00:02:51.395
Was if I had a headquarters, let's see
that we work for a grocery store, right?

58
00:02:51.395 --> 00:02:53.695
And you had a headquarters
located in one city and

59
00:02:53.695 --> 00:02:58.515
you had 50 stores located out across
the country or state or whatever.

60
00:02:58.515 --> 00:03:01.865
Well, how do all of those stores
connect back to your headquarters?

61
00:03:01.865 --> 00:03:04.875
I mean, you probably have a centralized
database, email servers, stuff like that.

62
00:03:04.875 --> 00:03:07.310
So how do they get back to that Data?

63
00:03:07.310 --> 00:03:10.400
Well the older days you'd
buy point to point line.

64
00:03:10.400 --> 00:03:14.630
You'd buy T1 lines or
fiber optic lines and get them run.

65
00:03:14.630 --> 00:03:16.190
That is expensive.

66
00:03:16.190 --> 00:03:18.640
It's costly and it's not very flexible,

67
00:03:18.640 --> 00:03:21.890
it assumes that all your employers
are going to be at those locations.

68
00:03:23.140 --> 00:03:26.850
What happens if we have
sales people that travel,

69
00:03:26.850 --> 00:03:30.060
or a great example I use to work for
an insurance company, and so

70
00:03:30.060 --> 00:03:32.920
yes we had insurance offices
all over the state of Florida.

71
00:03:32.920 --> 00:03:35.100
And all of those offices were
wired up with point-to-point

72
00:03:35.100 --> 00:03:35.910
lines that you could get to.

73
00:03:35.910 --> 00:03:39.410
So it was a stable very
consistent network.

74
00:03:39.410 --> 00:03:43.620
But when a hurricane would hit,
we had adjusters and

75
00:03:43.620 --> 00:03:45.500
the adjusters would go out into the field.

76
00:03:45.500 --> 00:03:47.043
And they wouldn't be doing
work in their office,

77
00:03:47.043 --> 00:03:48.623
they wouldn't be doing
work at the headquarters,

78
00:03:48.623 --> 00:03:50.330
they wouldn't even be
doing work at the hotel.

79
00:03:50.330 --> 00:03:54.120
They would be in the middle of nowhere
with a cellular card stuck on their laptop

80
00:03:54.120 --> 00:03:56.930
trying to be able to file a claim and

81
00:03:56.930 --> 00:04:00.270
issue a check to be able to
get people's' stuff repaired.

82
00:04:00.270 --> 00:04:02.340
How do you provide secure
access to somebody like that?

83
00:04:02.340 --> 00:04:03.520
When it's not even your network?

84
00:04:03.520 --> 00:04:05.360
They're on a cellular network.

85
00:04:05.360 --> 00:04:07.680
Well, that's where VPNs come in.

86
00:04:07.680 --> 00:04:12.270
With a VPN, you can take your laptop and
go anywhere and

87
00:04:12.270 --> 00:04:16.970
build a secure connection
across a public network.

88
00:04:16.970 --> 00:04:18.960
Let me show you a little
diagram that I've got here.

89
00:04:18.960 --> 00:04:22.210
So, we typically have
a headquarters network and

90
00:04:22.210 --> 00:04:23.830
that's where our servers are going to be.

91
00:04:23.830 --> 00:04:27.770
Things like if we have file servers and
certificate authorities and

92
00:04:27.770 --> 00:04:30.480
all those other things that we
typically have at a headquarters.

93
00:04:30.480 --> 00:04:32.200
They're all gonna be right
up here at our headquarters.

94
00:04:32.200 --> 00:04:35.900
And we've got a firewall that
connects to the Internet via

95
00:04:35.900 --> 00:04:37.300
whatever connection it is we have.

96
00:04:37.300 --> 00:04:43.130
Maybe we've got a OC12 or cable modem or

97
00:04:43.130 --> 00:04:46.800
who knows what bandwidth it is, we have
a metro Ethernet connection, right.

98
00:04:46.800 --> 00:04:50.080
And we have branch offices and
at those branch offices

99
00:04:50.080 --> 00:04:52.510
they probably have a firewall and
a connection to the Internet also.

100
00:04:52.510 --> 00:04:56.800
Maybe broadband, cable, DSL,
maybe fiber, who knows.

101
00:04:56.800 --> 00:04:58.460
And then you have people
that are at home or

102
00:04:58.460 --> 00:05:02.550
remote, wandering the Earth as they
see like in the Kung-Fu shows.

103
00:05:02.550 --> 00:05:05.830
So they're wandering from village
to village helping people and

104
00:05:05.830 --> 00:05:09.860
they need access to the domain controller,
or to the file server,

105
00:05:09.860 --> 00:05:12.710
to the other resources
back at headquarters.

106
00:05:12.710 --> 00:05:17.790
Well, if they communicate using a common
network like the Internet, that works.

107
00:05:17.790 --> 00:05:19.970
I can go anywhere in the world,
and get on the Internet,

108
00:05:19.970 --> 00:05:23.860
and if my home office is connected to
the Internet also we can see each other.

109
00:05:23.860 --> 00:05:25.410
That's awesome,
I don't even have to go to,

110
00:05:25.410 --> 00:05:30.150
I can just go to a coffee shop in any
city and connect back to my headquarters.

111
00:05:30.150 --> 00:05:32.380
The problem is,
we don't control the Internet.

112
00:05:32.380 --> 00:05:34.480
The Internet is the wild west, right?

113
00:05:34.480 --> 00:05:36.690
There's all sorts of bad
stuff going on out there.

114
00:05:36.690 --> 00:05:40.760
And you don't want to send sensitive
corporate data over that Internet link if

115
00:05:40.760 --> 00:05:41.280
you can avoid it.

116
00:05:42.290 --> 00:05:46.900
So what we do is we build a tunnel.

117
00:05:46.900 --> 00:05:52.310
And a tunnel is an encrypted session
you can build between a laptop

118
00:05:52.310 --> 00:05:55.810
and a remote access server
back at your headquarters.

119
00:05:55.810 --> 00:05:59.530
And these days, a remote access
server is often times your firewall.

120
00:05:59.530 --> 00:06:02.350
A larger organization will have
a dedicated VPN concentrator or

121
00:06:02.350 --> 00:06:05.360
a server that acts as that
remote access server.

122
00:06:05.360 --> 00:06:08.520
Smaller companies, like ours,
we use our firewall, so

123
00:06:08.520 --> 00:06:10.990
we just VPN right into
the firewall to gain access.

124
00:06:10.990 --> 00:06:16.110
And when somebody VPNs in like this
all of their data is encrypted

125
00:06:16.110 --> 00:06:20.580
on their laptop and sent across
the Internet in an encrypted form.

126
00:06:21.580 --> 00:06:25.020
And at the other end of the remote
access server it's decrypted and

127
00:06:25.020 --> 00:06:27.220
dumped on the network here, right?

128
00:06:27.220 --> 00:06:31.710
So now they have access to all
the headquarters resources

129
00:06:31.710 --> 00:06:32.820
as if they were there.

130
00:06:32.820 --> 00:06:35.160
As if their laptop was physically
in the headquarters building.

131
00:06:35.160 --> 00:06:39.320
And they can access everything whether
the protocols support encryption or not.

132
00:06:39.320 --> 00:06:42.790
They can reach out and connect and
gain access to those resources.

133
00:06:42.790 --> 00:06:44.910
And that's a key and important thing.

134
00:06:44.910 --> 00:06:48.630
I don't have to be in the office
to have access to my resources.

135
00:06:48.630 --> 00:06:51.340
And it's still secure,
it's virtually private.

136
00:06:51.340 --> 00:06:53.520
That's the name virtual private network.

137
00:06:53.520 --> 00:06:55.970
Our data is safe and secure.

138
00:06:55.970 --> 00:06:58.970
Now when you build up a connection like
this there's several different protocols

139
00:06:58.970 --> 00:06:59.930
that are out there.

140
00:06:59.930 --> 00:07:05.220
If it's laptop dialing into a server,
you're gonna use L2TP or

141
00:07:05.220 --> 00:07:10.190
PPTP, SSTP, all these different protocols
that are out there that you can use.

142
00:07:10.190 --> 00:07:13.680
But a lot of times, we're doing firewall
to firewall, like in my example of

143
00:07:13.680 --> 00:07:17.250
the branch office connecting to the
headquarters, they both had a firewall.
