episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don discuss various aspects of proper and security disposal of storage devices. They talk about file-level, disk-level and tape encryption. They also examine soft wipe vs hard wipe formatting, physical destruction of the media as well as remote data wipes.
episodes.title: Secure Storage Disposal
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:05.521
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host,
Don Pezet [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:05.521 --> 00:00:08.287
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.287 --> 00:00:12.044
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:12.044 --> 00:00:14.660
>> Welcome to another exciting
episode here at IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:14.660 --> 00:00:16.470
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:16.470 --> 00:00:20.370
And in today's episode, we're continuing
through our CompTIA Server+ SK0004

7
00:00:20.370 --> 00:00:24.090
certification, if I can get all that out.

8
00:00:24.090 --> 00:00:27.580
And here to join us in the studios
today is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

9
00:00:27.580 --> 00:00:28.740
Don, how you doing, sir?

10
00:00:28.740 --> 00:00:29.720
>> I'm doing just well, Wes.

11
00:00:29.720 --> 00:00:32.490
Ready to dive right back into Server+.

12
00:00:32.490 --> 00:00:35.870
In this episode, we are talking
about secure storage disposal.

13
00:00:35.870 --> 00:00:38.630
That's right,
we're chucking storage in the trash today.

14
00:00:38.630 --> 00:00:41.520
And that's probably a good way to start.

15
00:00:41.520 --> 00:00:44.460
All right, because throwing storage in
the trash is something we all have to

16
00:00:44.460 --> 00:00:45.460
do eventually.

17
00:00:45.460 --> 00:00:49.700
Hard drives get old or whatever storage
media does get old, it gets aged.

18
00:00:49.700 --> 00:00:51.610
It has to be replaced.

19
00:00:51.610 --> 00:00:54.140
And what do you do with the old
stuff after you've replaced it?

20
00:00:55.260 --> 00:00:56.550
Generally you throw it away.

21
00:00:56.550 --> 00:00:58.600
Problem is, we've got data on it.

22
00:00:58.600 --> 00:01:01.460
If you have data that's still on that
disk and you throw it away, well,

23
00:01:01.460 --> 00:01:04.318
the odds are it's going to go to
the landfill, it's gonna get buried,

24
00:01:04.318 --> 00:01:07.740
it's never going to get seen again and
that's that, right?

25
00:01:07.740 --> 00:01:12.490
But, there's always the possibility
that someone could intercept that drive,

26
00:01:12.490 --> 00:01:16.370
take it, hook it up to their own system,
and recover your data off of it.

27
00:01:16.370 --> 00:01:19.760
And you've potentially leaked out
information from your company and

28
00:01:19.760 --> 00:01:22.820
you don't even know it because
you've thrown the disk away.

29
00:01:22.820 --> 00:01:24.690
If somebody broke into
your data center and

30
00:01:24.690 --> 00:01:27.920
stole a hard drive right out of
the server, you'd know it, right?

31
00:01:27.920 --> 00:01:31.790
That server's not booting up, or it's
services aren't working, you would know.

32
00:01:31.790 --> 00:01:36.150
But if somebody steals a hard drive
you threw away, you'd have no idea.

33
00:01:36.150 --> 00:01:40.260
And so we've got to be really
protective of how that data is handled

34
00:01:40.260 --> 00:01:44.640
to make sure that when we dispose of our
storage it's done in a secure manner

35
00:01:44.640 --> 00:01:47.390
where somebody else can't
retrieve our information.

36
00:01:47.390 --> 00:01:52.910
Now, the key thing about
secure storage disposal,

37
00:01:52.910 --> 00:01:56.880
is that in your planning for it you should
always assume that your storage is going

38
00:01:56.880 --> 00:01:59.070
to be disposed of improperly, right?

39
00:01:59.070 --> 00:02:01.190
Just assume that it's
not gonna happen right.

40
00:02:01.190 --> 00:02:03.880
Because you're setting it up today.

41
00:02:03.880 --> 00:02:06.250
It might be somebody
else that disposes of it.

42
00:02:06.250 --> 00:02:09.280
Or it might be a scenario where you have
to trust somebody else to dispose of it.

43
00:02:09.280 --> 00:02:11.080
Let me give you an example of that.

44
00:02:11.080 --> 00:02:14.680
Amazon web services,
Microsoft Azure or Google Cloud.

45
00:02:14.680 --> 00:02:16.180
All these cloud services.

46
00:02:16.180 --> 00:02:18.460
I could go to any one of them and
I can spin up a server right now.

47
00:02:18.460 --> 00:02:21.470
I can spin up an Oracle database and

48
00:02:21.470 --> 00:02:25.370
I can load all of my financial data
right into that Oracle database.

49
00:02:25.370 --> 00:02:27.960
And when I'm done with it,
I can delete the virtual machine.

50
00:02:29.020 --> 00:02:33.660
And Google, or Amazon, or Microsoft
will say, okay, we deleted your data,

51
00:02:33.660 --> 00:02:34.250
it's all good.

52
00:02:35.630 --> 00:02:36.130
Did they?

53
00:02:37.150 --> 00:02:38.310
I don't know.

54
00:02:38.310 --> 00:02:43.280
Who's the person who was responsible for
erasing your VM?

55
00:02:43.280 --> 00:02:44.580
Did they do it securely?

56
00:02:44.580 --> 00:02:45.180
I don't know.

57
00:02:45.180 --> 00:02:45.900
I hope they did.

58
00:02:45.900 --> 00:02:49.570
They say they did, it said right there
on the webpage, but I don't know.

59
00:02:49.570 --> 00:02:54.270
And that's not a good way to secure your
data, to not know, you need to know.

60
00:02:54.270 --> 00:02:57.160
So the best way to plan for
disposal is to just plan for

61
00:02:57.160 --> 00:02:58.790
the disposal to be done wrong.

62
00:02:58.790 --> 00:03:01.810
So assuming it's done wrong,
let's just assume the worst.

63
00:03:01.810 --> 00:03:05.910
The worst case scenario is I have
a server I don't need anymore, and so

64
00:03:05.910 --> 00:03:09.100
somebody takes it and sells it on Ebay.

65
00:03:09.100 --> 00:03:11.880
And if somebody buys it on Ebay,
they're gonna use it.

66
00:03:11.880 --> 00:03:12.950
They're gonna take that server and use it.

67
00:03:12.950 --> 00:03:15.240
So they're gonna fire it up,
and there's my data.

68
00:03:15.240 --> 00:03:17.100
That's the worst case scenario.

69
00:03:17.100 --> 00:03:18.270
So how can I make it so

70
00:03:18.270 --> 00:03:21.630
that when they fire that server up,
that they're not going to have my data.

71
00:03:21.630 --> 00:03:24.100
That they're not gonna be
able to see that information.

72
00:03:24.100 --> 00:03:27.840
The number one best way to do
it is to encrypt your data.

73
00:03:27.840 --> 00:03:30.290
Well, I guess the best way would be to
not have data in the first place, but

74
00:03:30.290 --> 00:03:31.820
that's not really an option for
most of us.

75
00:03:31.820 --> 00:03:33.440
So, encrypting the data.

76
00:03:33.440 --> 00:03:37.160
Now, when it comes to encrypting the data,
there's a few different choices we've got.

77
00:03:37.160 --> 00:03:37.820
For example,

78
00:03:37.820 --> 00:03:41.650
we can encrypt individual files or
we can encrypt entire hard drives.

79
00:03:41.650 --> 00:03:46.400
Encrypting individual files is
nice cuz it's a little bit faster.

80
00:03:46.400 --> 00:03:49.450
And you just encrypt what's sensitive,
right.

81
00:03:49.450 --> 00:03:53.330
The negative side of encrypting individual
files is it's easy to forget that yeah,

82
00:03:53.330 --> 00:03:56.500
I might have secured 10 or
20 of my secure files, and

83
00:03:56.500 --> 00:03:58.790
then I add another one a year later and
I forget about it.

84
00:03:58.790 --> 00:04:00.060
And so I don't encrypt it.

85
00:04:00.060 --> 00:04:02.330
Or sometimes it's hard to tell
what's encrypted and what isn't.

86
00:04:02.330 --> 00:04:04.190
Things get mixed up, right.

87
00:04:04.190 --> 00:04:07.130
So that's kind of the challenge
in doing individual files.

88
00:04:07.130 --> 00:04:09.950
If you do the whole disk, now,
I don't have to worry about it.

89
00:04:09.950 --> 00:04:12.080
I've encrypted the entire hard drive.

90
00:04:12.080 --> 00:04:15.810
So, if I put a file on there, it's
encrypted, if I take a file off, it's not.

91
00:04:15.810 --> 00:04:16.770
There we go.

92
00:04:16.770 --> 00:04:18.780
I don't have to remember that at all.

93
00:04:18.780 --> 00:04:21.540
But, we take a little bit
of a performance hit.

94
00:04:21.540 --> 00:04:23.880
Because every time we write to the hard
drive we've got to encrypt the data.

95
00:04:23.880 --> 00:04:26.400
And every time we read from the hard
drive, we have to decrypt the data.

96
00:04:26.400 --> 00:04:30.490
So, we're trading performance for
security.

97
00:04:30.490 --> 00:04:32.320
Or vice versa, we're trading security for

98
00:04:32.320 --> 00:04:35.120
performance by choosing
one over the other.

99
00:04:35.120 --> 00:04:39.650
Now most modern operating systems
support full disk encryption.

100
00:04:39.650 --> 00:04:41.250
So you've got the ability to turn it on.

101
00:04:42.260 --> 00:04:46.490
Most modern operating systems support
individual file encryption also, but

102
00:04:46.490 --> 00:04:48.040
you've got to turn it on.

103
00:04:48.040 --> 00:04:53.410
There's only a few operating systems
that actually encrypt by default.

104
00:04:53.410 --> 00:04:55.950
Most of them don't,
including Windows Server.

105
00:04:55.950 --> 00:04:57.420
Like Windows Server doesn't
encrypt by default.

106
00:04:57.420 --> 00:05:00.790
You can turn it on if you want,
but it doesn't encrypt by default.

107
00:05:00.790 --> 00:05:01.660
Linux distros?

108
00:05:01.660 --> 00:05:03.910
I don't know a single Linux
distro that encrypts by default.

109
00:05:03.910 --> 00:05:06.040
They've all got the option, right,
I'm not saying they're bad.

110
00:05:06.040 --> 00:05:07.850
I'm saying they give you the option,
right.

111
00:05:07.850 --> 00:05:08.940
But they don't by default.

112
00:05:08.940 --> 00:05:12.910
And the reason they don't is they know
that everybody wants performance.

113
00:05:12.910 --> 00:05:15.090
And as long as you're doing your
physical security, right, and

114
00:05:15.090 --> 00:05:18.900
you're disposing of your drives properly,
you don't have to worry about it.

115
00:05:18.900 --> 00:05:20.850
You don't need full-disk encryption.

116
00:05:20.850 --> 00:05:22.710
So that's why it's off by default.

117
00:05:22.710 --> 00:05:24.830
But if you know you can't
trust your environment,

118
00:05:24.830 --> 00:05:27.820
if you know you can't trust these
drives will be disposed properly,

119
00:05:27.820 --> 00:05:30.860
then you need to make sure
you can encrypt, all right?

120
00:05:30.860 --> 00:05:33.270
So let's take a look at some of
the different ways we can do this.

121
00:05:33.270 --> 00:05:34.270
I'm just gonna show you a few here.

122
00:05:34.270 --> 00:05:35.756
On the exam, they don't really nickle and

123
00:05:35.756 --> 00:05:37.334
dime you on actually
configuring the stuff.

124
00:05:37.334 --> 00:05:41.170
But just to show you, like here on my Mac.

125
00:05:41.170 --> 00:05:42.920
On a Mac you can do full disk encryption.

126
00:05:42.920 --> 00:05:44.660
It has what's called FileVault, but

127
00:05:44.660 --> 00:05:47.870
I can encrypt individual files
using third party software.

128
00:05:47.870 --> 00:05:49.570
And this is true on Linux and
Windows also.

129
00:05:49.570 --> 00:05:53.490
One of the most popular ways to encrypt
individual files is through using

130
00:05:53.490 --> 00:05:55.340
a software called PGP.

131
00:05:55.340 --> 00:05:57.930
PGP stands for Pretty Good Privacy.

132
00:05:57.930 --> 00:06:03.720
And it's an open sourced suite of software
that lets you encrypt and decrypt files.

133
00:06:03.720 --> 00:06:06.550
So, I have a little document sitting here,
this test document.

134
00:06:06.550 --> 00:06:14.130
And if I want to encrypt it, I can fire
up Open PGP and I can encrypt the file.

135
00:06:14.130 --> 00:06:15.630
See where I can digitally sign it?

136
00:06:15.630 --> 00:06:18.300
Signing a file is nice if I just want
people to know whether it's been

137
00:06:18.300 --> 00:06:21.570
tampered with or not, but
it doesn't actually encrypt it.

138
00:06:21.570 --> 00:06:23.950
So I can come in here and
I can encrypt the file.

139
00:06:23.950 --> 00:06:28.710
And when I do that, it's gonna launch
Open PGP, which is what I'm using or

140
00:06:28.710 --> 00:06:30.840
GPG services.

141
00:06:30.840 --> 00:06:33.140
And I can pick what key I
want to encrypt it with.

142
00:06:33.140 --> 00:06:34.840
I'm gonna encrypt it with my key, right?

143
00:06:34.840 --> 00:06:38.640
So here's the Don Pezet key, I'm gonna
choose it, and I'm gonna encrypt it.

144
00:06:38.640 --> 00:06:43.855
Now, I can encrypt it with a password or
I can encrypt it with my key and

145
00:06:43.855 --> 00:06:45.780
that's' what I'm gonna do,
is encrypt it with my key.

146
00:06:45.780 --> 00:06:50.160
Now, when I do that,
I'm encrypting it with a particular key.

147
00:06:51.420 --> 00:06:55.970
And anybody who receives this
needs to be able to decrypt it.

148
00:06:55.970 --> 00:07:00.020
Well, when you encrypt something,
you encrypt with a public key.

149
00:07:00.020 --> 00:07:02.310
And then they decrypt using a private key.

150
00:07:02.310 --> 00:07:07.420
If I encrypt this with my private key,
only I can decrypt it and

151
00:07:07.420 --> 00:07:09.390
that's what I want, okay.

152
00:07:09.390 --> 00:07:11.670
If I were to encrypt this with my key and

153
00:07:11.670 --> 00:07:15.450
send it to Wes,
Wes couldn't open it my key.

154
00:07:15.450 --> 00:07:18.380
I would need Wes to
send me his public key.

155
00:07:18.380 --> 00:07:23.200
And then I can encrypt it with Wes'
public key and send him the file.

156
00:07:23.200 --> 00:07:26.390
And he could decrypt it
using his private key.

157
00:07:26.390 --> 00:07:29.550
So if I'm transmitting it to somebody
else I need to encrypt it with their key.

158
00:07:29.550 --> 00:07:32.310
But if I'm just encrypting it for me, I
don't want anybody else to get into this.

159
00:07:32.310 --> 00:07:36.320
I can choose my key and I can come
in here and tell it to encrypt it.

160
00:07:36.320 --> 00:07:39.670
And so now it's going to encrypt it,
it's finished, and

161
00:07:39.670 --> 00:07:42.880
now over here I can see I've
got two different files.

162
00:07:42.880 --> 00:07:45.490
I've got my test document which is an RTF.

163
00:07:45.490 --> 00:07:51.913
And now I've got Test Document.rtf.gpg,
the encrypted version of that file.

164
00:07:51.913 --> 00:07:55.859
Now the negative is, any time I open this,
I've got to decrypt it first.

165
00:07:55.859 --> 00:07:57.865
Then I can work with it, and
then I have to re-encrypt it.

166
00:07:57.865 --> 00:08:00.489
It's a manual process,
that's the biggest negative.

167
00:08:00.489 --> 00:08:04.030
Of using individual file
encryption like this.

168
00:08:04.030 --> 00:08:07.450
There are some vendors like Microsoft
that have tried to make it easier.

169
00:08:07.450 --> 00:08:09.890
But they don't support
sharing it with other people,

170
00:08:09.890 --> 00:08:13.457
because then you've gotta use their key,
and they don't have a key exchange.

171
00:08:13.457 --> 00:08:16.882
GPG does, it's got a little key exchange
we can do to get somebody else's key to

172
00:08:16.882 --> 00:08:18.570
encrypt and send to them.

173
00:08:18.570 --> 00:08:23.438
But for example, if was in
Microsoft Windows, I could create,

174
00:08:23.438 --> 00:08:25.977
here I'll create Don's Stuff.

175
00:08:25.977 --> 00:08:30.905
So I'm going to create a folder,
and in that folder I will create

176
00:08:30.905 --> 00:08:35.590
a text document which I'll call
My Test Document all right.

177
00:08:35.590 --> 00:08:38.230
And if I pull up
the properties on that file.

178
00:08:39.940 --> 00:08:41.860
It can be read only, it can be hidden.

179
00:08:41.860 --> 00:08:45.760
If I go to advance I can encrypt
the contents of the file.

180
00:08:45.760 --> 00:08:47.850
Just a little check mark, right?

181
00:08:47.850 --> 00:08:50.790
So I hit the check mark, it's asking
if I wanna encrypt just the file or

182
00:08:50.790 --> 00:08:51.710
the entire folder.

183
00:08:51.710 --> 00:08:53.872
I'm just gonna do the file.

184
00:08:53.872 --> 00:08:57.600
And now that that's done, it's encrypted.

185
00:08:57.600 --> 00:08:59.390
Now as end user,
how do I know it's encrypted?

186
00:08:59.390 --> 00:09:02.600
Well It doesn't look much different,
does it?

187
00:09:02.600 --> 00:09:06.490
If I zoom way in,
the little lock on that icon.

188
00:09:06.490 --> 00:09:08.030
But it's so stinking small, and

189
00:09:08.030 --> 00:09:11.680
it's yellow on white, that you
don't even notice most of the time.

190
00:09:11.680 --> 00:09:15.382
When I hear full resolution,
I can barely read the filename, better yet

191
00:09:15.382 --> 00:09:16.180
see that icon.

192
00:09:16.180 --> 00:09:18.390
But the cool part here
is it's all automated.

193
00:09:18.390 --> 00:09:21.390
If I open that file,
I didn't have to decrypt it.

194
00:09:21.390 --> 00:09:24.090
I just type in it, right?

195
00:09:24.090 --> 00:09:28.270
And there it is, and when I close
it I didn't have to re-encrypt it,

196
00:09:28.270 --> 00:09:31.290
it just does it for me,
it's all automated, so that's nice.

197
00:09:31.290 --> 00:09:35.040
Individual file encryption and I didn't
have to get involved with it, right?

198
00:09:35.040 --> 00:09:39.340
So that's a solution that works in
the Microsoft world, in the Linux and

199
00:09:39.340 --> 00:09:41.910
Mac world you have GPG,
which is a little more manual.

200
00:09:41.910 --> 00:09:44.780
GPG works in Windows also, so
you can use it everywhere.

201
00:09:44.780 --> 00:09:49.030
And on those guys they would rather
you did full disk encryption

202
00:09:49.030 --> 00:09:51.550
because full disk encryption you
also don't have to worry about but

203
00:09:51.550 --> 00:09:53.680
it's only encrypted right
there on your drive.

204
00:09:53.680 --> 00:09:58.440
If I attach a file to an email and email
it to somebody it's not encrypted anymore,

205
00:09:58.440 --> 00:10:00.738
it was only encrypted
while it was on my drive.

206
00:10:00.738 --> 00:10:03.030
Versus GPG where I encrypt it, and

207
00:10:03.030 --> 00:10:05.580
now it's encrypted forever
until somebody decrypts it.

208
00:10:05.580 --> 00:10:07.730
That GPG file is gonna be encrypted.

209
00:10:07.730 --> 00:10:09.340
>> Don,
when you mention Full Disk Encryption,

210
00:10:09.340 --> 00:10:11.120
you said File Vault
there in the Mac world.

211
00:10:11.120 --> 00:10:14.740
Is that akin to something like for
instance Bit Locker in Windows?

212
00:10:14.740 --> 00:10:16.632
Would they be comparative
to the technologies even

213
00:10:16.632 --> 00:10:17.292
though
>> Absolutely.

214
00:10:17.292 --> 00:10:18.048
>> Different flavors?

215
00:10:18.048 --> 00:10:20.680
>> Absolutely, yeah, absolutely, and
on the Macs, you have File Vault.

216
00:10:20.680 --> 00:10:22.150
On Windows, you have Bit Locker.

217
00:10:22.150 --> 00:10:24.586
In Linux, you have LUKS, L-U-K-S.

218
00:10:24.586 --> 00:10:27.185
Each of them are full
disk encryption models.

219
00:10:27.185 --> 00:10:32.604
And then there's third parties out
there like and a few other people.

220
00:10:32.604 --> 00:10:34.980
What's the Truecrypt?

221
00:10:34.980 --> 00:10:36.260
>> Truecrypt.
>> They changed their name?

222
00:10:36.260 --> 00:10:36.811
What's the new name?

223
00:10:36.811 --> 00:10:37.439
>> I'm not sure.

224
00:10:37.439 --> 00:10:40.970
>> Veracrypt, so you have VeraCrypt,
which is a open source,

225
00:10:40.970 --> 00:10:43.040

00:23:32.570 --> 00:23:33.820
It's read only.

462
00:23:33.820 --> 00:23:35.920
But because you have full control,
you can go and

463
00:23:35.920 --> 00:23:38.380
remove the read-only attribute, right?

464
00:23:38.380 --> 00:23:40.639
Which isn't hard for a user,
that attribute's easy, right?

465
00:23:40.639 --> 00:23:45.328
Cuz you can just browse right to the file,
and you pull up its properties, and shoot,

466
00:23:45.328 --> 00:23:49.464
I'm already in my properties, but it's
just a little check mark in a little box

467
00:23:49.464 --> 00:23:53.479
right there to remove the read-only
attribute itself, easy enough to do but

468
00:23:53.479 --> 00:23:55.493
the user would have to know to do that.

469
00:23:55.493 --> 00:23:58.626
So that's more like security through
annoyance than actual security through

470
00:23:58.626 --> 00:23:59.249
enforcement.

471
00:23:59.249 --> 00:24:02.633
Just be aware that there are multiple
levels that we have to deal with this

472
00:24:02.633 --> 00:24:03.137
stuff on.

473
00:24:03.137 --> 00:24:05.470
So as we get out permissions kinda set,

474
00:24:05.470 --> 00:24:08.310
we finally get it to the way
that we want it to be.

475
00:24:08.310 --> 00:24:12.210
Now I've got system has read access,
Wes has read access,

476
00:24:12.210 --> 00:24:15.692
Jane has modify,
administrators have full control.

477
00:24:15.692 --> 00:24:17.780
That's kinda the way
that I want this to be.

478
00:24:17.780 --> 00:24:21.720
I've been setting this on
the Employee Handbook folder, right?

479
00:24:21.720 --> 00:24:23.780
So on the folder itself.

480
00:24:23.780 --> 00:24:27.990
So when I go into the Employee Handbook
folder and I start to create something.

481
00:24:27.990 --> 00:24:33.090
Like if I come in, I create a text
document, and I'll this Handbook, and

482
00:24:33.090 --> 00:24:37.160
then we maybe stick a day on it,
I wanna say the 18th.

483
00:24:37.160 --> 00:24:41.550
So I'll just give it a date and
we get that set, right.

484
00:24:41.550 --> 00:24:44.660
So here's my first
addition to this handbook.

485
00:24:44.660 --> 00:24:47.600
Well, I didn't set
permissions on this file, but

486
00:24:47.600 --> 00:24:49.764
it inherited what came from the parent.

487
00:24:49.764 --> 00:24:54.620
So if I go into my properties and security
I'll see in here where system has read

488
00:24:54.620 --> 00:24:58.570
access, Wes has read access, Jane has
modify administrators have full control.

489
00:24:58.570 --> 00:25:00.870
It brought those permissions with it.

490
00:25:00.870 --> 00:25:01.750
Everybody got what they needed.

491
00:25:02.980 --> 00:25:07.330
Okay, now that's just one folder.

492
00:25:07.330 --> 00:25:08.620
Then I've got my other folders, right?

493
00:25:08.620 --> 00:25:09.750
Network documentation.

494
00:25:09.750 --> 00:25:11.170
This one's kind of the opposite, right?

495
00:25:11.170 --> 00:25:12.710
On network documentation,

496
00:25:12.710 --> 00:25:18.370
I probably want Wes to have full control,
or at least modify.

497
00:25:18.370 --> 00:25:20.870
And Jane,
maybe I just give her read access or

498
00:25:20.870 --> 00:25:22.710
maybe I don't give Jane access at all.

499
00:25:22.710 --> 00:25:25.250
Does Jane really need access
to the network documentation?

500
00:25:25.250 --> 00:25:30.210
She works in HR, she needs access to
payroll and vacation calendars and

501
00:25:30.210 --> 00:25:32.220
all the things that HR deals with.

502
00:25:32.220 --> 00:25:34.650
HR's not dealing with IP
address assignments and

503
00:25:34.650 --> 00:25:37.750
router backup configurations and
stuff like that.

504
00:25:37.750 --> 00:25:40.140
So she may not need access to this at all.

505
00:25:40.140 --> 00:25:44.450
So I'm gonna go in here and I'm gonna
remove the permissions that are on there.

506
00:25:45.470 --> 00:25:49.850
And then I'll go back and assign who
it is that I want to have access.

507
00:25:49.850 --> 00:25:54.660
And so I'm gonna give Wes access and
so on, right?

508
00:25:54.660 --> 00:25:59.090
So I'll just add administrators and
keep this kind of short.

509
00:25:59.090 --> 00:26:00.340
I'm running low on time.

510
00:26:00.340 --> 00:26:01.800
So I'm gonna add that one in.

511
00:26:01.800 --> 00:26:03.600
And there we go, all right?

512
00:26:03.600 --> 00:26:07.120
Now once that's in place
now I can come through and

513
00:26:07.120 --> 00:26:09.640
say, Wes gets modify,
administrators get full control.

514
00:26:09.640 --> 00:26:12.840
Wes is probably an administrator so he'll
probably end up with full control anyway.

515
00:26:12.840 --> 00:26:14.570
But just because you're in
the IT department doesn't mean

516
00:26:14.570 --> 00:26:16.080
you're an administrator, right?

517
00:26:16.080 --> 00:26:18.920
You might be at the help desk and
you need to read the documentation but

518
00:26:18.920 --> 00:26:19.920
you're not the one who writes it.

519
00:26:19.920 --> 00:26:22.340
So you get different levels of access.

520
00:26:22.340 --> 00:26:24.170
So I can come in and I can set that up.

521
00:26:24.170 --> 00:26:26.530
And now those permissions
are assigned too, okay?

522
00:26:27.690 --> 00:26:30.040
Once that's done, I'm good to go.

523
00:26:30.040 --> 00:26:32.440
I've got my permissions set, everybody
can access what they need to access.

524
00:26:33.560 --> 00:26:37.470
But the way I've done it here
is not really the best way.

525
00:26:37.470 --> 00:26:40.600
The biggest challenge that I'm gonna
have here is when I add a new employee.

526
00:26:40.600 --> 00:26:43.300
So let's say I go and
hire another IT person.

527
00:26:43.300 --> 00:26:46.140
So Wes is just getting overburdened,
so we hire somebody else, right?

528
00:26:46.140 --> 00:26:48.020
I create an account for
myself, right, I need access.

529
00:26:48.020 --> 00:26:50.030
So I'm gonna create a dpezet account,
right?

530
00:26:50.030 --> 00:26:56.270
Well, I can go over here into my users,
and I can create a new users,

531
00:26:56.270 --> 00:27:01.460
which I'll create as dpezet,
and if I can spell my own name.

532
00:27:01.460 --> 00:27:07.830
And I'll give myself a password,
and get that set.

533
00:27:07.830 --> 00:27:11.730
There we go and so now I've got a user
account, and I'm gonna be working along

534
00:27:11.730 --> 00:27:14.580
side Wes and so I need to get
the same permissions that Wes has.

535
00:27:15.670 --> 00:27:17.990
How do I get the same
permissions that Wes has?

536
00:27:17.990 --> 00:27:20.900
Well, I've got to go to every folder.

537
00:27:20.900 --> 00:27:23.740
I've got to pull up the properties,
I've got to go to security,

538
00:27:23.740 --> 00:27:26.160
I've got to look at what Wes has.

539
00:27:26.160 --> 00:27:31.520
And then I've got to add my self in,
so I'm gonna add Don Pezet.

540
00:27:32.740 --> 00:27:37.320
And I need to give myself
the same permissions that he had,

541
00:27:37.320 --> 00:27:38.780
which I've already screwed up there.

542
00:27:38.780 --> 00:27:42.590
So I'll set that and then I need to go to
the next folder, and the next folder, and

543
00:27:42.590 --> 00:27:44.980
the next folder and assign all of this.

544
00:27:44.980 --> 00:27:47.490
And I keep talking about folders.

545
00:27:47.490 --> 00:27:49.990
We can assign permissions not
just on folders, but on files.

546
00:27:49.990 --> 00:27:52.550
It can be done on printers,
so who's allowed to print,

547
00:27:52.550 --> 00:27:56.770
who's not allowed to print, who can cut
to the front of the print queue line.

548
00:27:56.770 --> 00:27:59.060
And some of those are all
things that we can protect.

549
00:27:59.060 --> 00:28:01.500
You can even do things
like peripheral devices.

550
00:28:01.500 --> 00:28:07.590
You might have external hard drives or
USB ports that you wanna restrict.

551
00:28:07.590 --> 00:28:12.950
We can do things that are not an item but

552
00:28:12.950 --> 00:28:17.300
an action like who's allowed
to shut down the computer?

553
00:28:17.300 --> 00:28:19.550
Who's allowed to change the clock?

554
00:28:19.550 --> 00:28:21.640
We can set permissions on items like that.

555
00:28:21.640 --> 00:28:26.810
That's all part of creating access control
is defining who has access to what.

556
00:28:26.810 --> 00:28:31.140
But now that I've kind of defined it here,
it's kind of a pain to work with.

557
00:28:31.140 --> 00:28:32.320
Every time I hire an IT person,

558
00:28:32.320 --> 00:28:35.960
I've gotta go to all these different
places, these printers, these folders,

559
00:28:35.960 --> 00:28:41.510
these files, these actions and set those
permissions and that becomes a nightmare.

560
00:28:41.510 --> 00:28:47.900
So instead of doing it per person,
you should always do it based on a role.

561
00:28:47.900 --> 00:28:50.950
A role, what role does that
person perform in the company?

562
00:28:50.950 --> 00:28:52.700
So are they an accountant?

563
00:28:54.320 --> 00:28:55.002
Are they an HR?

564
00:28:55.002 --> 00:28:56.360
Are they an IT?

565
00:28:56.360 --> 00:29:00.510
Not who are they, what's their name,
but what do they do.

566
00:29:00.510 --> 00:29:01.030
What's their job?

567
00:29:02.090 --> 00:29:06.190
And when we know jobs you can start
assigning permissions based on that and

568
00:29:06.190 --> 00:29:07.770
it makes life so much easier.

569
00:29:07.770 --> 00:29:10.090
So for example, I was in the user section.

570
00:29:10.090 --> 00:29:16.480
I can go under groups and I'm gonna
create a group called IT Department.

571
00:29:16.480 --> 00:29:20.510
And any time I hire somebody in the IT
Department I will put them in this group.

572
00:29:20.510 --> 00:29:25.840
Right now it's empty so
I'm gonna add Wes, and myself, okay?

573
00:29:25.840 --> 00:29:28.180
So we're just gonna get
ourselves put in here.

574
00:29:28.180 --> 00:29:32.750
And then I'll create another
group called Human Resources.

575
00:29:32.750 --> 00:29:36.510
And anytime I hire somebody in
Human Resources, I can put them in here.

576
00:29:36.510 --> 00:29:40.860
So I'll add Jane, and
now she's in here, okay?

577
00:29:40.860 --> 00:29:42.360
And so I've created these groups.

578
00:29:42.360 --> 00:29:45.750
And you'll see where Microsoft has
created a bunch of groups already

579
00:29:45.750 --> 00:29:49.340
like the Backup Operator's group,
the Administrator's group,

580
00:29:49.340 --> 00:29:51.550
the Event Log Readers and so on.

581
00:29:51.550 --> 00:29:55.040
These are roles that people perform.

582
00:29:55.040 --> 00:29:57.740
What is your job responsibility?

583
00:29:57.740 --> 00:29:58.980
I work in the IT department.

584
00:29:58.980 --> 00:30:02.028
Or I'm an accountant, I'm in HR.

585
00:30:02.028 --> 00:30:07.790
And now when I create folders like this I
can go to that employee handbook folder

586
00:30:07.790 --> 00:30:12.020
and instead of giving permissions
to an individual person.

587
00:30:12.020 --> 00:30:16.000
I can take Jane out, so
I'm just gonna remove Jane.

588
00:30:16.000 --> 00:30:21.890
So we'll pull her right out of there and
I'm gonna add the Human Resources group.

589
00:30:23.300 --> 00:30:26.880
And when I add the human resources
group I can give the entire group

590
00:30:26.880 --> 00:30:28.850
modified permissions.

591
00:30:28.850 --> 00:30:31.620
And then I can go down to
network documentation or

592
00:30:31.620 --> 00:30:35.990
wherever and
I can assign that entire group.

593
00:30:35.990 --> 00:30:40.660
By doing that anytime I hire
a human resources person

594
00:30:40.660 --> 00:30:43.450
I can just put them in the HR group.

595
00:30:43.450 --> 00:30:47.720
And once they're in the HR group, they get
access to all the stuff that's out there.

596
00:30:47.720 --> 00:30:51.070
And I didn't have to go and modify each
individual folder or each printer,

597
00:30:51.070 --> 00:30:54.110
each action, each file,
each external device.

598
00:30:54.110 --> 00:30:56.580
I don't have to do that,
they're in the group.

599
00:30:56.580 --> 00:30:59.530
And if somebody gets a transfer,
maybe Jane really loves IT.

600
00:30:59.530 --> 00:31:03.590
And she gets tired of the HR circus and
says, hey I'm getting out and

601
00:31:03.590 --> 00:31:04.790
I'm gonna go take over the IT department.

602
00:31:04.790 --> 00:31:06.560
So now she's vice president of IT.

603
00:31:06.560 --> 00:31:08.980
Well she needs to get
access to all the IT stuff.

604
00:31:08.980 --> 00:31:12.550
I just move her from the HR group,
over to the IT group, and

605
00:31:12.550 --> 00:31:15.430
now she's our CIO or
whatever her title is.

606
00:31:15.430 --> 00:31:17.980
And she gets all that access, and
all I had to do was change her group.

607
00:31:17.980 --> 00:31:20.230
It makes management so much easier.

608
00:31:20.230 --> 00:31:21.760
>> Don, I've heard this term before.

609
00:31:21.760 --> 00:31:23.660
Maybe this is exactly what
you're explaining here,

610
00:31:23.660 --> 00:31:27.340
another acronym that I'll throw at you,
RBAC, role-based access control.

611
00:31:27.340 --> 00:31:28.330
Is that what this is?

612
00:31:28.330 --> 00:31:30.730
Is this a form of
role-based access control?

613
00:31:30.730 --> 00:31:32.930
>> Absolutely, yeah,
and we're doing groups.

614
00:31:32.930 --> 00:31:37.200
There's ways to do role-based access
control without using groups, and so

615
00:31:37.200 --> 00:31:38.590
that's why they had
the two different terms.

616
00:31:38.590 --> 00:31:41.450
You'll hear some people, like me,
where they'll say roles and

617
00:31:41.450 --> 00:31:43.050
groups interchangeably.

618
00:31:43.050 --> 00:31:46.490
But sometimes you have software
that defines a role and

619
00:31:46.490 --> 00:31:48.370
it's not an actual group
in the operating system.

620
00:31:48.370 --> 00:31:49.880
So that's where that separation is.

621
00:31:49.880 --> 00:31:52.100
The way I'm using it here, it's the same.

622
00:31:52.100 --> 00:31:53.420
Roles and groups are the same.

623
00:31:53.420 --> 00:31:56.580
I have a role for an employee,
you work in IT, and

624
00:31:56.580 --> 00:32:00.840
I have a group that corresponds to that
role, and so I'm using them the same.

625
00:32:00.840 --> 00:32:04.000
But they could be different,
I could have a role that was

626
00:32:07.070 --> 00:32:10.100
able to read the employee hand book.

627
00:32:10.100 --> 00:32:13.270
So I might create a group called
able to read the employee handbook.

628
00:32:13.270 --> 00:32:15.060
And I give that permissions.

629
00:32:15.060 --> 00:32:17.080
What's my role in the company,
what's my job.

630
00:32:17.080 --> 00:32:19.780
My job is not able to read
the employee handbook but

631
00:32:19.780 --> 00:32:22.970
I have a group called able to
create the employee handbook so

632
00:32:22.970 --> 00:32:26.040
that's where roles and groups start
to separate but I use them together.

633
00:32:26.040 --> 00:32:31.480
I might have ten different roles that are
all able to read the employee handbook,

634
00:32:31.480 --> 00:32:34.680
and at that point you're creating
what are called nested groups.

635
00:32:34.680 --> 00:32:39.080
A user will go into a group that
corresponds to their role, their role will

636
00:32:39.080 --> 00:32:43.850
go into another group that corresponds
to the permission that I'm giving them.

637
00:32:43.850 --> 00:32:46.440
And then that final group will get
permissions on the resource they're

638
00:32:46.440 --> 00:32:47.030
trying to access.

639
00:32:47.030 --> 00:32:49.290
So it's getting a little complex, right?

640
00:32:49.290 --> 00:32:52.690
But when you build it out that way,
it makes expandability and

641
00:32:52.690 --> 00:32:55.280
growth become trivial and easy.

642
00:32:55.280 --> 00:32:58.160
Managing permissions on a per
user basis is a nightmare.

643
00:32:58.160 --> 00:33:00.710
And if your company has more
than ten employees it gets to be

644
00:33:00.710 --> 00:33:02.940
really challenging and really frustrating.

645
00:33:02.940 --> 00:33:07.430
But if you're using groups and rolls
properly you could have tens of thousands

646
00:33:07.430 --> 00:33:11.160
of employees and be hiring and firing on
a daily basis and it's not a big deal.

647
00:33:11.160 --> 00:33:12.560
It's just really easy to move people in.

648
00:33:13.910 --> 00:33:17.120
All right, now I still have more
to talk about on permissions.

649
00:33:17.120 --> 00:33:20.830
We've been kind of focused on permissions
assigned right to a resource.

650
00:33:20.830 --> 00:33:24.210
I wanna talk about share permissions,
and permissions conflict

651
00:33:24.210 --> 00:33:26.840
which what Wes was asking about earlier,
but in a lot of time so

652
00:33:26.840 --> 00:33:30.840
what will do is we'll tackle those in
a part two, get a chance to see them.

653
00:33:30.840 --> 00:33:35.070
But what we seen right here in
part one is core fundamental

654
00:33:35.070 --> 00:33:39.750
process assigning permission, and
I did it Windows the same in Linux and

655
00:33:39.750 --> 00:33:43.680
Unix, same over Mac OS that
others process for doing this.

656
00:33:43.680 --> 00:33:46.008
But the steps might be little different,
but

657
00:33:46.008 --> 00:33:49.070
the theory of what you're
applying is the same.

658
00:33:49.070 --> 00:33:51.094
>> All right,
a lot of great information there, Don.

659
00:33:51.094 --> 00:33:53.460
Look forward to seeing you
back in there part two.

660
00:33:53.460 --> 00:33:56.260
However, as you've already mentioned,
time to wrap this one up.

661
00:33:56.260 --> 00:33:59.469
But before we do, got any final words that
you might like to impart to our viewers?

662
00:34:00.500 --> 00:34:03.080
>> It's usually gonna be faster to
assign permissions to a person if

663
00:34:03.080 --> 00:34:03.960
you're in a hurry.

664
00:34:03.960 --> 00:34:04.760
Don't make that mistake.

665
00:34:04.760 --> 00:34:07.870
Take the extra time, create the groups,
put the users in the groups.

666
00:34:07.870 --> 00:34:11.120
It'll save you a ton of time down
the road, it makes life so much easier.

667
00:34:11.120 --> 00:34:12.470
Definitely take the time to do it right.

668
00:34:12.470 --> 00:34:15.150
>> All right,
great words of wisdom from Don Pezet.

669
00:34:15.150 --> 00:34:16.942
Thanks for
being here in the studios with us Don, and

670
00:34:16.942 --> 00:34:18.460
thank you to the viewer
watching out there.

671
00:34:18.460 --> 00:34:21.900
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

672
00:34:21.900 --> 00:34:22.570
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

673
00:34:22.570 --> 00:34:23.670
>> And we'll see you next time.

674
00:34:23.670 --> 00:34:31.335
[MUSIC]

675
00:34:31.335 --> 00:34:35.840
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

00:23:34.500 --> 00:23:35.913
POP3 is not encrypted.

476
00:23:35.913 --> 00:23:40.686
When it's running on port 110,
it's unencrypted, and maybe we use POPS,

477
00:23:40.686 --> 00:23:44.340
where you're stuck on SSL,
right, or TLS on top of it.

478
00:23:44.340 --> 00:23:45.932
But it's not widely supported.

479
00:23:45.932 --> 00:23:48.439
It's kind of a clog that's just
been added after the fact, so

480
00:23:48.439 --> 00:23:51.400
maybe I say, you know what,
we're gonna run regular POP unencrypted.

481
00:23:51.400 --> 00:23:54.790
But we're gonna use IP sec to secure it,
and

482
00:23:54.790 --> 00:23:59.560
if the IP sec tunnel is up,
I'll allow you to connect via POP.

483
00:23:59.560 --> 00:24:02.074
But if the IPsec tunnel is down,
I won't allow you to connect,

484
00:24:02.074 --> 00:24:04.310
cuz I'm not gonna allow you

485
00:24:04.310 --> 00:24:07.070
It's a great way to secure protocols
that don't necessarily have encryption

486
00:24:07.070 --> 00:24:07.690
built into them.

487
00:24:07.690 --> 00:24:09.340
IPsec is wonderful for that.

488
00:24:09.340 --> 00:24:11.580
I'm gonna leave mine be, though.

489
00:24:11.580 --> 00:24:15.810
And then, we can specify in

00:24:15.810 --> 00:24:20.280

00:24:20.280 --> 00:24:24.310

492
00:24:24.310 --> 00:24:27.008
So here we have Domain,

00:24:27.008 --> 00:24:31.070

00:24:40.560 --> 00:24:42.120
And so, we can specify that here.

00:24:43.324 --> 00:24:44.650
And I can finish that up.

500
00:24:44.650 --> 00:24:48.940
This will be my Mail Server Rule or
whatever it is you wanna call it.

501
00:24:48.940 --> 00:24:53.550
Now, what I'm looking at
here is my Mail Server Rule,

00:24:53.550 --> 00:24:58.590
which is one access control entry, an ACE.

503
00:24:58.590 --> 00:25:02.980
In my access control list,
this huge list of all these

00:25:02.980 --> 00:25:08.350
different things that I'm allowing
through my server or blocking.

505
00:25:08.350 --> 00:25:11.326
Most of these are allowing, the gray ones
are rules that are actually turned off.

506
00:25:11.326 --> 00:25:13.530
And then, I didn't see any red circles.

507
00:25:13.530 --> 00:25:15.690
A red would be something
we're specifically blocking.

508
00:25:15.690 --> 00:25:19.440
So we can come through and punch these in
and we're securing our network access.

509
00:25:19.440 --> 00:25:20.550
Not a file, not a folder,

510
00:25:20.550 --> 00:25:24.170
not a printer, but network access
with this access control list.

511
00:25:24.170 --> 00:25:26.950
>> All right, Don, I got another acronym
floating around in my head here.

512
00:25:26.950 --> 00:25:29.940
And I'm gonna say RBAC, R-B-A-C, and
you're gonna say, well, wait Wes,

513
00:25:29.940 --> 00:25:31.820
in the first part part of this,
weren't you there?

514
00:25:31.820 --> 00:25:34.080
I thought I explained what
Role Based Access Control is.

515
00:25:34.080 --> 00:25:37.390
But fortunately we've got an acronym
that has more than one meaning.

516
00:25:37.390 --> 00:25:41.143
Is this an example of
Rule Based Access Control?

517
00:25:41.143 --> 00:25:42.631
>> Yeah, technically, it is.

518
00:25:42.631 --> 00:25:46.430
Yes, because we're defining a rule.

519
00:25:46.430 --> 00:25:50.350
A rule that states various
criteria that have to be met.

520
00:25:51.840 --> 00:25:54.930
There is a way we can configure this where
I don't use some of the advanced features,

521
00:25:54.930 --> 00:25:56.510
where it's not truly a rule anymore.

522
00:25:56.510 --> 00:26:00.140
Where it is really just
a particular match, and that's it.

523
00:26:00.140 --> 00:26:03.110
But if we use the various options and
we use it the way I just did it, and

524
00:26:03.110 --> 00:26:04.290
then yes, it is a rule.

525
00:26:04.290 --> 00:26:08.700
So we're creating a rule-based
access control list, and it's done.

526
00:26:10.140 --> 00:26:14.694
The big differentiator when we deal
with a typical ACLs or role-based access

527
00:26:14.694 --> 00:26:19.950
control and rule-based, is that
rule-based, the entire list applies.

528
00:26:19.950 --> 00:26:23.710
With role based, you kinda pick and
choose through the roles and

529
00:26:23.710 --> 00:26:25.490
combine them to create the best.

530
00:26:25.490 --> 00:26:27.792
You don't create the best with rule-based.

531
00:26:27.792 --> 00:26:31.970
With rule-based, you start at the top and
you work your way down to the bottom.

532
00:26:31.970 --> 00:26:36.290
So when a connection comes in to my
server, it looks at rule number one.

533
00:26:37.480 --> 00:26:40.970
And if rule number one matches,
it does whatever rule number one says, and

534
00:26:40.970 --> 00:26:42.660
then it stops.

535
00:26:42.660 --> 00:26:45.750
But if rule number one doesn't match, it
goes to rule two, and then rule three, and

536
00:26:45.750 --> 00:26:47.260
then rule four, and five, and

537
00:26:47.260 --> 00:26:52.380
continues down the list hitting each of
the other ones until it hits a match.

538
00:26:52.380 --> 00:26:55.490
The first match it finds is
the one that takes effect.

539
00:26:55.490 --> 00:26:56.450
And I gotta be careful with that,

540
00:26:56.450 --> 00:27:00.580
because if I put a rule in here,
that is a block rule.

541
00:27:00.580 --> 00:27:04.544
So I'm gonna come in here and
I'm gonna block a port and

542
00:27:04.544 --> 00:27:06.707
it's gonna be TCP Port 25.

543
00:27:06.707 --> 00:27:09.520
And I'm gonna tell it to
block the connection.

544
00:27:09.520 --> 00:27:11.860
So I've just defined that, Block SMTP.

545
00:27:11.860 --> 00:27:16.492
Now, I've got a rule here
that says Block SMTP, and

546
00:27:16.492 --> 00:27:21.142
right after it I've got
a rule that says allow SMTP.

547
00:27:21.142 --> 00:27:24.110
If you're from these IPs.

548
00:27:24.110 --> 00:27:30.771
Well, if it applies from the top down,
it hits the first rule and blocks SMTP.

549
00:27:30.771 --> 00:27:34.760
And that's it,
SMTP is not allowed no matter who you are.

550
00:27:34.760 --> 00:27:35.430
It's gonna be blocked.

551
00:27:36.670 --> 00:27:38.670
If it didn't match,
it would go to the second rule.

552
00:27:38.670 --> 00:27:41.210
So if it was POP3, it's coming in on 110,
it doesn't match the first rule,

553
00:27:41.210 --> 00:27:42.810
it goes to the second one.

554
00:27:42.810 --> 00:27:44.740
It's permitted, and it stops there.

555
00:27:44.740 --> 00:27:45.660
And it permits the traffic.

556
00:27:45.660 --> 00:27:47.550
It never gets to anything after.

557
00:27:47.550 --> 00:27:52.130
So with rule-based, we've really got to
pay attention to the order of our entries.

558
00:27:52.130 --> 00:27:56.150
With regular ACLs that are just role
based like what we saw in the finals.

559
00:27:56.150 --> 00:27:57.070
But order doesn't matter.

560
00:27:57.070 --> 00:27:59.690
I don't care if Wes is first on
the list or last on the list.

561
00:27:59.690 --> 00:28:02.060
When it checks his permission,
it looks for Wes.

562
00:28:02.060 --> 00:28:03.690
And it finds him anywhere on the list.

563
00:28:03.690 --> 00:28:06.040
And then, it looks for the groups that
he's in, and it finds those two and

564
00:28:06.040 --> 00:28:07.100
combines them all together.

565
00:28:07.100 --> 00:28:07.970
All that magic.

566
00:28:07.970 --> 00:28:08.720
That doesn't happen here.

567
00:28:08.720 --> 00:28:10.550
These are much more simple.

568
00:28:10.550 --> 00:28:12.400
And implied very, very literally.

569
00:28:12.400 --> 00:28:15.670
So you do have to pay attention to
the order these things are in and

570
00:28:15.670 --> 00:28:19.250
that you've created them in
a method that makes sense.

571
00:28:19.250 --> 00:28:21.850
And when I talk about the order,
I'm on a Windows Server,

572
00:28:21.850 --> 00:28:24.420
which is a really bad
place to show this cuz you

573
00:28:24.420 --> 00:28:27.400
can change the order sort of
alphabetically by name and stuff.

574
00:28:27.400 --> 00:28:31.440
But on a CISCO router or on a Juniper
router, we would actually be able to move

575
00:28:31.440 --> 00:28:35.520
the rules up, and
down to change that order and apply it.

576
00:28:35.520 --> 00:28:38.680
On a Windows Server, the best place is
that it would be in a policy module which

577
00:28:38.680 --> 00:28:40.580
I don't think I have
installed on this server.

578
00:28:40.580 --> 00:28:42.271
Yeah, I don't.

579
00:28:42.271 --> 00:28:45.760
I've got a little security too,
that's not what I want.

580
00:28:45.760 --> 00:28:46.880
But you can actually go in there and

581
00:28:46.880 --> 00:28:48.620
you can change like if you
have a remote access server,

582
00:28:48.620 --> 00:28:50.890
you can change the order of the rules.

583
00:28:50.890 --> 00:28:54.680
And that's why I hesitated to say that
this is role-based, is that it can be when

584
00:28:54.680 --> 00:28:59.090
it's applied properly but
the way it is here, it can also not be.

585
00:28:59.090 --> 00:29:00.210
It's a bit of a mix.

586
00:29:00.210 --> 00:29:04.043
But that's kinda the difference
with role-based access control.

587
00:29:04.043 --> 00:29:07.490
I think that pretty much wraps
up our access control list.

588
00:29:07.490 --> 00:29:09.620
Key thing to remember on this is,

589
00:29:09.620 --> 00:29:12.640
we've gotta be careful to
keep these things maintained.

590
00:29:12.640 --> 00:29:17.340
That you might have it setup perfectly
on day 1 and then on day 500,

591
00:29:17.340 --> 00:29:19.590
things are just completely holds up.

592
00:29:19.590 --> 00:29:21.780
And permission has been thrown
about it and messed up.

593
00:29:21.780 --> 00:29:23.640
So you gotta constantly
maintain a stand up.

594
00:29:23.640 --> 00:29:26.780
You got to do audits and
make sure everything is in place.

595
00:29:26.780 --> 00:29:31.420
The other thing is you can confuse
what we've done here with some other

596
00:29:31.420 --> 00:29:33.890
technologies that are don't
actually provide security.

597
00:29:33.890 --> 00:29:37.620
So for example, the groups that I've been
creating, those are security groups.

598
00:29:37.620 --> 00:29:39.770
Security groups are designed for
permissions.

599
00:29:39.770 --> 00:29:41.580
There's also distribution groups.

600
00:29:41.580 --> 00:29:43.770
And I don't think it gave me
that option when I made it.

601
00:29:43.770 --> 00:29:45.420
Let's see if I even had that option.

602
00:29:45.420 --> 00:29:47.840
When you make a group here,
it's just creating a group.

603
00:29:47.840 --> 00:29:50.850
But if I was in the Microsoft Active
Directory, when you create a group,

604
00:29:50.850 --> 00:29:53.470
you can create a security group or
a distribution group.

605
00:29:53.470 --> 00:29:54.660
They both hold user accounts.

606
00:29:54.660 --> 00:29:55.480
You put user accounts in.

607
00:29:55.480 --> 00:29:56.500
It's great.

608
00:29:56.500 --> 00:30:00.290
But a distribution group can't be used for
permissions.

609
00:30:00.290 --> 00:30:03.750
You can't assign permissions to
one of those, their designed for

610
00:30:03.750 --> 00:30:05.388
email or things like that.

611
00:30:05.388 --> 00:30:07.960
If I wanna communicate to a group of
people, I put them in a distribution

612
00:30:07.960 --> 00:30:11.590
group, and I can send an email to that
group and the email goes to all of them.

613
00:30:11.590 --> 00:30:13.750
Is that access control?

614
00:30:13.750 --> 00:30:15.430
No, I sort of.

615
00:30:15.430 --> 00:30:17.200
It's who's gonna get that email.

616
00:30:17.200 --> 00:30:20.070
But you can just add somebody to
the CC line, and that solves that.

617
00:30:20.070 --> 00:30:21.450
And then, they get the email.

618
00:30:21.450 --> 00:30:26.200
So distribution groups and groups of
that nature, don't provide security.

619
00:30:26.200 --> 00:30:29.350
Security groups,
ones that you can assign permissions to.

620
00:30:29.350 --> 00:30:32.610
Those are ones that provide security and
can be used in access control lists.

621
00:30:32.610 --> 00:30:34.030
So don't get confused on that.

622
00:30:34.030 --> 00:30:36.168
It is easy to mix them up.

623
00:30:36.168 --> 00:30:39.560
>> All right, Don, well, thank you for
rounding up our topics here, does look

624
00:30:39.560 --> 00:30:43.732
like we're coming to the end of another
episode, but are we truly done here?

625
00:30:43.732 --> 00:30:46.420
We gotta give you a chance, Don,
you have any additional words,

626
00:30:46.420 --> 00:30:50.750
maybe you like to give our viewers when
it comes to logical access control.

627
00:30:50.750 --> 00:30:54.790
>> I focus on Windows in these last two
episodes because that was on the exam, but

628
00:30:54.790 --> 00:30:59.090
in real life you gonna have far more
service running Linux than Windows and so

629
00:30:59.090 --> 00:31:00.720
make sure you're familiar with it there.

630
00:31:00.720 --> 00:31:04.300
In the Unix environment, permissions are
done a little bit different because you

631
00:31:04.300 --> 00:31:07.980
have one user, one group, and
then everyone else who has access.

00:31:07.980 --> 00:31:11.230
So to manage it because you only have
one group tied to a file folder,

633
00:31:11.230 --> 00:31:13.288
you're going to have to do nesting.

634
00:31:13.288 --> 00:31:16.140
You gonna have the nest groups together to
get permission set that the way you want

635
00:31:16.140 --> 00:31:17.290
in the Unix world.

636
00:31:17.290 --> 00:31:18.170
Same goes for Mac OS,

637
00:31:18.170 --> 00:31:20.720
although they do have some extended

638
00:31:20.720 --> 00:31:23.680
So pay attention to your operating system,
understand

639
00:31:23.680 --> 00:31:26.720
that it might be a little different, but
the fundamentals in theory, identical.

640
00:31:26.720 --> 00:31:31.630
It's the same rule that you wanna make
sure you do the principle of least

641
00:31:31.630 --> 00:31:35.450
privilege, give people as minimum access
as they need to get their job done, and

642
00:31:35.450 --> 00:31:37.880
make sure that you maintain and
document it.

643
00:31:37.880 --> 00:31:40.460
>> All right, Don, it's been
a pleasure having you in the studios.

644
00:31:40.460 --> 00:31:42.590
And it's been a pleasure having
you the viewer watching.

645
00:31:42.590 --> 00:31:45.610
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

646
00:31:45.610 --> 00:31:46.290
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

647
00:31:46.290 --> 00:31:47.567
>> And we'll see you next time.

502
00:25:10.290 --> 00:25:12.170
So it's not even an option for us.

503
00:25:12.170 --> 00:25:14.780
There's no way for
us to get a second grid here.

504
00:25:14.780 --> 00:25:18.580
And that's where generators and
UPSs become that much more

505
00:25:18.580 --> 00:25:20.810
important if you don't have the option for
a second grid.

506
00:25:20.810 --> 00:25:24.350
If you have a second grid and
one goes down, the second one's still up.

507
00:25:24.350 --> 00:25:28.070
And you might not even need generators and
UPSs.

508
00:25:28.070 --> 00:25:29.360
You probably need UPSs though,

509
00:25:29.360 --> 00:25:33.480
just to handle the flip over to the other
grid because that does take a moment.

510
00:25:33.480 --> 00:25:35.260
But there's ways around that.

511
00:25:35.260 --> 00:25:36.960
We're gonna talk about PDUs.

512
00:25:36.960 --> 00:25:39.970
And you can actually have PDUs where they
were running the two separate grids and

513
00:25:39.970 --> 00:25:41.086
really get rid there.

514
00:25:41.086 --> 00:25:43.180
And you wouldn't even need to
worry about UPSs at that point.

515
00:25:43.180 --> 00:25:45.960
But we're talking about costs that
are really skyrocketing here.

516
00:25:45.960 --> 00:25:50.880
So we're really at military levels
when you start talking about

517
00:25:50.880 --> 00:25:52.480
that level of redundancy.

518
00:25:52.480 --> 00:25:54.450
It's just not something
available to most people, and

519
00:25:54.450 --> 00:25:58.060
that's where UPS's combined with
generators become that proper solution.

520
00:25:58.060 --> 00:26:00.410
>> All right, Don,
well I'm looking at our objectives here.

521
00:26:00.410 --> 00:26:01.780
I know that we do have more.

522
00:26:01.780 --> 00:26:04.830
You've already heard Don mention it,
but looks like we're gonna go ahead and

523
00:26:04.830 --> 00:26:05.860
go into a part two.

524
00:26:05.860 --> 00:26:09.450
Don, before we do, do you have any
additional words of caution, maybe?

525
00:26:09.450 --> 00:26:11.490
I know we've been talking
about electricity.

526
00:26:11.490 --> 00:26:14.220
Or any additional words you
might like to tell our viewers.

527
00:26:14.220 --> 00:26:15.640
>> All right, the maintenance.

528
00:26:15.640 --> 00:26:17.320
I mentioned maintenance on batteries,

529
00:26:17.320 --> 00:26:20.560
that you've got to properly test
the batteries every so often.

530
00:26:20.560 --> 00:26:22.210
You've got to do the same
thing with generators.

531
00:26:22.210 --> 00:26:23.510
Even more important with generators,

532
00:26:23.510 --> 00:26:26.970
because if they're diesel,
the diesel fuel can gel in the tanks and

533
00:26:26.970 --> 00:26:30.580
it can actually clog the engine and stop
it from working right when you need it.

534
00:26:30.580 --> 00:26:32.000
So you don't want that to happen.

535
00:26:32.000 --> 00:26:34.720
Definitely make sure you
got maintenance there.

536
00:26:34.720 --> 00:26:39.590
Also you need to be tracking the power
consumption of your servers.

537
00:26:39.590 --> 00:26:42.620
As you add more servers, as you add
more equipment into the servers,

538
00:26:42.620 --> 00:26:44.990
that's gonna increase their
load that they generate.

539
00:26:44.990 --> 00:26:46.950
And you've gotta make
sure that your ups' and

540
00:26:46.950 --> 00:26:48.730
your generator's are able to handle that.

541
00:26:48.730 --> 00:26:53.070
So over time, you might have a project
where you need to deploy ten more servers.

542
00:26:53.070 --> 00:26:55.690
And you find their maximum load and
you run it against your system, and

543
00:26:55.690 --> 00:26:59.100
you find out where ooh,
we don't have enough power for that.

544
00:26:59.100 --> 00:27:03.770
So now it's not a matter of just buying
ten servers, you've gotta buy additional

545
00:27:03.770 --> 00:27:08.070
generators or additional UPS units,
batteries or whatever, to power that.

546
00:27:08.070 --> 00:27:11.180
And so it needs to become part of your
cost calculation for every project.

547
00:27:11.180 --> 00:27:15.880
I've seen many projects go over budget
because they didn't take power and

548
00:27:15.880 --> 00:27:17.230
cooling into consideration.

549
00:27:17.230 --> 00:27:18.890
Because you've gotta have AC units,

550
00:27:18.890 --> 00:27:20.910
they're cooling the heat
these systems generate.

551
00:27:20.910 --> 00:27:23.880
So paying attention to the BTUs,
the heat they generate,

552
00:27:23.880 --> 00:27:29.510
as well as the power consumption
are gonna be key and critical things.

553
00:27:29.510 --> 00:27:30.140
Allright, Don.

554
00:27:30.140 --> 00:27:32.660
Well, we appreciate you being
here in the studios with us and

555
00:27:32.660 --> 00:27:34.640
we appreciate you the viewer watching.

556
00:27:34.640 --> 00:27:36.640
We're going to go ahead and
sign of for IT ProTV.

557
00:27:36.640 --> 00:27:39.150
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

558
00:27:39.150 --> 00:27:39.870
>> And I'm Don Pazzete.

559
00:27:39.870 --> 00:27:40.750
>> And we'll see you next time.

560
00:27:40.750 --> 00:27:48.856
[MUSIC]

561
00:27:48.856 --> 00:27:50.137
>> Thank you for watching.

562
00:27:50.137 --> 00:27:50.637
ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their exploration of various power concepts related to environmental controls. They explain power distribution units or PDUs and the characteristics associated with them such as PDU ratings, UPS ratings, total potential draw and redundancy considerations through multiple circuits.
episodes.title: Environmental Controls Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:03.453
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.453 --> 00:00:06.424
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.424 --> 00:00:08.249
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.249 --> 00:00:11.058
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.058 --> 00:00:14.460
>> Welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.460 --> 00:00:19.330
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and
in today's episode we are continuing

7
00:00:19.330 --> 00:00:23.070
through our CompTIA Server+
SK0004 Certification course.

8
00:00:23.070 --> 00:00:26.430
And we're coming back with a part
two on environmental controls.

9
00:00:26.430 --> 00:00:30.428
And Don's here to lend his expertise
on hugging the environment.

10
00:00:30.428 --> 00:00:32.210
>> [LAUGH] That's right.

11
00:00:32.210 --> 00:00:34.980
In this episode, we're gonna be
talking a little bit more about power.

12
00:00:34.980 --> 00:00:39.210
And in part one, we talked about UPSs, all
right, uninterruptible power supplies and

13
00:00:39.210 --> 00:00:39.750
batteries.

14
00:00:39.750 --> 00:00:42.340
We talked a little bit about
generators and how they work.

15
00:00:42.340 --> 00:00:45.540
Well, that was getting
power into our building.

16
00:00:45.540 --> 00:00:49.430
Now we actually need to
get power to the servers.

17
00:00:49.430 --> 00:00:51.530
And what we need to do that
is what's called a PDU,

18
00:00:51.530 --> 00:00:53.840
or a Power Distribution Unit.

19
00:00:53.840 --> 00:00:58.005
Now Power Distribution Units, I mean
it sounds like a technical term, and

20
00:00:58.005 --> 00:00:59.315
it's all advanced and stuff, a PDU.

21
00:00:59.315 --> 00:01:02.465
But what we're really talking
about are power strips.

22
00:01:02.465 --> 00:01:05.735
And most of us have power strips
under our desk, in our homes,

23
00:01:05.735 --> 00:01:07.235
under our dressers, whatever.

24
00:01:07.235 --> 00:01:11.015
Where we take one outlet on the wall and
we run it to a power strip,

25
00:01:11.015 --> 00:01:14.305
where it now becomes six outlets, or eight
outlets, and you can provide power for

26
00:01:14.305 --> 00:01:16.290
all your little gadgets and devices.

27
00:01:16.290 --> 00:01:21.200
Well, we use the same things in server
rooms, except it's not exactly the same.

28
00:01:21.200 --> 00:01:26.860
A regular power strip like what you'd buy
at the store is not really very powerful.

29
00:01:26.860 --> 00:01:29.135
I mean it might say it's
a surge suppressor and

30
00:01:29.135 --> 00:01:31.130
has all this crazy magic and stuff in it.

31
00:01:31.130 --> 00:01:34.670
But at the end of the day,
it's taking the power from one outlet.

32
00:01:34.670 --> 00:01:38.960
And then, evenly distributing it across
the other outlets, so that one device

33
00:01:38.960 --> 00:01:43.590
could draw too much power and effect
other devices that are on the same link.

34
00:01:43.590 --> 00:01:46.180
And they're not really designed
to push too much power at all.

35
00:01:46.180 --> 00:01:49.500
Here in the United States, when you
go to the store to buy a power strip,

36
00:01:49.500 --> 00:01:52.630
they're all going to be 120 volt, right.

37
00:01:52.630 --> 00:01:56.580
You're not gonna find ones
that are 240 at the store.

38
00:01:56.580 --> 00:01:58.760
They just, they don't sell those.

39
00:01:58.760 --> 00:02:02.730
So when we get into a server room,
and I have a bunch of servers that

40
00:02:02.730 --> 00:02:06.650
are all expecting 240, I can't just
use a regular all power strip.

41
00:02:06.650 --> 00:02:07.890
I wouldn't want to anyway, right.

42
00:02:07.890 --> 00:02:13.590
We need stuff that designed for the data
center, that is designed for higher levels

43
00:02:13.590 --> 00:02:17.610
of power over longer periods of time,
higher levels of amperage or current.

44
00:02:17.610 --> 00:02:20.380
So that they can handle that
without it catching on fire.

45
00:02:20.380 --> 00:02:24.110
And that are better able to manage the
different workloads that we provide to it.

46
00:02:24.110 --> 00:02:27.790
For example, I might have 208
power going into the strip.

47
00:02:27.790 --> 00:02:29.880
And then the strip is providing 120 or

48
00:02:29.880 --> 00:02:33.040
240 out to the nodes that
are plugged into it, right?

49
00:02:33.040 --> 00:02:36.710
So the strip may actually be
converting the type of electricity.

50
00:02:36.710 --> 00:02:39.810
And that means these power
strips that I'm talking about

51
00:02:39.810 --> 00:02:43.250
are very different than
what we're used to seeing.

52
00:02:43.250 --> 00:02:44.540
So let's start with some simple ones,

53
00:02:44.540 --> 00:02:47.710
then I'll get to some more advanced
ones as the episode goes on.

54
00:02:47.710 --> 00:02:53.690
On the simple side, at a minimum, we need
our power strips to be rack mountable.

55
00:02:53.690 --> 00:02:55.290
You have racks in your data center.

56
00:02:55.290 --> 00:02:58.350
And so these power strips, you don't
want them just laying on the floor.

57
00:02:58.350 --> 00:02:59.818
They need to be rack mounted.

58
00:02:59.818 --> 00:03:04.661
Now, key thing to be aware of here with
power strips is that usually you will have

59
00:03:04.661 --> 00:03:06.270
a fire code for your area.

60
00:03:06.270 --> 00:03:10.010
And your fire code will dictate how many
of these power strips you could have.

61
00:03:10.010 --> 00:03:12.690
For example, I've seen people
where they daisy chain PDUs.

62
00:03:12.690 --> 00:03:15.100
And you're not allowed to do that.

63
00:03:15.100 --> 00:03:18.130
A PDU has to directly plug into an outlet.

64
00:03:18.130 --> 00:03:21.110
Well if you have a data center
with hundreds of racks,

65
00:03:21.110 --> 00:03:23.180
that means you're going to
need hundreds of outlets.

66
00:03:23.180 --> 00:03:27.950
You're going to need a certified
electrician to put outlets by each rack.

67
00:03:27.950 --> 00:03:29.800
When you look at the racks behind me,

68
00:03:29.800 --> 00:03:35.580
there is actually a set of outlets at the
bottom on the ground underneath each rack.

69
00:03:35.580 --> 00:03:40.240
And so the PDUs that are in that rack
plug right into the outlets right there.

70
00:03:40.240 --> 00:03:45.210
They're not daisy chained or linked
because that, well, first off, it further

71
00:03:45.210 --> 00:03:48.340
distributes out the power, and weakens
the amount of power that you can provide.

72
00:03:48.340 --> 00:03:50.570
And then secondly, it's a fire hazard.

73
00:03:50.570 --> 00:03:52.360
It could potentially catch on fire.

74
00:03:52.360 --> 00:03:54.540
And fires in a data center are really bad.

75
00:03:54.540 --> 00:03:57.620
We're gonna talk about fire control,
maybe in this episode,

76
00:03:57.620 --> 00:04:00.190
probably in part three, but
we'll get to fire control, too.

77
00:04:01.300 --> 00:04:05.277
But on the PDU side of things, these are
going to need to plug into actual outlets.

78
00:04:05.277 --> 00:04:09.868
And so when you buy PDUs for a server
room, unlike the little power strips you

79
00:04:09.868 --> 00:04:14.060
get at home that might have a 3 foot or
a one meter cord on them.

80
00:04:14.060 --> 00:04:16.910
These are usually gonna have 25 or
30 foot cords on them,

81
00:04:16.910 --> 00:04:20.930
because they're designed to run to
outlets that might be further away.

82
00:04:20.930 --> 00:04:23.240
And some of them don't
even come with cords.

83
00:04:23.240 --> 00:04:24.980
They expect an electrician to come in and

84
00:04:24.980 --> 00:04:28.210
custom cut the cord to fit
the environment that you need.

85
00:04:28.210 --> 00:04:30.050
That is very common also.

86
00:04:30.050 --> 00:04:33.850
So just be aware that there's different
levels of power distribution units

87
00:04:33.850 --> 00:04:34.780
that are out there.

88
00:04:34.780 --> 00:04:38.570
And some of them have really impressive
technology built right into them.

89
00:04:38.570 --> 00:04:39.560
Some are very basic.

90
00:04:39.560 --> 00:04:40.950
So let's start with a basic one.

91
00:04:40.950 --> 00:04:42.880
I've actually got a couple
laying on the floor here.

92
00:04:42.880 --> 00:04:43.909
I'm gonna grab a small one.

93
00:04:45.070 --> 00:04:45.942
And bring this one up.

94
00:04:45.942 --> 00:04:49.626
Now, this small one as
I dash off camera here,

95
00:04:49.626 --> 00:04:54.742
this small one is designed for
a standard 120 volt workload.

96
00:04:54.742 --> 00:04:59.372
Like what you would see in a just
a regular office shop server or laptop,

97
00:04:59.372 --> 00:05:02.550
any kind of electronic
device router switches.

98
00:05:02.550 --> 00:05:05.970
A lot of them are all designed
to receive 110 or 120 outlet so

99
00:05:05.970 --> 00:05:08.630
that's what this provides.

100
00:05:08.630 --> 00:05:12.770
And if you look across the front, what I'm
seeing are a bunch of, these are standard

101
00:05:12.770 --> 00:05:16.990
grounded NEMA 15 outlets, which is what
we use here in the US or NEMA 5-15.

102
00:05:16.990 --> 00:05:19.406
So I see all those outlets.

103
00:05:19.406 --> 00:05:22.670
I can see that it's providing some
surge suppression or whatever,

104
00:05:22.670 --> 00:05:26.462
which we don't worry so much about surge
suppression inside of a data center.

105
00:05:26.462 --> 00:05:29.642
Because these PDUs are not normally
plugged directly into wall power,

106
00:05:29.642 --> 00:05:31.790
they're normally plugged into UPS's.

107
00:05:31.790 --> 00:05:34.350
And the UPS's do all the power
conditioning for us so

108
00:05:34.350 --> 00:05:35.850
we don't get surges.

109
00:05:35.850 --> 00:05:37.360
So when you buy these,

110
00:05:37.360 --> 00:05:41.090
you might be thinking your home equipment
where I need a surge suppressor.

111
00:05:41.090 --> 00:05:42.610
But in your data center, you really don't,

112
00:05:42.610 --> 00:05:45.590
because your power conditioning should
already be happening at the UPSs.

113
00:05:45.590 --> 00:05:49.220
The UPSs act as the surge suppression for
you.

114
00:05:49.220 --> 00:05:51.720
Has got a power switch,
if I point to the right side over here.

115
00:05:51.720 --> 00:05:53.910
And see how it's got
this plastic cover on it.

116
00:05:53.910 --> 00:05:57.350
You'll see that pretty often where there's
a plastic cover on the power switches.

117
00:05:57.350 --> 00:06:01.450
Because they want to prevent you from
accidentally powering it off and

118
00:06:01.450 --> 00:06:02.630
knocking the whole strip out.

119
00:06:02.630 --> 00:06:04.020
So we've got that.

120
00:06:04.020 --> 00:06:06.560
If we look on the back side,
let's switch over to our sky cam, so

121
00:06:06.560 --> 00:06:08.340
we can kind of see this a little better.

122
00:06:08.340 --> 00:06:09.623
So I was just showing you the front side.

123
00:06:09.623 --> 00:06:13.100
We saw all these outlets and
the power switch and so on.

124
00:06:13.100 --> 00:06:16.110
On the back side, I've got another
set of outlets, all right?

125
00:06:16.110 --> 00:06:18.942
Now why two sets of outlets on this thing?

126
00:06:18.942 --> 00:06:22.500
Well, it's rack mountable,
so it's got rack ears.

127
00:06:22.500 --> 00:06:25.920
And when I mount it in the rack, this
is gonna be pointing either forwards or

128
00:06:25.920 --> 00:06:27.800
backwards, depending on how I mount it.

129
00:06:27.800 --> 00:06:32.180
So anything that needs a power
outlet on the front would have it.

130
00:06:32.180 --> 00:06:34.400
But what about the stuff that's behind it?

131
00:06:34.400 --> 00:06:37.700
I would have to run the cable out and
loop behind it, which is a pain.

132
00:06:37.700 --> 00:06:41.340
So this one actually has outlets on
both sides to be able to provide that.

133
00:06:41.340 --> 00:06:46.600
Now this is a horizontal PDU,
a horizontal power distribution unit.

134
00:06:46.600 --> 00:06:49.910
And so it goes into the rack sideways,
horizontally.

135
00:06:49.910 --> 00:06:51.054
And we've said this before,

136
00:06:51.054 --> 00:06:53.720
that when you have something like
this it's measured in rack units.

137
00:06:53.720 --> 00:06:57.320
So this is one rack unit or
1.75 inches tall.

138
00:06:57.320 --> 00:07:00.720
And it's 19 inches wide because
that's the standard rack width

139
00:07:00.720 --> 00:07:02.780
that we see in computer racks.

140
00:07:02.780 --> 00:07:06.230
You can only get so
many outlets in 19 inches.

141
00:07:06.230 --> 00:07:08.730
If I needed more,
it might have to go to 2U or

142
00:07:08.730 --> 00:07:10.760
even 3U to provide the extra outlets.

143
00:07:10.760 --> 00:07:15.180
Or, they stick the outlets on the back
side, and that's what you see here.

144
00:07:15.180 --> 00:07:18.197
Now, these are typical 3 prong outlets.

145
00:07:18.197 --> 00:07:20.829
A lot of times,
you'll see a slightly different plug,

146
00:07:20.829 --> 00:07:23.242
which I'll show some pictures
of here in a moment.

147
00:07:23.242 --> 00:07:28.070
Where it is, instead of a female connector
like this, it's a male connector.

148
00:07:28.070 --> 00:07:30.160
And it's the opposite end of a d plug,

149
00:07:30.160 --> 00:07:31.870
what you'd see in the power
supply of a computer.

150
00:07:31.870 --> 00:07:33.240
And you'll pop those in.

151
00:07:33.240 --> 00:07:35.460
They'll take a slightly different cable.

152
00:07:35.460 --> 00:07:38.333
Those are a little more
resistant to coming loose.

153
00:07:38.333 --> 00:07:42.347
Three prong connections like these can
wiggle, they can come loose and fall out,

154
00:07:42.347 --> 00:07:43.850
and now you lose power.

155
00:07:43.850 --> 00:07:47.680
The other connectors they pop in and
they hold a little tighter.

156
00:07:47.680 --> 00:07:51.850
They have that big around the outside
that kind of locks them in place.

157
00:07:51.850 --> 00:07:53.720
I'll show you guys
a picture in a little bit.

158
00:07:53.720 --> 00:07:55.957
But this is an example
of a horizontal PDU.

159
00:07:55.957 --> 00:07:58.639
These are pretty cheap and
not particularly special.

160
00:07:58.639 --> 00:08:02.394
This is probably the lowest end of
a PDU that you'd see in a server rack.

161
00:08:02.394 --> 00:08:06.113
Cuz all it's really doing Is
taking that single connection,

162
00:08:06.113 --> 00:08:11.160
usually 120 in this case and
then popping it out into multiple outlets.

163
00:08:11.160 --> 00:08:14.270
Whatever amps I'm pulling in on this

164
00:08:14.270 --> 00:08:18.180
is the maximum amount of amps that
I can put out on all these ports.

165
00:08:18.180 --> 00:08:23.610
So even though I've got, what do I have
here, 10, 11, 12, 12 outlets, so even

166
00:08:23.610 --> 00:08:27.840
though I've got 12 outlets, that doesn't
