00:20:28.568 --> 00:20:32.331
both power supplies were plugged into
the same circuit and the circuit trips,

389
00:20:32.331 --> 00:20:33.944
both power supplies go offline.

390
00:20:33.944 --> 00:20:35.475
If I have a UPS they can power it, but

391
00:20:35.475 --> 00:20:37.940
if the UPS goes offline I might
have my own problem there.

392
00:20:37.940 --> 00:20:40.073
And if they run to a generator and
the generator fails to start,

393
00:20:40.073 --> 00:20:41.640
I could have my own problem there.

394
00:20:41.640 --> 00:20:46.850
So if I want true full redundancy,
what we'd probably do is have

395
00:20:46.850 --> 00:20:51.885
two generators, run to two different UPSs,
run to two different sets of circuits,

396
00:20:51.885 --> 00:20:54.810
cuz you have many, many circuits, that
are then run throughout the data center.

397
00:20:54.810 --> 00:20:58.110
And in each rack, instead of
having one big PDU like this one,

398
00:20:58.110 --> 00:21:00.140
let me just take it back out.

399
00:21:00.140 --> 00:21:04.979
Instead of having one big PDU,
you'll get multiple smaller PDUs.

400
00:21:06.430 --> 00:21:11.650
And you'll come in and just rack those,
right inside of the rack,

401
00:21:11.650 --> 00:21:13.170
one on each side.

402
00:21:13.170 --> 00:21:17.430
And as you plug your servers in,
you can just take those servers and

403
00:21:17.430 --> 00:21:22.300
run one power supply to the left, and
the other power supply to the right.

404
00:21:22.300 --> 00:21:25.070
And now they're on two different circuits,
two different UPSs,

405
00:21:25.070 --> 00:21:25.900
two different generators.

406
00:21:25.900 --> 00:21:29.110
If you've got two different power grids,
these could be two different power grids.

407
00:21:29.110 --> 00:21:33.022
One could be whoever your local power
provider is, Con Ed or whoever it is.

408
00:21:33.022 --> 00:21:37.310
And then,
some other power providers in your area.

409
00:21:37.310 --> 00:21:39.940
I don't know that many power
providers to choose from.

410
00:21:39.940 --> 00:21:43.266
We have GRU here and
maybe, Clay Cooperative or

411
00:21:43.266 --> 00:21:45.518
whatever and that's about it.

412
00:21:45.518 --> 00:21:49.825
So you could actually have that divided up
and now your cost is obviously climbing as

413
00:21:49.825 --> 00:21:54.150
you install this infrastructure but that's
how you get that through redundancy.

414
00:21:54.150 --> 00:21:58.280
How you get the ability to balance
the higher workloads that your

415
00:21:58.280 --> 00:21:59.820
servers may well need.

416
00:21:59.820 --> 00:22:03.507
And by having this mounted in the racks
basically inside in the side panels,

417
00:22:03.507 --> 00:22:05.300
that'll take any space.

418
00:22:05.300 --> 00:22:09.800
You can still fill up all the server
slots, all the rack units here are still

419
00:22:09.800 --> 00:22:16.120
available, and we can go in and really
maximize what we're capable of doing.

420
00:22:16.120 --> 00:22:20.280
And here you'll see,
still have multiple phases.

421
00:22:20.280 --> 00:22:24.828
So we can get additional current provided
into them to power our servers and

422
00:22:24.828 --> 00:22:26.426
really power things out.

423
00:22:26.426 --> 00:22:29.884
So just understand that a lot goes
into the decision of PDUs and

424
00:22:29.884 --> 00:22:33.556
which ones we're gonna use and
how we're gonna implement them.

425
00:22:33.556 --> 00:22:37.880
I think I talked about most
of what I wanted to go on.

426
00:22:37.880 --> 00:22:39.400
I did call out APC and

427
00:22:39.400 --> 00:22:43.180
Tripp Lite specifically just cuz those
are two really big names in power.

428
00:22:43.180 --> 00:22:46.570
But there's plenty of other
vendors out there that make them.

429
00:22:46.570 --> 00:22:53.739
Just be aware that PDUs when we buy them,
we typically expect them to last forever.

430
00:22:53.739 --> 00:22:57.950
It's not like they wear down
like a hard drive or whatever.

431
00:22:57.950 --> 00:23:01.990
But you do still need to do some basic
maintenance on them just as far as testing

432
00:23:01.990 --> 00:23:02.559
them out.

433
00:23:02.559 --> 00:23:05.782
A lot of people will take a multi meter,
however you wanna say it, and

434
00:23:05.782 --> 00:23:09.503
just test the outlets from time to time
to make sure that you're getting the full

435
00:23:09.503 --> 00:23:11.415
capabilities those outlets provided.

436
00:23:11.415 --> 00:23:14.560
It's a good idea to check but
typically they don't fail.

437
00:23:14.560 --> 00:23:17.817
There's not really all that
much to a PDU that can fail.

438
00:23:17.817 --> 00:23:20.563
Some have fuses built into them and
the fuses can blow and

439
00:23:20.563 --> 00:23:22.030
you might have to replace it.

440
00:23:22.030 --> 00:23:24.170
This one does have fuses beside me.

441
00:23:24.170 --> 00:23:25.840
But, again,

442
00:23:25.840 --> 00:23:28.640
in a normal environment that's not
really gonna be a problem that we have.

443
00:23:28.640 --> 00:23:31.190
>> Yeah, Don, we've been talking a lot
about electricity and one thing that we

444
00:23:31.190 --> 00:23:34.750
haven't talked about and maybe you
can help me out on this is grounding.

445
00:23:34.750 --> 00:23:37.330
I know it's important to keep
all your circuits grounded,

446
00:23:37.330 --> 00:23:38.490
there's different considerations.

447
00:23:38.490 --> 00:23:39.780
How about grounding?

448
00:23:39.780 --> 00:23:42.330
>> So grounding is kinda weird
when we get into this stuff.

449
00:23:42.330 --> 00:23:45.810
Like, with the giant PDU that I
was showing you guys earlier.

450
00:23:45.810 --> 00:23:48.340
It's three prongs so
one of those is gonna be a ground,

451
00:23:48.340 --> 00:23:49.580
I actually have no idea which one.

452
00:23:49.580 --> 00:23:50.750
But one of them will be a ground.

453
00:23:50.750 --> 00:23:52.510
And it's gonna ground out that strip.

454
00:23:52.510 --> 00:23:53.230
That's great, right?

455
00:23:53.230 --> 00:23:56.300
I plug my power into there,
I got good stable ground.

456
00:23:56.300 --> 00:24:01.160
It's bolted onto the rack and so
does the rack benefit from that grounding?

457
00:24:01.160 --> 00:24:01.751
It actually doesn't.

458
00:24:01.751 --> 00:24:05.506
And there's an important reason for that
because if I have two power strips that

459
00:24:05.506 --> 00:24:09.262
are run to two different circuits that
potentially could be run to two different

460
00:24:09.262 --> 00:24:12.513
power grids altogether, That would
be a strange situation to try and

461
00:24:12.513 --> 00:24:15.670
ground out both of them and
to count on that being reliable.

462
00:24:15.670 --> 00:24:18.620
So what you're gonna find is that yes,
your power strip's ground and

463
00:24:18.620 --> 00:24:21.950
anything that's got a three prong plug
is typically gonna have a ground to it.

464
00:24:21.950 --> 00:24:24.640
So you've got a nice,
safe electrical system.

465
00:24:24.640 --> 00:24:29.610
But your racks will typically
need to be grounded, also.

466
00:24:29.610 --> 00:24:33.810
In a commercial data center, you can kinda
walk across the backside of the racks and

467
00:24:33.810 --> 00:24:38.340
you'll notice these little, I think are
copper bolts, they might be brass bolts,

468
00:24:38.340 --> 00:24:42.280
but these little bolts that'll be in there
with what is typically a green wire.

469
00:24:42.280 --> 00:24:45.160
It doesn't have to be green but
they almost always run green for

470
00:24:45.160 --> 00:24:45.982
whatever reason.

471
00:24:45.982 --> 00:24:49.530
And itll be a solid copper wire that will
run through a grounding system somewhere.

472
00:24:49.530 --> 00:24:52.730
Sometimes they run up to the roof grid and
they ground the roof grid somewhere else.

473
00:24:52.730 --> 00:24:56.270
Other times, that green wire will run
all the way back to some giant block.

474
00:24:56.270 --> 00:24:59.662
And I guess you can't really see on
camera cuz it's been painted black, but

475
00:24:59.662 --> 00:25:02.895
behind me we actually have a grounding
block on the wall that has a bunch of

476
00:25:02.895 --> 00:25:04.380
those green wires running to it.

477
00:25:04.380 --> 00:25:06.190
It's been painted black so
you can't see it.

478
00:25:06.190 --> 00:25:09.870
But it helps to ground
all that into one place.

479
00:25:09.870 --> 00:25:13.060
And that way, if there is some kind
of electrical surge that happens,

480
00:25:13.060 --> 00:25:15.180
it can get dissipated
right into that ground.

481
00:25:15.180 --> 00:25:18.060
Now, where does that
electrical surge come from?

482
00:25:18.060 --> 00:25:20.980
In theory, if you've got UPSs
they're conditioning the line and

483
00:25:20.980 --> 00:25:22.430
it doesn't happen.

484
00:25:22.430 --> 00:25:25.290
But we can create that surge, too.

485
00:25:25.290 --> 00:25:29.174
Remember way back in the server components
episode where we took that server apart,

486
00:25:29.174 --> 00:25:32.100
I put on an ESD wristband.

487
00:25:32.100 --> 00:25:36.490
And I clipped it to the case
of that server while I was

488
00:25:36.490 --> 00:25:38.990
working on it to discharge
any electricity I had in me.

489
00:25:38.990 --> 00:25:43.080
Well, your server racks
should be grounded.

490
00:25:43.080 --> 00:25:45.770
And if they're grounded, when you go to
work on a server, you can take your ESD

491
00:25:45.770 --> 00:25:48.640
wristband and instead of attaching
it to the server that you might be

492
00:25:48.640 --> 00:25:51.410
pulling out or removing, it might be
plugged in, it might be unplugged,

493
00:25:51.410 --> 00:25:54.970
it might not have a reliable ground,
you can clip right onto the rack.

494
00:25:54.970 --> 00:25:59.530
And when you clip onto that rack, now
you're grounded regardless of the status

495
00:25:59.530 --> 00:26:03.650
of the server and you can work on it and
know that it's being done safely.

496
00:26:03.650 --> 00:26:08.190
Now, I'll tell you a funny story,
which is one of my embarrassing moments,

497
00:26:08.190 --> 00:26:12.480
is I used to do server warranty repair for
Compact and HP DC.

498
00:26:12.480 --> 00:26:14.858
That's really all the same company.

499
00:26:14.858 --> 00:26:18.040
And so, [LAUGH] I used to go and
do field warranty repair for it.

500
00:26:18.040 --> 00:26:20.730
And when you do that,
I had to work on the servers and

501
00:26:20.730 --> 00:26:24.090
I had to have my hands free, and the wrist
bands really get in the way sometimes when

502
00:26:24.090 --> 00:26:26.460
you're working with the larger
memory boards and stuff.

503
00:26:26.460 --> 00:26:30.040
And so, I used to use an ankle band,
one that would attach to my ankle, and

504
00:26:30.040 --> 00:26:33.010
then that way I could clip it onto
the rack and I would have my hands free.

505
00:26:33.010 --> 00:26:34.680
And it worked great.

506
00:26:34.680 --> 00:26:38.290
And the story I tell people,
the reason I stopped doing that is,

507
00:26:38.290 --> 00:26:41.460
I was working on a server one day and
somebody asked me a question.

508
00:26:41.460 --> 00:26:45.790
And so I turned to answer their
question and when I was done,

509
00:26:45.790 --> 00:26:48.740
I continued turning the same direction.

510
00:26:48.740 --> 00:26:51.240
So then I then was looking
at the server again, but

511
00:26:51.240 --> 00:26:55.990
my ESD band was now wrapped around my
ankles, both ankles, and I didn't know it.

512
00:26:55.990 --> 00:26:59.890
And so when I was done, I went to
walk away and I tripped and fell.

513
00:26:59.890 --> 00:27:04.280
I fell on my face, and in server rooms we
have metal floor, you usually a sub floor.

514
00:27:04.280 --> 00:27:07.610
It doesn't feel too good and you look
really, really stupid when you do it.

515
00:27:07.610 --> 00:27:10.649
Kind of hard to play off that I'm a
professional when I'm laying on the ground

516
00:27:10.649 --> 00:27:11.741
with a rope around my legs.

517
00:27:11.741 --> 00:27:14.374
But is that a situation?

518
00:27:14.374 --> 00:27:17.552
Somebody's going to edit this sound
bite and its going to sound silly, but

519
00:27:17.552 --> 00:27:20.390
it is something that happens, so
you need to be careful with that.

520
00:27:20.390 --> 00:27:22.060
You're gonna need to ground yourself.

521
00:27:22.060 --> 00:27:23.730
You can ground to the rack.

522
00:27:23.730 --> 00:27:26.650
The wristband, while it does get in
the way, is at least entirely obvious and

523
00:27:26.650 --> 00:27:27.410
you remember it's there.

524
00:27:27.410 --> 00:27:28.900
The ankle ones are little more dangerous.

525
00:27:28.900 --> 00:27:30.300
I don't use those any more.

526
00:27:30.300 --> 00:27:32.420
But you can't round to that.

527
00:27:32.420 --> 00:27:36.180
So just be aware that even though
your PDUs are grounded and

528
00:27:36.180 --> 00:27:38.170
that they are providing high levels very,

529
00:27:38.170 --> 00:27:42.200
very safely, you don't wanna connect
your ESD wristband to a PDU.

530
00:27:42.200 --> 00:27:43.700
That's a recipe for disaster.

531
00:27:43.700 --> 00:27:44.630
Don't do that.

532
00:27:44.630 --> 00:27:48.090
Attach your wristband to the rack,
the rack should be grounded.

533
00:27:48.090 --> 00:27:51.010
If you're not sure if the rack
is grounded, or if you know for

534
00:27:51.010 --> 00:27:55.480
a fact the rack is not grounded, then
attach your ESD wristband to the server,

535
00:27:55.480 --> 00:27:58.430
to the metal casing on the server,
the chassis.

536
00:27:58.430 --> 00:28:00.350
That's gonna be your best bet there.

537
00:28:00.350 --> 00:28:03.635
But if you know the rack is grounded,
definitely attach that, it's easier and

538
00:28:03.635 --> 00:28:04.773
it doesn't get in the way.

539
00:28:04.773 --> 00:28:06.668
>> All right Don,
well that's a lot of great information.

540
00:28:06.668 --> 00:28:08.535
Now, I know that we've
got some more to go,

00:28:08.535 --> 00:28:11.175
we've got more safety procedures
that you wanna let us know.

542
00:28:11.175 --> 00:28:13.385
But it does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

00:28:13.385 --> 00:28:13.985
So how about this?

544
00:28:13.985 --> 00:28:17.205
How about we go ahead, we'll stop it here,
we'll go into a part two.

545
00:28:17.205 --> 00:28:18.115
And then you can come back and

546
00:28:18.115 --> 00:28:21.395
you can finish up some of the other topics
I know that you still have to talk about.

547
00:28:21.395 --> 00:28:25.094
But before we do, do you have any
additional words that you maybe would like

548
00:28:25.094 --> 00:28:27.337
to throw to our viewers
as we wrap this one up?

549
00:28:27.337 --> 00:28:31.125
I just had an idea pop into my head
that I really kinda wanna try PDU

550
00:28:31.125 --> 00:28:32.440
pole vaulting now.

551
00:28:32.440 --> 00:28:33.340
We got this one right here.

552
00:28:33.340 --> 00:28:34.685
I bet I could get some height on this one.

553
00:28:34.685 --> 00:28:36.610
[LAUGH]
>> Would you call that electrical limbo?

554
00:28:36.610 --> 00:28:37.474
There we go.
>> That's right.

555
00:28:37.474 --> 00:28:39.437
>> That's right..
>> All right, well all the fun and

556
00:28:39.437 --> 00:28:42.010
games aside,
PDU shopping is an important aspect.

557
00:28:42.010 --> 00:28:44.360
You do wanna make sure you understand
the maximum load of your servers,

558
00:28:44.360 --> 00:28:46.200
which means read documentation.

559
00:28:46.200 --> 00:28:49.530
You gotta pull the engineering docs for
any equipment that you've purchased to

560
00:28:49.530 --> 00:28:52.510
make sure you're provided the appropriate
power and influence your decision.

561
00:28:52.510 --> 00:28:56.860
Don't cheap out on PDUs, the cheaper
they are, the worst power they provide.

562
00:28:56.860 --> 00:28:59.560
The worse power your server gets,
the shorter the lifetime is.

563
00:28:59.560 --> 00:29:03.697
So it makes sense to invest in
a good power distribution system.

564
00:29:03.697 --> 00:29:05.119
>> All right, words of wisdom, Don.

565
00:29:05.119 --> 00:29:08.461
We appreciate having you
here in the studio with us.

566
00:29:08.461 --> 00:29:10.720
And we appreciate you
the viewers watching.

567
00:29:10.720 --> 00:29:13.490
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

00:29:13.490 --> 00:29:14.190
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

569
00:29:14.190 --> 00:29:15.171
>> And we'll see you next time.

Well, first off,

rule number one, there probably shouldn't

00:23:16.585 --> 00:23:20.175
The face of these servers
should be sucking in cool air.

497
00:23:20.175 --> 00:23:22.795
And the face of these other servers
should also be sucking in cool air.

498
00:23:22.795 --> 00:23:26.860
And they can do that because the cool
air is coming right out of the ground.

499
00:23:26.860 --> 00:23:29.420
And going right into the face
plates of those servers.

500
00:23:29.420 --> 00:23:30.900
That's a cool aisle.

501
00:23:30.900 --> 00:23:35.638
They're both getting a nice fresh supply
of cool air going right into those

502
00:23:35.638 --> 00:23:36.547
face plates.

503
00:23:36.547 --> 00:23:40.450
And they take that cool air and
they run it over their hard drives.

504
00:23:40.450 --> 00:23:45.250
Over their CPU, over their memory,
through their power supply and

505
00:23:45.250 --> 00:23:50.070
that cool air ejects out
the back as hot air now.

506
00:23:50.070 --> 00:23:51.680
It's been heated.

507
00:23:51.680 --> 00:23:55.710
And if you look the next rack is
facing the opposite direction, so

508
00:23:55.710 --> 00:23:59.050
it's ejecting its hot
air in the same manner.

509
00:23:59.050 --> 00:24:01.270
Hot air to hot air.

510
00:24:01.270 --> 00:24:04.056
And that's where the exit vent is,
so that hot air raises up,

511
00:24:04.056 --> 00:24:06.630
hits the exit vent and
leaves the building.

512
00:24:06.630 --> 00:24:10.520
>> Now Don, let's say maybe I haven't
done my planning in my data center so

513
00:24:10.520 --> 00:24:14.260
well and I've got a couple of racks
in there that aren't fully populated.

514
00:24:14.260 --> 00:24:16.970
It looks like there were
space in between there,

515
00:24:16.970 --> 00:24:20.900
this system right here would be kind
of degraded in its performance.

516
00:24:20.900 --> 00:24:24.450
Are there things that we can do on the
rack itself if they're not fully populated

517
00:24:24.450 --> 00:24:27.800
to help maybe even this system,
or an internal system?

518
00:24:27.800 --> 00:24:30.930
>> Yeah, you really shouldn't have
blank space in a server rack.

519
00:24:30.930 --> 00:24:32.300
So if I have 42U rack and

520
00:24:32.300 --> 00:24:36.960
I've only got 12U of servers in there,
what about the other 30U?

521
00:24:36.960 --> 00:24:38.520
I've got 30U of empty space.

522
00:24:38.520 --> 00:24:42.080
Well that empty space is space that air
can move around in a different pattern.

523
00:24:42.080 --> 00:24:47.310
So for example, I could have hot air that
is exiting the back of the rack, but

524
00:24:47.310 --> 00:24:50.300
just leaks back and
comes back into the cool aisle or

525
00:24:50.300 --> 00:24:53.350
potentially get suck back in by
the phase played by that server.

526
00:24:53.350 --> 00:24:56.698
That's a problem, and so
when you have a rack with empty space,

527
00:24:56.698 --> 00:24:59.251
you need to put what you
call blanking panels in.

528
00:24:59.251 --> 00:25:02.977
Blanking panels are just metal
rectangles that bolt right on and

529
00:25:02.977 --> 00:25:06.229
you can get them in one U two,
U three, U four, U sizes.

530
00:25:06.229 --> 00:25:09.562
Normally, you just by one and two U, cuz
then you can kinda piece them together and

531
00:25:09.562 --> 00:25:13.290
meet whatever you need, and fill up
the gaps that you have inside of the rack.

532
00:25:13.290 --> 00:25:17.030
By putting that paneling in place,
it stops hot air

533
00:25:17.030 --> 00:25:20.210
from reintroducing itself to the face
plates, to the front of the servers.

534
00:25:20.210 --> 00:25:22.460
It creates a wall on
the front of the rack.

535
00:25:22.460 --> 00:25:23.720
And you're gonna need those.

536
00:25:23.720 --> 00:25:28.090
You should probably have just a supply of
them handy, because as you add servers,

537
00:25:28.090 --> 00:25:30.050
you'll take blanking panels out.

538
00:25:30.050 --> 00:25:33.050
And then as you remove servers, you'll put
blanking panels in to fill the gaps, and

539
00:25:33.050 --> 00:25:35.190
that controls that air flow.

540
00:25:35.190 --> 00:25:38.430
If you make a mistake in
how this stuff is arranged.

541
00:25:38.430 --> 00:25:40.170
If you have a server rack for

542
00:25:40.170 --> 00:25:45.590
example that is put in backwards,
then you're gonna bump into a situation.

543
00:25:45.590 --> 00:25:48.000
Well, that's totally not
what I was trying to do, but

544
00:25:48.000 --> 00:25:53.370
you can bump into a situation where it
is moving air in the wrong direction.

545
00:25:53.370 --> 00:25:57.990
And now we have where
we've got a hot aisle, and

546
00:25:57.990 --> 00:26:04.830
that hot air is unfortunately gonna end
up going right into the face plates.

547
00:26:04.830 --> 00:26:09.780
And so that server is now taking in
that hot air and spitting hot air out

548
00:26:09.780 --> 00:26:12.780
into the cold aisle where other
things are expecting to have it.

549
00:26:12.780 --> 00:26:13.810
That's a problem, right?

550
00:26:13.810 --> 00:26:16.370
We've gotta think about that air flow and
how this is gonna

551
00:26:16.370 --> 00:26:19.780
result inside of my data center and
make sure that we're stopping it.

552
00:26:19.780 --> 00:26:23.820
You never want hot air to enter
into a cold aisle because

553
00:26:23.820 --> 00:26:28.470
you feed hot air into a system and you're
gonna start having thermal shutdowns and

554
00:26:28.470 --> 00:26:29.910
other inconsistencies.

555
00:26:29.910 --> 00:26:33.570
>> Yeah, Don, you've mentioned how
important this cooling system is and

556
00:26:33.570 --> 00:26:36.430
I can only imagine that we don't want
to be guessing at something like that

557
00:26:36.430 --> 00:26:39.950
when it’s so detrimental or
important to our environment.

558
00:26:39.950 --> 00:26:41.420
How can we take the guess work out and

559
00:26:41.420 --> 00:26:43.850
make sure that our HVAC
system is working correctly?

560
00:26:43.850 --> 00:26:47.130
>> A lot of servers will do their own
monitoring and they can email you and

561
00:26:47.130 --> 00:26:49.640
notify you, but usually by the time
the server notices a problem,

562
00:26:49.640 --> 00:26:51.090
it’s too late, right?

563
00:26:51.090 --> 00:26:53.920
So we're typically gonna
leverage a combination of

564
00:26:53.920 --> 00:26:57.040
manual monitoring where somebody is
actually going into the rooms and

565
00:26:57.040 --> 00:27:00.658
checking the systems and
automated monitoring.

566
00:27:00.658 --> 00:27:03.193
There's plenty of organizations out there,

567
00:27:03.193 --> 00:27:06.965
companies like APC that make
environmental monitoring equipment.

568
00:27:06.965 --> 00:27:07.590
I like open gear,

569
00:27:07.590 --> 00:27:09.979
it's another one let me show you
some of their stuff that they make.

570
00:27:09.979 --> 00:27:11.744
They make these little sensors,

571
00:27:11.744 --> 00:27:16.010
these little kinda tan boxes that you
can wire up through your building.

572
00:27:16.010 --> 00:27:20.620
And if you look, you'll see where it's got
a couple of connectors and a network jack.

573
00:27:20.620 --> 00:27:24.740
And so it can monitor for
things like temperature, humidity, and

574
00:27:24.740 --> 00:27:28.780
other things in the atmosphere,
and report it back to you.

575
00:27:28.780 --> 00:27:32.030
And more importantly,
you can log this and monitor for trends.

576
00:27:32.030 --> 00:27:34.820
So you can see if the temperature
is slowly increasing or

577
00:27:34.820 --> 00:27:38.010
if it's decreasing,
if I'm having spikes at certain times.

578
00:27:38.010 --> 00:27:42.030
You can track a lot of that and
communicate it back to central locations.

579
00:27:42.030 --> 00:27:45.091
And they have bigger appliance solutions
too, they have all sorts of stuff.

580
00:27:45.091 --> 00:27:48.515
Even smoke detectors and alarms,
these are all different things we can use

581
00:27:48.515 --> 00:27:51.210
to monitor so
that we don't actually have to be there.

582
00:27:51.210 --> 00:27:54.090
That this could be a DR center on the
other side of the country that I've never

583
00:27:54.090 --> 00:27:55.330
even set foot in.

584
00:27:55.330 --> 00:27:59.630
But I know at a moment's glance exactly
what the status is in that data center.

585
00:27:59.630 --> 00:28:01.090
>> Don,
the other thing I might ask you, and

586
00:28:01.090 --> 00:28:05.650
this one is you've mentioned that
the PDUs have remote management.

587
00:28:05.650 --> 00:28:08.600
You can turn a port on,
or an outlet on or off.

588
00:28:08.600 --> 00:28:13.010
Is there any kind of way that we can,
short of putting up an entire SCADA

589
00:28:13.010 --> 00:28:16.650
system, that we can actually control
this from a remote location, or

590
00:28:16.650 --> 00:28:18.790
is it more just going to
be about the monitoring?

591
00:28:18.790 --> 00:28:19.850
So yes and no.

592
00:28:19.850 --> 00:28:23.020
Yes, a lot of these can be remotely
controlled, at the expensive ones.

593
00:28:23.020 --> 00:28:24.340
If you do the cheap ones,
they can't, right?

594
00:28:24.340 --> 00:28:27.310
Air conditioning units, you expect to
have a thermostat you manually adjust.

595
00:28:27.310 --> 00:28:30.240
But there's plenty of remote control
thermostats that are available.

596
00:28:30.240 --> 00:28:33.540
Be very, very careful, because now, you're

597
00:28:33.540 --> 00:28:37.110
bringing what would typically be offline
equipment into an online environment.

598
00:28:37.110 --> 00:28:39.720
If a hacker were to get into your system,
they could turn off the AC.

599
00:28:39.720 --> 00:28:41.920
That would be fun, wouldn't it, right?

600
00:28:41.920 --> 00:28:43.780
Or they could override your
temperature controls so

601
00:28:43.780 --> 00:28:45.500
you don't know that there's a problem.

602
00:28:45.500 --> 00:28:50.530
You need to have a dedicated management
network, a network that is solely used for

603
00:28:50.530 --> 00:28:54.290
your environmental controls that is
separate from your data network.

604
00:28:54.290 --> 00:28:57.280
And I mean separate, separate switches,
separate everything.

605
00:28:57.280 --> 00:28:58.480
Not even VLANs, right?

606
00:28:58.480 --> 00:29:02.760
We want this to be an isolated network
that is not connected to the internet.

607
00:29:02.760 --> 00:29:05.030
I am shocked at the amount of,

608
00:29:05.030 --> 00:29:09.670
you mentioned SCADA systems,
the amount of just industrial

609
00:29:09.670 --> 00:29:12.530
computers that are connected to the
internet when they shouldn't have been.

610
00:29:12.530 --> 00:29:15.270
And what's happening is there's a company,
we assume that these

611
00:29:15.270 --> 00:29:19.260
industrial manufacturers take
the precautions to secure their equipment.

612
00:29:19.260 --> 00:29:23.030
And they assume that you're taking the
precautions to protect the equipment and

613
00:29:23.030 --> 00:29:26.570
what happens is nobody protects it,
and you end up in a really bad spot.

614
00:29:26.570 --> 00:29:30.910
So a completely isolated
environmental management network

615
00:29:30.910 --> 00:29:33.610
is really essential if
you're going to do that.

616
00:29:33.610 --> 00:29:34.660
Most organizations don't.

617
00:29:34.660 --> 00:29:36.278
They just have somebody go and
manually check.

618
00:29:36.278 --> 00:29:40.134
Let's go check the temperature, let's go
see and report or they'll have monitors

619
00:29:40.134 --> 00:29:43.515
like these open gear ones that don't
actually control the temperature.

620
00:29:43.515 --> 00:29:47.480
They can report on it, and yes that's on
my network, fine they can report on it.

621
00:29:47.480 --> 00:29:49.080
But they're not actually
able to control it.

622
00:29:49.080 --> 00:29:51.880
I would have to go in and
manually adjust that air conditioning.

623
00:29:51.880 --> 00:29:53.470
So you gotta pick and choose.

624
00:29:53.470 --> 00:29:55.130
Security is important though.

625
00:29:55.130 --> 00:29:59.162
Don't open yourself up to having somebody
attack your environmental systems.

626
00:29:59.162 --> 00:30:02.243
>> All right Don,
well we see a lot of things to consider

627
00:30:02.243 --> 00:30:05.054
here when it comes to
environmental controls.

628
00:30:05.054 --> 00:30:08.460
But it does look like we're coming to the
end of another episode, but before we do,

629
00:30:08.460 --> 00:30:11.496
do you have any additional words that
you might like to tell the audience?

630
00:30:11.496 --> 00:30:15.040
>> A lot of this stuff falls under
the realm of security, right?

631
00:30:15.040 --> 00:30:18.320
We think of it as infrastructure or
maintenance, facilities.

632
00:30:18.320 --> 00:30:19.610
But it's security.

633
00:30:19.610 --> 00:30:23.190
If one of these systems fails,
our servers go offline.

634
00:30:23.190 --> 00:30:24.500
If we have an outage or

635
00:30:24.500 --> 00:30:27.370
remember the security is trying
to provide three things.

636
00:30:27.370 --> 00:30:31.000
We have, I'm trying to remember,
the CIA tri-pod.

637
00:30:31.000 --> 00:30:34.420
Confidentiality, Integrity,
and availability, right?

638
00:30:34.420 --> 00:30:37.470
Having an air conditioning doesn't
provide me confidentiality.

639
00:30:37.470 --> 00:30:39.020
It doesn't provide the integrity.

640
00:30:39.020 --> 00:30:40.760
It provides availability.

641
00:30:40.760 --> 00:30:42.560
And that falls under
the security umbrella.

642
00:30:42.560 --> 00:30:46.140
So coordinate this with your
CISO if you have one or

643
00:30:46.140 --> 00:30:50.180
your two security officer if you
have an IT security department.

644
00:30:50.180 --> 00:30:52.310
They need to be involved
in this process too.

645
00:30:52.310 --> 00:30:55.100
And they're the one's who
are particularly gonna be maintaining and

646
00:30:55.100 --> 00:30:58.140
monitoring the environmental systems
to make sure it all falls under

647
00:30:58.140 --> 00:31:03.540
the right maintenance levels and so on.

648
00:31:03.540 --> 00:31:07.820
>> All right, Don, well we appreciate you
joining us and lending us your expertise.

649
00:31:07.820 --> 00:31:10.180
And we appreciate you,
the viewer watching.

650
00:31:10.180 --> 00:31:12.350
We're gonna go ahead and
sign out here for ITProTV.

651
00:31:12.350 --> 00:31:14.390
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

652
00:31:14.390 --> 00:31:15.070
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

653
00:31:15.070 --> 00:31:16.132
>> And we'll see you next time

654
00:31:20.961 --> 00:31:24.049
[MUSIC]

655
00:31:24.049 --> 00:31:26.070
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don discuss the basics of IP addressing and common services used in TCP/IP. They talk about various topics such as IPv4, IPv6, static vs. dynamic IP address configurations, default gateways, classless inter domain routing, DNS and WINS.
episodes.title: IP Addressing and Services
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.034 --> 00:00:06.266
Welcome to ITPROTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.266 --> 00:00:08.412
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.412 --> 00:00:12.264
>> You're watching ITPROTV.

4
00:00:12.264 --> 00:00:15.946
>> Welcome to another exciting episode
here at ITPROTV, I'm your host Wes Bryan

5
00:00:15.946 --> 00:00:18.920
and in today's episode we've got
a real fun one coming at you.

6
00:00:18.920 --> 00:00:20.170
That's Server Plus and

7
00:00:20.170 --> 00:00:23.290
joining us in the studios today,
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:23.290 --> 00:00:24.570
Don, how are you doing, sir?

9
00:00:24.570 --> 00:00:27.370
>> I'm doing great Wes, ready to dive
right back into the world of servers.

10
00:00:27.370 --> 00:00:30.920
And in this episode we're gonna take a
look at the networking aspects of setting

11
00:00:30.920 --> 00:00:31.780
up a new server.

12
00:00:31.780 --> 00:00:34.170
And a big part of that is IP addressing.

13
00:00:34.170 --> 00:00:36.610
And then just setting up an address for
the server in general so

14
00:00:36.610 --> 00:00:39.730
that we can talk to other systems
out there on the network.

15
00:00:39.730 --> 00:00:40.920
It is a rare,

16
00:00:40.920 --> 00:00:44.390
rare server that we set up that's not
connected to a network these days.

17
00:00:44.390 --> 00:00:48.260
There are going to be those situations,
like a certificate authority, the root

18
00:00:48.260 --> 00:00:52.950
CA that you want to be air-gapped, you
want it to be separate from the network.

19
00:00:52.950 --> 00:00:55.220
But pretty much everything else
is going to be plugged in there.

20
00:00:55.220 --> 00:00:56.790
So we're going to run
through those settings.

21
00:00:56.790 --> 00:00:59.210
For most of you, you've already
been through network plus or

22
00:00:59.210 --> 00:01:01.700
certifications like that, or
you've got the experience.

23
00:01:01.700 --> 00:01:05.130
So I'm probably not going to give you
anything earth shattering or new here.

24
00:01:05.130 --> 00:01:07.650
But it's important that we understand it
cuz it's all on the exam objectives and

25
00:01:07.650 --> 00:01:09.480
these are the things
that we need to study.

26
00:01:09.480 --> 00:01:12.970
So let's kick things off by
talking about IP addressing.

27
00:01:12.970 --> 00:01:16.735
Now, the first thing I wanna mention
before I dive too far into IP addressing,

28
00:01:16.735 --> 00:01:20.633
is that it's not like the old days where
there was just one type of IP addressing.

29
00:01:20.633 --> 00:01:25.239
Now we've got two, IPv4 and IPv6, right.

30
00:01:25.239 --> 00:01:28.115
IP is the internet protocol,
version 4 is the old version, and

31
00:01:28.115 --> 00:01:30.250
version 6 is the new version.

32
00:01:30.250 --> 00:01:35.310
When you configure a server, you may need
to configure one or the other or both.

33
00:01:35.310 --> 00:01:38.000
A lot of people run dual stack
where they're both configured.

34
00:01:38.000 --> 00:01:41.360
In fact, if you're installing something
like a Microsoft Windows Server,

35
00:01:41.360 --> 00:01:44.420
it'll have both, IPv4 and
IPv6 running by default.

36
00:01:44.420 --> 00:01:48.750
If you're setting up a Red Hat server,
it'll have both enabled for

37
00:01:48.750 --> 00:01:50.480
automatic addressing by default.

38
00:01:50.480 --> 00:01:53.050
There's other systems that still
just default to IPv4 though, so

39
00:01:53.050 --> 00:01:55.980
you'll need to check with your
distribution, whatever operating system it

40
00:01:55.980 --> 00:01:58.210
is you're running,
to determine which one you've got.

41
00:01:58.210 --> 00:02:02.390
But after that, the rest of the settings
are all pretty much the same.

42
00:02:02.390 --> 00:02:04.680
So, hey,
how do I choose which protocol I want?

43
00:02:04.680 --> 00:02:07.630
Well, for most of us,
it's not really much of a choice.

44
00:02:07.630 --> 00:02:11.790
IPv4 is the current standard
that everybody supports,

45
00:02:11.790 --> 00:02:14.070
IPv6 is the new standard.

46
00:02:14.070 --> 00:02:17.230
I hate calling it new because it was,
when was it,

47
00:02:17.230 --> 00:02:19.500
it was RFC 20 years ago it seems like.

48
00:02:19.500 --> 00:02:20.210
It was a long time ago.

49
00:02:20.210 --> 00:02:21.440
>> It's been around for a long time.

50
00:02:21.440 --> 00:02:26.240
>> And so it's one of those things
that is just still catching on, right?

51
00:02:26.240 --> 00:02:30.060
So IPv6 is widely supported across
the Internet but not everyone runs it yet.

52
00:02:30.060 --> 00:02:34.870
So you're pretty much guaranteed to
use IPv4 versus IPv6 which you may or

53
00:02:34.870 --> 00:02:36.050
may not have.

54
00:02:36.050 --> 00:02:39.980
Now, the big difference between
the two is simply address space.

55
00:02:39.980 --> 00:02:44.600
Under IPv4, you have a 32-bit
address which allows for up to, and

56
00:02:44.600 --> 00:02:49.760
I always screw this number up,
it's around 4.3 billion IP addresses.

57
00:02:49.760 --> 00:02:50.840
And I know that sounds like a lot.

58
00:02:50.840 --> 00:02:54.727
It sounded like a lot when they
created TCP/IP back in the late '70s,

59
00:02:54.727 --> 00:02:57.240
early '80s but it's just not enough.

60
00:02:57.240 --> 00:02:59.995
If you think about over 6
billion people on planet Earth,

61
00:02:59.995 --> 00:03:04.230
4.3 billion IPs that's not enough for
everyone to have one address.

62
00:03:04.230 --> 00:03:05.130
So there is a shortage and

63
00:03:05.130 --> 00:03:09.430
that shortage is the real thing it's going
on right now, IPv6 works to fix that.

64
