on my local network.

285
00:14:42.150 --> 00:14:44.820
If I wanna get out to the Internet,
though, or get up to other networks,

286
00:14:44.820 --> 00:14:47.240
other subnets,
I'm gonna need a gateway also.

287
00:14:47.240 --> 00:14:50.715
The router I go to when I can't talk
to somebody that's on my network.

288
00:14:50.715 --> 00:14:52.269
So I'm gonna assign a static IP.

289
00:14:52.269 --> 00:14:58.275
I'm gonna make this one,
10.0.222., I don't know 101.

290
00:14:58.275 --> 00:15:01.900
All right, so I'm gonna punch that in.

291
00:15:01.900 --> 00:15:04.957
Here in Red Hat it's actually doing
a little error checking for me.

292
00:15:04.957 --> 00:15:07.179
So if I type in a bad address,
see how it turns red?

293
00:15:07.179 --> 00:15:08.893
Not every distribution does that.

294
00:15:08.893 --> 00:15:13.884
Some won't even let you type
in a bad number, some will.

295
00:15:13.884 --> 00:15:15.722
But they're just kind of
checking that number for me.

296
00:15:15.722 --> 00:15:16.469
That's why it turned red.

297
00:15:16.469 --> 00:15:18.239
And I need to provide a netmask.

298
00:15:18.239 --> 00:15:21.329
Now netmasks can be
misunderstood pretty easily.

299
00:15:21.329 --> 00:15:25.394
When I look at my address,
part of my address is a network ID and

300
00:15:25.394 --> 00:15:27.770
part of it is a host ID.

301
00:15:27.770 --> 00:15:30.954
The network ID, if I have 20 computers and
they all have the same network ID,

302
00:15:30.954 --> 00:15:33.968
they'll all be able to talk to each
other without going through a router.

303
00:15:33.968 --> 00:15:35.625
If they have different network IDs,

304
00:15:35.625 --> 00:15:38.790
they'll have to go through
a router to talk to each other.

305
00:15:38.790 --> 00:15:43.430
The subnet mask is what identifies
what is our network ID.

306
00:15:43.430 --> 00:15:47.250
And there are a ton of different
subnet masks that can be used.

307
00:15:47.250 --> 00:15:51.070
And I don't wanna dive too deep into it
here cuz it's covered in Network Plus and

308
00:15:51.070 --> 00:15:52.830
things that you guys should
already be familiar with.

309
00:15:52.830 --> 00:15:55.004
But there's three primary
network masks that we use.

310
00:15:55.004 --> 00:15:59.073
There's the old class A,
the old class B, and the old class C.

311
00:15:59.073 --> 00:16:00.871
I say the old,
nobody uses classes anymore.

312
00:16:00.871 --> 00:16:01.733
Everything's classless.

313
00:16:01.733 --> 00:16:05.693
But these net masks have kinda stayed
because they're so easy to read.

314
00:16:05.693 --> 00:16:10.640
The class A subnet mask was 255.0.0.0.

315
00:16:10.640 --> 00:16:16.400
And what that means is that when I look at
an IP address, this 255 is the network ID.

316
00:16:16.400 --> 00:16:19.650
So the 10 is my network ID.

317
00:16:19.650 --> 00:16:22.760
And everything else is the host ID.

318
00:16:22.760 --> 00:16:26.730
With this network mask I can talk to
anybody who's IP starts with a 10 without

319
00:16:26.730 --> 00:16:28.260
going through a router.

320
00:16:28.260 --> 00:16:30.510
If they start with an 11,
I've gotta go through a router.

321
00:16:30.510 --> 00:16:32.875
So, that separation.

322
00:16:32.875 --> 00:16:37.077
I can do a class B which
would be 255.255.0.0.

323
00:16:37.077 --> 00:16:40.640
This tells me that the first two
octets are part of the network ID.

324
00:16:40.640 --> 00:16:44.232
So, anybody who starts with 10.0,
I can talk to.

325
00:16:44.232 --> 00:16:48.968
And then we go to the old class
C which is 255.255.255.0.

326
00:16:48.968 --> 00:16:51.552
Now, if somebody out there
started with 10.0.222,

327
00:16:51.552 --> 00:16:53.747
I could talk to them without
going through a router.

328
00:16:53.747 --> 00:16:56.440
So having the right net mask is important.

329
00:16:56.440 --> 00:17:00.189
And a lot of people learn at home and
they learn with like 192.168.0 or

330
00:17:00.189 --> 00:17:03.680
192.168.1 which is a home
router set up for.

331
00:17:03.680 --> 00:17:10.857
And they use this subnet mask right
here which is a network of 254 machines.

332
00:17:10.857 --> 00:17:14.643
For a home, that's plenty, but for
an office, for a data center, for

333
00:17:14.643 --> 00:17:16.610
an enterprise, that's not a lot.

334
00:17:16.610 --> 00:17:20.180
And so, it's pretty rare that we use the
subnet mask in a corporate environment.

335
00:17:20.180 --> 00:17:22.720
We're usually using larger networks.

336
00:17:22.720 --> 00:17:23.960
And, when you do that,

337
00:17:23.960 --> 00:17:26.520
you use different subnet masks,
you gotta make sure you get this correct.

338
00:17:26.520 --> 00:17:30.410
If you get it wrong, you might be able to
talk to some hosts and not talk to others,

339
00:17:30.410 --> 00:17:34.020
and that can really create
a problem on the network.

340
00:17:34.020 --> 00:17:39.470
Now here in our studios, we use the 10.0
network and we use it as a class

341
00:17:39.470 --> 00:17:42.730
B even though technically, to be a class
A, everything is classless these days.

342
00:17:42.730 --> 00:17:46.220
So you can use whatever
subnet mask you want.

343
00:17:46.220 --> 00:17:47.210
All right, so

344
00:17:47.210 --> 00:17:52.800
now I can talk to anybody whose IP starts
with 10.0, but what about everybody else?

345
00:17:52.800 --> 00:17:57.420
For everybody else, I need to go
through a router and your router,

346
00:17:57.420 --> 00:18:01.680
it might be a dedicated device that is a
router, it might be a layer three switch,

347
00:18:01.680 --> 00:18:02.740
it might be a firewall.

348
00:18:02.740 --> 00:18:05.700
Here in the studios, we actually
do those straight to a firewall.

349
00:18:05.700 --> 00:18:09.600
We have a router on the outside of the
firewall not the inside because firewalls

350
00:18:09.600 --> 00:18:10.460
can rout.

351
00:18:10.460 --> 00:18:14.340
So, I'm gonna punch in the IP address
of our firewall in the network and

352
00:18:14.340 --> 00:18:15.110
that's who I'm gonna go to.

353
00:18:15.110 --> 00:18:18.788
If I ever wanna get to a network
that doesn't start with 10.0,

354
00:18:18.788 --> 00:18:21.980
I'll go to the firewall, and
it will help me the rest of the way out.

355
00:18:23.390 --> 00:18:25.990
Once that's set, I'm done.

356
00:18:25.990 --> 00:18:26.840
I can now talk to the network.

357
00:18:26.840 --> 00:18:29.050
I can get out to the internet,
I can do all sorts of great stuff.

358
00:18:29.050 --> 00:18:30.160
I can come down here and

359
00:18:30.160 --> 00:18:35.690
hit the old Apply button and
let me reset that network adapter.

360
00:18:35.690 --> 00:18:36.550
There we go.

361
00:18:36.550 --> 00:18:39.390
And I can see I got my address,
10.0.222.101, I got my default route,

362
00:18:39.390 --> 00:18:41.800
I'm good to go.

363
00:18:42.930 --> 00:18:44.930
Well, to an extent, right?

364
00:18:44.930 --> 00:18:47.865
If I test this out, whoops.

365
00:18:47.865 --> 00:18:51.930
[LAUGH] If I test it out by making
my screen go crazy, there we go.

366
00:18:52.970 --> 00:18:57.830
I should be able to verify my address,
if I do a ip addr,

367
00:18:57.830 --> 00:19:03.430
I can see I've got 10.0.222.101,
right, so there's my address.

368
00:19:03.430 --> 00:19:07.510
And, if I try and ping somebody like
our firewall, I can ping it, so

369
00:19:07.510 --> 00:19:10.420
I'm able to talk to other hosts
right here on the network with me.

370
00:19:10.420 --> 00:19:12.719
And if I try and
ping out to the internet, right?

371
00:19:12.719 --> 00:19:16.165
So, somebody like that,
I can get all the way up to the internet,

372
00:19:16.165 --> 00:19:18.063
things are working great, right?

373
00:19:18.063 --> 00:19:22.120
But I didn't set up name lookups.

374
00:19:22.120 --> 00:19:25.250
So if I try and access something by name,
that's not gonna work.

375
00:19:25.250 --> 00:19:27.270
So that's usually the next
thing that we set up.

376
00:19:27.270 --> 00:19:28.480
It's not technically required.

377
00:19:28.480 --> 00:19:32.020
If everything you're doing is based
on IPs, you don't need name lookups.

378
00:19:32.020 --> 00:19:34.480
But it's usually the next step for
us, right?

379
00:19:34.480 --> 00:19:39.425
So I'm gonna go back into my network
settings and we'll get that set up.

380
00:19:39.425 --> 00:19:43.250
Oops, I'm gonna click the wrong
thing here, there we go.

381
00:19:43.250 --> 00:19:44.890
All right, so I was under IPv4 and

382
00:19:44.890 --> 00:19:50.420
I set my address net mask gateway and
if I keep scrolling down, you'll see DNS.

383
00:19:50.420 --> 00:19:53.350
Right, which is the domain naming service.

384
00:19:53.350 --> 00:19:57.030
The domain name service,
it's been around a long time.

385
00:19:57.030 --> 00:20:04.310
It was developed under BSD at the-
>> Berkeley University of California?

386
00:20:04.310 --> 00:20:07.170
>> Yeah, it was done in part by them and
a part by a few other organizations.

387
00:20:07.170 --> 00:20:08.760
Berkeley's really known for BIND.

388
00:20:08.760 --> 00:20:10.930
>> Right.
>> The original DNS server that's kind

389
00:20:10.930 --> 00:20:12.340
of the core of everything that we create.

390
00:20:12.340 --> 00:20:14.160
So, we kind of attribute it there, but

391
00:20:14.160 --> 00:20:17.080
there were several different people
that were involved in creating it.

392
00:20:17.080 --> 00:20:21.100
But, they recognize early on that hey,
it's not easy to remember IP addresses.

393
00:20:21.100 --> 00:20:23.350
So, it's easier to remember names.

394
00:20:23.350 --> 00:20:26.710
And we can map the names
to the IP addresses, right?

395
00:20:26.710 --> 00:20:29.080
And so, we need to point to a DNS
server to be able to connect to that.

396
00:20:29.080 --> 00:20:31.970
So I can just specify one and
I'll use Google's.

397
00:20:31.970 --> 00:20:33.690
Google has public DNS servers.

398
00:20:33.690 --> 00:20:35.900
You might have internal DNS
servers that you want to use.

399
00:20:35.900 --> 00:20:36.888
Most companies do.

400
00:20:36.888 --> 00:20:40.155
If you have things like Microsoft Active
Directory, you need to look at your own

401
00:20:40.155 --> 00:20:42.692
DNS servers to find all your
directory entries, otherwise,

402
00:20:42.692 --> 00:20:45.997
they're gonna be missing from your public
ones, but I'm gonna punch that in.

403
00:20:45.997 --> 00:20:48.749
Now, when I populate the DNS server,

404
00:20:48.749 --> 00:20:54.570
I can leave it just like it is here and
I'm done or I can add more than one.

405
00:20:54.570 --> 00:20:58.380
It is a good idea to have two, right?

406
00:20:58.380 --> 00:21:02.119
So I'm gonna add maybe another Googles,
right?

407
00:21:02.119 --> 00:21:03.210
8.8.4.4.

408
00:21:03.210 --> 00:21:08.270
Now, when I do that, I've got
a primary DNS server and a secondary.

409
00:21:08.270 --> 00:21:10.700
My machine is only gonna
use the first one.

410
00:21:10.700 --> 00:21:15.150
I'm only gonna use 8.8.8.8,
unless it goes down.

411
00:21:15.150 --> 00:21:19.236
If it fails, then I go to 8.8.4.4.

412
00:21:19.236 --> 00:21:21.672
I've seen people get really hard core.

413
00:21:21.672 --> 00:21:22.410
And like, you know what?

414
00:21:22.410 --> 00:21:25.640
I'm gonna add a bunch because
I want full redundancy.

415
00:21:25.640 --> 00:21:29.970
Hey, these are Google, let me add layer
three, level three communications and

416
00:21:29.970 --> 00:21:33.450
we'll come in here and punch them in,
they have three servers.

417
00:21:35.130 --> 00:21:36.440
We'll punch them in, so there.

418
00:21:36.440 --> 00:21:37.310
Now I got five.

419
00:21:37.310 --> 00:21:38.950
This is super redundancy.

420
00:21:38.950 --> 00:21:41.980
But, it really is overkill
because this last one, 4.2.2.3,

421
00:21:41.980 --> 00:21:46.650
we're not gonna get to that one unless
all four of these others have failed.

422
00:21:46.650 --> 00:21:49.540
What are the odds of all
four of these failing?

423
00:21:49.540 --> 00:21:53.620
If all four of these have failed, there's
something really wrong with the internet,

424
00:21:53.620 --> 00:21:56.400
and you've got bigger problems than
name lookups to worry about, right?

425
00:21:56.400 --> 00:21:58.630
So, this is something that's
gonna be catastrophic.

426
00:21:58.630 --> 00:22:01.300
So, typically, I don't go crazy on this.

427
00:22:01.300 --> 00:22:02.070
Just do two.

428
00:22:02.070 --> 00:22:07.499
I do recommend that you do two that
are in different subnets, right?

429
00:22:07.499 --> 00:22:11.860
Notice I've got 4.2.2.1,
4.2.2.2, 4.2.2.3, all right?

430
00:22:11.860 --> 00:22:14.120
I don't care how you're subnetting that.

431
00:22:14.120 --> 00:22:15.780
Those are all gonna be
in the same network.

432
00:22:15.780 --> 00:22:17.950
No matter how small you make that network,

433
00:22:17.950 --> 00:22:21.220
these three are all gonna
be in the same subnet.

434
00:22:21.220 --> 00:22:23.050
What if I lose my route to that subnet?

435
00:22:24.190 --> 00:22:28.180
I could lose all three, or
those three servers could be up and happy.

436
00:22:28.180 --> 00:22:29.070
But if I lose my route,

437
00:22:29.070 --> 00:22:33.300
if I have a routing table problem,
I just lost all three servers.

438
00:22:33.300 --> 00:22:34.190
And that happens, right?

439
00:22:34.190 --> 00:22:38.220
It happened to Microsoft a few years ago
where they had massive server clusters set

440
00:22:38.220 --> 00:22:39.280
up for their DNS servers,

441
00:22:39.280 --> 00:22:41.990
and they were all on the same subnet and
the route went down.

442
00:22:41.990 --> 00:22:44.710
And they learned their lesson and
now they're spread out, right?

443
00:22:44.710 --> 00:22:46.300
Google, if you look at theirs.

444
00:22:47.380 --> 00:22:53.148
Sure they both start with 8.8, but
you've got 8.8.8.8 and 8.8.4.4.

445
00:22:53.148 --> 00:22:57.355
And they're in two completely different
locations using two completely different

446
00:22:57.355 --> 00:22:58.605
routes that get you there.

447
00:22:58.605 --> 00:23:01.945
This gives you more network redundancy
to get to those destinations.

448
00:23:01.945 --> 00:23:04.555
But you might even wanna do
vendor independence, right?

449
00:23:04.555 --> 00:23:08.790
So, instead of using it the way that
I'm doing, you could come in and say,

450
00:23:08.790 --> 00:23:14.310
I'm gonna do Google as my primary, and
level three as my backup, or vice versa.

451
00:23:14.310 --> 00:23:17.710
You do have to be careful with this
though cuz sometimes you can get

452
00:23:17.710 --> 00:23:20.970
one response from Google and
a different response from level three,

453
00:23:20.970 --> 00:23:24.140
depending on whether DNS
records are propagating out.

454
00:23:24.140 --> 00:23:27.190
So, I encourage you to make sure
that they're either at least two

455
00:23:27.190 --> 00:23:27.990
different networks.

456
00:23:27.990 --> 00:23:30.450
When you start going multiple providers
just make sure you test it out,

457
00:23:30.450 --> 00:23:33.240
and then everything works out fine for
your use case scenario.

458
00:23:33.240 --> 00:23:34.370
For most people, it's perfectly fine.

459
00:23:35.580 --> 00:23:37.900
All right, so now I've got a little
bit of redundancy there and

460
00:23:37.900 --> 00:23:39.830
i'll be able to do my name lookups.

461
00:23:39.830 --> 00:23:42.970
Now, DNS is not the only type of
name lookup that's out there, right?

462
00:23:42.970 --> 00:23:47.054
If you've got Windows servers, Windows
has another type of lookup called WINS.

463
00:23:47.054 --> 00:23:52.500
W-I-N-S which is
the Windows Internet Name Service.

464
00:23:52.500 --> 00:23:53.028
Is that right?
Okay.

465
00:23:53.028 --> 00:23:55.800
So [LAUGH] It's been a long
time since I've used it.

466
00:23:55.800 --> 00:23:58.032
It was created a long time ago, really,

467
00:23:58.032 --> 00:24:01.919
by Intel because it was part of the old
LAN manager suite that they had.

468
00:24:01.919 --> 00:24:05.127
And, what it did was name resolution for
local networks.

469
00:24:05.127 --> 00:24:08.610
It didn't use fully qualified
domain names, FQDNs.

470
00:24:08.610 --> 00:24:13.088
When you look at a domain name like,
www.google.com,

471
00:24:13.088 --> 00:24:16.610
right, www, that's the server.

472
00:24:16.610 --> 00:24:19.120
And then, Google, that's the domain.

473
00:24:19.120 --> 00:24:21.890
And com, that's the top-level domain.

474
00:24:21.890 --> 00:24:26.530
So, when Google bought their domain, they
went to a registrar that controlled .com.

475
00:24:26.530 --> 00:24:28.070
And they bought Google.

476
00:24:28.070 --> 00:24:31.120
And so then they had Google.com, and
then underneath it, they added www.

477
00:24:31.120 --> 00:24:37.040
There might be 100,000 servers across
this planet that are called www.

478
00:24:37.040 --> 00:24:38.370
But I know which one is Google's,

479
00:24:38.370 --> 00:24:43.000
because of the fully qualified domain
name, the FQDN, www.google.com.

480
00:24:43.000 --> 00:24:48.780
Well, when the networking age
kinda was just starting and we had

481
00:24:48.780 --> 00:24:54.050
the old netbios communications that were
just local communications on a network.

482
00:24:54.050 --> 00:24:57.160
I might have Windows 3.1 on my laptop.

483
00:24:57.160 --> 00:24:58.690
Probably didn't have laptops then, so.

484
00:24:58.690 --> 00:25:02.460
Windows 3.1 on my desktop and
Wes is over there running Windows 95.

485
00:25:02.460 --> 00:25:03.430
You just upgraded.

486
00:25:03.430 --> 00:25:06.440
And we wanted to talk
to each other by name.

487
00:25:06.440 --> 00:25:12.120
Well, TCP/IP wasn't included in
those operating systems by default.

488
00:25:12.120 --> 00:25:13.840
You had to add it if you wanted it.

489
00:25:13.840 --> 00:25:16.900
That a lot of them still ran IPX/SPX or

490
00:25:16.900 --> 00:25:21.850
NetBEUI or Banyan VINES or the crazy
old protocols that are all gone now.

491
00:25:21.850 --> 00:25:24.840
Well, when they wanted
to do a name lookup,

492
00:25:24.840 --> 00:25:26.550
they didn't have a function for that.

493
00:25:26.550 --> 00:25:30.380
And so, Microsoft created wins
to be able to provide that and

494
00:25:30.380 --> 00:25:34.038
it resolves single name to an IP.

495
00:25:34.038 --> 00:25:37.510
So I might have a name in
there called west laptop and

496
00:25:37.510 --> 00:25:41.570
then it maps to an IP or
it maps to some other kind of address.

497
00:25:41.570 --> 00:25:43.560
But that's what Windows is
trying to do a single name,

498
00:25:43.560 --> 00:25:45.560
it can give you qualified domains.

499
00:25:45.560 --> 00:25:48.840
And that means it really wasn't
suitable for use on the Internet.

500
00:25:48.840 --> 00:25:53.150
It expected us to only have one
machine with a particular name.

501
00:25:53.150 --> 00:25:56.730
If there's a www, there's only one
machine called www, and that's it.

502
00:25:56.730 --> 00:25:58.820
And that's not true of the whole world.

503
00:25:58.820 --> 00:26:01.470
So WINS was really just
in the Microsoft world.

504
00:26:01.470 --> 00:26:04.720
Now, you might ask yourself,
why am I bothering to bring it up now?

505
00:26:04.720 --> 00:26:07.370
The problem is,
a lot of the old protocols are gone.

506
00:26:07.370 --> 00:26:09.610
Most of us don't use NetBEUI at all.

507
00:26:09.610 --> 00:26:13.730
And NetBIOS, even, is really reduced to
a very small portion about what we do.

508
00:26:13.730 --> 00:26:17.390
But there were a lot of software
applications that were written that

509
00:26:17.390 --> 00:26:20.660
depended on it, and
we haven't moved away from those.

510
00:26:20.660 --> 00:26:22.560
So there are still some
people who need it.

511
00:26:22.560 --> 00:26:26.150
So if you install Windows Server today,
you can still add WINs to it.

512
00:26:26.150 --> 00:26:31.450
Even though here we are in 2017,
and you know, it's unconscionable.

513
00:26:31.450 --> 00:26:35.110
I set up a WINs server for
the first time in 1998, I think.

514
00:26:35.110 --> 00:26:40.300
And so here we are, almost 20 years
later and it's still out there, right?

515
00:26:40.300 --> 00:26:42.430
But just be aware, I'm on a Linux box, so

516
00:26:42.430 --> 00:26:44.220
it doesn't have winds
support baked into it.

517
00:26:44.220 --> 00:26:49.360
If I had Samba, it does, and I can do
WINs lookups right from my Linux box.

518
00:26:49.360 --> 00:26:51.414
But for most of us,
we just have DNS, on a Windows box,

519
00:26:51.414 --> 00:26:54.307
you'll have another entry here for
WINs which you may or may not need to use.

520
00:26:56.501 --> 00:27:00.165
All right, once I've got that setup
I'm in pretty good shape here,

521
00:27:00.165 --> 00:27:02.258
as far as getting my settings in place.

522
00:27:02.258 --> 00:27:07.080
I've got my router, I've got my DNS,
I've got my IP addresses set.

523
00:27:07.080 --> 00:27:09.890
We're pretty good to go on the IPv4 side.

524
00:27:09.890 --> 00:27:13.870
On the IPv6 side,
it's not much different, right?

525
00:27:13.870 --> 00:27:16.920
Let me just hit apply really quick,
so the settings saved and

526
00:27:16.920 --> 00:27:20.950
I'll go right back in and
I'm gonna take a look at at the IPv6 side.

527
00:27:20.950 --> 00:27:25.420
On the IPv6 side, I've got right
now that my addresses is automatic.

528
00:27:25.420 --> 00:27:27.590
And in IPv6, the addresses are so

529
00:27:27.590 --> 00:27:33.810
long that we really do rely on name
lookups, more than we do on IPs.

530
00:27:33.810 --> 00:27:37.650
And so, for most of our systems,
we may choose to leave them as automatic.

531
00:27:37.650 --> 00:27:41.122
But you can do a manual IP if you want.

532
00:27:41.122 --> 00:27:43.730
And IPv6, you can set that, and
you can type it right in there.

533
00:27:43.730 --> 00:27:46.970
You can go link local only, so you're only
talking to people in the same network as

534
00:27:46.970 --> 00:27:51.300
you Or you can do automatic DHCP only or
automatic.

535
00:27:51.300 --> 00:27:53.130
You know, what's that about, right?

536
00:27:53.130 --> 00:27:55.170
I thought automatic was DHCP.

537
00:27:55.170 --> 00:27:59.752
Well IPv6 has ways of
generating it's own address.

538
00:27:59.752 --> 00:28:04.420
There's a standard called Eli64,
where it can use the Mac Address

539
00:28:04.420 --> 00:28:07.870
assigned to the network adapter
to call an IPv6 Address.

540
00:28:07.870 --> 00:28:12.600
It listens for a router on the network and
it sees what subnet the router is in.

541
00:28:12.600 --> 00:28:15.540
And it takes that subnet and
then it takes the MAC address,

542
00:28:15.540 --> 00:28:18.160
the network adapter,
pads it with a few extra values and

543
00:28:18.160 --> 00:28:22.650
pops that together to create a 128-bit
address that's unique to this machine.

544
00:28:22.650 --> 00:28:25.100
You don't get duplicates because you don't
have multiple machines with the same

545
00:28:25.100 --> 00:28:26.240
MAC address.

546
00:28:26.240 --> 00:28:28.255
And they're able to communicate,
that's automatic.

547
00:28:28.255 --> 00:28:31.991
But when you do automatic,
where does it get its DNS servers from?

548
00:28:31.991 --> 00:28:33.917
Where does it get its
default gateway from?

549
00:28:33.917 --> 00:28:37.546
Well it can listen on the network
to find those two, or,

550
00:28:37.546 --> 00:28:39.412
you can get those from DHCP.

551
00:28:39.412 --> 00:28:43.480
And so there is DHCP for IPv6,
it's just most people don't use it.

552
00:28:43.480 --> 00:28:46.861
Normally we listen on the network and
we get it, or we do manual assignments.

553
00:28:46.861 --> 00:28:48.086
If I choose manual though,

554
00:28:48.086 --> 00:28:51.781
you'll notice everything here is pretty
much the same as what we saw under IPV4.

555
00:28:51.781 --> 00:28:54.130
The address is gonna be really different.

556
00:28:54.130 --> 00:28:59.770
So if I come in and start to punch
in whatever my address is gonna be,

557
00:28:59.770 --> 00:29:03.950
I can punch that in and then my prefix.

558
00:29:03.950 --> 00:29:07.910
Well the old subnet masks were
really denoting how many bits

559
00:29:07.910 --> 00:29:11.490
of the address were part of
the network ID versus the host ID.

560
00:29:11.490 --> 00:29:15.160
Here, you wouldn't want to write
255.255.255.255.255, right, I mean

561
00:29:15.160 --> 00:29:20.540
it would just go on and on and on,
because the address is so long.

562
00:29:20.540 --> 00:29:22.450
So, instead,
we just write the prefix bits.

563
00:29:22.450 --> 00:29:24.853
And most people just do a 64-bit prefix.

564
00:29:24.853 --> 00:29:26.000
It's 128-bit address.

565
00:29:26.000 --> 00:29:27.850
So the first half of
the address is the network ID,

566
00:29:27.850 --> 00:29:30.070
the second half is the host ID.

567
00:29:30.070 --> 00:29:34.050
We can afford to waste,
because the address space is so big

568
00:29:34.050 --> 00:29:38.229
that this give us nice, huge networks to
be able to use inside of our environment.

569
00:29:39.460 --> 00:29:41.200
And then your gateway is just
the router that you're gonna use.

570
00:29:41.200 --> 00:29:45.341
Maybe it's the very first
device in this network.

571
00:29:46.729 --> 00:29:48.189
Whatever it is, you punch that in.

572
00:29:48.189 --> 00:29:51.510
And then your name servers that you're
gonna be doing lookups for, right?

573
00:29:51.510 --> 00:29:53.203
So whatever, whoops.

574
00:29:53.203 --> 00:29:56.000
[LAUGH] Darn it.

575
00:29:56.000 --> 00:30:02.320
Whatever network that happens to be
if I can get my shortcut done here.

576
00:30:02.320 --> 00:30:03.480
There we go.

577
00:30:03.480 --> 00:30:04.830
All right, so I'll just punch that in.

578
00:30:07.170 --> 00:30:09.899
And now I've got my name lookups,
and I can provide multiples there.

579
00:30:09.899 --> 00:30:14.452
Google, Level 3, those guys, they all
have IPv6 DNS servers that are out there.

580
00:30:14.452 --> 00:30:15.761
You might have your own,
you punch those in.

581
00:30:15.761 --> 00:30:18.630
Really no different than IPv4.

582
00:30:18.630 --> 00:30:20.660
You get those configured,
and they're in place.

583
00:30:20.660 --> 00:30:23.630
Now, I do have to watch out, because
RedHat does some interesting things.

584
00:30:23.630 --> 00:30:27.050
See how mine still says
automatic on here for DNS?

585
00:30:27.050 --> 00:30:29.490
I'm manually entering DNS but
it says automatic, and

586
00:30:29.490 --> 00:30:33.120
that means it's still going to try to
learn DNS servers from the network.

587
00:30:33.120 --> 00:30:35.120
I'm overriding it, but
it'll still learn those as backups.

588
00:30:35.120 --> 00:30:36.000
I may or may not want that.

589
00:30:36.000 --> 00:30:39.150
I can turn that off, and now it's only
going to use the ones that I specify here.

590
00:30:40.190 --> 00:30:43.810
Okay, so once we got that,
now we're good to go, I can apply that.

591
00:30:43.810 --> 00:30:48.610
Let me reset that adapter, and
once it resets, I can see that

592
00:30:48.610 --> 00:30:53.020
I've got my IPv4 and IPv6 addresses, and
I'm ready to rock and communicate on them.

593
00:30:53.020 --> 00:30:55.780
Now I need to go update
my documentation to say,

594
00:30:55.780 --> 00:30:59.270
Don just brought up this server,
here's the IP and so on.

595
00:30:59.270 --> 00:31:02.550
And I need to verify on my DNS
servers that I've got a proper mapping

596
00:31:02.550 --> 00:31:06.360
in there that's mapping that host
name to an IP so that, that's there.

597
00:31:06.360 --> 00:31:09.150
And the reverse look up records,
right, the PTRs.

598
00:31:09.150 --> 00:31:12.880
You need those for IPv4 and IPv6,
so people can look at the address.

599
00:31:12.880 --> 00:31:14.240
And figure out the name
that's attached to it.

600
00:31:14.240 --> 00:31:18.000
That's all an important
step of assigning an IP.

601
00:31:18.000 --> 00:31:20.580
All right, I've got a few more things
that I wanna talk about on here.

602
00:31:20.580 --> 00:31:22.200
But I know I'm short on time.

603
00:31:22.200 --> 00:31:24.375
So let's bump into a part two.

604
00:31:24.375 --> 00:31:26.640
It'll probably be a shorter one,
but we'll bump it to a part two.

605
00:31:26.640 --> 00:31:29.980
And I just wanna wrap up a few more things
with setting up network adapters on

606
00:31:29.980 --> 00:31:31.470
servers that we need to worry about.

607
00:31:31.470 --> 00:31:34.730
But we've kind of seen the bulk of what
we need to know for server plus and

608
00:31:34.730 --> 00:31:36.470
what we need to know in real life.

609
00:31:36.470 --> 00:31:38.152
>> A lot of great information there Don,
and

610
00:31:38.152 --> 00:31:39.940
we definitely appreciate having you here.

611
00:31:39.940 --> 00:31:43.110
And if any of this information that
you're looking at right now might seem

612
00:31:43.110 --> 00:31:46.770
unfamiliar, keep in mind that we do have
the A plus and Net plus content that you

613
00:31:46.770 --> 00:31:49.730
can go back and watch and then join
us back here in Server plus, Don.

614
00:31:49.730 --> 00:31:52.660
But before we sign out, do you have any
additional information you'd like to throw

615
00:31:52.660 --> 00:31:54.830
in, we'll go ahead and
just leave that for the part two.

616
00:31:54.830 --> 00:31:58.640
The most important part about IP
addressing is good documentation, right?

617
00:31:58.640 --> 00:32:01.340
You don't wanna end up with duplicate IPs,
so always keep track of that.

618
00:32:01.340 --> 00:32:03.890
If you're not good about keeping
a spreadsheet of IP addresses,

619
00:32:03.890 --> 00:32:06.020
get third party software
that can track it.

620
00:32:06.020 --> 00:32:09.140
You just need to make sure you keep those
straight, it is an important piece.

621
00:32:09.140 --> 00:32:12.310
>> All right Don, well as always,
we appreciate having you in the studios.

622
00:32:12.310 --> 00:32:14.030
We appreciate you, the viewer.

623
00:32:14.030 --> 00:32:16.860
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

624
00:32:16.860 --> 00:32:17.804
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

625
00:32:17.804 --> 00:32:19.953
>> And we'll see you next time.

626
00:32:19.953 --> 00:32:26.120
[MUSIC]

627
00:32:26.120 --> 00:32:28.000
Thank you for watching IT PRO TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their discussion on the basics of IP addressing and common services used in TCP/IP. They talk about network address translation, port address translation, NIC teaming, speeds and duplex types.
episodes.title: IP Addressing and Services Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.680
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.680 --> 00:00:08.385
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.385 --> 00:00:12.290
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.290 --> 00:00:14.904
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:14.904 --> 00:00:16.376
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:16.376 --> 00:00:19.340
And in today's episode we're continuing
through our series in Server+.

7
00:00:19.340 --> 00:00:20.220
That's right,

8
00:00:20.220 --> 00:00:25.020
CompTIA Server+, coming back with a part
two on IP addressing and services.

9
00:00:25.020 --> 00:00:28.780
And joining us to help us round up this
topic is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:28.780 --> 00:00:29.820
Don, how you doing, sir?

11
00:00:29.820 --> 00:00:30.910
I'm doing just swell, Wes.

12
00:00:30.910 --> 00:00:34.820
Ready to dive right back in, and I rambled
on a little too long in the last episode.

13
00:00:34.820 --> 00:00:38.350
I have a few more things to point out
before we wrap up IP addressing and

14
00:00:38.350 --> 00:00:40.364
that's some of the services
that we need to focus on.

15
00:00:40.364 --> 00:00:42.963
So that's what we're gonna be picking
up with right here in this episode.

16
00:00:42.963 --> 00:00:45.090
If you didn't watch part one,
you definitely wanna check it out.

17
00:00:45.090 --> 00:00:47.750
But when we set up a new server,

18
00:00:47.750 --> 00:00:50.802
one of the first things that we need to do
is to get it communicating on the network.

19
00:00:50.802 --> 00:00:53.140
If you think about your
standard server setup, right,

20
00:00:53.140 --> 00:00:56.510
you gotta install the operating system and
then you need to do your updates.

21
00:00:56.510 --> 00:00:59.780
Updates are very,
very high up on the list of things to do.

22
00:00:59.780 --> 00:01:02.130
Well, you usually need to be on
the network to do your updates,

23
00:01:02.130 --> 00:01:03.500
even if you have a local update server.

24
00:01:03.500 --> 00:01:05.750
So that's why this is kind of a key and
critical step.

25
00:01:05.750 --> 00:01:08.501
So in the last episode,
we talked about assigning the addresses.

26
00:01:08.501 --> 00:01:12.006
Now I wanna talk about some of the other
things we might need to configure on those

27
00:01:12.006 --> 00:01:15.530
network adapters to get them up and
running and being happy.

28
00:01:15.530 --> 00:01:20.610
Now, once we have an IP assigned, what
did we talk about in the last episode?

29
00:01:20.610 --> 00:01:23.989
We did IP address, we did subnet mask,
we did a default gateway or router, right.

30
00:01:23.989 --> 00:01:26.640
Different operating systems
call it different things.

31
00:01:26.640 --> 00:01:31.360
We did a DNS server, potentially
a Win Server, although unlikely.

32
00:01:31.360 --> 00:01:33.630
So those are some of the components
that we've already seen.

33
00:01:33.630 --> 00:01:38.500
Now I wanna talk about a few other
things we might need to worry about.

34
00:01:38.500 --> 00:01:42.360
One of the bigger ones is NAT and
PAT, right, NAT and PAT.

35
00:01:42.360 --> 00:01:45.010
NAT is network address translation.

36
00:01:45.010 --> 00:01:47.330
When we assign an IP address to a server,

37
00:01:47.330 --> 00:01:51.160
your server might be connected
directly to the Internet.

38
00:01:51.160 --> 00:01:54.260
You might have a full-blown public
IP assigned to your server, and

39
00:01:54.260 --> 00:01:57.040
it's exposed to the world, and off you go.

40
00:01:57.040 --> 00:01:58.630
But that's not terribly common.

41
00:01:58.630 --> 00:02:03.580
It's not common because of the security
risks that are just a part

42
00:02:03.580 --> 00:02:05.070
of exposing a server like that.

43
00:02:05.070 --> 00:02:08.785
So, typically, you're gonna have a
firewall in-between you and the Internet.

44
00:02:08.785 --> 00:02:12.337
If that's the case, you might still
have a public IP on your server.

45
00:02:12.337 --> 00:02:16.523
The firewall is filtering and protecting
you as best it can, or an IDS box or

46
00:02:16.523 --> 00:02:19.719
something like that,
an intrusion detection service.

47
00:02:19.719 --> 00:02:23.684
But if you don't, what a lot of people
will do is they'll leverage a firewall

48
00:02:23.684 --> 00:02:28.263
that's connected to the Internet, and then
they'll use private IPs on their servers.

49
00:02:28.263 --> 00:02:31.826
And if you have a private IP, you're
not allowed to talk to the Internet.

50
00:02:31.826 --> 00:02:35.321
Your ISP is actually required to drop
traffic for private networks as soon as

51
00:02:35.321 --> 00:02:38.176
they hit the Internet, so
you're not even routed out there.

52
00:02:38.176 --> 00:02:40.570
Private IPs aren't
allowed to get out there.

53
00:02:40.570 --> 00:02:44.245
So we leverage a router, or
a firewall that's acting as a router,

54
00:02:44.245 --> 00:02:47.270
to perform network address translation.

55
00:02:47.270 --> 00:02:47.850
And with NAT,

56
00:02:47.850 --> 00:02:53.420
network address translation, we're
changing that private IP into a public IP.

57
00:02:53.420 --> 00:02:57.610
Now, when you do that, it can be
a one-to-one mapping or a one-to-many.

58
00:02:57.610 --> 00:03:01.380
If you think about the home routers
that people use, you might have 10 or

59
00:03:01.380 --> 00:03:02.990
15 devices in your house.

60
00:03:02.990 --> 00:03:07.240
And they all share one public IP address
on their way out to the Internet.

61
00:03:07.240 --> 00:03:09.070
And that's fine for a home.

62
00:03:09.070 --> 00:03:13.370
But if I have five web servers, and
they're all running on port 80,

63
00:03:13.370 --> 00:03:18.210
and they all share one IP,
how is that gonna work out?

64
00:03:18.210 --> 00:03:20.880
It's not, right, I can't do that.

65
00:03:20.880 --> 00:03:25.890
So in that scenario,
I need to have one IP for each device.

66
00:03:25.890 --> 00:03:28.991
That way, they each get their own and they
can all use the same port number if they

67
00:03:28.991 --> 00:03:31.220
want, I can have five
different web servers.

68
00:03:31.220 --> 00:03:36.770
And we do a one-to-one mapping,
we map a public IP to a private IP.

69
00:03:36.770 --> 00:03:39.458
When that happens, the server only
knows about its private IP, so

70
00:03:39.458 --> 00:03:42.585
when it browses out to the Internet or
whatever, it's getting translated.

71
00:03:42.585 --> 00:03:45.553
And that's kind of what's happening
to my Linux server that I stood up

72
00:03:45.553 --> 00:03:46.468
in the last episode.

73
00:03:46.468 --> 00:03:49.584
If we take a look at my
configuration on this one,

74
00:03:49.584 --> 00:03:53.081
I gave mine an address of 10.0.222.101.

75
00:03:53.081 --> 00:03:54.425
That's my address.

76
00:03:54.425 --> 00:03:58.769
When I go out to the Internet,
I can't because I start with a 10, and

77
00:03:58.769 --> 00:04:02.270
that's an RFC 1918, or a private address.

78
00:04:02.270 --> 00:04:03.400
So I've gotta get translated.

79
00:04:04.490 --> 00:04:06.610
If you've got a firewall in place,
or a router,

80
00:04:06.610 --> 00:04:08.437
it's likely already doing this for you.

81
00:04:08.437 --> 00:04:13.806
And if I go and
browse to a site like showmemy.info,

82
00:04:13.806 --> 00:04:18.571
I can see what the Internet
sees as my address.

83
00:04:18.571 --> 00:04:23.189
And my address is showing is 66.249.88.51.

84
00:04:23.189 --> 00:04:25.510
But that's not what's
assigned to my server.

85
00:04:25.510 --> 00:04:28.548
That's because the firewall
changed my address on the way out.

86
00:04:28.548 --> 00:04:30.263
That's network address translation.

87
00:04:30.263 --> 00:04:32.520
Now, why do I bring that up here?

88
00:04:32.520 --> 00:04:34.600
I bring it up here because of two reasons.

89
00:04:34.600 --> 00:04:38.070
One, if I didn't have this, I wouldn't
be able to communicate to the Internet.

90
00:04:38.070 --> 00:04:40.920
So there's more than just
assigning an IP to your server.

91
00:04:40.920 --> 00:04:42.816
You've gotta make sure that you've
got the infrastructure in place

92
00:04:42.816 --> 00:04:44.220
to communicate out.

93
00:04:44.220 --> 00:04:50.330
The other reason is if I want to do
a one-to-one mapping, where I map

94
00:04:50.330 --> 00:04:56.000
a public IP to a private IP, that's got to
be done on the firewall or on the router.

95
00:04:56.000 --> 00:04:57.560
That's where it's got to be set up.

96
00:04:57.560 --> 00:04:59.230
>> Now, Don, if you're doing,
like you're saying,

97
00:04:59.230 --> 00:05:03.660
a one-to-one mapping, and let's say I
have ten devices on my internal network,

98
00:05:03.660 --> 00:05:07.310
they're all using those non-routable
addresses, does that mean I have to have

99
00:05:07.310 --> 00:05:11.090
ten public IP addresses if it's
a one-to-one mapping like that?

100
00:05:11.090 --> 00:05:13.615
Yes, yeah, you really do.

101
00:05:13.615 --> 00:05:17.635
If I'm gonna have ten servers, and
I want them all to have a public IP,

102
00:05:17.635 --> 00:05:21.536
I need to call up my ISP and
I need to say, hey, I need ten public IPs.

103
00:05:21.536 --> 00:05:22.790
And they'll give you the ten.

104
00:05:22.790 --> 00:05:26.840
And you could opt to put those ten
IPs right on your machines and

105
00:05:26.840 --> 00:05:28.370
expose them to Internet.

106
00:05:28.370 --> 00:05:30.401
Or you could opt to do
the one-to-one mappings.

107
00:05:30.401 --> 00:05:32.150
Now, what's the difference?

108
00:05:32.150 --> 00:05:34.773
You can have a firewall in-between in
either model, so why not just go ahead and

109
00:05:34.773 --> 00:05:36.390
assign them a public IP?

110
00:05:36.390 --> 00:05:40.660
Well, sometimes it's beneficial to have
the private IP because you can always

111
00:05:40.660 --> 00:05:42.850
change the mapping to
point somewhere else.

112
00:05:42.850 --> 00:05:44.700
When it comes to time
to upgrade that server,

113
00:05:44.700 --> 00:05:47.610
I can bring up a whole new server
with a different internal IP.

114
00:05:47.610 --> 00:05:50.360
So they can both be up and
running at the same time.

115
00:05:50.360 --> 00:05:54.140
And when I get the new server all set
up just the way I want, I can go and

116
00:05:54.140 --> 00:05:56.930
change the mapping and
point it to the new server.

117
00:05:56.930 --> 00:05:57.870
And now it's done, right.

118
00:05:57.870 --> 00:06:01.630
So it makes it very easy to move
the IP from one location to another.

119
00:06:01.630 --> 00:06:04.490
We can also have that IP
point to a load balancer.

120
00:06:04.490 --> 00:06:07.320
I might have 50 servers and
just one IP, and

121
00:06:07.320 --> 00:06:10.250
I'm load balancing that traffic across
the 50 servers on the back end.

122
00:06:10.250 --> 00:06:11.380
You can do that, too.

123
00:06:11.380 --> 00:06:14.350
Not if you assign the IP
directly to the host, but

124
00:06:14.350 --> 00:06:18.660
if you assign the IP to a one- to-one
mapping and use private IPs on the inside.

125
00:06:18.660 --> 00:06:20.440
So it opens you up to a lot of options.

126
00:06:20.440 --> 00:06:22.700
And so that's why I generally
prefer to do it that way,

127
00:06:22.700 --> 00:06:24.270
where you've got one-to-one mappings.

128
00:06:24.270 --> 00:06:26.645
It does mean you've gotta go and
manually enter them in.

129
00:06:26.645 --> 00:06:28.076
But if you were doing static assignments,

130
00:06:28.076 --> 00:06:29.834
you'd have to manually
enter them in there anyway.

131
00:06:29.834 --> 00:06:32.128
So it's not really that much more work,
and

132
00:06:32.128 --> 00:06:35.260
the benefit that you get from
it is typically worth it.

133
00:06:35.260 --> 00:06:38.470
So that's the way that we
normally wanna run on that.

134
00:06:38.470 --> 00:06:39.890
So that's a key thing.

135
00:06:39.890 --> 00:06:42.870
I do wanna talk a little
bit more about PAT, though.

136
00:06:42.870 --> 00:06:45.180
PAT is port address translation.

137
00:06:45.180 --> 00:06:47.590
When you're doing a one-to-one mapping,

138
00:06:47.590 --> 00:06:50.640
you have one internal host
tied to one public IP.

139
00:06:50.640 --> 00:06:54.800
We don't have to worry about
things like port numbers because

140
00:06:54.800 --> 00:06:58.330
you have exclusive access to that IP.

141
00:06:58.330 --> 00:07:00.880
But when you have multiple
machines sharing the same IP,

142
00:07:00.880 --> 00:07:03.450
like what you see on a home router,

143
00:07:03.450 --> 00:07:06.440
you don't have exclusive access to
the IP anymore, you gotta share it.

144
00:07:06.440 --> 00:07:10.790
So if Wes and I are being NATted behind
the same IP, and he brings up a web server

145
00:07:10.790 --> 00:07:16.080
on port 80 and I bring up a web server on
port 80, we can't both work on port 80.

146
00:07:16.080 --> 00:07:19.336
Incoming traffic on port 80
is gonna go to either him or

147
00:07:19.336 --> 00:07:21.497
me, it's not gonna go to both of us.

148
00:07:21.497 --> 00:07:24.356
So one of us might work now,
the other one might work later.

149
00:07:24.356 --> 00:07:26.038
It's gonna go back and forth,
it's not gonna be consistent,

150
00:07:26.038 --> 00:07:27.580
it's not gonna function.

151
00:07:27.580 --> 00:07:29.153
So in those scenarios,

152
00:07:29.153 --> 00:07:32.750
you'll have to leverage what's
called port address translation.

153
00:07:32.750 --> 00:07:34.990
And that's where,
not only do you change the address, but

154
00:07:34.990 --> 00:07:37.140
you change the port number also.

155
00:07:37.140 --> 00:07:39.250
Most home routers do this automatically.

156
00:07:39.250 --> 00:07:43.460
But when you get to higher end devices,
like Cisco ASA firewalls and

157
00:07:43.460 --> 00:07:46.660
stuff, they typically don't do port
address translation unless you

158
00:07:46.660 --> 00:07:47.420
tell them to, right.

159
00:07:47.420 --> 00:07:49.062
Cisco calls it overload.

160
00:07:49.062 --> 00:07:52.620
They have this overload option you
can turn on that tells it to do that.

161
00:07:52.620 --> 00:07:56.382
Cisco assumes that you're doing one-to-one
mappings, right, or that you're creating

162
00:07:56.382 --> 00:07:59.142
a pool that's available,
a dynamic pool, that you can draw from.

163
00:07:59.142 --> 00:08:01.139
>> Now, Don,
that seems like in the home network,

164
00:08:01.139 --> 00:08:03.930
the port address translation would
be a little bit more efficient.

165
00:08:03.930 --> 00:08:06.909
Cuz I can think of my home network right
now and I I think the last time I checked

166
00:08:06.909 --> 00:08:09.299
my router's interface,
I had like ten devices connected.

167
00:08:09.299 --> 00:08:12.212
And I certainly wouldn't wanna
have to go to an ISP and

168
00:08:12.212 --> 00:08:15.125
lease an IP address just to
let my cell phone connect,

169
00:08:15.125 --> 00:08:19.460
maybe not through the cellular network,
but through my Wi-Fi network.

170
00:08:19.460 --> 00:08:22.230
>> Right, and when you're talking
about outbound connections,

171
00:08:22.230 --> 00:08:27.630
when we connect to a system outbound,
you use any number of ports, right?

172
00:08:27.630 --> 00:08:32.071
Cuz the port numbers,
they run from 1 to 65,535.

173
00:08:32.071 --> 00:08:36.288
And the upper block, it's like 49,000 and
something all the way to 65,000 and

174
00:08:36.288 --> 00:08:40.396
something, so it's a good chunk of 15,000
port numbers, those are available for

175
00:08:40.396 --> 00:08:41.074
dynamic use.

176
00:08:41.074 --> 00:08:42.970
You just grab one on your way out.

177
00:08:42.970 --> 00:08:46.940
And so on the way out, people don't
really care what their port number is.

178
00:08:46.940 --> 00:08:48.370
It's the destination, the way in, right?

179
00:08:48.370 --> 00:08:52.548
When you're coming to the server,
it expects web traffic to be on port 80,

180
00:08:52.548 --> 00:08:56.173
it expects FTP traffic to be on port 21,
or SSH to be on port 22.

181
00:08:56.173 --> 00:08:58.521
It expects that, right,
at the server side.

182
00:08:58.521 --> 00:09:02.125
So when you're on your cell phone or
your laptop or your desktop,

183
00:09:02.125 --> 00:09:03.901
we're fine with sharing an IP.

184
00:09:03.901 --> 00:09:06.416
Cuz we're going out,
we're connecting to other people.

185
00:09:06.416 --> 00:09:08.056
But when you're a server,

186
00:09:08.056 --> 00:09:12.063
you're expecting that traffic to
come in on one particular port.

187
00:09:12.063 --> 00:09:14.330
And when that doesn't happen,
it causes problems.

188
00:09:14.330 --> 00:09:16.850
And so that's where you might
need to leverage something

189
00:09:16.850 --> 00:09:20.240
like a one-to-one mapping,
cuz now you have access to those ports,

190
00:09:20.240 --> 00:09:22.260
and you don't have to worry about
conflicting with other people.

191
00:09:22.260 --> 00:09:25.789
So just be aware that that's not something
that you configure on the server itself,

192
00:09:25.789 --> 00:09:28.870
it's something that you configure in your
network infrastructure that you can put in

193
00:09:28.870 --> 00:09:33.462
place and it affects the way you
communicate out to the network, all right?

194
00:09:33.462 --> 00:09:36.330
I see this a lot with Amazon Web Services,
right?

195
00:09:36.330 --> 00:09:39.820
So of you go into AWS and
you spin up a server in EC2,

196
00:09:39.820 --> 00:09:44.730
it used to be that you got a public
IP right there on the server.

197
00:09:44.730 --> 00:09:46.200
It's not like that anymore.

198
00:09:46.200 --> 00:09:49.710
Now you set up these
Virtual Private Containers, these VPCs.

199
00:09:49.710 --> 00:09:54.692
And inside of them, it'll use a 172.16 or
all the way through 31,

200
00:09:54.692 --> 00:09:57.160
one of those private IP ranges.

201
00:09:57.160 --> 00:10:00.630
And they do a one-to-one mapping right
there inside of that cloud infrastructure.

202
00:10:00.630 --> 00:10:02.799
So you see it all over the place now,
and it's pretty common.

203
00:10:04.320 --> 00:10:08.554
All right, another thing to think
about is our MAC address, right?

204
00:10:08.554 --> 00:10:11.480
When I say a MAC address,
I'm not talking about Mac like Macintosh.

205
00:10:11.480 --> 00:10:15.340
I'm talking about a media
access control address.

206
00:10:15.340 --> 00:10:18.530
If I take a look at my Linux box here,
let me just bring this one back up, and

207
00:10:18.530 --> 00:10:19.469
go into my settings.

208
00:10:20.490 --> 00:10:22.440
And go under my Details.

209
00:10:22.440 --> 00:10:29.793
You can see this Hardware Address, right,
mine's 00:0C:29:4A:03:AB, all right.

210
00:10:29.793 --> 00:10:37.010
That is a 48 bit hexadecimal number that's
been burned into my network adapter.

211
00:10:37.010 --> 00:10:39.860
When they manufacture network adapters,
they burn these addresses in.

212
00:10:39.860 --> 00:10:42.580
And in theory they're globally unique.

213
00:10:42.580 --> 00:10:45.090
In other words, there shouldn't be a
network adapter anywhere else in the world

214
00:10:45.090 --> 00:10:47.250
that has this same address.

215
00:10:47.250 --> 00:10:53.542
Now, the way they achieve that, is the
first three values here, for me 00:0C:29,

216
00:10:53.542 --> 00:10:58.707
that's the OID, that identifies
whoever the manufacturer was, right?

217
00:10:58.707 --> 00:11:02.160
I think I've got an Intel adapter here,
so that'll map back to Intel.

218
00:11:02.160 --> 00:11:05.433
And then the last three values,
in my case,

219
00:11:05.433 --> 00:11:10.730
4A:03:AB, identifies this
particular network adapter.

220
00:11:10.730 --> 00:11:12.770
So if I buy five Intel network adapters,

221
00:11:12.770 --> 00:11:16.230
they might all have the same
first three values.

222
00:11:16.230 --> 00:11:18.730
But then they'll have different values for
the last three.

223
00:11:18.730 --> 00:11:20.074
So they're unique, right?

224
00:11:20.074 --> 00:11:23.462
And if I buy cards from Intel and
cards from Broadcom and

225
00:11:23.462 --> 00:11:27.270
cards from whoever else,
they'll have different OIDs.

226
00:11:27.270 --> 00:11:30.352
So they won't match,
just because of the different vendors.

227
00:11:30.352 --> 00:11:35.790
So these MAC addresses are how machines
communicate to their next hop for

228
00:11:35.790 --> 00:11:38.200
their local connections.

229
00:11:38.200 --> 00:11:41.140
If I wanna talk to Wes' laptop
right here beside me on the table,

230
00:11:41.140 --> 00:11:42.480
we're gonna use these
MAC addresses to talk.

231
00:11:42.480 --> 00:11:44.222
That's a layer two address.

232
00:11:44.222 --> 00:11:47.891
We have layer three addresses that helps
us figure out whether we're on the same

233
00:11:47.891 --> 00:11:48.393
network.

234
00:11:48.393 --> 00:11:51.446
But we use the layer two
address to actually talk.

235
00:11:51.446 --> 00:11:54.896
If I'm talking to somebody out on the
Internet, I need to go through a router,

236
00:11:54.896 --> 00:11:57.428
and I'll use the layer two
address to talk to the router.

237
00:11:57.428 --> 00:11:59.958
Now, the nice thing about these is
they're burned in your adapter, so

238
00:11:59.958 --> 00:12:01.278
you don't have to worry about them.

239
00:12:01.278 --> 00:12:04.450
They're just already set,
it's not like I have to set them.

240
00:12:04.450 --> 00:12:05.510
And they're not routable,

241
00:12:05.510 --> 00:12:07.540
they only let you talk to somebody
right there on the same network as you.

242
00:12:07.540 --> 00:12:10.490
So there's no subnets to worry about,
or route statements or

243
00:12:10.490 --> 00:12:14.240
anything, it's just,
you see them on the same link as you.

244
00:12:15.430 --> 00:12:16.838
When you configure a server,

245
00:12:16.838 --> 00:12:19.438
it's not normally something
you have to worry about.

246
00:12:19.438 --> 00:12:21.718
One time, in my entire IT career,

247
00:12:21.718 --> 00:12:27.140
have I seen two physical adapters that
actually had the same MAC address.

248
00:12:27.140 --> 00:12:31.400
And what happens when you do that
is that any traffic destined for

249
00:12:31.400 --> 00:12:33.600
that MAC address ends up being
delivered to both hosts.

250
00:12:33.600 --> 00:12:36.492
And so you end up losing a lot
of bandwidth on those hosts and

251
00:12:36.492 --> 00:12:39.100
you get some erratic behaviors,
it's kind of an odd situation.

252
00:12:39.100 --> 00:12:42.370
It's extremely rare that it occurs,
and it really shouldn't ever happen.

253
00:12:42.370 --> 00:12:45.665
You should never have two adapters
with the same MAC address.

254
00:12:45.665 --> 00:12:50.940
Unfortunately, we don't use as many
physical adapters as we used to.

255
00:12:50.940 --> 00:12:53.180
Now we virtualize everything.

256
00:12:53.180 --> 00:12:54.680
And when you virtualize, yeah,

257
00:12:54.680 --> 00:12:58.055
you've got a physical adapter under
the hood that's tied to the host, but

258
00:12:58.055 --> 00:13:00.805
your virtual machines will
have virtual network adapters.

259
00:13:00.805 --> 00:13:05.240
And those virtual network adapters
have to make up a MAC address.

260
00:13:05.240 --> 00:13:08.770
And so when they do,
they've got on OID, right?

261
00:13:08.770 --> 00:13:15.120
They've got a vendor assigned to them
that we map to VMware or Parallels or

262
00:13:15.120 --> 00:13:18.980
whoever it is, Citrix, whoever is it
that made your virtualization software.

263
00:13:18.980 --> 00:13:22.182
But the remainder of that
address is being made up.

264
00:13:22.182 --> 00:13:27.950
And it's not uncommon to get two virtual
servers that have the same MAC address,

265
00:13:27.950 --> 00:13:29.510
and that can really wreak havoc.

266
00:13:29.510 --> 00:13:32.240
So what I encourage most companies to do

267
00:13:32.240 --> 00:13:35.130
is statically assign MAC
addresses on virtual machines.

268
00:13:35.130 --> 00:13:35.940
It's not hard to do.

269
00:13:35.940 --> 00:13:37.600
You can come in and punch them in.

270
00:13:37.600 --> 00:13:41.520
And keep track of,
I usually use this value right here.

271
00:13:41.520 --> 00:13:46.030
So the first set of three here, that's
gonna identify this as a virtual MAC

272
00:13:46.030 --> 00:13:49.450
address, it's tied to Microsoft or
Hyper-V, right?

273
00:13:49.450 --> 00:13:54.330
And then I'll use the second one
here to identify the server, and

274
00:13:54.330 --> 00:13:56.700
then the other two to
identify the virtual machine.

275
00:13:56.700 --> 00:13:58.280
And so
that way you can kinda keep track of it,

276
00:13:58.280 --> 00:14:01.024
like you keep track of IPs, and make sure
that you don't end up with duplicates

277
00:14:01.024 --> 00:14:02.450
anywhere in your environment, right.

278
00:14:02.450 --> 00:14:04.180
But it can happen.

279
00:14:04.180 --> 00:14:07.320
Now, most operating systems
won't allow you to change it.

280
00:14:07.320 --> 00:14:10.600
So as I'm in here,
I'm in my Linux box, and

281
00:14:10.600 --> 00:14:14.240
as far as it's concerned,
that address is set, right?

282
00:14:14.240 --> 00:14:17.398
Well, if they have the virtualization
features installed,

283
00:14:17.398 --> 00:14:19.490
they'll allow you to override it.

284
00:14:19.490 --> 00:14:23.044
And overriding a MAC address is a tool
that a lot of hackers use to perform man

285
00:14:23.044 --> 00:14:25.316
in the middle attacks and
masquerade attacks.

286
00:14:25.316 --> 00:14:30.058
So it's not necessarily something that
a normal user's gonna make use of, but

287
00:14:30.058 --> 00:14:31.630
on virtual servers it is.

288
00:14:31.630 --> 00:14:35.096
And you'll see right here,
I know this is a virtual adapter,

289
00:14:35.096 --> 00:14:37.490
cuz the eno number is way up there.

290
00:14:37.490 --> 00:14:42.150
Normally, on a Red Hat box, if I had
a physical adapter, I would have eno1,

291
00:14:42.150 --> 00:14:46.830
eno2, eno3, right, for
my Ethernet adapters, and each number.

292
00:14:46.830 --> 00:14:52.016
But in this case, I've got eno16777736
because it's a virtual adapter,

293
00:14:52.016 --> 00:14:54.324
so it assigned a high number to it.

294
00:14:54.324 --> 00:14:58.356
So since it's a virtual adapter,
I could override that address.

295
00:14:58.356 --> 00:15:01.168
And here it's showing me the actual
address of this adapter, or

296
00:15:01.168 --> 00:15:02.060
I could type one in.

297
00:15:02.060 --> 00:15:06.170
Now, why would I wanna type one in
here if it was a physical server?

298
00:15:06.170 --> 00:15:08.875
Well, I might be replacing a old
server with a new server, and

299
00:15:08.875 --> 00:15:11.125
I might have a lot of stuff
tied to that MAC address.

300
00:15:11.125 --> 00:15:14.064
I might have DHCP reservations,
or software licenses, or

301
00:15:14.064 --> 00:15:16.021
other things tied to that MAC address.

302
00:15:16.021 --> 00:15:20.480
So I might want to preserve that MAC
address when I move it over here, right?

303
00:15:20.480 --> 00:15:25.182
Or I might have a one-to-one NAT mapping
where the public IP has a certain MAC tied

304
00:15:25.182 --> 00:15:27.512
to it, and I wanna mirror that MAC here.

305
00:15:27.512 --> 00:15:30.514
Usually it's the other way around, I
wanna mirror this MAC on the net mapping.

306
00:15:30.514 --> 00:15:33.178
But you can go in and
specify that and override it.

307
00:15:33.178 --> 00:15:40.466
So I could type in an address if I wanted,
whatever that happens to be.

308
00:15:40.466 --> 00:15:45.006
And now I know that MAC Address is set and
it'll be a part of that adapter.

309
00:15:45.006 --> 00:15:48.589
Just be careful with this,
on a physical adapter, it's burned in, so

310
00:15:48.589 --> 00:15:51.696
it's still gonna function,
it's still gonna be there, but

311
00:15:51.696 --> 00:15:55.602
you'll have this additional MAC address
tied to the adapter tied to this IP.

312
00:15:55.602 --> 00:15:59.209
If you have more than one IP, potentially
you could have more than one MAC address

313
00:15:59.209 --> 00:16:01.240
tied to the same adapter,
that is Possible.

314
00:16:01.240 --> 00:16:04.032
Especially if you're doing things
like load balancing across adapters.

315
00:16:04.032 --> 00:16:06.946
They'll create a virtual MAC Address
that's shared across the adapters.

316
00:16:06.946 --> 00:16:08.885
That is part of NIC teaming.

317
00:16:08.885 --> 00:16:11.964
NIC teaming is network
interface card teaming.

318
00:16:11.964 --> 00:16:14.641
I'm gonna have two adapters or
three or four adapters, right?

319
00:16:14.641 --> 00:16:19.042
Most servers have at least two network
adapters in them, some have four.

320
00:16:19.042 --> 00:16:21.990
And you can take those and
bond them together.

00:26:56.800 --> 00:26:58.350
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

550
00:26:58.350 --> 00:26:58.920
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

551
00:26:58.920 --> 00:27:00.671
>> And we'll see you next time.

552
00:27:00.671 --> 00:27:07.426
[MUSIC]

553
00:27:07.426 --> 00:27:10.143
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore TCP/IP ports and protocols. They explain the purpose of ports, port ranges, TCP vs. UDP as well as taking a look at some of the common protocols that are used within todays networks.
episodes.title: Ports and Protocols
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:02.232
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.232 --> 00:00:06.543
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.543 --> 00:00:08.290
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.290 --> 00:00:11.958
>> Your watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.958 --> 00:00:16.136
>> Welcome to another great episode here
at ITProTV, I'm your host Wes Bryan, and

6
00:00:16.136 --> 00:00:20.500
in todays episode we're continuing through
a very fun series that is the server plus

7
00:00:20.500 --> 00:00:22.030
series from Comptia.

8
00:00:22.030 --> 00:00:24.970
And joining us in the studios for
this very endeavor is none other than Mr.

9
00:00:24.970 --> 00:00:25.610
Don Pezet.

10
00:00:25.610 --> 00:00:26.720
Don, how are you doing, sir?

11
00:00:26.720 --> 00:00:27.680
>> I'm doing great, Wes,

12
00:00:27.680 --> 00:00:31.190
ready to continue our networking
adventure inside of Server Plus.

13
00:00:31.190 --> 00:00:33.930
In these last couple of episodes,
what we've been doing is tackling network

14
00:00:33.930 --> 00:00:38.150
concepts that we need to know as we deploy
servers to get them ready on the network.

15
00:00:38.150 --> 00:00:40.920
In a previous episode we talked
about assigning IP addresses.

16
00:00:40.920 --> 00:00:44.830
In this episode we're gonna talk
a little bit about network ports.

17
00:00:44.830 --> 00:00:48.690
And ports are really important on
a server, because when we set up a server,

18
00:00:48.690 --> 00:00:51.060
we typically want people to
be able to connect to it.

19
00:00:51.060 --> 00:00:53.890
And that means the server has
some data that's important to

20
00:00:53.890 --> 00:00:54.660
us that we want to share.

21
00:00:54.660 --> 00:00:57.280
And if the data's important to us,
we wanna protect it.

22
00:00:57.280 --> 00:01:01.250
And if you're gonna protect it,
you usually do that with a firewall.

23
00:01:01.250 --> 00:01:03.650
Well, if there's a firewall
in between our server and

24
00:01:03.650 --> 00:01:07.300
our clients, we need to make sure
that we open up the appropriate

25
00:01:07.300 --> 00:01:10.840
ports on that firewall to allow people
to connect to our services, and

26
00:01:10.840 --> 00:01:14.020
don't allow them to connect to any
other ports that are available.

27
00:01:14.020 --> 00:01:16.760
So we do need to have a good
understanding of how these ports work.

28
00:01:16.760 --> 00:01:20.430
What they do and
what some of the common port numbers are.

29
00:01:20.430 --> 00:01:24.970
So let's just start off right off the
beginning here with what ports are, right?

30
00:01:24.970 --> 00:01:28.070
When I connect from my laptop to a server,
right?

31
00:01:28.070 --> 00:01:29.970
So let's say I go to www.google.com.

32
00:01:29.970 --> 00:01:32.310
I go to their website, right.

33
00:01:32.310 --> 00:01:35.150
Well I take my traffic and
I put it into a packet,

34
00:01:35.150 --> 00:01:38.240
that ultimately gets thrown into a frame,
and thrown out across the internet.

35
00:01:38.240 --> 00:01:41.800
And it makes all the way across the world
to wherever Google's servers are.

36
00:01:41.800 --> 00:01:43.580
And it lands on one of their servers.

37
00:01:43.580 --> 00:01:47.287
When the server receives that packet,
how does it know what to do with it?

38
00:01:47.287 --> 00:01:49.270
It looks to the port number.

39
00:01:49.270 --> 00:01:52.812
That packet will have a destination port
number, and the destination port number

40
00:01:52.812 --> 00:01:56.780
helps that server identify
where that traffic needs to go.

41
00:01:56.780 --> 00:02:01.630
So, for example secure web traffic, HTTPS.

42
00:02:01.630 --> 00:02:04.670
HTTPS uses port 443, so

43
00:02:04.670 --> 00:02:09.690
any time a server receives traffic on port
443 it knows that it's secure web traffic.

44
00:02:09.690 --> 00:02:12.770
And it'll say okay,
I need to hand this over to my web server.

45
00:02:12.770 --> 00:02:15.540
Versus if it receives traffic
on something like port 25,

46
00:02:15.540 --> 00:02:17.030
it says hey, that's email traffic.

47
00:02:17.030 --> 00:02:18.670
I need to give that to my email server.

48
00:02:18.670 --> 00:02:22.900
So the port numbers help us to
identify what the traffic is.

49
00:02:22.900 --> 00:02:26.220
And these are being done all the time
in the background of your system and

50
00:02:26.220 --> 00:02:27.810
you don't really notice.

51
00:02:27.810 --> 00:02:31.520
For example, here,
I'll take this Linux box, and

52
00:02:31.520 --> 00:02:34.890
let me get a terminal open and
a web browser.

53
00:02:34.890 --> 00:02:40.100
So I'm gonna browse to our
firewall here in the building.

54
00:02:40.100 --> 00:02:41.810
So if I go to 10.0.0.1,

55
00:02:41.810 --> 00:02:46.840
here's our firewall's web page right it's
a PF Sense firewall and it used HTTPS.

56
00:02:46.840 --> 00:02:50.030
So I made a secure
connection to that firewall.

57
00:02:50.030 --> 00:02:52.320
Well, if I jump over to my terminal.

58
00:02:53.460 --> 00:03:00.460
I can do a netstat -an, and
I'm gonna search for 10.0.0.1, all right.

59
00:03:00.460 --> 00:03:05.340
And what netstat -an does is it says,
show me all of my connections and

60
00:03:06.450 --> 00:03:09.790
do name trans or don't do name
translations, it just shows me the IPs.

61
00:03:09.790 --> 00:03:12.360
Name translations take a long time,
so let's skip those.

62
00:03:12.360 --> 00:03:17.708
And what I can see is that I created
a TCP connection between my laptop,

63
00:03:17.708 --> 00:03:21.518
10.0.222.101, and the firewall,

64
00:03:21.518 --> 00:03:25.978
10.0.0.1, right, there's that connection.

65
00:03:25.978 --> 00:03:29.838
And I've got a source port and
a destination port.

66
00:03:29.838 --> 00:03:32.276
And that destination port,
that's what's really important right?

67
00:03:32.276 --> 00:03:39.160
443, I wanted to connect to a secure
web server, and I did that on port 443.

68
00:03:39.160 --> 00:03:40.710
On the source port,

69
00:03:40.710 --> 00:03:44.110
this is really just a random port
number that I picked myself, right?

70
00:03:44.110 --> 00:03:47.330
You picked it right out of the cloud and
said hey, I'm gonna use this number.

71
00:03:47.330 --> 00:03:48.810
I need a random number,

72
00:03:48.810 --> 00:03:53.470
because what if I open up more than
one tab to that server, right?

73
00:03:53.470 --> 00:03:56.820
So if you think about it if I were
to browse to CNN's web page and

74
00:03:56.820 --> 00:04:01.490
I had three different tabs that
were all opened up to CNN, right?

75
00:04:01.490 --> 00:04:02.960
So let's do this.

76
00:04:02.960 --> 00:04:08.222
So if I go to cnn.com and then I'll do
the same thing in another tab here,

77
00:04:08.222 --> 00:04:12.644
I'll go to cnn.com and
I'll do one more cnn.com, right?

78
00:04:12.644 --> 00:04:17.170
So I've got three connections
to CNN all from my laptop,

79
00:04:17.170 --> 00:04:23.930
my laptop 10:02.22.101,
all connecting out here to this site.

80
00:04:23.930 --> 00:04:27.660
Well when I go to one of these tabs,
I've seen they're all identical.

81
00:04:27.660 --> 00:04:33.570
If I go to one of them and I click on
a link to read this article, right?

82
00:04:33.570 --> 00:04:38.140
See the other tabs didn't change pages,
only this one tab did.

83
00:04:38.140 --> 00:04:39.960
How did it know which tab it went to?

84
00:04:39.960 --> 00:04:42.170
If they all using the same
destination port,

85
00:04:42.170 --> 00:04:44.510
they're all going port,
this is not secure.

86
00:04:44.510 --> 00:04:46.860
This is all going on port 80, right.

87
00:04:46.860 --> 00:04:51.550
Well, the reason it was able to do that,
was because,

88
00:04:51.550 --> 00:04:55.380
back here, if I search for,
I don't know the IP of that one.

89
00:04:55.380 --> 00:04:58.160
So let me just search for
anything on port 80.

90
00:04:58.160 --> 00:05:01.330
I can see all these connections
that I've established on port 80.

91
00:05:01.330 --> 00:05:03.000
And as you look in here,

92
00:05:03.000 --> 00:05:07.060
I'll find duplicates because I've
got more than one connection to CNN.

93
00:05:07.060 --> 00:05:10.782
And, shoot,
they're behind a load balancer.

94
00:05:10.782 --> 00:05:13.932
But, all right, so here's one,
52.204.201.112 and

95
00:05:13.932 --> 00:05:17.170
right down here I've got
another one 52.204.201.112.

96
00:05:17.170 --> 00:05:21.520
So let me shrink down my
search a little bit here.

97
00:05:23.780 --> 00:05:26.127
And we'll search for just that IEP.

98
00:05:26.127 --> 00:05:31.588
Shoot, the connections do time out after a
little bit, they don't stay open forever.

99
00:05:31.588 --> 00:05:32.812
So apparently I waited too long.

100
00:05:32.812 --> 00:05:34.200
All right, we can just look up here.

101
00:05:34.200 --> 00:05:39.306
So when I find those entries and I look at
them, here's one, and my source port was

102
00:05:39.306 --> 00:05:44.201
52612 and if I scroll up to the other one,
my source port was 52610.

103
00:05:44.201 --> 00:05:46.573
And there's probably
a 52611 somewhere in here,

104
00:05:46.573 --> 00:05:49.953
it might have timed out by that point cuz
it's just incrementing by one each time

105
00:05:49.953 --> 00:05:52.640
and that's how we know that
these are two separate tabs.

106
00:05:52.640 --> 00:05:56.100
And when I get the reply from the server,
I know exactly which tab to send it to.

107
00:05:56.100 --> 00:05:58.870
So the source port is really just
used to differentiate traffic.

108
00:05:58.870 --> 00:06:00.161
But the destination port,

109
00:06:00.161 --> 00:06:03.370
that's how I tell the server
what I'm trying to connect to.

110
00:06:03.370 --> 00:06:05.910
So that destination port
is pretty important and

111
00:06:05.910 --> 00:06:08.440
that's used every time we communicate.

112
00:06:08.440 --> 00:06:10.130
That's a part of our communications.

113
00:06:10.130 --> 00:06:12.860
We build a communication with a source and

114
00:06:12.860 --> 00:06:16.640
destination IP and a source and
a destination port number.

115
00:06:16.640 --> 00:06:20.150
And the server receives that traffic and
knows what to do with it.

116
00:06:20.150 --> 00:06:23.580
And when they reply, it flips them around.

117
00:06:23.580 --> 00:06:26.080
So the source from the server is port 80.

118
00:06:26.080 --> 00:06:30.100
But the destination is that random port
number that I chose when I reached out.

119
00:06:30.100 --> 00:06:31.580
So it can come back to me and connect.

120
00:06:31.580 --> 00:06:34.820
So port numbers are in constant
use in every communication you do

121
00:06:34.820 --> 00:06:38.920
in the background, whether it's
IPv4 like I'm showing here or IPv6.

122
00:06:38.920 --> 00:06:43.330
They all use port numbers to be
able to uniquely identify traffic.

123
00:06:44.810 --> 00:06:50.170
Now, when we reach out and connect,
there is more than one way to connect,

124
00:06:50.170 --> 00:06:53.450
you probably notice when I was looking
at it here, see on the left side,

125
00:06:53.450 --> 00:06:55.430
all these show tcp.

126
00:06:55.430 --> 00:06:58.490
Right, these are all using
Transmission Control Protocol.

127
00:06:58.490 --> 00:07:04.450
Well, on IP based networks, there's really
two main protocols we use, TCP and UDP.

128
00:07:05.710 --> 00:07:09.300
Transmission Control Protocol and
User Datagram Protocol.

129
00:07:09.300 --> 00:07:11.790
TCP and UDP really achieve the same goal.

130
00:07:11.790 --> 00:07:14.030
They allow us to talk to
somebody else on the network.

131
00:07:14.030 --> 00:07:16.660
And for the most part,
we don't really care which one we use.

132
00:07:16.660 --> 00:07:19.792
But they do function differently,
the two of them.

133
00:07:19.792 --> 00:07:22.360
TCP is what's called
the reliable protocol.

134
00:07:22.360 --> 00:07:27.790
In other words when I send a packet,
if I send from me to CNN's web server,

135
00:07:27.790 --> 00:07:32.340
I want to guarantee that traffic gets
to CNN and if it doesn't get there,

136
00:07:32.340 --> 00:07:34.740
I wanna retransmit,
I wanna resend it, right?

137
00:07:34.740 --> 00:07:38.410
Because when I communicate I may
often break up one packet into many,

138
00:07:38.410 --> 00:07:40.445
many segments to get it to
fit on the network, right?

139
00:07:40.445 --> 00:07:43.110
Networks can only carry
packets of a certain size.

140
00:07:43.110 --> 00:07:45.700
You have a maximum transmission
unit you have to fall under.

141
00:07:45.700 --> 00:07:49.396
And so, if we have to break something
up into segments, I need to make sure I

142
00:07:49.396 --> 00:07:52.701
get every single piece so
I can put it back together again, right?

143
00:07:52.701 --> 00:07:56.277
I don't want half of my email,
I want all of my email, right?

144
00:07:56.277 --> 00:07:58.640
I don't want half of an image,
I want the whole image.

145
00:07:58.640 --> 00:08:03.043
And we need a way to track that and
keep that straight, and TCP does that.

146
00:08:03.043 --> 00:08:07.501
It keeps track of each segment, so that it
can reassemble them and put them back in

147
00:08:07.501 --> 00:08:12.960
order, and if any piece is missing, it can
request a re-transmit to get those back.

148
00:08:12.960 --> 00:08:17.150
So, when you see TCP working on a network,
it looks like this.

149
00:08:17.150 --> 00:08:19.580
When you send data across, right?

150
00:08:20.630 --> 00:08:22.080
And on the other side,

151
00:08:22.080 --> 00:08:26.170
when it receives that data,
it sends an acknowledgement back.

152
00:08:26.170 --> 00:08:28.890
An acknowledgement is saying yes,
I got the data.

153
00:08:28.890 --> 00:08:32.600
Or it sends a negative acknowledgement,
a NACK back saying, no,

154
00:08:32.600 --> 00:08:34.150
I didn't get the data.

155
00:08:34.150 --> 00:08:35.260
And then we can retransmit it.

156
00:08:35.260 --> 00:08:36.600
We can send it across.

157
00:08:36.600 --> 00:08:39.887
So anytime you communicate with TCP,
there is a handshake that happens,

158
00:08:39.887 --> 00:08:43.439
where you synchronize your sequence
numbers, so that the other side knows what

159
00:08:43.439 --> 00:08:46.849
numbers to expect, and you know what
numbers to expect from the other side.

160
00:08:46.849 --> 00:08:49.991
And that way, if anything gets missed,
you'll know, you'll spot it,

161
00:08:49.991 --> 00:08:54.180
you'll be able to recognize that that's
missing and request a retransmit.

162
00:08:54.180 --> 00:08:57.960
That's good for
reliable transmission of data.

163
00:08:57.960 --> 00:09:00.220
It's not so good for speed though, right?

164
00:09:00.220 --> 00:09:02.748
If I have to request a retransmit,
that's a delay.

165
00:09:02.748 --> 00:09:06.440
So, I've gotta put this on hold, let
me go get what I missed, get that back.

166
00:09:06.440 --> 00:09:07.870
Now we can move forward again.

167
00:09:07.870 --> 00:09:08.530
That doesn't work so

168
00:09:08.530 --> 00:09:12.130
well with real time protocols,
things that need to go fast, right?

169
00:09:12.130 --> 00:09:13.500
What needs to go fast?

170
00:09:13.500 --> 00:09:14.780
Voice over IP.

171
00:09:14.780 --> 00:09:18.180
If I'm the phone with somebody,
and a packet gets dropped,

172
00:09:18.180 --> 00:09:22.950
do I want the call to pause,
have it request that traffic over again?

173
00:09:22.950 --> 00:09:25.650
And then inject that data and
let me hear it?

174
00:09:25.650 --> 00:09:27.520
And then start moving forward again?

175
00:09:27.520 --> 00:09:31.350
Well, it might only be a nanosecond or
two.

176
00:09:31.350 --> 00:09:32.950
It could be a millisecond or two.

177
00:09:32.950 --> 00:09:36.670
It could, more realistically,
be like 40 or 50 milliseconds.

178
00:09:36.670 --> 00:09:37.720
That adds up after awhile.

179
00:09:37.720 --> 00:09:39.030
After enough of these pauses,

180
00:09:39.030 --> 00:09:42.700
the call gets so out of sync,
that it's no longer able to function.

181
00:09:42.700 --> 00:09:46.188
So, for things like streaming video,
streaming audio,

182
00:09:46.188 --> 00:09:50.230
voice-over IP,
we don't normally want retransmits.

183
00:09:50.230 --> 00:09:53.040
Hey, if I miss a packet,
just skip over it.

184
00:09:53.040 --> 00:09:55.400
Most people won't even
notice a single one missing.

185
00:09:55.400 --> 00:09:57.730
If there's a series of them,
yeah, they might hear it.

186
00:09:57.730 --> 00:10:00.120
It drops out for a second,
but just continue on.

187
00:10:00.120 --> 00:10:02.030
Don't put me back.

188
00:10:02.030 --> 00:10:05.250
Anything that's live,
you just want to skip what was missed.

189
00:10:05.250 --> 00:10:07.290
And that's where UDP comes in.

190
00:10:07.290 --> 00:10:10.690
UDP, the User Datagram Protocol,
it just sends.

191
00:10:10.690 --> 00:10:12.820
There's no handshake,
there's no acknowledgement or

192
00:10:12.820 --> 00:10:15.280
negative acknowledgment,
there's just synchronization.

193
00:10:15.280 --> 00:10:18.120
We just start throwing data
over at the other side.

194
00:10:18.120 --> 00:10:19.370
Right, and the other side gets it.

195
00:10:19.370 --> 00:10:21.830
And if it misses something,
big deal, it skips over it.

196
00:10:21.830 --> 00:10:25.990
So, this isn't a reliable transport,
this is called a best effort transport.

197
00:10:25.990 --> 00:10:29.080
We make our best effort to get
the data to the other side, but

198
00:10:29.080 --> 00:10:31.770
if it doesn't get there,
it just doesn't get there.

199
00:10:34.080 --> 00:10:37.931
That's not good for email, that's not good
for file transfers, but it is good for

200
00:10:37.931 --> 00:10:39.544
life things.Things like voice.

201
00:10:39.544 --> 00:10:43.743
>> So, traditional traffic like things
like FTP, like you were talking about,

202
00:10:43.743 --> 00:10:45.152
like SMTP and these mail.

203
00:10:45.152 --> 00:10:49.795
They can handle like transmission control
protocol, almost needed, versus the more.

204
00:10:49.795 --> 00:10:53.385
And high bandwidth, high priority,
very fast delivery,

205
00:10:53.385 --> 00:10:56.965
we're gonna use UDP, because we certainly
don't need things reconstructed,

206
00:10:56.965 --> 00:11:00.095
put back in the right order,
and then process that data.

207
00:11:00.095 --> 00:11:01.375
>> Yeah, absolutely.

208
00:11:01.375 --> 00:11:05.835
And there's scenarios with video with hey,
maybe you want to stream 4k video, and you

209
00:11:05.835 --> 00:11:10.670
want to get the best experience possible,
so you use TCP, you can do it, right?

210
00:11:10.670 --> 00:11:13.040
But, anytime packets drop,

211
00:11:13.040 --> 00:11:17.730
you would have to pause the video while
it kind of got what was missing, right?

212
00:11:17.730 --> 00:11:20.230
So, that's why most video
players will do buffering.

213
00:11:20.230 --> 00:11:24.580
They'll buffer 30 seconds,
or a minute worth of video.

214
00:11:24.580 --> 00:11:26.360
And that way, if packets drop,

215
00:11:26.360 --> 00:11:29.100
it's got 30 seconds to be
able to get what was missing.

216
00:11:29.100 --> 00:11:31.960
And that's fine for
data that's already been created.

217
00:11:31.960 --> 00:11:34.010
But if you're on the phone with somebody,

218

00:12:51.250 --> 00:12:54.030

00:12:54.030 --> 00:12:57.330

00:14:09.489 --> 00:14:13.819

00:20:25.636 --> 00:20:30.192

00:20:40.784 --> 00:20:43.360

As a client you might read your

00:21:38.283 --> 00:21:41.490

00:21:43.750 --> 00:21:47.901

00:21:47.901 --> 00:21:50.810

00:21:50.810 --> 00:21:55.315

00:21:55.315 --> 00:22:00.905

00:22:00.905 --> 00:22:04.330

00:22:04.330 --> 00:22:07.810

00:22:07.810 --> 00:22:10.410
