00:22:10.410 --> 00:22:13.990

00:22:13.990 --> 00:22:14.850

00:22:14.850 --> 00:22:16.280

00:22:16.280 --> 00:22:17.640

00:22:17.640 --> 00:22:21.410
I don't need to worry

00:22:21.410 --> 00:22:23.650

00:22:23.650 --> 00:22:25.740
We could always jump to a whole

00:22:25.740 --> 00:22:28.360

00:22:34.350 --> 00:22:36.950

00:22:36.950 --> 00:22:43.630

00:22:43.630 --> 00:22:47.360

00:22:47.360 --> 00:22:51.370
And so, in that scenario, you can switch

00:22:51.370 --> 00:22:53.870

00:22:53.870 --> 00:22:57.920
So most DNS servers will make that

00:22:57.920 --> 00:23:01.940

00:23:03.080 --> 00:23:06.800
Then the server will respond either

00:23:06.800 --> 00:23:09.560
Now, if it's gonna respond with TCP,

00:23:09.560 --> 00:23:14.050

00:23:14.050 --> 00:23:16.780
But, otherwise, it will just respond

434
00:23:16.780 --> 00:23:19.310
So it can use either one,

you may not always use both of them.

661
00:35:34.360 --> 00:35:37.270
And both of them listen on TCP and UDP.

662
00:35:37.270 --> 00:35:38.507
It's kinda like DNS.

663
00:35:38.507 --> 00:35:45.555
If the query'll fit inside of UDP,
one packet, it'll use it.

664
00:35:45.555 --> 00:35:47.686
If it's too big, we'll switch to TCP.

665
00:35:47.686 --> 00:35:51.985
A lot of systems just use TCP by default,
because if I'm trying to authenticate,

666
00:35:51.985 --> 00:35:53.683
it's not gonna get out of sync.

667
00:35:53.683 --> 00:35:56.771
If I just do a single retransmitter or
a couple of retransmits,

668
00:35:56.771 --> 00:36:00.970
we have to get more than five minutes out
of the sync to really cause a problem.

669
00:36:00.970 --> 00:36:05.300
And a TCP retransmit, if it's exceeding
five minutes, you got bigger problems.

670
00:36:05.300 --> 00:36:06.820
You've got a physical network issue there.

671
00:36:06.820 --> 00:36:09.150
So that's not too big of a deal there.

672
00:36:10.600 --> 00:36:12.910
All right, so
I know that's not the most exciting thing.

673
00:36:12.910 --> 00:36:16.250
But what we did is we just ran through
the protocols that commT expects

674
00:36:16.250 --> 00:36:16.760
you to know, right?

675
00:36:16.760 --> 00:36:19.595
These are the common protocols, and we're
gonna see more of these all throughout

676
00:36:19.595 --> 00:36:23.130
this series as we configure services and
implement things on the network.

677
00:36:23.130 --> 00:36:26.310
The reason we need to know them is that,
first off,

678
00:36:26.310 --> 00:36:28.300
we gotta set up the server,
so there's that.

679
00:36:28.300 --> 00:36:32.170
Secondly, you probably have
a software firewall on your server.

680
00:36:32.170 --> 00:36:36.060
Something like firewall D or IP Tables,
the Windows firewall, whatever.

681
00:36:36.060 --> 00:36:37.590
And you're gonna have to open ports there.

682
00:36:37.590 --> 00:36:40.900
You probably have a hardware firewall that
you need to be able to configure to open

683
00:36:40.900 --> 00:36:42.360
up these ports and make them available.

684
00:36:42.360 --> 00:36:45.540
You probably have nat mappings that
you've gotta configure to forward these

685
00:36:45.540 --> 00:36:46.460
ports appropriately.

686
00:36:46.460 --> 00:36:49.280
These are all parts of implementing
a new server where you need

687
00:36:49.280 --> 00:36:51.060
to understand what your
services are using.

688
00:36:51.060 --> 00:36:54.040
If you forget them,
you're just a search away from finding it.

689
00:36:54.040 --> 00:36:57.280
And if you're using third-party software,
they typically have guides that give you

690
00:36:57.280 --> 00:36:59.380
all the information you need for
configuring it.

691
00:36:59.380 --> 00:37:02.050
But on the exam, they want you
to have these memorized, right?

692
00:37:02.050 --> 00:37:03.910
The standard common ports,

693
00:37:03.910 --> 00:37:06.409
all the ones that we just went through,
you should now those by heart.

694
00:37:07.430 --> 00:37:09.635
>> Yeah, Don,
there's nothing like a laundry list for

695
00:37:09.635 --> 00:37:11.105
memorization on any exam for sure.

696
00:37:11.105 --> 00:37:13.443
But boy,
do they keep coming up over and over.

697
00:37:13.443 --> 00:37:16.929
Just about every exam I think I've taken
has had ports on it at least at one

698
00:37:16.929 --> 00:37:17.681
point or time.

699
00:37:17.681 --> 00:37:20.161
Now Don, it does look like we're
coming to the end of another episode.

700
00:37:20.161 --> 00:37:22.710
But before we do, do you have any
additional piece of advice or

701
00:37:22.710 --> 00:37:24.780
words of wisdom you might
wanna give our viewers?

702
00:37:24.780 --> 00:37:27.990
>> [LAUGH] In the show notes, I've got
a table that lists all these ports.

703
00:37:27.990 --> 00:37:29.380
It really does come down to memorization.

704
00:37:29.380 --> 00:37:30.890
Just look at them and memorize them.

705
00:37:30.890 --> 00:37:33.480
Odds are, like Wes said, you've
already seen them in other exams, so

706
00:37:33.480 --> 00:37:36.510
you should be at least briefly familiar
with them, so it shouldn't be a big deal.

707
00:37:36.510 --> 00:37:38.970
But these are easy questions
to get right on the exam, so

708
00:37:38.970 --> 00:37:41.550
just memorize the table and
you'll be ready to rock.

709
00:37:41.550 --> 00:37:44.580
>> All right, well, that looks like
it's a good place to wrap this one up.

710
00:37:44.580 --> 00:37:46.670
Don, we appreciate you being
here in the studios, and

711
00:37:46.670 --> 00:37:48.300
we appreciate you the viewer watching.

712
00:37:48.300 --> 00:37:51.254
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

713
00:37:51.254 --> 00:37:52.054
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

714
00:37:52.054 --> 00:37:54.217
>> And we'll see you next time.

715
00:37:54.217 --> 00:38:00.259
[MUSIC]

716
00:38:00.259 --> 00:38:03.528
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore  the concepts and components of cable management. They look at copper media and talk about the attributes of CAT 5, 5e, CAT 6 cabling as well as mentioning the different copper cable types such as crossover straight through, and rollover. They will also look at fiber optic cabling and discuss  LC, ST, SC and RJ-45 connectors.
episodes.title: Cable Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:02.703
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:02.703 --> 00:00:06.532
I'm your host Don-
>> [NOISE]

3
00:00:06.532 --> 00:00:08.422
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.422 --> 00:00:12.160
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.160 --> 00:00:14.785
Welcome to another great
episode here at ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:14.785 --> 00:00:16.147
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:16.147 --> 00:00:19.130
And in today's episode we're continuing
through our server plus series,

8
00:00:19.130 --> 00:00:22.345
and we're gonna be talking about a topic
today that really could be a nightmare for

9
00:00:22.345 --> 00:00:24.915
some if you don't get it right,
and that's cable management.

10
00:00:24.915 --> 00:00:27.835
Thank goodness we have our super
guru in the house today, Don Pezet.

11
00:00:27.835 --> 00:00:29.055
Don, how you doing, sir?

12
00:00:29.055 --> 00:00:30.685
>> I'm doing great Wes,
and I'm really excited for

13
00:00:30.685 --> 00:00:32.215
this show cuz it's gonna be a lot of fun.

14
00:00:32.215 --> 00:00:33.056
And the main reason is?

15
00:00:33.056 --> 00:00:33.884
I brought toys.

16
00:00:33.884 --> 00:00:36.390
>> [LAUGH]
>> I brought piles of stuff

17
00:00:36.390 --> 00:00:38.210
behind me here to show on this episode.

18
00:00:38.210 --> 00:00:40.662
We're gonna be taking a look
at some of the cables and

19
00:00:40.662 --> 00:00:43.072
cable types that are used
in a typical data center.

20
00:00:43.072 --> 00:00:45.571
And we're gonna talk a little bit
about how those cables are run and

21
00:00:45.571 --> 00:00:47.285
managed in solani in that environment.

22
00:00:47.285 --> 00:00:51.145
It's a little bit different than how
you might do it in your office or home.

23
00:00:51.145 --> 00:00:54.735
When you're in a data center there's a lot
of things we have to be concerned with and

24
00:00:54.735 --> 00:00:56.435
we've gotta make sure that
we manage things properly.

25
00:00:56.435 --> 00:00:58.585
So, we're gonna get
a chance to see all that,

26
00:00:58.585 --> 00:01:02.415
make sure we've got a good grasp on all
the things that Comte expects us to know.

27
00:01:02.415 --> 00:01:05.185
Now, where I wanna start is with

28
00:01:05.185 --> 00:01:07.770
the cabling types that
are really the most common.

29
00:01:07.770 --> 00:01:10.770
When you've got a server rack,
like the racks that are behind us here,

30
00:01:10.770 --> 00:01:12.710
we've got a number of
servers that are hooked up.

31
00:01:12.710 --> 00:01:15.410
The most common type of cabling
that you're gonna be using is

32
00:01:15.410 --> 00:01:17.070
copper Ethernet cabling.

33
00:01:17.070 --> 00:01:19.350
Right, and we refer to it as UTP or

34
00:01:19.350 --> 00:01:23.730
unshielded twisted pair, which is kind
of a descriptor of how that cable works.

35
00:01:23.730 --> 00:01:27.817
But really what it is at the end of
the day, is a plastic sheathing and

36
00:01:27.817 --> 00:01:30.424
inside of it you have
eight a copper wires.

37
00:01:30.424 --> 00:01:33.030
And then they're all insulated from
each other so you don't get crosstalk.

38
00:01:33.030 --> 00:01:36.200
And there's different
types of that cabling.

39
00:01:36.200 --> 00:01:39.020
And it all looks the same, but

40
00:01:39.020 --> 00:01:41.550
inside it's actually manufactured
a little bit differently.

41
00:01:41.550 --> 00:01:44.210
And so CompTIA wants to make sure that
we've got a good understanding of that

42
00:01:44.210 --> 00:01:45.230
copper cabling and

43
00:01:45.230 --> 00:01:47.950
we're using the right kind when
we're connecting servers together.

44
00:01:47.950 --> 00:01:50.950
And wiring up a rack and
getting things hooked up, right?

45
00:01:50.950 --> 00:01:53.900
So the first kinda
differentiation I wanna make is,

46
00:01:53.900 --> 00:01:56.640
I mentioned there's eight
wires inside of these cables.

47
00:01:56.640 --> 00:02:00.900
When we plug in a server,
you can grab a cable that looks fine but

48
00:02:00.900 --> 00:02:04.190
is actually different than
what you expect it to be.

49
00:02:04.190 --> 00:02:07.570
And let me show you guys an example
to kind of drive this point home.

50
00:02:07.570 --> 00:02:11.020
I've got a few different cables
laying around back here.

51
00:02:11.020 --> 00:02:12.660
Just bring up a few examples.

52
00:02:12.660 --> 00:02:16.580
So, what I'm looking at right here,
this is a small link,

53
00:02:16.580 --> 00:02:18.340
a little bit more than a foot.

54
00:02:18.340 --> 00:02:21.686
Actually, what is this, category 6?

55
00:02:21.686 --> 00:02:25.240
Yeah, this is category 6 unshielded
twisted pair of cabling.

56
00:02:25.240 --> 00:02:27.710
All right,
that name unshielded twisted pair,

57
00:02:27.710 --> 00:02:31.120
if you're not familiar with it,
comes from, well first, it's unshielded.

58
00:02:31.120 --> 00:02:35.460
Back in the old days wherein coaxial
cable, a lot of coaxial cable had a tin

59
00:02:35.460 --> 00:02:39.100
foil layer inside that wrapped around
its core and that was the shielding.

60
00:02:39.100 --> 00:02:40.558
We don't have that anymore.

61
00:02:40.558 --> 00:02:44.264
We don't have that because with coaxial
cable you have a single copper core that

62
00:02:44.264 --> 00:02:46.540
runs through the middle of the cable.

63
00:02:46.540 --> 00:02:49.270
But when you've got
twisted pair like this,

64
00:02:49.270 --> 00:02:51.600
we've got a number of cables inside of it.

65
00:02:51.600 --> 00:02:54.100
And here, I'm gonna take,
we're gonna go dangerous today.

66
00:02:54.100 --> 00:02:56.202
I'm gonna take a razor blade and
cut this open so

67
00:02:56.202 --> 00:02:58.420
we can kind of see what it
looks like on the inside.

68
00:02:58.420 --> 00:03:03.090
And what we're gonna see here
are the eight wires that are inside of it.

69
00:03:03.090 --> 00:03:09.402
And they're twisted together and
they're twisted oddly enough into pairs.

70
00:03:09.402 --> 00:03:11.990
Right, so
that's where the unshielded twisted pair,

71
00:03:11.990 --> 00:03:13.460
part of that name, comes from.

72
00:03:13.460 --> 00:03:17.270
So, when you look at that,
we've got blue, green, orange,

73
00:03:17.270 --> 00:03:19.310
and brown, twisted together.

74
00:03:19.310 --> 00:03:21.350
And there's a white wire
twisted with each one, and

75
00:03:21.350 --> 00:03:23.880
the white actually has a little
bit of color to it also.

76
00:03:23.880 --> 00:03:25.830
So, the one that's wrapped
around green here,

77
00:03:25.830 --> 00:03:27.700
is probably the easiest to see on camera.

78
00:03:28.760 --> 00:03:30.310
If we take a look at that one.

79
00:03:30.310 --> 00:03:32.730
The white cable isn't just white,

80
00:03:32.730 --> 00:03:37.440
it's actually white with little splashes
of green on it every here and there.

81
00:03:37.440 --> 00:03:40.480
To show you that that's the white
cable that pairs up with the green.

82
00:03:40.480 --> 00:03:44.380
And that twist keeps electrical
interference out of the cable.

83
00:03:44.380 --> 00:03:48.990
When you have a cable run through a wall
or a rack or near lighting or whatever,

84
00:03:48.990 --> 00:03:52.520
you can get a lot of electromagnetic
interference into the cable itself.

85
00:03:52.520 --> 00:03:54.920
And so by having that twist,
it prevents it.

86
00:03:54.920 --> 00:03:58.080
And that twist also makes
it where we don't need that

87
00:03:58.080 --> 00:04:00.800
foil wrapping around it
like we had with coax.

88
00:04:00.800 --> 00:04:02.430
If I were to take a coaxial cable and

89
00:04:02.430 --> 00:04:05.320
cut it open, which I've got
a length of around here somewhere.

90
00:04:05.320 --> 00:04:08.190
If I were to cut that open you'd actually
see a little piece of tin foil that wraps

91
00:04:08.190 --> 00:04:10.010
around the core that
isolates that cable and

92
00:04:10.010 --> 00:04:12.650
makes sure that we don't get
interference that way, all right.

93
00:04:12.650 --> 00:04:16.320
Now, as far as the wires,
there's eight wires in there.

94
00:04:16.320 --> 00:04:20.316
And if I look at terminated cable, so
here is a terminated cable here is one

95
00:04:20.316 --> 00:04:24.520
is ready to be used on a server is
got RJ-45 jacks that are stuck on it.

96
00:04:24.520 --> 00:04:26.770
I can plug that right
into a network adapter,

97
00:04:26.770 --> 00:04:30.620
I can plug this on into a switch or
a wall and I'm ready to go, right?

98
00:04:30.620 --> 00:04:35.894
Well, I've gotta pay attention to
what's going on inside of that cable.

99
00:04:35.894 --> 00:04:38.640
The wires are arranged in a certain order,
and

100
00:04:38.640 --> 00:04:41.900
that order influences how
this cable functions.

101
00:04:41.900 --> 00:04:44.210
Now when I look at this one,
the connector on the left and

102
00:04:44.210 --> 00:04:46.970
the connector on the right
are in the same order.

103
00:04:46.970 --> 00:04:50.760
So I've got white orange orange,
white green blue, white blue green,

104
00:04:50.760 --> 00:04:54.540
white brown brown,
on both connectors in that same order.

105
00:04:54.540 --> 00:04:57.800
So this is what's considered
a straight-through cable, and

106
00:04:57.800 --> 00:05:02.650
with a cable like this,
this is what we use to connect a server or

107
00:05:02.650 --> 00:05:05.250
workstation or laptop to a switch, right?

108
00:05:05.250 --> 00:05:07.675
This is what we connect
a device to a switch.

109
00:05:07.675 --> 00:05:13.120
Now, there are scenarios where the cables
are in different orders on the two sides.

110
00:05:13.120 --> 00:05:14.540
And when they're in a different order,

111
00:05:14.540 --> 00:05:17.690
what you're normally looking at is
what's called a crossover cable.

112
00:05:17.690 --> 00:05:22.250
A crossover cable is designed to connect
a computer directly to another computer.

113
00:05:22.250 --> 00:05:25.290
Computers don't expect to be
plugged directly into each other.

114
00:05:25.290 --> 00:05:28.060
They expect there to be a switch or
a hub in between them.

115
00:05:28.060 --> 00:05:29.770
But if you're just running
between two machines,

116
00:05:29.770 --> 00:05:33.790
a crossover cable is actually
flipping two of the wires.

117
00:05:33.790 --> 00:05:37.310
And let me show you
what I'm talking about.

118
00:05:37.310 --> 00:05:41.300
When you look at a straight through cable,
it looks like this,

119
00:05:41.300 --> 00:05:44.010
see how you've got white green green,
white orange blue.

120
00:05:44.010 --> 00:05:48.073
This is a different standard and what I
said a moment ago is the 568B standard,

121
00:05:48.073 --> 00:05:49.946
on the slide here I've got 568A.

122
00:05:49.946 --> 00:05:50.932
It's another standard,

123
00:05:50.932 --> 00:05:53.940
they've effectively work the same
when it comes to patch cables.

124
00:05:53.940 --> 00:06:00.680
But the transmits on one side are supposed
to be mapped to the receive on the other

125
00:06:00.680 --> 00:06:03.680
side, and the receive on one side is
mapped to the transmit from the other.

126
00:06:03.680 --> 00:06:07.430
So one side is transmitting to the others
receiver, that's what you would expect.

127
00:06:07.430 --> 00:06:09.850
And one side is receiving what
the other is transmitting.

128
00:06:10.950 --> 00:06:14.290
Well if you look at it here,
it's not like that, is it?

129
00:06:14.290 --> 00:06:16.900
My cables run to the same
place on each side.

130
00:06:16.900 --> 00:06:21.255
So my transmit on one side would be
running to the transmit on the other side.

131
00:06:21.255 --> 00:06:23.420
We'd both be transmitting with each
other and we'd get a collision.

132
00:06:23.420 --> 00:06:25.540
So that doesn't work.

133
00:06:25.540 --> 00:06:26.955
Well, switches expect that.

134
00:06:26.955 --> 00:06:29.940
Switches expecting you to be communicating
that way and they are ready to receive it.

135
00:06:29.940 --> 00:06:30.685
So are hubs.

136
00:06:30.685 --> 00:06:32.700
But another computer isn't.

137
00:06:32.700 --> 00:06:35.810
So if we're running a cable
directly between computers,

138
00:06:35.810 --> 00:06:38.610
we'll have to do a crossover.

139
00:06:38.610 --> 00:06:42.080
And with the crossover here
you can see where pins one and

140
00:06:42.080 --> 00:06:46.190
two don't just run right to pin one and
two over on the the other side.

141
00:06:46.190 --> 00:06:50.380
Instead pin one and
two run over here to pins three and six.

142
00:06:50.380 --> 00:06:54.470
The transmits on one side are mapped
to the receive on the other.

143
00:06:54.470 --> 00:06:57.600
Now if I just run into the server,
into the storage closet and

144
00:06:57.600 --> 00:06:58.830
grab a cable real quick, I'm like,

145
00:06:58.830 --> 00:07:02.310
here I got this, I can go plug it
into my servers, it might not work.

146
00:07:02.310 --> 00:07:06.660
Because it could be a straight through
cable or it could be a crossover cable.

147
00:07:06.660 --> 00:07:09.550
You've gotta look at
the connector to verify.

148
00:07:09.550 --> 00:07:14.070
>> Don with that crossover cable,
essentially is it right to say that

149
00:07:14.070 --> 00:07:17.220
the crossover cable is essentially
doing what the switch would be doing?

150
00:07:17.220 --> 00:07:19.790
When it comes to forwarding
information from transmit and

151
00:07:19.790 --> 00:07:24.260
receive, it's crossing itself so it's
kind of acting like the switch with out

152
00:07:24.260 --> 00:07:26.860
actually doing any
communications switching.

153
00:07:26.860 --> 00:07:28.910
>> Yeah, I mean,
you don't get the buffering,

154
00:07:28.910 --> 00:07:30.810
you don't get the Mac
address table look ups.

155
00:07:30.810 --> 00:07:33.600
But you don't need that when it's a point
to point cable between two nodes.

156
00:07:33.600 --> 00:07:35.520
It just gets them connected quick and
dirty and off you go.

157
00:07:35.520 --> 00:07:39.010
So very simple, very easy to get up and
running and off you go.

158
00:07:39.010 --> 00:07:41.910
But typically we're not gonna
use crossover cables, right?

159
00:07:41.910 --> 00:07:44.050
When you're in a data center,
you've got switches.

160
00:07:44.050 --> 00:07:46.345
We usually have a switch at
the top of every rack and

161
00:07:46.345 --> 00:07:49.365
then those switches all aggregate
into a core switch somewhere.

162
00:07:49.365 --> 00:07:50.583
We don't usually use crossover cables.

163
00:07:50.583 --> 00:07:54.222
Now, if you're running switch to switch,
you use a crossover cable then.

164
00:07:54.222 --> 00:07:57.246
But most switches these
days do what's called MDIX.

165
00:07:57.246 --> 00:07:59.740
They’ll detect when they
should do a crossover and

166
00:07:59.740 --> 00:08:03.227
they'll just automatically do it in

606
00:31:37.545 --> 00:31:39.575
I know we've had this conversation before.

607
00:31:39.575 --> 00:31:42.755
What is the benefit when it
comes to the cable versus

608
00:31:42.755 --> 00:31:44.465
the ports on your switch to an LC?

609
00:31:44.465 --> 00:31:45.199
What's the benefit of an LC connector?

610
00:31:45.199 --> 00:31:45.830
>> Okay, so,

611
00:31:45.830 --> 00:31:49.895
there's actually three different types
of connectors that you might see.

612
00:31:49.895 --> 00:31:54.452
And as far as benefits,
they all provide the same speed.

613
00:31:54.452 --> 00:31:57.013
They all provide the same bandwidth and
functionality.

614
00:31:57.013 --> 00:31:59.478
So we don't normally
care about the connector,

615
00:31:59.478 --> 00:32:01.770
we just want to get the one that fits.

616
00:32:01.770 --> 00:32:04.400
But they have changed over the years and
there's reasons for that.

617
00:32:04.400 --> 00:32:05.940
The original connectors,

618
00:32:05.940 --> 00:32:09.110
the ones we saw the most,
were what were called ST connectors.

619
00:32:09.110 --> 00:32:10.590
And I don't have any of
those laying around so

620
00:32:10.590 --> 00:32:13.770
I've got a picture here on my laptop
of what an ST connector looks like.

621
00:32:13.770 --> 00:32:15.670
This is what ST looked like.

622
00:32:15.670 --> 00:32:18.140
They were basically little
round connectors, and

623
00:32:18.140 --> 00:32:20.190
they weren't stuck together,
they were independent.

624
00:32:20.190 --> 00:32:23.040
So you could flip transmit and
receive really easily with these and

625
00:32:23.040 --> 00:32:26.100
they just snapped on
like a BNC cable would.

626
00:32:26.100 --> 00:32:30.540
You still see these used in a lot
of fiber termination closets.

627
00:32:30.540 --> 00:32:34.670
So the network guys that run them through
the walls, and run them to an MDF or

628
00:32:34.670 --> 00:32:38.590
SDF somewhere, when they run those
they'll typically use these connectors

629
00:32:38.590 --> 00:32:41.560
because it's so
easy to flip transmit and receive.

630
00:32:41.560 --> 00:32:44.420
Really easy to maintain these and
so that's where they get used.

631
00:32:44.420 --> 00:32:48.170
They're not so good on servers, where
it's very easy to confuse the two and

632
00:32:48.170 --> 00:32:48.700
mess those up.

633
00:32:48.700 --> 00:32:51.550
And they take a lot of room,
the connectors they stick out.

634
00:32:52.550 --> 00:32:56.440
The female side of this connector
protrudes from the card and

635
00:32:56.440 --> 00:32:57.320
that's always a problem, too.

636
00:32:57.320 --> 00:32:59.670
It makes it harder to replace the card and
all that.

637
00:32:59.670 --> 00:33:02.410
So, they're not the most
convenient connectors.

638
00:33:02.410 --> 00:33:05.090
And so
that's where the SC connector came from,

639
00:33:05.090 --> 00:33:07.830
that's this other one that I showed
on camera a little bit earlier.

640
00:33:07.830 --> 00:33:13.350
This is the SC connector, and with
the SC there two big square connectors,

641
00:33:13.350 --> 00:33:16.700
I've gotta protector in one of them,
two square connectors there.

642
00:33:16.700 --> 00:33:19.860
And they're in a little sheathing
here that is, again, not so

643
00:33:19.860 --> 00:33:22.916
hard to separate out and
swap transmitted receiver if you need to.

644
00:33:22.916 --> 00:33:28.500
And these were really the standard
connector throughout the 1990s.

645
00:33:28.500 --> 00:33:31.990
If you were doing a data center in
the 1990s, and even in the early 2000s,

646
00:33:31.990 --> 00:33:34.380
you were running these connectors.

647
00:33:34.380 --> 00:33:37.760
On these, the female side
is recessed into the cards.

648
00:33:37.760 --> 00:33:40.030
These pop right into the card,
and that's that.

649
00:33:41.310 --> 00:33:44.288
These would still be in use today,
if it weren't for the size.

650
00:33:44.288 --> 00:33:45.750
They're just big.

651
00:33:45.750 --> 00:33:47.406
And when you look at an SFP,

652
00:33:47.406 --> 00:33:52.378
they tried to get the size of fiber down
to about the size of an RJ45 jack, right?

653
00:33:52.378 --> 00:33:53.579
Of a regular network cable, right.

654
00:33:53.579 --> 00:33:57.800
And this is significantly bigger, so
that's not gonna work out, right?

655
00:33:57.800 --> 00:34:02.780
So what they did is they came up with a
new connector that's effectively the same.

656
00:34:02.780 --> 00:34:06.400
I still have the two square posts
inside of it, they're just smaller.

657
00:34:06.400 --> 00:34:10.410
The fiber cable is really small anyway,
you didn't need all this bulk around it.

658
00:34:10.410 --> 00:34:13.540
So they just shrunk it down,
functionality wise, they're the same.

659
00:34:13.540 --> 00:34:16.880
And that's why you can get
adapter cables like this one

660
00:34:16.880 --> 00:34:20.050
where I've got LC on one side and
ST on the other,

661
00:34:20.050 --> 00:34:24.760
I mean SC on the other, it doesn't matter
cuz the fiber is fiber on the inside.

662
00:34:24.760 --> 00:34:25.710
I'm just getting the one that fits.

663
00:34:25.710 --> 00:34:28.390
So this is what we used back in
the day when we were migrating.

664
00:34:28.390 --> 00:34:30.520
When you had some switches
with the old connector and

665
00:34:30.520 --> 00:34:32.880
other switches with the new
connector you'd run these.

666
00:34:32.880 --> 00:34:36.870
And it would connect it to and off you
went, that was it, it was that easy.

667
00:34:36.870 --> 00:34:40.885
On newer equipment like what you
see behind me, we just get these.

668
00:34:40.885 --> 00:34:44.040
LC on both sides and
you run everything LC.

669
00:34:44.040 --> 00:34:48.410
We even have LC in our fiber closet, for
the fiber for the building, it's all LC.

670
00:34:48.410 --> 00:34:52.350
I don't think we have any other connectors
in production in the building anywhere

671
00:34:52.350 --> 00:34:54.480
other than what's laying
on this desk right here.

672
00:34:54.480 --> 00:34:57.320
So, those are some of
the different connectors and

673
00:34:57.320 --> 00:34:58.650
as far as advantages and stuff,

674
00:34:58.650 --> 00:35:01.850
there's not really an advantage on one
connector over another other than size.

675
00:35:03.100 --> 00:35:05.820
All right Wes, I've got a few more
things that I need to talk about but

676
00:35:05.820 --> 00:35:07.750
I know that we're short on time.

677
00:35:07.750 --> 00:35:10.250
So I need to talk a little bit
more about some of the other

678
00:35:10.250 --> 00:35:11.090
connectors that are out there.

679
00:35:11.090 --> 00:35:13.180
And we need to talk about
cable management, or

680
00:35:13.180 --> 00:35:15.700
how we run those cables
through the server rack.

681
00:35:15.700 --> 00:35:18.730
So that's all gonna come up here,
in I guess in a part two.

682
00:35:18.730 --> 00:35:19.510
What do you think Wes?

683
00:35:19.510 --> 00:35:22.118
>> Hey that sounds good,
in fact I can't wait to see more goodies.

684
00:35:22.118 --> 00:35:24.970
Man hey, when you've got all
the goodies laid in front of the table,

685
00:35:24.970 --> 00:35:26.820
I'm gonna be excited about that one, Don.

686
00:35:26.820 --> 00:35:28.360
I'll tell you what we'll do, exactly that.

687
00:35:28.360 --> 00:35:31.710
But before we do, do you wanna close out
anything on copper media and fiber or

688
00:35:31.710 --> 00:35:33.570
we're gonna go ahead and
save that for the part two?

689
00:35:33.570 --> 00:35:35.310
>> Let's save it for
the next one cuz I need to talk about,

690
00:35:35.310 --> 00:35:38.030
we got a question in the chat
room I need to talk about anyway,

691
00:35:38.030 --> 00:35:40.840
about the fiber that's run through walls,
through structures.

692
00:35:40.840 --> 00:35:43.310
That's different than the fiber
I'm showing you here, and so

693
00:35:43.310 --> 00:35:45.890
we need to address that a little bit and
just kinda tidy that up.

694
00:35:45.890 --> 00:35:48.680
So just know, there is more to come.

695
00:35:48.680 --> 00:35:49.220
>> All right, Don.

696
00:35:49.220 --> 00:35:52.640
Well as always, we appreciate you being in
the studio with us and we appreciate you,

697
00:35:52.640 --> 00:35:53.980
the viewer, watching.

698
00:35:53.980 --> 00:35:56.980
Signing out for IT Pro TV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

699
00:35:56.980 --> 00:35:57.580
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

700
00:35:57.580 --> 00:35:59.988
>> And we'll see you next time.

701
00:35:59.988 --> 00:36:05.713
[MUSIC]

702
00:36:05.713 --> 00:36:09.036
>> Thank you for watching IT Pro Tv.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their exploration on the concepts and components of cable management. They look at topics like cable placement and routing through vertical and horizontal management trays, bend radius protection and cable channels.
episodes.title: Cable Management Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:02.995
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.995 --> 00:00:08.395
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.395 --> 00:00:12.110
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.110 --> 00:00:15.760
>> Welcome to another great episode here
at ITPRO.TV, I'm your host Wes Bryan.

5
00:00:15.760 --> 00:00:19.710
And in today's episode, we're
continuing along in our Server+ track.

6
00:00:19.710 --> 00:00:22.520
We're actually coming back with
a part two on cable management.

7
00:00:22.520 --> 00:00:25.440
Joining us in the studios today
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

8
00:00:25.440 --> 00:00:26.460
Don, how are you doing, sir?

9
00:00:26.460 --> 00:00:27.180
>> I'm doing great, Wes.

10
00:00:27.180 --> 00:00:31.700
Ready to continue our cable adventure,
where we have been talking about copper

11
00:00:31.700 --> 00:00:35.140
cabling and fiber cabling that we use
in servers and typical data centers.

12
00:00:35.140 --> 00:00:37.210
I talked about a lot of
stuff in the last episode.

13
00:00:37.210 --> 00:00:40.050
And I just wanted to continue on with a
few more things we need to be aware of out

14
00:00:40.050 --> 00:00:43.020
there in the real world,
as well as on the exam.

15
00:00:43.020 --> 00:00:45.350
So let's just pick right
back up where we left off.

16
00:00:45.350 --> 00:00:47.170
I think I ended,
we were still talking about fiber.

17
00:00:47.170 --> 00:00:51.530
So let me continue on with fiber a bit
before we move into cable management.

18
00:00:51.530 --> 00:00:54.108
Now, as I waved about
the cables in the last episode,

19
00:00:54.108 --> 00:00:57.170
I think the two main cables that I was
showing were these two guys right here.

20
00:00:57.170 --> 00:01:00.150
I talked about the different
connectors and the speeds and all that.

21
00:01:00.150 --> 00:01:03.980
And one thing I never really mentioned
were the colors of the cable.

22
00:01:03.980 --> 00:01:07.260
I don't normally think about it too much,
but it is worth mentioning.

23
00:01:07.260 --> 00:01:11.060
You might have noticed that this cable
is light blue and this cable is yellow.

24
00:01:11.060 --> 00:01:14.540
And maybe you didn't care,
right, most people don't.

25
00:01:14.540 --> 00:01:17.760
When you have a copper cable,
like Cat 5 or Cat 6,

26
00:01:17.760 --> 00:01:19.240
whatever, the color doesn't matter.

27
00:01:19.240 --> 00:01:20.610
You just buy the color
that looks prettiest or

28
00:01:20.610 --> 00:01:21.780
whichever color is the cheapest.

29
00:01:21.780 --> 00:01:23.550
That's it, right, we don't care.

30
00:01:23.550 --> 00:01:26.920
But with fiber cabling,
the color actually does matter.

31
00:01:26.920 --> 00:01:30.540
The coloring is tied to
which standard the cable is.

32
00:01:30.540 --> 00:01:35.840
Now, you can buy fiber cabling that's
not colored to standard if you want.

33
00:01:35.840 --> 00:01:38.920
But typically it is going
to be colored to standard.

34
00:01:38.920 --> 00:01:42.472
And that's important because you don't
wanna just assume that it's a certain

35
00:01:42.472 --> 00:01:43.010
standard.

36
00:01:43.010 --> 00:01:45.190
And you can read on
the sheathing what it is.

37
00:01:45.190 --> 00:01:48.780
They write it on there just like
the Cat 6 cabling and whatever.

38
00:01:48.780 --> 00:01:53.242
So this yellow cabling is some
of the older, standard cable.

39
00:01:53.242 --> 00:01:56.690
This cable's actually pretty old, so
this is isn't what we'd normally use.

40
00:01:56.690 --> 00:01:59.160
But in a typical data center these days,

41
00:01:59.160 --> 00:02:00.860
you're gonna be using light
blue cabling like this.

42
00:02:00.860 --> 00:02:03.300
Light blue means OM3.

43
00:02:03.300 --> 00:02:07.890
OM3 is fiber optic cable capable of
carrying 10 gigabits of traffic.

44
00:02:07.890 --> 00:02:12.310
Now, on a 10 gig network, you're gonna
want a cable capable of carrying 10 gigs.

45
00:02:12.310 --> 00:02:14.640
And so OM3 is what we need.

46
00:02:14.640 --> 00:02:18.510
If you're doing 40 gig, well,
OM3 can actually carry that, too.

47
00:02:18.510 --> 00:02:20.110
So it's got a little bit of
future-proofing in it, and

48
00:02:20.110 --> 00:02:21.380
this is what we're going to run.

49
00:02:21.380 --> 00:02:23.270
This is what you'll see in
the racks behind us here.

50
00:02:23.270 --> 00:02:24.990
It's what we run here in our building.

51
00:02:24.990 --> 00:02:27.280
Now, if you have the older cable,
you're not out of luck.

52
00:02:27.280 --> 00:02:29.560
You may just not be able to
push some of the higher speeds.

53
00:02:29.560 --> 00:02:31.800
You may be able to,
you can always try it out.

54
00:02:31.800 --> 00:02:35.600
But they measure a lot of this very
specifically cuz we're talking about laser

55
00:02:35.600 --> 00:02:38.210
beams, and they need a high level
of accuracy over this stuff.

56
00:02:38.210 --> 00:02:40.790
So that's an important concern
when you deal with a cable, and

57
00:02:40.790 --> 00:02:42.980
the color actually does matter.

58
00:02:42.980 --> 00:02:47.670
I don't particularly like light blue, but
that's just the color that we've got.

59
00:02:47.670 --> 00:02:51.280
The other thing that I want to mention is
that all of the cabling that I showed in

60
00:02:51.280 --> 00:02:55.280
the last episode was cabling that
we'd use in our server racks.

61
00:02:55.280 --> 00:02:58.640
That we, as system admins,
would actually run between our servers and

62
00:02:58.640 --> 00:03:02.700
our switches, the things that we'd go
out and buy patch cables for and so on.

63
00:03:02.700 --> 00:03:05.770
This is not what you
would run in your wall.

64
00:03:05.770 --> 00:03:08.480
This is not infrastructure cabling, right.

65
00:03:08.480 --> 00:03:11.082
Infrastructure cabling is different.

66
00:03:11.082 --> 00:03:14.740
It's different mainly because
it's hard to run, right.

67
00:03:14.740 --> 00:03:16.730
So it's hard to run cable through a wall.

68
00:03:16.730 --> 00:03:19.980
So when you buy cabling,
fiber cabling to run through a wall,

69
00:03:19.980 --> 00:03:23.800
it's not typically just two
wires like this, right.

70
00:03:23.800 --> 00:03:26.570
When we talk about fiber patch cables,
there's a transmit and a receive.

71
00:03:26.570 --> 00:03:29.420
It's a pair of fiber optic connections.

72
00:03:29.420 --> 00:03:33.860
But when you run cabling in the wall,
you're gonna go out and you're gonna buy

73
00:03:33.860 --> 00:03:39.070
a giant spool of cabling, which would
normally be pretty hard to lift.

74
00:03:39.070 --> 00:03:40.830
But this one's fairly used up.

75
00:03:40.830 --> 00:03:44.370
This is an actual cable that we use to run

76
00:03:44.370 --> 00:03:46.460
fiber over to the other
side of our building.

77
00:03:46.460 --> 00:03:47.860
Just a few weeks ago.

78
00:03:47.860 --> 00:03:51.570
So you'll buy a spool of fiber
optic cabling like this.

79
00:03:51.570 --> 00:03:55.570
And inside of the spool,
notice this spool is light blue.

80
00:03:55.570 --> 00:03:58.910
So just like the patch cable this
is light blue because this is OM3,

81
00:03:58.910 --> 00:04:00.630
same type of fiber.

82
00:04:00.630 --> 00:04:05.390
And the cabling, itself,
is not two wires stuck together.

83
00:04:05.390 --> 00:04:09.179
Let me get this where we can
zoom in on it a bit and see.

84
00:04:10.380 --> 00:04:14.740
When I held up that patch cable over here,
if you look at it,

85
00:04:14.740 --> 00:04:19.980
you can actually see where
it's two wires stuck together.

86
00:04:19.980 --> 00:04:24.250
I shouldn't call them wires cuz they're
fiber strands, right, strands of fiber.

87
00:04:24.250 --> 00:04:27.450
So there's two strands stuck together.

88
00:04:27.450 --> 00:04:32.360
When I look at this cable from the spool,
it looks more like a Cat 5 cable or

89
00:04:32.360 --> 00:04:33.350
something, doesn't it?

90
00:04:33.350 --> 00:04:35.520
It's one big cable.

91
00:04:35.520 --> 00:04:38.550
Well, that's because when you
run cabling through the wall,

92
00:04:38.550 --> 00:04:40.980
you don't wanna have to go and
run more later on.

93
00:04:40.980 --> 00:04:46.350
And so, typically, the infrastructure
cabling has more than two strands in it.

94
00:04:46.350 --> 00:04:49.360
You'll normally find it with six or
eight, or even more.

95
00:04:49.360 --> 00:04:52.630
They even have 12 strand,
24 strand, and even bigger, so

96
00:04:52.630 --> 00:04:54.740
you're running a ton of strands.

97
00:04:54.740 --> 00:04:58.660
And then you can pull those pairs out and
use them for all sorts of things.

98
00:04:58.660 --> 00:05:01.490
So when I look at this cabling,
it's hard to see here, but

99
00:05:01.490 --> 00:05:03.350
I've got a cable that is cut open.

100
00:05:03.350 --> 00:05:07.570
When you cut open the cabling, the first
thing you're gonna see is that it's

101
00:05:07.570 --> 00:05:12.070
got a ton of this stuff in there because
now we're not talking about just one wire,

102
00:05:12.070 --> 00:05:14.345
we're talking about several, right.

103
00:05:14.345 --> 00:05:17.430
I believe this one has
eight strands inside of it.

104
00:05:17.430 --> 00:05:21.020
And those strands, if I were to tug
on them, could yank right out and

105
00:05:21.020 --> 00:05:22.320
get displaced, right.

106
00:05:22.320 --> 00:05:24.349
So they're stuck in here,
there's a white one.

107
00:05:25.600 --> 00:05:26.620
Here's the others.

108
00:05:26.620 --> 00:05:31.750
We've got, there's green,
orange, brown, and so on.

109
00:05:31.750 --> 00:05:35.650
So each of these are fiber strands
that are inside of this cable.

110
00:05:35.650 --> 00:05:38.000
And each one is capable
of carrying a signal.

111
00:05:38.000 --> 00:05:42.590
And I can divide them up into pairs,
and there's eight.

112
00:05:42.590 --> 00:05:47.480
This is really somewhat hard to see
with all this filler in the way.

113
00:05:47.480 --> 00:05:50.770
But there's eight different
strands in there, so

114
00:05:50.770 --> 00:05:52.800
that means I can make four pairs, right.

115
00:05:52.800 --> 00:05:57.080
So by running this one cable,
I could carry four different connections.

116
00:05:57.080 --> 00:05:59.870
And if I'm running 10 gig,
I can have four 10 gig connections.

117
00:05:59.870 --> 00:06:02.620
If I had Cisco switches,
I could do port aggregation.

118
00:06:02.620 --> 00:06:05.250
Aggregate them together,
now I've got a 40 gig link, right.

119
00:06:05.250 --> 00:06:08.870
Or if I have a server with
four fiber connections in it,

120
00:06:08.870 --> 00:06:13.170
then I could connect these up and
do NIC teaming, or whatever, and

121
00:06:13.170 --> 00:06:15.530
load balance across them
to get increased bandwidth.

122
00:06:15.530 --> 00:06:18.720
Now, in the very middle of this is
something that looks like a fiber strand,

123
00:06:18.720 --> 00:06:19.840
this white one, but it isn't.

124
00:06:19.840 --> 00:06:24.010
This is actually a really
stiff piece of plastic, right.

125
00:06:24.010 --> 00:06:28.160
And that stiff piece of plastic is there
to give some rigidity to this cable,

126

00:28:57.770 --> 00:29:01.580
So if I look at this package,
this is actually a Cat5e package.

576
00:29:01.580 --> 00:29:04.260
So when I take this out,
if it wasn't on the package,

577
00:29:04.260 --> 00:29:07.530
I would have no idea of knowing this
is Cat5e, is Cat6, I have no clue.

578
00:29:07.530 --> 00:29:11.700
They don't write it on here as far as
I know, so I'd have no way of telling.

579
00:29:11.700 --> 00:29:13.150
So you gotta pay attention
to that packaging.

580
00:29:13.150 --> 00:29:15.560
You gotta keep them together so
you don't mix that up.

581
00:29:15.560 --> 00:29:18.820
But you can terminate these, for
those of you that did Network Plus,

582
00:29:18.820 --> 00:29:20.510
you've already learned how to do it.

583
00:29:20.510 --> 00:29:24.380
But basically you just arrange your wires,
and with a crimper you can snap that on.

584
00:29:24.380 --> 00:29:27.881
The crimper, unlike a fiber
termination kit, a crimper is,

585
00:29:27.881 --> 00:29:29.844
you can get a cheap one for $30.

586
00:29:29.844 --> 00:29:31.870
So it becomes a lot more practical.

587
00:29:31.870 --> 00:29:35.510
But be careful,
when cables are made at the factory,

588
00:29:35.510 --> 00:29:37.370
they get tested and certified.

589
00:29:37.370 --> 00:29:41.690
When you make a cable yourself,
it's not getting tested and certified.

590
00:29:41.690 --> 00:29:45.710
So it may work but it may not work
to 100 meters like it's suppose to.

591
00:29:46.990 --> 00:29:51.670
We make the joke around here that's
there's three cabling standards,

592
00:29:51.670 --> 00:29:56.400
there's 568A, 568B, and
568W, 568W is 568 Wes and

593
00:29:56.400 --> 00:29:58.975
that cable has a 50/50 chance of working.

594
00:29:58.975 --> 00:29:59.980
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

595
00:29:59.980 --> 00:30:04.275
we're not even gonna talk about that,
the heck with the 55 meters or Cat6,

596
00:30:04.275 --> 00:30:07.260
we'll just be lucky if we
get a link light [LAUGH].

597
00:30:07.260 --> 00:30:11.160
>> So if you terminate your own cable,
my first suggestion would be don't,

598
00:30:11.160 --> 00:30:11.780
there's that.

599
00:30:11.780 --> 00:30:13.190
But if you're on a budget or

600
00:30:13.190 --> 00:30:17.060
if you just wanna custom cut the links
in cables you certainly can.

601
00:30:17.060 --> 00:30:21.470
The ends just make sure you get the same
category standard as your cabling, and

602
00:30:21.470 --> 00:30:24.468
then you can get a crimper,
the crimper is the same for Cat5,

603
00:30:24.468 --> 00:30:27.720
Cat6E Cat6 all RJ45 that's the same.

604
00:30:27.720 --> 00:30:30.030
But make sure the ends
match the cabling and

605
00:30:30.030 --> 00:30:32.500
the other thing is,
invest in a cable tester.

606
00:30:32.500 --> 00:30:36.950
And I don't mean just a little signal pair
tester, those you can get for 35 bucks but

607
00:30:36.950 --> 00:30:41.560
usually for $300 or $400,
you can get a cable certifier.

608
00:30:41.560 --> 00:30:44.000
It's a little box that you stick
on one end of the cable and

609
00:30:44.000 --> 00:30:48.910
it can certify the cable, it can
measure it, it checks the impedance or

610
00:30:48.910 --> 00:30:51.610
whatever it is, the resistance and

611
00:30:51.610 --> 00:30:54.670
all that, and it can identify if
there's a break in the line and so on.

612
00:30:54.670 --> 00:30:58.140
And it prints out a little receipt
that certifies that cable.

613
00:30:58.140 --> 00:31:01.780
If you're a contractor that does cabling,
you probably already have one of those.

614
00:31:01.780 --> 00:31:03.760
If you're a sys admin,
though, you probably don't.

615
00:31:03.760 --> 00:31:06.070
And you might be thinking,
I don't need that, that's junk.

616
00:31:06.070 --> 00:31:08.950
But if you're custom cutting your own
cable, and you wanna make sure you're

617
00:31:08.950 --> 00:31:12.830
running the best cable possible into your
servers, and providing that connectivity,

618
00:31:12.830 --> 00:31:15.270
that cable certifier will
make sure that you've got it.

619
00:31:15.270 --> 00:31:17.630
And it'll be one less thing to worry
about when it comes time to troubleshoot.

620
00:31:17.630 --> 00:31:21.480
You'll know your cables are good.

621
00:31:21.480 --> 00:31:22.582
All right Wes,
can you think anything we left out?

622
00:31:22.582 --> 00:31:25.520
>> No, other than which
you've already talked about.

623
00:31:25.520 --> 00:31:29.190
You talked a little bit about labelling,
just making sure that our cables

624
00:31:29.190 --> 00:31:32.110
are marked right and you've already
mentioned that when you talked about

625
00:31:32.110 --> 00:31:35.150
the fiber pairs, making sure that
they're not twisted if you will.

626
00:31:35.150 --> 00:31:35.660
>> Absolutely.

627
00:31:35.660 --> 00:31:39.180
>> Yeah, so I think that's about it and
a lot of great toys,

628
00:31:39.180 --> 00:31:41.230
lot of great information and remember,

629
00:31:41.230 --> 00:31:43.840
cable management can be a nightmare
as Don's already showed you.

630
00:31:43.840 --> 00:31:47.390
So make sure when you start out
you just follow that consistency.

631
00:31:47.390 --> 00:31:50.370
Now Don does look like we're coming to the
end of another episode but before we do,

632
00:31:50.370 --> 00:31:53.880
do you have any additional word of wisdom
you'd like to impart to the viewers?

633
00:31:53.880 --> 00:31:55.220
>> No, that's just about it for us here.

634
00:31:55.220 --> 00:31:58.140
Just remember,
getting your server room nice and

635
00:31:58.140 --> 00:32:00.270
neat, that's only part of the challenge.

636
00:32:00.270 --> 00:32:02.840
Keeping it nice and neat,
that's the hard part.

637
00:32:02.840 --> 00:32:05.130
So cable management is a ongoing activity.

638
00:32:05.130 --> 00:32:08.090
You need to constantly be monitoring and
making sure that, people

639
00:32:08.090 --> 00:32:11.090
get in a hurry they start troubleshooting
things, you gotta come back afterwards,

640
00:32:11.090 --> 00:32:14.960
clean things up, get it put back, so make
that a part of your ongoing activities.

641
00:32:14.960 --> 00:32:17.630
>> Well Don we appreciate
your info on this subject and

642
00:32:17.630 --> 00:32:19.610
we appreciate you the viewer watching.

643
00:32:19.610 --> 00:32:23.330
We're gonna go ahead and sign out here for
ITProTV, I've been your host Wes Bryan.

644
00:32:23.330 --> 00:32:23.970
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

645
00:32:23.970 --> 00:32:26.311
>> And we'll see you next time.

646
00:32:26.311 --> 00:32:32.257
[MUSIC]

647
00:32:32.257 --> 00:32:35.334
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explain disaster recovery principles. They discuss hot, cold and warm site types, replication methods like disk-to-disk, server-to-server and site-to-site. They will explore continuity of operations techniques through planning including disaster recovery plans (DRPs), business continuity plans and business impact analysis.
episodes.title: Disaster Recovery Principles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:03.175
Welcome to ITProTV I'm
your host Don [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:03.175 --> 00:00:05.476
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,

3
00:00:05.476 --> 00:00:06.809
California [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.809 --> 00:00:08.511
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.511 --> 00:00:12.320
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.320 --> 00:00:14.600
>> Welcome to another great
episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.600 --> 00:00:18.473
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and in today's
episode we're continuing through our comp

8
00:00:18.473 --> 00:00:19.945
TS server plus certification.

9
00:00:19.945 --> 00:00:23.580
Joining us in the studios today
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:23.580 --> 00:00:24.630
Don how you doing sir?

11
00:00:24.630 --> 00:00:28.050
>> I'm doing just well Wes, ready to dive
right back into the world of sever plus.

12
00:00:28.050 --> 00:00:30.624
And in this episode we're gonna
be talking about bad things.

13
00:00:30.624 --> 00:00:34.060
We're going to be talking about
disaster recovery principles and

14
00:00:34.060 --> 00:00:37.630
some of the concepts we need to be
familiar with for real life mostly.

15
00:00:37.630 --> 00:00:41.110
But also for the exam to be prepared to
dig in there and answer those questions.

16
00:00:41.110 --> 00:00:45.590
But, when it comes to disaster recovery,
there is a lot to think about and so,

17
00:00:45.590 --> 00:00:49.110
we need to make sure we have at least
a basic grasp of the general concepts and

18
00:00:49.110 --> 00:00:53.390
principles that we know that we're
at least taking the right actions or

19
00:00:53.390 --> 00:00:55.080
accounting for
the right things in our plan.

20
00:00:56.170 --> 00:00:57.199
The first part which is having a plan.

21
00:00:57.199 --> 00:01:00.190
If you don't have a plan then you
kind of have already surrendered.

22
00:01:00.190 --> 00:01:01.970
But how do you come up with that plan?

23
00:01:01.970 --> 00:01:03.060
What else is part of that?

24
00:01:03.060 --> 00:01:04.530
What are some of the solutions out there?

25
00:01:04.530 --> 00:01:07.995
Those are the things we're gonna take
a look at right here in this episode.

26
00:01:07.995 --> 00:01:12.130
Now, let's talk about just why we even
have to worry about disaster recovery in

27
00:01:12.130 --> 00:01:13.360
the first place.

28
00:01:13.360 --> 00:01:17.910
The main thing with disaster recovery
is that the current solutions

29
00:01:17.910 --> 00:01:21.700
that companies are creating
are becoming increasingly complex.

30
00:01:21.700 --> 00:01:26.140
Back in the olden days,
let's go into the days of yore,

31
00:01:26.140 --> 00:01:29.730
you could get a program
that was on a floppy disk.

32
00:01:29.730 --> 00:01:32.150
And you'd sit down at your computer,
you'd pop the floppy disk in, and

33
00:01:32.150 --> 00:01:33.610
you'd run the program.

34
00:01:33.610 --> 00:01:37.580
And if something went wrong on your
computer, you took the floppy disk and

35
00:01:37.580 --> 00:01:41.140
you went to another computer and you
popped it in and it worked there, right?

36
00:01:41.140 --> 00:01:43.441
Or if it was the floppy disk that
went back, you just went and

37
00:01:43.441 --> 00:01:45.574
got another copy and pop it in and
off you went, right?

38
00:01:45.574 --> 00:01:47.950
So things were very simple back then.

39
00:01:47.950 --> 00:01:52.250
And terms like disaster recovery,
they didn't really come into play because

40
00:01:52.250 --> 00:01:56.120
businesses weren't completely dependent
on their IT infrastructure back then.

41
00:01:56.120 --> 00:02:01.610
That computers played a part, but
they could still continue to sell and

42
00:02:01.610 --> 00:02:05.650
whatever it is their company did
even if the computers were down.

43
00:02:05.650 --> 00:02:08.980
But in today's world,
things are very different.

44
00:02:08.980 --> 00:02:14.060
Imagine if you went to a department
store or a grocery store, right.

45
00:02:14.060 --> 00:02:16.250
So you get a bunch of groceries,
you walk up to the cash register,

46
00:02:16.250 --> 00:02:17.600
and the cash register's down.

47
00:02:18.850 --> 00:02:21.746
Well, they don't have a back up plan.

48
00:02:21.746 --> 00:02:24.277
If the cash register is down,
you can't buy stuff then I can say,

49
00:02:24.277 --> 00:02:26.506
well I'll write it down on paper and
do you have cash?

50
00:02:26.506 --> 00:02:29.737
Yeah, we can't do credit cards right now,
right?

51
00:02:29.737 --> 00:02:31.960
People don't still carry
cash like they used to or

52
00:02:31.960 --> 00:02:33.120
even a checkbook for that matter.

53
00:02:33.120 --> 00:02:34.960
So there's no back up plan there.

54
00:02:34.960 --> 00:02:39.160
They need their computer infrastructure to
be up and running for them to do business.

55
00:02:39.160 --> 00:02:40.990
Look at us, ITPRO TV, right?

56
00:02:40.990 --> 00:02:42.500
We do video streaming on the internet.

57
00:02:43.640 --> 00:02:45.940
What if our network goes down, right?

58
00:02:45.940 --> 00:02:47.770
If our facilities go down?

59
00:02:47.770 --> 00:02:48.670
We don't have a backup.

60
00:02:48.670 --> 00:02:50.380
We're not gonna mail DVDs to everybody,
right?

61
00:02:50.380 --> 00:02:53.090
Or VHS [LAUGH] tapes or whatever, Betamax.

62
00:02:53.090 --> 00:02:54.060
It's not gonna happen, right?

63
00:02:54.060 --> 00:02:58.230
So you've got to have an IT infrastructure
that is stable and up and running.

64
00:02:58.230 --> 00:02:59.760
Sometimes because you want it, right?

65
00:02:59.760 --> 00:03:02.113
Sometimes it's just because you want your
customers to have a good experience.

66
00:03:02.113 --> 00:03:05.500
Sometimes because you're required, right?

67
00:03:05.500 --> 00:03:07.867
You might have government
regulations that you have to meet,

68
00:03:07.867 --> 00:03:09.013
otherwise you get shut down.

69
00:03:09.013 --> 00:03:13.519
I used to work in the banking industry and
at the bank that I worked for

70
00:03:13.519 --> 00:03:15.360
we were FDIC insured.

71
00:03:15.360 --> 00:03:18.889
And they had a rule, they said if
you ever have a computer outage or

72
00:03:18.889 --> 00:03:22.739
something that causes your customers
not to be able to get their money,

73
00:03:22.739 --> 00:03:25.770
you have to be back up and
running in 72 hours, right?

74
00:03:25.770 --> 00:03:30.607
So we had three days, if there was ever
a failure that shut down our systems,

75
00:03:30.607 --> 00:03:32.690
we had three days to fix it.

76
00:03:32.690 --> 00:03:35.330
And if we weren't back online in
three days, they would come and

77
00:03:35.330 --> 00:03:37.470
seize the bank and
take over control, right?

78
00:03:37.470 --> 00:03:39.460
And basically take care of the customers,
that's what they do,

79
00:03:39.460 --> 00:03:41.830
that's what FDIC insurance is all about.

80
00:03:41.830 --> 00:03:44.915
So we had a deadline that
wasn't really an option for us,

81
00:03:44.915 --> 00:03:46.538
we had to meet that deadline.

82
00:03:46.538 --> 00:03:48.955
So how do you make sure you can do that,
right?

83
00:03:48.955 --> 00:03:51.390
Cuz a lot of times, something goes wrong
with a computer and you look at it and

84
00:03:51.390 --> 00:03:55.370
you're like well, something's wrong,
I wish I knew what it was.

85
00:03:55.370 --> 00:03:56.750
And then you start
trying to figure it out.

86
00:03:56.750 --> 00:03:59.310
Right well, how long is it gonna
take you to figure that out?

87
00:03:59.310 --> 00:04:01.008
Who knows,
you don't know what the problem is, right?

88
00:04:01.008 --> 00:04:02.220
So you gotta troubleshoot it.

89
00:04:02.220 --> 00:04:03.206
Some problems might take you 10 minutes.

90
00:04:03.206 --> 00:04:06.728
Some problems might take you four hours,
some problems might take you weeks

91
00:04:06.728 --> 00:04:09.165
of troubleshooting and
researching to figure out.

92
00:04:09.165 --> 00:04:10.881
But if you only got three days,

93
00:04:10.881 --> 00:04:13.984
you've got to solve any problem
you have in three days.

94
00:04:13.984 --> 00:04:16.560
And that's where disaster
recovery planning comes in.

95
00:04:16.560 --> 00:04:18.607
If you have a disaster, and

96
00:04:18.607 --> 00:04:24.570
by disaster I mean an event that stops
your business from functioning, right?

97
00:04:24.570 --> 00:04:27.538
So if we have a disaster that stops
the business from functioning,

98
00:04:27.538 --> 00:04:28.333
how do I recover?

99
00:04:28.333 --> 00:04:30.660
How do I get back online?

100
00:04:30.660 --> 00:04:34.250
And you don't wanna figure that out
flying by the seat of your pants.

101
00:04:34.250 --> 00:04:37.264
You want to have this plan
in place ahead of time.

102
00:04:37.264 --> 00:04:39.688
So you know exactly what you need
to do to get back online and

103
00:04:39.688 --> 00:04:41.200
get things back up and going.

104
00:04:41.200 --> 00:04:43.190
That's a key concept for

105
00:04:43.190 --> 00:04:45.270
any business that's trying to
take care of their customer.

106
00:04:45.270 --> 00:04:47.370
>> And I can only imagine,
Don, a plan like this,

107
00:04:47.370 --> 00:04:51.390
you're gonna be able to find out, if you
have it in place, you're gonna be able to

108
00:04:51.390 --> 00:04:53.720
find out things like your crucial systems,
your critical systems,

109
00:04:53.720 --> 00:04:57.410
systems that need to be back on within
minutes, within hours, versus, maybe

110
00:04:57.410 --> 00:05:00.532
something that can wait a week or so,
>> Yeah, and you've gotta do it, you've

111
00:05:00.532 --> 00:05:04.141
gotta classify your systems, classify your
data, figure out what is truly important.

112
00:05:04.141 --> 00:05:07.100
Because remember what I
said a disaster is, right?

113
00:05:07.100 --> 00:05:09.630
Somethings that stops
the business from functioning.

114
00:05:09.630 --> 00:05:14.066
If Wes's laptop over here died right now,
which is pretty likely, if it happened,

115
00:05:14.066 --> 00:05:17.133
that's not gonna stop us from
filming this show, right?

116
00:05:17.133 --> 00:05:18.864
He's browsing YouTube or whatever so

117
00:05:18.864 --> 00:05:21.770
it's not gonna [LAUGH] stop
us from filming the show.

118
00:05:21.770 --> 00:05:23.150
That's not a disaster, right?

119
00:05:23.150 --> 00:05:26.680
I mean, it's a failure we had a device
that does need to be fixed or

120
00:05:26.680 --> 00:05:28.140
replaced or whatever.

121
00:05:28.140 --> 00:05:29.970
But it didn't stop the show.

122
00:05:29.970 --> 00:05:31.979
If our internet connection goes down,
well,

123
00:05:31.979 --> 00:05:34.047
all right that'll stop
the stream to you guys.

124
00:05:34.047 --> 00:05:37.010
Those of you that are watching it live,
you wouldn't see it live.

125
00:05:37.010 --> 00:05:39.970
But, we'd still film the rest
of the show and record it.

126
00:05:39.970 --> 00:05:42.620
We'd just have to post it online,
you can watch it recorded later.

127
00:05:42.620 --> 00:05:45.820
But if the power went out of
the building and all the cameras and

128
00:05:45.820 --> 00:05:48.170
lights went off that's a disaster.

129
00:05:48.170 --> 00:05:49.390
Now we can't film the show.

130
00:05:49.390 --> 00:05:51.610
The show goes offline, right?

131
00:05:51.610 --> 00:05:53.900
So that will be true disaster.

132
00:05:53.900 --> 00:05:56.060
That would stop our
business from functioning.

133
00:05:56.060 --> 00:05:58.090
So how do we plan around that.

134
00:05:58.090 --> 00:06:01.310
How do we make sure that
we don't have those issues.

135
00:06:01.310 --> 00:06:03.550
And there's a few different ways to do it.

136
00:06:03.550 --> 00:06:06.630
Now in this series,
we're focusing on servers, servers plus.

137
00:06:06.630 --> 00:06:09.030
We're not talking about if the lights
go out, who cares about the lights.

138
00:06:09.030 --> 00:06:10.390
We need our servers up and running.

139
00:06:10.390 --> 00:06:11.915
And your servers depend on the network.

140
00:06:11.915 --> 00:06:14.060
There's a lot of dependencies in here.

141
00:06:14.060 --> 00:06:18.670
So I've made a little diagram here
to show you guys those dependencies.

142
00:06:18.670 --> 00:06:20.580
Let's say that you've got
a web application, right?

143
00:06:20.580 --> 00:06:23.790
This is far more complicated than
a little program on a floppy disk.

144
00:06:23.790 --> 00:06:26.350
So I've got a web application
that my company uses.

145
00:06:26.350 --> 00:06:29.670
Maybe it's like a document imaging
software or something like that.

146
00:06:29.670 --> 00:06:32.410
Well, my end users,
they just see this one program.

147
00:06:32.410 --> 00:06:33.980
That's all they see.

148
00:06:33.980 --> 00:06:39.860
But it is made up of a ton of components
any which one could have a mistake and

149
00:06:39.860 --> 00:06:41.360
cause a failure, right?

150
00:06:41.360 --> 00:06:45.330
So the application itself,
the application has to get installed.

151
00:06:45.330 --> 00:06:46.990

then email address outage

00:23:31.850 --> 00:23:33.640

00:23:35.530 --> 00:23:38.100

00:23:38.100 --> 00:23:41.570
A business impact analysis is designed

00:23:50.510 --> 00:23:53.730

00:23:57.012 --> 00:24:04.938

00:24:06.180 --> 00:24:07.490
That's good.

00:24:07.490 --> 00:24:12.450

00:24:12.450 --> 00:24:14.640

00:24:14.640 --> 00:24:16.180

How much money are we

00:25:53.380 --> 00:25:57.070
They're actually two different

00:25:57.070 --> 00:25:59.530

00:25:59.530 --> 00:26:02.410
Business continuity is saying

00:26:02.410 --> 00:26:07.210

So the difference,

00:26:11.050 --> 00:26:15.400
business resumption is all

00:26:15.400 --> 00:26:18.750

00:26:18.750 --> 00:26:22.740

00:26:22.740 --> 00:26:24.880

00:26:24.880 --> 00:26:27.930

00:26:29.920 --> 00:26:32.860
So you have business continuity, and

00:27:03.610 --> 00:27:06.410

00:27:06.410 --> 00:27:09.500
