Day one, day two.

610
00:28:26.075 --> 00:28:29.855
Reading the business resumption plans is
a great way for me to learn the network.

611
00:28:29.855 --> 00:28:33.365
Because now I can learn what's critical,
what system's intertwined.

612
00:28:33.365 --> 00:28:35.695
Which one's worked together and
how they connect and all that.

613
00:28:35.695 --> 00:28:36.755
It's all right there in the plan.

614
00:28:36.755 --> 00:28:40.360
And if I go work somewhere they
don't have a plan, I'm like, crap,

615
00:28:40.360 --> 00:28:41.740
these guys don't know their own network.

616
00:28:41.740 --> 00:28:44.240
They might have papers,
but what does that mean.

617
00:28:44.240 --> 00:28:47.870
So now I've got to figure things out and
I've got to create that plan and

618
00:28:47.870 --> 00:28:48.450
get it in place.

619
00:28:48.450 --> 00:28:50.100
You definitely will need to do that.

620
00:28:50.100 --> 00:28:54.260
So, those are some of the concepts and
principles that we need to be aware of.

621
00:28:54.260 --> 00:28:56.550
Obviously, there's way
more to it than that.

622
00:28:56.550 --> 00:29:01.000
As a sys admin, you should know,
whether you have a BRP or BCP.

623
00:29:01.000 --> 00:29:03.180
You should know whether your
company is following those.

624
00:29:03.180 --> 00:29:06.910
And more importantly,
anytime you make a change to a server,

625
00:29:06.910 --> 00:29:11.700
you should know that you need to go and
update the BRP or BCP to reflect that.

626
00:29:11.700 --> 00:29:14.000
I might have a server which is
a Window Server 2008 today,

627
00:29:14.000 --> 00:29:18.170
and then next week it's
Window Server 2012.

628
00:29:18.170 --> 00:29:21.080
So now the BRP needs to be
updated to reflect, hey,

629
00:29:21.080 --> 00:29:25.020
when I restore that server, I need to
install Windows Server 2012, not 2008.

630
00:29:25.020 --> 00:29:28.640
If I don't update the BRP and we fail
over, now I'm going to put 2008 in there,

631
00:29:28.640 --> 00:29:30.580
and it might break things,and
you've got a problem.

632
00:29:30.580 --> 00:29:33.050
So you've got to keep it updated.

633
00:29:33.050 --> 00:29:36.800
Test it every six months or however often
to make sure everything's the same.

634
00:29:36.800 --> 00:29:38.310
And that it's working the way you expect.

635
00:29:38.310 --> 00:29:39.962
So that when a failure does happen,
you're prepared.

636
00:29:39.962 --> 00:29:43.750
>> Boy Don, I can tell you I think the one
thing that we've definitely learned in

637
00:29:43.750 --> 00:29:46.890
this episode is documentation and
documentation.

638
00:29:46.890 --> 00:29:50.330
Now, speaking of this episode it does look
like we're coming to the end of another

639
00:29:50.330 --> 00:29:50.920
great episode.

640
00:29:50.920 --> 00:29:51.580
But before we do,

641
00:29:51.580 --> 00:29:54.840
do you have any additional advice
you'd like to give our audience.

642
00:29:54.840 --> 00:29:58.600
>> Yeah, if you don't have a plan at all,
it's a really daunting task.

643
00:29:58.600 --> 00:30:00.320
Don't be ashamed to call in contractors.

644
00:30:00.320 --> 00:30:02.980
There's a lot of contractors and
auditors out there that can come in and

645
00:30:02.980 --> 00:30:04.880
help you create that and
get it and put it in place.

646
00:30:04.880 --> 00:30:07.790
And then after that, you just go into
maintenance mode, you maintain the plan.

647
00:30:07.790 --> 00:30:10.110
But it is important,
you do need to get it done.

648
00:30:10.110 --> 00:30:12.075
>> All right,
well we appreciate your wisdom on this.

649
00:30:12.075 --> 00:30:15.465
I know that you've been in disaster
recovery situations before.

650
00:30:15.465 --> 00:30:16.915
We do appreciate you, the viewer.

651
00:30:16.915 --> 00:30:18.955
Looks like we're gonna
wrap this one up here.

652
00:30:18.955 --> 00:30:21.755
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

653
00:30:21.755 --> 00:30:22.395
>> And I'm Don Pizet.

654
00:30:22.395 --> 00:30:22.960
>> And we'll see you next time.

655
00:30:22.960 --> 00:30:30.954
[MUSIC]

656
00:30:30.954 --> 00:30:33.257
>> Thank you for watching It Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don tackle the concepts of backup techniques. They look at common backup methodologies, backup medium, restoration and medium retention best practices and backup location considerations.
episodes.title: Backup Techniques
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.546
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.546 --> 00:00:02.880
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.880 --> 00:00:06.787
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.787 --> 00:00:08.691
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.691 --> 00:00:12.260
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:12.260 --> 00:00:15.388
>> Hello and welcome to another
great episode of ITPro.TV.

7
00:00:15.388 --> 00:00:18.076
I'm your host Wes Bryan and
in today's episode,

8
00:00:18.076 --> 00:00:22.049
we are continuing through our
series in CompTIA Server+ SK0-004.

9
00:00:22.049 --> 00:00:25.105
And joining us in the studio for
this very endeavour is none other than Mr.

10
00:00:25.105 --> 00:00:25.609
Don Pezet.

11
00:00:25.609 --> 00:00:26.716
Don, how are you doing, sir?

12
00:00:26.716 --> 00:00:27.686
>> I'm doing well, Wes.

13
00:00:27.686 --> 00:00:30.722
Ready to dive into the world of backups,
right?

14
00:00:30.722 --> 00:00:33.120
We're continuing our Server+ adventure and

15
00:00:33.120 --> 00:00:37.304
talking about a very important topic that
really focuses around making sure that

16
00:00:37.304 --> 00:00:40.335
we're able to recover from
a failure on a server, right?

17
00:00:40.335 --> 00:00:42.647
Server fails, we lose data.

18
00:00:42.647 --> 00:00:44.658
Sometimes it's hardware,
sometimes it's software, right?

19
00:00:44.658 --> 00:00:47.251
In terms of hardware, it's easy.

20
00:00:47.251 --> 00:00:50.970
Hard drives fail, they do,
we count on it, we know its gonna happen.

21
00:00:50.970 --> 00:00:54.262
You're lucky to get three years out of
most hard drives, if you go beyond that,

22
00:00:54.262 --> 00:00:55.452
okay count your blessings.

23
00:00:55.452 --> 00:00:58.853
But it's gonna fail one day, and
you need to be able to recover your data.

24
00:00:58.853 --> 00:01:02.010
On the software side,
users delete stuff by accident,

25
00:01:02.010 --> 00:01:03.965
hackers delete stuff on purpose.

26
00:01:03.965 --> 00:01:07.331
There's all sorts of things that can
happen as far as data corruption.

27
00:01:07.331 --> 00:01:10.507
And now need to be able
to recover our data, and

28
00:01:10.507 --> 00:01:13.560
the way we do that is
by leveraging backups.

29
00:01:13.560 --> 00:01:16.840
Now there are many different ways to do
backups, and you've gotta make sure that

30
00:01:16.840 --> 00:01:20.278
you're choosing the correct ones for
your environment.

31
00:01:20.278 --> 00:01:21.510
And so CompTIA, they call out,

32
00:01:21.510 --> 00:01:24.910
I don't know probably eight different
types of backups here in the objectives.

33
00:01:24.910 --> 00:01:28.330
And we need to make sure we understand
what the difference is between all eight.

34
00:01:28.330 --> 00:01:31.040
And when one is appropriate
versus another.

35
00:01:31.040 --> 00:01:34.564
So let's start with the most simple one,
which is a full backup.

36
00:01:34.564 --> 00:01:38.756
A full backup,
is where we backup everything, right?

37
00:01:38.756 --> 00:01:43.158
We have a selection of data,
that we wanna backup,and we backup

38
00:01:43.158 --> 00:01:47.230
the whole thing whether
file has changed or not.

39
00:01:47.230 --> 00:01:51.800
If a have a 100 gig collection of data,
so a 100 gigabytes of data.

40
00:01:51.800 --> 00:01:55.375
And I run a backup every night at
midnight then every night at midnight,

41
00:01:55.375 --> 00:01:58.300
I'm backing up 100 gigabytes of data.

42
00:01:58.300 --> 00:02:02.001
And 100 gigs is not really all that much,
so that's a perfectly reasonable scenario.

43
00:02:02.001 --> 00:02:04.978
But what if I have 100 terabytes of data?

44
00:02:04.978 --> 00:02:08.972
If I'm backing up 100 terabytes
of data and I start at midnight,

45
00:02:08.972 --> 00:02:10.522
when's it gonna finish?

46
00:02:10.522 --> 00:02:12.060
It depends on the media that I'm using.

47
00:02:12.060 --> 00:02:19.187
If I'm backing up to serialized tape that
could take more than a day to back up.

48
00:02:19.187 --> 00:02:23.248
Well that means my first back up is still
running by the time my second back up

49
00:02:23.248 --> 00:02:23.771
starts.

50
00:02:23.771 --> 00:02:27.106
Can't run two backups at once,
it's not a reasonable model.

51
00:02:27.106 --> 00:02:30.922
So I need something a little better
when I'm handling large volumes of data.

52
00:02:30.922 --> 00:02:33.251
And so that's one of the decisions
that we have to make.

53
00:02:33.251 --> 00:02:38.122
When you do a backup, we have to pick and
choose what we backup.

54
00:02:38.122 --> 00:02:39.050
And so in Comp TIA,

55
00:02:39.050 --> 00:02:42.311
they call out things like selective
backups versus a full backup.

56
00:02:42.311 --> 00:02:47.350
When we say a full backup, the terminology
gets a little bit weird, right?

57
00:02:47.350 --> 00:02:51.355
If I have a failure on a server and
I need to do a restore,

58
00:02:51.355 --> 00:02:56.682
the type of restore I do is gonna depend
upon the type of backup that I did.

59
00:02:56.682 --> 00:02:59.620
And just saying a full backup
isn't actually enough.

60
00:02:59.620 --> 00:03:04.100
You can do what's called a bare
metal backup or a selected backup.

61
00:03:04.100 --> 00:03:09.975
A bare metal backup is where I backup
every single file on the hard drives for

62
00:03:09.975 --> 00:03:11.100
that server.

63
00:03:11.100 --> 00:03:15.099
Following the idea that someone was to
give me a brand new server that was just

64
00:03:15.099 --> 00:03:19.426
the hardware with no operating system on
the hard drive completely blank drives.

65
00:03:19.426 --> 00:03:23.540
I could restore everything from backup
because I backed up everything.

66
00:03:23.540 --> 00:03:27.217
So I could restore it all in place,
power the server on and I'm back up and

67
00:03:27.217 --> 00:03:28.618
running like new, right?

68
00:03:28.618 --> 00:03:29.980
That's a bare metal backup,

69
00:03:29.980 --> 00:03:32.766
the problem with bare metal
backups is really two problems.

70
00:03:32.766 --> 00:03:35.678
One is they're big, cuz you have to
back up the entire operating system.

71
00:03:35.678 --> 00:03:39.550
What if it's a web server and the web
pages add up to a blazing 200 megabytes?

72
00:03:40.980 --> 00:03:44.218
But if I do a bare metal backup,
I've got to get the operating system.

73
00:03:44.218 --> 00:03:47.942
So I'm gonna be at least 20 gigabytes
by the time I get all of that, and

74
00:03:47.942 --> 00:03:49.135
the website and so on.

75
00:03:49.135 --> 00:03:50.710
Backups are much larger.

76
00:03:50.710 --> 00:03:52.521
So bare metal backups are bigger, but

77
00:03:52.521 --> 00:03:55.700
they're really easy to restore
because you've got everything.

78
00:03:55.700 --> 00:03:58.200
You just restore it all and
you're back in business.

79
00:03:58.200 --> 00:04:01.252
A selective backup is where I say,
I'm not gonna backup everything.

80
00:04:01.252 --> 00:04:01.992
It's just a web server.

81
00:04:01.992 --> 00:04:03.319
I'm gonna backup the web pages.

82
00:04:03.319 --> 00:04:08.530
They're only 200 megabytes, 200 megabytes
versus 20 gigabytes, that's far smaller.

83
00:04:08.530 --> 00:04:11.120
I can back it up faster and easier, and

84
00:04:11.120 --> 00:04:14.170
it will be less expensive cuz I need
less storage medium to back up to.

85
00:04:15.270 --> 00:04:18.837
But when I go to do a restore,
it somebody gives me a blank server.

86
00:04:18.837 --> 00:04:21.837
A server with blank hard drives on it,
and I need to restore the web server.

87
00:04:21.837 --> 00:04:24.314
I can't just restore the webpages and
that's it.

88
00:04:24.314 --> 00:04:26.360
I've gotta install the operating system.

89
00:04:26.360 --> 00:04:26.940
I've got to go and

90
00:04:26.940 --> 00:04:30.880
get a copy of RedHat Enterprises Linux or
Windows Server or whatever.

91
00:04:30.880 --> 00:04:33.380
I've got to reinstall it, and
then I've got to reconfigure it.

92
00:04:33.380 --> 00:04:35.481
I've got to name it the same way
the server used to be named.

93
00:04:35.481 --> 00:04:38.353
I've gotta give it the IP
address the server used to have.

94
00:04:38.353 --> 00:04:41.437
I've gotta join it to a directory or a
domain or whatever it is that I have, and

95
00:04:41.437 --> 00:04:43.103
we've gotta do all this configuration.

96
00:04:43.103 --> 00:04:46.777
And when all the configuration is done,
then I can restore the web pages,

97
00:04:46.777 --> 00:04:49.871
which are only 200 megabytes,
super easy, and off we go.

98
00:04:49.871 --> 00:04:57.055
Well a selective restore is not a very
friendly thing to have in a total failure.

99
00:04:57.055 --> 00:05:00.337
In a partial failure,
somebody deleted a web page by accident.

100
00:05:00.337 --> 00:05:01.866
I can go to the selective restore,

101
00:05:01.866 --> 00:05:04.252
I can bring that one web page
back no big deal, right?

102
00:05:04.252 --> 00:05:08.423
But if the whole server fails,
I'm gonna want that bare metal backup.

103
00:05:08.423 --> 00:05:12.570
So normally companies do both,
why pick one when you can do both, right?

104
00:05:12.570 --> 00:05:17.547
That we do a full backup maybe or not
a full backup sorry, a bare metal backup.

105
00:05:17.547 --> 00:05:21.589
Maybe once a month, once a month you
grab an image of the entire server.

106
00:05:21.589 --> 00:05:23.918
And then all throughout
the rest of the month,

107
00:05:23.918 --> 00:05:27.020
you just do a selective backup
of the data on the server.

108
00:05:27.020 --> 00:05:31.080
Just backing up the data and that way if
you ever have a failure, you can go and

109
00:05:31.080 --> 00:05:34.370
you can do the bare metal
restore to get it backup.

110
00:05:34.370 --> 00:05:37.218
Even though that restore might
be data that's a month old.

111
00:05:37.218 --> 00:05:40.666
And then I can take the data backup
that I just took that same day and

112
00:05:40.666 --> 00:05:43.320
throw it on there and
now I'm backup in business.

113
00:05:43.320 --> 00:05:46.310
And that's when we start mixing and
matching some of these backup technologies

114
00:05:46.310 --> 00:05:49.280
to find the perfect model for
our environment.

115
00:05:49.280 --> 00:05:53.135
You gotta pick and
choose based on what you can do and

116
00:05:53.135 --> 00:05:56.101
what your system can support, right?

117
00:05:56.101 --> 00:06:00.180
Usually it's built around how long you
have to get back online again, right?

118
00:06:00.180 --> 00:06:03.140
What's the maximum time
I can be offline for?

119
00:06:03.140 --> 00:06:04.390
If I can leave for to be offline for

120
00:06:04.390 --> 00:06:08.800
an hour, I need a backup solution that
has to be restore in under an hour.

121
00:06:08.800 --> 00:06:13.050
I can't install Windows and configure it
and assign an IP is an ad software and

122
00:06:13.050 --> 00:06:15.390
then restore data in under
an hour just takes too long.

123
00:06:15.390 --> 00:06:16.500
It's not the reasonable solution, so

124
00:06:16.500 --> 00:06:17.720
I've got to come up with
the solution that works.

125
00:06:19.180 --> 00:06:23.209
Now whether you're doing bare metal or
whether you're doing selective.

126
00:06:23.209 --> 00:06:30.894
From there you pick whether you want to do
a full differential shoot, brain freeze.

127
00:06:30.894 --> 00:06:34.337
Incremental, there we go,
I had to look at my notes,

128
00:06:34.337 --> 00:06:37.177
differential incremental or copy backup.

129
00:06:37.177 --> 00:06:38.667
And so what are all these?

130
00:06:38.667 --> 00:06:39.888
A full backup.

131
00:06:39.888 --> 00:06:43.798
A full backup says, for the files that I
pick which might be the entire system or

132
00:06:43.798 --> 00:06:45.053
it might just be my data.

133
00:06:45.053 --> 00:06:47.706
I'm gonna backup everything
whether it's changed or not.

134
00:06:47.706 --> 00:06:50.745
I don't care if it's changed,
I'm gonna back it up.

135
00:06:50.745 --> 00:06:52.126
Full backups are nice.

136
00:06:52.126 --> 00:06:55.148
Because when you have a failure, you just
go and get the most recent full backup,

137
00:06:55.148 --> 00:06:56.590
that's gonna have everything.

138
00:06:56.590 --> 00:06:59.750
I just get that one backup, it's got
the most recent data and I run with it.

139
00:07:00.910 --> 00:07:04.912
But if it's a huge set of data,
if it's multiple terabytes of data,

140
00:07:04.912 --> 00:07:07.122
that full backup just takes too long.

141
00:07:07.122 --> 00:07:08.980
So I might only run it once a week.

142
00:07:08.980 --> 00:07:10.170
Maybe every Saturday I run it,

143
00:07:10.170 --> 00:07:15.390
because it's okay to run over to Sunday,
or once a month, I do this massive backup.

144
00:07:15.390 --> 00:07:19.140
And the rest of the time,
I need to find something smaller.

145
00:07:19.140 --> 00:07:23.632
And the solution to do a smaller backup
is an incremental or a differential.

146
00:07:23.632 --> 00:07:26.378
So let's talk about
the differences between these two.

147
00:07:26.378 --> 00:07:32.341
The differential is the most common and
with a differential, what happens is,

148
00:07:32.341 --> 00:07:38.290
when we go to do our backups,
a differential just backs up what changed.

149
00:07:38.290 --> 00:07:41.280
So if we take a look at this backup
scenario that I've got here.

150
00:07:41.280 --> 00:07:43.920
On Monday, I'm doing a full backup.

151
00:07:43.920 --> 00:07:46.376
I'm backing up 100 gigabytes of data.

152
00:07:46.376 --> 00:07:48.732
I'm backing up everything, all right?

153
00:07:48.732 --> 00:07:54.464
Well Monday at 6 AM,
I'm running a differential backup.

154
00:07:54.464 --> 00:08:00.548
And a differential backup will only backup
what's changed Since the last full backup.

155
00:08:00.548 --> 00:08:05.223
So there was a full backup at midnight,
and so in that time six hours passed,

156
00:08:05.223 --> 00:08:07.600
five gigabytes of data changed.

157
00:08:07.600 --> 00:08:10.180
And so I just back up five gigabytes.

158
00:08:10.180 --> 00:08:13.510
That's a very small backup,
it can happen very quickly.

159
00:08:13.510 --> 00:08:15.830
At noon well,

160
00:08:15.830 --> 00:08:19.820
we've had ten gigabytes of data that's
changed all the way since the full backup.

161
00:08:19.820 --> 00:08:24.090
And so now,
we do a backup in this ten gigs in size.

162
00:08:24.090 --> 00:08:25.030
And then at 6 p.m.

163
00:08:25.030 --> 00:08:26.090
We do another backup.

164
00:08:26.090 --> 00:08:27.700
And now five more gigs have changed.

165
00:08:27.700 --> 00:08:28.950
So we're up to 15 gigs.

166
00:08:28.950 --> 00:08:32.750
We're getting bigger and
bigger and bigger each time.

167
00:08:32.750 --> 00:08:36.020
>> My question is gonna be why is that,
Don?

168
00:08:36.020 --> 00:08:40.645
Why are you, by the time you get to
1800 hours there, you're at 15 gigabytes

169
00:08:40.645 --> 00:08:44.430
when you've already got a backup
at 600 hours there a five gigs.

170
00:08:44.430 --> 00:08:47.870
Why is that just steadily
get increased in size?

171
00:08:47.870 --> 00:08:51.610
>> What it comes down to is
the difficulty to restore.

172
00:08:51.610 --> 00:08:55.540
The idea here is that if I have a failure,
where is that failure, right?

173
00:08:55.540 --> 00:09:00.923
So let say the failure occurs
right here at 2300 hours.

174
00:09:00.923 --> 00:09:04.310
So at 2300 hours, I had a failure.

175
00:09:04.310 --> 00:09:06.760
It's 11 p.m.
It's almost midnight and I have a failure.

176
00:09:06.760 --> 00:09:10.160
Well, I was about to run a full back

00:31:02.680 --> 00:31:06.800
How could I have solved that problem or
maybe, remedied that problem beforehand?

627
00:31:06.800 --> 00:31:11.320
>> I've been there and
it's not a fun place,

628
00:31:11.320 --> 00:31:15.690
I had a former student call me, this was
years ago, where they're trying to restore

629
00:31:15.690 --> 00:31:18.170
a backup for their company and
it wasn't working and they needed my help.

630
00:31:18.170 --> 00:31:21.395
And I came out there and
their backups had been set up incorrectly.

631
00:31:21.395 --> 00:31:26.280
They'd been set up incorrectly since day
one, and I went through, it was like 30 or

632
00:31:26.280 --> 00:31:29.540
40 different backup tapes, trying to find
the day that he was looking for it, and

633
00:31:29.540 --> 00:31:30.990
it wasn't on any of them.

634
00:31:30.990 --> 00:31:34.280
They had never tested the backups,
a lot of people do backups and

635
00:31:34.280 --> 00:31:35.480
never test a restore.

636
00:31:35.480 --> 00:31:38.730
You need to test restore,
grab the tape, take a server offline,

637
00:31:38.730 --> 00:31:40.130
whatever, try and do the restore.

638
00:31:40.130 --> 00:31:42.130
Can you restore your data?

639
00:31:42.130 --> 00:31:43.750
If you've never tried
to restore your data,

640
00:31:43.750 --> 00:31:46.300
you don't know if you're backing up the
right data and you definitely don't have

641
00:31:46.300 --> 00:31:49.350
documented procedures on how to do the
restore if you've never done it, right.

642
00:31:49.350 --> 00:31:52.558
So you need to do it at least once anyway
to get the documentation written up.

643
00:31:52.558 --> 00:31:56.392
On top of that, tapes go bad,
they're magnetic, discs go bad,

644
00:31:56.392 --> 00:32:00.741
they have moving parts, or SSD go bad
if they write to them too many times.

645
00:32:00.741 --> 00:32:03.375
So all of these things go bad eventually.

646
00:32:03.375 --> 00:32:05.446
So you need to be testing, verifying.

647
00:32:05.446 --> 00:32:09.129
Most backup software, like Arc Serve,
Semantic Backup Exec, Comvault,

648
00:32:09.129 --> 00:32:12.811
they support backing up to a media, and
then doing a verification where they

649
00:32:12.811 --> 00:32:16.145
compare the bits that you backed up
to the bits on the actual storage,

650
00:32:16.145 --> 00:32:20.520
to make sure they match and that things
didn't get corrupted while being written.

651
00:32:20.520 --> 00:32:21.390
You need to do that.

652
00:32:21.390 --> 00:32:22.110
It takes a long time.

653
00:32:22.110 --> 00:32:24.290
It'll make your backup take twice as long.

654
00:32:24.290 --> 00:32:26.760
If I have a backup that takes three
hours and I turn verification on,

655
00:32:26.760 --> 00:32:31.490
it now takes six hours, but it's worth it,
cuz I'll know that backup was good.

656
00:32:31.490 --> 00:32:34.550
Otherwise I would have to test
every single backup that I do, and

657
00:32:34.550 --> 00:32:36.090
we just don't have time for that.

658
00:32:36.090 --> 00:32:39.310
Well, in a mission critical environment
you may, and you'll have dedicated backup

659
00:32:39.310 --> 00:32:42.881
administrators that just do that, that's
their only job is running the backups.

660
00:32:42.881 --> 00:32:46.142
Cuz it's that important,
it is really a critical thing to have.

661
00:32:46.142 --> 00:32:49.517
So we always want to make
sure we test our integrity,

662
00:32:49.517 --> 00:32:52.750
that files are written in their original
form, they didn't get corrupted.

663
00:32:52.750 --> 00:32:54.960
We want to verify we can do our restores,

664
00:32:54.960 --> 00:32:57.950
make sure we're actually able to
restore that and get it in place.

665
00:32:57.950 --> 00:33:02.490
And we need to make sure that we're
tracking our rotation and retention.

666
00:33:02.490 --> 00:33:05.840
That we're rotating through tapes to
make sure that we have even usage across

667
00:33:05.840 --> 00:33:08.720
the tapes, and that we're
maintaining data to a certain age.

668
00:33:08.720 --> 00:33:11.250
If I want to maintain six months of data,

669
00:33:11.250 --> 00:33:15.480
the tape I'm reusing today should have
data on it that's over six months old.

670
00:33:15.480 --> 00:33:18.030
I don't want to use something that
only has two months old data on it,

671
00:33:18.030 --> 00:33:20.090
because that's too new,
I need to retain that.

672
00:33:20.090 --> 00:33:21.950
So we need to rotate through our tapes,
and

673
00:33:21.950 --> 00:33:24.330
make sure we're retaining whatever
the window of time is we need.

674
00:33:24.330 --> 00:33:26.600
Different companies have
different retention needs.

675
00:33:26.600 --> 00:33:29.140
If you don't have any, you might just
make your own up and say all right well,

676
00:33:29.140 --> 00:33:32.430
I'm going to maintain one a day for
the last two weeks.

677
00:33:32.430 --> 00:33:34.640
And then one a week for
the next four weeks.

678
00:33:34.640 --> 00:33:36.810
And then one a month for
the last six months.

679
00:33:36.810 --> 00:33:39.930
And that way I can restore
anything up til six months ago.

680
00:33:39.930 --> 00:33:42.170
Over six months,
can't restore it, it's gone.

681
00:33:42.170 --> 00:33:46.090
You gotta draw a line somewhere,
otherwise you have to buy a ton of tapes.

682
00:33:46.090 --> 00:33:47.390
But that's all stuff that
we need to think about.

683
00:33:48.490 --> 00:33:52.250
And then lastly, backups are great, and
they'll save you from a lot of trouble.

684
00:33:52.250 --> 00:33:55.910
A lot of software trouble,
hardware trouble on a single server.

685
00:33:55.910 --> 00:33:59.150
But if you have a full data
center destruction event, right,

686
00:33:59.150 --> 00:34:03.050
a massive disaster,
you're gonna lose your facility.

687
00:34:03.050 --> 00:34:05.790
And if you lose your facility
you might lose your tapes also.

688
00:34:05.790 --> 00:34:10.730
So you want to make sure your store
your tapes somewhere that plans for

689
00:34:10.730 --> 00:34:11.750
the disaster, right.

690
00:34:11.750 --> 00:34:14.470
You might have a fire proof
safe in your data center, so

691
00:34:14.470 --> 00:34:16.780
if your data center burns down,
you'll have tapes right there.

692
00:34:16.780 --> 00:34:19.520
But tapes cook pretty well
even in a fire proof safe, so

693
00:34:19.520 --> 00:34:21.630
that's not normally a guarantee.

694
00:34:21.630 --> 00:34:24.478
We want to make sure that they're
stored off site somewhere.

695
00:34:24.478 --> 00:34:27.270
And you gotta be really careful with off
site backups because if somebody gets

696
00:34:27.270 --> 00:34:28.770
a hold of your backup, what do they have?

697
00:34:28.770 --> 00:34:30.080
All of your data.

698
00:34:30.080 --> 00:34:32.990
So usually we encrypt the backups,
that helps with that, but

699
00:34:32.990 --> 00:34:34.650
its better to use a secure service.

700
00:34:34.650 --> 00:34:36.335
I mentioned Iron Mountain,
they are just one example,

701
00:34:36.335 --> 00:34:37.960
there's plenty of companies
out there that do it.

702
00:34:37.960 --> 00:34:41.860
That they have certified technicians that
come to your building, pick up the tapes,

703
00:34:41.860 --> 00:34:45.050
they take custody, and then they go and
they lock it in a vault, and

704
00:34:45.050 --> 00:34:47.130
no one has access to the vault but
Iron Mountain.

705
00:34:47.130 --> 00:34:49.180
And when you need a tape back,
you call them, and

706
00:34:49.180 --> 00:34:50.970
they withdraw it from the vault and
bring it to you.

707
00:34:50.970 --> 00:34:55.170
You never even get to see the vault,
it's all off site and secured.

708
00:34:55.170 --> 00:34:57.120
You trust them to store that data.

709
00:34:57.120 --> 00:34:58.760
If you decide to do it yourself,

710
00:34:58.760 --> 00:35:01.180
make sure you got a location
you can trust, all right?

711
00:35:01.180 --> 00:35:03.290
Don't just throw it in
the trunk of your car.

712
00:35:03.290 --> 00:35:04.430
What happens when your car gets stolen?

713
00:35:05.490 --> 00:35:06.690
Your backup just got stolen.

714
00:35:06.690 --> 00:35:08.160
You don't want that to happen, right?

715
00:35:08.160 --> 00:35:10.480
So it needs to be stored
securely somewhere.

716
00:35:10.480 --> 00:35:15.010
It's okay to have onsite backups, but
you also want to have offsite, right?

717
00:35:15.010 --> 00:35:17.370
Your offsite backup might not
be as timely as your onsite.

718
00:35:17.370 --> 00:35:21.310
Maybe it's a few days old versus
one that was taken an hour ago.

719
00:35:21.310 --> 00:35:23.460
But you do want to have at
least one backup offsite so

720
00:35:23.460 --> 00:35:26.830
that you can recover something in
the event of a total disaster.

721
00:35:26.830 --> 00:35:29.740
And it all comes down to how much
data you can afford to lose.

722
00:35:29.740 --> 00:35:30.270
>> All right, Don.

723
00:35:30.270 --> 00:35:32.220
A lot of great information
when it comes to backup.

724
00:35:32.220 --> 00:35:34.330
A lot of things that we
have to consider for sure.

725
00:35:34.330 --> 00:35:38.056
But one thing our tape is not going to
restore are the minutes on the clock.

726
00:35:38.056 --> 00:35:40.220
>> [LAUGH]
>> So before we do sign out here,

727
00:35:40.220 --> 00:35:42.550
do you have any additional words
on such an important topic?

728
00:35:42.550 --> 00:35:44.600
>> The only the other things is on tapes,

729
00:35:44.600 --> 00:35:46.210
we do have to worry about
environmental conditions.

730
00:35:46.210 --> 00:35:49.270
That tapes are magnetic, and so
if they're exposed to magnetic fields or

731
00:35:49.270 --> 00:35:53.720
electrical current, if they're exposed
to even drops over three feet or

732
00:35:53.720 --> 00:35:56.180
shaken, the tapes can lose tension.

733
00:35:56.180 --> 00:36:00.130
So tapes are actually not that hard
to damage if you manhandle them.

734
00:36:00.130 --> 00:36:03.690
Most of us will get a case that has nice
foam little dividers in it where you can

735
00:36:03.690 --> 00:36:06.170
store tapes, and they'll be nice and
secure, even if it gets beat up and

736
00:36:06.170 --> 00:36:06.670
thrown around.

737
00:36:06.670 --> 00:36:09.147
If you're storing off site,
always keep that in mind,

738
00:36:09.147 --> 00:36:11.162
the environmental conditions of that tape.

739
00:36:11.162 --> 00:36:13.403
You don't want to melt them or
expose them to magnets.

740
00:36:13.403 --> 00:36:15.300
They need to maintain your data.

741
00:36:15.300 --> 00:36:15.974
>> All right, Don.

742
00:36:15.974 --> 00:36:19.288
Wealth of information, thank you for
being here in the studios with us and

743
00:36:19.288 --> 00:36:21.008
thank you to you the viewer watching.

744
00:36:21.008 --> 00:36:23.600
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your house, Wes Bryan.

745
00:36:23.600 --> 00:36:24.400
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

746
00:36:24.400 --> 00:36:25.260
>> And we'll see you next time.

747
00:36:32.200 --> 00:36:35.287
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don discuss the concepts surrounding steps used in troubleshooting methodologies. They talk about identification of problems, determining the scope, establishing theories of probable cause. They will also explore testing theories, action plans, implementing the action plan, root cause analysis and documentation.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Methodologies
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:04.130
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:04.130 --> 00:00:06.622
I'm your host
>> [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.622 --> 00:00:08.291
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.291 --> 00:00:12.150
You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.150 --> 00:00:14.570
>> Hello, and welcome to another
great episode here at ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:14.570 --> 00:00:15.903
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:15.903 --> 00:00:17.196
And in today's episode,

8
00:00:17.196 --> 00:00:21.209
we're continuing through our
CompTIA Server+ SK0-004 certification.

9
00:00:21.209 --> 00:00:25.340
And joining us in the studio today
is none other than Mister Don Pezet.

10
00:00:25.340 --> 00:00:26.380
Don, how are you doing, sir?

11
00:00:26.380 --> 00:00:26.971
>> I'm doing great.

12
00:00:26.971 --> 00:00:28.949
Let's start to dive right back
into the world of Server+.

13
00:00:28.949 --> 00:00:33.970
And we're starting a new objective on this
and we're moving into troubleshooting.

14
00:00:33.970 --> 00:00:36.340
And we have got a ton
of stuff to talk about.

15
00:00:36.340 --> 00:00:39.590
We're gonna break things down by area and
talk about hardware troubleshooting, and

16
00:00:39.590 --> 00:00:41.050
software, and network, and

17
00:00:41.050 --> 00:00:44.225
all the different areas where we might
have problems and have to troubleshoot.

18
00:00:44.225 --> 00:00:47.526
Bu,t we're gonna start out with a little
bit of fundamentals and theory, and

19
00:00:47.526 --> 00:00:48.687
this is kind of important.

20
00:00:48.687 --> 00:00:51.993
It's important in real life and
it's really important on the exam,

21
00:00:51.993 --> 00:00:56.160
because CompTIA has a approved methodology
for how we should troubleshoot a problem.

22
00:00:56.160 --> 00:00:58.911
There's basically eight steps
that we should be going

23
00:00:58.911 --> 00:01:01.791
through with any problem and
not just troubleshooting.

24
00:01:01.791 --> 00:01:03.820
It's actually moving
through to the resolution.

25
00:01:03.820 --> 00:01:07.030
So, it's actually kinda like the whole
lifecycle of a service ticket.

26
00:01:07.030 --> 00:01:11.320
And it makes a lot of sense,
these eight steps, that if you don't have

27
00:01:11.320 --> 00:01:14.440
a troubleshooting methodology of your own,
this is a great one to adopt.

28
00:01:14.440 --> 00:01:17.130
If you've already got one, you likely
incorporating these various steps.

29
00:01:17.130 --> 00:01:20.720
You might have eight
distinct separate steps.

30
00:01:20.720 --> 00:01:23.775
You might be blending several together or
even skipping in some scenarios and

31
00:01:23.775 --> 00:01:24.720
that's fine, right?

32
00:01:24.720 --> 00:01:26.140
Your way is not bad.

33
00:01:26.140 --> 00:01:28.340
Their way is not better necessarily.

34
00:01:28.340 --> 00:01:31.960
It's just, they have to establish
something and this is kind of a tried and

35
00:01:31.960 --> 00:01:33.810
true methodology that we've seen.

36
00:01:33.810 --> 00:01:37.200
If you've done your A+, Net Plus, or
you've probably seen this methodology

37
00:01:37.200 --> 00:01:40.480
before, but
if this is your first exposure to CompTIA,

38
00:01:40.480 --> 00:01:42.810
well this is a methodology
you need to be familiar with.

39
00:01:42.810 --> 00:01:45.230
So, that's what we're gonna move
through right here in this episode,

40
00:01:45.230 --> 00:01:48.660
is looking at each of the steps for
when we have a problem.

41
00:01:48.660 --> 00:01:49.580
So, let's kick it off.

42
00:01:49.580 --> 00:01:53.670
I've got a little, I usually hate
to do text slides like these, but

43
00:01:53.670 --> 00:01:55.230
this is one where I don't
really have a choice.

44
00:01:55.230 --> 00:01:57.780
We just have eight steps to talk about.

45
00:01:57.780 --> 00:02:02.530
And we'll start right here with step
number one, which is determine the scope.

46
00:02:02.530 --> 00:02:07.170
Now, if you think about a problem that
you're having on a server, or a network,

47
00:02:07.170 --> 00:02:09.700
or whatever, what does it start with?

48
00:02:09.700 --> 00:02:12.130
It starts with somebody or

49
00:02:12.130 --> 00:02:16.340
some monitoring system coming to you and
telling you there's a problem, right.

50
00:02:16.340 --> 00:02:17.600
Hopefully, it's a monitoring system.

51
00:02:17.600 --> 00:02:19.520
Hopefully, it's you
seeing the problem first.

52
00:02:19.520 --> 00:02:21.120
But sometimes, it's an end user.

53
00:02:21.120 --> 00:02:24.440
And the end user calls up the help desk or
calls you directly if

54
00:02:24.440 --> 00:02:26.460
they've unfortunately gotten
a hold of your phone number.

55
00:02:26.460 --> 00:02:27.420
And they call you and

56
00:02:27.420 --> 00:02:32.340
they say hey I can't check my email,
or somebody sent me an email and

57
00:02:32.340 --> 00:02:36.330
I haven't received it, or I'm trying
to access a server and I can't connect.

58
00:02:36.330 --> 00:02:38.880
That server is running slow today,
what's going on?

59
00:02:38.880 --> 00:02:41.460
They give you some kind of
report like that, okay.

60
00:02:41.460 --> 00:02:44.390
So that's really where things initiate,
that's where they start.

61
00:02:44.390 --> 00:02:48.090
And that's what kicks off a process
of you needing to troubleshoot.

62
00:02:48.090 --> 00:02:51.600
And step one is establish the scope.

63
00:02:51.600 --> 00:02:56.350
Now by scope,
what we really mean is what systems and

64
00:02:56.350 --> 00:03:00.050
what people are affected by the problem,
right?

65
00:03:00.050 --> 00:03:03.030
If somebody calls me up and says hey,
I can't get to that server.

66
00:03:03.030 --> 00:03:04.670
It could be a problem on the server.

67
00:03:04.670 --> 00:03:06.520
And if it's a problem on the server,

68
00:03:06.520 --> 00:03:09.650
every user who accesses that
server could be affected.

69
00:03:09.650 --> 00:03:10.890
That's a pretty big scope.

70
00:03:12.260 --> 00:03:17.240
Or the person who called in,
maybe their network cable's unplugged.

71
00:03:17.240 --> 00:03:21.170
And so yeah, they can't connect to
the server, but everybody else can.

72
00:03:21.170 --> 00:03:23.960
Now, it's more than likely
a problem on their machine,

73
00:03:23.960 --> 00:03:25.460
their network cable became unplugged.

74
00:03:25.460 --> 00:03:29.600
Now the scope is very small,
it's only affected one user.

75
00:03:29.600 --> 00:03:33.160
But establishing the scope helps
us to figure out where to look.

76
00:03:33.160 --> 00:03:38.530
If I've got 10,000 users, and
only one person is complaining,

77
00:03:38.530 --> 00:03:41.070
I probably shouldn't spend a lot of
time troubleshooting on the server,

78
00:03:41.070 --> 00:03:44.350
because the problem is more
than likely not on the server.

79
00:03:44.350 --> 00:03:48.170
The problem is more than likely on their
end, or on a network device in between.

80
00:03:48.170 --> 00:03:49.580
But even on a network device in between,

81
00:03:49.580 --> 00:03:51.830
you would still have more
than one user affected.

82
00:03:51.830 --> 00:03:55.560
Maybe, everyone in the sales
department Is complaining, but

83
00:03:55.560 --> 00:03:56.870
everyone in the marketing
department is fine.

84
00:03:56.870 --> 00:03:58.900
Or everybody in accounting is fine.

85
00:03:59.940 --> 00:04:04.810
Maybe it's users on the third floor
are experiencing a problem, but

86
00:04:04.810 --> 00:04:07.270
on the fourth and
fifth floors everything's fine.

87
00:04:07.270 --> 00:04:13.380
Maybe it's users in Australia aren't able
to connect, but users in Europe can.

88
00:04:13.380 --> 00:04:15.150
Right.
This helps us to establish a scope,

89
00:04:15.150 --> 00:04:19.310
and helps point us in the right direction
of finding where the problem is.

90
00:04:19.310 --> 00:04:22.440
So, how do we go about
establishing a scope?

91
00:04:22.440 --> 00:04:27.410
Well, we use the most important skill that
we have as an IT professional: we listen.

92
00:04:27.410 --> 00:04:30.460
We listen to what the user is telling us,
or customer,

93
00:04:30.460 --> 00:04:32.470
or end-user,
whoever it is that's telling us.

94
00:04:32.470 --> 00:04:35.350
If you are tier two or
tier three tech support,

95
00:04:35.350 --> 00:04:38.730
It will be whatever the tier one person is
telling you, whoever took the phone call,

96
00:04:38.730 --> 00:04:42.120
who received the email ticket and
is now relaying the information to you.

97
00:04:42.120 --> 00:04:43.000
You listen.

98
00:04:43.000 --> 00:04:44.420
Listen to what they have to say and

99
00:04:44.420 --> 00:04:47.010
they'll tell you about the problem
that they're witnessing.

100
00:04:47.010 --> 00:04:48.990
And what they're seeing are symptoms,
right?

101
00:04:48.990 --> 00:04:50.850
We'll get to the whole cause
a little bit later on.

102
00:04:50.850 --> 00:04:53.800

00:07:59.341 --> 00:08:00.952

00:08:00.952 --> 00:08:03.535
My theory is,

00:08:03.535 --> 00:08:05.191
I need to go and find out.

172
00:08:05.191 --> 00:08:08.940
I need to gather information and

173
00:08:08.940 --> 00:08:10.720
There's other devices that

174
00:08:10.720 --> 00:08:12.340
I could access control lists.

175
00:08:12.340 --> 00:08:13.220
I could say,

00:08:13.220 --> 00:08:17.150
well I wonder if there have been any

00:08:17.150 --> 00:08:20.930
The first problem report came

00:08:20.930 --> 00:08:24.910

00:08:24.910 --> 00:08:27.300
Right, maybe right prior to that,

00:08:27.300 --> 00:08:30.930
So I gather documentation, I go and I look

00:08:30.930 --> 00:08:35.360
I look for change requests that were

00:08:35.360 --> 00:08:38.492
I'm looking for that documentation,

00:08:38.492 --> 00:08:41.919

00:08:56.580 --> 00:08:58.190

00:08:58.190 --> 00:09:03.050

00:09:03.050 --> 00:09:05.830

00:09:05.830 --> 00:09:08.740
Absolutely.

00:09:08.740 --> 00:09:13.520

00:09:13.520 --> 00:09:16.840
And I can look, and is there a little

00:09:16.840 --> 00:09:17.610
Yes.

00:09:17.610 --> 00:09:18.650
Well, I got a link light.

00:09:18.650 --> 00:09:22.620

00:09:22.620 --> 00:09:25.740

00:09:25.740 --> 00:09:27.600

00:09:27.600 --> 00:09:29.180

00:09:29.180 --> 00:09:31.320

00:09:31.320 --> 00:09:32.980
What can I communicate, right?

00:09:32.980 --> 00:09:35.640
And if it's a server, can I connect to it?

203
00:09:35.640 --> 00:09:38.100
Can I connect to it on this
port versus another port?

204
00:09:38.100 --> 00:09:41.340
Can I VNC or remote desktop, SSH into it?

205
00:09:41.340 --> 00:09:43.740
Is the server even powered
on in the first place?

206
00:09:43.740 --> 00:09:47.510
These are all things that we can check

207
00:09:47.510 --> 00:09:49.100
You're testing your theory.

208
00:09:49.100 --> 00:09:52.570
And what you might find is, hey,

00:09:52.570 --> 00:09:54.640

00:09:54.640 --> 00:09:55.850
So that's not it.

00:09:55.850 --> 00:09:57.600
I can throw that theory out the window.

00:09:57.600 --> 00:09:59.200

213
00:09:59.200 --> 00:10:01.940
Maybe the problem is with routing,

00:10:01.940 --> 00:10:03.470

00:10:03.470 --> 00:10:05.800
But not changing the network.

00:10:07.090 --> 00:10:12.590

00:10:12.590 --> 00:10:14.240

Okay, I can't ping across that fiber link.

00:10:19.370 --> 00:10:21.690

221
00:10:21.690 --> 00:10:25.090

222
00:10:25.090 --> 00:10:28.580

00:10:28.580 --> 00:10:30.550
How can I fix that, right?

00:10:30.550 --> 00:10:31.730
Do I need to replace the cable?

00:10:31.730 --> 00:10:33.530
Do I need to have it re-terminated?

00:10:33.530 --> 00:10:35.700
Do I need to replace a switch?

227
00:10:35.700 --> 00:10:36.679
What is it that I wanna do?

228
00:10:36.679 --> 00:10:40.210
And now is when we're talking
about changing the network.

229
00:10:40.210 --> 00:10:42.090
But we're not actually changing it.

00:10:42.090 --> 00:10:45.610
What we're doing now, is filling out

00:10:45.610 --> 00:10:47.970

00:10:47.970 --> 00:10:50.440

00:10:50.440 --> 00:10:52.010
This is how I think it will fix it.

234
00:10:52.010 --> 00:10:54.370
Here's how we can undo
the change if it doesn't fix it.

235
00:10:54.370 --> 00:10:55.270
Now, that's important.

236
00:10:55.270 --> 00:10:57.760

early on in my IT career.

237
00:10:57.760 --> 00:11:03.330

00:11:03.330 --> 00:11:07.490
And he would go and
make five changes and fix the problem.

239
00:11:07.490 --> 00:11:10.060
Well, which of the five changes fixed it?

240
00:11:10.060 --> 00:11:12.650
He wouldn't know and
he'd leave them all in there, right?

241
00:11:12.650 --> 00:11:16.780
But turns out maybe it would just
change number 3 to fix the problem.

242
00:11:16.780 --> 00:11:20.010
So change number 1, 2,
4 and 5, what do they do?

243
00:11:20.010 --> 00:11:22.970

changed settings that didn't need to be

00:11:22.970 --> 00:11:26.490

00:11:26.490 --> 00:11:30.520
configuration that's gonna cost problems
years down the road, we don't know.

246
00:11:30.520 --> 00:11:34.555
And that's why you make one change and one
change only and you make sure it worked.

247
00:11:34.555 --> 00:11:37.231
And if it didn't, you undo the change and
then you make your second change.

248
00:11:37.231 --> 00:11:41.352
And if it doesn't work you undo it and

249
00:11:41.352 --> 00:11:43.610
And that's why we need to
have steps in there for

250
00:11:43.610 --> 00:11:45.600

00:11:45.600 --> 00:11:48.530
Also if the whole network breaks at that

00:11:48.530 --> 00:11:51.130
trouble that we know what to do to

00:11:52.720 --> 00:11:55.830
Once our change ticket is approved,

00:11:55.830 --> 00:11:58.780
And step 5 is implementing the solution,

00:11:58.780 --> 00:12:01.820

00:12:01.820 --> 00:12:03.190

00:12:03.190 --> 00:12:04.790
We put the change in place.

00:12:04.790 --> 00:12:06.080

00:12:06.080 --> 00:12:11.940
You come up with a plan, you make the one
change, and then you move to step 6.

00:12:11.940 --> 00:12:14.505
Verify a full system functionality.

00:12:23.020 --> 00:12:25.295

>> [LAUGH]
>> Well, so

According to CompTIA, you should be

00:12:34.890 --> 00:12:36.170
determine the skill.

00:12:36.170 --> 00:12:38.320
Remember when I mentioned

00:12:38.320 --> 00:12:41.750
right, well they're saying is how

00:12:41.750 --> 00:12:45.370
who knows how bad it's gonna get,

00:12:45.370 --> 00:12:48.960

00:13:02.490 --> 00:13:04.970
It can happen, and

00:13:06.880 --> 00:13:12.040
So what we need to do is make sure that

Easy to roll back.

00:13:18.470 --> 00:13:21.420
Other things you might test

00:13:21.420 --> 00:13:23.120
That maybe they can't be

00:13:23.120 --> 00:13:26.140

00:13:26.140 --> 00:13:29.210
before you then go and roll it
forward in a production environment.

00:13:29.210 --> 00:13:32.050
So, there's different kind of methods for

00:13:33.610 --> 00:13:35.210

00:13:35.210 --> 00:13:38.480

Don't verify that you

00:13:52.460 --> 00:13:59.080
In the testing world,
they have terms like stories and CI and

00:13:59.080 --> 00:14:03.310
all the different things that they talk

00:14:03.310 --> 00:14:09.010
like this, your company has several

00:14:09.010 --> 00:14:11.550
Do all those ways still work, right?

301
00:14:11.550 --> 00:14:13.690
I made a file server and

302
00:14:13.690 --> 00:14:17.340
the user is reporting that they
can't connect to the file server.

00:14:17.340 --> 00:14:20.630
And it turns out that some protocol's not

00:14:20.630 --> 00:14:21.810
Now that user can connect.

305
00:14:21.810 --> 00:14:23.260
Great, but

306
00:14:23.260 --> 00:14:26.470
there may be other systems in my company

307
00:14:26.470 --> 00:14:30.840
When I reset the protocol, maybe I lost
some configuration changes because I reset

00:14:30.840 --> 00:14:33.640
it, right, and

00:14:33.640 --> 00:14:36.619
We see that, when people use the NSH

00:14:36.619 --> 00:14:38.400

00:14:38.400 --> 00:14:41.565

00:14:41.565 --> 00:14:46.260

00:14:46.260 --> 00:14:47.310

00:14:47.310 --> 00:14:49.880

00:14:49.880 --> 00:14:52.350
So when we take a look at

00:14:52.350 --> 00:14:55.590
We need to verify we fixed
the problem we were targeting.

317
00:14:55.590 --> 00:14:57.450
And everybody else.

00:14:57.450 --> 00:15:00.298
The stuff we weren't targeting
is still functional.

00:15:00.298 --> 00:15:03.080
We never wanna make the server worse
than it was when we started on it.

00:15:03.080 --> 00:15:03.910
But it does happen.

321
00:15:03.910 --> 00:15:05.430
We've gotta check for that.

322
00:15:05.430 --> 00:15:08.910
And if it does, if we made it worse,

00:15:08.910 --> 00:15:10.238

00:15:10.238 --> 00:15:13.390
In step 6, if we didn't fix the problem,

00:15:13.390 --> 00:15:16.370
And so what will happen,

00:15:16.370 --> 00:15:19.220
Is that we came up with a theory.

00:15:19.220 --> 00:15:20.670
We test the theory.

00:15:20.670 --> 00:15:23.438
And if that theory didn't work out,

00:15:23.438 --> 00:15:24.800

00:15:24.800 --> 00:15:26.290

00:15:26.290 --> 00:15:30.000
So you might bounce back and forth
between step 2 and 3 quite a few times.

00:15:30.000 --> 00:15:33.830
The same thing happens with 4, 5, and 6.

00:15:33.830 --> 00:15:35.510
We come up with a plan.

334
00:15:35.510 --> 00:15:38.280
We implement the plan and
we verify the plan.

335
00:15:38.280 --> 00:15:42.220
And if that didn't work,
we gotta go all the way back to step 4.

336
00:15:42.220 --> 00:15:47.770
We undo the plan, undo the change and
then we establish a new plan of action.

337
00:15:47.770 --> 00:15:50.010
And we implement that solution and
we verify the plan.

338
00:15:50.010 --> 00:15:51.700
If that didn't, then we roll back,
we go back to step 4.

339
00:15:51.700 --> 00:15:54.560
So you might bounce back and
fourth between these.

340
00:15:54.560 --> 00:15:57.954
And if it gets really bad, you might
go to all the way back to step 2.

341
00:15:57.954 --> 00:16:00.651
Hey, I just tried five fixes and
none of them worked.

342
00:16:00.651 --> 00:16:01.581
I'm really confused.

343
00:16:01.581 --> 00:16:04.448
Let's go all the way back to step 2 and
come up with a new theory.

344
00:16:04.448 --> 00:16:06.712
Maybe we've diagnosed this problem wrong.

345
00:16:06.712 --> 00:16:09.337
And that's where I mentioned symptoms,

346
00:16:09.337 --> 00:16:14.670
that you might be trying to fix a symptom,
and not understand what the cause is.

347
00:16:14.670 --> 00:16:18.100
And, so you might temporary fix a symptom
that just comes right back again, and

348
00:16:18.100 --> 00:16:20.280
then that's not going to work for
you long term.

349
00:16:20.280 --> 00:16:22.920
So we've gotta make sure that we're
double-checking that, and that we're

350
00:16:22.920 --> 00:16:27.190
only implementing changes that actually
work, that actually solve our problem.

351
00:16:27.190 --> 00:16:30.410
Now, let's say we implement that
change and everything works great.

352
00:16:30.410 --> 00:16:33.720
We verify our full system functionality,
life is good.

353
00:16:33.720 --> 00:16:35.971
We're ready to party, right.

354
00:16:35.971 --> 00:16:37.827
Well, then we need to
move on to step seven,

355
00:16:37.827 --> 00:16:40.200
which is perform a root cause analysis.

356
00:16:40.200 --> 00:16:42.720
Why did the problem happen
in the first place?

357
00:16:42.720 --> 00:16:45.290
Why did that fiber link to
the third floor go down?

358
00:16:46.340 --> 00:16:47.997
Maybe a squirrel chewed through it, right,

359
00:16:47.997 --> 00:16:50.170
that's a popular one to
blame it on these days.

360
00:16:50.170 --> 00:16:53.947
Or maybe just the connectors got old or
the switch vibrated, and so

361
00:16:53.947 --> 00:16:57.430
over time the little
connector worked its way out.

362
00:16:57.430 --> 00:16:58.070
Who knows?

363
00:16:58.070 --> 00:16:59.210
We need to find out why.

364
00:16:59.210 --> 00:17:01.310
Why did that happen?

365
00:17:01.310 --> 00:17:04.500
A lot of times you'll hear people,
they say, well, the server locked up so

366
00:17:04.500 --> 00:17:06.760
I rebooted it, and now it's fine.

367
00:17:06.760 --> 00:17:09.540
Okay, well, why did the server lock up?

368
00:17:09.540 --> 00:17:12.050
Yes, the reboot fixed it, right,
I came up with a plan of action.

369
00:17:12.050 --> 00:17:13.810
My plan was reboot the server.

370
00:17:13.810 --> 00:17:14.960
Good plan.

371
00:17:14.960 --> 00:17:17.470
We joke about it, but that actually is
a good plan, it usually works, right.

372
00:17:17.470 --> 00:17:19.820
So we reboot the server and it works.

373
00:17:19.820 --> 00:17:21.390
I verify full system functionality.

374
00:17:21.390 --> 00:17:22.795
Everybody's back in, everybody's happy.

375
00:17:22.795 --> 00:17:24.389
I'm done.

376
00:17:24.389 --> 00:17:26.980
Well, not really.

377
00:17:26.980 --> 00:17:29.060
The server locked up, that's a symptom.

378
00:17:29.060 --> 00:17:31.310
I rebooted it, now it's happy again.

379
00:17:31.310 --> 00:17:32.530
But what was the cause?

380
00:17:32.530 --> 00:17:34.740
What caused it to lock up?

381
00:17:34.740 --> 00:17:38.720
Well, I need to find out because
if I don't fix what caused it,

382
00:17:38.720 --> 00:17:40.150
it could happen again.

383
00:17:40.150 --> 00:17:43.280
Now, I had this happen, actually,
just yesterday with my own laptop,

384
00:17:43.280 --> 00:17:49.010
where I would launch Chrome and
my laptop would reboot, just miraculously.

385
00:17:49.010 --> 00:17:50.340
And it took me a while to figure it out.

386
00:17:50.340 --> 00:17:53.080
The laptop would reboot and
then things seem fine.

387
00:17:53.080 --> 00:17:56.010
When I got home,
everything was working fine.

388
00:17:56.010 --> 00:17:58.150
So it was just when I was here in
the office, that was really weird.

389
00:17:58.150 --> 00:18:00.190
When I'm in the office,
if I launch Chrome, my laptop reboots.

390
00:18:00.190 --> 00:18:01.420
What's up with that?

391
00:18:01.420 --> 00:18:05.120
Well, in the office,
I was using a USB network adapter.

392
00:18:05.120 --> 00:18:08.350
And the driver for that network
adapter was causing a problem.

393
00:18:08.350 --> 00:18:10.960
And when I would launch Chrome,
my laptop would reboot.

394
00:18:10.960 --> 00:18:13.550
Well, when I went home,
I wasn't using that adapter.

395
00:18:13.550 --> 00:18:16.520
I was on my wireless at home, and
I could launch Chrome and it worked fine.

396
00:18:16.520 --> 00:18:20.650
So Chrome crashing, and
the laptop crashing, that was the symptom.

397
00:18:20.650 --> 00:18:23.270
The cause was the USB network driver.

398
00:18:23.270 --> 00:18:26.330
And when I replaced that driver,
everything started working fine.

399
00:18:26.330 --> 00:18:29.560
But had I not done that, I would've
gone home and said, the problem's fine.

400
00:18:29.560 --> 00:18:30.720
The laptop's working great.

401
00:18:30.720 --> 00:18:34.150
But when I come back into the office,
the problem exists again, right.

402
00:18:34.150 --> 00:18:35.940
So you've gotta find out
what that cause was,

403
00:18:35.940 --> 00:18:40.290
do a root cause analysis, so
you can prevent recurrence in the future.

404
00:18:40.290 --> 00:18:43.625
>> Don, it seems like step six and
seven kinda run hand in hand.

405
00:18:43.625 --> 00:18:47.531
As you've said in the previous steps here,
that, hey, we might have to test again,

406
00:18:47.531 --> 00:18:49.920
and then come back and
implement, test again.

407
00:18:49.920 --> 00:18:52.680
How about performing
a root cause analysis?

408
00:18:52.680 --> 00:18:55.550
It does say implement
preventative measures.

409
00:18:55.550 --> 00:18:59.540
What happens if you don't know what those
preventive measures are until you perform

410
00:18:59.540 --> 00:19:01.000
a root cause analysis?

411
00:19:01.000 --> 00:19:01.820
Well, you don't, right.

412
00:19:01.820 --> 00:19:03.250
So if I don't know what the cause was,

413
00:19:03.250 --> 00:19:05.341
how can I implement any kind
of preventative measure?

414
00:19:05.341 --> 00:19:08.500
I've got to know what the cause is,
otherwise, I'm just guessing in the dark,

415
00:19:08.500 --> 00:19:11.420
which sadly is what a lot of
security professionals do.

416
00:19:12.770 --> 00:19:15.879
If we really identify the problem,
if we really know what it is,

417
00:19:15.879 --> 00:19:19.229
then you can formulate a true,
preventative maintenance, right.

418
00:19:19.229 --> 00:19:22.040
So let me give you an example
of the wrong way to do it.

419
00:19:22.040 --> 00:19:24.340
I'm got a service that's crashing.

420
00:19:24.340 --> 00:19:28.230
So once a day this service crashes and
it stops working.

421
00:19:28.230 --> 00:19:29.150
So what do I do?

422
00:19:29.150 --> 00:19:32.280
Well, on a Linux system,
I could write a cron job that looks for

423
00:19:32.280 --> 00:19:34.400
when the service stops and
just start it again.

424
00:19:34.400 --> 00:19:37.780
Or in Windows, I can use the service
recovery feature and say, hey,

425
00:19:37.780 --> 00:19:40.170
if it crashes,
just restart it five seconds later.

426
00:19:40.170 --> 00:19:41.330
And it restarts.

427
00:19:41.330 --> 00:19:46.190
Okay, well, I found my problem,
my problem was the service crashing.

428
00:19:46.190 --> 00:19:50.430
And I put a fix in to just
start it back up again, right.

429
00:19:50.430 --> 00:19:53.170
But I'm just fixing the symptom there, and

430
00:19:53.170 --> 00:19:55.290
the cause is still present
in the background.

431
00:19:55.290 --> 00:19:56.700
I haven't found the cause.

432
00:19:56.700 --> 00:19:58.770
And so all I'm really doing
is what's called a kludge.

433
00:19:58.770 --> 00:20:02.800
I'm just putting a little hack-type
fix in there that's not a real fix.

434
00:20:02.800 --> 00:20:04.200
I'm still having down time.

435
00:20:04.200 --> 00:20:07.260
It might be a micro outage, but
it's still happening, right.

436
00:20:07.260 --> 00:20:09.050
I've gotta figure out what that cause is,

437
00:20:09.050 --> 00:20:13.040
otherwise I'm just throwing darts in
the dark, trying to hit a target.

438
00:20:13.040 --> 00:20:15.680
If I can figure out why
that service is crashing,

439
00:20:15.680 --> 00:20:19.260
now I can make it where it just
stays up in the first place.

440
00:20:19.260 --> 00:20:23.160
And I don't seem some crazy script running
cuz what's gonna happen is eventually

441
00:20:23.160 --> 00:20:25.000
that script is gonna stop running.

442
00:20:25.000 --> 00:20:27.130
Or it will be tied to a user account, and

443
00:20:27.130 --> 00:20:29.590
the user account's password will
expire and now the script won't run.

444
00:20:29.590 --> 00:20:31.112
Now the service starts locking up again,
and

445
00:20:31.112 --> 00:20:33.364
you're gonna have to deal with
the ticket all over again, right.

446
00:20:33.364 --> 00:20:34.168
That's called rework,

447
00:20:34.168 --> 00:20:36.580
when you have to deal with
the service ticket more than once.

448
00:20:36.580 --> 00:20:37.450
You don't want that.

449
00:20:37.450 --> 00:20:40.620
You want to make sure you solve
it correctly in the first place.

450
00:20:40.620 --> 00:20:43.519
Now, assuming that you
find the root cause, and

451
00:20:43.519 --> 00:20:48.338
you come up with a resolution and you get
it corrected, then we're in business.

452
00:20:48.338 --> 00:20:51.790
Now, the world is safe once more,
and we make it to step eight,

453
00:20:51.790 --> 00:20:53.625
which is the most important one.

454
00:20:53.625 --> 00:20:55.620
Document our findings.

455
00:20:55.620 --> 00:20:57.780
How do we troubleshoot the problem?

456
00:20:57.780 --> 00:20:59.740
How do we implement a solution?

457
00:20:59.740 --> 00:21:01.620
What worked, what didn't work?

458
00:21:01.620 --> 00:21:06.520
And at the end of the day, what was
the final fix and how do we verify it?

459
00:21:06.520 --> 00:21:07.750
All of that important.

460
00:21:07.750 --> 00:21:11.630
And the main reason it's important is
that you may only have this problem

461
00:21:11.630 --> 00:21:15.820
one time in your entire life, and that's
it and the documentation doesn't matter.

462
00:21:15.820 --> 00:21:17.925
Or you might see this problem again.

463
00:21:17.925 --> 00:21:19.500
And I'm really guilty of this.

464
00:21:20.970 --> 00:21:24.540
Again, just yesterday I was working on
a network camera that we had here in

465
00:21:24.540 --> 00:21:25.530
the office.

466
00:21:25.530 --> 00:21:28.010
And I was having a problem with it, and

467
00:21:28.010 --> 00:21:32.550
I had the exact same problem,
probably, six months ago.

468
00:21:32.550 --> 00:21:37.217
And I know I fixed it six months ago,
and I can't remember what I did.

469
00:21:37.217 --> 00:21:41.230
I did research, I read the manuals,
I found the problem, I fixed it.

470
00:21:41.230 --> 00:21:43.240
And then I put it out of my mind and
I didn't write it down.

471
00:21:43.240 --> 00:21:47.910
And here I am today, this very moment,
trying to remember what I did six months

472
00:21:47.910 --> 00:21:50.490
ago, and regretting the fact
that I didn't write it down.

473
00:21:50.490 --> 00:21:54.920
Well, in a server environment that happens
a lot because in a server environment,

474
00:21:54.920 --> 00:21:59.080
you usually have a large
quantity of very similar systems.

475
00:21:59.080 --> 00:22:03.090
And a problem affecting one will
likely affect others down the road, so

476
00:22:03.090 --> 00:22:05.180
we want to make sure we document that.

477
00:22:05.180 --> 00:22:06.400
I used to work for a consulting company.

478
00:22:06.400 --> 00:22:09.310
We had this file,
it was called nice to know.

479
00:22:09.310 --> 00:22:11.840
And I thought it was funny
when I was first hired, but

480
00:22:11.840 --> 00:22:15.210
by the time I left that company,
I lived in that folder.

481
00:22:15.210 --> 00:22:17.520
Any time a technician solved a problem,
they would write it up,

482
00:22:17.520 --> 00:22:19.360
and they would stick in it
in this nice to know folder.

483
00:22:19.360 --> 00:22:21.265
This was all digital, not paper.

484
00:22:21.265 --> 00:22:23.170
I'm acting like it was paper.

485
00:22:23.170 --> 00:22:27.140
And if you had a problem you could go and
search through that nice to know folder,

486
00:22:27.140 --> 00:22:29.980
and you'd find all sorts of gems
in there that people would find.

487
00:22:29.980 --> 00:22:32.640
And I mean just really amazing stuff.

488
00:22:32.640 --> 00:22:34.360
That's the value that we can create.

489
00:22:34.360 --> 00:22:37.130
Everyone's environment is so different
that it's not really possible to have one

490
00:22:37.130 --> 00:22:39.670
big nice to know folder for
the entire world.

491
00:22:39.670 --> 00:22:42.170
But in your company, you can create one.

492
00:22:42.170 --> 00:22:44.950
And now you and the other engineers
can all share information and

493
00:22:44.950 --> 00:22:47.200
make sure that you're making
the right decisions, and

494
00:22:47.200 --> 00:22:50.290
solving things as quickly and
efficiently as possible.

495
00:22:50.290 --> 00:22:53.620
All right, so that eight step
troubleshooting method methodology,

496
00:22:53.620 --> 00:22:54.640
it's mostly common sense.

497
00:22:54.640 --> 00:22:58.110
I probably didn't tell you guys anything
that was earth-shattering or mind-numbing.

498
00:22:58.110 --> 00:22:59.870
It's pretty straightforward.

499
00:22:59.870 --> 00:23:03.190
But if you don't have a documented
methodology, this is a great one to adopt

500
00:23:03.190 --> 00:23:05.940
because it really does cover all
the bases of what you need to do.

501
00:23:05.940 --> 00:23:08.220
And it is just a suggestion and guideline.

502
00:23:08.220 --> 00:23:11.940
You can always change this around
to meet the needs of your company.

503
00:23:11.940 --> 00:23:14.110
But it's pretty solid
the way that it's written, so

504
00:23:14.110 --> 00:23:15.920
it's definitely one that I recommend.

505
00:23:15.920 --> 00:23:19.750
Now, how we troubleshoot is
gonna be a little bit different.

506
00:23:19.750 --> 00:23:22.150
And as we talk about troubleshooting
over the next few episodes,

507
00:23:22.150 --> 00:23:23.260
what are we really talking about?

508
00:23:23.260 --> 00:23:26.700
What we're really talking about
is establishing a theory, right.

509
00:23:26.700 --> 00:23:31.540
When we troubleshoot a problem,
we're establishing a theory, right.

510
00:23:31.540 --> 00:23:34.585
When we fix the problem,
we're implementing the solution.

511
00:23:34.585 --> 00:23:37.560
So steps two and five, those are really
what we're gonna focus on in the next

512
00:23:37.560 --> 00:23:40.440
four or five episodes, as we go through
that, on software, and hardware, and

513
00:23:40.440 --> 00:23:43.350
networking and all that good stuff,
storage and so on.

514
00:23:43.350 --> 00:23:46.462
But the process is much bigger, right.

515
00:23:46.462 --> 00:23:49.506
We need to go through all these various
steps to make sure the systems are working

516
00:23:49.506 --> 00:23:50.726
the way that we intend them to.

517
00:23:50.726 --> 00:23:56.930
And then implement them in a repeatable
manner that everybody can benefit from.

518
00:23:56.930 --> 00:23:58.570
>> All right, Don,
a lot of great information.

519
00:23:58.570 --> 00:24:01.190
And, boy, I know that you have
used troubleshooting methods

520
00:24:01.190 --> 00:24:03.045
many times in life, in your career.

521
00:24:03.045 --> 00:24:03.660
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

522
00:24:03.660 --> 00:24:06.510
it does look like I don't know if we're
gonna be able to troubleshoot the clock

523
00:24:06.510 --> 00:24:07.141
running out of minutes.

524
00:24:07.141 --> 00:24:10.210
So [LAUGH] before we bring this one to
an end, do you have any final words?

525
00:24:11.350 --> 00:24:12.040
>> That's about it.

526
00:24:12.040 --> 00:24:13.950
I know it's another bureaucracy episode,
so

527
00:24:13.950 --> 00:24:15.520
it doesn't sound as exciting as possible.

528
00:24:15.520 --> 00:24:18.380
It'll get more exciting when we get into
the actual trouble-shooting episodes.

529
00:24:18.380 --> 00:24:21.290
But just bear in mind, there is
a reason why we have all these steps.

530
00:24:21.290 --> 00:24:25.010
And I can't encourage you enough,
only make one change at a time.

531
00:24:25.010 --> 00:24:26.810
Make one change, test it.

532
00:24:26.810 --> 00:24:27.510
If it works, great.

533
00:24:27.510 --> 00:24:28.860
If it doesn't, roll it back.

534
00:24:28.860 --> 00:24:31.050
Don't make multiple changes.

535
00:24:31.050 --> 00:24:33.060
It's just gonna lead to trouble.

536
00:24:33.060 --> 00:24:34.740
>> All right,
words of wisdom from Don Pezet.

537
00:24:34.740 --> 00:24:36.780
Thank you for
being here in the studios with us.

538
00:24:36.780 --> 00:24:38.260
And thank you to you, the viewer watching.

539
00:24:38.260 --> 00:24:40.440
Keep in mind,
we got a lot more troubleshooting to come.

540
00:24:40.440 --> 00:24:43.423
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

541
00:24:43.423 --> 00:24:44.221
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

542
00:24:44.221 --> 00:24:45.319
>> And we'll see you next time.

543
00:24:45.319 --> 00:24:52.193
[MUSIC]

544
00:24:52.193 --> 00:24:55.355
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explain the basics of troubleshooting hardware. They talk about common problems like POST failing, memory failures, CPU and hard drive failures. They look at some of the common causes, environmental issues as well as looking at some hardware tools.

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:08.417
Welcome to ITPRO.TV I'm your

3
00:00:12.012 --> 00:00:14.839
Hello and welcome to another
great episode here at ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:14.839 --> 00:00:19.217
I am your host Wes Bryan and in today's
episode we are continuing through

5
00:00:19.217 --> 00:00:22.103
our CompTIA Server+ SK0-004 training.

6
00:00:22.103 --> 00:00:25.015
And joining us back in the studios
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

7
00:00:25.015 --> 00:00:26.005
Don how are you doing sir?

8
00:00:26.005 --> 00:00:26.683
>> I'm doing great.

9
00:00:26.683 --> 00:00:30.172
Wes ready to dive right back into server
plus and we've kicked off troubleshooting.

10
00:00:30.172 --> 00:00:31.850
We've talked about some fundamentals and
theories.

11
00:00:31.850 --> 00:00:35.310
In this episode, we're going to talk
about troubleshooting hardware.

12
00:00:35.310 --> 00:00:38.570
Fortunately, troubleshooting hardware
with a server is usually pretty easy,

13
00:00:38.570 --> 00:00:41.050
because the vendors don't want
you to mess with the hardware.

14
00:00:41.050 --> 00:00:42.300
When you have it under warranty and

15
00:00:42.300 --> 00:00:44.400
something goes wrong,
they want to come and fix it.

16
00:00:44.400 --> 00:00:46.750
It's under warranty,
that's the whole point.

17
00:00:46.750 --> 00:00:48.401
But if it's not under warranty, or

18
00:00:48.401 --> 00:00:51.382
if you're just trying to get

00:11:14.350 --> 00:11:17.650

00:11:56.520 --> 00:12:02.130

00:12:03.800 --> 00:12:06.370

00:12:06.370 --> 00:12:09.772

00:12:28.410 --> 00:12:30.360
They're tied together in a way.

00:12:30.360 --> 00:12:34.010

00:12:34.010 --> 00:12:35.390

00:12:35.390 --> 00:12:36.240

00:12:53.030 --> 00:12:57.110

00:12:57.110 --> 00:12:59.680

00:12:59.680 --> 00:13:02.240

00:13:02.240 --> 00:13:04.170

00:13:05.850 --> 00:13:07.980

00:13:07.980 --> 00:13:10.350

00:13:10.350 --> 00:13:13.680

00:13:13.680 --> 00:13:16.020

00:13:16.020 --> 00:13:19.480

00:13:19.480 --> 00:13:25.310

00:13:25.310 --> 00:13:27.710

00:13:30.660 --> 00:13:33.140

00:13:33.140 --> 00:13:38.020

300
00:13:38.020 --> 00:13:41.400

a fan stuck right on top of them.

301
00:13:41.400 --> 00:13:45.290

the server, nice and clear.

302
00:13:45.290 --> 00:13:47.980
And if they get too hot,
it's what's called baking.

303
00:13:47.980 --> 00:13:50.880
The processor bakes and it damages itself.

304
00:13:50.880 --> 00:13:54.022
CPUs have millions of micro
transistors inside of them.

305
00:13:54.022 --> 00:13:57.480

it takes a microscope to see them.

306
00:13:57.480 --> 00:14:01.410
So an excess of temperature can

307
00:14:01.410 --> 00:14:05.000
And they get very hot on their own
even just through normal usage.

308
00:14:05.000 --> 00:14:08.500
And that's normally where

309
00:14:08.500 --> 00:14:11.825
You can also have a chip creep on a CPU,

00:14:11.825 --> 00:14:13.335

00:14:13.335 --> 00:14:14.705
But the design on those things is so

00:14:14.705 --> 00:14:18.935

00:14:18.935 --> 00:14:22.145
The silicon wafers are designed

00:14:22.145 --> 00:14:24.485

00:14:24.485 --> 00:14:28.205

00:14:28.205 --> 00:14:30.170
Well, like a really, really hot server.

00:14:30.170 --> 00:14:31.930

00:14:31.930 --> 00:14:36.340

00:14:50.690 --> 00:14:54.650

00:14:54.650 --> 00:14:56.961

00:14:56.961 --> 00:14:58.620

00:14:58.620 --> 00:15:01.290

00:16:52.970 --> 00:16:53.979
Well, those boards can fail.

Adding cards are much

Test it then.

00:18:33.730 --> 00:18:34.580

00:18:34.580 --> 00:18:37.180
