do that cause the failures too.

696
00:32:18.930 --> 00:32:20.860
For example, environmental issues.

697
00:32:20.860 --> 00:32:21.380
Right?
And

698
00:32:21.380 --> 00:32:23.060
compTIA calls out several of the big ones.

699
00:32:23.060 --> 00:32:25.940
Dust, that we talked about in
the server maintenance episodes.

700
00:32:25.940 --> 00:32:28.740
Temperature which we also talked
about in server maintenance.

701
00:32:28.740 --> 00:32:31.710
Those are all things that can
lead to damage on the servers.

702
00:32:31.710 --> 00:32:34.980
You've got to make sure
the environment around your servers is

703
00:32:34.980 --> 00:32:36.500
capable of sustaining those servers.

704
00:32:36.500 --> 00:32:38.450
If its not it's gonna
shorten their life span.

705
00:32:38.450 --> 00:32:41.130
Its gonna lead to them failing much,
much sooner.

706
00:32:41.130 --> 00:32:44.003
The temperature around your servers,
humidity,

707
00:32:44.003 --> 00:32:46.958
and just power surges,
power failures in general.

708
00:32:46.958 --> 00:32:48.602
Those are very jarring
experiences to a server.

709
00:32:48.602 --> 00:32:52.120
So that's why we don't normally plug
a server right in to a wall socket.

710
00:32:52.120 --> 00:32:55.070
We normally run to a UPS that's
doing power conditioning, right?

711
00:32:55.070 --> 00:32:57.064
That power conditioning
is really important for

712
00:32:57.064 --> 00:32:58.773
us to make sure that everything is right.

713
00:32:58.773 --> 00:33:00.775
On the temperature and humidity,

714
00:33:00.775 --> 00:33:04.233
a lot of times we'll leverage
devices like these from APC.

715
00:33:04.233 --> 00:33:07.927
They have temperature and humidity sensors
that you can install throughout your data

716
00:33:07.927 --> 00:33:11.080
center, so that you can spot
when you've got a problem.

717
00:33:11.080 --> 00:33:14.170
A lot of times, the temperature might
be just fine in your server room, and

718
00:33:14.170 --> 00:33:18.310
you don't realize that the humidity
is way to high or way to low.

719
00:33:18.310 --> 00:33:19.470
If the humidity is too high,

720
00:33:19.470 --> 00:33:22.200
it can lead to shorts in the equipment
as well as rust and corrosion.

721
00:33:22.200 --> 00:33:27.880
If humidity is too low, it can lead
to build-ups in ESD or in static

722
00:33:27.880 --> 00:33:32.680
electricity so that you can accidentally
shock your systems, and break components.

723
00:33:32.680 --> 00:33:34.089
So we've always gotta be careful there.

724
00:33:36.330 --> 00:33:38.920
Some of the tools of the trade
we've already talked about,

725
00:33:38.920 --> 00:33:41.710
we've talked about multimeters,
however you want to say it.

726
00:33:41.710 --> 00:33:45.340
I talked a little bit about
the power supply testers.

727
00:33:45.340 --> 00:33:46.486
Simple things that you'll
want to keep handy.

728
00:33:46.486 --> 00:33:48.102
Things like canned air and vacuums.

729
00:33:48.102 --> 00:33:51.350
I know we've talked about
those in other episodes too.

730
00:33:51.350 --> 00:33:54.740
But most of us have seen or
used canned air.

731
00:33:54.740 --> 00:33:57.240
At some point,
it's not fancy technology, right.

732
00:33:57.240 --> 00:34:00.340
We just spray it and it blows dust off.

733
00:34:00.340 --> 00:34:05.660
Make sure that you're using canned air
that is okay for electrical components.

734
00:34:05.660 --> 00:34:08.300
There is some canned air out there
that isn't, but most of it is and

735
00:34:08.300 --> 00:34:10.870
you can spray dust and
other debris right off the system.

736
00:34:10.870 --> 00:34:12.510
Really helps for air flow.

737
00:34:12.510 --> 00:34:16.220
If you need to go up to a vacuum cleaner
or you want an electronic version of that,

738
00:34:16.220 --> 00:34:17.240
they do make them.

739
00:34:17.240 --> 00:34:20.110
Make sure that they're ESD safe, right?

740
00:34:20.110 --> 00:34:22.500
Canned air is nice cuz
there's no electricity in it.

741
00:34:22.500 --> 00:34:26.460
But when you use a plug in vacuum or
a plug in duster like this one.

742
00:34:26.460 --> 00:34:29.480
This is like canned air
that lasts forever.

743
00:34:29.480 --> 00:34:31.560
It can generate static electricity.

744
00:34:31.560 --> 00:34:33.220
See, it even comes with ESD wristband.

745
00:34:33.220 --> 00:34:36.020
That's because we need to
have stuff that is rated

746
00:34:36.020 --> 00:34:39.200
to support our servers and equipment.

747
00:34:39.200 --> 00:34:42.165
I think I've pretty much
covered all the tests there.

748
00:34:42.165 --> 00:34:44.990
Hardware diagnostics I talked about also.

749
00:34:44.990 --> 00:34:47.770
All of these are different components,
all tools of the trade.

750
00:34:47.770 --> 00:34:50.420
But fortunately for us as long as
our system is under maintenance,

751
00:34:50.420 --> 00:34:53.200
covered by a warranty, troubleshooting
hardware is usually pretty easy.

752
00:34:53.200 --> 00:34:55.510
Cuz step one, you call a vendor.

753
00:34:55.510 --> 00:34:58.910
And you're paying them for
that warranty to maintain a system.

754
00:34:58.910 --> 00:35:03.330
It's when a system's not under warranty or
when a system is custom built, that's when

755
00:35:03.330 --> 00:35:06.560
we have to worry about really getting
in there and diagnosing the hardware.

756
00:35:06.560 --> 00:35:10.120
And you wanna make sure you choose
hardware that supports that.

757
00:35:10.120 --> 00:35:13.020
If you're gonna support your own systems,
you might wanna go a standard ATX power

758
00:35:13.020 --> 00:35:17.360
supplies because you can do power
testing with an easy tester.

759
00:35:17.360 --> 00:35:17.940
That kind of stuff.

760
00:35:17.940 --> 00:35:21.100
Those are decisions we have to make when
we custom build our server hardware.

761
00:35:21.100 --> 00:35:22.350
That's a great piece of advice there.

762
00:35:22.350 --> 00:35:24.790
If you've got a warranty,
let them fix it, not you!

763
00:35:24.790 --> 00:35:26.780
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now, one thing I see, Don here,

764
00:35:26.780 --> 00:35:29.140
is that we are coming to
the end of another episode.

765
00:35:29.140 --> 00:35:31.040
Does look like we're running
a little bit low on time.

766
00:35:31.040 --> 00:35:32.280
But before we wrap this one up,

767
00:35:32.280 --> 00:35:35.890
do you have any additional words that
you'd like to impart to our viewers?

768
00:35:35.890 --> 00:35:37.950
>> Remember that not ever
vendor is created equal.

769
00:35:37.950 --> 00:35:41.140
And you might find that you have really
great luck with one vendor, and not so

770
00:35:41.140 --> 00:35:42.300
much luck with another one.

771
00:35:42.300 --> 00:35:46.330
So always try out the different vendors
before selecting one to stick with.

772
00:35:46.330 --> 00:35:50.020
But when you buy a server, don't just
look for the functions of that server.

773
00:35:50.020 --> 00:35:51.010
Look for
the support that's built around it.

774
00:35:51.010 --> 00:35:53.451
So for example, I really like HPE.

775
00:35:53.451 --> 00:35:55.260
They have these great diagnostic disks and

776
00:35:55.260 --> 00:35:58.850
stuff that make it super easy to
troubleshoot and maintain their servers.

777
00:35:58.850 --> 00:36:00.460
I really appreciate that.

778
00:36:00.460 --> 00:36:04.860
There's other systems out there,
companies out there, like System x where

779
00:36:04.860 --> 00:36:08.650
they had these kind of generic
servers they sell at a very low cost.

780
00:36:08.650 --> 00:36:11.690
And you don't get any of that support,
software that comes along with it.

781
00:36:11.690 --> 00:36:15.770
It's good hardware, but if you have
problems, you're kinda left on your own.

782
00:36:15.770 --> 00:36:16.750
You get what you pay for, right?

783
00:36:16.750 --> 00:36:19.600
Make sure that you choose equipment
that's gonna be reliable.

784
00:36:19.600 --> 00:36:23.410
It may be more expensive, but
the reduced downtime will be worth it.

785
00:36:23.410 --> 00:36:26.580
>> All right, Don, well we appreciate
you being here in the studios with us.

786
00:36:26.580 --> 00:36:28.590
And we appreciate you,
the viewer, watching.

787
00:36:28.590 --> 00:36:31.570
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

788
00:36:31.570 --> 00:36:32.891
And I'm Don Pezet and
we'll see you next time.

789
00:36:32.891 --> 00:36:40.630
[MUSIC]

790
00:36:40.630 --> 00:36:47.200
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don tackle the world of troubleshooting software. They talk about user log on problems, resource access issues and memory leaks. They will also address some of the common causes of these problems
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Software
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.695
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.695 --> 00:00:06.433
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.433 --> 00:00:08.466
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.466 --> 00:00:12.078
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.078 --> 00:00:14.630
>> Hello and welcome to another
great episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.630 --> 00:00:18.610
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and in today's
episode we are continuing through our

7
00:00:18.610 --> 00:00:22.520
CompTIA Server+ SK0004 certification.

8
00:00:22.520 --> 00:00:25.710
And joining us back in the studios
again is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

9
00:00:25.710 --> 00:00:26.540
Don, how ya doing, sir?

10
00:00:26.540 --> 00:00:27.550
>> I am great, Wes.

11
00:00:27.550 --> 00:00:31.168
Ready to have another magical time
troubleshooting hardware, software, and

12
00:00:31.168 --> 00:00:33.549
all sorts of other crazy
stuff in CompTIA Server+.

13
00:00:33.549 --> 00:00:35.933
In this episode,
we are gonna be focusing on software and

14
00:00:35.933 --> 00:00:37.710
some of the issues that creep up.

15
00:00:37.710 --> 00:00:42.405
I know in the hardware episode, I made
the comment that fortunately with servers,

16
00:00:42.405 --> 00:00:46.039
they're built to a higher level
of quality than workstations.

17
00:00:46.039 --> 00:00:49.855
And so we have less failures as a result,
and we have longer warranties.

18
00:00:49.855 --> 00:00:51.444
So we have vendors that can help us.

19
00:00:51.444 --> 00:00:54.828
And so, troubleshooting hardware is
really actually not that big of a deal

20
00:00:54.828 --> 00:00:55.430
on a server.

21
00:00:56.500 --> 00:00:59.828
Software though, is a different story.

22
00:00:59.828 --> 00:01:02.759
Software has a lot of moving parts,
a lot of ones and zeros,

23
00:01:02.759 --> 00:01:06.110
a lot of different people
involved in the development.

24
00:01:06.110 --> 00:01:09.840
And a lot of the time,
the people developing the software

25
00:01:09.840 --> 00:01:13.250
don't have access to the same
hardware that we do.

26
00:01:13.250 --> 00:01:16.540
And when you put the two together,
that's where the magic happens, right?

27
00:01:16.540 --> 00:01:20.200
That's where things don't necessarily
behave the way we expect them to behave,

28
00:01:20.200 --> 00:01:22.520
and we've got to get in there and
troubleshoot.

29
00:01:22.520 --> 00:01:25.130
So if you think about the two primary
server operating systems that are out

30
00:01:25.130 --> 00:01:27.160
there, Linux and Windows.

31
00:01:27.160 --> 00:01:32.201
Well, Microsoft as a commercial entity,
they make a ton of money, right?

32
00:01:32.201 --> 00:01:35.530
And their operating system is very
entrenched in the business world.

33
00:01:35.530 --> 00:01:39.325
So in small and medium businesses,
it's almost entirely Windows environments.

34
00:01:39.325 --> 00:01:41.240
And when you get into large and

35
00:01:41.240 --> 00:01:44.660
enterprise organizations, their
workstations are almost entirely Windows.

36
00:01:44.660 --> 00:01:46.600
Their servers, not so much, right?

37
00:01:46.600 --> 00:01:50.900
On the server side, we see a lot of Linux
growth, in the enterprise market, and

38
00:01:50.900 --> 00:01:52.370
on the internet as a whole.

39
00:01:52.370 --> 00:01:55.753
Most of the websites that you go
to these days are Linux driven.

40
00:01:55.753 --> 00:01:58.160
You're watching this show right now.

41
00:01:58.160 --> 00:02:00.590
The video streaming servers,
the web servers,

42
00:02:00.590 --> 00:02:05.860
the encoders that are making all of this
happen, everyone of them is running Linux.

43
00:02:05.860 --> 00:02:08.072
I don't think there's a Windows
system in that work flow.

44
00:02:08.072 --> 00:02:12.190
There's a couple of Macs somewhere for
editing, but the rest of it's all Linux.

45
00:02:12.190 --> 00:02:14.040
So, very common on that server side.

46
00:02:14.040 --> 00:02:18.152
Now, on the Microsoft side,
because they generate so much revenue,

47
00:02:18.152 --> 00:02:22.961
vendors like Dell and HP and Lenovo, they
all work to make sure that their hardware

48
00:02:22.961 --> 00:02:25.416
is compatible with Microsoft software.

49
00:02:25.416 --> 00:02:28.302
So they develop drivers and
they get that pushed through.

50
00:02:28.302 --> 00:02:31.040
On the Linux side,
we don't see that so much.

51
00:02:31.040 --> 00:02:34.398
That there are some vendors where they
will take the time to create the right

52
00:02:34.398 --> 00:02:37.824
drivers to make sure that they're
operating systems works with hardware.

53
00:02:37.824 --> 00:02:40.060
Or vice-versa, the hardware works for
the operating system.

54
00:02:40.060 --> 00:02:42.110
But they're usually much more selective.

55
00:02:42.110 --> 00:02:46.294
And that is where a big part of our
software troubleshooting is gonna come in.

56
00:02:46.294 --> 00:02:50.296
If I buy a HPE server, and
I go to their website and I purchase it,

57
00:02:50.296 --> 00:02:55.740
I can pretty much guarantee that
they're gonna have drivers for Windows.

58
00:02:55.740 --> 00:02:59.000
On the Linux side, I can guarantee they'll
have drivers for Linux too, but not for

59
00:02:59.000 --> 00:03:00.590
every distro.

60
00:03:00.590 --> 00:03:03.620
Right now,
the two most common are Ubuntu Server and

61
00:03:03.620 --> 00:03:05.600
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server.

62
00:03:05.600 --> 00:03:09.360
So those are the two main ones, and
I can expect to see drivers for that.

63
00:03:09.360 --> 00:03:10.700
After that, you have OpenSUSE,

64
00:03:10.700 --> 00:03:13.870
is another one that you'll see plenty
of vendors making drivers for.

65
00:03:13.870 --> 00:03:18.130
But beyond those three,
it really becomes a mixed bag.

66
00:03:18.130 --> 00:03:22.790
So if you're running CentOS, maybe you
can use the R-H-E-L drivers, maybe not,

67
00:03:22.790 --> 00:03:24.350
sometimes they work, sometimes they don't.

68
00:03:24.350 --> 00:03:26.870
Sometimes there's some proprietory stuff
in there so they don't release them for

69
00:03:26.870 --> 00:03:29.820
CentOS, and they just do it for R-H-E-L.

70
00:03:29.820 --> 00:03:34.832
If you're running Arch Linux, or
Slackware, or any of the myriad other

71
00:03:34.832 --> 00:03:40.356
distributions that are out there,
hopefully, there's drivers available.

72
00:03:40.356 --> 00:03:43.833
But if not, you may be forced to
take drivers that were developed for

73
00:03:43.833 --> 00:03:47.140
a different distro and try and
port them over to yours.

74
00:03:47.140 --> 00:03:48.780
And that can lead to a lot of trouble, and

75
00:03:48.780 --> 00:03:51.850
that's where software stops
behaving the way we intend to.

76
00:03:51.850 --> 00:03:55.541
But even when there's the right
drivers available, so

77
00:03:55.541 --> 00:04:00.894
I buy a new Dell Poweredge Server,
I install a Windows Server 2016 on there.

78
00:04:00.894 --> 00:04:05.027
Microsoft could still occasionally push
updates out, that cause conflicts, and

79
00:04:05.027 --> 00:04:06.750
now I start to have failures.

80
00:04:06.750 --> 00:04:09.650
So we need to have a good understanding
of how to troubleshoot software failures,

81
00:04:09.650 --> 00:04:11.610
how to locate where the issue is.

82
00:04:11.610 --> 00:04:15.582
And understand that, while sometimes
the problem is just in software,

83
00:04:15.582 --> 00:04:19.309
sometimes the problem is combined
between software and hardware.

84
00:04:19.309 --> 00:04:22.310
And it's the two working together that
team up to create the disaster that you

85
00:04:22.310 --> 00:04:23.450
now have to fix.

86
00:04:23.450 --> 00:04:27.317
So we're gonna run down a whole laundry
list of common problems that we encounter

87
00:04:27.317 --> 00:04:28.200
on servers.

88
00:04:28.200 --> 00:04:32.333
And the different things we do
troubleshoot, isolate and correct those.

89
00:04:32.333 --> 00:04:35.732
>> Don, it's kind of interesting,
I was driving in this morning, and

90
00:04:35.732 --> 00:04:38.088
I was listening to one
of our local talk-show.

91
00:04:38.088 --> 00:04:41.121
And one of the talk show hosts, supposed
to report on the news in the morning.

92
00:04:41.121 --> 00:04:44.338
And one of the things he said,
he came in at four in the morning and

93
00:04:44.338 --> 00:04:46.790
realized that he hadn't
changed his password.

94
00:04:46.790 --> 00:04:47.541
So he said it,

95
00:04:47.541 --> 00:04:51.628
now this is his fault because he said it
warned him a week ago and he ignored it.

96
00:04:51.628 --> 00:04:55.050
So he couldn't log on to machines,
now that's a user's fault.

97
00:04:55.050 --> 00:05:00.200
Have you seen it, in some cases, where you
can't log on, it's not the user's fault?

98
00:05:00.200 --> 00:05:01.520
>> It can certainly happen.

99
00:05:01.520 --> 00:05:04.893
So in several of the environments
where I've worked,

100
00:05:04.893 --> 00:05:09.158
we've done a thing where we look at
the trouble tickets that you get.

101
00:05:09.158 --> 00:05:13.170
And you try and find what's the most
frequent trouble ticket that comes in.

102
00:05:13.170 --> 00:05:15.470
Cuz if you can eliminate that trouble,

103
00:05:15.470 --> 00:05:17.480
that cuts down on your help desk calls,
right?

104
00:05:17.480 --> 00:05:19.599
So every six months or
once a year, you sit down,

105
00:05:19.599 --> 00:05:23.031
you take a look at all the historic
trouble tickets, and you categorize them.

106
00:05:23.031 --> 00:05:28.080
And every time, the number one ticket is,
I forgot my password.

107
00:05:28.080 --> 00:05:32.040
Or, I don't know my password, or
I can't login, my password's not working.

108
00:05:32.040 --> 00:05:34.290
Password problems are always number one.

109
00:05:34.290 --> 00:05:36.000
End users forget their passwords.

110
00:05:36.000 --> 00:05:39.260
Now, end users typically are logging
into their own workstation, so

111
00:05:39.260 --> 00:05:40.460
it's kind of their own problem.

112
00:05:40.460 --> 00:05:43.920
But if they're logging into your servers,
if they're logging in to check email and

113
00:05:43.920 --> 00:05:46.090
they can't get in, what's the problem?

114
00:05:46.090 --> 00:05:49.000
Well, typically, it is their fault,
like Wes said, right?

115
00:05:49.000 --> 00:05:52.524
They didn't choose to reset in the window
they had, and now the password is expired.

116
00:05:52.524 --> 00:05:55.800
Or they forgot their password, or
something of that nature, right?

117
00:05:55.800 --> 00:05:57.490
But it could on the server side, too.

118
00:05:57.490 --> 00:06:01.547
When you log in,
what are you logging in against?

119
00:06:01.547 --> 00:06:05.039
Well, if you're logging into a local
account, that's not a big deal.

120
00:06:05.039 --> 00:06:08.184
But if you're logging in against
an active directory domain,

121
00:06:08.184 --> 00:06:12.370
you've got to be able to talk to
a domain controller, to authenticate.

122
00:06:12.370 --> 00:06:14.650
And it's possible that that's not working,
that's not functioning.

123
00:06:14.650 --> 00:06:16.350
Now, when you have a problem like that,

124
00:06:16.350 --> 00:06:18.740
it's easy to test,
cuz you can try with your own account.

125
00:06:18.740 --> 00:06:21.330
It wouldn't just affect that one end user.

126
00:06:21.330 --> 00:06:25.240
If the email server is no longer
able to talk to your directory,

127
00:06:25.240 --> 00:06:27.120
then you won't be able to log in either.

128
00:06:27.120 --> 00:06:30.660
So we can always verify that, and
that goes back to the eight step

129

00:28:35.700 --> 00:28:39.290
If you do free -h,
that puts it in a human-readable format so

585
00:28:39.290 --> 00:28:45.770
I can see this server has according to it,
it's got 3.7 gigs of RAM.

586
00:28:45.770 --> 00:28:47.940
And right now, it's got 1.3 gigs free.

587
00:28:47.940 --> 00:28:51.080
So I'm consuming 2.5
gigs of RAM apparently.

588
00:28:51.080 --> 00:28:55.350
And then I can see it's got another 4
gigs of swap file that's entirely free.

589
00:28:55.350 --> 00:28:56.180
That's what I want.

590
00:28:56.180 --> 00:28:59.170
I wanna see that,
I love it when I see an empty swap file.

591
00:28:59.170 --> 00:29:00.100
Means I'm not swapping.

592
00:29:00.100 --> 00:29:03.220
Means I've got enough RAM to handle my
workload and I'm not writing down to it.

593
00:29:03.220 --> 00:29:05.590
So that's one thing that we can see.

594
00:29:05.590 --> 00:29:08.061
The problem is it's just showing
me a single point in time.

595
00:29:08.061 --> 00:29:09.559
I would have to sit here and run it.

596
00:29:09.559 --> 00:29:12.421
All right and I'll run it again and
then I'll run it again.

597
00:29:12.421 --> 00:29:13.583
And you just keep running it and
running it and

598
00:29:13.583 --> 00:29:14.630
running it to see if you can spot a trend.

599
00:29:14.630 --> 00:29:16.280
That's not the most effective.

600
00:29:16.280 --> 00:29:17.940
Same thing with the top command.

601
00:29:17.940 --> 00:29:22.340
The top command will come up and
it will show you CPU and

602
00:29:22.340 --> 00:29:26.750
memory consumption as well as virtual
memory that's being consumed.

603
00:29:26.750 --> 00:29:31.940
So I can spot that and I can see
applications that are consuming memory and

604
00:29:31.940 --> 00:29:33.640
I can watch to see if they're growing and
growing or

605
00:29:33.640 --> 00:29:36.680
if they're consuming just huge
amounts more than they should, right?

606
00:29:36.680 --> 00:29:37.820
We can spot that.

607
00:29:37.820 --> 00:29:39.690
But it doesn't really help us for
trending.

608
00:29:39.690 --> 00:29:41.780
There's not really a great
way to trend here.

609
00:29:41.780 --> 00:29:44.600
You could write a cron job
that harvested the data and

610
00:29:44.600 --> 00:29:47.918
wrote it to a file every five minutes or
every two minutes or whatever.

611
00:29:47.918 --> 00:29:52.680
But having third party software to monitor
that is really gonna help you a lot more.

612
00:29:54.402 --> 00:29:56.380
All right, let's see,
I'm running low on time.

613
00:29:56.380 --> 00:29:58.960
I got a few others that I need to talk
about, actually I got quite a few others.

614
00:29:58.960 --> 00:30:01.550
So I think we're gonna have to go into
a part two on this one as we run through

615
00:30:01.550 --> 00:30:06.270
some of the more common software scenario
type issues that we run in to on service.

616
00:30:06.270 --> 00:30:06.960
>> All right, Don,

617
00:30:06.960 --> 00:30:10.238
well you've already mentioned it, it looks
like that is a great place to wrap it up.

618
00:30:10.238 --> 00:30:10.875
But before we do,

619
00:30:10.875 --> 00:30:13.634
do you have any additional words that you
might want to throw into this one, or

620
00:30:13.634 --> 00:30:16.670
are we gonna just leave them with
a cliffhanger and say join us in part two?

621
00:30:16.670 --> 00:30:19.020
>> Well one word of advice
is with memory leaks.

622
00:30:19.020 --> 00:30:21.450
If it's third party software,
you need to engage with them, right?

623
00:30:21.450 --> 00:30:24.560
Whoever the author is they'll
be able to help diagnose it and

624
00:30:24.560 --> 00:30:26.680
hopefully create a fix or a patch.

625
00:30:26.680 --> 00:30:29.890
It happens, you can have software that's
been running fine for ten years and

626
00:30:29.890 --> 00:30:33.670
a little patch update comes out and
it introduces a memory leak, it happens.

627
00:30:33.670 --> 00:30:36.840
You can get memory leaks on appliances,
I've seen them on network switches.

628
00:30:36.840 --> 00:30:39.672
I've had Cisco switches that had
memory leaks where every three weeks,

629
00:30:39.672 --> 00:30:41.630
they'd have to be rebooted
until that was fixed.

630
00:30:41.630 --> 00:30:43.738
So, this type of stuff happens and

631
00:30:43.738 --> 00:30:47.747
engaging the vendor is a great way
to get that resolved and fixed.

632
00:30:47.747 --> 00:30:49.902
On your own,
you might be able to find the leak and

633
00:30:49.902 --> 00:30:53.162
then not be able to do anything about
it except schedule a routine reboot or

634
00:30:53.162 --> 00:30:56.330
something, which is not a great
way to fix the problem.

635
00:30:56.330 --> 00:30:56.980
>> All right, Don.

636
00:30:56.980 --> 00:30:59.110
Well, we appreciate having
you here in the studio.

637
00:30:59.110 --> 00:31:00.720
We appreciate you, the viewer watching.

638
00:31:00.720 --> 00:31:04.830
We hope you've enjoyed, signing out for
ITProTV, I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

639
00:31:04.830 --> 00:31:05.587
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

640
00:31:05.587 --> 00:31:06.628
>> And we'll see you next time.

641
00:31:06.628 --> 00:31:13.330
[MUSIC]

642
00:31:13.330 --> 00:31:16.360
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their exploration of the world of troubleshooting software. They talk about BSODs, kernel panics, boot failures, driver issues, runaway processes and drive mounting issues. They will also address some of the common causes of these problems
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Software Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:06.378
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:06.378 --> 00:00:08.194
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.194 --> 00:00:11.834
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:11.834 --> 00:00:15.365
>> Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:15.365 --> 00:00:16.269
I'm you're host, Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:16.269 --> 00:00:17.511
And in today's episode,

7
00:00:17.511 --> 00:00:21.075
we are continuing through our series
in Comptia's Server Plus SK004.

8
00:00:22.905 --> 00:00:24.495
Joining us back in the studios for

9
00:00:24.495 --> 00:00:27.420
a part two of troubleshooting
software Is Don Pezet.

10
00:00:27.420 --> 00:00:28.210
Don, how you doing sir?

11
00:00:28.210 --> 00:00:29.640
>> I am doing swell, Wes.

12
00:00:29.640 --> 00:00:32.040
Ready to dive right back into
troubleshooting software.

13
00:00:32.040 --> 00:00:33.000
And in this episode,

14
00:00:33.000 --> 00:00:37.940
we're gonna kick things off with
the big guy which is a stop error.

15
00:00:37.940 --> 00:00:42.031
A stop error is when a server just well,
stops.

16
00:00:42.031 --> 00:00:44.630
It just stops working, right.

17
00:00:44.630 --> 00:00:47.299
This could manifest a few different ways,
but the way

18
00:00:47.299 --> 00:00:51.287
it normally works is in a Window server
you get the dreaded blue screen of death.

19
00:00:51.287 --> 00:00:54.860
The bsod where the whole screen goes
blue and you get some text on there.

20
00:00:54.860 --> 00:00:55.753
That means nothing to you.

21
00:00:55.753 --> 00:00:58.428
And then the server reboots right.

22
00:00:58.428 --> 00:01:02.397
On a Linux server you'll typically see
a seg fault or something like that where

23
00:01:02.397 --> 00:01:06.063
there might be some kind of error
message at the bottom of the screen, but

24
00:01:06.063 --> 00:01:08.790
typically the screen goes black,
and then reboots.

25
00:01:08.790 --> 00:01:12.665
If you're running an OS 10 server, it just
reboots, you don't get a screen at all,

26
00:01:12.665 --> 00:01:15.955
and then when it comes back up you get
a black screen with some text saying

27
00:01:15.955 --> 00:01:19.530
by the way, the system rebooted due
to an error, do you want to continue.

28
00:01:19.530 --> 00:01:20.990
Again, not much information.

29
00:01:22.340 --> 00:01:26.328
There's some similar components here
because all of them are really caused

30
00:01:26.328 --> 00:01:27.083
the same way.

31
00:01:27.083 --> 00:01:30.911
Occasionally we can perform
an activity on a server that is so

32
00:01:30.911 --> 00:01:36.420
far beyond what the operating system
expected that it doesn't know what to do.

33
00:01:36.420 --> 00:01:38.100
It doesn't know how to recover and

34
00:01:38.100 --> 00:01:43.630
when that happens its only choice is
to shut down, to stop, to reboot.

35
00:01:44.760 --> 00:01:49.270
So most operating systems have a kernel
monitor that's running in the background.

36
00:01:49.270 --> 00:01:51.240
Remember that,
in your operating system what we see,

37
00:01:51.240 --> 00:01:54.940
what we interact with is really
just a GUI, is a user interface.

38
00:01:54.940 --> 00:01:59.738
Under the hood, there's a single small
application that's called a kernel.

39
00:01:59.738 --> 00:02:01.960
And the kernel is what's
actually running the show.

40
00:02:01.960 --> 00:02:04.289
And it's small.
It's usually under 2 MB in size,

41
00:02:04.289 --> 00:02:05.290
very small.

42
00:02:05.290 --> 00:02:07.090
But its what’s really doing the work.

43
00:02:07.090 --> 00:02:13.920
And, when the kernel doesn’t know
what to do it freezes it stops right?

44
00:02:13.920 --> 00:02:18.682
They call it a kernel panic,
where the kernel just freezes well,

45
00:02:18.682 --> 00:02:20.165
it panics, right?

46
00:02:20.165 --> 00:02:23.472
And if there is a monitoring
service running in the background,

47
00:02:23.472 --> 00:02:27.520
that's running even higher than
the kernel and it sees that.

48
00:02:27.520 --> 00:02:28.420
It can say all right,

49
00:02:28.420 --> 00:02:31.850
let me restart the kernel which
effectively restarts the whole system.

50
00:02:31.850 --> 00:02:34.320
That's why when you get
a blue screen of death or

51
00:02:34.320 --> 00:02:36.890
you get a stop error,
your system becomes unresponsive.

52
00:02:36.890 --> 00:02:38.670
Your keyboard doesn't work,
your mouse doesn't work,

53
00:02:38.670 --> 00:02:41.940
you can't interact with the system anymore
because the kernel's dead in the water and

54
00:02:41.940 --> 00:02:43.720
the kernel drives everything.

55
00:02:43.720 --> 00:02:47.858
And then the kernel reboots and the system
comes back up and everything runs fine.

56
00:02:47.858 --> 00:02:50.300
All right, now what can cause this?

57
00:02:50.300 --> 00:02:52.690
There's a few things that can
cause a blue screen of death or

58
00:02:52.690 --> 00:02:55.410
a kernel panic, segment fault, whatever.

59
00:02:55.410 --> 00:02:59.230
Sometimes their names can really be very,
very detailed.

60
00:02:59.230 --> 00:03:03.230
What happens is we have to perform some
kind of action that the kernel just has no

61
00:03:03.230 --> 00:03:07.160
way of tolerating a great example
of that is a buffer overflow.

62
00:03:07.160 --> 00:03:10.520
A buffer overflow is when a program
stores a variable in memory.

63
00:03:10.520 --> 00:03:12.310
It sets aside a certain
amount of memory for it.

64
00:03:12.310 --> 00:03:14.840
So let's say I have a program and

65
00:03:14.840 --> 00:03:19.000
it sets aside 16 bytes of
memory to store some values.

66
00:03:19.000 --> 00:03:20.980
And then it writes 17 bytes to it.

67
00:03:22.230 --> 00:03:23.768
What happens to the 17th byte?

68
00:03:23.768 --> 00:03:26.336
Right, bytes one through 16, they fit.

69
00:03:26.336 --> 00:03:28.960
Byte 17, what does it do?

70
00:03:28.960 --> 00:03:31.430
Well the software is supposed to recognize
that it's doing something bad and

71
00:03:31.430 --> 00:03:32.650
it's supposed to throw out that bit.

72
00:03:32.650 --> 00:03:34.660
It's supposed to not allow it to go in.

73
00:03:34.660 --> 00:03:37.640
But sometimes software doesn't check.

74
00:03:37.640 --> 00:03:41.750
And hackers can take advantage of that and
they can push in extra bytes.

75
00:03:41.750 --> 00:03:46.640
And when that happens, one of two things
is going to occur In a worst case

76
00:03:46.640 --> 00:03:52.220
scenario, the 17th byte gets written
over whatever's next in memory.

77
00:03:52.220 --> 00:03:56.150
And whatever's next in memory could be
applications running with root level or

78
00:03:56.150 --> 00:03:57.900
administrative level privileges.

79
00:03:57.900 --> 00:04:02.370
And now you've got a remotely exploitable
vulnerability in your server.

80
00:04:02.370 --> 00:04:03.360
That's bad, right?

81
00:04:04.550 --> 00:04:06.140
Or in a more common scenario,

82
00:04:06.140 --> 00:04:09.760
that 17th bit goes to overwrite something
it shouldn't overwrite and it goes to

83
00:04:09.760 --> 00:04:14.490
overwrite something that's in use causing
the system to freak out and freeze.

84
00:04:14.490 --> 00:04:17.710
That's what we normally see
when we have a buffer overflow.

85
00:04:17.710 --> 00:04:21.470
The same thing goes for most of the other
areas out there like a segment fault

86
00:04:21.470 --> 00:04:24.540
where we're expecting data to be there,
when we go to read it and

87
00:04:24.540 --> 00:04:28.760
the data is not there we have a fault,
and the system freezes.

88
00:04:28.760 --> 00:04:30.720
It just can't deal with it.

89
00:04:30.720 --> 00:04:32.550
Well, there's a lot of errors
that it can deal with.

90
00:04:32.550 --> 00:04:36.040
For example, I might be in Firefox,
and I go to some webpage and

91
00:04:36.040 --> 00:04:39.740
a plug in loads, and
the plug in has a problem, and it crashes.

92
00:04:39.740 --> 00:04:44.250
Well the plug in crashes,
Firefox crashes but my system stays up.

93
00:04:44.250 --> 00:04:46.060
The kernel stays up, right?

94
00:04:46.060 --> 00:04:51.710
When you run applications on your system,
you have userland and kernelland, right?

95
00:04:51.710 --> 00:04:56.240
And in kernelland, that's where
the hardcore system stuff runs.

96
00:04:56.240 --> 00:04:59.630
In userland,
that's stuff that you run as an end user.

97
00:04:59.630 --> 00:05:03.380
And normally,
when you crash things in user land,

98
00:05:03.380 --> 00:05:06.050
it just affects you,
the application you're running.

99
00:05:06.050 --> 00:05:07.780
It doesn't affect the rest of the system.

100
00:05:07.780 --> 00:05:11.840
But crashes in kernel land will
bring the whole system down.

101
00:05:11.840 --> 00:05:17.110
Well most of our programs don't run in
the kernel space, but our drivers do.

102
00:05:17.110 --> 00:05:19.720
All of your hardware drivers
run in that kernel space.

103
00:05:19.720 --> 00:05:21.250
They might be loaded in user space, but

104
00:05:21.250 --> 00:05:23.490
they're being accessed
by the kernel directly.

105
00:05:23.490 --> 00:05:27.367
And if there's problem with a driver,
it can lead to one of these faults.

106
00:05:27.367 --> 00:05:28.800
You will see like the IRQ.

107
00:05:28.800 --> 00:05:29.620
The interrupt request,

108
00:05:29.620 --> 00:05:32.800
that'll generate faults when we go
to access hardware inappropriately.

109
00:05:32.800 --> 00:05:35.020
You can end up with things
that that can lead to a crash.

110
00:05:36.080 --> 00:05:38.790
Also, running out of memory or
just any system resource really.

111
00:05:38.790 --> 00:05:41.690
If you're running out of CPU cycles
those can lead to environments ending up

112
00:05:41.690 --> 00:05:43.710
with one of these crashes.

113
00:05:43.710 --> 00:05:46.985
Most of you have already seen these
before, if you ever wanna see one.

114
00:05:46.985 --> 00:05:50.401
In the Windows world there's a little
program Microsoft puts out called

115
00:05:50.401 --> 00:05:53.873
Not My Fault, which is kind of a funny
program because it lets you generate

116
00:05:53.873 --> 00:05:56.010
crashes like these that I can create.

117
00:05:56.010 --> 00:05:59.450
Buffer overflows, or
stack overflows, double freeze.

118
00:05:59.450 --> 00:06:04.740
I can create all of the different types of
errors that could cause a system to fault.

119
00:06:04.740 --> 00:06:05.330
So for example,

120
00:06:05.330 --> 00:06:09.620
if I wanted to do a high IRQL fault,
right, this is a kernel mode fault.

121
00:06:09.620 --> 00:06:14.430
And what it is, is where the kernel
goes to access a piece of hardware, and

122
00:06:14.430 --> 00:06:18.460
it's going to use an interrupt
request to reach out to that hardware.

123
00:06:18.460 --> 00:06:21.150
And something goes wrong with
that interrupt request, right?

124
00:06:21.150 --> 00:06:23.790
That it's not able to contact
the hardware it freaks out.

125
00:06:23.790 --> 00:06:24.450
It doesn't know what to do.

126
00:06:24.450 --> 00:06:27.730
The kernel is supposed to be the only
thing that can access the hardware.

127
00:06:27.730 --> 00:06:29.320
Something else is accessing it?

128
00:06:29.320 --> 00:06:30.690
Doesn't make any sense.

129
00:06:30.690 --> 00:06:31.610
It doesn't know what to do.

130
00:06:31.610 --> 00:06:32.780
The system freaks out.

131
00:06:32.780 --> 00:06:36.460
So, if I do that,
what's gonna happen to my system?

132
00:06:36.460 --> 00:06:39.650
It's gonna crush and the blue screen of
death has changed a lot over the years,

133
00:06:39.650 --> 00:06:41.100
it looks a little prettier now.

134
00:06:41.100 --> 00:06:46.620
But what its doing is kind of the same, I
get driver IRQL not less or equal, right?

135
00:06:46.620 --> 00:06:49.970
So that's the error message that
I've got and the system reboot.

136
00:06:49.970 --> 00:06:51.540
But notice how it didn't
reboot right away?

137
00:06:52.900 --> 00:06:55.350
It's doing a system dump.

138
00:06:55.350 --> 00:06:59.060
In the Linux world you have a service
called kdump, which is a kernel dump.

139
00:06:59.060 --> 00:07:00.810
Same thing, it's optional.

140
00:07:00.810 --> 00:07:03.270
You can turn it off in Windows and
you can turn it off in Linux but

141
00:07:03.270 --> 00:07:04.870
it's on by default.

142
00:07:04.870 --> 00:07:07.870
And what happens is when
that fault gets generated,

143
00:07:07.870 --> 00:07:13.200
when the system crashes like that It says,
oops, that's not what I wanted.

144
00:07:13.200 --> 00:07:17.230
It says we just had a crash,
this is really bad.

145
00:07:17.230 --> 00:07:21.938
And the monitoring service, the one that's
watching the kernel to see if it locks up,

146
00:07:21.938 --> 00:07:24.968
it says, hey, before I reboot,
if I reboot right now,

147
00:07:24.968 --> 00:07:26.920
you'll never know what happened.

148
00:07:26.920 --> 00:07:29.720
Right, we lose everything that's in RAM.

149
00:07:29.720 --> 00:07:32.595
So what we're gonna use is we're
gonna check the part of RAM,

150
00:07:32.595 --> 00:07:36.487
that the kernel was last accessing, and
we’re going to write it to the hard drive.

151
00:07:36.487 --> 00:07:39.679
We’re going to write that to the hard
drive so that when we reboot,

152
00:07:39.679 --> 00:07:42.985
you’ll have a nice little kernel
dump sitting there on the hard drive

153
00:07:42.985 --> 00:07:46.710
that a developer can look at, and
find out what happened, right?

154
00:07:46.710 --> 00:07:49.870
That’s an important
piece of troubleshooting

155
00:07:49.870 --> 00:07:51.610
a blue screen of death like this.

156
00:07:51.610 --> 00:07:55.216
Now, it takes a developer to interpret
what's in those kernel lumps cause

157
00:07:55.216 --> 00:07:57.003
it's really a dump of memory space.

158
00:07:57.003 --> 00:08:00.303
So, you've got to understand what's being
stored in what memory addresses and

159
00:08:00.303 --> 00:08:02.630
there's not a lot of information
that a regular system,

160
00:08:02.630 --> 00:08:05.463
[INAUDIBLE] can get of that It's to
confusing jumble of mess, right.

161
00:08:05.463 --> 00:08:08.935
But, to a developer they can open that
up and they can see what the programs

162
00:08:08.935 --> 00:08:13.410
are accessing, what they were doing, and
try and identify what that problem is.

163
00:08:13.410 --> 00:08:15.835
Normally, for most of us,
we're gonna take that file and

164
00:08:15.835 --> 00:08:20.835
we're gonna send it in to the Red Hat
tech support or Microsoft tech support or

165
00:08:20.835 --> 00:08:23.295
whoever to get them to

388
00:19:49.520 --> 00:19:51.660

00:19:51.660 --> 00:19:52.890

00:19:52.890 --> 00:19:55.810

00:19:55.810 --> 00:19:57.710
And then I got to access the console and

00:19:57.710 --> 00:20:02.460

393
00:20:02.460 --> 00:20:05.350
What happens is sometimes
a program will try and

394
00:20:05.350 --> 00:20:07.395

the action will fail.

395
00:20:07.395 --> 00:20:10.150

396
00:20:10.150 --> 00:20:13.920

it just continues to retry over and

00:20:13.920 --> 00:20:14.840

00:20:14.840 --> 00:20:15.860

399
00:20:15.860 --> 00:20:17.680

more resources.

00:20:17.680 --> 00:20:21.610

00:20:21.610 --> 00:20:23.680

00:20:31.260 --> 00:20:35.500

00:20:35.500 --> 00:20:37.160

00:20:37.160 --> 00:20:40.380
And when you do that,

00:24:24.617 --> 00:24:27.770

00:24:45.840 --> 00:24:49.040
But if I can't mount it for

00:24:49.040 --> 00:24:52.050
Well, usually it’s gonna

00:24:52.050 --> 00:24:53.880
That I’ve got a disk that for
one reason or

00:24:53.880 --> 00:24:57.630
another is just not able
to be worked with anymore.

00:24:57.630 --> 00:25:00.220
And so when that happens,

00:25:00.220 --> 00:25:03.574

00:25:03.574 --> 00:25:05.400

00:25:10.060 --> 00:25:12.370

00:25:12.370 --> 00:25:16.600
Now, hopefully, the disks will

If they say offline,

00:25:19.250 --> 00:25:22.120
If it said offline, that would let

00:25:22.120 --> 00:25:23.840
problem where I'm not touching the disk.

00:25:23.840 --> 00:25:27.490
You'll see that with SAN disks a lot,

00:25:27.490 --> 00:25:30.858
And you can right-click and

00:25:30.858 --> 00:25:34.050
Mine is already online,

00:25:34.050 --> 00:25:38.050
And if you go to bring it online and it

00:25:38.050 --> 00:25:40.970

00:25:40.970 --> 00:25:44.084
If the drive is showing up, though,

00:25:44.084 --> 00:25:46.063
and maybe it doesn't have a drive letter.

00:25:46.063 --> 00:25:50.030
When that happens, well, if it doesn't

00:25:50.030 --> 00:25:51.200

00:25:51.200 --> 00:25:53.099
So you've got that
Change Drive Letters and Paths.

507
00:25:53.099 --> 00:25:57.640
But if you still get an error,

00:25:57.640 --> 00:26:00.810
Now, there's physical damage and
logical damage.

509
00:26:00.810 --> 00:26:02.410
If it's logical damage, we can correct it.

510
00:26:02.410 --> 00:26:05.450
If it's physical damage,
you can't correct it, can you?

511
00:26:05.450 --> 00:26:06.980
All you can do is work around it.

512
00:26:06.980 --> 00:26:10.780
You ever run one of those disk checkers,
where it scans the disk looking for

513
00:26:10.780 --> 00:26:12.664

514
00:26:12.664 --> 00:26:13.410
What does it do?

515
00:26:13.410 --> 00:26:18.930
Well, what it's doing is it finds an error
and it reads that sector like 20 times.

516
00:26:18.930 --> 00:26:20.550
And it reads it 20 times, and it says,

517
00:26:20.550 --> 00:26:25.080
okay, out of all 20 times, 15 of the times
it looked like there was a one there,

518
00:26:25.080 --> 00:26:27.510
and 5 times it looked like
there was a zero there.

519
00:26:27.510 --> 00:26:31.130
So more often it looked like a one,
I'm gonna assume there was a one there.

520
00:26:31.130 --> 00:26:33.714
And I'm gonna put that in
a different sector, somewhere, and

521
00:26:33.714 --> 00:26:37.500
then I'm gonna take this sector and
mark it as bad, so I don't use it again.

522
00:26:37.500 --> 00:26:41.513
It doesn't fix the error, it just puts
a little rope around it that says,

00:26:41.513 --> 00:26:42.950
don't go there, right?

524
00:26:42.950 --> 00:26:45.099
Imagine if there was
a pothole on the road, and

00:26:45.099 --> 00:26:47.520
you'd just stick an orange
cone on the pothole.

526
00:26:47.520 --> 00:26:50.030
That didn't fix the problem, it just
gets people drive around it, right?

527
00:26:50.030 --> 00:26:52.920
That's what a hard drive sector
repair does, or when you scan a disk.

528
00:26:52.920 --> 00:26:56.610
Just telling people to walk around,
it's not a long-term solution.

529
00:26:56.610 --> 00:27:00.535
And when you have one failure,
it's gonna lead to two, to three, to four.

00:27:00.535 --> 00:27:03.255
Hard drives don't get better, they don't
self-heal, they just get worse, and

531
00:27:03.255 --> 00:27:03.890
worse, and worse.

532
00:27:03.890 --> 00:27:07.207
So the moment you find one

00:27:07.207 --> 00:27:10.228
it needs to be replaced immediately,

00:27:10.228 --> 00:27:14.892
That's the rule, and everybody, Dell,

00:27:14.892 --> 00:27:16.447
they'll replace it.

00:27:16.447 --> 00:27:17.557
That's it, right?

00:27:17.557 --> 00:27:20.527
Even if you get a SMART error, and

00:27:20.527 --> 00:27:21.387
they'll still replace it.

00:27:21.387 --> 00:27:24.287
Like, they don't mess around

540
00:27:24.287 --> 00:27:30.920
But if it's a logical error, maybe I have

00:27:30.920 --> 00:27:35.790
Or I was halfway writing to a file when

00:27:35.790 --> 00:27:38.910
That's not a physical error,

00:27:38.910 --> 00:27:40.170

00:27:55.380 --> 00:27:59.640

00:28:03.280 --> 00:28:07.268

00:28:07.268 --> 00:28:09.085

00:28:09.085 --> 00:28:12.870
And with fsck,

00:28:21.710 --> 00:28:23.130
But what if you have more

00:28:23.130 --> 00:28:27.180
You might have some that are ext,

00:28:27.180 --> 00:28:32.475
The easiest way to scan those and

00:28:32.475 --> 00:28:38.150

00:28:38.150 --> 00:28:41.750
This one right here has a list of
all the file systems that are being

00:28:41.750 --> 00:28:42.420

00:28:42.420 --> 00:28:45.825
And if one of them is failing to boot,
what you can do is,

00:28:45.825 --> 00:28:47.425
way over here on the side.

564
00:28:47.425 --> 00:28:51.820
Let me make this window a little bit

00:28:51.820 --> 00:28:56.306
Way over here on the side,

00:28:56.306 --> 00:28:59.620

00:29:10.710 --> 00:29:13.000
And it'll run the appropriate one for

00:29:13.000 --> 00:29:14.780

00:29:14.780 --> 00:29:18.530
That's important if you've got

00:29:18.530 --> 00:29:20.930

00:29:20.930 --> 00:29:25.430
So that'll make it check it during the

00:29:25.430 --> 00:29:27.980
Or you can just use your

having you here in the studios with us.

612
00:30:56.720 --> 00:30:58.680
And we appreciate you,
the viewer, watching.

613
00:30:58.680 --> 00:31:01.480
Signing out for ITPRO.TV,
I’ve been your host, Wes Bryan.

614
00:31:01.480 --> 00:31:02.120
>> And I’m Don Pezet.

615
00:31:02.120 --> 00:31:03.689
>> And we’ll see you next time.

616
00:31:03.689 --> 00:31:09.837
[MUSIC]

617
00:31:09.837 --> 00:31:12.967
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their exploration of the world of troubleshooting software. They talk about system log write errors, slow operating system performance, patch update failures, service failures, print issues and more. They will also address some of the common causes of these problems.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Software Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.443
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.443 --> 00:00:06.344
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.344 --> 00:00:08.206
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.206 --> 00:00:11.844
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.844 --> 00:00:14.950
>> Hello and welcome to another
great episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.950 --> 00:00:18.203
I'm your host Wes Bryan,
and in today's episode

7
00:00:18.203 --> 00:00:23.030
we are continuing through our
series in CompTIA Server+ SK0-004.

8
00:00:23.030 --> 00:00:25.820
Joining us back in the studios again
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

9
00:00:25.820 --> 00:00:27.120
Don, how are we doing, sir?

10
00:00:27.120 --> 00:00:27.637
>> I'm doing swell, Wes.

11
00:00:27.637 --> 00:00:31.940
Ready to dive right back in and continue
troubleshooting software on our servers,

12
00:00:31.940 --> 00:00:34.040
which is a full time job for most people.

13
00:00:34.040 --> 00:00:36.725
We're gonna be kicking things off with
a couple of different topics here.

14
00:00:36.725 --> 00:00:40.335
The one I wanna launch with is,
cannot write to the system log.

15
00:00:40.335 --> 00:00:44.604
So I've mentioned the system log
in part one and in part two.

16
00:00:44.604 --> 00:00:50.045
And I mentioned that was the first thing
I go to when I troubleshoot a server.

17
00:00:50.045 --> 00:00:53.935
What happens if your system can't
write to the system log, though?

18
00:00:53.935 --> 00:00:55.870
And it does happen, it does happen.

19
00:00:55.870 --> 00:00:59.152
It's a super pain, first off,
cuz you can't write to the system log.

20
00:00:59.152 --> 00:01:02.123
So how are you supposed to add new
events to it if you don't have any

21
00:01:02.123 --> 00:01:03.500
more room to write?

22
00:01:03.500 --> 00:01:05.030
You'll really get into some trouble.

23
00:01:05.030 --> 00:01:09.465
Okay, well, this can be caused
through two different sides.

24
00:01:09.465 --> 00:01:12.020
One side is an actual error,
a problem that you need to correct.

25
00:01:12.020 --> 00:01:14.790
And the other side is a mistake that
you made by configuring things wrong.

26
00:01:14.790 --> 00:01:16.510
So either way, it is a problem.

27
00:01:16.510 --> 00:01:18.540
Let's start with the mistake
that we can make.

28
00:01:18.540 --> 00:01:20.590
System logs grow, they get log messages.

29
00:01:20.590 --> 00:01:23.150
They get bigger and
bigger and bigger over time.

30
00:01:23.150 --> 00:01:26.993
And as they get bigger, eventually
they can fill up the hard drive.

31
00:01:26.993 --> 00:01:30.832
And if your hard drive runs out of space,
can you write anymore to it?

32
00:01:30.832 --> 00:01:33.180
No, you can't, right?

33
00:01:33.180 --> 00:01:38.020
Even on a gigantic hard drive, you can
still have where the log file grows to

34
00:01:38.020 --> 00:01:44.290
such a size it exceeds the maximum
file size for your file system.

35
00:01:44.290 --> 00:01:50.490
Remember that NTFS and EXT4 and XFS,
they all have a maximum file size.

36
00:01:50.490 --> 00:01:52.540
One file can only grow to a certain size.

37
00:01:52.540 --> 00:01:56.030
And if your log file exceeds that,
you can't write any more messages, right?

38
00:01:56.030 --> 00:01:57.860
Those are things that can
lead to this type of problem.

39
00:01:57.860 --> 00:02:00.283
You run out of space and
you got a problem.

40
00:02:00.283 --> 00:02:01.880
So how do we get around that?

41
00:02:01.880 --> 00:02:05.240
Well, there's two technologies
that we need to leverage here.

42
00:02:05.240 --> 00:02:07.341
The first one is log rotation.

43
00:02:07.341 --> 00:02:10.757
Log rotation is where we say,
all right, at the end of each day, or

44
00:02:10.757 --> 00:02:14.661
at the end of each week I take the log,
and I split it off into a separate file,

45
00:02:14.661 --> 00:02:18.710
and I compress it or just let it sit
there or move it somewhere else.

46
00:02:18.710 --> 00:02:22.660
And then I create an all-new
empty log file for the next day.

47
00:02:22.660 --> 00:02:25.140
By doing that,
it's breaking up the log file into pieces.

48
00:02:25.140 --> 00:02:27.820
Now you won't exceed your
maximum file size, but

49
00:02:27.820 --> 00:02:29.830
you could still fill up the hard drive.

50
00:02:29.830 --> 00:02:33.960
And that's where we need
to engage log overwrite.

51
00:02:33.960 --> 00:02:37.290
That it's nice to have a history of logs.

52
00:02:37.290 --> 00:02:40.770
But you don't necessarily need a year's
worth of event log messages for

53
00:02:40.770 --> 00:02:41.620
a server, right?

54
00:02:41.620 --> 00:02:45.590
So we might want to overwrite older
events to make room for newer events.

55
00:02:45.590 --> 00:02:46.700
And you can do that.

56
00:02:46.700 --> 00:02:48.243
It's called,
well there's a few different names.

57
00:02:48.243 --> 00:02:49.909
You hear people call it circular logging,

58
00:02:49.909 --> 00:02:52.780
where you're overwriting old
stuff to make room for new stuff.

59
00:02:52.780 --> 00:02:55.640
Or just phasing out the old records.

60
00:02:55.640 --> 00:02:59.800
It's a good system unless you do
need log messages from a year ago.

61
00:02:59.800 --> 00:03:01.190
What if I need that?

62
00:03:01.190 --> 00:03:03.970
Well, in that scenario you need
to leverage a syslog server or

63
00:03:03.970 --> 00:03:05.100
a remote logging server.

64
00:03:05.100 --> 00:03:07.864
So that your log messages are getting
dumped into a database somewhere, and

65
00:03:07.864 --> 00:03:09.243
that way you can flush out the server,

66
00:03:09.243 --> 00:03:11.770
but know that you have still access
to those records somewhere else.

67
00:03:11.770 --> 00:03:14.585
Database servers can grow really huge.

68
00:03:14.585 --> 00:03:18.075
Message logs aren't designed
to grow that huge, okay?

69
00:03:18.075 --> 00:03:20.205
So that's the number one thing
is that we need to verify, and

70
00:03:20.205 --> 00:03:21.555
now most of our systems
are already doing that.

71
00:03:21.555 --> 00:03:25.946
So for example on this Linux system,
if I take a look at /var/log and

72
00:03:25.946 --> 00:03:28.975
poke around in there,
I can find messages, but

73
00:03:28.975 --> 00:03:34.228
then I've also got these other messages
files here where it's rotated the logs.

74
00:03:34.228 --> 00:03:38.327
At the end of that day it split
it off into its own log file and

75
00:03:38.327 --> 00:03:39.592
it kept it there.

76
00:03:39.592 --> 00:03:46.910
And if we look around inside of our
/etc folder, we'll find logrotate.conf.

77
00:03:46.910 --> 00:03:53.630
And if you look at it,
it's defining in here how to rotate.

78
00:03:53.630 --> 00:03:58.942
And it's set right now to rotate on a,
whoops, what is going on?

79
00:03:58.942 --> 00:04:00.680
Apparently it doesn't
want to let me scroll.

80
00:04:00.680 --> 00:04:03.190
There, so it's set to rotate weekly, so

81
00:04:03.190 --> 00:04:05.320
once a week it's gonna
generate a new file.

82
00:04:05.320 --> 00:04:08.380
It's only gonna keep four
weeks' worth of logs.

83
00:04:08.380 --> 00:04:10.560
So when something's five
weeks old it deletes it.

84
00:04:10.560 --> 00:04:11.240
It makes room.

85
00:04:11.240 --> 00:04:12.990
And I can come in and
edit this and change it and

86
00:04:12.990 --> 00:04:15.200
manipulate it to meet
the needs that I want.

87
00:04:15.200 --> 00:04:17.850
Most Linux distros would
give you that functionality.

88
00:04:17.850 --> 00:04:18.850
Windows is the same way.

89
00:04:18.850 --> 00:04:21.420
In the Windows environment you
have your event viewer, right?

90
00:04:21.420 --> 00:04:25.510
And in the event viewer you can pull
up the properties of any of your logs.

91
00:04:25.510 --> 00:04:28.250
So I can come in here and
take my system log.

92
00:04:28.250 --> 00:04:34.080
And I can jump into it and take a look
at what happens when it gets full.

93
00:04:34.080 --> 00:04:36.450
Now Microsoft doesn't like to break
theirs up into multiple files.

94
00:04:36.450 --> 00:04:38.470
They keep it in a little database already.

95
00:04:38.470 --> 00:04:43.210
But I can still set a maximum log size and
what to do when it's full.

96
00:04:43.210 --> 00:04:47.700
If it's set to Do not override events and
it gets full, I'm not gonna be able to

97
00:04:47.700 --> 00:04:51.780
write to the event log anymore, and I'm
gonna lose error messages and that's bad.

98
00:04:51.780 --> 00:04:56.730
I can say Overwrite events as needed,
which would only do it when it gets full,

99
00:04:56.730 --> 00:04:58.990
or Archive the log when it's full.

100
00:04:58.990 --> 00:05:02.877
Now it will break it up into separate
files, but it's up to me to go and

101
00:05:02.877 --> 00:05:05.170
clean up those old files if I need to.

102
00:05:05.170 --> 00:05:06.750
All right, so
that's something we can customize and

103
00:05:06.750 --> 00:05:10.300
configure to make sure that we get
the retention that we're looking for.

104
00:05:10.300 --> 00:05:11.570
You've got to plan for that.

105
00:05:12.580 --> 00:05:16.860
Now it might be, on the error side, that
your log files are configured properly,

106
00:05:16.860 --> 00:05:19.940
that everything's configured,
you've got rotation in place.

107
00:05:19.940 --> 00:05:21.810
But if your disk runs out of space for

108
00:05:21.810 --> 00:05:27.390
some other reason, now you might not
be able to write to the log files.

109
00:05:27.390 --> 00:05:29.690
So you've always got to
monitor your disk utilization.

110
00:05:29.690 --> 00:05:32.460
In Windows you can use
any number of utilities,

111
00:05:32.460 --> 00:05:34.000
like a performance monitor to do it.

112
00:05:34.000 --> 00:05:35.390
You can use third party software.

113
00:05:35.390 --> 00:05:38.290
In Unix you can use
simple utilities like df.

114
00:05:38.290 --> 00:05:40.820
df will show you each of your drives and

115
00:05:40.820 --> 00:05:43.490
let you evaluate how
much space you've got.

116
00:05:43.490 --> 00:05:47.040
So I can see I've got plenty of
available space on all of my disks.

117
00:05:47.040 --> 00:05:50.030
My logs are being stored in /var/log.

118
00:05:50.030 --> 00:05:55.140
And if I look at my mount points here,
/var doesn't have a separate partition.

119
00:05:55.140 --> 00:05:57.940
A lot of people will put /var
on a separate partition.

120
00:05:57.940 --> 00:06:00.870
On this one it's just gonna be
right here alongside the root.

121
00:06:00.870 --> 00:06:05.220
And that means that while I have
34 gigs available on the root,

122
00:06:05.220 --> 00:06:09.980
anything could eat up that 34 gigs and
that's less space available for my logs.

123
00:06:09.980 --> 00:06:11.813
So I might wanna move those
off to a separate partition so

124
00:06:11.813 --> 00:06:13.221
they're isolated a little more, right?

125
00:06:13.221 --> 00:06:15.568
It's up to me how I want to do that.

126
00:06:15.568 --> 00:06:18.525
All right, there are other things that
could happen, for example file corruption.

127
00:06:18.525 --> 00:06:21.980
I could have where the message
logs get corrupted.

128
00:06:21.980 --> 00:06:25.557
But message logs are so important that
most systems will just create new

129
00:06:25.557 --> 00:06:27.702
empty ones if they ever get corrupted, and

130
00:06:27.702 --> 00:06:31.181
the first entry in that new file will
be that we had to create a new log.

131
00:06:31.181 --> 00:06:33.750
[LAUGH] And so you'll see that right
there as the very first entry.

132
00:06:33.750 --> 00:06:36.350
Doesn't happen often, but
file corruption is possible.

133
00:06:36.350 --> 00:06:38.723
You can run a surface scan of
your disc to look for errors.

134
00:06:38.723 --> 00:06:40.890
If you find any,
definitely replace the disc.

135
00:06:40.890 --> 00:06:42.229
I think we talked about
that in the last episode.

136
00:06:43.740 --> 00:06:45.120
Let's see, what else do we have?

137
00:06:45.120 --> 00:06:47.583
Slow operating system performance.

138
00:06:47.583 --> 00:06:49.370
This one just happens, right?

139
00:06:49.370 --> 00:06:53.220
Operating systems always tend to
feel slower after time goes by.

140
00:06:53.220 --> 00:06:56.660
And sometimes it's just perceived,
I just feel like it's slower.

141
00:06:56.660 --> 00:06:59.460
My laptop is the exact same speed
it was the first day I got it, but

142
00:06:59.460 --> 00:07:02.790
it feels slower today than
when I first got it, right?

143
00:07:02.790 --> 00:07:04.130
But sometimes it's not.

144
00:07:04.130 --> 00:07:07.820
Sometimes there's something actually
different on the system, and

145
00:07:07.820 --> 00:07:09.850
I talked about this in
the server maintenance episode.

146
00:07:09.850 --> 00:07:11.720
So if you didn't watch that,
turn back and check it.

147
00:07:11.720 --> 00:07:16.660
But what you need to do is you need to
always have a baseline of your server.

148
00:07:16.660 --> 00:07:21.575
That baseline is how your server
performs under normal conditions.

149
00:07:21.575 --> 00:07:25.707
And then when things seem weird,
you just run the performance monitor or

150
00:07:25.707 --> 00:07:30.110
whatever performance logging system
you're using to collect new data, and

151
00:07:30.110 --> 00:07:33.080
you compare the new data to the old data.

152
00:07:33.080 --> 00:07:35.150
If it matches, your server's not slower.

153
00:07:35.150 --> 00:07:37.360
But if it doesn't match,
you can spot where it's different.

154
00:07:37.360 --> 00:07:39.316
Hey, my CPU utilization is
higher than it used to,

155
00:07:39.316 --> 00:07:41.370
or my network bandwidth is
higher than it's used to.

156
00:07:41.370 --> 00:07:42.370
Why?

157
00:07:42.370 --> 00:07:43.870
Now you can start digging deeper.

158
00:07:43.870 --> 00:07:46.290
How many users do I have
simultaneously in the system?

159
00:07:46.290 --> 00:07:47.490
Which disks are involved?

160
00:07:47.490 --> 00:07:49.360
Are the disks all healthy, right?

161
00:07:49.360 --> 00:07:53.178
Normally performance comes down to disk on
most systems, if you have spinning disks.

162
00:07:53.178 --> 00:07:55.827
And if you have like a RAID 5
array that's currently degraded,

163
00:07:55.827 --> 00:07:57.457
that's gonna kill your performance.

164
00:07:57.457 --> 00:07:58.669
And so you can find that.

165
00:07:58.669 --> 00:08:02.178
You've gotta look for what's actually
causing that system slow down.

166
00:08:02.178 --> 00:08:03.780
It could just be increased usage, though.

167
00:08:03.780 --> 00:08:05.490
Your company grows, resources grow.

168
00:08:05.490 --> 00:08:08.350
People become more dependent on them and
now the system runs slower.

169
00:08:08.350 --> 00:08:09.670
So it's time to upgrade.

170
00:08:09.670 --> 00:08:11.860
And you can see that with
trending in performance analysis.

171
00:08:11.860 --> 00:08:17.370
I think I've mentioned that 20 times
this series, so I won't harp on it here.

172
00:08:17.370 --> 00:08:19.600
Patch update failure.

173
00:08:19.600 --> 00:08:22.820
This is one of those that is super
frustrating, cuz it shouldn't happen.

174
00:08:22.820 --> 00:08:23.860
But I've had it happen.

175
00:08:23.860 --> 00:08:28.570
I've had it where Microsoft releases
Service Pack 3 for an operating system.

176
00:08:28.570 --> 00:08:32.980
And I go and download the service pack and
I run it, and it fails to install.

177
00:08:32.980 --> 00:08:35.840
Here's a service pack, a service that
is supposed to be fixing bugs and for

178
00:08:35.840 --> 00:08:37.680
some reason, it won't install.

179
00:08:37.680 --> 00:08:40.990
All right now,
why would a patch not install?

180
00:08:40.990 --> 00:08:42.230
It could be there's
a problem with the patch.

181
00:08:42.230 --> 00:08:42.850
That does happen.

182
00:08:42.850 --> 00:08:45.855
Every now and then a bad patch makes
it through quality control and

183
00:08:45.855 --> 00:08:48.433
gets released to the public,
but it's not very often.

184
00:08:48.433 --> 00:08:51.431
If you're ever worried about that, you
can always go and check the news feeds,

185
00:08:51.431 --> 00:08:54.430
right, look at the Microsoft blog,
or the Red Hat blog, or whatever.

186
00:08:54.430 --> 00:08:55.910
Go to their communities and forums and

187
00:08:55.910 --> 00:08:57.585
see if other people
are reporting the same problem.

188
00:08:57.585 --> 00:09:00.180
That's a good way to spot if
it's a problem with the update.

189
00:09:00.180 --> 00:09:02.294
But if it's just a problem on your system,

190
00:09:02.294 --> 00:09:05.320
then it's normally gonna
come down to two things.

191
00:09:05.320 --> 00:09:09.380
One is HIPS,
host-based intrusion prevention systems.

192
00:09:09.380 --> 00:09:12.930
That if you have anti-virus,
or anti-malware, or

193
00:09:12.930 --> 00:09:18.060
if you have application whitelist,
all those can block patches and updates.

194
00:09:18.060 --> 00:09:21.400
So, I might be trying to apply a patch,
and my anti-virus software is stopping it,

195
00:09:21.400 --> 00:09:24.440
or my intrusion prevention, or whatever it
is that I’m running might be stopping it.

196
00:09:24.440 --> 00:09:29.120
So I might need to either white list
the update, or disable the HIPS

197
00:09:29.120 --> 00:09:31.850
while I’m doing the update and
then I can turn the HIPS back on, right?

198
00:09:31.850 --> 00:09:34.620
So, that’s kind of one
thing that can cause it.

199
00:09:34.620 --> 00:09:36.780
The other thing that can cause it is,

200
00:09:36.780 --> 00:09:40.290
often times we can get conflicting
updates from different sources.

201
00:09:40.290 --> 00:09:42.400
I get this with network
adapters all the time.

202
00:09:42.400 --> 00:09:47.470
If I get a server from HPE,
and it's got Intel NICs in it.

203
00:09:47.470 --> 00:09:49.990
Those Intel NICs are gonna
get drivers from HPE.

204
00:09:49.990 --> 00:09:52.980
And I can download and install them and
have the latest drivers.

205
00:09:52.980 --> 00:09:54.900
Or, are they the latest?

206
00:09:54.900 --> 00:09:58.760
I can get the latest drivers
that HPE has certified.

207
00:09:58.760 --> 00:10:01.580
But Intel is putting out
new drivers all the time.

208
00:10:01.580 --> 00:10:06.260
So I might go to Intel's website,
and find an even newer version.

209
00:10:06.260 --> 00:10:12.284
Maybe HPE is pushing out 10.4.3 and
on Intel's site they have 10.4.11.

210
00:10:12.284 --> 00:10:14.410
And they fixed some bug
that I'm experiencing.

211
00:10:14.410 --> 00:10:17.120
So I go and get Intel's version and
I deploy it.

212
00:10:17.120 --> 00:10:21.670
Well, once I've deployed that, if
an update comes out from HPE it might be

213
00:10:21.670 --> 00:10:24.950
older than what I've already got and
the patch will fail to apply.

214
00:10:24.950 --> 00:10:26.870
This happens a lot with Microsoft.

215
00:10:26.870 --> 00:10:31.280
Microsoft does push hardware
updates with Windows updates.

216
00:10:31.280 --> 00:10:32.500
You do get them.

217
00:10:32.500 --> 00:10:36.930
I don't know if this server has taken any,
but if I take this server and

218
00:10:36.930 --> 00:10:41.670
go into, let's see, Programs and Features.

219
00:10:42.700 --> 00:10:44.840
And we take a look at

00:13:41.030 --> 00:13:49.800

00:21:31.010 --> 00:21:32.341
