examining your hardware.

457
00:21:41.670 --> 00:21:46.270
If I have a server that just does a total
hang like that, the first thing I do,

458
00:21:46.270 --> 00:21:48.000
run a hardware diagnostic.

459
00:21:48.000 --> 00:21:50.166
If it's a Dell server,
I go Dell's site and

460
00:21:50.166 --> 00:21:52.400
I get their Dell
diagnostic bootable media.

461
00:21:52.400 --> 00:21:54.927
I boot off of that, and
I run the hardware diagnostic.

462
00:21:54.927 --> 00:21:57.250
If it's HP, I do the same thing,
but with their diagnostic.

463
00:21:57.250 --> 00:22:00.150
Each of them have their own little
diagnostic you can run and more

464
00:22:00.150 --> 00:22:03.530
often than not, you'll find a hardware
failure that goes along with that, okay?

465
00:22:03.530 --> 00:22:06.393
Now if you don't find a hardware,
if the hardware is fine and

466
00:22:06.393 --> 00:22:10.056
you're getting a hang like that,
that usually means something really bad.

467
00:22:10.056 --> 00:22:12.055
It's gotta be something
with that operating system,

468
00:22:12.055 --> 00:22:14.160
and I'll typically rebuild the server.

469
00:22:14.160 --> 00:22:16.700
Go to your backups,
bring the system back up from backups.

470
00:22:16.700 --> 00:22:17.550
It sounds like a lot of work,

471
00:22:17.550 --> 00:22:20.000
but I don't want a server that's
just gonna randomly freeze.

472
00:22:20.000 --> 00:22:21.274
Who knows when that outage is gonna be?

473
00:22:21.274 --> 00:22:22.398
It's time to rebuild.

474
00:22:22.398 --> 00:22:23.750
All right?
But I'll always check the hardware,

475
00:22:23.750 --> 00:22:24.979
because that's usually where
that one will come from.

476
00:22:26.720 --> 00:22:30.073
All right, the last one is becoming
a decreasing problem over the years.

477
00:22:30.073 --> 00:22:31.690
And it's users can't print.

478
00:22:31.690 --> 00:22:33.340
When I used to film these shows,

479
00:22:33.340 --> 00:22:37.000
I would always talk about how most users
are happy as long as they can print.

480
00:22:37.000 --> 00:22:39.590
It's the moment a user can't print
that they really start to annoy

481
00:22:39.590 --> 00:22:40.500
the heck out of you.

482
00:22:40.500 --> 00:22:43.470
I don't know why people always had this
dependency on printing, but now thanks to

483
00:22:43.470 --> 00:22:47.640
email, people email attachments and
we see people print a lot less.

484
00:22:47.640 --> 00:22:49.200
But, if people can't print,
they still get annoyed.

485
00:22:49.200 --> 00:22:53.480
And usually printer errors come
down to just a couple of things.

486
00:22:53.480 --> 00:22:54.990
Permissions can be a big part.

487
00:22:54.990 --> 00:22:56.530
If you don't have permission
to access the printer,

488
00:22:56.530 --> 00:22:57.670
you're not going to be able to print.

489
00:22:57.670 --> 00:22:59.320
But, that's not normally a random thing.

490
00:22:59.320 --> 00:23:02.330
They usually either never had
the permissions or they always had them.

491
00:23:02.330 --> 00:23:02.920
One or the other.

492
00:23:02.920 --> 00:23:05.160
It's not like we're changing
permissions all the time.

493
00:23:05.160 --> 00:23:05.960
Well maybe you are.

494
00:23:05.960 --> 00:23:07.524
Maybe you get bored and you do it.

495
00:23:07.524 --> 00:23:10.880
But other things that can cause
us not to be able to print.

496
00:23:10.880 --> 00:23:12.520
Running out of disk space.

497
00:23:12.520 --> 00:23:13.110
Right?

498
00:23:13.110 --> 00:23:17.040
When you print what you're printing
to is actually printing to a driver,

499
00:23:17.040 --> 00:23:18.400
like a virtual device.

500
00:23:18.400 --> 00:23:20.330
And it takes your print job and
it turns it into an image and

501
00:23:20.330 --> 00:23:22.040
it stores it on the hard drive.

502
00:23:22.040 --> 00:23:23.281
And then it takes that image and

503
00:23:23.281 --> 00:23:25.686
it sends that to the physical
printer where it gets output.

504
00:23:25.686 --> 00:23:27.351
And once it comes out of
the physical printer,

505
00:23:27.351 --> 00:23:29.430
then it deletes the image
on the hard drive.

506
00:23:29.430 --> 00:23:31.430
Well if your hard drive is full,
can you print?

507
00:23:32.660 --> 00:23:33.399
Not usually.

508
00:23:33.399 --> 00:23:36.663
Some systems like Cups under Linux,
you can tell it to just cache in RAM, but

509
00:23:36.663 --> 00:23:39.366
the problem in caching in RAM is
if the server ever reboots or for

510
00:23:39.366 --> 00:23:41.120
some reason you lose all the print jobs.

511
00:23:41.120 --> 00:23:42.895
If it's written to the hard drive,
you can reboot and

512
00:23:42.895 --> 00:23:44.050
then the jobs are all still there.

513
00:23:44.050 --> 00:23:46.627
So, they normally write to the disk,
and if the disk is full,

514
00:23:46.627 --> 00:23:48.475
you're not gonna be able to print, right?

515
00:23:48.475 --> 00:23:49.908
So that can cause it.

516
00:23:49.908 --> 00:23:52.500
But the other thing that can
cause it is just print drivers.

517
00:23:52.500 --> 00:23:54.709
Printer drivers are weird.

518
00:23:54.709 --> 00:23:57.541
There are so many different types of
printers these days because they couldn't

519
00:23:57.541 --> 00:23:58.481
leave well enough alone.

520
00:23:58.481 --> 00:23:59.830
It's kinda like cell phones, right?

521
00:23:59.830 --> 00:24:02.500
You get a cell phone, it can make phone
calls, and it can send an email, and

522
00:24:02.500 --> 00:24:05.680
it can browse the web, and it can play
music, and it's got bluetooth and all

523
00:24:05.680 --> 00:24:08.950
this crazy stuff that has nothing to do
with phone calls, but it does it, right?

524
00:24:08.950 --> 00:24:09.630
That's how printers are.

525
00:24:09.630 --> 00:24:14.349
They have scanners built in to them,
and staplers, and hole-punchers,

526
00:24:14.349 --> 00:24:18.110
and paper trays, and
all sorts of crazy stuff on them.

527
00:24:18.110 --> 00:24:20.282
Right, you can watch SportsCenter on them.

528
00:24:20.282 --> 00:24:23.060
And it's just way more than
what a normal printer does.

529
00:24:23.060 --> 00:24:26.500
So you need special drivers and
software to be able to handle that.

530
00:24:26.500 --> 00:24:29.760
Well operating system patches and
updates can break those drivers.

531
00:24:29.760 --> 00:24:32.480
The drivers themselves are not
normally all that well written.

532
00:24:32.480 --> 00:24:34.620
So we need to make sure those
drivers are staying up to date and

533
00:24:34.620 --> 00:24:35.870
that they're compatible.

534
00:24:35.870 --> 00:24:37.770
If I'm using a print server,

535
00:24:37.770 --> 00:24:40.750
I'll have a server that might be
a 64 bit server with 64 bit drivers.

536
00:24:40.750 --> 00:24:45.460
And then I have clients that might
be 32 bit, using 32 bit drivers.

537
00:24:45.460 --> 00:24:47.190
Not exactly compatible, are they?

538
00:24:47.190 --> 00:24:48.770
Well, maybe they are.

539
00:24:48.770 --> 00:24:50.760
Maybe the print job is the same and
it moves through just fine.

540
00:24:50.760 --> 00:24:51.510
Or maybe they aren't.

541
00:24:51.510 --> 00:24:54.150
I need to evaluate that and
find out is that a viable alternative?

542
00:24:54.150 --> 00:24:55.010
Can I use that?

543
00:24:55.010 --> 00:24:58.360
Or I might be in a situation where
even though I have a 64-bit server,

544
00:24:58.360 --> 00:25:02.570
I have to use the 32-bit driver to match
the clients, to make sure it communicates.

545
00:25:02.570 --> 00:25:04.120
It's not always like that,
but I have seen it.

546
00:25:04.120 --> 00:25:06.380
So we always doublecheck those drivers.

547
00:25:06.380 --> 00:25:09.860
That's a big part of
bring unable to print.

548
00:25:09.860 --> 00:25:11.410
Permissions and drivers.

549
00:25:11.410 --> 00:25:12.710
That's usually where we go.

550
00:25:12.710 --> 00:25:14.830
Running out of disk space
is usually pretty obvious,

551
00:25:14.830 --> 00:25:16.220
but it's another possibility.

552
00:25:17.590 --> 00:25:20.560
Also keep in mind that most printers
are network printers these days.

553
00:25:20.560 --> 00:25:23.670
So people aren't using a print servers,
they're going straight to the printer and

554
00:25:23.670 --> 00:25:24.630
that bypasses this need.

555
00:25:24.630 --> 00:25:27.100
That's another reason why we see
this less and less these days.

556
00:25:28.930 --> 00:25:31.740
All right, I think we chewed through
all the common problems at this point.

557
00:25:31.740 --> 00:25:34.210
There's only a few little things
that I haven't mentioned.

558
00:25:34.210 --> 00:25:37.500
On the printing side
there is one other thing,

559
00:25:37.500 --> 00:25:40.070
like if there's a printer driver issue.

560
00:25:40.070 --> 00:25:43.570
There's normally a sister service that
goes along with it called a print spooler.

561
00:25:43.570 --> 00:25:46.044
When you write to the hard drive,
it's the spooler that does that, and

562
00:25:46.044 --> 00:25:46.919
the spooler could stop.

563
00:25:46.919 --> 00:25:51.110
So the old fix in Windows that we used to
always do is just restart that service.

564
00:25:51.110 --> 00:25:54.390
So, if you jump into your Windows
services, you can hunt in here and

565
00:25:54.390 --> 00:25:56.030
find that print spooler.

566
00:25:56.030 --> 00:25:56.950
It'll be buried in here.

567
00:25:56.950 --> 00:25:59.850
It's usually just called print spooler.

568
00:25:59.850 --> 00:26:05.020
And restarting that print spooler
can cause it to reload the drivers,

569
00:26:05.020 --> 00:26:07.330
and when it reloads the drivers
that can fix a problem, right?

570
00:26:07.330 --> 00:26:08.540
It doesn't change the drivers.

571
00:26:08.540 --> 00:26:09.997
If you've got a bad driver,
it's still gonna be bad and

572
00:26:09.997 --> 00:26:10.995
you're still not gonna be printing.

573
00:26:10.995 --> 00:26:14.840
But if your jobs are stuck, that kind
of frees it up and move it along.

574
00:26:14.840 --> 00:26:17.859
Same thing in Linux with the CUPS system,
you can restart its service and

575
00:26:17.859 --> 00:26:19.854
then off you go there and
you're able to print.

576
00:26:19.854 --> 00:26:23.210
CUPS is the Common Unix Print Service.

577
00:26:23.210 --> 00:26:27.380
It's the equivalent of
the Windows print spooler system.

578
00:26:27.380 --> 00:26:30.600
All right Don, well we've been through
a lot of different situations here.

579
00:26:30.600 --> 00:26:31.476
A lot of technologies and

580
00:26:31.476 --> 00:26:33.488
it does look like we're coming
to the end of the episode.

581
00:26:33.488 --> 00:26:37.560
But before we do, do you have any last
things maybe you would like to talk about

582
00:26:37.560 --> 00:26:41.560
or maybe some words of advice when it
comes to troubleshooting software?

583
00:26:41.560 --> 00:26:45.832
>> All right, I have one last thing I have
to mention to be objective completely.

584
00:26:45.832 --> 00:26:48.262
We wanna make sure we cover
all the exam objective and

585
00:26:48.262 --> 00:26:51.660
CompTIA calls out disk fragmentation,
right?

586
00:26:51.660 --> 00:26:55.635
In today's world, we don't worry
about disk fragmentation anymore.

587
00:26:55.635 --> 00:26:58.135
If you have SSDs,
fragmentation's actually a good thing.

588
00:26:58.135 --> 00:27:01.085
You're able to read and write from
different sectors at the same speed as if

589
00:27:01.085 --> 00:27:03.455
they were all in order, so
it doesn't really matter.

590
00:27:03.455 --> 00:27:08.347
Even on spinning disks, though,
most of our file systems, like EXT4, and

591
00:27:08.347 --> 00:27:11.897
XFS, NTFS, they're all self defragmenting.

592
00:27:11.897 --> 00:27:15.047
So as files get broken up on the disk,
the next time you access them,

593
00:27:15.047 --> 00:27:16.497
it tries to fix it for you.

594
00:27:16.497 --> 00:27:18.454
So for most of us,
we never worry about fragmentation.

595
00:27:18.454 --> 00:27:19.917
But they do call it out on the exam.

596
00:27:19.917 --> 00:27:23.602
If you see server performance starting
to decline, usually it's after you done

597
00:27:23.602 --> 00:27:27.230
like millions of deletes, if you have a
ton of small files, then you start to see

598
00:27:27.230 --> 00:27:31.270
performance declining, and
you might need to run a defragmentation.

599
00:27:31.270 --> 00:27:34.270
In the Linux and
Unix world it's done automatically,

600
00:27:34.270 --> 00:27:37.130
in the Windows world it's done
automatically too if you've got NTFS.

601
00:27:37.130 --> 00:27:40.780
But if you're still running FAT32,
or exFAT, they fragment,

602
00:27:40.780 --> 00:27:42.900
and they don't automatically defragment.

603
00:27:42.900 --> 00:27:45.370
And so on those scenarios you
might need to defragment.

604
00:27:45.370 --> 00:27:48.400
It's very uncommon, but it is
something that's still out there, and

605
00:27:48.400 --> 00:27:50.010
the tools are all still in there.

606
00:27:50.010 --> 00:27:52.860
If I take my Windows Server
that I've got sitting here.

607
00:27:52.860 --> 00:27:56.110
Let me just bring up computer management.

608
00:27:56.110 --> 00:27:58.490
We can get into our disk management.

609
00:27:58.490 --> 00:28:03.660
And inside of disk management, you can
pick a disk and pull up its properties.

610
00:28:04.770 --> 00:28:06.010
And in the Tools screen.

611
00:28:06.010 --> 00:28:08.690
I brought this screen up earlier when I
was showing some of the like check for

612
00:28:08.690 --> 00:28:09.730
errors and stuff.

613
00:28:09.730 --> 00:28:11.980
You've got optimize and defragment drive.

614
00:28:11.980 --> 00:28:14.320
So, I can actually defragment right here.

615
00:28:14.320 --> 00:28:17.240
But, I'll tell you right now,
if you have SSD.

616
00:28:17.240 --> 00:28:19.130
It's not gonna make any difference, right?

617
00:28:19.130 --> 00:28:20.950
You don't need to defragment.

618
00:28:20.950 --> 00:28:24.110
If you've got NTFS,
it's self defragmenting.

619
00:28:24.110 --> 00:28:25.830
So, you really shouldn't
have to mess with it,

620
00:28:25.830 --> 00:28:30.640
unless you've done millions of small
deletes all in a short period of time.

621
00:28:30.640 --> 00:28:33.020
So really just comes down to FAT32 and
exFAT.

622
00:28:33.020 --> 00:28:35.600
If you got file systems that are like
that, you need to come in here.

623
00:28:35.600 --> 00:28:37.050
Do a quick analyze.

624
00:28:37.050 --> 00:28:41.160
And then run the defragmentation just to
make sure all the files are in order to

625
00:28:41.160 --> 00:28:42.090
optimize performance.

626
00:28:42.090 --> 00:28:44.786
So they call it [INAUDIBLE] objectives,
because you might have older servers.

627
00:28:44.786 --> 00:28:46.341
You might still have some
of those file systems.

628
00:28:46.341 --> 00:28:49.908
But if you do, your real troubleshooting
steps here should be finding out why you

629
00:28:49.908 --> 00:28:51.940
haven't planned to replace them yet.

630
00:28:51.940 --> 00:28:53.320
That would be the real step.

631
00:28:53.320 --> 00:28:56.610
>> All right, well that's a great place
to round this one up, Don, as always.

632
00:28:56.610 --> 00:28:58.870
We do appreciate having you
with us in the studios.

633
00:28:58.870 --> 00:29:00.870
And we appreciate you the viewer watching.

634
00:29:00.870 --> 00:29:03.890
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

635
00:29:03.890 --> 00:29:04.520
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

636
00:29:04.520 --> 00:29:05.759
>> And we'll see you next time.

637
00:29:05.759 --> 00:29:12.296
[MUSIC]

638
00:29:12.296 --> 00:29:15.244
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this, episode Wes and Don tackle troubleshooting networking issues that arise on modern networks. They talk about various topics such as Internet connection failures, resource unavailability, DHCP issues, DNS issues and more.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Networking
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.180
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.180 --> 00:00:03.425
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.425 --> 00:00:05.664
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.664 --> 00:00:07.485
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.485 --> 00:00:11.022
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.100 --> 00:00:14.900
Hello and welcome to another
great episode here at ITPro TV.

7
00:00:14.900 --> 00:00:17.730
I'm your host Wes Bryan and
today's episode,

8
00:00:17.730 --> 00:00:22.200
we're continuing through our
series on CompTIA Server+ SK0-004.

9
00:00:22.200 --> 00:00:25.499
And joining us in the studios today
is non other than Mister Don Pezet.

10
00:00:25.499 --> 00:00:26.420
Don, how you doing, sir?

11
00:00:26.420 --> 00:00:28.787
>> I am doing swell Wes, ready to dive
right back in to troubleshooting.

12
00:00:28.787 --> 00:00:31.950
>> We've talked about hardware,
we've talked about software.

13
00:00:31.950 --> 00:00:34.340
Now we're gonna jump over to networking,

14
00:00:34.340 --> 00:00:37.560
and networking is kind of a fun one
to troubleshoot on a server because

15
00:00:37.560 --> 00:00:40.330
it's pretty rare that the problem
is on the server itself.

16
00:00:40.330 --> 00:00:43.370
Usually when there's a network issue it's,
well, it's the network, right?

17
00:00:43.370 --> 00:00:45.293
I mean that's the whole
point of a network issue.

18
00:00:45.293 --> 00:00:50.040
But we don't normally see it on
the network, we see it on the server.

19
00:00:50.040 --> 00:00:53.750
So the issue develops,
we see an issue on our server, and

20
00:00:53.750 --> 00:00:55.640
then we need to troubleshoot and
figure out where that problem is.

21
00:00:55.640 --> 00:00:57.429
And if it does turn out to
be problem on the server,

22
00:00:57.429 --> 00:00:58.846
obviously we can resolve it and fix it.

23
00:00:58.846 --> 00:01:00.864
But if it's a problem on the network,

24
00:01:00.864 --> 00:01:04.470
we can engage with the networking
services team, or whoever it is.

25
00:01:04.470 --> 00:01:06.016
In a small business, it might be you.

26
00:01:06.016 --> 00:01:09.251
In a large organization,
you'll have a separate network team, and

27
00:01:09.251 --> 00:01:12.152
you can engage with them and
provide them the information that

28
00:01:12.152 --> 00:01:14.620
will best help them define and
resolve the issue.

29
00:01:14.620 --> 00:01:16.130
Right, that's really
what this is all about,

30
00:01:16.130 --> 00:01:18.930
is we wanna help people have the right
information to solve problems as

31
00:01:18.930 --> 00:01:20.290
quickly as possible.

32
00:01:20.290 --> 00:01:22.610
Well, in the server world,

33
00:01:22.610 --> 00:01:25.670
there's not all that much variation
in the way of networking, right?

34
00:01:25.670 --> 00:01:27.270
If you think about it, like a laptop.

35
00:01:28.490 --> 00:01:31.830
I might have wireless connectivity,
I might have wired connectivity.

36
00:01:31.830 --> 00:01:35.198
I might have a cellular
card plugged into it.

37
00:01:35.198 --> 00:01:37.043
But what are we gonna have in a server?

38
00:01:37.043 --> 00:01:38.223
Well in a server,

39
00:01:38.223 --> 00:01:43.358
we're usually just going to have
physical network adapters and that's it.

40
00:01:43.358 --> 00:01:48.067
So when I jump into my network screens
here and I go to change my adapter

41
00:01:48.067 --> 00:01:52.950
setting, I'm just gonna see pretty
much typical ethernet adapters.

42
00:01:52.950 --> 00:01:55.700
I may have one, I may have two,
I may have four but

43
00:01:55.700 --> 00:01:58.710
they're normally going to be
copper based ethernet adapters.

44
00:01:58.710 --> 00:02:00.190
You may have fiber from time to time, but

45
00:02:00.190 --> 00:02:02.840
even the fiber ones
are ethernet at this point.

46
00:02:02.840 --> 00:02:07.106
So the technology is so consistent that
it makes troubleshooting things very,

47
00:02:07.106 --> 00:02:09.810
very simple and pretty straightforward.

48
00:02:09.810 --> 00:02:12.820
Also there's a lot of technology
that you use on a mobile device or

49
00:02:12.820 --> 00:02:14.240
a desktop that you don't
use on the server side.

50
00:02:14.240 --> 00:02:16.270
For example, DHCP right?

51
00:02:16.270 --> 00:02:18.483
DHCP, dynamic host configuration protocol.

52
00:02:18.483 --> 00:02:23.930
CompTIA calls that as one of the common
problems is DHCP server misconfigured.

53
00:02:23.930 --> 00:02:25.720
It can be misconfigured, absolutely.

54
00:02:25.720 --> 00:02:29.092
And for work stations, that will
really affect them, but for servers,

55
00:02:29.092 --> 00:02:30.819
we typically do static IPs, right.

56
00:02:30.819 --> 00:02:33.470
So that's not really something
we have to worry about.

57
00:02:33.470 --> 00:02:37.420
But not always, there are plenty of
organizations that leverage DHCP

58
00:02:37.420 --> 00:02:41.900
with their servers and
you really see it in the cloud.

59
00:02:41.900 --> 00:02:46.100
When we're deploying cloud services,
we're doing things like with Amazon's EC2,

60
00:02:46.100 --> 00:02:47.438
you can do auto-scaling.

61
00:02:47.438 --> 00:02:50.680
So I might have ten servers right now and
as things get busy, it grows to 20 or

62
00:02:50.680 --> 00:02:51.960
50 servers.

63
00:02:51.960 --> 00:02:55.615
Well if those servers are just
spinning up almost at random,

64
00:02:55.615 --> 00:02:59.998
I can't be assigning static IPs to all
of them and keeping track of that.

65
00:02:59.998 --> 00:03:04.165
I need this to be dynamic,
so they're gonna use DHCP.

66
00:03:04.165 --> 00:03:07.675
Or I might be using static IPs, but

67
00:03:07.675 --> 00:03:12.205
still using DHCP to get things like
my DNS servers or my default gateway.

68
00:03:12.205 --> 00:03:15.314
You can get pieces of your network
configuration with DHCP and

69
00:03:15.314 --> 00:03:17.004
have other parts of it be static.

70
00:03:17.004 --> 00:03:19.837
Now, why don't we use DHCP with a server?

71
00:03:19.837 --> 00:03:20.407
Well, why not?

72
00:03:20.407 --> 00:03:24.197
Well, we typically don't want one server

73
00:03:24.197 --> 00:03:27.660
to be dependent on another server
unless we absolutely have to.

74
00:03:27.660 --> 00:03:32.320
If I have a web server and the content
on that website is being rendered from

75
00:03:32.320 --> 00:03:35.110
a database, the web server is
dependent on the database.

76
00:03:35.110 --> 00:03:38.070
So if the database goes offline,
the website doesn't work.

77
00:03:38.070 --> 00:03:40.440
If the website goes offline,
people can't get to the database.

78
00:03:40.440 --> 00:03:43.791
So those two are dependent and
there's not much you can do about that.

79
00:03:43.791 --> 00:03:45.810
But a DHCP server,

80
00:03:45.810 --> 00:03:48.860
what happens if the DHCP server's
offline and my server reboots?

81
00:03:50.040 --> 00:03:51.439
It can't get an address, right?

82
00:03:51.439 --> 00:03:54.860
If it can't get an address, nobody can
get to it, it's not gonna function.

83
00:03:54.860 --> 00:03:58.550
And all I had to do was assign a static IP
and I didn't have to have that dependency.

84
00:03:58.550 --> 00:04:01.140
So if we can eliminate that dependency,
all the better.

85
00:04:02.150 --> 00:04:06.765
But not everybody does that because you're
planning for things like autoscaling,

86
00:04:06.765 --> 00:04:10.865
where it becomes important to have
flexibility over reduced dependency.

87
00:04:10.865 --> 00:04:15.890
Now, how do we solve that flexibility
over reduced dependency thing?

88
00:04:15.890 --> 00:04:17.990
We have more servers,
more networks, right?

89
00:04:17.990 --> 00:04:20.548
If you're deploying in the cloud,
you just don't deploy in one data center,

90
00:04:20.548 --> 00:04:22.271
you deploy in two, or three,
or four data centers.

91
00:04:22.271 --> 00:04:25.854
And that if the DHCP system fails in
one center, you still have servers in

92
00:04:25.854 --> 00:04:30.120
the other centers that are working just
fine, so you overcome it by scale.

93
00:04:30.120 --> 00:04:34.188
And if you're in an enterprise environment
you probably have 100s, 1,000s,

94
00:04:34.188 --> 00:04:38.580
10,000s of servers, it's very realistic
that you have that kind of model.

95
00:04:38.580 --> 00:04:41.190
In a medium sized business or
a small business,

96
00:04:41.190 --> 00:04:44.310
you probably do all static IPs
on your servers to reduce that.

97
00:04:44.310 --> 00:04:48.940
Whenever you do static IPs, there's
always the risk of misconfiguration.

98
00:04:48.940 --> 00:04:51.890
You could misconfigure the IP address,
although that doesn't normally happen.

99
00:04:51.890 --> 00:04:55.610
Normally, it's misconfiguring
the subnet mask with a default gateway.

100
00:04:55.610 --> 00:05:00.230
If I put the wrong subnet mask in, I don't
know what hosts are on my network and

101
00:05:00.230 --> 00:05:01.990
what hosts aren't on my network.

102
00:05:01.990 --> 00:05:06.190
So for example, here in the ITProTV
studios, we use the 10-dot Network.

103
00:05:06.190 --> 00:05:11.518
And most of our equipment, like this
server that I'm connected to right now,

104
00:05:11.518 --> 00:05:15.717
this server is, actually I'm
probably gonna regret this but

105
00:05:15.717 --> 00:05:18.238
I think it's actually set for DHCP.

106
00:05:18.238 --> 00:05:20.570
[LAUGH] No, it does have a static IP,
so this is server has a static IP.

107
00:05:20.570 --> 00:05:24.785
And it's on the 10-dot network,
see how it's 10.0.222.223?

108
00:05:24.785 --> 00:05:28.200
Well, let's say that
information wasn't in there.

109
00:05:28.200 --> 00:05:32.400
When I fill this out and I come in to
start typing all of the information in

110
00:05:32.400 --> 00:05:36.080
that it needs for an IP address,
Microsoft tries to help me.

111
00:05:36.080 --> 00:05:39.130
And so when I type in 10.0.222.223 and
hit Tab,

112
00:05:39.130 --> 00:05:42.910
see how it tried to fill
in the subnet mask for me?

113
00:05:43.910 --> 00:05:47.690
And it looked at that first octet and
said, well back in the old days,

114
00:05:47.690 --> 00:05:50.780
something that starts with a 10 would be
a Class A, and that's gonna be 255.0.0.0.

115
00:05:50.780 --> 00:05:56.363
So it puts that in as a suggestion.

116
00:05:56.363 --> 00:06:00.265
But we don't use it that way here
in the studio, here in the studio,

117
00:06:00.265 --> 00:06:02.402
it's actually 255 255 0 0.

118
00:06:02.402 --> 00:06:03.394
We treat it as a Class B so

119
00:06:03.394 --> 00:06:06.530
that we have enough IPs to handle
the machines here on the network.

120
00:06:06.530 --> 00:06:09.115
And then we have a VPN network that
uses 10.1, I think, and 10.2 and

121
00:06:09.115 --> 00:06:12.640
10.3 are used by some of the other
tenants here in the building.

122
00:06:12.640 --> 00:06:14.457
And they get used by other people.

123
00:06:14.457 --> 00:06:18.554
If I use the wrong subnet mask,
I'm gonna assume that anybody that

124
00:06:18.554 --> 00:06:22.225
starts with 10-dot is gonna
be on the same network as me.

125
00:06:22.225 --> 00:06:26.820
And I can get to them without going
through a router, but that's not true.

126
00:06:26.820 --> 00:06:31.130
In reality, I can only get to
people who start with 10.0 and

127
00:06:31.130 --> 00:06:32.900
my subnet mask has to be correct.

128
00:06:32.900 --> 00:06:37.790
So if you have a server that is unable
to connect to some internal hosts but

129
00:06:37.790 --> 00:06:41.460
can connect to others, it's oftentimes
tied to an incorrect subnet mask.

130
00:06:41.460 --> 00:06:44.768
And we can correct that pretty easily and
get it put back in place.

131
00:06:44.768 --> 00:06:48.111
These auto-suggested subnet masks
are pretty frequently wrong, because a lot

132
00:06:48.111 --> 00:06:51.390
of us are doing what's called VLSM,
Variable Length Subnet Masking.

133
00:06:51.390 --> 00:06:53.550
We're changing the length
of the subnet mask and

134
00:06:53.550 --> 00:06:55.560
throwing away the old classical system.

135
00:06:55.560 --> 00:06:58.680
So, you can't interpret, you can't guess
what the subnet mask is going to be.

136
00:06:59.969 --> 00:07:03.874
Now, the default gateway, that's when I'm
gonna be talking to somebody who's not on

137
00:07:03.874 --> 00:07:05.790
the same network as me.

138
00:07:05.790 --> 00:07:10.660
If I leave it empty like this, I can talk
to other people on the same network, but

139
00:07:10.660 --> 00:07:12.330
I can't talk to people
on a different network.

140
00:07:12.330 --> 00:07:15.680
So I'd be able to talk to
anybody who started with 10.0

141
00:07:15.680 --> 00:07:19.800
regardless of what the rest of their IP
was, I could talk to somebody who's 10.0.

142
00:07:19.800 --> 00:07:24.645
But if I wanted to talk to somebody that
was 10.1 or 172.16 or any other number,

143
00:07:24.645 --> 00:07:26.656
I would have to go through a gateway.

144
00:07:26.656 --> 00:07:28.670
And if I don't have one,
I won't be able to do it.

145
00:07:29.860 --> 00:07:32.770
So missing a default gateway will cause

146
00:07:32.770 --> 00:07:35.150
you to not have a route
to get to the host.

147
00:07:35.150 --> 00:07:38.990
And there's several of the common problems
that CompTIA calls out that are really

148
00:07:38.990 --> 00:07:41.960
the resulting error messages of a ping.

149
00:07:41.960 --> 00:07:42.860
And when you run a ping,

150
00:07:42.860 --> 00:07:45.620
you're testing the network to see if
you can get between two locations.

151
00:07:45.620 --> 00:07:49.838
And the answer you get back is going
to guide you kind of into what that

152
00:07:49.838 --> 00:07:50.662
problem is.

153
00:07:50.662 --> 00:07:54.461
And in this scenario,
where we have no default gateway,

154
00:07:54.461 --> 00:07:59.935
if I don't have a way to get there, Well
that's gonna be no route to destination.

155
00:07:59.935 --> 00:08:02.139
I've got no route,
no way to get there, right?

156
00:08:02.139 --> 00:08:03.520
I have to have a way.

157
00:08:03.520 --> 00:08:07.200
Now I'm gonna leave that gateway
off on purpose so that we can kinda

158
00:08:07.200 --> 00:08:10.260
trouble shoot what that would look like
on a system that can't communicate.

159
00:08:10.260 --> 00:08:14.020
Now I'm remoted into this
server from my laptop.

160
00:08:14.020 --> 00:08:18.180
And when I change that subnet mask,
I'm gonna get disconnected, right?

161
00:08:18.180 --> 00:08:19.850
See there I got disconnected.

162
00:08:19.850 --> 00:08:21.170
Why did that happen?

163
00:08:21.170 --> 00:08:25.180
When you change the IP address,
it resets the network adapter.

164
00:08:25.180 --> 00:08:28.530
And when that adapter resets, remote
connections like mine get disconnected.

165
00:08:28.530 --> 00:08:30.310
Now I'll reconnect in a little bit.

166
00:08:30.310 --> 00:08:32.630
Even though it doesn't have a default
gateway, if I just wait here a second.

167
00:08:32.630 --> 00:08:33.520
And there we go, all right.

168
00:08:33.520 --> 00:08:35.480
So now I'm reconnected, I'm back in.

169
00:08:35.480 --> 00:08:38.370
And here I am on the system that doesn't
have a default gateway, all right?

170
00:08:38.370 --> 00:08:40.050
So how's that going to affect me?

171
00:08:40.050 --> 00:08:43.430
It's gonna affect me when I'm
reaching out to other hosts.

172
00:08:43.430 --> 00:08:49.460
Now when we have a server and somebody
calls in and says, hey, I can't I can't

173
00:08:49.460 --> 00:08:53.770
get to the Internet or I can't do updates
or whatever, we need to troubleshoot that.

174
00:08:53.770 --> 00:08:56.610
And there's a handful of
tools that all help with

175
00:08:56.610 --> 00:08:59.300
troubleshooting to find
out why that's a problem.

176
00:08:59.300 --> 00:09:03.509
And one of the most useful tools that
we're gonna have is a utility called

177
00:09:03.509 --> 00:09:04.415
ping, right?

178
00:09:04.415 --> 00:09:08.372
What ping does is it sends out echo
requests, it sends out a message.

179
00:09:08.372 --> 00:09:11.030
Like I could say, hey,
Wes, do you hear me?

180
00:09:11.030 --> 00:09:13.770
And then, Wes could respond and
say, yes, I hear you, right?

181
00:09:13.770 --> 00:09:16.965
I send an echo request,
he sends an echo reply.

182
00:09:16.965 --> 00:09:20.429
And the reason they call it an echo is
I'm gonna send a string of text and

183
00:09:20.429 --> 00:09:23.631
I'm expecting the other end to
send that same string back to me.

184
00:09:23.631 --> 00:09:26.630
So that we can use that information
to gauge all sorts of things.

185
00:09:26.630 --> 00:09:29.520
How long did it take the message
to get there and back again?

186
00:09:29.520 --> 00:09:31.200
Did the message get there
in the first place?

187
00:09:31.200 --> 00:09:34.810
And we find out all sorts of
good stuff right here in our

188
00:09:34.810 --> 00:09:36.840
trusty old command prompt.

189
00:09:36.840 --> 00:09:40.880
Now our default command prompt on
this server is near microscopic.

190
00:09:40.880 --> 00:09:43.040
So I'm gonna bump this thing
up to a little bit bigger so

191
00:09:43.040 --> 00:09:44.300
we'll be able to see it.

192
00:09:44.300 --> 00:09:48.479
And then from here, I'm gonna use
the Ping utility to troubleshoot this.

193
00:09:48.479 --> 00:09:52.771
If I had a device where we
couldn't get out to the network,

194
00:09:52.771 --> 00:09:58.036
maybe I'm on this computer,
I need to download some drivers from HPE.

195
00:09:58.036 --> 00:10:02.420
So I'm trying to go to www.hpe.com,
and I'm not getting there.

196
00:10:02.420 --> 00:10:06.796
Well, I could drop to a command prompt,
and I can try and

197
00:10:06.796 --> 00:10:10.068
ping www.hpe.com, and see what I get.

198
00:10:10.068 --> 00:10:14.793
Well, I get ping request could
not find host www.hpe.com.

199
00:10:14.793 --> 00:10:16.585
Please check the name and try again.

200
00:10:16.585 --> 00:10:19.167
Couldn't find the host.

201
00:10:19.167 --> 00:10:20.628
Well, what does that mean?

202
00:10:20.628 --> 00:10:25.040
Well, that means It couldn't do a DNS
lookup, it couldn't do a name lookup.

203
00:10:25.040 --> 00:10:28.252
It couldn't resolve that name to an IP.

204
00:10:28.252 --> 00:10:31.601
When we reach out to a host by name,
the computer doesn't need a name.

205
00:10:31.601 --> 00:10:35.290
The computer needs an IP and
it wasn't able to figure that out.

206
00:10:35.290 --> 00:10:39.030
So I might immediately think, oo,
I've got a DNS problem, right?

207
00:10:39.030 --> 00:10:43.270
Now I know because I removed the default
gateway that the problem is that I can't

208
00:10:43.270 --> 00:10:46.440
get out to the Internet.

209
00:10:46.440 --> 00:10:50.420
Well, if I'm using Internet based DNS
servers, I can't get to them either.

210
00:10:50.420 --> 00:10:53.192
So yes, I have a DNS problem,
but that's a symptom.

211
00:10:53.192 --> 00:10:54.536
Not a cause.

212
00:10:54.536 --> 00:10:55.763
DNS servers are fine.

213
00:10:55.763 --> 00:10:58.045
If I go on and
verify my network configuration and so on.

214
00:10:58.045 --> 00:11:01.962
So, what we really need to do here
is take a standardized approach to

215
00:11:01.962 --> 00:11:03.810
troubleshooting this.

216
00:11:03.810 --> 00:11:05.790
And what I was told people I like to do,

217
00:11:05.790 --> 00:11:09.610
is I like to do is called
pinging from the inside out.

218
00:11:09.610 --> 00:11:14.179
I need to understand the path that I
follow to figure out where the failure is.

219
00:11:14.179 --> 00:11:17.571
The failure could be right
here on my own machine.

220
00:11:17.571 --> 00:11:22.228
Or the failure could be on any one
of the number routers that sit in

221
00:11:22.228 --> 00:11:23.704
between me and hpe.

222
00:11:23.704 --> 00:11:26.232
Or the failure could be at hpe.

223
00:11:26.232 --> 00:11:27.641
Or the failure could be on the DNS server.

224
00:11:27.641 --> 00:11:29.048
It could be in any of these places.

225
00:11:29.048 --> 00:11:31.010
So where do we start looking?

226
00:11:31.010 --> 00:11:33.210
Well, in the olden days,

227
00:11:33.210 --> 00:11:37.310
I used to always just immediately
go to the traceroute utility.

228
00:11:37.310 --> 00:11:41.630
The traceroute utility lets you see
the path from you to a destination.

229
00:11:41.630 --> 00:11:44.274
And you see every hop in between,
and wherever it stops,

230
00:11:44.274 --> 00:11:45.770
that's where your problem is.

231
00:11:45.770 --> 00:11:47.114
Easy enough.

232
00:11:47.114 --> 00:11:50.720
But more and more, we're seeing people
block traceroute with their firewalls.

233
00:11:50.720 --> 00:11:52.710
So traceroute doesn't always work.

234
00:11:52.710 --> 00:11:55.123
And in my scenario,
where I can't even find the host,

235
00:11:55.123 --> 00:11:57.890
I'm not sure that it's
gonna get very far at all.

236
00:11:57.890 --> 00:12:02.097
If I do a traceroute which on a Linux
system I would type traceroute just

237
00:12:02.097 --> 00:12:02.822
like this.

238
00:12:02.822 --> 00:12:05.915
On a Windows system, it's tracert.

239
00:12:05.915 --> 00:12:09.350
Same command, just Microsoft chose to
abbreviate it for whatever reason.

240
00:12:09.350 --> 00:12:14.491
So I'll do a traceroute to www.hpe.com.

241
00:12:14.491 --> 00:12:18.203
I wanna see all the stuff
in between me and HP.

242
00:12:18.203 --> 00:12:19.640
Well, what do I get?

243
00:12:19.640 --> 00:12:21.650
Unable to resolve the target system.

244
00:12:21.650 --> 00:12:23.450
I can't get it.

245
00:12:23.450 --> 00:12:25.120
Well, it's unable to resolve,

246
00:12:25.120 --> 00:12:27.520
at least this one's giving me a better
hint than what I saw up here.

247
00:12:27.520 --> 00:12:29.590
It can't figure out the IP address.

248
00:12:29.590 --> 00:12:33.897
Well, nslookup is a utility we can use
to figure out whether we're able to look

249
00:12:33.897 --> 00:12:34.429
that up.

250
00:12:34.429 --> 00:12:38.202
If I do www.nslcup www.hpe.com,

251
00:12:38.202 --> 00:12:42.227
I can run that and see if I get an answer.

252
00:12:42.227 --> 00:12:47.202
All right, now the nice thing
about NS lookup is that it will

253
00:12:47.202 --> 00:12:50.397
allow me to overwrite the DNL server.

254
00:12:50.397 --> 00:12:54.237
So if I think my DNS server is
the problem, I can try a different one.

255
00:12:54.237 --> 00:12:59.223
Hey, I tried 8.8.8.8,
which is one of Google's DNS servers,

256
00:12:59.223 --> 00:13:01.309
and it didn't work, right?

257
00:13:01.309 --> 00:13:05.928
I could try it again and
add 4.2.2.1 at the end.

258
00:13:05.928 --> 00:13:08.136
That's one of Level 3's DNS servers.

259
00:13:08.136 --> 00:13:11.071
I like to choose big companies cuz I
know their DNS servers are gonna be

260
00:13:11.071 --> 00:13:11.840
online, right?

261
00:13:11.840 --> 00:13:13.270
So I'm gonna pick Level 3.

262
00:13:13.270 --> 00:13:15.610
And I'll run against that one, same thing.

263
00:13:15.610 --> 00:13:21.487
Now what are the odds of Google and Level
3 both having a DNS outage right now?

264
00:13:21.487 --> 00:13:23.247
It's pretty unlikely.

265
00:13:23.247 --> 00:13:26.943
So the fact that I can't get to two of
them is making me think that I've probably

266
00:13:26.943 --> 00:13:29.082
got some kind of Internet
connection issue.

267
00:13:29.082 --> 00:13:31.870
Or some issue that's more
than likely my problem.

268
00:13:31.870 --> 00:13:34.220
Cuz I doubt there's gonna
be an outtage this big.

269
00:13:34.220 --> 00:13:37.910
It could be that I only have one ISP and
the ISP is down right now.

270
00:13:37.910 --> 00:13:39.600
That could be it.

00:22:21.916 --> 00:22:23.571

00:22:23.571 --> 00:22:26.360

00:22:26.360 --> 00:22:27.740

00:22:43.760 --> 00:22:46.330

00:22:46.330 --> 00:22:47.340
General Failure.

00:22:47.340 --> 00:22:49.991
The general failure,

00:22:50.769 --> 00:22:52.630

00:22:52.630 --> 00:22:57.060

00:22:57.060 --> 00:22:58.510

00:22:58.510 --> 00:23:01.640

I remove my default gateway so

that they hire the most talented
network engineers in the world,

724
00:35:43.978 --> 00:35:46.794
like that's where the big
network engineers go, so

725
00:35:46.794 --> 00:35:51.420
they've got the best employees and they're
monitoring it better than anyone else.

726
00:35:51.420 --> 00:35:54.499
So, by the time you see the problem,
they're already well aware of it and

727
00:35:54.499 --> 00:35:57.094
working on a solution, so
you don't do anything, you wait.

728
00:35:57.094 --> 00:36:00.541
If the problem is the destination,
you might report it to them, but

729
00:36:00.541 --> 00:36:04.550
it's hard to report it to the destination
if their network is down.

730
00:36:04.550 --> 00:36:09.662
If I can't get to Adobe's website,
and it turns out to be on their end,

731
00:36:09.662 --> 00:36:12.828
do you have a phone number for
Adobe to call?

732
00:36:12.828 --> 00:36:15.632
They've got a sales number,
you can call and talk to a sales guy and

733
00:36:15.632 --> 00:36:18.486
buy stuff, but they don't have
a tech support number you can call,

734
00:36:18.486 --> 00:36:20.710
they're proud of that for some reason.

735
00:36:20.710 --> 00:36:23.333
So, there's nobody you can kind of
reach out to and you just have to wait.

736
00:36:23.333 --> 00:36:26.882
But if it's your ISP, there is an action
item you can follow, you can call them up.

737
00:36:26.882 --> 00:36:29.077
>> All right, Don,
lot of great information.

738
00:36:29.077 --> 00:36:32.481
Now I know we got more to go, but it does
look like we're running to the end of

739
00:36:32.481 --> 00:36:34.960
this episode judging by that time clock.

740
00:36:34.960 --> 00:36:38.784
However, but before we do wrap this one
up, do you have any additional words?

741
00:36:38.784 --> 00:36:40.318
>> All right,
remember to do your research.

742
00:36:40.318 --> 00:36:42.619
Run trace route,
gather this information together,

743
00:36:42.619 --> 00:36:45.869
because when you fill out your trouble
ticket, this is going to be supporting

744
00:36:45.869 --> 00:36:48.420
information that goes in to
indicate where the failure was,

745
00:36:48.420 --> 00:36:52.140
how we're going to fix it, how we're going
to route around the problem, or whatever.

746
00:36:52.140 --> 00:36:54.912
You want to make sure you document that,
so you have an understanding of it, so

747
00:36:54.912 --> 00:36:57.643
that you can also come up with a way to
prevent it from happening in the future.

748
00:36:57.643 --> 00:37:01.222
>> All right, Don, as always, we
appreciate having you here in the studios

749
00:37:01.222 --> 00:37:03.950
with us and we appreciate,
you, the viewer watching.

750
00:37:03.950 --> 00:37:05.593
We hope you've enjoyed this episode,

751
00:37:05.593 --> 00:37:08.141
signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

752
00:37:08.141 --> 00:37:09.008
>> And, I'm Don Pezet.

753
00:37:09.008 --> 00:37:09.916
>> And we'll see you next time.

754
00:37:09.916 --> 00:37:17.660
[MUSIC]

755
00:37:17.660 --> 00:37:19.910
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes continue their exploration as they continue to tackle troubleshooting issues that arise on modern networks. They talk about various topics including routing issues, VLAN issues, port security, firewall issues and more.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Networking Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.906
Welcome to IT Pro TV,
I'm your host Don Pizzet.

2
00:00:01.906 --> 00:00:04.812
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.812 --> 00:00:08.163
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.163 --> 00:00:12.054
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:12.054 --> 00:00:15.130
>> Hello and welcome to another
great episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.130 --> 00:00:19.504
I am your host Wes Bryan and in today's
episode we are continuing through

7
00:00:19.504 --> 00:00:22.957
our series in CompTIA's Server+,
the SK0-004.

8
00:00:22.957 --> 00:00:24.847
We're actually coming
back with a part two and

9
00:00:24.847 --> 00:00:27.240
joining us in the studio is
none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:27.240 --> 00:00:28.410
Don, how you doing, sir?

11
00:00:28.410 --> 00:00:30.271
>> I'm doing swell, Wes.

12
00:00:30.271 --> 00:00:32.950
Ready to continue on with the networking
adventures we talk about troubleshooting.

13
00:00:32.950 --> 00:00:34.900
We talked about some of
the basics in the last episode.

14
00:00:34.900 --> 00:00:36.880
How we can use ping and trace route and

15
00:00:36.880 --> 00:00:41.070
a few other other utilities to
figure out where an error is.

16
00:00:41.070 --> 00:00:43.389
In this episode, I wanna continue with
that and cover a few more commands and

17
00:00:43.389 --> 00:00:45.106
take some of the commands
we've already talked about.

18
00:00:45.106 --> 00:00:49.100
And go a little bit further with them,
as far as isolating issues and

19
00:00:49.100 --> 00:00:51.020
trouble on the network.

20
00:00:51.020 --> 00:00:53.320
All right, so let's kick things off.

21
00:00:53.320 --> 00:00:56.220
I talked about the majority of the common
problems in the last episode but

22
00:00:56.220 --> 00:00:58.960
there was one that I left off,
which was email failure.

23
00:00:58.960 --> 00:01:03.420
Email failure is specifically called
out on the exam and with email, well,

24
00:01:03.420 --> 00:01:05.040
people really like their email.

25
00:01:05.040 --> 00:01:08.420
And if they can't use it,
they get really annoyed.

26
00:01:08.420 --> 00:01:09.940
That and browsing the Internet, right?

27
00:01:09.940 --> 00:01:13.730
So troubleshooting those are gonna
be common tickets that you get.

28
00:01:13.730 --> 00:01:16.620
Email, though,
is considered critical to many businesses.

29
00:01:16.620 --> 00:01:19.520
Browsing the Internet isn't considered
[LAUGH] critical to many businesses,

30
00:01:19.520 --> 00:01:21.380
but email is.

31
00:01:21.380 --> 00:01:24.220
And so, when you have somebody call in
to report an email type issue, hey,

32
00:01:24.220 --> 00:01:28.670
I can't get to the mail server, well, that
could be a mail server problem, right?

33
00:01:28.670 --> 00:01:31.890
The server could be down,
the mailbox database could be offline.

34
00:01:31.890 --> 00:01:32.740
People can't connect.

35
00:01:32.740 --> 00:01:34.080
That happens.

36
00:01:34.080 --> 00:01:36.030
But assuming that you've
kept the database happy and

37
00:01:36.030 --> 00:01:40.000
healthy, there's certain networking
issues that can cause a problem too.

38
00:01:40.000 --> 00:01:45.020
And it usually centers around filtering,
especially on the Internet.

39
00:01:45.020 --> 00:01:47.090
Email, it gets abused a lot.

40
00:01:47.090 --> 00:01:49.490
I get,
how many spam messages do you get a day?

41
00:01:49.490 --> 00:01:52.170
I get the same,
I get a ton every single day.

42
00:01:52.170 --> 00:01:55.130
And fortunately, I have spam filters and
things like that that filter it out.

43
00:01:55.130 --> 00:01:59.465
But as a result, we can't just have
open email relays on the Internet,

44
00:01:59.465 --> 00:02:01.501
like they used to back in the day.

45
00:02:01.501 --> 00:02:03.970
Now, everything has to be locked down.

46
00:02:03.970 --> 00:02:06.990
And so, it's possible that you're
trying to connect to a mail server and

47
00:02:06.990 --> 00:02:09.160
you can't because it's being blocked.

48
00:02:09.160 --> 00:02:12.890
So for example at home,
I have a cable broadband modem.

49
00:02:12.890 --> 00:02:15.730
And just a regular home
carrier service class stuff.

50
00:02:15.730 --> 00:02:20.060
And I get Internet connectivity and
it works fine.

51
00:02:20.060 --> 00:02:25.915
But, from my house, if I try and
connect to a SMTP server on Port 25,

52
00:02:25.915 --> 00:02:30.281
if I try to reach out on TCP
port 25 to a SMTP server,

53
00:02:30.281 --> 00:02:35.082
no matter what host I specify,
Cox Cable intercepts me.

54
00:02:35.082 --> 00:02:38.340
And I get connected to
the Cox Cable SMTP server.

55
00:02:38.340 --> 00:02:41.650
Doesn't matter if I'm pointing to Gmail or
Microsoft or anybody.

56
00:02:41.650 --> 00:02:44.547
I get connected to Cox's SMTP server.

57
00:02:44.547 --> 00:02:48.088
And the reason they're doing that is they
wanna filter spam before it leaves their

58
00:02:48.088 --> 00:02:50.880
network so that they don't get
flagged as a spam relay, right?

59
00:02:50.880 --> 00:02:52.420
They're trying to take that extra step.

60
00:02:52.420 --> 00:02:54.060
That causes problems.

61
00:02:54.060 --> 00:02:56.150
For example, the ITPro.TV domain.

62
00:02:56.150 --> 00:03:02.510
When I send email, it's don@itpro.tv and
we use SPF records and

63
00:03:02.510 --> 00:03:07.040
DCIM digital signing to make sure that
people know our emails are legitimate.

64
00:03:07.040 --> 00:03:09.960
That it is actually from me and
not somebody impersonating me.

65
00:03:09.960 --> 00:03:13.520
Well, if my email, my outgoing emails
are intercepted by Cox Cable and

66
00:03:13.520 --> 00:03:17.470
sent through their SMTP servers,
what happens?

67
00:03:17.470 --> 00:03:18.680
It looks like spam.

68
00:03:18.680 --> 00:03:21.260
It looks like it's coming
from somebody who isn't me.

69
00:03:21.260 --> 00:03:22.460
And that's a problem.

70
00:03:22.460 --> 00:03:25.010
So not a problem on our servers, but

71
00:03:25.010 --> 00:03:27.980
a problem with the network in
between our clients and our servers.

72
00:03:27.980 --> 00:03:31.430
And that's why it's so important to move
people over to encrypted connections.

73
00:03:31.430 --> 00:03:38.170
So if you're doing SMTPS, right, if you're
doing SMTP using SSL over port 587.

74
00:03:38.170 --> 00:03:40.090
Now it's encrypted and

75
00:03:40.090 --> 00:03:44.170
it can't be intercepted by
whoever your ISP is, or whatever.

76
00:03:44.170 --> 00:03:47.410
And it'll have to go to the actual
server to be able to relay out.

77
00:03:47.410 --> 00:03:49.228
Or you may have to leverage VPN tunnels.

78
00:03:49.228 --> 00:03:52.096
I've been in hotel networks where just
no matter what you did you couldn't

79
00:03:52.096 --> 00:03:52.606
send email.

80
00:03:52.606 --> 00:03:57.440
So I had to VPN back into my office
to be able to email and communicate.

81
00:03:57.440 --> 00:03:59.490
Those things all happen, right?

82
00:03:59.490 --> 00:04:02.630
And those are all stuff that can
cause email not to function.

83
00:04:02.630 --> 00:04:06.330
After that, it's just a matter of
keeping your email server up and online.

84
00:04:06.330 --> 00:04:08.525
Now if you ever need
to troubleshoot email,

85
00:04:08.525 --> 00:04:10.310
there's actually a neat
way that you can do it.

86
00:04:10.310 --> 00:04:12.199
If you know your email server,

87
00:04:13.480 --> 00:04:17.430
you can just use the telnet
command to troubleshoot it.

88
00:04:17.430 --> 00:04:20.879
So, for example,
if I'm trying to send an email to Wes, and

89
00:04:20.879 --> 00:04:22.918
Wes says, yeah, just email me.

90
00:04:22.918 --> 00:04:24.467
It's wes@aol.com.

91
00:04:24.467 --> 00:04:25.831
Because Wes is old school.

92
00:04:25.831 --> 00:04:28.279
Well, I wanna send him an email.

93
00:04:28.279 --> 00:04:33.440
So I can come in here and I can take
nslookup and I can set my type to MX,

94
00:04:33.440 --> 00:04:37.801
so I'm gonna look for MX records,
and I can do aol.com.

95
00:04:37.801 --> 00:04:40.715
And I can find out the mail servers for
AOL.

96
00:04:40.715 --> 00:04:46.620
So here's a mail server for AOL,
mailin-03.mx.aol.com, okay?

97
00:04:46.620 --> 00:04:51.280
And then I can take that and I can Telnet

98
00:04:52.480 --> 00:04:57.290
into that host and specify a port number.

99
00:04:57.290 --> 00:05:00.170
I'm gonna tell it to Telnet on port 25.

100
00:05:00.170 --> 00:05:02.610
And, shoot,
actually you don't need a -p on this one.

101
00:05:02.610 --> 00:05:06.440
There, and what should happen is,
you should connect.

102
00:05:06.440 --> 00:05:09.730
If you connect, and you get a header,
see I got a header here.

103
00:05:09.730 --> 00:05:14.684
421 mtaig-ma blah blah blah,
service unavailable, try again later.

104
00:05:14.684 --> 00:05:16.172
That's an odd little message to get,
right?

105
00:05:16.172 --> 00:05:18.030
It's telling me service not available.

106
00:05:18.030 --> 00:05:21.560
It's because I didn't follow that up
with the email commands that I wanted.

107
00:05:21.560 --> 00:05:23.610
Instead, I did a get a header though.

108
00:05:23.610 --> 00:05:25.920
Their mail server talked to me.

109
00:05:25.920 --> 00:05:27.730
It told me that it was there.

110
00:05:27.730 --> 00:05:29.919
So I know I can communicate on port 25.

111
00:05:29.919 --> 00:05:31.900
It's a neat way to test.

112
00:05:31.900 --> 00:05:33.750
You can actually use Telnet
to test a lot of things.

113
00:05:33.750 --> 00:05:37.560
You can connect to servers on port 80
just to test whether the base HTTP

114
00:05:37.560 --> 00:05:38.900
is functioning or other things.

115
00:05:38.900 --> 00:05:41.890
You can connect on port 22 for SSH.

116
00:05:41.890 --> 00:05:44.260
And you should see a certificate
message pop up and

117
00:05:44.260 --> 00:05:46.420
then you stop communicating
cuz you're not encrypted.

118
00:05:46.420 --> 00:05:49.755
So, those are simply ways that we
can test basic connectivity by using

119
00:05:49.755 --> 00:05:51.633
port numbers with the Telnet command.

120
00:05:51.633 --> 00:05:53.709
Telnet doesn't just have to be used for
Telnet.

121
00:05:53.709 --> 00:05:57.595
In fact, I probably use it more for
troubleshooting than I do for Telnet.

122
00:05:57.595 --> 00:06:00.175
I don't establish Telnet sessions anymore.

123
00:06:00.175 --> 00:06:02.179
But I use it plenty of times for
testing other protocols.

124
00:06:04.298 --> 00:06:06.545
All right, some of the other
things we need to think about.

125
00:06:06.545 --> 00:06:14.760
I mentioned the I mentioned VLANs in the
last episode, Virtual Local Area Networks.

126
00:06:14.760 --> 00:06:18.810
And I wanted to show you guys an example
of how that kind of thing works.

127
00:06:18.810 --> 00:06:22.490
That when you connect
into a enterprise switch,

128
00:06:22.490 --> 00:06:25.160
a switch that has a tons of ports in it.

129
00:06:25.160 --> 00:06:30.700
Well, those ports are not
necessarily all connected together.

130
00:06:30.700 --> 00:06:36.010
Those ports could be subdivided and broken
up into a number of different networks.

131
00:06:36.010 --> 00:06:38.730
So this switch that I'm pulling
up right now is actually

132
00:06:38.730 --> 00:06:41.130
the big switch that's in
the background behind Wes.

133
00:06:41.130 --> 00:06:43.690
It's got a ton of ports in it, right?

134
00:06:43.690 --> 00:06:47.413
So here's all these different ports that
we've got, for all these different cards,

135
00:06:47.413 --> 00:06:48.695
and some of them are gigabit.

136
00:06:48.695 --> 00:06:53.175
Most of these are gigabit poe ports, and
then we've got some down here that are 10

137
00:06:53.175 --> 00:06:56.750
gigabit ports and
some extra fiber ports there.

138
00:06:56.750 --> 00:07:01.039
But not every port is
being treated the same.

139
00:07:01.039 --> 00:07:06.410
When you look at some of these ports,
they can be on different VLANs.

140
00:07:06.410 --> 00:07:09.472
So for example,
there might be an interface here that my

141
00:07:09.472 --> 00:07:12.349
laptop is plugged into, and
it might be on VLAN one.

142
00:07:12.349 --> 00:07:17.287
And then there might be another
interface here somewhere that is

143
00:07:17.287 --> 00:07:19.430
on a different VLAN.

144
00:07:19.430 --> 00:07:22.220
Because it's connected to
a Internet network, right?

145
00:07:22.220 --> 00:07:23.910
Maybe it's one of our WAN interfaces.

146
00:07:23.910 --> 00:07:25.510
And so it's isolated out.

147
00:07:25.510 --> 00:07:30.030
And I can't just tell by looking
at the front of the switch, right?

148
00:07:30.030 --> 00:07:33.390
I actually have to go into
that VLAN communication or

149
00:07:33.390 --> 00:07:35.780
configuration to find out what's going on.

150
00:07:35.780 --> 00:07:37.970
And so
if I go into the VLAN management side,

151
00:07:37.970 --> 00:07:41.340
I can see where we've got all
sorts of different VLANs created.

152
00:07:41.340 --> 00:07:44.006
All for different things like vlan 110 for
lab machines.

153
00:07:44.006 --> 00:07:47.523
We have our lab machines separated
out because one of our other hosts,

154
00:07:47.523 --> 00:07:50.453
Mike Rodrick,
is always doing this hacky exploit stuff.

155
00:07:50.453 --> 00:07:52.838
And so you can't have that on your
regular network, so we separate that out.

156
00:07:52.838 --> 00:07:54.764
So you have each of these.

157
00:07:54.764 --> 00:07:57.140
Here's some of the WAN interfaces
that pass through our switches.

158
00:07:57.140 --> 00:08:01.271
And when we look at those and we you
come down you'll see it's port based and

159
00:08:01.271 --> 00:08:02.591
I can pull up the ports.

160
00:08:02.591 --> 00:08:06.669
It's only ports A1, A2 and B1.

161
00:08:06.669 --> 00:08:11.824
So when I go back out
to my main switch view,

162
00:08:11.824 --> 00:08:17.422
A1, A2 and B1, that's A1, A2 and B1.

163
00:08:17.422 --> 00:08:21.130
Those three ports,
they're on a separate VLAN.

164
00:08:21.130 --> 00:08:25.362
And nobody else is gonna be able to talk
to them unless they're on that same VLAN.

165
00:08:25.362 --> 00:08:28.184
So just understand that if you plug in
a network cable for your server and

166
00:08:28.184 --> 00:08:31.163
you get a link light, it doesn't
guarantee you're on the right network.

167
00:08:31.163 --> 00:08:33.800
That that switch may be
subdivided out like that.

168
00:08:33.800 --> 00:08:37.950
And the network team can jump in there and
correct it and assign VLANs as needed.

169
00:08:37.950 --> 00:08:41.280
Where it gets really tricky,
though, are trunks.

170
00:08:41.280 --> 00:08:46.720
A trunk is where you have one link
that's carrying more than one VLAN.

171
00:08:46.720 --> 00:08:49.756
For example,
I believe this port is a trunk for us.

172
00:08:49.756 --> 00:08:50.348
Which is gonna be what?

173
00:08:50.348 --> 00:08:52.148
A21.

174
00:08:52.148 --> 00:08:56.184
So if I come in and
pull up that interface, and

175
00:08:56.184 --> 00:09:00.940
take a look at A21,
let me just find it real quick.

176
00:09:00.940 --> 00:09:03.270
If I pull up A21 and come down and

177
00:09:03.270 --> 00:09:07.630
look at what VLAN its on, or actually I
pulled up its physical status, haven't I?

178
00:09:07.630 --> 00:09:08.568
Yeah, that's not gonna help me.

179
00:09:08.568 --> 00:09:13.617
So if I pull up its VLANs though,
it'll actually be on more than one VLAN.

180
00:09:13.617 --> 00:09:16.945
And the reason it's on more than
one VLAN is because it's a trunk,

181
00:09:16.945 --> 00:09:19.270
it's carrying several different networks.

182
00:09:19.270 --> 00:09:24.891
So when I take a look at the networks that
I have available like IT Pro TV Guest and

183
00:09:24.891 --> 00:09:28.979
look at its ports,
I'll find where it's tied to A21,

184
00:09:28.979 --> 00:09:31.727
right there, written really small.

185
00:09:31.727 --> 00:09:35.732
But then if I go and look at another VLAN,
like instead of ITProTV guest,

186
00:09:35.732 --> 00:09:37.253
we'll do DEFAULT_VLAN.

187
00:09:37.253 --> 00:09:41.443
And I can go in and find where
A21 is on the default VLAN also.

188
00:09:41.443 --> 00:09:43.461
It's carrying more than one VLAN.

189
00:09:43.461 --> 00:09:45.504
Now normally you would
never do that to a server.

190
00:09:45.504 --> 00:09:47.796
You'd do that between switches.

191

I can override names to IPs.

00:21:08.390 --> 00:21:12.685
So for example,
this is the IP that points to ITPRO.TV.

417
00:21:12.685 --> 00:21:18.440
Well, I could override that and
I'll say 1.1.1.1

418
00:21:18.440 --> 00:21:22.790
points to ITPro.tv which is not accurate.

419
00:21:22.790 --> 00:21:24.960
But maybe for testing purposes,
I need to point somewhere else.

420
00:21:24.960 --> 00:21:28.045
I might have a production,
and a test server.

421
00:21:28.045 --> 00:21:30.535
And so normally I am going to
production but I need to override and

422
00:21:30.535 --> 00:21:34.045
point to test for a minute while I try
something out, and then I can put it back.

423
00:21:34.045 --> 00:21:37.605
That's an easy way to make the names
work on an alternate server.

424
00:21:37.605 --> 00:21:42.062
So I am gonna set that and
exit out of that file.

425
00:21:42.062 --> 00:21:44.102
Now here's where it gets tricky.

426
00:21:44.102 --> 00:21:48.122
Some utilities recognize the host file and
some don't.

427
00:21:48.122 --> 00:21:55.132
If I try and ping itpro.tv right now,
it's trying to ping 1.1.1.1, right?

428
00:21:55.132 --> 00:21:57.242
It's been overwritten,
that's the wrong IP.

429
00:21:58.482 --> 00:22:03.760
But if I do an nslookup of
itpro.tv what do I get?

430
00:22:03.760 --> 00:22:06.888
I get the right IP,
now that's really weird, why is that?

431
00:22:06.888 --> 00:22:11.890
Well nslookup bypasses the host file.

432
00:22:11.890 --> 00:22:14.780
It doesn't use any local cached values or

433
00:22:14.780 --> 00:22:17.970
any host files, it just goes
straight out to the DNS server.

434
00:22:17.970 --> 00:22:21.450
It's a name server lookup utility,
you're looking up against the name server.

435
00:22:21.450 --> 00:22:26.196
Well ping on the other hand,
uses the whole lookup process.

436
00:22:26.196 --> 00:22:30.550
It uses where it looks to the host file
first, actually looks to the cache first,

437
00:22:30.550 --> 00:22:33.910
then looks to the host file and
then it looks up against the DNS server.

438
00:22:33.910 --> 00:22:37.750
So it's going through each one and
I might have bad values somewhere.

439
00:22:37.750 --> 00:22:39.710
If I have bad values in the cache,
that's not a big deal.

440
00:22:39.710 --> 00:22:45.740
We can do ipconfig /flushdns and
that will wipe out that cache, right?

441
00:22:45.740 --> 00:22:50.146
So I don't have that anymore but the host
file I'm gonna have to go and edit that.

442
00:22:50.146 --> 00:22:51.800
I have to go edit and undo it.

443
00:22:51.800 --> 00:22:53.880
Remove it.
You'll see a lot of rootkits and

444
00:22:53.880 --> 00:22:57.440
malware that will override
things in the host file.

445
00:22:57.440 --> 00:23:01.440
So like when you try and go to google,
instead you go to some malware site.

446
00:23:01.440 --> 00:23:02.970
So it's an attack vector.

447
00:23:02.970 --> 00:23:05.560
And that's why a lot of vendors have
been trying to get rid of that file, but

448
00:23:05.560 --> 00:23:08.550
it still serves a pretty
important purpose, so it's there.

449
00:23:08.550 --> 00:23:11.180
And you have it in Linux, too,
it's not just a Windows thing.

450
00:23:11.180 --> 00:23:16.880
If I go into the /etc/ folder, I will find
the hosts file dumped in here somewhere.

451
00:23:17.910 --> 00:23:19.760
Right here, hosts.

452
00:23:19.760 --> 00:23:22.770
And it's basically formatted the same way.

453
00:23:22.770 --> 00:23:25.310
It's got an IP on the left,
followed by a name or

454
00:23:25.310 --> 00:23:27.000
names on the right, and that's that.

455
00:23:27.000 --> 00:23:27.930
So you can overwrite it.

456
00:23:27.930 --> 00:23:29.670
Same thing, same basic principle there.

457
00:23:31.615 --> 00:23:35.235
Okay, let's see, I think we are nearing
the end of our little journey here.

458
00:23:35.235 --> 00:23:38.075
Couple last little odds and
ends that we need to get to.

459
00:23:38.075 --> 00:23:40.685
In the last episode,
we talked about routes.

460
00:23:40.685 --> 00:23:43.190
And I used under Windows
the route print command.

461
00:23:43.190 --> 00:23:45.990
And under Linux or
Unix I use the netstack command.

462
00:23:47.030 --> 00:23:49.620
Netstack can do a heck of a lot
more than just show routes.

463
00:23:49.620 --> 00:23:50.400
So I wanna talk about that.

464
00:23:50.400 --> 00:23:52.810
But I also wanna mention
another thing about routes.

465
00:23:52.810 --> 00:23:58.001
Under Windows and in Unix, you can
enter in routes manually if you want.

466
00:23:58.001 --> 00:23:58.965
There's times when you need that.

467
00:23:58.965 --> 00:24:01.871
I might have a VPN tunnel available for
a partner network and

468
00:24:01.871 --> 00:24:03.974
I wanna send that traffic a different way.

469
00:24:03.974 --> 00:24:06.215
So for example,
I could drop here to the command prompt.

470
00:24:06.215 --> 00:24:12.941
And I can say, route add, and
I can add a route for a network.

471
00:24:12.941 --> 00:24:22.270
I can say, for example, I want
the 10.5.0.0 network and provide its mask.

472
00:24:22.270 --> 00:24:26.255
I want that network to be available
via a different default gateway.

473
00:24:26.255 --> 00:24:28.671
I'm going to point it to 10.0.0.2, right?

474
00:24:28.671 --> 00:24:30.340
And I can add that in.

475
00:24:30.340 --> 00:24:32.330
Now when I add it in this way,
it's not persistent.

476
00:24:32.330 --> 00:24:33.742
If I reboot it's going to go away.

477
00:24:33.742 --> 00:24:37.512
If I add a -p,
it'll become permanent, it'll stay.

478
00:24:37.512 --> 00:24:40.000
And then even if I reboot,
that route will be there.

479
00:24:40.000 --> 00:24:44.100
And when I override it like that,
if I do a route print and

480
00:24:44.100 --> 00:24:47.360
look at my routing table,
it'll show up in there.

481
00:24:47.360 --> 00:24:49.248
So as I look at my routing table,

482
00:24:49.248 --> 00:24:54.150
here's the 10.0 that I get because
I'm plugged into that network.

483
00:24:54.150 --> 00:25:01.605
And right below it here,
I've got 10.5.0.0 is pointing to 10.0.0.2.

484
00:25:01.605 --> 00:25:04.570
Now that's assuming
that it's a good route.

485
00:25:04.570 --> 00:25:06.536
The computer assumes that
we know what we're doing.

486
00:25:06.536 --> 00:25:08.114
It could be a bad route though.

487
00:25:08.114 --> 00:25:10.080
If I'm pointing to the wrong gateway.

488
00:25:10.080 --> 00:25:11.902
Maybe I needed that to go to 10.0.0.1.

489
00:25:11.902 --> 00:25:15.038
I Pointed at 10.0.0.2,
now I've got a problem.

490
00:25:15.038 --> 00:25:19.203
>> You know Don, we had a great question
come in off of our Facebook Live feed

491
00:25:19.203 --> 00:25:23.642
that said with these routes, Don,
if I power cycle the router, don't those

492
00:25:23.642 --> 00:25:27.830
routes get removed from the routing
table once the router comes back on?

493
00:25:27.830 --> 00:25:28.656
We had a question about that.

494
00:25:28.656 --> 00:25:31.570
>> Yeah, well again, it comes down
to how they're entered in, right?

495
00:25:31.570 --> 00:25:36.390
If it's a Cisco router or Juniper
router and you put a route in like this

496
00:25:36.390 --> 00:25:39.710
if you don't save the config if you
reboot you lose the route, right?

497
00:25:39.710 --> 00:25:43.400
On a desktop or a server like this,
it's gonna come down to that command.

498
00:25:43.400 --> 00:25:47.470
When I put it in, I didn't do a -p,
I didn't make it persistent.

499
00:25:47.470 --> 00:25:51.500
So if I were to rerun that
command throw a -p on it, so

500
00:25:51.500 --> 00:25:55.930
I think I need to do it here yeah there.

501
00:25:55.930 --> 00:25:57.320
I run it.
Now it's persistent.

502
00:25:57.320 --> 00:26:00.390
Now even if I reboot that route's
going to stay there okay?

503
00:26:00.390 --> 00:26:03.560
And so if I put a bad route in,
that's gonna cause a problem.

504
00:26:03.560 --> 00:26:07.510
So when we use the route print
command under Windows or under Linux,

505
00:26:07.510 --> 00:26:09.230
you use the netstat-r right?

506
00:26:09.230 --> 00:26:11.860
That's kind of what got
me on this whole topic.

507
00:26:11.860 --> 00:26:14.120
If I do netstat-r,
I can look at that routing table and

508
00:26:14.120 --> 00:26:17.530
if I see something weird in there,
I might need to go and override that and

509
00:26:17.530 --> 00:26:20.278
get it out, change that configuration and
fix things the way they are.

510
00:26:20.278 --> 00:26:25.670
All right, the netstat command was
the next thing I needed to talk about.

511
00:26:25.670 --> 00:26:26.610
And actually, looking at the clock,

512
00:26:26.610 --> 00:26:28.785
I'm kind of a little low
on time to talk about it.

513
00:26:28.785 --> 00:26:32.260
Netstat does a heck of a lot more
than just show a routing table.

514
00:26:32.260 --> 00:26:34.090
It's not even it's original purpose.

515
00:26:34.090 --> 00:26:35.570
So I want to talk about netstat some more.

516
00:26:35.570 --> 00:26:39.218
I've got nbtstat to talk about and netuse.

517
00:26:39.218 --> 00:26:41.130
A few other commands we need to deal with.

518
00:26:41.130 --> 00:26:43.990
And then physical property, we're
gonna talk about physical cabling too.

519
00:26:43.990 --> 00:26:47.540
So I think we've got a part three
in our future on this one Wes,

520
00:26:47.540 --> 00:26:48.320
is that gonna be all right?

521
00:26:48.320 --> 00:26:48.820
>> Hey, that sounds great.
>> [LAUGH]

522
00:26:48.820 --> 00:26:49.412
>> In fact,

523
00:26:49.412 --> 00:26:54.154
as long as you don't mention the new
cabling standard that I've invented,

524
00:26:54.154 --> 00:26:56.550
that 568W, that's for sure.

525
00:26:56.550 --> 00:26:57.990
Well, Don, you've already mentioned it.

526
00:26:57.990 --> 00:27:00.010
It does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

527
00:27:00.010 --> 00:27:03.220
But before we sign out, do you have
anything else you might like to throw

528
00:27:03.220 --> 00:27:05.460
into this episode for our viewers?

529
00:27:05.460 --> 00:27:07.740
Most of the scenarios I've laid out for
you is pretty uncommon.

530
00:27:07.740 --> 00:27:09.849
It's pretty uncommon to have a bad
route in your routing table.

531
00:27:09.849 --> 00:27:12.400
It can happen, but it's pretty uncommon.

532
00:27:12.400 --> 00:27:14.741
So usually it's gonna be
something far simpler.

533
00:27:14.741 --> 00:27:16.150
it's gonna be a loose network cable.

534
00:27:16.150 --> 00:27:19.030
It's gonna be a firewall
misconfigured on the network.

535
00:27:19.030 --> 00:27:21.740
It's gonna be some down stream
provider having an outage.

536
00:27:21.740 --> 00:27:24.880
So understand that we're trying
to cover all our bases here.

537
00:27:24.880 --> 00:27:27.540
Because these things do pop up,
they're just rare.

538
00:27:27.540 --> 00:27:30.360
And so just having it somewhere in
the back of your mind that some of these

539
00:27:30.360 --> 00:27:32.240
weird things can happen will
help you to isolate and

540
00:27:32.240 --> 00:27:34.330
find those problems in event that they do.

541
00:27:34.330 --> 00:27:36.940
>> Well very good Don, thank you for
being here in the studio with us.

542
00:27:36.940 --> 00:27:38.670
And thank you to you the viewer watching.

543
00:27:38.670 --> 00:27:40.160
We hope you've enjoyed the show.

544
00:27:40.160 --> 00:27:41.486
Signing off for ITProTV.

545
00:27:41.486 --> 00:27:42.861
I've been your host Wes Brian.

546
00:27:42.861 --> 00:27:43.743
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

547
00:27:43.743 --> 00:27:44.850
>> And we'll see you next time.

548
00:27:44.850 --> 00:27:51.745
[MUSIC]

549
00:27:51.745 --> 00:27:54.702
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes continue their exploration as they continue to tackle troubleshooting issues that arise on modern networks. They talk about various topics including bad cables, bad operating system routes, host file configuration issues and more.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Networking Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:08.262
Welcome to ITRO.TV [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:08.262 --> 00:00:12.105
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:12.105 --> 00:00:15.230
Welcome back to another great
episode here at ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:15.230 --> 00:00:18.460
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and in today's
episode we're continuing through our

5
00:00:18.460 --> 00:00:21.280
series in CompTIA Server Plus SK00004 and

6
00:00:21.280 --> 00:00:25.170
joining us in the studio is again,
is none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

7
00:00:25.170 --> 00:00:26.018
Don, how are you doing, sir?

8
00:00:26.018 --> 00:00:27.200
>> I'm doing well, Wes.

9
00:00:27.200 --> 00:00:28.320
Ready to wrap this one up.

10
00:00:28.320 --> 00:00:31.160
We've got a couple of, just a little
bit of tidbits to tackle on the network

11
00:00:31.160 --> 00:00:34.188
troubleshooting side to make sure that
we are objective complete for the exam.

12
00:00:34.188 --> 00:00:36.820
But also that we have
the right tools in our toolbox

13
00:00:36.820 --> 00:00:38.890
to be able to troubleshoot
networking issues in the workplace.

14
00:00:38.890 --> 00:00:41.780
So let's dive right back into it.

15
00:00:41.780 --> 00:00:44.970
I wanna start off with some weird things.

16
00:00:44.970 --> 00:00:45.880
NetBIOS.

17
00:00:45.880 --> 00:00:48.890
Now when I say NetBIOS,
I normally get the look from Wes,

18
00:00:48.890 --> 00:00:53.770
like Don why are we talking
about a 25 year old technology?

19
00:00:53.770 --> 00:00:57.948
Back in the day, all right,
let's go all the way back to Windows 3.1.

20
00:00:57.948 --> 00:01:00.742
Windows 3.1 had no networking in it.

21
00:01:00.742 --> 00:01:01.674
Zero.

22
00:01:01.674 --> 00:01:06.373
But you could pay a little extra and
get Windows 3.11 for work groups, and

23
00:01:06.373 --> 00:01:07.610
it had networking.

24
00:01:07.610 --> 00:01:11.303
It had some TCP IP as well as some NetBUI
technology built in the background so

25
00:01:11.303 --> 00:01:14.548
that it could talk to other
workstations that were on the network.

26
00:01:14.548 --> 00:01:15.640
And you could share files.

27
00:01:15.640 --> 00:01:16.810
It's great!

28
00:01:16.810 --> 00:01:22.730
We're talking probably 1990 was
when this was really all happening.

29
00:01:22.730 --> 00:01:24.790
So a long, long, long time ago.

30
00:01:24.790 --> 00:01:27.970
Well in today's world we don't
really use that anymore.

31
00:01:27.970 --> 00:01:30.880
We use TCP/IP and
we have standard protocols.

32
00:01:30.880 --> 00:01:32.680
Right, it's all nice and new.

33
00:01:32.680 --> 00:01:37.080
Well a lot of those old protocols were
carried over into the TCP/IP world and

34
00:01:37.080 --> 00:01:42.130
even though we're using things like
DNS and TCP and multicast, you still

35
00:01:42.130 --> 00:01:47.270
have some of that underlying technology
from the olden days right in your system.

36
00:01:47.270 --> 00:01:52.027
If you have a Windows file server,
or if you have a Linux Samba server,

37
00:01:52.027 --> 00:01:56.948
you're sharing files, and
you're sharing files using the SIFS format

38
00:01:56.948 --> 00:02:01.167
that come in internet file service,
I'm gonna say it twice.

39
00:02:01.167 --> 00:02:03.802
So you're using it to share things out,
and

40
00:02:03.802 --> 00:02:06.803
it's all built off this
old NetBIOS technology.

41
00:02:06.803 --> 00:02:10.554
And so, occasionally, you might run into
a situation where you need to troubleshoot

42
00:02:10.554 --> 00:02:12.190
using some of the older tools.

43
00:02:12.190 --> 00:02:13.845
There's really just two that
we need to worry about.

44
00:02:13.845 --> 00:02:16.330
And so I wanna show you guys those.

45
00:02:16.330 --> 00:02:19.300
It's a little bit hard to demonstrate
because our networks don't

46
00:02:19.300 --> 00:02:21.330
run the same way that they used to.

47
00:02:21.330 --> 00:02:24.980
Nowadays if I wanna talk to Wes' computer,
I don't send out some giant

48
00:02:24.980 --> 00:02:29.250
broadcast across the whole network to try
and find Wes' computer and start talking.

49
00:02:29.250 --> 00:02:32.500
Instead I do a DNS lookup
to get his IP address.

50
00:02:32.500 --> 00:02:35.250
I might have to do an ARP broadcast
to find his Mac address, but

51
00:02:35.250 --> 00:02:37.130
usually we've already seen
it on the network, and

52
00:02:37.130 --> 00:02:40.370
then I can talk directly to them,
and not mess with anybody else.

53
00:02:40.370 --> 00:02:44.500
Versus things like NetBUI, and those older
technologies where they would broadcast

54
00:02:44.500 --> 00:02:47.270
out for darn near anything, and
try and find people in the network and

55
00:02:47.270 --> 00:02:49.520
start talking, because networks
were much smaller back then.

56
00:02:49.520 --> 00:02:51.580
Those protocols weren't efficient.

57
00:02:51.580 --> 00:02:54.190
But if you're still using
NetBIOS in any form.

58
00:02:54.190 --> 00:02:55.820
Well you need to be able to troubleshoot.

59
00:02:55.820 --> 00:02:58.240
Now some people are using NetBIOS and
they don't even realize it.

60
00:02:58.240 --> 00:03:01.530
They think well I'm running
all Windows Server 2016 and

61
00:03:01.530 --> 00:03:02.990
all my clients are Windows 10.

62
00:03:02.990 --> 00:03:04.570
Yeah I've got some Linux boxes but

63
00:03:04.570 --> 00:03:07.070
they're all running Samba
in a full DNS environment.

64
00:03:07.070 --> 00:03:08.610
I don't use NetBIOS.

65
00:03:08.610 --> 00:03:09.850
Well you might not.

66
00:03:09.850 --> 00:03:10.370
You don't have to.

67
00:03:10.370 --> 00:03:13.190
You certainly could be using
entirely name lookup systems.

68
00:03:13.190 --> 00:03:17.743
But if you do any single name lookups,
when you browse across the network to

69
00:03:17.743 --> 00:03:22.513
a server and you use a single name to
reference it, then you are using NetBIOS,

70
00:03:22.513 --> 00:03:25.068
you are using a communication like that.

71
00:03:25.068 --> 00:03:27.270
And so those happen a lot.

72
00:03:27.270 --> 00:03:32.000
If you ever find yourself pulling up
a run prompt and browsing to a server.

73
00:03:32.000 --> 00:03:36.050
If you do a \\fileserver and press Enter.

74
00:03:36.050 --> 00:03:37.160
You're technically using NetBIOS.

75
00:03:37.160 --> 00:03:39.884
You're using NetBIOS over TCP/IP but
you are using NetBIOS.

76
00:03:39.884 --> 00:03:44.960
If you do //fileserver.domain.com,
now it's a different story.

77
00:03:44.960 --> 00:03:47.690
Now we're doing a DNS lookup,
we can go right to that person.

78
00:03:47.690 --> 00:03:51.210
But even then Windows will still
like to use NetBIOS for some things.

79
00:03:51.210 --> 00:03:54.150
So if I'm trying to reach out and
connect to a server using NetBIOS, and

80
00:03:54.150 --> 00:03:57.050
it's not working,
troubleshooting with ping and

81
00:03:57.050 --> 00:04:00.660
other utilities isn't really going to
help me cuz they're not using NetBIOS.

82
00:04:00.660 --> 00:04:03.880
So we still have some utilities that
are available to troubleshoot that.

83
00:04:03.880 --> 00:04:07.430
And unlike the other ones where I showed
you guys stuff on Windows and Linux,

84
00:04:07.430 --> 00:04:11.040
I'm just gonna stick with Windows because
If you're using NetBIOS under Linux,

85
00:04:11.040 --> 00:04:12.680
you're missing the whole point of Linux.

86
00:04:12.680 --> 00:04:16.460
You should be using NFS or
some other file system, or

87
00:04:16.460 --> 00:04:19.430
even SIFs but
through regular TCP/IP communications.

88
00:04:19.430 --> 00:04:21.210
Not through NetBIOS.
