552
00:25:03.990 --> 00:25:07.390
You plug into this port on the wall,
you'll get gigabit, no problem.

553
00:25:07.390 --> 00:25:09.340
You don't really know,
will you get gigabits?

554
00:25:09.340 --> 00:25:12.060
So, being able to certify that,
and they should be doing it.

555
00:25:12.060 --> 00:25:14.970
Any good network admin will be doing
that to make sure everything is okay.

556
00:25:14.970 --> 00:25:17.541
But just know that there are different
types of testers, they test for

557
00:25:17.541 --> 00:25:18.596
different types of things.

558
00:25:18.596 --> 00:25:21.593
And the more bandwidth you're
pushing on that copper wire,

559
00:25:21.593 --> 00:25:23.247
the more important that test is.

560
00:25:23.247 --> 00:25:26.830
Or the more important it is to use factory
built cables instead of building your own.

561
00:25:26.830 --> 00:25:29.510
We used to crimp ends
on cables all the time.

562
00:25:29.510 --> 00:25:30.800
But in today's world,

563
00:25:30.800 --> 00:25:34.400
I usually just do factory cables,
cuz it's such a pain to get it done right.

564
00:25:34.400 --> 00:25:37.210
The Cat 6 cabling,
the ends are always a lot more tight.

565
00:25:37.210 --> 00:25:38.860
It's just much more difficult to do.

566
00:25:38.860 --> 00:25:41.360
So I just let the factory do it.

567
00:25:41.360 --> 00:25:44.480
But that's not always an option,
sometimes you need to custom cut cable.

568
00:25:44.480 --> 00:25:46.370
In which case you really
need to test that out.

569
00:25:46.370 --> 00:25:49.370
You can see some odd behavior on a server
when you've got a bad network cable.

570
00:25:49.370 --> 00:25:52.420
It's really obvious if you fire up
a network sniffer, like Wireshark,

571
00:25:52.420 --> 00:25:54.770
and you'll see a lot of
retransmits on the network.

572
00:25:54.770 --> 00:25:56.590
A lot of times where it's
having to retransmit,

573
00:25:56.590 --> 00:25:59.570
you'll get negative acknowledgments
in TCP/IP that are showing,

574
00:25:59.570 --> 00:26:02.610
hey I didn't get this and
I was supposed to, or failed checksums.

575
00:26:02.610 --> 00:26:06.240
You'll get CRC failures a lot, and
you can see that in a network sniffer.

576
00:26:06.240 --> 00:26:08.700
You don't really see that
in the operating systems.

577
00:26:08.700 --> 00:26:10.870
In the Linux world you
have the TCPDUMP command,

578
00:26:10.870 --> 00:26:14.220
and you can use TCPDUMP to see all
that stuff that's coming across.

579
00:26:14.220 --> 00:26:17.940
In the Windows world you have open
source software like Wireshark.

580
00:26:17.940 --> 00:26:20.890
And then there's some closed source stuff
like the Network Monitor from Microsoft

581
00:26:20.890 --> 00:26:22.680
that hasn't been updated in a long time.

582
00:26:22.680 --> 00:26:25.450
Wireshark's really the best
way to go to see that stuff.

583
00:26:25.450 --> 00:26:27.670
>> Alright Don,
that's a lot of great information.

584
00:26:27.670 --> 00:26:30.510
I know that we've been through a lot
of different concepts there, but

585
00:26:30.510 --> 00:26:33.470
it does look like we are coming
to the end of another episode.

586
00:26:33.470 --> 00:26:34.100
Before we do,

587
00:26:34.100 --> 00:26:37.960
do you have any additional words you might
like to let our viewers know in this one?

588
00:26:37.960 --> 00:26:42.840
>> Main thing is, if you've got a network
team get them engaged to have the best

589
00:26:42.840 --> 00:26:46.180
data center possible, the network team and
the sys admin team need to work together.

590
00:26:46.180 --> 00:26:47.680
They need to be able to trust each other.

591
00:26:47.680 --> 00:26:49.550
But in order to ask them for help,

592
00:26:49.550 --> 00:26:51.220
you need to at least have
an idea where the problem is.

593
00:26:51.220 --> 00:26:54.750
So use all the tools at your
disposal to try and isolate and

594
00:26:54.750 --> 00:26:58.170
figure out where that issue is before
going to the network team to help them.

595
00:26:58.170 --> 00:27:00.820
So they can kind of dial in
right on it and get it resolved.

596
00:27:00.820 --> 00:27:03.710
But definitely engage them
if you are the network team.

597
00:27:03.710 --> 00:27:06.870
If it's a small shop and
you're kind of wearing more than one hat,

598
00:27:06.870 --> 00:27:10.150
then just don't always assume
the problem is the server, or

599
00:27:10.150 --> 00:27:11.540
don't always assume
the problem is the network.

600
00:27:11.540 --> 00:27:12.410
It could be either one or

601
00:27:12.410 --> 00:27:15.553
it could even be both that leads
to the problem that you've got.

602
00:27:15.553 --> 00:27:16.370
>> All right Don.

603
00:27:16.370 --> 00:27:18.360
Thank you for
being here in the studios with us, and

604
00:27:18.360 --> 00:27:19.930
thank you to you the viewer watching.

605
00:27:19.930 --> 00:27:23.121
Signing out for
ITProTV I've been your host Wes Bryan.

606
00:27:23.121 --> 00:27:23.991
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

607
00:27:23.991 --> 00:27:25.965
And we'll see you next time.

608
00:27:25.965 --> 00:27:32.066
[MUSIC]

609
00:27:32.066 --> 00:27:33.860
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don discuss various problems that arise when storage troubleshooting. They look at problems like slow file access, OS not found, error lights, data corruption and more.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Storage
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:00.984
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:00.984 --> 00:00:01.840
I'm your host.

3
00:00:01.840 --> 00:00:08.208
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:08.208 --> 00:00:11.873
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.873 --> 00:00:15.024
>> Hello and welcome to another
great episode here at ITPro TV.

6
00:00:15.024 --> 00:00:16.285
I am your host Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:16.285 --> 00:00:17.835
And in today's episode,

8
00:00:17.835 --> 00:00:22.349
we're continuing through our series
in CompTIA's Server plus SK004.

9
00:00:22.349 --> 00:00:25.161
And joining us back in the studios
again is Mr. Don Pezet.

10
00:00:25.161 --> 00:00:26.329
Don, how are you doing, sir?

11
00:00:26.329 --> 00:00:27.457
>> I am doing great, Wes.

12
00:00:27.457 --> 00:00:28.884
Ready to dive right back into Server Plus.

13
00:00:28.884 --> 00:00:32.464
And in this episode, we're gonna be
talking about troubleshooting storage.

14
00:00:32.464 --> 00:00:34.793
And it is an important process.

15
00:00:34.793 --> 00:00:38.251
It's actually one of the more important
things that we troubleshoot but

16
00:00:38.251 --> 00:00:39.961
it's also one of the easiest ones.

17
00:00:39.961 --> 00:00:44.340
Because when storage fails,
it's usually very, very obvious.

18
00:00:44.340 --> 00:00:47.479
It's not like memory errors where they
come and go and they're intermittent.

19
00:00:47.479 --> 00:00:52.517
Storage errors are typically permanent and
they can be intermittent sometimes.

20
00:00:52.517 --> 00:00:55.630
But they're normally permanent,
which makes them very, very easy to spot.

21
00:00:55.630 --> 00:01:01.210
So for example, if you maintain
a datacenter, one of your jobs, or

22
00:01:01.210 --> 00:01:05.160
somebody's job in the organization, should
be to go and visually inspect servers.

23
00:01:05.160 --> 00:01:07.740
And you visually inspect the servers
once a day, once a week,

24
00:01:07.740 --> 00:01:09.870
whatever interval it is that
you're comfortable with.

25
00:01:09.870 --> 00:01:12.260
But when you visually inspect the servers,
what you're doing is looking for

26
00:01:12.260 --> 00:01:13.570
things like dust buildup.

27
00:01:13.570 --> 00:01:15.990
You're looking to make sure racks
are locked like they're supposed to.

28
00:01:15.990 --> 00:01:19.190
The servers are in place and
powered on, those things.

29
00:01:19.190 --> 00:01:22.480
But you're also checking,
because most servers have a little LCD

30
00:01:22.480 --> 00:01:24.730
screen on them that can
give you error messages.

31
00:01:24.730 --> 00:01:28.311
They have a blinking light that can
let you know if there's an error,

32
00:01:28.311 --> 00:01:30.618
and all of the hard
drives will have lights.

33
00:01:30.618 --> 00:01:33.039
And the hard drive lights
are typically blinking green,

34
00:01:33.039 --> 00:01:34.810
letting you know that the disk is active.

35
00:01:34.810 --> 00:01:38.386
Or if the server's really super idle for
some reason, they might just be sitting

36
00:01:38.386 --> 00:01:41.630
there with a steady green light or
no green light at all.

37
00:01:41.630 --> 00:01:45.640
But when something goes wrong,
that's when that red light lights up, or

38
00:01:45.640 --> 00:01:46.730
an amber light.

39
00:01:46.730 --> 00:01:50.670
And when that light is lit, that tells you
that something went wrong with the drive.

40
00:01:50.670 --> 00:01:54.720
You can visually and easily inspect and
see that and know that there's a problem.

41
00:01:54.720 --> 00:01:56.950
But you don't really
know what the problem is.

42
00:01:56.950 --> 00:01:59.130
Is the drive not spinning anymore?

43
00:01:59.130 --> 00:02:02.990
Did the drive get a recoverable error,
like one bad read on it and

44
00:02:02.990 --> 00:02:06.050
it was able to salvage the data and
you're continuing to run fine?

45
00:02:06.050 --> 00:02:10.748
Is the drive failed and a hot spare has
already jumped in and taken its place so

46
00:02:10.748 --> 00:02:12.220
you're safe?

47
00:02:12.220 --> 00:02:13.540
You don't know all that.

48
00:02:13.540 --> 00:02:16.400
The light doesn't tell
you all that information.

49
00:02:16.400 --> 00:02:17.940
It just lets you know there's a problem.

50
00:02:17.940 --> 00:02:18.710
Gives you a warning.

51
00:02:18.710 --> 00:02:21.260
Your warning you need to go and
find what's going on.

52
00:02:21.260 --> 00:02:23.800
Now you don't necessarily
wanna rely on the lights.

53
00:02:23.800 --> 00:02:27.002
Because if you're like me, I don't go
in that server room every day, and

54
00:02:27.002 --> 00:02:28.965
if it weren't for
this glass wall behind me,

55
00:02:28.965 --> 00:02:31.511
I probably wouldn't see those
servers on any given week.

56
00:02:31.511 --> 00:02:35.997
So how do we know if we're not
actually paying attention?

57
00:02:35.997 --> 00:02:38.067
Well, that's when you set
up an alerting system.

58
00:02:38.067 --> 00:02:42.048
Most environments will use something
like the HP insight system,

59
00:02:42.048 --> 00:02:44.189
where it will monitor the servers.

60
00:02:44.189 --> 00:02:46.491
And if there's a drive failure,
it'll shoot you an email or

61
00:02:46.491 --> 00:02:47.448
send you a text message.

62
00:02:47.448 --> 00:02:50.553
They can even, if they're smart enough,
if the system's under warranty,

63
00:02:50.553 --> 00:02:52.660
can even call in the warranty ticket for
you.

64
00:02:52.660 --> 00:02:55.060
And all of a sudden a hard drive shows up
the next day that you can go and swap out.

65
00:02:55.060 --> 00:02:57.093
That stuff is really, really nice.

66
00:02:57.093 --> 00:03:02.180
So as far as troubleshooting,
it might already be taken care of for us.

67
00:03:02.180 --> 00:03:06.800
But there are some problems that
can creep in we might not notice.

68
00:03:06.800 --> 00:03:09.230
And we might not even
trigger our monitoring alert.

69
00:03:09.230 --> 00:03:12.850
And that's the spots where we need
to be able to step in, and look, and

70
00:03:12.850 --> 00:03:14.050
find out what's going on.

71
00:03:14.050 --> 00:03:17.420
And the number one instance that I wanna
mention is when somebody calls in and

72
00:03:17.420 --> 00:03:20.780
complains, and says, boy,
this server seems awfully slow today.

73
00:03:20.780 --> 00:03:22.450
Or email is slow today.

74
00:03:22.450 --> 00:03:26.636
Or, I'm trying to use our company website,
and it's taking forever to load.

75
00:03:26.636 --> 00:03:31.151
Well, when you have a performing
issue like that, it could be CPU,

76
00:03:31.151 --> 00:03:32.269
it could be RAM.

77
00:03:32.269 --> 00:03:36.578
But storage is the slowest
component in your computer.

78
00:03:36.578 --> 00:03:39.997
If you crack up your computer, you start
ripping out all the different pieces,

79
00:03:39.997 --> 00:03:41.333
the CPU is pretty darned fast.

80
00:03:41.333 --> 00:03:43.460
Your RAM, pretty darned fast.

81
00:03:43.460 --> 00:03:45.820
Your storage, not so much.

82
00:03:45.820 --> 00:03:48.950
Now, if it's spinning disk,
it's absolutely slow.

83
00:03:48.950 --> 00:03:53.420
But if it's an SSD, it's faster but
it's still not as fast as your RAM.

84
00:03:53.420 --> 00:03:55.500
And it's still not as fast as your CPU.

85
00:03:55.500 --> 00:03:57.660
So when people start
complaining about performance,

86
00:03:57.660 --> 00:03:59.290
storage is often a big part of that.

87
00:03:59.290 --> 00:04:00.651
It's often the bottleneck.

88
00:04:00.651 --> 00:04:02.299
Not a guarantee, but often.

89
00:04:02.299 --> 00:04:06.923
>> You know Don, with something like the
HP software that you're talking about and

90
00:04:06.923 --> 00:04:07.740
monitoring.

91
00:04:07.740 --> 00:04:10.030
It's not inside of our operating system.

92
00:04:10.030 --> 00:04:11.970
But it is monitoring the hardware.

93
00:04:11.970 --> 00:04:14.990
How are we gonna be able to detect
something if the very software that we

94
00:04:14.990 --> 00:04:18.350
have to detect problems kinda turns
a blind eye or doesn't see it?

95
00:04:18.350 --> 00:04:20.860
How are we actually gonna
diagnose those errors?

96
00:04:20.860 --> 00:04:24.010
>> All right, so that's where we go back
to one of the things we mentioned way back

97
00:04:24.010 --> 00:04:26.470
in the beginning of the series is
that when you install a new server,

98
00:04:26.470 --> 00:04:28.290
you should do a performance baseline.

99
00:04:28.290 --> 00:04:35.100
And part of that baseline is tracking
CPU and memory and network and disk I/O.

100
00:04:35.100 --> 00:04:38.390
On the disk I/O side, we need to know
how much time it takes to read and

101
00:04:38.390 --> 00:04:39.435
write data to the disk.

102
00:04:39.435 --> 00:04:41.940
What's the average disk queue
length over any given time?

103
00:04:41.940 --> 00:04:44.692
Those little metrics that tell
us how a drive is performing.

104
00:04:44.692 --> 00:04:48.220
And then that way when somebody calls and
complains that the drive is slow,

105
00:04:48.220 --> 00:04:50.074
the drive might show as being healthy.

106
00:04:50.074 --> 00:04:51.978
But then I go and pull up my metrics and

107
00:04:51.978 --> 00:04:56.030
sure enough I see where the drive
latency is higher than it should be.

108
00:04:56.030 --> 00:05:00.460
Or it's just taking longer to
retrieve data from that disk,

109
00:05:00.460 --> 00:05:02.160
something of that nature.

110
00:05:02.160 --> 00:05:05.040
And I go and look and
the hardware is actually fine.

111
00:05:05.040 --> 00:05:09.870
The hardware might be perfectly fine, but
the load on the server has increased.

112
00:05:09.870 --> 00:05:11.566
And monitoring software
isn't gonna pick that up.

113
00:05:11.566 --> 00:05:15.090
Monitoring software is watching for
the health of the hardware, right?

114
00:05:15.090 --> 00:05:19.600
HP's Insight Manager is designed to
watch the health of the hardware.

115
00:05:19.600 --> 00:05:22.780
And Dell's software,
whose name I can never remember,

116
00:05:22.780 --> 00:05:27.950
if you're running things like
CA Unicenter, or WhatsUp Gold,

117
00:05:27.950 --> 00:05:31.855
or whatever, they're all designed to
monitor that health of the system.

118
00:05:31.855 --> 00:05:34.662
And usually the health of the hardware and
not so much performance.

119
00:05:34.662 --> 00:05:35.370
Cuz they don't know.

120
00:05:35.370 --> 00:05:37.970
They don't know what's normal
performance for you and what's not.

121
00:05:37.970 --> 00:05:40.080
Now obviously,
if you're running at a 100% CPU,

122
00:05:40.080 --> 00:05:42.640
everybody knows that's probably
not a good thing, right?

123
00:05:42.640 --> 00:05:46.260
But if you're running at 80% CPU,
that might be normal for you.

124
00:05:46.260 --> 00:05:47.750
But that might be high for me.

125
00:05:47.750 --> 00:05:49.760
So we've gotta make sure
we set those boundaries.

126
00:05:49.760 --> 00:05:52.510
We've gotta go in and
customize that software to meet our needs.

127
00:05:52.510 --> 00:05:54.510
The other thing is there's
different types of storage.

128
00:05:54.510 --> 00:05:57.640
And so you can have problems that
are being affected by other components.

129
00:05:57.640 --> 00:05:59.440
That's the real challenge
of troubleshooting storage.

130
00:05:59.440 --> 00:06:01.950
Is it used to be we all had
direct attached storage, right?

131
00:06:01.950 --> 00:06:04.050
So like the diagram that
I've got pulled up here.

132
00:06:04.050 --> 00:06:05.437
I've got a bunch of servers.

133
00:06:05.437 --> 00:06:07.725
And these are virtualization hosts, right?

134
00:06:07.725 --> 00:06:10.657
So VM Hosts one through four, and
they've all got direct attached storage.

135
00:06:10.657 --> 00:06:13.360
Storage that's either right
inside of the chassis or

136
00:06:13.360 --> 00:06:15.709
in an external array
directly attached to it.

137
00:06:15.709 --> 00:06:18.045
And so if a server is performing poorly,

138
00:06:18.045 --> 00:06:21.700
it might just be its own storage
right there inside of that box.

139
00:06:21.700 --> 00:06:25.220
It's all self-contained,
I can troubleshoot, and look at it.

140
00:06:25.220 --> 00:06:29.470
But what if I have a SAN
with a redundant fabric?

141
00:06:30.840 --> 00:06:33.580
Now I've got a lot of
components in the mix.

142
00:06:33.580 --> 00:06:36.943
First off,
I might have my four VM hosts down here.

143
00:06:36.943 --> 00:06:38.833
But they've all got two HBAs and

144
00:06:38.833 --> 00:06:42.199
the HBAs run over fiber links
to two different switches.

145
00:06:42.199 --> 00:06:45.008
And the two different switches run
over fiber links to two completely

146
00:06:45.008 --> 00:06:46.010
different SANS.

147
00:06:46.010 --> 00:06:47.748
And the SANS are shared.

148
00:06:47.748 --> 00:06:54.310
So Node 3 might be just fine accessing
SAN 1, but Node 1 can't access SAN 1.

149
00:06:54.310 --> 00:06:58.070
Or Node 3 is generating more
utilization than normal.

150
00:06:58.070 --> 00:07:00.370
And Node 1 is running at
its normal utilization, but

151
00:07:00.370 --> 00:07:04.220
now it's slow because Node 3 is
consuming more than it should.

152
00:07:04.220 --> 00:07:08.926
So I'm seeing symptoms on Node 1
when nothing is wrong with Node 1.

153
00:07:08.926 --> 00:07:12.760
I'm seeing symptoms on Node 1
because Node 3 is going crazy and

154
00:07:12.760 --> 00:07:15.251
consuming all the bandwidth into SAN 1.

155
00:07:15.251 --> 00:07:19.747
See, I've got this one link in the SAN
1 right here via that switch, and

156
00:07:19.747 --> 00:07:22.270
that can start to cause issues.

157
00:07:22.270 --> 00:07:25.918
Where it gets even more complex is
if you're doing something like MPIO.

158
00:07:25.918 --> 00:07:28.810
MPIO is multi-path input
output operations,

159
00:07:28.810 --> 00:07:32.810
or multipath for
mesh networks like this one.

160
00:07:32.810 --> 00:07:36.600
Where I might be load balancing
across these two connections.

161
00:07:36.600 --> 00:07:41.510
So that I can go through this switch to
get to SAN 1 and I can follow this link

162
00:07:41.510 --> 00:07:45.690
over to the other switch over to SAN 1,
I can double my bandwidth.

163
00:07:45.690 --> 00:07:48.740
Well, now I might see a performance hit,
which link is it?

164
00:07:48.740 --> 00:07:51.739
It could be a problem with switch 1 or
a problem with switch 2.

165
00:07:51.739 --> 00:07:53.531
Now things get really confusing.

166
00:07:53.531 --> 00:07:56.656
So when you look at storage issues,
you have to think about the path.

167
00:07:56.656 --> 00:07:59.504
The path that your server
has to take to get to it.

168
00:07:59.504 --> 00:08:01.790

00:08:01.790 --> 00:08:04.210

00:08:09.040 --> 00:08:12.140

the PCI bus to an HBA.

172
00:08:12.140 --> 00:08:16.510
And then cross the HBA over to the fiber

00:08:16.510 --> 00:08:19.460
down to a particular LUN

00:08:19.460 --> 00:08:21.030

00:08:22.050 --> 00:08:25.658

00:08:25.658 --> 00:08:30.580

00:08:30.580 --> 00:08:32.900

00:08:32.900 --> 00:08:36.440
Far less things for me to troubleshoot and

00:08:36.440 --> 00:08:39.060

00:08:39.060 --> 00:08:42.200

00:08:42.200 --> 00:08:44.000

00:08:46.130 --> 00:08:48.730

00:08:48.730 --> 00:08:49.706

00:09:06.067 --> 00:09:08.252

00:09:08.252 --> 00:09:13.923

00:09:23.500 --> 00:09:26.670

00:09:26.670 --> 00:09:30.160

00:09:30.160 --> 00:09:33.340

00:09:33.340 --> 00:09:35.510

00:09:35.510 --> 00:09:36.930

00:09:36.930 --> 00:09:39.862

00:09:39.862 --> 00:09:42.390

00:09:44.930 --> 00:09:46.810

00:09:46.810 --> 00:09:48.730

00:09:48.730 --> 00:09:51.545

00:09:51.545 --> 00:09:53.585

I gotta send all 15, the whole thing.

395
00:19:00.040 --> 00:19:02.050
The server's offline,
already, that's bad enough.

396
00:19:02.050 --> 00:19:04.190
Now I gotta send the whole thing in for
reclamation.

397
00:19:04.190 --> 00:19:09.350
That is not a economical process, and
it's definitely not a timely process.

398
00:19:09.350 --> 00:19:10.880
So we need to have back ups.

399
00:19:10.880 --> 00:19:14.070
If we have back ups,
I don't care if the hardware fails.

400
00:19:14.070 --> 00:19:16.680
I care if I have a little down time,
but I know I can recover my data and

401
00:19:16.680 --> 00:19:18.760
I'll be safe, right?

402
00:19:18.760 --> 00:19:20.220
Unless my backups failed.

403
00:19:20.220 --> 00:19:23.840
So as part of monitoring storage,
you also need to be monitoring backups.

404
00:19:23.840 --> 00:19:26.281
That should be part of your
disaster recovery process anyway.

405
00:19:26.281 --> 00:19:29.250
You need to make sure that your
backups are successful and stable,

406
00:19:29.250 --> 00:19:30.532
that is an important thing.

407
00:19:32.412 --> 00:19:35.332
Most of the other errors that CompTIA
calls out are all kinda tied to

408
00:19:35.332 --> 00:19:36.280
the same thing.

409
00:19:36.280 --> 00:19:38.120
We've got unable to mount the device.

410
00:19:38.120 --> 00:19:41.230
If the disk won't mount,
it can be a hardware error,

411
00:19:41.230 --> 00:19:43.170
if it's a hardware error
the disk typically won't show up.

412
00:19:43.170 --> 00:19:44.675
If you have a disk that won't mount,

413
00:19:44.675 --> 00:19:47.560
a lot of times it's more like
a partition table type problem.

414
00:19:47.560 --> 00:19:49.840
You might need to fix or
repair your partition table.

415
00:19:49.840 --> 00:19:52.450
In the Unix world you can
use fdisk to do that.

416
00:19:52.450 --> 00:19:54.800
In the Windows world you have Fix NBR,

417
00:19:54.800 --> 00:19:57.640
a number of other command
line utilities you can use.

418
00:19:57.640 --> 00:20:00.220
In Windows you have Boot CFG and
stuff that'll go through and

419
00:20:00.220 --> 00:20:03.300
fix some of these boot files that
you can use then to repair that.

420
00:20:03.300 --> 00:20:06.230
But that's more on the software
side than the storage side.

421
00:20:06.230 --> 00:20:08.040
The bigger question though
is why did that happen?

422
00:20:08.040 --> 00:20:09.470
Why did we get that?

423
00:20:09.470 --> 00:20:12.670
And it could be that I'm getting
data corruption on the disc.

424
00:20:12.670 --> 00:20:15.220
Which is caused by bad sectors.

425
00:20:15.220 --> 00:20:20.250
Or the heads on the disc going bad, or an
SSD that's been written to too many times.

426
00:20:20.250 --> 00:20:22.550
And there's no way to
reverse that process.

427
00:20:22.550 --> 00:20:25.820
So as soon as we see that happening, we
need to replace that storage, otherwise,

428
00:20:25.820 --> 00:20:27.600
it's just gonna be an outage eventually.

429
00:20:27.600 --> 00:20:29.690
Whether or not we want it to be or not.

430
00:20:31.050 --> 00:20:34.260
All right I already talked a little
bit about slow IO performance, but

431
00:20:34.260 --> 00:20:36.050
let me double back on that real quick.

432
00:20:36.050 --> 00:20:40.490
If your disks are appearing to be slow,
oftentimes they're just slow,

433
00:20:40.490 --> 00:20:42.360
that's how disks are, right?

434
00:20:42.360 --> 00:20:44.390
But they might be slower than normal.

435
00:20:44.390 --> 00:20:46.900
And that's where we need to have that
baseline, and you can use any performance

436
00:20:46.900 --> 00:20:51.496
monitor type utility to go in there and
monitor how that disk performance is.

437
00:20:51.496 --> 00:20:53.412
What is your seek time, and so on?

438
00:20:53.412 --> 00:20:56.410
There's third-party utilities out
there you can use to test it,

439
00:20:56.410 --> 00:20:58.280
if you wanna try to get
an independent view.

440
00:20:58.280 --> 00:21:00.810
But in Windows, I just usually
use the performance monitor.

441
00:21:00.810 --> 00:21:02.170
It can run through and do that.

442
00:21:02.170 --> 00:21:05.200
In the Unix world, there's actually
a number of different utilities

443
00:21:05.200 --> 00:21:07.910
you can use to gauge it, and
measure that performance.

444
00:21:07.910 --> 00:21:11.570
So it depends on which you're running.

445
00:21:11.570 --> 00:21:14.420
What else do we have on this one?

446
00:21:14.420 --> 00:21:16.220
I talk about backup failure.

447
00:21:16.220 --> 00:21:19.710
CompTIA specifically calls
out restore failure also.

448
00:21:19.710 --> 00:21:24.450
When we do a backup, a lot of times the
backup job can say that it was successful.

449
00:21:24.450 --> 00:21:26.830
But there was a problem with the data.

450
00:21:26.830 --> 00:21:28.950
If you're backing up bad data,
what are you gonna restore?

451
00:21:28.950 --> 00:21:30.960
You're gonna restore bad data.

452
00:21:30.960 --> 00:21:32.980
So if there's an unreadable
sector on a drive and

453
00:21:32.980 --> 00:21:35.330
you go to back it up,
that sector is unreadable.

454
00:21:35.330 --> 00:21:38.101
Whatever was there isn't gonna be
retrieved and now we can't restore it.

455
00:21:38.101 --> 00:21:41.083
So dont just assume that you're
backup will save the day.

456
00:21:41.083 --> 00:21:42.620
You're supposed to test backups.

457
00:21:42.620 --> 00:21:43.440
Try them out.

458
00:21:43.440 --> 00:21:46.200
When you run a backup, most backup
software has the option to do a verify

459
00:21:46.200 --> 00:21:48.430
that makes the backup take
a heck of a lot longer.

460
00:21:48.430 --> 00:21:51.610
But it's testing to make sure that it
can reread everything off of the backup

461
00:21:51.610 --> 00:21:52.700
in order to do the restore.

462
00:21:52.700 --> 00:21:54.240
And that kind of stuff is handy.

463
00:21:54.240 --> 00:21:58.740
Cause it's gonna help you with
recovering that system, it is important.

464
00:21:59.980 --> 00:22:05.060
If you see multiple drive failure,
multiple drive failure is typically

465
00:22:05.060 --> 00:22:08.370
an indicator that you have
a bigger problem than just drives.

466
00:22:08.370 --> 00:22:12.390
Your problem is more than
likely backplane or power.

467
00:22:12.390 --> 00:22:14.550
If the drives aren't getting enough
power they can't spin up right,

468
00:22:14.550 --> 00:22:18.040
and if they can't spin up right
then you're gonna get errors.

469
00:22:18.040 --> 00:22:21.120
If they're SSDs they draw power too,
not as much, right.

470
00:22:21.120 --> 00:22:23.460
So it's not,
it's a lot less likely to need power.

471
00:22:23.460 --> 00:22:28.190
But both SSD and spinning disk, plug into
a backplane, and the backplanes do fail.

472
00:22:28.190 --> 00:22:29.870
Especially on a hot swaps system.

473
00:22:29.870 --> 00:22:32.330
Most system have hot plug hard drives.

474
00:22:32.330 --> 00:22:36.100
As you push them in and pull them back out
over time, it will wear out that port.

475
00:22:36.100 --> 00:22:40.110
I talk about that in
the troubleshooting hardware episode,

476
00:22:40.110 --> 00:22:41.780
that the backplane can fail.

477
00:22:41.780 --> 00:22:44.340
And it might look like
multiple drive failures

478
00:22:44.340 --> 00:22:46.830
when in actuality the drives are fine.

479
00:22:46.830 --> 00:22:50.440
But it's not unheard of to
get a bad batch of drives.

480
00:22:50.440 --> 00:22:53.530
When you buy a server with 15 drives and
you get them all at the same time,

481
00:22:53.530 --> 00:22:56.380
those drives are all
manufactured at the same time.

482
00:22:56.380 --> 00:22:58.990
And so if there was a bad batch
manufactured at the factory,

483
00:22:58.990 --> 00:23:01.820
you could see multiple
drives fail all at once.

484
00:23:01.820 --> 00:23:04.570
Usually a quick call to the vendor
is all it takes to figure that out,

485
00:23:04.570 --> 00:23:05.430
cuz they'll know.

486
00:23:05.430 --> 00:23:06.390
We've seen it here.

487
00:23:06.390 --> 00:23:10.710
Wes, do you remember the drives that we
had, they were like raptors or something?

488
00:23:10.710 --> 00:23:12.850
>> Yes,
they were 10,000 RPM velociraptors and

489
00:23:12.850 --> 00:23:16.520
about 50% of them had
a failure in the first year.

490
00:23:16.520 --> 00:23:19.300
>> Yeah, and those were all
purchased at the same time, and so

491
00:23:19.300 --> 00:23:22.220
that kinda stuff does happen,
right, we've seen it.

492
00:23:22.220 --> 00:23:24.740
But it's more of an outlier,
it's not something that happens often.

493
00:23:24.740 --> 00:23:27.739
So just be aware that when you see
multiple drive failures normally

494
00:23:27.739 --> 00:23:30.160
indicating a backplane
failure are possibly power.

495
00:23:31.540 --> 00:23:35.440
All right last thing I have to mention
on common problems is cache failure.

496
00:23:35.440 --> 00:23:41.230
That if you have a raid controller with
a battery backed write cache controller,

497
00:23:41.230 --> 00:23:44.160
then usually the cache
is an add in module.

498
00:23:44.160 --> 00:23:46.139
If you go back to the server
components episode,

499
00:23:46.139 --> 00:23:49.242
the raid controller that I showed in
there had that, had that add in module.

500
00:23:49.242 --> 00:23:51.535
Because it's an addin
module it can wiggle loose.

501
00:23:51.535 --> 00:23:53.370
It can come loose and it can go bad.

502
00:23:53.370 --> 00:23:54.991
Any component can go bad.

503
00:23:54.991 --> 00:23:57.551
And if that happens,
it's easy enough to swap it out.

504
00:23:57.551 --> 00:23:58.917
If you have an extra one laying around.

505
00:23:58.917 --> 00:23:59.898
But who does?

506
00:23:59.898 --> 00:24:02.160
Who has extra cache memory
just laying on a table?

507
00:24:02.160 --> 00:24:02.750
Most of us don't.

508
00:24:02.750 --> 00:24:04.920
So that one gets to be challenging.

509
00:24:04.920 --> 00:24:07.750
Fortunately, most RAID controllers,
when that cache controller starts to

510
00:24:07.750 --> 00:24:11.100
come loose, they just disable the cache
and they start writing to the disk.

511
00:24:11.100 --> 00:24:13.430
We see that as a performance decrease.

512
00:24:13.430 --> 00:24:14.110
But you might not notice.

513
00:24:14.110 --> 00:24:16.700
If it's something you're
not paying attention to.

514
00:24:16.700 --> 00:24:18.340
So that's where you need
your monitoring software.

515
00:24:18.340 --> 00:24:20.080
If I had a right cache controller fail,

516
00:24:20.080 --> 00:24:22.580
I would see it in my HP
array configuration utility.

517
00:24:22.580 --> 00:24:24.650
It would show me that cache
wasn't working right.

518
00:24:24.650 --> 00:24:27.020
I would get a warning and
be able to act on that.

519
00:24:27.020 --> 00:24:29.980
Same thing with Dell power and
RAID controllers, they do the same thing.

520
00:24:29.980 --> 00:24:33.780
They can alert you if that cache has
a failing battery or something else.

521
00:24:33.780 --> 00:24:36.110
You'll actually see it on the little
LCD screen on the front of the server.

522
00:24:38.410 --> 00:24:41.110
Okay, I've talked about
a lot of different things.

523
00:24:41.110 --> 00:24:42.490
And a lot of the common problems.

524
00:24:42.490 --> 00:24:45.690
We're kind of running down the list
here to see if I missed any of them.

525
00:24:45.690 --> 00:24:48.055
Wes is telling me I missed a couple.

526
00:24:48.055 --> 00:24:50.500
[LAUGH] The human stuff, right?

527
00:24:50.500 --> 00:24:55.050
Misconfiguration and, when I come
to you it gets funny sometimes.

528
00:24:55.050 --> 00:24:56.580
So misconfiguration.

529
00:24:56.580 --> 00:24:59.010
As a human being,
we can set up things wrong.

530
00:24:59.010 --> 00:25:00.470
It certainly happens.

531
00:25:00.470 --> 00:25:04.700
I can configure an array incorrectly,
and my performance takes a hit on that.

532
00:25:04.700 --> 00:25:08.740
So never underestimate the human
ability to mess things up.

533
00:25:08.740 --> 00:25:11.460
I could have a stand
where I've accidentally

534
00:25:11.460 --> 00:25:14.640
assigned the same LUM number
to two different servers.

535
00:25:14.640 --> 00:25:16.670
And I've got two different servers
trying to access the same storage

536
00:25:16.670 --> 00:25:17.190
at the same time.

537
00:25:17.190 --> 00:25:18.620
What's that gonna result in?

538
00:25:18.620 --> 00:25:19.840
Data corruption.

539
00:25:19.840 --> 00:25:21.820
And I might think,
I keep getting data corruption.

540
00:25:21.820 --> 00:25:23.520
This drive must be bad.

541
00:25:23.520 --> 00:25:24.620
It's not the drive.

542
00:25:24.620 --> 00:25:28.160
You connected two servers to the same
storage, that's gonna cause problems.

543
00:25:28.160 --> 00:25:33.880
So misconfiguration on our part can
certainly lead to challenges like that.

544
00:25:33.880 --> 00:25:36.450
And then the other thing CompTIA
calls out is improper termination.

545
00:25:36.450 --> 00:25:40.290
Now I laughed when I saw this
objective because termination is not

546
00:25:40.290 --> 00:25:43.270
something I've had to deal with in
storage in well over ten years.

547
00:25:43.270 --> 00:25:46.545
So it's not something most of
us ever have to mess with.

548
00:25:46.545 --> 00:25:50.390
But just for completeness,
in the olden days when you had a SCSI bus,

549
00:25:50.390 --> 00:25:53.250
the end of the SCSI bus
had to be terminated.

550
00:25:53.250 --> 00:25:57.200
Well, all the newer standards
of SCSI auto terminate.

551
00:25:57.200 --> 00:26:02.980
So, what will happen is you
daisy chain the drives.

552
00:26:02.980 --> 00:26:03.555
You have a big ribbon cable and

553
00:26:03.555 --> 00:26:04.732
you can have up to 14 drives
attached to this ribbon cable.

554
00:26:04.732 --> 00:26:07.727
And each one had a SCSI ID number on it,
and

555
00:26:07.727 --> 00:26:11.763
whoever was the last one on
that chain had to terminate.

556
00:26:11.763 --> 00:26:15.940
The electrical signal that would cross
the line had to stop and reflect back.

557
00:26:15.940 --> 00:26:17.990
And so the terminator did that job.

558
00:26:17.990 --> 00:26:21.880
Your signal would go all the way to the
end, hit that terminator and bounce back.

559
00:26:21.880 --> 00:26:23.490
Now if the terminator wasn't there,

560
00:26:23.490 --> 00:26:27.080
the signal would just go on and
then disappear and never come back.

561
00:26:27.080 --> 00:26:31.260
And so we wouldn't have a way to know did
all the drives receive the signal or not.

562
00:26:31.260 --> 00:26:33.290
By that signal bouncing back to us,

563
00:26:33.290 --> 00:26:35.560
that's how we would know that it made
it all the way to the end of the line.

564
00:26:35.560 --> 00:26:38.030
If the terminator wasn't there,
wouldn't happen.

565
00:26:38.030 --> 00:26:42.930
Well, modern drives all sense whether
they're the last one on the bus.

566
00:26:42.930 --> 00:26:45.320
If they don't see any other
drives talking beyond them,

567
00:26:45.320 --> 00:26:48.150
they assume they're the last ones,
and they auto terminate.

568
00:26:48.150 --> 00:26:50.830
So we don't have to worry about it, right?

569
00:26:50.830 --> 00:26:55.120
If a drive fails though, maybe it's not
auto terminating like it's supposed to.

570
00:26:55.120 --> 00:26:57.520
And so now it malfunctions,
we might have a problem there.

571
00:26:57.520 --> 00:27:00.890
But in the olden days we used to
actually take these little blocks,

572
00:27:00.890 --> 00:27:03.590
these little SCSI terminators,
just stick them on the end of that cable.

573
00:27:03.590 --> 00:27:05.860
And if you didn't have it there,
it didn't work.

574
00:27:05.860 --> 00:27:08.400
At least it didn't work right,
so you'd have problems.

575
00:27:08.400 --> 00:27:09.800
But we're talking about
ancient technology.

576
00:27:09.800 --> 00:27:12.770
Those drives,
we are well beyond their lifetime.

577
00:27:12.770 --> 00:27:16.312
So if you're dealing with termination or
any termination issues,

578
00:27:16.312 --> 00:27:20.414
the real issue is probably accounting,
right, that you need to get a budget to

579
00:27:20.414 --> 00:27:23.789
replace those servers cuz you're
well beyond their lifetime.

580
00:27:23.789 --> 00:27:29.785
Okay, after that, one of the tricky
parts with storage is that we spend so

581
00:27:29.785 --> 00:27:34.830
much time trying to make sure
that it is stable and redundant.

582
00:27:34.830 --> 00:27:36.660
We put things like RAID
controllers in there.

583
00:27:36.660 --> 00:27:39.630
And you can have failures and
not even know it.

584
00:27:39.630 --> 00:27:41.400
Because they recover themselves, right.

585
00:27:41.400 --> 00:27:45.170
If you have a RAID array and a drive
fails, it starts running on parity and

586
00:27:45.170 --> 00:27:46.300
you don't even know it.

587
00:27:46.300 --> 00:27:48.890
If you have a RAID 10 array and
one fails, or a mirror.

588
00:27:48.890 --> 00:27:50.610
A mirror, one fails and
you just flip over to the other drive.

589
00:27:50.610 --> 00:27:52.180
You don't even see a performance hit.

590
00:27:52.180 --> 00:27:53.620
So unless you're monitoring them for

591
00:27:53.620 --> 00:27:56.700
these failures, you're never
going to see that they happened.

592
00:27:56.700 --> 00:28:00.683
And so you're gonna end up in a situation
where everything just seems to be right,

593
00:28:00.683 --> 00:28:03.181
but there is actually
a failure in the background.

594
00:28:05.368 --> 00:28:08.750
Other things that you might see, for
example, that I mentioned cache failure.

595
00:28:08.750 --> 00:28:10.980
If a cache fails,
the cache gets turned off.

596
00:28:10.980 --> 00:28:14.730
Well, if it gets turned off,
you might not notice that.

597
00:28:14.730 --> 00:28:16.060
It's a performance decrease.

598
00:28:16.060 --> 00:28:17.040
That's what you see.

599
00:28:17.040 --> 00:28:19.110
And again, unless you have a reporting
software, you're not gonna see.

600
00:28:19.110 --> 00:28:20.480
So always be aware of that,

601
00:28:20.480 --> 00:28:23.300
if you lose your storage,
you've effectively lost your server.

602
00:28:23.300 --> 00:28:25.180
So that's why we built so
much redundancy into it.

603
00:28:25.180 --> 00:28:27.670
That's why we have these
components that are designed to

604
00:28:27.670 --> 00:28:29.710
handle failure a little more resiliently.

605
00:28:29.710 --> 00:28:31.930
Which makes it harder for
us to spot that failure.

606
00:28:31.930 --> 00:28:33.750
It's a double-edge sword, right?

607
00:28:33.750 --> 00:28:35.130
The high N redundancy.

608
00:28:36.780 --> 00:28:42.480
Okay, another problem that we
might have is mismatched drives.

609
00:28:42.480 --> 00:28:46.970
When you start throwing drives into a
server, if I've got all 10,000 RPM drives

610
00:28:46.970 --> 00:28:52.520
and one drive fails, and I go to my
closet and I pull out a spare drive and

611
00:28:52.520 --> 00:28:55.970
it's a 7,200 RPM and I chuck it in there,
what's gonna happen?

612
00:28:55.970 --> 00:28:59.210
I've got one drive reading
slower than the others, and

613
00:28:59.210 --> 00:29:01.930
that's going to affect
performance on the array.

614
00:29:01.930 --> 00:29:03.920
If I go and get a 15K RPM Drive and

615
00:29:03.920 --> 00:29:06.899
chuck it in there,
it's gonna go faster than the others, and

616
00:29:06.899 --> 00:29:10.580
so I'm gonna get weird numbers when
I try monitor performance on that.

617
00:29:10.580 --> 00:29:12.130
It can cause an issue.

618
00:29:12.130 --> 00:29:15.780
Also it doesn't help that
serial attached SCSI and

619
00:29:15.780 --> 00:29:18.470
SATA drives these days
pretty much look the same.

620
00:29:18.470 --> 00:29:20.130
The connector under that's
a little bit different.

621
00:29:20.130 --> 00:29:24.300
But from the front, top, bottom,
side, they look the same.

622
00:29:24.300 --> 00:29:28.560
So you might be trying to stick
a SATA drive into a SAS slot and

623
00:29:28.560 --> 00:29:29.420
it's not working.

624
00:29:29.420 --> 00:29:32.180
It's not going in right,
so that can be a problem.

625
00:29:32.180 --> 00:29:37.550
But even when they're two SATA drives,
I might have one that is SATA 2 and

626
00:29:37.550 --> 00:29:40.430
one that is SATA 3, or
a SAS 2 and a SAS 3 drive,

627
00:29:40.430 --> 00:29:43.850
the different standards within
that individual connector.

628
00:29:43.850 --> 00:29:44.790
So we need to try and

629
00:29:44.790 --> 00:29:47.570
keep our drives as similarly configured
as possible when they're in an array.

630
00:29:47.570 --> 00:29:49.770
If it's not in an array then
we don't care about it, right?

631
00:29:49.770 --> 00:29:53.670
If I have two drives mirrored for the
operating system, those might be 10k RPM.

632
00:29:53.670 --> 00:29:55.787
But then I might have five drives or

633
00:29:55.787 --> 00:30:00.679
six drives in a RAID 10 array that's
gotta all 15,000 RPM SAS drives and

634
00:30:00.679 --> 00:30:04.990
they might be SAS3 whereas
the operating systems were SATA 2.

635
00:30:04.990 --> 00:30:07.020
That's okay,
because they're separate arrays.

636
00:30:07.020 --> 00:30:11.490
But within an array you wanna try to keep
them the same and with your spare discs.

637
00:30:11.490 --> 00:30:14.910
Because the spare during a failure
is gonna become a real disc.

638
00:30:14.910 --> 00:30:18.835
And when you replace the failed disc,
it becomes the spare.

639
00:30:18.835 --> 00:30:21.825
And you're not normally gonna fail
them back over cuz it takes too long.

640
00:30:21.825 --> 00:30:25.885
So your spare disk should be
the same as your main disks.

641
00:30:25.885 --> 00:30:28.845
It's not like in a car where your
spare tire might be that cheesy

642
00:30:28.845 --> 00:30:29.895
little donut thing.

643
00:30:29.895 --> 00:30:33.235
Because you know you're just gonna swap
it back to a regular tire later on.

644
00:30:33.235 --> 00:30:37.865
Here, it takes so long to swap back to
a disk that you don't typically do it.

645
00:30:37.865 --> 00:30:43.650
You just have the spare be the same and
then you run from that.

646
00:30:43.650 --> 00:30:45.690
Okay, now I did show some
troubleshooting tools.

647
00:30:45.690 --> 00:30:50.640
I showed the computer management
tool in Windows which lets me see

648
00:30:50.640 --> 00:30:54.410
the discs that are in my system and
kind of customize those.

649
00:30:54.410 --> 00:30:57.260
I showed the limitation there and
how we usually want to use

650
00:30:57.260 --> 00:31:00.420
our hardware utilities for
managing those array controllers.

651
00:31:00.420 --> 00:31:02.140
I used Windows as an example.

652
00:31:02.140 --> 00:31:03.210
It's the same in Linux.

653
00:31:03.210 --> 00:31:07.000
HP has the same exact utility
that runs under Linux.

654
00:31:07.000 --> 00:31:08.500
And depending on your Linux distro,

655
00:31:08.500 --> 00:31:13.740
like I've got a Red Hat system here, it'll
have an equivalent of the disk manager.

656
00:31:13.740 --> 00:31:17.520
It might be, you go to the command
prompt and run DiskPart ED.

657
00:31:17.520 --> 00:31:18.160
That might be it.

658
00:31:18.160 --> 00:31:19.610
You might just use fdisk.

659
00:31:19.610 --> 00:31:22.710
Or in Red Hat there's actually
a little disks utility.

660
00:31:22.710 --> 00:31:24.690
It is buried in here somewhere.

661
00:31:24.690 --> 00:31:25.470
Where's that, Sundry?

662
00:31:25.470 --> 00:31:27.200
Now I just have to find it.

663
00:31:27.200 --> 00:31:28.680
There it is, under utilities.

664
00:31:28.680 --> 00:31:32.060
So I've got a disks utility, and I can
see all the disks in this server, and

665
00:31:32.060 --> 00:31:33.500
start to work with it.

666
00:31:33.500 --> 00:31:35.670
Same limitations as Windows, though.

667
00:31:35.670 --> 00:31:38.080
It's not gonna see a hardware RAID array.

668
00:31:38.080 --> 00:31:41.840
It's gonna see it as a single disk, so it
doesn't really know what these disks are.

669
00:31:41.840 --> 00:31:44.369
So these utilities are really designed for
partition management.

670
00:31:44.369 --> 00:31:46.908
For configuring our partitions and
adjusting them.

671
00:31:46.908 --> 00:31:49.777
So if I have a partition issue,
yes these tools are great.

672
00:31:49.777 --> 00:31:53.532
If I've got a hardware issue, not so much.

673
00:31:53.532 --> 00:31:57.610
And then lastly, the only thing
worth mentioning is the event logs,

674
00:31:57.610 --> 00:32:01.770
the event logs in your system,
even if you don't have this software.

675
00:32:01.770 --> 00:32:03.840
So for example,
let's say I've got a Windows server,

676
00:32:03.840 --> 00:32:06.240
and it's a Core Services install.

677
00:32:06.240 --> 00:32:08.940
So all these GUI utilities,
they're not gonna help me, right?

678
00:32:08.940 --> 00:32:10.560
Not in a Core Services install.

679
00:32:10.560 --> 00:32:12.960
But I've got my event log, and

680
00:32:12.960 --> 00:32:17.280
in my Event Viewer, I'll have my
system log that we can get into.

681
00:32:17.280 --> 00:32:20.770
And hardware errors will typically
represent themselves here.

682
00:32:20.770 --> 00:32:24.183
But if it's not a hardware issue,
it could be a software issue.

683
00:32:24.183 --> 00:32:27.185
And so I might need to look under
my applications and come down here.

684
00:32:27.185 --> 00:32:28.271
And even under Applications,

685
00:32:28.271 --> 00:32:31.040
you'll see where you've got
a separate Hardware Events folder.

686
00:32:31.040 --> 00:32:33.810
And that's where you'd see issues
that are popping up there with

687
00:32:33.810 --> 00:32:35.320
communicating with the RAID controller and
so on.

688
00:32:35.320 --> 00:32:36.650
It's another place to look.

689
00:32:37.800 --> 00:32:42.160
The only objective that I haven't
covered is the net use or mount command.

690
00:32:42.160 --> 00:32:45.380
Net use is for mounting network drives and
connecting to them.

691
00:32:45.380 --> 00:32:48.580
I talked about it in the troubleshooting
networking episodes.

692
00:32:48.580 --> 00:32:51.910
But with net use, you're connecting to
a shared folder somewhere on the network.

693
00:32:51.910 --> 00:32:54.700
And so if you have an issue there,
that's typically gonna come up with that.

694
00:32:54.700 --> 00:32:57.590
But you can also use it to assign
drive letters to a disk, and

695
00:32:57.590 --> 00:33:00.520
you can assign more than one
drive letter if you need to.

696
00:33:00.520 --> 00:33:03.790
And that, you can use other
things like Disk Utility for it.

697
00:33:03.790 --> 00:33:06.080
In the LINUX and UNIX world,
you have the mount command.

698
00:33:06.080 --> 00:33:09.237
And they don't really help you with
troubleshooting beyond seeing that you

699
00:33:09.237 --> 00:33:10.230
can't mount the disk.

700
00:33:10.230 --> 00:33:12.781
So if you try and mount it like normal,
and you can't, well,

701
00:33:12.781 --> 00:33:16.870
now you know you can't access the disk,
which you probably already knew.

702
00:33:16.870 --> 00:33:18.120
They don't help you find out why.

703
00:33:18.120 --> 00:33:19.640
And so now you've gotta go a step further,

704
00:33:19.640 --> 00:33:23.290
and that's where our hardware
diagnostics really save the day.

705
00:33:23.290 --> 00:33:24.770
>> All right, Don,
lot of great information.

706
00:33:24.770 --> 00:33:25.770
Yeah, I've always wondered that.

707
00:33:25.770 --> 00:33:28.180
With all the different
components in a switch fabric,

708
00:33:28.180 --> 00:33:30.070
how can you keep all of that monitored?

709
00:33:30.070 --> 00:33:31.480
So it's interesting to learn that.

710
00:33:31.480 --> 00:33:33.630
Now, it does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

711
00:33:33.630 --> 00:33:36.450
But before we do, Don,
do you have any final words that

712
00:33:36.450 --> 00:33:39.850
you might like to impart to our viewers
when it comes to troubleshooting storage?

713
00:33:39.850 --> 00:33:43.640
>> Main thing, any time you set a server
budget, always set a budget for spares.

714
00:33:43.640 --> 00:33:48.296
Even if you have a four-hour response time
warranty, you don't want to lose data.

715
00:33:48.296 --> 00:33:49.900
You don't wanna have
to go to your backups.

716
00:33:49.900 --> 00:33:52.650
Anything you can do to avoid going
to your backups, you'll appreciate,

717
00:33:52.650 --> 00:33:54.040
cuz it saves time.

718
00:33:54.040 --> 00:33:56.510
So when you buy a server, have a spare.

719
00:33:56.510 --> 00:33:58.961
And a hot spare is nice, but there's
nothing wrong with cold spares, too.

720
00:33:58.961 --> 00:34:02.099
You can have drives that you share
across 20 different servers,

721
00:34:02.099 --> 00:34:04.090
because you wanna save some money.

722
00:34:04.090 --> 00:34:06.870
They sit on the shelf, and
a cold spare will actually last longer,

723
00:34:06.870 --> 00:34:08.390
cuz the disk isn't spinning.

724
00:34:08.390 --> 00:34:11.375
On a hot spare, the disk is actually
spinning while it sits there.

725
00:34:11.375 --> 00:34:14.830
And so that does wear it down over time,
usually a long, long time,

726
00:34:14.830 --> 00:34:16.010
but it can happen.

727
00:34:16.010 --> 00:34:16.640
>> All right, Don.

728
00:34:16.640 --> 00:34:17.760
Well, thank you for being here.

729
00:34:17.760 --> 00:34:19.480
And thank you to you, the viewer watching.

730
00:34:19.480 --> 00:34:20.450
We hope you've enjoyed it.

731
00:34:20.450 --> 00:34:23.510
Singing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

732
00:34:23.510 --> 00:34:24.400
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

733
00:34:24.400 --> 00:34:25.367
>> And we'll see you next time.

734
00:34:25.367 --> 00:34:32.285
[MUSIC]

735
00:34:32.285 --> 00:34:34.586
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don explore troubleshooting security. They talk about common security problems like file integrity, privilege esculation and application whitelisting.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Security
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.190
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.190 --> 00:00:01.917
I'm your host.

3
00:00:01.917 --> 00:00:08.382
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:08.382 --> 00:00:12.105
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.105 --> 00:00:14.385
>> Hello, and welcome to another
great episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.385 --> 00:00:16.435
ITProTV, I'm your host Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:16.435 --> 00:00:19.125
And in today's episode we're
continuing through our series in

8
00:00:19.125 --> 00:00:22.475
CompTIA Server Plus SK0-004 and

9
00:00:22.475 --> 00:00:25.315
joining us back in the studios again
is none other than Mr Don Pezet.

10
00:00:25.315 --> 00:00:26.355
Don, how are you doing, sir?

11
00:00:26.355 --> 00:00:27.535
>> I am doing just well, Wes.

12
00:00:27.535 --> 00:00:30.195
To wrap up our troubleshooting series for

13
00:00:30.195 --> 00:00:35.870
the CompTIA Server+ certification and
the last topic we have is well, security.

14
00:00:35.870 --> 00:00:40.450
We're gonna be troubleshooting security
related issues, and before you run away

15
00:00:40.450 --> 00:00:43.520
with this, don't think that the security's
just hackers getting the system.

16
00:00:43.520 --> 00:00:46.330
There's any number of failures that all
kind of fall under that umbrella of

17
00:00:46.330 --> 00:00:47.230
security.

18
00:00:47.230 --> 00:00:49.500
And we need to understand
what is available to us,

19
00:00:49.500 --> 00:00:50.920
to help ensure those things don't happen.

20
00:00:50.920 --> 00:00:54.390
There's some just basic steps and
processes we can go through to make sure

21
00:00:54.390 --> 00:00:56.140
thing work the way that
they're supposed to.

22
00:00:56.140 --> 00:00:59.260
And that's what we're gonna take
a look at right here in this episode.

23
00:00:59.260 --> 00:01:03.100
The first thing that I wanna start
talking about is file integrity.

24
00:01:03.100 --> 00:01:08.600
File integrity is where we're dealing
with files that are effectively damaged.

25
00:01:08.600 --> 00:01:10.440
They aren't the way they intend to be.

26
00:01:10.440 --> 00:01:12.210
Now what do I mean by damaged?

27
00:01:12.210 --> 00:01:15.630
It could mean that they're damaged
in a way that makes them unreadable.

28
00:01:15.630 --> 00:01:18.915
So maybe I have a Word document and
I'm trying to open it and

29
00:01:18.915 --> 00:01:20.865
it just, it won't open, just corrupt.

30
00:01:20.865 --> 00:01:21.373
And that's it.

31
00:01:21.373 --> 00:01:24.815
Well, why is that?

32
00:01:24.815 --> 00:01:26.105
There's a number of things
that can lead to that.

33
00:01:26.105 --> 00:01:27.805
Usually we think failing hard drive.

34
00:01:27.805 --> 00:01:29.545
A failing hard drive can lead to that.

35
00:01:29.545 --> 00:01:32.925
But, where did that file come
from in the first place?

36
00:01:32.925 --> 00:01:37.490
More often than not, the way that it was
transferred to our disk could be at fault.

37
00:01:37.490 --> 00:01:39.610
And now the disk was damaged in transit.

38
00:01:39.610 --> 00:01:42.140
It might be fine wherever
it's stored originally but

39
00:01:42.140 --> 00:01:45.250
in transit to getting placed onto
our drive it got damaged somehow.

40
00:01:45.250 --> 00:01:47.320
So that's one type of damage.

41
00:01:47.320 --> 00:01:49.990
Another type of damage is intentional.

42
00:01:49.990 --> 00:01:53.365
That I may have a Word document
that is what I wanted and

43
00:01:53.365 --> 00:01:56.515
I could open it and
it works just fine but a hacker or

44
00:01:56.515 --> 00:02:00.669
somebody else is has gotten ahold
of it and stuck a macro in there.

45
00:02:00.669 --> 00:02:03.680
A macro that when I launch the Word
document in the background

46
00:02:03.680 --> 00:02:07.280
it's emailing my keystrokes
after somebody else, right?

47
00:02:07.280 --> 00:02:10.870
I don't see the file as damaged,
I can open the file, I can read it.

48
00:02:10.870 --> 00:02:12.930
But it's doing other
things in the background.

49
00:02:12.930 --> 00:02:16.560
Effectively a Trojan Horse like
a malware or a virus, right?

50
00:02:16.560 --> 00:02:18.590
That 's damage to the file also.

51
00:02:18.590 --> 00:02:23.140
Anything that modifies a file
beyond what we expect it to be

52
00:02:23.140 --> 00:02:26.760
is an integrity issue, right,
a file integrity issue.

53
00:02:26.760 --> 00:02:31.940
Now, on the security side, we can leverage
things like malware and antivirus.

54
00:02:31.940 --> 00:02:34.180
Any kind of intrusion prevention or

55
00:02:34.180 --> 00:02:36.950
intrusion detection system
should be able to see that.

56
00:02:36.950 --> 00:02:39.150
And we see steps like that
in our software anyway.

57
00:02:39.150 --> 00:02:43.240
If you open up a Word document
Microsoft Word blocks macros by default.

58
00:02:43.240 --> 00:02:44.890
So if I'm expecting to see some letter and

59
00:02:44.890 --> 00:02:48.680
I get a message about a macro that's a red
flag for me, hey that shouldn't be there.

60
00:02:48.680 --> 00:02:52.590
But is that happening on a server,
not normally.

61
00:02:52.590 --> 00:02:54.970
On a server we wouldn't be
running Microsoft Word.

62
00:02:54.970 --> 00:02:59.820
It might be a file server and this
malicious document is stored on the file

63
00:02:59.820 --> 00:03:03.250
server but it's not actually
being opened on the file server.

64
00:03:03.250 --> 00:03:07.380
So, is the server going to see that
a file is damaged and malicious?

65
00:03:07.380 --> 00:03:08.520
Not normally.

66
00:03:08.520 --> 00:03:12.200
So what steps can we take on the server
to be able to prevent that stuff?

67
00:03:12.200 --> 00:03:14.760
Well, you can run antivirus scans.

68
00:03:14.760 --> 00:03:17.470
You can have software, or hardware for

69
00:03:17.470 --> 00:03:21.890
that matter, that is inspecting these
files as they're deposited on the server.

70
00:03:21.890 --> 00:03:23.780
And if they're infected it stops now.

71
00:03:23.780 --> 00:03:27.260
And as they're being read off of
the server we can inspect them or

72
00:03:27.260 --> 00:03:30.880
we can just do timed scans every so
often you can run those right.

73
00:03:30.880 --> 00:03:34.885
On the software side there's any number
of companies like Trend Micro and

74
00:03:34.885 --> 00:03:38.670
Sophos Antivirus that make software that
can run on your Windows and Linux and

75
00:03:38.670 --> 00:03:42.030
Mac servers and actually scan all
the files on there periodically.

76
00:03:42.030 --> 00:03:45.220
On the hardware side there's companies
like Barracuda where they have the network

77
00:03:45.220 --> 00:03:49.370
firewalls that will scan the traffic
as it passes over the network.

78
00:03:49.370 --> 00:03:52.640
And that used to be a problem
because what if traffic's encrypted,

79
00:03:52.640 --> 00:03:53.910
how can it scan that?

80
00:03:53.910 --> 00:03:57.390
But now they've got where if it's internal
traffic you can take your internal

81
00:03:57.390 --> 00:03:59.140
certificates and
load them on the device so

82
00:03:59.140 --> 00:04:02.990
it's actually able to decrypt it, scan it,
and then reencrypt it and send it along.

83
00:04:02.990 --> 00:04:05.680
It's kind of a man in the middle
attack but in a good way.

84
00:04:05.680 --> 00:04:09.760
It's a man in the middle repair,
or something like that, but

85
00:04:09.760 --> 00:04:13.220
those kind of devices can really
help to ensure that doesn't happen.

86
00:04:13.220 --> 00:04:15.370
We can also do it manually
ourselves though.

87
00:04:15.370 --> 00:04:19.110
More and more sites are starting
to do checksums with a file, so,

88
00:04:19.110 --> 00:04:23.630
you go to download some file, and when you
go to download it, they provide a checksum

89
00:04:23.630 --> 00:04:26.820
for you, so, for example,
here I'm on Red Hat's web page and

90
00:04:26.820 --> 00:04:29.000
I'm about to download a copy
of Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

91
00:04:29.000 --> 00:04:31.850
I wanna download an ISO from them, right?

92
00:04:31.850 --> 00:04:34.920
And so when I come down here to download
and I see all my Download Now buttons so

93
00:04:34.920 --> 00:04:37.290
I can come and find the DVD right here.

94
00:04:37.290 --> 00:04:41.320
So the Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.3
Binary DVD, I wanna download it.

95
00:04:41.320 --> 00:04:46.309
And then right here it gives
me a SHA-256 checksum.

96
00:04:46.309 --> 00:04:48.570
All right now what is this checksum?

97
00:04:49.590 --> 00:04:53.910
What it means is they ran
the SHA-256 algorithm against it

98
00:04:53.910 --> 00:04:54.860
to generate a file hash.

99
00:04:54.860 --> 00:04:59.870
A hash of that file as it was in
its original state at Red Hat,

100
00:04:59.870 --> 00:05:00.770
at their server farm.

101
00:05:01.940 --> 00:05:04.022
And then I can download the ISO.

102
00:05:04.022 --> 00:05:08.400
I can download it from them, I can
download it from another server on my

103
00:05:08.400 --> 00:05:12.530
network, I can go to a bit torrent
site and torrent it, right?

104
00:05:12.530 --> 00:05:16.530
And once I get it,
how do I know if it's been tampered with?

105
00:05:16.530 --> 00:05:18.720
Or if it just got damaged in transit?

106
00:05:18.720 --> 00:05:21.540
If I'm pulling from another one of my
servers it's probably fine, if I download

107
00:05:21.540 --> 00:05:24.210
it from the Internet, something could've
gone wrong during the download.

108
00:05:24.210 --> 00:05:28.460
If I'm pulling from a torrent site well,
all sorts of stuff could happen.

109
00:05:28.460 --> 00:05:32.370
Somebody could've intentionally taken
that disk and injected code into it, so

110
00:05:32.370 --> 00:05:35.140
that when it set up a boot
loader on my system

111
00:05:35.140 --> 00:05:36.910
it would already have
a root kit as a part of it.

112
00:05:36.910 --> 00:05:38.390
I wouldn't even know it was there.

113
00:05:38.390 --> 00:05:39.780
That happens.

114
00:05:39.780 --> 00:05:41.500
