570
00:28:03.550 --> 00:28:05.790
And then after that, we can go through and

571
00:28:05.790 --> 00:28:09.620
start to dictate whether we have
a particular application we wanna track.

572
00:28:09.620 --> 00:28:11.800
Now, I do like that
they also do DLL rules,

573
00:28:11.800 --> 00:28:15.640
cuz dynamic link libraries, same thing in
Linux where you have regular libraries,

574
00:28:15.640 --> 00:28:18.290
that those libraries can be attacked.

575
00:28:18.290 --> 00:28:19.770
They are effectively executables.

576
00:28:19.770 --> 00:28:21.620
You just don't run them directly.

577
00:28:21.620 --> 00:28:24.170
So if they get modified,
they can compromise the system too.

578
00:28:24.170 --> 00:28:26.140
But you can come in and configure this.

579
00:28:26.140 --> 00:28:30.860
And once you get it set up, you can start
to approve individual applications and

580
00:28:30.860 --> 00:28:33.270
dictate what's allowed to run and
what's not.

581
00:28:33.270 --> 00:28:37.419
In our executable rules is where we can
come in and actually define the programs,

582
00:28:39.130 --> 00:28:41.830
and you can specify publishers,
exceptions.

583
00:28:41.830 --> 00:28:45.900
It will take the hash for you, and you
can add additional hashes as new updates

584
00:28:45.900 --> 00:28:47.910
come out, and
you can provide that functionality.

585
00:28:47.910 --> 00:28:51.950
So, if you wanna learn more about it,
check out Microsoft's App Blocker.

586
00:28:51.950 --> 00:28:52.450
>> All right, Don.

587
00:28:52.450 --> 00:28:53.970
Well, there's a lot of great information.

588
00:28:53.970 --> 00:28:56.520
And maybe you're following
along with the objectives and

589
00:28:56.520 --> 00:28:59.760
you'll probably realize that, well,
we've got a lot more to go but

590
00:28:59.760 --> 00:29:02.400
we do not have the time on the clock for
this episode.

591
00:29:02.400 --> 00:29:04.560
But before we go in to a part two,
and sign out, Don,

592
00:29:04.560 --> 00:29:06.310
do you have any additional words?

593
00:29:06.310 --> 00:29:09.540
>> Just remember that every
time you increase security,

594
00:29:09.540 --> 00:29:12.870
it does make people's jobs harder,
it makes it harder to access the system.

595
00:29:12.870 --> 00:29:13.970
But it's a trade-off, right?

596
00:29:13.970 --> 00:29:17.280
In exchange for a little inconvenience,
you get more security and in this day and

597
00:29:17.280 --> 00:29:19.340
age, it's typically worth it.

598
00:29:19.340 --> 00:29:24.040
But you don't wanna go too far, there does
come a point where you make the system so

599
00:29:24.040 --> 00:29:25.990
secure people can't do their job anymore.

600
00:29:25.990 --> 00:29:30.200
So, always think about the work that
people have to do just to get done.

601
00:29:30.200 --> 00:29:32.292
Your company needs to be able to
make money to stay in business.

602
00:29:32.292 --> 00:29:35.878
So always keep that in mind as you
apply various security policies.

603
00:29:35.878 --> 00:29:37.800
>> All right, Don,
well thank you for being here.

604
00:29:37.800 --> 00:29:41.040
We look forward to seeing you in part two
and the same thing to you, the audience.

605
00:29:41.040 --> 00:29:41.910
Thank you for being here.

606
00:29:41.910 --> 00:29:43.280
Signing out for ITProTV.

607
00:29:43.280 --> 00:29:44.980
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

608
00:29:44.980 --> 00:29:45.710
>> And I'm Don Pazet.

609
00:29:45.710 --> 00:29:46.507
>> And we'll see you next time.

610
00:29:46.507 --> 00:29:52.219
[MUSIC]

611
00:29:52.219 --> 00:29:56.388
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Don continue their exploration on troubleshooting security. They talk about network file access issues, excessive access and permissions considerations.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Security Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:06.336
Welcome to ITPro.Tv, I'm-
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.336 --> 00:00:08.296
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.296 --> 00:00:11.964
>> You're watching ITPro.Tv.

4
00:00:11.964 --> 00:00:16.025
>> Welcome to another great episode here
at ITProTV, I'm your host Wes Bryan.

5
00:00:16.025 --> 00:00:17.085
And in today's episode,

6
00:00:17.085 --> 00:00:21.166
we are continuing through our series
in CompTIA's Server+ (SK0-004).

7
00:00:21.166 --> 00:00:24.485
We're actually coming back with
a part 2 in troubleshooting security.

8
00:00:24.485 --> 00:00:26.895
And joining us in the studios is Mr.
Don Pezet.

9
00:00:26.895 --> 00:00:28.120
Don, how you doing sir?

10
00:00:28.120 --> 00:00:29.450
>> I'm doing swell, Wes.

11
00:00:29.450 --> 00:00:31.618
Ready to dive right back
into the world of security.

12
00:00:31.618 --> 00:00:34.420
And we're gonna kick things off by

13
00:00:34.420 --> 00:00:36.750
wrapping up three different
areas in one on this one.

14
00:00:36.750 --> 00:00:40.030
So, as we read down our objectives,
some of these areas are very similar.

15
00:00:40.030 --> 00:00:43.690
We've got,
cannot access network files and shares.

16
00:00:43.690 --> 00:00:45.890
We've got, unable to open files.

17
00:00:45.890 --> 00:00:48.320
And we've got, excessive access.

18
00:00:48.320 --> 00:00:53.070
All three of these common problems
deal with the same thing, permissions.

19
00:00:53.070 --> 00:00:54.760
When somebody accesses files or

20
00:00:54.760 --> 00:00:57.600
resources on the network,
we need to have permissions in place.

21
00:00:57.600 --> 00:01:01.730
And hopefully, your network is configured
at the sweet spot where everybody

22
00:01:01.730 --> 00:01:05.190
has the right privileges for
the access that they need, right?

23
00:01:05.190 --> 00:01:08.250
Earlier in the series I talked
about the privilege of least, no!

24
00:01:08.250 --> 00:01:10.730
The principle of least privilege,
there we go.

25
00:01:10.730 --> 00:01:14.612
Where you never wanna give anybody
too much access or too little access.

26
00:01:14.612 --> 00:01:17.440
You wanna give them exactly
what they need to do their job.

27
00:01:17.440 --> 00:01:20.130
If you give them too little access,
they can't read or

28
00:01:20.130 --> 00:01:21.860
write to files that they need access to.

29
00:01:21.860 --> 00:01:22.630
They can't do their job.

30
00:01:22.630 --> 00:01:26.296
If you give them too much access,
they'll have access to files and

31
00:01:26.296 --> 00:01:28.064
folders they shouldn't have,

32
00:01:28.064 --> 00:01:32.003
and potentially if it's malicious,
they get in and mess with things.

33
00:01:32.003 --> 00:01:34.858
But even accidentally,
they could accidentally delete,

34
00:01:34.858 --> 00:01:38.282
or modify files that they didn't
intend to, it just sort of happened,

35
00:01:38.282 --> 00:01:40.870
and it's because we gave
them too much access.

36
00:01:40.870 --> 00:01:44.800
So we always wanna make sure that we
give people exactly what they need.

37
00:01:44.800 --> 00:01:49.260
Well, if we've misconfigured,
you're gonna see errors like, hey,

38
00:01:49.260 --> 00:01:52.400
I'm trying to access this file on
the network share, and I can't access it.

39
00:01:52.400 --> 00:01:56.360
Or hey I can't find this file,
I know I saved it to the network share

40
00:01:56.360 --> 00:01:58.740
yesterday and now it's gone,
what happened?

41
00:01:58.740 --> 00:02:01.080
They start to see that kinda problem.

42
00:02:01.080 --> 00:02:04.980
And that's an indicator that we've
kind of lost control of our data.

43
00:02:04.980 --> 00:02:07.540
That we've either given too much or
too little access.

44
00:02:07.540 --> 00:02:10.150
Well, if you go back and
watch out networking episode,

45
00:02:10.150 --> 00:02:11.600
we talk a little bit
about permissions there.

46
00:02:11.600 --> 00:02:16.320
But really, back in A+ and network+ and
the Windows server shows and the Red Hat

47
00:02:16.320 --> 00:02:20.940
shows, we talk about file permissions in
all of those because it is so important.

48
00:02:20.940 --> 00:02:25.060
But in this show we specifically talk
about how there were share permissions and

49
00:02:25.060 --> 00:02:26.110
there were file permissions.

50
00:02:26.110 --> 00:02:30.190
There were two different sets of
permissions and they work together.

51
00:02:30.190 --> 00:02:32.970
And because they work together, it means
that I can mess one of them up and

52
00:02:32.970 --> 00:02:34.420
it will mess the other one up, right?

53
00:02:34.420 --> 00:02:35.110
They work together.

54
00:02:35.110 --> 00:02:36.230
You're screwing both up at the same time.

55
00:02:36.230 --> 00:02:36.960
It's awesome.

56
00:02:36.960 --> 00:02:38.580
So when we go to troubleshoot,

57
00:02:38.580 --> 00:02:42.300
you've got to remember that there's
two different places to look.

58
00:02:42.300 --> 00:02:45.669
So for example,
if I take a Windows machine like this one.

59
00:02:46.786 --> 00:02:48.530
And in part 1,

60
00:02:48.530 --> 00:02:51.760
I had just created a temporary folder
real quick to demonstrate a point.

61
00:02:51.760 --> 00:02:54.620
But if I go and find that folder,
which apparently I've deleted since then.

62
00:02:54.620 --> 00:02:59.700
So I'll recreate it, that we can took
a look at that folder and its permissions.

63
00:02:59.700 --> 00:03:02.370
So I'm just gonna pull up
the Properties of that folder.

64
00:03:02.370 --> 00:03:04.140
And I'm gonna go into Security.

65
00:03:04.140 --> 00:03:07.150
And what I'm looking at here on
the Security tab are the permissions

66
00:03:07.150 --> 00:03:09.080
on this folder itself.

67
00:03:09.080 --> 00:03:12.800
And these permissions apply when
somebody comes in via the network or

68
00:03:12.800 --> 00:03:16.270
when they sit right here in front
of this machine and use it.

69
00:03:16.270 --> 00:03:20.470
So these permissions are always going
to take effect and I might have given

70
00:03:20.470 --> 00:03:24.510
somebody too many permissions or too
little permissions but I'll see it in here

71
00:03:24.510 --> 00:03:27.840
that they've either got or
don't have the permissions that they need.

72
00:03:27.840 --> 00:03:30.450
Where it gets tricky though is when
they come in over the network,

73
00:03:30.450 --> 00:03:33.080
we also have Sharing Permissions.

74
00:03:33.080 --> 00:03:35.610
And this folder is not shared for
me because I just created it.

75
00:03:35.610 --> 00:03:39.190
But, if I do share it,
I get to pick who has what access.

76
00:03:39.190 --> 00:03:42.220
And this works in tandem
with the other permissions.

77
00:03:42.220 --> 00:03:44.140
Now remember that when they combine,

78
00:03:44.140 --> 00:03:47.180
the end user gets the most
restrictive permission.

79
00:03:47.180 --> 00:03:51.720
So on the share,
I might have full control, access,

80
00:03:51.720 --> 00:03:54.320
the ability to access everything in there.

81
00:03:54.320 --> 00:03:58.470
But then, I go back to the file
permissions and I have read only.

82
00:03:58.470 --> 00:04:01.410
And the end result will be,
I get read only.

83
00:04:01.410 --> 00:04:04.550
From a troubleshooting perspective,
we have to know to look both places.

84
00:04:04.550 --> 00:04:07.080
Because an end user might call and
say, hey I can't write to that file.

85
00:04:07.080 --> 00:04:09.250
And I go and
look at the share permissions and

86
00:04:09.250 --> 00:04:11.310
I see where that user has full control.

87
00:04:11.310 --> 00:04:12.230
They should be able to write.

88
00:04:12.230 --> 00:04:13.900
They must be doing something wrong.

89
00:04:13.900 --> 00:04:15.350
Well, they're not doing anything wrong,

90
00:04:15.350 --> 00:04:17.580
it's the file permissions
that aren't backing them up.

91
00:04:17.580 --> 00:04:19.640
So we've gotta go and double check that.

92
00:04:19.640 --> 00:04:23.340
The same thing happens in the UNIX world,
that you have file permissions there.

93
00:04:23.340 --> 00:04:25.600
Let me switch over to a Linux server.

94
00:04:25.600 --> 00:04:27.350
So when I look at a file,

95
00:04:27.350 --> 00:04:32.070
I've got permissions dictated over
here based on group,and owner, and

96
00:04:32.070 --> 00:04:34.910
everyone else, and what permission
they have access to, right?

97
00:04:34.910 --> 00:04:36.280
So there's the file permissions.

98
00:04:36.280 --> 00:04:38.540
These always take effect.

99
00:04:38.540 --> 00:04:42.410
But then, I might be sharing
these folders out with NFS, and

100
00:04:42.410 --> 00:04:44.170
NFS has its own permissions too.

101
00:04:44.170 --> 00:04:47.740
If I create an NFS share and
I flag the whole share as read-only,

102
00:04:47.740 --> 00:04:50.690
it doesn't matter, people have
read-write all over the place here,

103
00:04:50.690 --> 00:04:53.720
they're gonna end up with read only
cuz the NFS share is read only.

104
00:04:53.720 --> 00:04:55.565
So just know that when you
share things on the network,

105
00:04:55.565 --> 00:04:58.890
there maybe two different places
you have to check permissions.

106
00:04:58.890 --> 00:05:00.150
Always double check that.

107
00:05:00.150 --> 00:05:02.900
If that's not the issue,
if everything is fine there,

108
00:05:02.900 --> 00:05:05.390
typically your problem is
gonna being authentication.

109
00:05:05.390 --> 00:05:06.616
Authentication is kinda crazy,

110
00:05:06.616 --> 00:05:09.290
this is one of those where we
start to tie in other services.

111
00:05:09.290 --> 00:05:13.370
Most systems use some form of Kerberos for
network authentication these days.

112
00:05:13.370 --> 00:05:14.370
Windows has switched to it.

113
00:05:14.370 --> 00:05:17.030
Most Linux and
Unix systems have been using it for years.

114
00:05:17.030 --> 00:05:20.980
And with Kerberos, Curberas,
or however you wanna say it.

115
00:05:20.980 --> 00:05:25.540
What it does is, it uses
a token-based authentication system.

116
00:05:25.540 --> 00:05:28.170
And the token has
a timestamp attached to it.

117
00:05:28.170 --> 00:05:31.520
And when you're sending your token back
and forth to prove you're authenticated,

118
00:05:31.520 --> 00:05:36.180
if that timestamp gets too far off, it
will look like somebody's doing a man in

119
00:05:36.180 --> 00:05:40.288
the middle attack, like a replay attack,
and systems will reject it.

120
00:05:40.288 --> 00:05:42.690
So most Kerberos-based systems,

121
00:05:42.690 --> 00:05:46.160
like the Microsoft Active Directory,
have a five minute window.

122
00:05:46.160 --> 00:05:49.770
If your clock is off by
more than five minutes,

123
00:05:49.770 --> 00:05:51.260
you won't be able to authenticate.

124
00:05:51.260 --> 00:05:54.910
So the permissions might be perfectly
fine on the network share, but

125
00:05:54.910 --> 00:05:55.880
when you go to access it,

126
00:05:55.880 --> 00:05:59.140
your token's expired, looks like a man
in the middle attack and it stops you.

127
00:05:59.140 --> 00:06:02.330
So having good clock synchronization
is importing in making sure people

128
00:06:02.330 --> 00:06:05.580
can authenticate in the Unix world
as well as in the Windows world.

129
00:06:08.020 --> 00:06:11.090
Okay, a couple other things
to dive in on this one.

130
00:06:11.090 --> 00:06:16.130
Beyond that, we do have enhanced
security layers that kick in,

131
00:06:16.130 --> 00:06:18.720
that let you manipulate how programs work.

132
00:06:18.720 --> 00:06:21.880
And on a server, these are really,
really important.

133
00:06:21.880 --> 00:06:26.600
Okay, I talked a little bit about
privilege escalation in the last episode.

134
00:06:26.600 --> 00:06:29.170
When a hacker targets a server, so

135
00:06:29.170 --> 00:06:30.940
if they've targeted a web
server that I've got.

136
00:06:30.940 --> 00:06:32.830
The web server's running Apache.

137
00:06:32.830 --> 00:06:33.930
They can talk to Apache.

138
00:06:33.930 --> 00:06:37.650
And Apache is doing things on
the back end as the Apache server,

139
00:06:37.650 --> 00:06:39.330
at least it normally is.

140
00:06:39.330 --> 00:06:43.910
If an attacker can break into it,
and somehow assume the role of

141
00:06:43.910 --> 00:06:48.450
the root user of the server,now they can
start performing commands as the system,

142
00:06:48.450 --> 00:06:51.720
and get elevated privileges and
do whatever they want with that server.

143
00:06:51.720 --> 00:06:55.070
Install software, transfer data,
do whatever they want.

144
00:06:55.070 --> 00:06:58.010
Usually use it as a springboard
to then access backend systems

145
00:06:58.010 --> 00:06:59.640
they wouldn't normally have access to.

146
00:06:59.640 --> 00:07:00.570
All sorts of bad things.

147
00:07:01.580 --> 00:07:04.840
Well, that type of privilege
escalation is a problem.

148
00:07:04.840 --> 00:07:06.840
And we need to make
sure it doesn't happen.

149
00:07:06.840 --> 00:07:09.070
We've already got permissions in place so
that it shouldn't happen.

150
00:07:09.070 --> 00:07:11.440
But they exploited some
vulnerability in the system and so

151
00:07:11.440 --> 00:07:14.280
they were able to get
around those limitations.

152
00:07:14.280 --> 00:07:18.610
So there's security sub layers behind
the scenes that work to prevent that.

153
00:07:18.610 --> 00:07:25.360
That work to, kind of, mitigate, or
at least, contain the compromise.

154
00:07:25.360 --> 00:07:29.003
And, there's no better example of
that than a utility called chroot.

155
00:07:29.003 --> 00:07:34.175
chroot is the change root utility and
what you can do is when you run a program,

156
00:07:34.175 --> 00:07:37.025
normally the program sees
your entire hard drive.

157
00:07:37.025 --> 00:07:39.945
And you can create rules that say yeah,
you're allowed to write to this folder or

158
00:07:39.945 --> 00:07:42.425
write to that folder but you're not
allowed to write to these other folders.

159
00:07:42.425 --> 00:07:45.600
But if they can get root access,
they can overcome that, can't they?

160
00:07:45.600 --> 00:07:47.243
You can't look a root user out.

161
00:07:47.243 --> 00:07:51.093
So with chroot, what it does is it
says when you run that program,

162
00:07:51.093 --> 00:07:53.484
it doesn't see the hard drive any more.

163
00:07:53.484 --> 00:07:57.034
It sees a particular folder as the root.

164
00:07:57.034 --> 00:08:00.889
And no matter what level of permission you
are, if you're the root user or full blown

165
00:08:00.889 --> 00:08:05.170
administrator or if you're a regular user,
you only see what's in that one folder.

166
00:08:05.170 --> 00:08:07.350
So they might be able
to compromise Apache.

167
00:08:07.350 --> 00:08:09.150
And get at all of the Apache stuff.

168
00:08:09.150 --> 00:08:10.680
But they won't be able to get
at the rest of the server.

169
00:08:10.680 --> 00:08:12.690
They won't be able to use
it to springboard to other

170
00:08:12.690 --> 00:08:14.220
systems inside of the network.

171
00:08:14.220 --> 00:08:15.830
They're contained, right?

172
00:08:15.830 --> 00:08:18.820
You hear people call it chroot,
some people call it a jail.

173
00:08:18.820 --> 00:08:21.710
I think the original versions of
it were actually called a jail.

174
00:08:21.710 --> 00:08:24.200
It was developed in the BSD world and
in Solaris.

175
00:08:24.200 --> 00:08:26.340
Solaris is BSD anyway.

176
00:08:26.340 --> 00:08:30.130
So it came from that stuff
before jumping into Linux.

177
00:08:30.130 --> 00:08:32.310
And even making the jump
over into Windows.

178
00:08:32.310 --> 00:08:34.630
Although, it's far less obvious
in Windows the way that it works.

179
00:08:35.760 --> 00:08:38.410
Those systems are pretty straightforward.

180
00:08:38.410 --> 00:08:40.270
Not every application supports it.

181
00:08:40.270 --> 00:08:43.220
Because some applications really
break when you give them a fake root.

182
00:08:43.220 --> 00:08:44.920
They expect to see a root directory.

183
00:08:44.920 --> 00:08:46.150
Think about what's off of the root.

184
00:08:46.150 --> 00:08:50.580
On a Linux server, if I,
let me just pull up my root directory.

185
00:08:50.580 --> 00:08:54.780
If you look at what all's in the root
directory, you've got things like /lib,

186
00:08:54.780 --> 00:08:57.550
that's kind of important
because a lot of the libraries,

187
00:08:57.550 --> 00:08:59.200
the linked libraries are in there.

188

I probably don't wanna
do that here anyway.

415
00:21:15.970 --> 00:21:18.230
I'm in the website folder, so
if I dump into a file here,

416
00:21:18.230 --> 00:21:20.840
it's kind of in a bad spot, so
let me change my home directory.

417
00:21:20.840 --> 00:21:27.670
And I'm gonna rerun that with a -M, there.

418
00:21:27.670 --> 00:21:28.620
There we go.
And

419
00:21:28.620 --> 00:21:30.920
it's going to generate a little module for
me.

420
00:21:30.920 --> 00:21:34.514
That module's is this httpd.pp file.

421
00:21:34.514 --> 00:21:38.010
Okay, that's the SELinux
policy file that I need.

422
00:21:38.010 --> 00:21:41.915
And I can take that and
I can load that in to the system.

423
00:21:41.915 --> 00:21:46.821
So I'm gonna import httpd.pp.

424
00:21:46.821 --> 00:21:49.225
So I'm importing that into SELinux, so

425
00:21:49.225 --> 00:21:52.767
it now knows these new rules
that I wanna have in the system.

426
00:21:52.767 --> 00:21:55.340
It takes just a moment.

427
00:21:55.340 --> 00:22:00.280
And once that's loaded,
I can switch my enforcement back to 1.

428
00:22:00.280 --> 00:22:04.650
So now I'm back to enforcing my policies.

429
00:22:04.650 --> 00:22:12.430
And if I restart, If I restart Apache,
whatever that program is called.

430
00:22:12.430 --> 00:22:16.910
There we go, now it will be
allowed to access that folder.

431
00:22:16.910 --> 00:22:20.820
Cuz I performed the action, generated the
errors, now it knows what to look for, and

432
00:22:20.820 --> 00:22:27.160
to allow it, and now when I go back here,
what should happen is I get I get that.

433
00:22:27.160 --> 00:22:27.920
I don't have permission.

434
00:22:27.920 --> 00:22:29.370
I have the file permission set wrong.

435
00:22:29.370 --> 00:22:32.490
But I don't get the test
page anymore because Apache

436
00:22:32.490 --> 00:22:34.180
is allowed to access that folder.

437
00:22:34.180 --> 00:22:38.940
But I've got different permission problems
here because if I look at /website and I

438
00:22:38.940 --> 00:22:42.650
look at the folders that are in there and
the files, see how they're owned by root?

439
00:22:43.850 --> 00:22:45.350
And what if I'm not root?

440
00:22:45.350 --> 00:22:46.720
Well, root gets read and write.

441
00:22:46.720 --> 00:22:49.320
Actually, everybody else gets read so
we should have access there.

442
00:22:49.320 --> 00:22:51.560
But I really should change
these to be owned by Apache.

443
00:22:51.560 --> 00:22:53.420
Set the group to Apache,
the owner to Apache and

444
00:22:53.420 --> 00:22:56.560
then that way it'll be able to
access it and access those files.

445
00:22:56.560 --> 00:22:59.200
But I'm not getting the test
page anymore which means Apache

446
00:22:59.200 --> 00:23:03.160
is indeed allowed to access
this folder and get to it.

447
00:23:03.160 --> 00:23:06.430
SELinux is setting the boundaries for
the application.

448
00:23:06.430 --> 00:23:08.290
And now I've removed those boundaries.

449
00:23:08.290 --> 00:23:12.170
If I go back to this screen
where I was tailing errors.

450
00:23:12.170 --> 00:23:17.031
Here's my last error that
I got where I was getting

451
00:23:17.031 --> 00:23:22.027
an access denied when it
was accessing the folder.

452
00:23:22.027 --> 00:23:23.194
And now I can come through here and

453
00:23:23.194 --> 00:23:25.620
look and see if I'm getting
anything new when I browse to it.

454
00:23:25.620 --> 00:23:26.205
I shouldn't be.

455
00:23:26.205 --> 00:23:27.820
SELinux should be allowing things.

456
00:23:27.820 --> 00:23:31.050
And from there now we can just
get everything else configured.

457
00:23:31.050 --> 00:23:32.250
And really straighten
up our permissions or

458
00:23:32.250 --> 00:23:35.370
whatever else is it we need to
get it up and going, right.

459
00:23:35.370 --> 00:23:38.110
Utilities like these are essential for

460
00:23:38.110 --> 00:23:42.450
getting a good security baseline on
your server configured in place.

461
00:23:42.450 --> 00:23:45.110
And if a hacker breaks in and
compromises something,

462
00:23:45.110 --> 00:23:47.570
it's gonna stop them from being able
to access any additional resources.

463
00:23:48.600 --> 00:23:50.330
>> All right, Don,
a lot of great information.

464
00:23:50.330 --> 00:23:51.570
Now, I'm looking at our list and

465
00:23:51.570 --> 00:23:54.280
I know that there's still some
more topics you need to cover, but

466
00:23:54.280 --> 00:23:57.550
it does look like we're at least coming
close to the end of another episode.

467
00:23:57.550 --> 00:23:58.820
But before we close this one out,

468
00:23:58.820 --> 00:24:01.430
do you have additional words you'd
like to throw in this episode?

469
00:24:01.430 --> 00:24:04.190
>> All right, Wes, not so much a point,
but just a matter of pride.

470
00:24:04.190 --> 00:24:05.330
I'm really quick in the background,

471
00:24:05.330 --> 00:24:08.180
fixing the error that I just got cuz
I hate ending the show on an error.

472
00:24:08.180 --> 00:24:12.180
But if you look at my computer here,
I changed the owner of that index file to

473
00:24:12.180 --> 00:24:14.660
switch it over, so it's owned by
Apache like it's supposed to be.

474
00:24:14.660 --> 00:24:17.310
It expects to have read and
execute on those files.

475
00:24:17.310 --> 00:24:21.380
So now that that's said, I should be
able to jump back over to Firefox.

476
00:24:21.380 --> 00:24:24.010
And if I browse to the page, there we go,

477
00:24:24.010 --> 00:24:26.880
now I get the nice white page
that I was expecting to get.

478
00:24:26.880 --> 00:24:28.150
I'm not getting the test page.

479
00:24:28.150 --> 00:24:29.410
I'm not getting an error.

480
00:24:29.410 --> 00:24:33.020
I'm actually getting index.html
like it's intended, right?

481
00:24:33.020 --> 00:24:37.370
We need to leverage our security
policies to provide what it is that we

482
00:24:37.370 --> 00:24:38.690
need to do, right?

483
00:24:38.690 --> 00:24:39.970
Now, I've got this nice restriction.

484
00:24:39.970 --> 00:24:43.424
And, if a hacker breaks
in to my APACHE service,

485
00:24:43.424 --> 00:24:46.981
yes they can mess around
with /var/www/html.

486
00:24:46.981 --> 00:24:49.690
And yes they can mess
around with /website.

487
00:24:49.690 --> 00:24:55.400
But they can't mess around with /etc or
/var/log, they can't get into those areas.

488
00:24:55.400 --> 00:24:57.475
They are completely isolated.

489
00:24:57.475 --> 00:25:00.840
SELinux will not allow the Apache
process to access those resources.

490
00:25:00.840 --> 00:25:02.390
That's what it does.

491
00:25:02.390 --> 00:25:03.570
It can get in the way.

492
00:25:03.570 --> 00:25:04.770
It can cause problems.

493
00:25:04.770 --> 00:25:06.760
It can annoy the heck out of you.

494
00:25:06.760 --> 00:25:09.770
But if you configure it right,
it can save your butt, and

495
00:25:09.770 --> 00:25:12.150
it can save you having
a data leak out there and

496
00:25:12.150 --> 00:25:14.430
having to report to all your
customers that you got compromised.

497
00:25:14.430 --> 00:25:16.072
So really important to take your time.

498
00:25:16.072 --> 00:25:17.958
Troubleshoot it,
run through the logs, right?

499
00:25:17.958 --> 00:25:21.980
/var/logs/audit/auto.log for that one.

500
00:25:21.980 --> 00:25:22.840
In the Windows world,

501
00:25:22.840 --> 00:25:26.600
you have protected file access and
Systems Integrity Protection and

502
00:25:26.600 --> 00:25:29.600
all that work doing the same basic
thing in preventing that access.

503
00:25:29.600 --> 00:25:32.550
You could check and make sure
that everything is unmodified and

504
00:25:32.550 --> 00:25:34.740
stored the way that it's supposed to.

505
00:25:34.740 --> 00:25:37.910
These things are really important to
stop you from having a compromise

506
00:25:37.910 --> 00:25:39.290
server on the network.

507
00:25:39.290 --> 00:25:41.040
>> All right, Don, great episode today.

508
00:25:41.040 --> 00:25:43.680
Thank you for being here in the studios
with us, and thank you to you,

509
00:25:43.680 --> 00:25:44.550
the viewer, watching.

510
00:25:44.550 --> 00:25:45.550
We hope you've enjoyed it.

511
00:25:45.550 --> 00:25:48.404
Signing out for IT Pro TV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

512
00:25:48.404 --> 00:25:49.290
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

513
00:25:49.290 --> 00:25:50.824
>> And we'll see you next time.

514
00:25:50.824 --> 00:25:57.113
[MUSIC]

515
00:25:57.113 --> 00:25:59.653
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

They talk about excessive memory utilization, open ports, active and inactive services, firewall rules as well as discussing some of security tools used like port scanners, sniffers and anti-malware
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Security Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.003 --> 00:00:02.251
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:02.251 --> 00:00:06.455
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.455 --> 00:00:08.191
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.191 --> 00:00:11.881
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.881 --> 00:00:15.210
>> Hello, and welcome to another
great episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.210 --> 00:00:16.600
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:16.600 --> 00:00:20.493
And in today's episode, we are continuing
through our series in CompTIA Server+.

8
00:00:20.493 --> 00:00:22.725
That's right, SK0-004.

9
00:00:22.725 --> 00:00:24.567
And joining us back in the studios for

10
00:00:24.567 --> 00:00:27.750
a part three on troubleshooting
security is mister Don Pezet.

11
00:00:27.750 --> 00:00:28.900
Don, how you doing, sir?

12
00:00:28.900 --> 00:00:30.729
>> I'm doing swell, Wes,
ready to wrap up security.

13
00:00:30.729 --> 00:00:32.760
And really wrap up the whole
troubleshooting section.

14
00:00:32.760 --> 00:00:35.910
I had a few things in the security topic
I didn't get to in the last episode, so

15
00:00:35.910 --> 00:00:38.160
we're gonna tackle those right here.

16
00:00:38.160 --> 00:00:40.690
Now we did talk about most of the common
problems that were out there.

17
00:00:40.690 --> 00:00:44.885
The only other common problem they
listed was excessive memory utilization.

18
00:00:44.885 --> 00:00:47.650
And excessive memory utilization is where

19
00:00:47.650 --> 00:00:50.420
one application starts
consuming way too much RAM.

20
00:00:50.420 --> 00:00:52.458
I know we talked about this
in the software episodes and

21
00:00:52.458 --> 00:00:53.490
the application troubleshooting.

22
00:00:53.490 --> 00:00:55.030
But we mention it here from security.

23
00:00:55.030 --> 00:00:57.615
Now why is it here in security?

24
00:00:57.615 --> 00:01:01.385
Well, typically where you see
excessive memory utilization

25
00:01:01.385 --> 00:01:03.905
is when people are doing
buffer overflow attacks.

26
00:01:03.905 --> 00:01:05.815
A buffer overflow attack
is where you try and

27
00:01:05.815 --> 00:01:08.705
write more into RAM
than you have room for.

28
00:01:08.705 --> 00:01:12.247
And the goal, what you're hoping for,
is that you fill up

29
00:01:12.247 --> 00:01:17.027
the spots that you have access to and the
overflow jumps into other applications.

30
00:01:17.027 --> 00:01:20.667
And you're hoping that those other
applications have administrative

31
00:01:20.667 --> 00:01:21.737
privileges that you don't.

32
00:01:21.737 --> 00:01:24.197
So that you can get privilege escalation,
that's the goal.

33
00:01:24.197 --> 00:01:27.887
But when somebody's doing a discovery for
that, how do they figure that out?

34
00:01:27.887 --> 00:01:30.770
It's hard, it's trial and
error, so they try a bunch.

35
00:01:30.770 --> 00:01:35.010
They keep dumping a bunch of data, and
it causes large memory consumption, right?

36
00:01:35.010 --> 00:01:37.050
So that's typically what we see.

37
00:01:37.050 --> 00:01:39.980
There are some other scenarios where you
see large memory consumption related to

38
00:01:39.980 --> 00:01:41.310
a security standpoint.

39
00:01:41.310 --> 00:01:44.260
But even a simple memory leak
over time will build up,

40
00:01:44.260 --> 00:01:47.747
your server runs out of RAM, and
it stops providing services.

41
00:01:47.747 --> 00:01:50.787
Your service goes offline,
and that is a security issue.

42
00:01:50.787 --> 00:01:52.933
>> Don,
maybe you can't tell right away, but

43
00:01:52.933 --> 00:01:56.241
how can you tell the difference
between maybe a bug in an application

44
00:01:56.241 --> 00:01:59.897
that's consuming all that memory
versus a legitimate attack like you've

45
00:01:59.897 --> 00:02:03.660
explained here where somebody's
trying to exploit the system?

46
00:02:03.660 --> 00:02:06.802
>> All right, well, it's difficult
because normally you might think, well,

47
00:02:06.802 --> 00:02:09.751
all right, if it's a memory leak,
it probably takes a long time to happen

48
00:02:09.751 --> 00:02:12.205
versus a hacker where it's
gonna happen very fast, right?

49
00:02:12.205 --> 00:02:14.530
They try and consume it very quickly,
but that's not always true.

50
00:02:14.530 --> 00:02:17.095
There are dedicated hackers out there
where they just take their time, right?

51
00:02:17.095 --> 00:02:19.034
It's all scripted, anyway,
what do they care, they go to sleep.

52
00:02:19.034 --> 00:02:22.170
And so it might take weeks or
even months to happen.

53
00:02:22.170 --> 00:02:24.010
Or it's just not very obvious.

54
00:02:24.010 --> 00:02:28.480
It could be an application memory leak
that just happens to be very fast, so

55
00:02:28.480 --> 00:02:29.650
you confuse the two.

56
00:02:29.650 --> 00:02:31.830
So the best way to interpret
it is to find out whether or

57
00:02:31.830 --> 00:02:34.064
not there's inappropriate
network access going on.

58
00:02:34.064 --> 00:02:37.094
If there's inappropriate network access
going on in conjunction with this memory

59
00:02:37.094 --> 00:02:39.040
leak, then you know there's a problem.

60
00:02:39.040 --> 00:02:41.664
Okay, now how do we see
inappropriate network access?

61
00:02:41.664 --> 00:02:45.390
Well, typically, we're gonna use
something like a network sniffer.

62
00:02:45.390 --> 00:02:49.230
A sniffer lets you look at the network and
see what's going on.

63
00:02:49.230 --> 00:02:53.120
And so I can spot whether there's
inappropriate traffic or access going on.

64
00:02:53.120 --> 00:02:56.460
If you have servers that are plugged
into enterprise-grade switches,

65
00:02:56.460 --> 00:02:59.240
those switches will support what's
called port mirroring, right?

66
00:02:59.240 --> 00:03:00.320
Some vendors have different names,

67
00:03:00.320 --> 00:03:03.310
like Cisco calls it SPAN,
the switch port analyzer.

68
00:03:03.310 --> 00:03:04.960
But at the end of the day,
it's port mirroring.

69
00:03:04.960 --> 00:03:07.850
Traffic on one port gets
mirrored to another port.

70
00:03:07.850 --> 00:03:11.240
And you can take your laptop or
whatever, and plug into that other port.

71
00:03:11.240 --> 00:03:15.140
And start to listen to the traffic
that's happening on that port.

72
00:03:15.140 --> 00:03:16.890
So you can hear what all's
being sent to the server.

73
00:03:16.890 --> 00:03:20.290
And you can look for
that network activity and what's going on.

74
00:03:20.290 --> 00:03:25.000
So for example, on my laptop,
let's see, I've got WireShark.

75
00:03:25.000 --> 00:03:29.186
So this is WireShark,
WireShark runs on Windows, Linux, and Mac.

76
00:03:29.186 --> 00:03:30.950
You can run it on darn near anything.

77
00:03:30.950 --> 00:03:34.950
And you can fire it up, and you can
start to capture a network adapter.

78
00:03:34.950 --> 00:03:36.621
And so I've got my WiFi adapter, or

79
00:03:36.621 --> 00:03:38.918
a couple of other adapters
that are on my system.

80
00:03:38.918 --> 00:03:41.120
Let's see,
who's generating some good traffic here?

81
00:03:41.120 --> 00:03:43.920
This Thunderbolt adapter
is dead in the water.

82
00:03:43.920 --> 00:03:46.130
This one is moving a little bit of data.

83
00:03:46.130 --> 00:03:49.520
So I can pick one of these, and
I'll take the wireless, what the heck.

84
00:03:49.520 --> 00:03:53.970
So I'll take my wireless adapter, and
here it goes, capturing wireless traffic.

85
00:03:53.970 --> 00:03:58.210
So this is data that's crossing my network
and people that are communicating, right?

86
00:03:58.210 --> 00:03:59.693
IPs talking to other IPs.

87
00:03:59.693 --> 00:04:03.310
And I'm seeing a lot of multicasting and
broadcasts cuz that's what you'd expect.

88
00:04:03.310 --> 00:04:07.710
But when you see this traffic,
you can then look at what it is.

89
00:04:07.710 --> 00:04:09.830
What type of traffic is that?

90
00:04:09.830 --> 00:04:12.590
And you can start to break that down and
interpret whether or

91
00:04:12.590 --> 00:04:14.150
not there's inappropriate access going on.

92
00:04:14.150 --> 00:04:17.880
If you're seeing a huge amount of traffic
coming from one host or something.

93
00:04:17.880 --> 00:04:18.940
The problem is you get so

94
00:04:18.940 --> 00:04:21.540
much data with software like this
that it's hard to interpret.

95
00:04:21.540 --> 00:04:25.160
And that's where software like
WireShark really can excel is up top,

96
00:04:25.160 --> 00:04:27.570
I've got this Statistics menu.

97
00:04:27.570 --> 00:04:30.927
And you can get it to really
summarize things down and

98
00:04:30.927 --> 00:04:33.143
get it to show you Conversations.

99
00:04:33.143 --> 00:04:36.092
And with Conversations,
now we can jump in and

100
00:04:36.092 --> 00:04:39.880
sort it by who's sending the most
packets or the most data.

101
00:04:39.880 --> 00:04:44.186
A hacker who's worth their salt will
send a large amount of packets, but

102
00:04:44.186 --> 00:04:46.050
a small amount of data.

103
00:04:46.050 --> 00:04:48.546
Our inclination is hey,
I'm gonna go in here, sort by bytes.

104
00:04:48.546 --> 00:04:49.866
If somebody's trying to
break into my system,

105
00:04:49.866 --> 00:04:51.370
they're probably sending a ton of bytes.

106
00:04:51.370 --> 00:04:54.290
Well, they're probably not,
they're sending little commands.

107
00:04:54.290 --> 00:04:55.970
How much space do you
need to send a command?

108
00:04:55.970 --> 00:04:56.470
Not much.

109
00:04:57.650 --> 00:05:00.320
So it's not so much the bytes,
but the packets.

110
00:05:00.320 --> 00:05:03.020
They might have to send a lot
of packets to do something.

111
00:05:03.020 --> 00:05:04.490
But not necessarily a lot of bytes.

112
00:05:04.490 --> 00:05:09.500
And so you can jump in here and pull the
IP communications, sort it out by packets,

113
00:05:09.500 --> 00:05:11.640
and get an idea of who
your biggest talker is.

114
00:05:11.640 --> 00:05:16.149
I can see that my laptop,
for example, 10.0.10.133,

115
00:05:16.149 --> 00:05:19.875
is communicating with 224.0.1.129 a lot.

116
00:05:19.875 --> 00:05:24.120
Well, 224 is a multi-cast, so
it's some kind of multicast communication.

117
00:05:24.120 --> 00:05:26.380
Probably the Apple discovery,
Apple chats a lot.

118
00:05:26.380 --> 00:05:29.320
So that one may be okay, and
I just start moving down the list.

119
00:05:29.320 --> 00:05:31.890
Here's other people that
are chatting to that same one.

120
00:05:31.890 --> 00:05:35.050
And then I get down to something
that's not a multicast.

121
00:05:35.050 --> 00:05:38.200
Which, apparently, I'm gonna have to
go pretty far down the list here.

122
00:05:38.200 --> 00:05:41.150
These are all multicast or
broadcast communications.

123
00:05:41.150 --> 00:05:43.645
When you run a sniffer, you will see
a lot of multicast and broadcast.

124
00:05:43.645 --> 00:05:45.269
Cuz you see that from the whole network.

125
00:05:45.269 --> 00:05:49.448
You're only gonna see unicasts that are
either destined for you or coming for you.

126
00:05:49.448 --> 00:05:52.290

00:23:15.820 --> 00:23:18.460

00:23:18.460 --> 00:23:19.410

00:23:19.410 --> 00:23:21.320

00:23:21.320 --> 00:23:24.308

00:23:28.231 --> 00:23:31.050

00:23:33.070 --> 00:23:34.400
